name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the Dutch Presidency's balance sheet (2016/2709(RSP)). I would like to point out now that there is no catch-the-eye procedure in this debate and no blue cards are allowed.

name: Mark Rutte
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, on 24 June, the morning after the night before, many Europeans woke up feeling pretty dreadful, and I was one of them. Clearly, Brexit has created a shock wave, and we do not yet know exactly what the consequences will be. We are in uncharted territory. And we must be honest: even if we find the perfect way to handle this ‘divorce’, our problems won’t simply melt away. It is not only British voters who have doubts about European cooperation. In other Member States too – including the Netherlands – there is widespread criticism and euroscepticism. And we need to address it. As a representative of the outgoing Presidency of the Council of the European Union, I feel conflicted standing here today. I am proud of the concrete results we have achieved in the past six months. But of course I am disappointed by our British friends’ decision to leave the EU. It is a decision that creates a big problem both for the citizens of the UK and also for the other Member States. It is a decision that shapes a new reality, and we should proceed with all due caution, to minimise the damage to the Member States and the British people themselves. It is in everyone’s interests to know as soon as possible – as soon as is responsible – how we will move forward, and this will demand our full attention in the coming period. The decision poses a whole range of broader concerns, too. Because this is not simply about a split that many people did not want. It is also about how Brexit affects the partnership between the other 27 Member States. The purpose of the European Union is to tackle issues and seize opportunities that transcend national borders. Issues and opportunities that are too big to tackle alone. The Member States all have their own interests, but to a large extent these overlap. These shared interests form the EU’s field of activity, and they provide a basis for public support and legitimacy. The EU can make a big difference. That is not a new insight, but it has been reaffirmed for me in the past six months. Because I have seen for myself how cooperation produces results that individual Member States could never achieve by themselves. The most obvious example is, of course, the EU’s agreement with Turkey on managing the flow of refugees from Syria. A lot has been said and written about it in the past few months. And in all honesty, is the agreement ideal in every respect? No. But was it sorely needed? Absolutely. And it was a deal we could only reach jointly. Because only by acting in concert could we break the criminal business model of the people smugglers. And greatly reduce the number of migrants drowning in the Aegean Sea. Last January alone the death toll was close to 90 and since 20 March fewer than 10 people have drowned – though that is still, of course, 10 too many. Only by acting in concert could we bolster the EU’s border-control capability. And only by acting in concert can we put into practice the measures we have agreed on setting up hot spots, improving registration, redistributing refugees among Member States and improving the situation in the region. You know as well as I do that implementing all this will be a big challenge. Progress is certainly being made, though. Between March and June almost 100 000 classroom places were created for refugee children in Turkey. Another example, of course, is the fight against terrorism – a threat that by definition transcends borders and demands an international response. We will never, never forget the attacks of 22 March, which hit Brussels, and with it the heart of Europe. Last week we were shocked once again by another dreadful attack, this time on Istanbul’s airport, and a few days ago, Baghad. In recent months the EU has taken some important decisions. On improving the exchange of information between intelligence services, for example. And on sharing passenger information without compromising privacy. It shows that both our vigilance and our willingness to join forces in this area are increasing. Which is great, because they are absolutely crucial. So the EU is more than simply the sum of its parts, and of course the best illustration of that is the single market. During the Dutch EU Presidency we worked on the principle that our most urgent problems – like the refugee crisis – should not overshadow our most important ambitions. So we made sure that enhancing the single market remained a priority. Last week, the European Council agreed that all the measures the Commission has planned for the single market must be adopted by the end of 2018 at the latest. And every year in June we will take stock of progress, in all openness. I am pleased with this new form of self-imposed commitment, which compels us into action.  You have an important role in this, as Members of the European Parliament. Not least as legislators, of course, but also as a champion of the single market. After all, your report on ‘the cost of non-Europe’ has played a big part in the discussion in recent months. Completing the single market could add an extra EUR 1.25 trillion to the EU economy, which would mean millions of new jobs, and this argument has proved a convincing one. Besides a deeper market we also need a fairer internal market where the principle of equal pay for equal work in the same place applies. So migration, terrorism, the single market and Brexit: these issues have grabbed the European headlines in recent months. But a lot of work has gone on in other areas too, both behind the scenes and out in the spotlight. Take the agreement on a common approach to combating tax avoidance by multinationals. Take the progress we have seen on the Fourth Railway Package, national emission ceilings and the EU Action Plan for the Circular Economy. I should add that there are also areas in which progress has not been as impressive. Take the trade defence instruments and the Posting of Workers Directive. More could have been done there. Although this short summary is perhaps a good illustration of the way European decision-making works: moving forward in small steps, with now and then a step back or sideways. The EU is still a work in progress, and in principle that is absolutely fine. But as I have said: Brexit is a signal – and certainly not the only signal – that change is needed. Indeed, it cannot be avoided. And I am certainly not the first person to say so. I firmly believe that the worst possible response to Brexit would be for ‘Brussels’ and the European capitals to continue with business as usual. This would show complete disregard for the reality in the Member States. I also believe it would be wrong to rush blindly forward towards more political integration and a more ‘federal’ Europe. Because that too would be a denial of the sentiment felt by many European people, to whom the EU is – or has become – something remote and aloof. When it comes to the issue of ‘more’ or ‘less’ Europe, I believe that the only sensible debate is the one about less bureaucracy, red tape and regulation, and more concrete, visible results in terms of prosperity, decent work and security. And having held the Presidency for the past six months, I am well aware that we cannot just silence the critics with a magic wand. Building public support takes time and effort. You may remember me saying in January that the Netherlands wanted a pragmatic Presidency. We wanted to serve the interests of the Member States, whose positions should be reflected in all joint decisions. We wanted to move the agenda forward. And we wanted to address the urgent challenges of migration and terrorism. I hope that this approach has been a visible one, and I hope it has contributed to the results we have achieved together. We do not have much time now to pause and reflect – and not only because of the Brexit situation. We need to implement the Turkey deal. The instability surrounding Europe and the related migration from North Africa demand urgent action. And of course there is still a lot to do on the single market. And for that reason I hope that the EU – its institutions, Member States and particularly citizens – will continue our pragmatic approach.  My experiences over the past six months have underlined that we need an EU that delivers. An EU that focuses on the essentials and on issues that transcend borders. An EU that makes and then sticks to agreements. This will be a stronger EU, and one that can grow still stronger.  In closing, I would like to express my thanks to the Commission, to our colleagues in the Council and, not least, to the European Parliament for an outstanding and constructive partnership. It was an honour and a pleasure for us to hold the Presidency, and we wish Slovakia every success for the coming six months.  (Applause)

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, to have a true measure of the progress achieved during the Dutch Presidency, we must remember where we started. As the New Year began, the refugee crisis had reached another critical moment. Thousands of people continue to risk their lives at sea. The humanitarian situation was becoming worse each day. At the same time, the terrorist attacks in Paris were fresh in our minds. We were determined to defend our way of life, but we understood that our open society would always be vulnerable. Sadly, this was confirmed a few months later in Brussels.  These were the difficult circumstances of the Dutch Presidency, but when you began to work, I was confident that this great country, one of our founding members, would call on its best qualities in a time of need. I am thinking of your belief in freedom and openness, your attachment to the rule of law and your commitment to responsible free trade and better law—making. This, as well as your pragmatism, will continue to shape the course of our Union in years to come. I am particularly grateful to the Dutch Presidency for having been an active supporter of one of the leitmotifs of this Commission: to be big on big issues and modest and timid on smaller ones.  Despite all the adverse circumstances, the Dutch Presidency has always shown prudence and perseverance. This attitude has been good for Europe as a whole. Thanks to the unexcited and gripping mediation of the Dutch, we have made great progress. So that we can manage the arrival of refugees in Greece, we now have an agreement with Turkey that has begun to work. The Dutch Presidency has played a decisive role in ensuring that this agreement with Turkey was reached and has played a decisive role in ensuring that these agreements are implemented in spirit and in letter. This has also provided the basis for addressing longer-term solutions. We have already made concrete proposals and progress to bring asylum systems into line and to share responsibility in Europe in a more solidarity-based way, because it is not only the place on the map that can decide how many refugees a country takes in. However, I would like to highlight the strong work of the Dutch Presidency on the protection of external borders and coasts. Within a few months – six months and a few days – we managed to put this important piece of foreign and domestic policy on the tracks. I would like to express my sincere thanks to the Dutch Presidency for this. There has been a trialogue, the agreement has been reached, it must now be implemented. And I would like this to happen quickly, because the citizens of Europe have a right to the protection of Europe's external borders. Monsieur le Président, l'une des grandes priorités de cette Commission est de compléter le marché intérieur l' o cela est nécessaire. Gr éce l'efficacité de la présidence néerlandaise, nous avons bien progressé sur plusieurs fronts, en particulier dans notre action pour une fiscalité des entreprises plus juste, mais aussi dans le domaine du marché numérique ou bien encore en mati re de financement des entreprises, surtout des petites et moyennes entreprises, avec l'indispensable mise en place d'une Union des marchés de capitaux. " cet égard, je me réjouis de l'accord intervenu au Conseil "Affaires économiques et financi éres" sur une feuille de route pour l'ach vement de l'union bancaire, complément indispensable de l'Union économique et monétaire et du marché intérieur. Pour conclure, Monsieur le Président, Meneer Eerste minister, je voudrais encore une fois rendre hommage l'efficacité de la présidence néerlandaise, qui ne m'a pas surpris parce que je m'attendais cette fa on de travailler. Nous avons pu – la présidence et la Commission - travailler de la meilleure fa on possible. Hartelijk thanks.

name: Esther de Lange
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Let me indeed welcome here for the last time the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister and all the others involved in the Dutch Presidency. I think that a special word of appreciation on behalf of colleagues should also go out to Minister Hennis who spent hour after hour here in the sessions that you could not be there, and that is greatly appreciated by this house.  On behalf of the EPP Group, let me also express our appreciation for your presidency. It is the twelfth time and a country that does this for the twelfth time does so like a well-oiled machine. You took over the president's gaver at a difficult time. You are giving it away at an even more difficult time whenever possible, and I have not yet said anything about the quality of the presidency in between.  The fact is, you were president at the time of the biggest migration and refugee crisis since the 1990s. Economically, investment in Europe lags far behind pre-crisis levels, and the situation at our borders is unstable. We've seen attacks.  The highlights, as far as I am concerned, the agreement on the Border and Coast Guard that we are going to vote on this week. I dare not mention the Turkey Agreement, because there are a number of things that you can question. On the other hand, it works. And a situation without a Turkey deal, we do not want to go back to that either. But the point I want to make here is: the Turkey deal buys time. But in the meantime, we will continue to be blackmailed by a country like Turkey if we do not get our own affairs in order. This means that further steps are needed in the area of a genuine asylum and migration policy: rapid assessment and also readmission agreements that propose some.  A highlight: the agreement on combating tax avoidance. The highlight, as far as I am concerned, is also the sharing of national terrorism lists. That is not enough when it comes to sharing information, but it is an important first step. I know that I am failing a lot of colleagues who have worked hard in their field to reach agreements. I would like to mention one: IORP 2 for enthusiasts and the techies, also for our country, a text which, as it stands now in black and white, represents a number of major improvements in relation to the Commission's proposal. But instead of expressing that, your government is pushing that agreement 24 hours before it takes Coreper to a House of Representatives and leaves it in the debate with that House of Representatives to underline the real benefits of that agreement.  I have arrived at one of the key points of europe's current malaise: we take decisions here together, the Council and the European Parliament on a proposal from the European Commission. It is time for the Council side to take responsibility for this at national level. Because taking decisions in Brussels, very collegial, and then promoting something else at home or even distancing themselves from them, destroys our cooperation. Just like delaying decisions over and over again! It took three months – just this one point, Mr President – before we got any indication from you what the Netherlands wanted to do after the No vote in the Ukraine referendum. And that indication was not very concrete either. So there is no clarity. We do not need years of ambiguity in the situation in the United Kingdom.  I conclude, you return to national politics. I wonder if you will remain as keen in the end of the banking union as you were as president. I would like to give you one wish, and that is that, under the Hague cheese stew, you will not be the first victim of the election in the Netherlands next year in the national elections in the Netherlands. The situation in the United Kingdom has shown us where that can lead.

name: Paul Tang
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – In his previous speech in this House in January, the Prime Minister spoke of Winston Churchill, who advocated shared values, shared interests and the shared need for security. He spoke passionately about it, and that fire is needed. But that hasn't been the last six months. On the contrary, after a battle between two Churchilladepts, Johnson and Cameron, the British people have opted for Brexit and the European flame has started to burn a little weaker.  The case for the European Union as a market, as a sweet shop, has not been able to convince the British people. The ratio of growing economy has not won the emotions of powerlessness and "take back control". In the age of globalisation, too many people in Europe still see the European Union as an extension of the free market, which is targeting their security, their jobs, their social security and their security. Europe must not threaten, but must protect, must be like a shield. Only then can we improve the environment, take in refugees humanely, tackle tax evasion. Only then can we defend ourselves against the dangers of the rings of instability around us.  The Dutch Presidency has played a role in this with gusto. Many thanks for that. The pragmatism of this Presidency has shown that Europe is more than that market, is more than that sweet shop, is more than a revenue model. And we have to show that.  Churchill has already seen that Europe is more than a market, and let it be a lesson for this Presidency that if we want to win referendums, we rely not only on the story of that market, but on Europe as a community, in which we stand together, countries and we, stronger.

name: Syed Kamall
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, there is no doubt that the Dutch Presidency will go down as a historic one, but for reasons for which you, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, cannot be blamed. Six months ago, the main challenge of this Presidency was the migration and refugee crisis and, while we cannot say that this crisis is over, we can say that it is more under control than in January, and this is due in no small part to the diligent work of your Presidency, thanks to the professionalism of your officials and the commitment of your ministers. This Chamber has benefited from the good sense of Bert Koenders and the input of our former colleague Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert and, as a result, under your watch we have found agreement on important legislation: the new Frontex European Border and Coast Guard, the Fourth Railway Package, passenger name records, data protection and other matters. You have achieved these agreements not by seeking to deliver an abstract vision but by delivering concrete and practical results that make the EU work better. The Dutch Presidency has set an example for other Presidencies to follow. A few years ago, Mr Rutte, you called for a policy of ‘European where necessary, national where possible’. You admitted that, all too often, agreements regarding the budget or the democratic rule of law have not been respected. You warned that Europe is being associated more and more with an anonymous, formal and impersonal layer of government in which national sovereignty is being replaced by normative rules from Brussels. Those in this House – as well as Commissioners and national leaders – who are impatient for a European army, who are impatient for a European FBI, who are impatient for European government would be advised to heed your words, and also to bear in mind the old Dutch proverb that ‘a handful of patience is worth more than a bushel of praise’. An EU with or without the UK needs to listen to those wise words now more than ever.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. I do not know, Chairman, dear Mark, whether it is so pleasant to be praised by those who leave us. I don't think that's so much fun. But I would like to thank you, the Dutch Presidency, Mr Koenders, also Jeanine Hennis. For her, coming home was natural, so that wasn't such a hard job. But I would like to thank you for those six difficult months for the Union. It was a turbulent sea, but we all know that the Netherlands is a seafaring nation, so to whom could this be left to it than to the Dutch Presidency?  I will not go into today, at least in this debate, the discussion 'What Europe should we go to now?' I only know one thing, which is that the greatest success the Netherlands has had was the Golden Age in the seventeenth century. That was the Republic of the United Netherlands, a federation of the seven provinces, which could not resist the Spanish armada, but when all warships and commercial fleets were placed under one command and were able to defeat the Spanish armada not only on the football field but also at sea. So having said that, I think that Dutch history contains a lot of interesting lessons for us today.  For the rest and otherwise, I would like to thank you mainly for the various points that the Dutch Presidency has managed to achieve: the European Border and Coast Guard, a number of Council decisions in the fight against terror, the fourth railway package, money market legislation, anti-tax evasion legislation and, perhaps most importantly, the new calendar to complete the single market. Because let us admit it honestly: 65% of the single market today is not one, not liberalised and not open. Finally, my wish to the Prime Minister is that he will also defend Europe in Dutch politics tomorrow and that he will not leave that to the populists and the nationalists. Because if it depends on Geert Wilders, even Spinoza can no longer enter the Netherlands.

name: Dennis de Jong
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – The Dutch Presidency is best characterised as large in the small and small in the large. On technical issues, the Presidency has shown that it can build bridges. I myself have experienced this as rapporteur for the Legal Aid Directive. That was fine cooperation and I would like to thank all those who worked the Dutch side to find solutions to this dossier, where initially the views of the Council and Parliament were far apart.  On a strategic-political level, it's a very different story. Of course, Prime Minister Rutte cannot be held personally responsible for the brexit referendum result. That was and is a British matter. However, we can hold him responsible for his reaction to the result of that referendum. This meant that citizens in the European Union must get more value for money by increasing and deepening the market. So even more market.  At the beginning of the presidency, Mark Rutte said he didn't like vistas. I understand that because when you're in a tunnel, you can't look far. The tunnel of the Dutch Presidency was called market, market, market, and it is precisely this fixation on the market that leads us all to become competitors of each other. One's profit equals the loss of the other. Just ask the army of unemployed people and the growing group that has been living in poverty for years. A world characterised by globalisation, based on market forces, makes people anxious and angry. They want to get a grip on their own environment. They want to have the space to set it up together for a common future. However, the fixation on the market turns people against each other and gives far-right away parties ample space. That's why I say, Mark, you were small in the big, you were stuck in your market fixation.  What we need now is a vista so that people find that they are protected when they need care or if they want to get a good education. Brussels must once again give people the space to build a new future together. Mark, there's enough market already.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – I'm not impressed at all. I would even say: I am extremely disappointed. And I will mention three examples of the failures of the Dutch Presidency.  Firstly, the fight against tax avoidance. I have heard Jeroen Dijsselbloem, Minister of Finance of the Netherlands and President of the Eurogroup, say several times: 'We were part of the problem, now we want to be part of the solution'. What is the result? A minimalist agreement that still offers Member States enormous opportunities to compete with each other in the battle over who is the best tax haven for companies in Europe.  Second example: the referendum on Ukraine. This agreement is an important part of the European Neighbourhood Policy. We have the Netherlands, which presides over the European Union. Where's the Prime Minister? At the head of the campaign? Not at all! On the sidelines, making sure he doesn't lose too many points. To whom? To Wilders and others, I suspect.  Thirdly, the refugee crisis. The Netherlands has a tradition, a centuries-old tradition of welcoming refugees. So I had expected your country to lead a coalition of volunteers that would stand alongside Chancellor Merkel to ensure that Europe welcomes its fair share of refugees.  What have we seen? Netherlands on the sidelines. Well, in the picture, Mr Rutte, when a morally unacceptable agreement was reached with Sultan Erdogan. But is this a surprise? I heard you say, Mr Rutte, before the end of your presidency: 'I have three priorities: the Netherlands, the Netherlands, the Netherlands'. You have said, 'Building support takes time', but with leadership like yours, I am concerned about the future of Europe.

name: Bill Etheridge
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I am sorry to hear that Mr Rutte woke up feeling dreadful on 24 June. I had been campaigning really hard for a long time before that, and I had spent at least the last two days unable to get any sleep at all. I had spent the whole night watching the results come in, drinking local beer and having a fantastic local curry, and I must say, I felt fantastic. But I think that is probably to do with the feeling of freedom. I think it does that for you.  Now is the time to embrace the democratic will of the people. Now is the time to stop with any further ‘project fear’, any talking down of the economy, any more concerns. Now is the time to be bright and positive, to look to the future, to put aside the arguments of the campaigns and to be friends, because Brexit brings hope – not just to the UK, but to all the peoples of Europe. We can have a better future, we can be different, we can have change, and we can show that through the democratic will which was shown in the UK and which, hopefully, will be shown in many countries – even in Mr Rutte’s. It is time to be positive, friendly and optimistic. The future for the UK is golden, but we truly wish the best for our friends in Europe too. There is no reason now for any further antipathy, any more of the unpleasantness that has been seen – in this place particularly, but also in other places. That time is gone. The EU is a failed project. The UK has shown the way to freedom, and I truly hope that all of our friends across Europe get the same chance that we had to embrace freedom and a bright future soon.

name: Olaf Stuger
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – For my part, also welcome to the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister.  Normally, I'm always standing here with a relatively negative story. But today is a historic Dutch presidency and I can be positive, because the presidency over the last six months has not been shaped by the Dutch Government, but by the Dutch people and also by the British people. With their democratic vote, they have finally committed to the de-decline of the EU. To the countries that will be allowed to use the president's gaver in the coming years, I would say: stop being difficult and endlessly search for a way to profile yourself. Just make sure that a referendum is held somewhere in a Member State in your six months, and then you are assured of a historic presidency.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – One of the main tasks during the Dutch Presidency would have been to stop immigration. In comparison, the Presidency has focused on dealing with the migrant crisis, the quotas on which migrants should be distributed and the penalties for countries that do not accept this forced resettlement. The Council is also not willing to accept the message of Brexit. Taking into account the Elections to the European Parliament, taking into account the opinion polls, taking into account the Austrian provincial and presidential elections, Brexit has only strengthened the people of Europe's rejection of the superstate establishment. They don't want to live in an empire where 500 million people's lives are controlled from a center! And how does the Council react? I quote: "The Europeans expect us to restore their faith in a better future, and we must solve this task in unity." For me, as a Hungarian MEMBER, the phrase of communist times is echoed, rather than confronted. A brighter future for European citizens comes when cooperation takes place within the framework of a Europe of nations.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, having listened carefully to the contributions, I think we have a few lessons to draw from the Dutch Presidency. First of all, we can only achieve something if the three institutions involved in taking decisions all take their responsibility and do not blame the others when things do not work. We are all responsible for the end result of what we do, and we should stop claiming success in national capitals and blaming Brussels if something goes wrong. Brussels, as a metaphor, is all of us – including the Council and its members. Secondly, I would argue, given what was said this morning here by you and by Prime Minister Rutte, that indeed it cannot be business usual, but at the same time, what was agreed between the three institutions on the priorities of the Commission is a good basis for not continuing with business as usual but rather doing the things we all agreed in the three institutions should be our priorities : getting the internal market to function better, advancing on the digital single market, doing more and better regulation, making sure the energy union gets going and making sure we get the issue of migration under control in a sustainable way. These are the priorities of a Commission that has chosen to be big on big things and small on small things, and this is also the way forward in the near future. Thanks to the Dutch Presidency, we can build on a basis that will allow us to choose these priorities and give them concrete results. The only thing that can convince wary and unconvinced citizens is concrete results in solving the problems they face every day and problems that, very often, can no longer be solved just at the national level.  If I may: if there is one thing we see after the British referendum, it is that people do not believe that they can get control of their lives back again within the European Union. That is why some chose to say, ‘OK, this is not working, let us try something else’. Whether that something else is going to work remains to be seen, but our task as Europeans is to prove that we can deliver the results for people who want to be able to be optimistic about their position, about their children’s future and about their grandchildren’s future. That should be our task. That is where I think the three institutions should be working together very closely indeed.  Thank you very much to the Dutch Presidency for a job well done.  (Applause)

name: Mark Rutte
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr. President, I would like to thank Frans Timmermans of the Commission for his very kind words.  Mr Timmermans, I do think you are absolutely right. It is about the three institutions working together, exactly as Esther de Lange also said in her short introduction. It is for the three institutions – the Council and the European Parliament, working on the basis of the proposals of the European Commission – to take the business of the European Union forward. Esther de Lange also spoke about Turkey, and I agree with her. I will now continue in Dutch, as otherwise I will be criticised in the press.  I agree with her that the Turkey deal must, of course, be part of an 'and-and', approach. It can't just be a Turkey deal. Stopping the way through is crucial, shutting down the Balkan route, investing in reception capacity in Turkey. Greece, where measures are taken to register, to absorb. So it's part of an "and-and-and" approach.  Paul Tang, rightly so, he said churchill is far away. I mentioned him in my speech in January. But Churchill would have been very unhappy with the decisions taken by the British people last week. I have no doubt about that. And I also agree with him, funnily enough, as a liberal right of the centre and he to the left of the centre, that Europe is more than the market. But that market, as Guy Verhofstadt has also talked about, is an engine to bring people prosperity and therefore jobs in the end. Mr. Kamall, thank you so much for your kind words and your compliments about our Presidency. I am, of course, extremely disappointed about the Brexit vote, not just for economic reasons, but also geopolitically. I think it is a great loss that, in an unstable world, the European Union now faces the second largest Member State leaving this Union. This is good news for some of those who do not wish us the best things in the world – and they are not part of the European Union – but it is not good news for those seeking protection and collective safety in the fact that we work so well together within the European Union. Guy Verhofstadt, thanks for the kind words. I agree with him as always, not in the matter of a more federal Europe. I think there may also be a difference in how Flemings see the word federally and how Dutch people see it. It also has to do with the translation of the word.  I do agree with him – and also thanks for his help during our presidency – that one of the most important tasks we have is to strengthen the internal market. And I say the same to Dennis de Jong, because it is wonderful to talk about values, about all great interests, but in the end, if we cannot take care of it, in the Netherlands for example, where we have more than 10 million jobs, that ultimately 2 million of those jobs are directly linked to the fact that the European Union exists and that the single market exists. , we would not be able to explain the relevance of that European Union to our people.  Then, Philip Lamberts had a lot of criticism, I could not quite convince him of the blessings of our presidency, i have deduced so much from that. We also criticise our approach to the refugee issue. But I'll tell him two things. If we had not made the deal with Turkey, 100 people would still be killed every month in the Aegean Sea. Ten more since March 20. That's still ten too many, but not 100 a month! So that business model of the people smugglers has now been scrapped. I think that's good news. And the second is that if we had not made these agreements with Turkey, the feeling that politicians are no longer in control of the situation would have grown in Germany, Sweden, Austria, the Netherlands and Belgium. And that is ultimately unacceptable. We must maintain our support, including in our countries, to ensure that people who are really fleeing real danger are safe. But the numbers have to be manageable.  Mr. Etheridge and Mr. Balczó, again I believe that Brexit is extremely unfortunate, especially for the United Kingdom. That country has now collapsed, politically, economically, monetarily and constitutionally, and you will have years of work ahead of you to get out of this mess. And that would also be an answer to Olaf Stuger who I actually hear flirting with that thought. "Why not other countries have such an exit scenario?" I would say, Mr Stuger, look at the United Kingdom! Is that what you want other countries to fall into the same mess as the UK did last Friday?  That's why I'd like to end with a simple statement. I believe that we as politicians should never, ever play games at all. playing with people's jobs, with people's interests, with people's futures. Flirting with exit scenarios in other countries is playing games. I'm not doing that. You will always find me on your way if you try!

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. (The session was suspended for a few minutes.) Written declarations (Article 162 CRP)

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – On 1 January 2016, the Netherlands took over the Presidency of the Council of the EU for the 12th time. The Dutch Presidency's priority was, inter alia, to increase EU innovation, focus on growth and jobs, a comprehensive approach to migration and border security, and a unified approach to climate change and sustainable development. One of the main elements of this Presidency's strategy was to strengthen the implementation of EU legislation and to improve the functioning of the market for services with high economic potential, inter alia by strengthening the principle of mutual recognition. In this context, it has been a great success to simplify the formalities to which citizens moving abroad are subject. The introduction of standard multilingual forms for most of the documents covered by the Regulation, including documents relating to residence, nationality, marital status or a certificate of non-criminal record, after entry into force, will avoid costly translations and make it much easier for Union citizens to move. Tackling the migration crisis and stemming the flow of refugees and combating terrorism and countering radicalisation were priorities of the Dutch Presidency in the area of justice and home affairs. Here, the greatest success was the signing of the EU-Turkey Agreement, under which Turkey is to accept irregular migrants crossing Greece's borders. In return, the Union will systematically accept Syrian refugees. It remains for me to congratulate the Netherlands on its successful presidency and on achieving many of its objectives.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – During the past six months, the incoherencies at the heart of the EU’s policymaking have become sharper. Following the terrorist attacks on Brussels, the Dutch referendum on the Ukraine agreement and now Brexit, the EU construct is increasingly being seen as ineffective. We are told that the only viable way forward is by promoting ‘more Europe’; that negotiating Brexit will mean first negotiating a British exit then negotiating what arrangement to apply for relations with the UK; that managing the migration crisis involves a deal with Turkey that amounts to a hidden strategy of refoulement plus the creation of an external borders agency; that to beat terrorism the cooperation between national security services needs to be strongly reinforced. All this is highlighting divergences within the Union, between its heterogeneous parts, divergences already accelerated by the neo-liberal austerity that is the hallmark of what passes for economic policy. It is puzzling that so many fail to recognise how, in order to stabilise the situation, we need consolidation, taking full account of national perspectives and interests, with, as first priority, the need to counter the divergences that have developed between north and south and between east and centre of the Union.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the European Council (28-29 June 2016) (2016/2711(RSP)). First of all, I give the floor to the President of the European Council, Mr Donald Tusk. Welcome, Mr Tusk!

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, before presenting the discussion on the political consequences of the UK referendum, I will first report on the other results of the June European Council: the EU cannot stand still. The referendum in the UK does not relieve the EU of its duty to resolve the migration crisis, which has undermined the sense of security across the whole of Europe. The EU must also boost its resistance to growing hybrid and cyber threats. To that end, we have adopted a decision on increased cooperation with NATO. Even in the UK referendum campaign, few questioned the fact that economic integration among Member States benefits Europeans, as it creates jobs. That is why we have made the decision to work more closely together in the areas of digital and capital markets. The decision taken during the summit will have a positive impact on the lives of Europeans, regardless of the UK’s leaving the EU. On migration, the leaders reviewed the situation on our external borders. Crossings from Turkey to the Greek islands have now almost come to a halt. In October 2015, that border was crossed irregularly by 7 000 people daily. Now it is around 50 per day. Given this significantly lower influx, we can now efficiently manage this part of our external border. This, in turn, should restore the sense of security in Europe, which has been our aim from the beginning. Now our attention will focus on the Central Mediterranean route, where flows of predominantly economic migrants remain too high, although there has not been a significant rise in numbers compared to the last two years. Leaders agreed to move to a new way of working with third countries, applying the necessary leverage to ensure fast and operational returns of illegal migrants. The aim is clear: all irregular economic migrants must be returned to their countries of origin. The High Representative is already taking negotiations with these countries forward. We also addressed Libya and what needs to be done to stabilise the situation there. More broadly, we welcomed the presentation by the High Representative of a new global strategy to guide the Union’s foreign and security policy. The leaders thanked Prime Minister Rutte for a very professional Dutch Presidency and the hard work over the past six months. This includes the arrangement with Turkey to stem migration flows to the Greek islands and also the political agreement on the new European Border and Coast Guard. I would like to thank this House for your invaluable contribution in helping to achieve this within the necessary time-frame. Let me now turn to Brexit, on which our discussion was calm and measured. Respecting the will of the British people, the EU leaders recognised that an  orderly exit process is now in everyone’s, and especially in the UK’s, interest. Prime Minister Cameron explained why he is leaving the decision to trigger Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union to the new leadership in Britain. The leaders understand that some time is needed to allow the political landscape to settle in Britain. But they are also looking to the UK Government to specify its intentions as soon as possible. We also considered the post-Brexit economic situation in the presence of the European Central Bank President, who reassured us about the cooperation of international financial institutions. However, it was also made clear that Brexit means substantially lower growth in the UK, with a possible negative spillover all over the world. For the second day of our summit the leaders met informally without the UK Prime Minister to discuss our common future. I would like to reassure you that the leaders are absolutely determined to remain united and work closely together as 27. We also agreed that there will be no negotiations of any kind until the UK formally notifies its intention to withdraw from the EU. It is now up to the British Government to submit such a notification to the European Council. We hope to have the UK as a close partner in the future. But leaders made it clear that access to the single market means acceptance of all four freedoms, including the freedom of movement. We will not sell off our freedoms and there will be no single market ‘à la carte’. This was the first exchange of the 27 leaders after the British referendum. It is still too early to draw conclusions more broadly on our future course. But it is clear that too many people in Europe are unhappy with the current state of affairs, be it on the national or European level, and expect us to do better. The leaders recalled during our debate that for decades Europe has brought hope and that we have a responsibility to return to that. This is why the EU-27 will meet informally on 16 September in Bratislava, kindly hosted by the Slovak Presidency. We will take the opportunity then to continue our political reflection.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. The truth is not in repetition. Therefore, I will not repeat what the President of the European Council has just said, since I am in full agreement with what he has said. Nor is the truth in paraphrase; I am therefore not going to paraphrase the conclusions of the European Council, since you have carefully studied them - I am not going to insult you by repeating what has been adopted in writing by the European Council.  I am particularly pleased that the European Council has adopted the Commission's programme on deepening the internal market. I am pleased that the European Council, once again, has stressed that the right response to the refugee crisis must be European, and that it has reconfirmed that the solution to the refugee crisis requires a much-needed solidarity between the Member States. I agree with the European Council that the priority now must be growth and jobs. This is exactly the first priority of the Commission which I have the honour of chairing, and which I presented as one of the ten priorities when I addressed you in July 2014. That is why I would have liked the European Council to have already agreed with the extension of the investment plan over the next three years, an investment plan that we have submitted, which Parliament has accompanied at a pace that has impressed me, and which is already producing results. To date, we have been able to mobilize investments of $108 billion, investments that would not have been made if the investment plan had not existed.  I agree with all those who say that we should not go on as before. But, to be honest, are we going on as before? We agreed, Parliament, the Council, which adopted a programme, and the Commission, to change its policy and pace. Do the priorities we have set need to be reviewed? No, we are not going to continue as we have done now, but we will ensure that the decisions made are implemented. I would like us to make the European Union the Union of Europeans. That is why we will have to make better use of the decisions we have made from now on. I say we can't go on like we used to, but I refuse to see everything again. I agree with those who say that now is not the time for institutional reforms that would go a long way; I agree with all those who say that the time has not come to review the treaties, but we must continue to implement the program. The digital union, the energy union, the union of capital markets are projects that come from afar and will go far and, therefore, we must accelerate reforms instead of changing their content. Wenn es um Brexit geht, habe ich auch keine Lust zu wiederholen, was ich letzte Woche im Plenum gesagt habe. Ich stelle nur fest, dass die strahlenden Brexithelden von gestern die traurigen Helden von heute sind. (Beifall) Diejenigen, die dieses Ergebnis in Groebritannien mit herbeigef-hrt haben, treten einer nach dem anderen von der Bàhne ab: Johnson, Farage, andere. Das sind eigentlich - und als solche entpuppen sie sich - Retronationalisten und keine Patrioten. Patrioten gehen nicht von Bord, wenn die Lage schwierig wird. Dann bleiben sie. (Beifall) That is the reason we are waiting for the British notification. I could understand that the Remain camp needs weeks to reflect but I do not understand why the Brexit camp needs months before knowing what to do. I would have thought that they would have had a plan. Instead of developing a plan, they are leaving the boat. So I totally agree with President Tusk: we are waiting for the notification. No negotiation before notification, and those who want to have free access to the internal market will have to respect the Four Freedoms, including freedom of movement. This has to be done. (Applause)

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has In the first hours after the Brexit decision, when the European Council, led by Donald Tusk, met, stability was the order of the day. I would like to start by thanking you. We have had unrest, including in the markets, the economy has been unsettled, and that is having an impact on jobs on this continent. I would like to express my sincere thanks for the wise behaviour, for the prudent behaviour of all those responsible, because stability has been maintained, and that was important. The second thing is that the Brexit result must be respected, and the framework, the rules for the talks now under way, are clear. I would like to thank Jean-Claude Juncker for the clarity that there are no informal negotiations. The internal market is closely linked to fundamental freedoms. This has been made clear by the European Council and by others. Let me put it in a picture: it is not acceptable for lorries on this continent to have free movement, but for the citizens to stand in front of closed trees. It must therefore be clear that the internal market is linked to fundamental freedoms. There are no treaty changes to come. Nevertheless, a period of reflection, a period of pause, and also of considering where our contributions lie, is right. I would also like to say that we should not be in a blockade now. If the British do not know how to deal with the result, please go to the second row and consider what happens next. But the remaining 27 should not be deterred from doing their jobs. What's going on in the UK? We discussed it last week: there is a problem in London and none in Berlin, Rome or Paris. Four million people are calling for the election to be repeated, Scotland is considering how to go its own way, the economy is suggesting that it no longer sees London as a priority, and the country is leaderless. We have the effect of people seeing that london, not the European Union, after Brexit – and I hope that the people of Europe will see this. The chaos is being condensed – Mr President of the Commission, thank you for the clear statements – by the fact that the campaigners, the Brexiteers, are leaving. Both the winners, Farage and Johnson, who were successful in Brexit, now prefer a beautiful life. Farage is no longer there. I don't know which island he's vacationing on now and enjoying life. But he is no longer there. From my assessment, such behaviour is simply cowardly. The credibility of politics is not destroyed by European policy, but by such irresponsible behaviour. We in Europe need to disase the myths. "Europe costs sovereignty," it is claimed. Anyone who looks at trade policy today – the Commission, for example, will continue to discuss privacy shields, data protection on the Internet – is a gain in sovereignty for the people and for the Member States, not a loss. Europe is undemocratic: no decision taken in Europe is decided by European ministers without a majority in the Council of the European Union – by and large even unanimously – and is responsible in the European Parliament. Every Member here is responsible to his homeland, to his citizenship at home. Europe does not need tutoring in democracy. Another myth is 'Europe does not act'. Yes, sometimes it takes time, sometimes it takes time for us to get together. But this week we will be voting on the European coastal protection, which we have launched and legislatively implemented within five months. Europe can deliver when the will is there. We have also proved this in the banking union. Last but not least, Europe is to blame for Brexit. Self-criticism is always called for, but to those who have been banned in recent months from having any opinion at all about Europe, namely at the European level, to say now that they are to blame for Brexit is slanderous and downright madness. Above all, we need a new culture of responsibility in Europe. Blaming is not a good way to solve the challenges of the future. A democracy of responsibility would be required. For example, if the ambassadors in the Council unanimously decide to extend the Russia sanctions, one sometimes wonders why, in the same week, foreign ministers of that continent criticise and question these Russia sanctions. Responsibility would mean standing at home and also explaining why the ambassador in Brussels agrees to these sanctions. We need a democracy of responsibility in Europe, also in the sense of state-supporting parties. In Britain, the mood has only changed when relevant Tory forces have opted for populism and tried to follow the populist path. We need not be afraid of Farage and populists, but we must be afraid if the responsible democratic forces follow this path. That is why our task today is to build a new democracy of responsibility in Europe and to achieve solutions on the substance.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, following the shock of the referendum, last week's summit, Mr Tusk, should have been the turning point. We see lights but also shadows. Let's start with the lights. The decision to say no to blackmail, not to negotiate before notification of the will to withdraw is a good one. No to considering the European Union as a menu from which you choose the dishes you want: the four freedoms go together. If we want market access, then we must also accept the free movement of persons. Good on immigration: let us move forward on the partnership with African countries. But, there are also shadows that would make me almost say that the mountain gave birth to the mouse.  In the face of this crisis, the unity that you mentioned, welcome, of the 27 should have led, right away, to a project of relaunch, of greater integration, and instead it was preferred to postpone everything until September, in Bratislava, pretending not to understand that we are at a point of no return. Let me make it quite clear: this delay is yet another proof of the weakness not of the European Union but of an intergovernmental Europe. I do not understand where Schäuble lives: but how do you say that the intergovernmental method has worked well in recent years? Where was Schäuble during the Greek crisis? And what role did he play? Where was he during the migrant crisis? The objective of this offensive is clear: to try to marginalise the European Commission as the centre of the Community engine.  But we're not there. We want to defend the Community method, by defending Mr Juncker and the European Commission, we are defending the Community method against an intergovernmental revival which is totally unacceptable, because it is fruitless and harmful. I therefore appeal to the Council to change its register. But I am also addressing the Commission, which has done well on many points: I urge you not to be afraid. I know, Jean-Claude, that you're a brave person. You don't have to be intimidated, you have to move on. Yes, the Brexit negotiations must be swift and we cannot waste time waiting for conservative party members to elect the new leader. But it's absurd! It is a species – as Jean-Claude said, Manfred Weber said so well – that the heroes of the disaster should let the disaster produce rubble and return here, to the place that they called hell. In the face of consistency. We must act: on social issues we need momentum to eliminate dumping, we need an all-out fight against fiscal dumping, tax havens; we must put an end, once and for all, to austerity, applying the budgetary rules with flexibility and intelligence, and I say this too, here too I do not want to open up polemics with anyone, today words and deeds must be based on support, encouragement, not sanctions, punishments, rigors that do not take account of reality.  Today is the time for action, not postponements; unity in doing, not unity in in watching.

name: Syed Kamall
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Winston Churchill once said that when the eagles are silent, the parrots begin to jabber. Thankfully, last Tuesday and Wednesday the eagles – the Heads of Government – spoke. Cooler and calmer heads began to prevail, drowning out the parrots. And, while the Council does not want to live in limbo forever, it is right that EU leaders are saying they must respect the Treaties and respect the right of the British Government to decide how best to respond. In the EU it is for the respective national governments to decide how best to respond to a national referendum. This is the case even now, where the Netherlands has been given the space to decide its response to its referendum in March. The Treaties are clear, and if anyone does not like what the Lisbon Treaty says, then blame the authors and the signatories. Who knows, maybe one or two of them are in this Chamber here today! Some here are quick to point the finger at others and accuse them of breaching the rule of law, while at the same time casting aside our own rules and precedents when it does not suit the majority: ganging up on political groups they do not agree with to deny them committee positions or responsibility for reports that they are entitled to under the D’Hondt system; or interfering in the internal affairs of Member States where they do not like the democratically elected government of that country. The more that Commissioners, the European Parliament and international leaders try to pressure the UK, the more they justify the decision that the British people have taken. The British referendum was just the latest wake-up call for the EU, and many rightly respond by calling for more reform. The problem is, it is not the reform that Mark Rutte speaks of when he said ‘European where necessary, national where possible’. Instead, they seek to pursue the 1950s European project, to build the United States of Europe and to ask why it has not happened already. Donald Tusk was right to say that people are disillusioned with grand utopian visions of the future and just want us to cope better with the present. Some in Brussels draw different conclusions and, instead of wanting to get on with a friendly relationship with the UK, foster hope that maybe a part of the United Kingdom can remain in the EU, rolling out the red carpet for the First Minister of Scotland. I am sure that the people of Flanders, Catalonia and the Basque country will be encouraged to see EU leaders enthusiastically embracing regional self-determination. In this Chamber we rightly talk about the lessons of history, but what about the lessons that warn of the peril when leaders become disconnected from their people? Increasingly, decisions in the EU are not necessarily being made in an open and transparent way, especially in this Chamber. Decisions are not always made by all 751 MEPs from across the continent. Politics is about perception and there is a perception that decisions are increasingly made by five men sitting in a room and cutting deals among themselves. This is not a perception of democracy – and, if you really want to show that you are open and transparent, then stop the ‘grand coalition’ backroom stitch-ups. My Group does not want the EU to break up, but to avoid this the EU must seriously change how it works. Whatever the challenge, ‘more Europe’ is not always the answer. Ignoring the results of national elections and referenda and saying we continue anyway is not a good enough response. EU Heads of State and Governments are rightly meeting in Bratislava this September to ask some tough questions, and that is what the ECR Group was created to do: to sometimes ask those tough questions that people in this Chamber do not necessarily want to hear. With or without the UK, there are a growing number of people across the European Union who want change. So my plea to all of you is, listen to those who want the EU to meet the challenges of the future. Listen to those who want politicians to start addressing their legitimate concerns even where we may disagree, and listen to those who want their leaders to focus on creating jobs and growth, rather than creating political utopias.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I always find it a little difficult that Mr Kamall gives lessons to us. Mr Kamall, you are leaving the Union and you are explaining here what to do in the future: it is incredible. Would it not be better if you knew what to do in Britain? In my opinion, the Brexiteers have no clue about what needs to be done for the moment. It would be better to give lessons in London and not here in Strasbourg. In fact, the Brexiteers remind me of rats fleeing a sinking ship. Cameron resigned, Johnson abandoned ship and Farage apparently wants more time for himself and his family to spend his European salary. So the Leave man remains – or has disappeared for the moment. I think that the last man standing in Britain will probably be a woman. That will happen and, like in the time of Margaret Thatcher, only a woman will be capable of managing a divided Tory party, as we see it today. Yes, women will rescue Britain. My second surprise last week, Mr Tusk, was the reaction of the European Council to this political earthquake – because what happened in Britain is an earthquake. The only reaction I have heard from the Council was that we should not change anything and that it is just a question of implementing the existing European policies. I find this shocking and I also find it irresponsible. I do not think that you understand what is happening. It is not only a Brexit referendum. Before that there was a referendum in Denmark: negative. There was a referendum on the Ukraine agreement in the Netherlands: negative. Now we have had this referendum in the UK. What are you waiting for? For the next referendum in France? The next referendum in Italy maybe? When will the Council recognise that you can no longer defend the European Union of today and that Europe needs to be reformed? In my opinion, a new project and a new vision should be presented to the citizens of Europe because the truth is that European citizens are not against Europe, they are against this Europe. The proof of that is the Eurobarometer. I wonder why the Commission and Parliament did not published this Eurobarometer much earlier because it dates from a few weeks ago, in April. Do you know what the results are? Eighty-two per cent of people want more European action on the fight against terrorism; 77% of European citizens want more European action in the fight against unemployment; 75% of European citizens ask for more European action in the fight against tax fraud; and 74% are asking for more European action on the issue of migration. On 14 of the 15 questions put to European citizens in this Eurobarometer a few weeks ago, people are asking for more European action, not less. The problem is that Europe has become ... what? Europe – our Europe – has become an expert on legislation on the exact measurements and colour of our cigarette packets. We have become an expert in deciding the amount of water flushing in toilets and also in the level of subsidies that a local football club can receive from local government. But what the citizens want – and that is what the European Eurobarometer tells us – is a European Border and Coast Guard, a European asylum and migration policy to tackle the migration crisis, European intelligence capacity to tackle terrorism, a European government to defend the euro and a European army to defend our borders and to end conflicts in our neighbourhood. That is what the citizens are asking for here. The inconvenient truth is that more of the same will not get us out of this crisis, dear colleagues. That is burying our heads in the sand. People want you to work on another Europe, a Europe that delivers results. By not doing that, you are sleepwalking towards disaster, towards 27 other referendums in the near future. So let us not be naive. The real problem today – and Mr Pittella is right when he mentions Schäuble – is intergovernmentalism. A loose configuration of nation states based on unanimity cannot work. That is the reality today that you have not recognised until now. I will conclude by saying that we are going to do our homework. Parliament will be ready in October with a global plan based on three reports on the way forward. We are not going to talk –you can be sure – about federalism, integration, deepening, widening, coordination, implementation and all these other buzzwords that are at the centre of our discussions. We are simply going to go back to the ideas of our founding fathers. That is what we have to do. That is the challenge. Now or never. Either the Union will change, Mr Tusk, or it will die. That is what is at stake. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I am confused by your comments and some of the other ones today. Are you aware of how British parliamentary democracy works? What happened was that the leaders of the main parties and of government were all EU fans – they were all on your side. The people voted the other way. It was not a change of government. You say the Brexit side has no plan, but the Brexit side is not the government: the government has to change to allow someone to be Prime Minister who will actually carry through the will of the people. That is how our democracy works, so when you say these assertions, you are missing the point of exactly what a referendum actually is.

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I was absolutely not pointing the finger at the people, the citizens of Britain. It is their right to decide what they have decided. I was pointing the finger at your leaders in Britain: at Mr Farage, Mr Johnson and Mr Gove, who today are leaving the political scene and yet have no clue what has to happen in the future, leaving the country with the markets in turmoil. That is my criticism: the citizens are right, but your political leaders are not.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I believe that enough attention has been paid to Mr Farage, Mr Johnson and Mr Cameron. We should not shower them with even more honours. For me, they only behaved like children who play with wooden blocks for the first time, built a turret and were happy when this wooden turret collapsed. However, this is possible in a children's room, and this is not possible within the EU. That is why I also think that, on the other hand, the results of last week's Council meeting were scandalous. To explain in such a situation that we need a new period of reflection, and ultimately nothing concrete to say, which should be pointed out by this reflection, what needs to be changed, reminds me of exactly the same reaction after the failed constitutional referendums in the Netherlands and France. We have had exactly the same debate here! Has the confidence of EU citizens in the EU institutions, in the Council, in the European Parliament, in the Commission changed since then? Yes, it has changed. After all, there is even more divergence. On this issue, I am also absolutely right to the previous speaker. If nothing is changed, if we do not finally make this European Union the Union of Citizens, then it will fail, and then we all have a shared responsibility for it here! But the messages that have been sent out in recent days are not messages of change. These are messages towards austerity, policies of rigid cuts to public budgets. After Greece, Spain and Portugal are now being targeted and threatened with drastic sanctions. The EU continues to be hierarchical. Open threats such as those made by German Finance Minister Schäuble are in the air: those who do not go along are left out. Individual states, groups of states, are announced. This will further increase inequalities within the EU and within the eurozone. In view of the protests of millions of citizens on TTIP and CETA, Mr Juncker, it is an absolute mishandling to declare that CETA should not be negotiated in the national parliaments. I don't know what you thought! They thus feed the idea of the UNdemocratic decision-making level of the EU, which cares a bit about what moves the citizens. But let us put aside the dispute over treaty changes and a Convention. As long as you just want to haggle over voting rights, weighting, different speeds, regrouping of power blocs, the citizens do not need a Convention. Many are fed up with the lone-offs, power struggles, blockades and failures of the economic, political elites in the Member States. But what is now immediately possible? Now immediately and practically feasible? It is high time that we now stand together in solidarity as Member States of the European Union and, for example, set up a European emergency humanitarian programme. Such a programme would send a clear signal, especially to the most marginalised, to those who have had to bear the crisis, the debt crisis in recent years, on their hump, and would be able to help appreciably. We want the immediate introduction of minimum incomes above the poverty line – we do not need a treaty change for that! We want the principle to finally apply: equal pay in the same place for the same work! This is also possible without a treaty amendment. In doing so, they wanted to take the tooth out of those who take advantage of the fear of social decline and the fear of refugees personally. This would give the Member States a minimum social standard. We could work on that. Give back their rights to the trade unions. Above all, you explain one thing: explain clearly, especially to the younger generation, that even if the UK leaves, the necessary redistributions in the EU budget will not lead to a reduction in youth assistance programmes, youth exchange programmes and not Erasmus either. Let young people continue their education in the European Union. Do not pass on the victim role to them. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Do you not appreciate that while you have spoken here about this great wooden tower – this Tower of Babel – it is built on a bed of straw? Its two key foundations, as we hear all the time – the two pillars that represent the European Union – are freedom of movement and the eurozone, yet the Italian banks are on the verge of an extra bailout. We see it cannot work. The big issue here, I would contend, is contagion. You really know, in your heart of hearts, that the people of the European Union supported trade, but they do not support political union.

name: Gabriele Zimmer (GUE/NGL)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I did not speak of the tower of Babel, but of the infantile behaviour of the leaders of Great Britain, the British conservative elite, which is playing with wooden blocks and throwing these towers together and then resenting them. The European Union is not a toy that can be thrown against the wall and then rejoices when something has broken down.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report and for the I don't know Boris Johnson, but I know Nigel Farage. And I have to say that i was not surprised by this dangerous mule- hero that he is now evasing his responsibilities. The situation in the United Kingdom is much more difficult than you have shown here. But in all the inconsistency of the last few days, one thing was surprising, namely that after the Brexit decision in Britain, the defeat of the European Union was the first time that an emotional discussion about the European Union had taken place. Suddenly, in the reports from the United Kingdom, there are the stories of tears flowing on the streets, in companies. There are words such as European pain or the word of the new desire for Europe, and I have to tell you that I have a great desire to deal with this. What happens next with the Brexit decision is likely to be in the hands of a new British government. The European Union of 27, on the other hand, must defend the interests of the 27. But anyone who looks at the whole of the UK today must say that Nicola Sturgeon, with her appeal and the speakers at the demonstration at the weekend, were absolutely right in their appeal that our doors must remain open for Britain. Ladies and gentlemen! What can we do to connect with those who have been on the streets of London? What is actually behind this Brexit decision? What happened? There are too many reports about these neo-nationalists, about populists and anti-Europeans of all stripes, who do not want to dissipate the concerns and insecurity of the citizens, but who simply use, cheer and convert for their ideas. And we need to deal politically with these concerns of the people who also contributed to this Brexit decision and give other answers. Few places I know in Europe represent the new and unjust social order as London. There is still room for the super-rich and the rich and some of the wealthy. Ordinary people, let alone have nothing, where are they still in this capital? And this social polarisation, this growing injustice, which people are also observing, to which we must give answers if we do not want to watch as it is used time and again by those who engage in nationalist and anti-European incitement. We have talked here time and again in recent years about how we can set fair taxes for companies, how we can tame or at least regulate the financial markets. We have talked about how a New Deal, a Green New Deal can create jobs and jobs and prospects and innovation, and we have also talked very often about the need for binding social standards throughout Europe, especially when we see that social security systems are simply collapsing throughout the countries of the European Union. What has occupied me a lot over the last few days is how the people who are now somehow looking weird out of the laundry have made the little people vote against their interests. I am a child of small backgrounds, and I have nothing but contempt, I have to tell you, for the Farages, the Le Pens and those of storks of this world, who incite small people against small people and against the weak. And I believe that it is really a big question, such as Poland, for example, like the PiS Group, the PiS delegation, that Poles in Britain, as citizens who have done a great deal for the country, are no longer suffering today. The European Union must change. The European Union must change, but only those who are prepared to defend this European Union will also have a chance against this neo-nationalism and the incitement of the continent. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Ms Harms, you seemed to be a bit contradictory in your exposition, because you seemed to be saying that the EU is a construction in favour of rich people – which I would agree with, but they are very rich people at the top. Do you understand that the people in the UK who voted to leave were in fact predominantly – not all, but predominantly – those people who have been hit hardest by the European Union, who have had to bear the economic burden: the people who do not have jobs, who do not have prospects, who are seeing their living standards being driven down? Do you understand that it was those people who voted to leave, and that, in fact, the EU is a construction for very rich people at the top: the big banks and the Goldman Sachs of this world?

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I would seek every responsibility, every central responsibility for how London has developed, from the British Government, not only from the last government, but also from some before it. And I find it really irresponsible that they have not been able to change that, to blame the Europeans as such and to incite the little people against the European Union. I also think that in the last few days we have seen that you really did not know what you wanted to do. After all, it is now being announced that corporate taxation will be reduced and that social benefits in the United Kingdom will be cut. This is your British Brexit policy for the little people!

name: Paul Nuttall
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I want to start by really changing the tone of this debate. Ms Harms, I am not going to rabble-rouse in any way, shape or form, because I am sure that things were said in the heat of the moment, in the aftermath of Brexit, which many people regret – not only certain people in this Chamber and in the Commission, but also in the UK itself. The British people have spoken, and threats and bullying are not the answer to the questions that the UK leaving the European Union has thrown up. I want to look forwards and not backwards, because what is needed is some fair and equitable negotiations that will ensure that the best deal is struck, both for the British people and for the European Union. As an elected representative, I have a duty to ensure that the will of our people is fulfilled. Now, Mr Juncker, I am not here to crow. I am not here to gloat. I am not here to hector, but merely to tell you that it is in both our interests to get the best deal possible. We, in the European Parliament, should put aside the language of conflict and, as elected representatives, work towards a viable and prosperous future together. The outcome of this referendum is clear. The British people want to leave the European Union and also cease being a member of the single market which entails freedom of movement of people. We want access to the single market, like the United States, like China, like Russia and many other countries around the globe.
