But we will take back control of our borders, our own laws and our own money. In the longer term, we would like to see a free trade deal between the European Union and ourselves. This makes sense not just for us, but also for the EU. We, the British, have a huge trading deficit with the European Union: GBP 60 billion alone last year. Millions of jobs on the continent are dependent on British trade. We are the French farmers’ biggest marketplace, purchasing 35 million bottles of champagne last year alone. We are the German car manufacturers’ biggest marketplace, buying 800 000 German cars last year. The last thing any of us want, in my country or here, is a tariff war, which will be mutually destructive for both our economies. The UK and Europe are joined by geography, culture, history and trade, and that will not change. Therefore, it is imperative on so many levels that we are good, healthy trading neighbours. We owe it to the citizens of both the UK and Europe to conduct these negotiations in a grown-up manner so we can get the best deal for everyone. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question. – You are right that recriminating leads nowhere, but I would like to ask you whether you are aware that the number of hate crimes in Great Britain has increased dramatically as a result of this rise in nationalism. What do you think of the fact that Poles, perhaps French people, but also Finnish people who have moved there are increasingly asked in everyday life when you will leave? What do you think of the change in mental climate in Britain caused by Brexit?

name: Paul Nuttall (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – The police have made it perfectly clear that what is happening in the UK in terms of hate crime tends to happen after any national or international event, and that the rise in hate crime is not actually that great. At the end of May, for example, there were 54 hate crimes in Britain, and there were 87 at the end of this month. But I want to say we should have no hate crimes not just in our country, but anywhere across Europe.  In terms of making it clear that people will not be moved, people are protected by something called the Vienna Convention, which predates even Britain’s membership of the European Union. Our people – pensioners in Spain and Portugal and Italy and everywhere else – are protected in the EU, just as EU citizens are protected in Britain. As I say, I want us to be good neighbours; I want us to crack on with negotiations and I want us to trade together.

name: Marine Le Pen
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, what hatred, what rage on the part of the Europeanists! Thank you, my dear friends, for showing your true face. The day after Brexit, I had a press conference saying to the French: "Listen to them, look at them well in the coming days, and then you will see the true face of the European Union and its defenders." The least we can say is that we have been served. After the gigantic manipulations of pre-Brexit, where we were told the apocalypse according to Tusk - European civilization was about to collapse, the stock market was going to explode and it was hardly if the United Kingdom was not going to sink - none of this obviously happened. So we have moved on to the second phase, the phase where we question the people, their will, democracy. Bertolt Brecht said: "When the people vote badly, the people must be dissolved." That may be what you have been doing for years with mass immigration, but you go much further. You say, "When the people vote badly, we must suppress the vote." It's so much simpler like that, indeed. So it was a contest: in France, it was proposed that young people vote double, it was proposed to ban the elderly from voting; in the United Kingdom, there were demonstrations, up to this totally bogus petition with millions of false signatures, of which you have made yourself, of course, relays throughout the media. At the 28-29 June summit, EU heads of state found no conclusion to Brexit: they remained dry. The European Union without the United Kingdom has no more ideas and a future than the European Union with the United Kingdom. Yet the challenge in the coming months is simple: will the separation between the European Union and the United Kingdom be conducted in good faith or bad faith, allowing partners to remain on good or bad terms? We have heard many Europeanists unable to admit the result that came out of the polls thundering that the British people had to pay dearly for this divorce, for the sole purpose of making an example, of course, to deter other peoples with terror. Of course, you will shoot yourself in the foot, as you well know, because this policy of the worst will be detrimental not only to the United Kingdom, but especially to France and many European countries. Our exports to the UK are well above our imports. You can see that it is absolutely not in our interest to create tensions, but with you, it is true, the worst is always safe. The reality is that the links between Switzerland and the countries of the European Union, for example, should be a model for forging a realistic and friendly partnership with the United Kingdom, but you do not want to see it. You refuse to admit that people reject your European Union; it's as simple as that. They tell you in every tone, they have told you every time they have been asked the question in recent years. You continue to want to impose more integration and more European Union, and you are even considering - and I almost want to thank you again - to pass CETA and TAFTA without the advice of parliaments. You'll show, again, your true face. The people want their sovereignty restored, they want to cooperate freely in a new Europe of nations and peoples. So your choice is simple: either you change radically or you disappear.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, the European Council on 27 and 28 June shows that, as here, most European leaders have not understood the situation. Instead of a Union based on the agreement of free states developing concrete programmes of cooperation between them, you always want more forced integration, which is increasingly causing distrust and hostility of the peoples. Two examples have been given of these conclusions: national parliaments will have no say in CETA, the agreement with Canada, and in July in Warsaw, our foreign and security policy will be further aligned with that of NATO, that is, that of the United States. But autism does not exclude contradictions. Mr Weber, for the EPP, is outraged that he does not see Mr Farage here, but Mr Verhofstadt, for the Liberals, is outraged that Mr Kamall is still here, and even dares to speak there. Mr Verhofstadt explains that, according to the Eurobarometer, European citizens want more action from the UNION, especially on migration. But yes, Mr Verhofstadt, to contain mass immigration, not to organise it, as was still done here yesterday in this Chamber. As for the United Kingdom, we went through all the stages of bullying, we tried to make it look like a series of terrible disasters. They don't happen. We try to provoke them with self-fulfilling prophecies. We want to keep people free, to impose it on the British if they want to maintain the free movement of trade. Yet you continue to negotiate with Japan, with the United States and many others, who do not have the free movement of people. Anger blinds you and it really seems that she is a bad counselor.

name: Herbert Reul (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his excellent work and for his excellent work. I do not accept anyone in this Chamber who does not respect this result from the British people. That is decided. But the way in which the last speeches have been discussed here makes me stunned! In all clarity, we must no longer allow – as we have often done in recent months – to allow such false statements, such populist slogans, lies that are spread here to simply remain uncontested and to plunge peoples into their misfortune. The British people will end up paying the bill. I have no desire for such sayings to infect other peoples in the future. This must be contradicted in all clarity. However, we also have to do our job, that is also true. (Applause) That simply means continuing, and it is not possible, but Mr Verhofstadt is right: less small-scale regulation. Incidentally, we do not mean that, with more Europe. Making Europe in the right places, where the citizens expect us to solve the problems that are there, but not to regulate every small, that is true. But we will do this again tomorrow with a database for energy efficiency labels. By the way, you may be taking part in this. I believe that we must then also say no to this small-scale regulation and concentrate on the essentials, as the President of the Commission once proposed and how we sometimes do not. That is the truth.  The refugee issue, the question of growth, the fight against terrorism, that is the truth. It has to be delivered, because people expect us to find answers and offer solutions and not just talk around and make some nice suggestions. Incidentally, we must also eliminate a few untruths among ourselves here. Now to discuss youth unemployment and austerity while Brexit was! What does Britain have to do with austerity and youth unemployment? This is a huge quark! All I can see is that a policy has been successful in Spain, and that in Portugal a policy that has been based on stability and growth promotion has been successful in the end. That is the truth that must be described here. Now they are saying: yes, this is not hoppla-hopp, not overnight. We do not live here in the dream or magic world, but this is tedious and goes step by step. But changing course every week – as some parts of this House do – is not a contribution to reliability and confidence building either.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you, Mr Reul, for allowing the question. Mr Reul, you also used the term 'populists' in your speech, and I agree with you that much of what comes from this side of the House is populist. But I would like to know: how do you describe those people on the more left side of the House who divide the world into the super-rich and the wealthy, as Mrs Harms has done, for example, who, with the most vile stereotypes, are rushing against important industries such as the pharmaceutical industry or the banks that defend the EU, which is a great free trade alliance, but at the same time spreads misinformation against free trade such as CETA and TTIP. Aren't they also populists?

name: Herbert Reul (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I have no problem with that at all. People who say the untruth, who unnecessarily incite people and rush in the wrong way – whether left or right, i am completely angry with me – are clearly opposed by us. We need to be more objective, we need to be more problem-solving. Let me give you an example, such as CETA now: the fact that parts of the House are currently upset that national parliaments must be involved in CETA, because it is only democratic, is a strange process. I have always thought that we would also be a democratic Parliament here. And I have always waited for everyone here in Parliament to say: 'We are a democratic parliament, and when we decide, it is as democratic as when national parliaments decide'.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we have heard a number of voices in this debate from British people who were pleased, indeed triumphant, that Britain is leaving the European Union. Allow me to speak as one of the 48% who voted to remain, who regret this decision and who will be sad if Britain leaves this Union that we have helped to build over many years. A referendum is normally called to settle an issue, but Britain at the moment does not seem to me to be calm and settled. It is in political turmoil. There are economic problems, with the pound falling and the AAA rating lost. Huge questions are being asked about what comes next. There are even people – perhaps surprisingly – challenging the result of this referendum. There is a petition to Parliament, started by a Leave supporter, which has had over 4 million signatures asking Parliament not to trigger Article 50. There are demonstrations. There is the Scottish Government saying that this decision should not necessarily apply to all the countries of Britain. Why do you think there are challenges to the result of a democratic referendum? Well, partly because Nigel Farage himself said that 52% to 48% settles nothing. Of course, when he said it he thought the result would be the other way around. People now are perhaps beginning to take him at his word. Others are just shocked at the number of Leave lies that were told in the referendum campaign, the number of issues where those wishing to leave simply told, and repeated, blatant lies. Finally, there are what I would call the Remain truths – the warnings about the consequences of leaving, which were rubbished as being scare tactics. However, the reality is beginning to show, with companies leaving Britain, what has happened to the pound and what has happened to the economy, and in these circumstances it is not surprising that many people wish to reconsider – those who voted to leave, crucially. Above all, there is one point that is much more important. Why has the Government not triggered Article 50? Because it cannot. There is no agreed position in Britain on what it should seek as an alternative. The Leave side offered two completely different visions. One group said ‘Let us stay in the single market’ (we heard that just now): ‘of course there will be no problem; they will let us trade with the single market.’ But then you have to follow the common rules for the common market (on which you would have no say anymore, by the way), including the principle of free movement, which is exactly what they were urging people to vote against. Others in the Leave campaign said ‘No, no: leave the European market. We will go global.’ But then you face a tariff barrier on every British good sold in the single market. So when the Government, or the future Prime Minister, comes off the fence and chooses one of those two options, there will be people in Britain, who voted to leave, who will say ‘Hang on a minute: that is not what we were told, that is not what we voted for.’ And I will not be surprised at all if you see Leave supporters asking for a rethink. This issue is not as settled as it might appear to be at first sight. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Corbett, if people here from other countries who wanted Britain to remain had been more positive about the EU, do you think you might have stayed? My example is Mr Verhofstadt, who is a European federalist integrationist, and his strongest argument in here seems to be that if you do not stay you will be a dwarf. If I said that to my wife in order to convince her to stay with me, she would leave, and she would be right. Mr Verhofstadt wants a united Europe. Do you think he has contributed to splitting it up?

name: Richard Corbett (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – The range of views on what should be the future of Europe was indeed widely debated in Britain and there are many views on the future of Europe, but let us remember the basic rule book of the European Union: the Treaties are laid down by agreement among all the Member States. So the idea that the Union could go off in a direction that was unacceptable to one or another of those Member States and that could be imposed on them against their will was just one of the other Leave lies that were put about in this referendum campaign.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! I call for a language of mutual respect. I know Mrs Harms well, we have been together in Ukraine in very difficult times, and I know that Mrs Harms does not really despise anyone. But let us not talk about contempt, let us say that we are different, even sometimes deeply. Let us be sure that the Brexiteers have made a mistake – and for their country and for Europe, but let us not say we despise them. That's a mistake in my opinion.  The Council may have recently given birth to Polish mouse, but the Council's conclusions include the key word sought by Poland and the government, and we are pleased with that word. There is talk of the need to reform the European Union, because this reform is absolutely necessary. If, just here, Mr Verhofstadt, with whom I first agreed during the last two years, says that the Union will either change or die, Then I will just say that, as Mr Verhofstadt wants, he will die even sooner. This is not about more integration, that there is a super state, it is about what Mr Verhofstadt's party colleague, Dutch Prime Minister M. Rutte, said in a great speech, that citizens must be listened to, that everything must be done to ensure that citizens feel influenced by the decisions of the European Union.  Finally, I wanted to say that, as Mr Pittella says, in order to speed up elections in the Tory party, it is really Europeans, European taxpayers, as they will find out that we want to regulate elections in individual parties, they will simply kill us with laughter. This will not strengthen the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Mr. Vice President, I'm sorry. I have always listened to your words with great respect. You have already referred to democracy, the voice of the people and other important things. But do you think it is fair that we expect you to make a decision here first, and then then we will discuss in the various bodies what it is really about. Because the way I see it, it's not a democracy.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I do not know whether I understood your question well and whether you understood my statement well. I am very unhappy with what has happened in the UK. Brexit is not in the uk's interest, although it is not my business, but it is not in Europe's interest, and Poland is a very important part of the European Union.  Finally, I would like people here who are in favour of Brexit to condemn loudly the attacks on my compatriots, on Poles in the European Union, also on the example of other nationalities. That's what I'm missing from the Brexiteers. I think Brexit is a problem, but let's talk about it in a different language, calmer, without emotion.

name: Catherine Bearder (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, there is a children’s poem that says ‘For the want of a nail, the kingdom was lost’. The British referendum was lost for the want of education and information – especially in our media – to fight the anti-European propaganda of years and years, especially by foreign—owned media bosses. For the want of governments that recognise the widening gaps in society, the haves and the have—nots and the left behind. For the want of truth. This referendum campaign was packed with exaggerations, threats and downright lies. For the want of all these things and more, the referendum was lost, and I, like the 48% who voted to stay in, am heartbroken. We’ve been overwhelmed by the support from friends across the EU who wanted us to stay, but I’m heartbroken most for the young, who will miss their opportunities; heartbroken for the entrepreneurs who see doors closing; heartbroken for scientists who see horizons shrinking; for businesses, for farmers, for bankers and for the rest, whose future is now so uncertain. I’m heartbroken. But it was all lost. In the UK, we must mend our politics – it is chaos and embarrassment and packed with hate. But we must move our politics into the 21st century, and we must have a general election soon: we cannot allow one single party to decide the leader of our country. The 48% must not be forgotten. As a Liberal Democrat, I am a pro-European, will continue to be pro-European, and will fight for that. We need to sort out our relationship with the EU. Europe, EU, we will miss you. You have your own work to do to adjust and to go forward, but this was not just a wake—up call for the UK. Please don’t ignore what happened in the UK: take your people with you.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you so much, dear colleague, for your warm and passionate plea for the EU. I have one short question. How do you assess the collapse of the mainstream political parties in the UK after the referendum, knowing that your party was the only one to fight for Europe?

name: Catherine Bearder (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Not the only one, the Greens too. Yes, it’s a crazy situation: one that the government thought they would win, and it was a poor campaign that was, as I said, packed with lies. We now have an awful lot to do: we have to repair our politics of abdication and chaos, where everybody has run away because it’s too difficult to sort out. We will be there, fighting for the pro-European voice to be heard: the voice of sense and the voice of the people.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Brexit could be more devastating for us than for the UNITED Kingdom: there is xenophobia in the British vote but there is something else and if we pretend to ignore it, xenophobia will take over Europe. The nemesis of Brexit does not fall from the sky: first came the contempt with which the Union buried the Greek anti-austerity referendum. We had a year to recognize that it was a Pyrrhic victory. A wasted year! Now that we're going to make up? Delegate more sovereignty? The remaining countries will not accept it. Blaming universal suffrage will punish us even more. The class war is not over: the old impoverished classes and the new ones that we have deprived of a name, tell us, like the commander in Don Giovanni, "time is up". Delegating powers to an oligarchy that is increasingly deaf to universal suffrage is no use. Only changing policies and democratising them can do anything.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), "blue card" question. We all know here that BREXIT relied heavily on lies and populism. I regret that the Left is repeating itself, and is, in fact, pouring water on the eurosceptic mill, that BREXIT came from austerity and the policies of the European Union.  We consider it an insult here that we democratically decide on all the issues on which the European Parliament and the other institutions of the European Union operate by a majority, trying to find reasons other than the real ones, than those for which BREXIT took place.  And I believe that one reason why there is Euroscepticism is because misinformation continues. I expect, particularly from the Left, to hear proposals. Proposals for growth, proposals for unemployment, proposals to tackle problems. Unfortunately, he enters the same camp of denial and dogmatism.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL)
text: Answer to a blue card question. I agree, My colleague: poverty is at the heart and so is the inability to cope with migration. There are proposals, put forward by the left, there are also proposals with regard to the integration of migrants and growth based on ecology. It is a proposal that generally remains in the minority, but that does not mean that it does not exist as a proposal.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I heard Mr Weber say earlier that ‘there is a problem in London’. What an understatement that was. The absence of political leadership from Westminster is absolutely shameful in these circumstances. The UK Government has no plan, and even those who led the leave campaign have no idea what to do next. Perhaps we should not be surprised, given that their campaign was based – as many have said – upon lies, but also that it seems that they did not expect to win. I am glad that colleagues have recognised that the UK is not one country. In fact, it is four different ones, and the Brexit referendum underlines that fact once again. The result in Scotland, my country, was a clear majority in favour of remaining in the European Union. The remain campaign in Scotland was based on the positive, outlining the many benefits which derive from EU membership and with a vision for the future. I think that the negative result in England was based on decades of failure by UK governments, decades of half—hearted approaches to EU membership, decades of blaming Brussels for anything that seems unpopular, and decades of failing to underline the fact that it is elected governments and MEPs who make the decisions in the European Union. By contrast, the Scottish Government and Nicola Sturgeon, with a cross-party mandate, seek to achieve and give effect to what Scotland voted for and, in the coming months, will be working hard and positively to that effect.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Hudghton, more Scots voted to remain in the United Kingdom in the neverendum which you inflicted on our country than voted to remain in the European Union. Therefore the matter is settled. Scotland is part of the United Kingdom. There is also not a great number of people who are in favour of the European Union. I speak for the 40% of Scots who voted against the European Union. We knew when we had the referendum that the decision would be for the entire United Kingdom. Why is Mrs Sturgeon continuing to damage the Scottish economy with her nonsense, creating trouble in Europe? The Europeans are not interested. The Spanish will veto it because they do not want any trouble with Catalonia and their other regions. So you are wasting your time and I wish you would stop damaging the Scottish economy. Do you agree with me, sir?

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – I struggled to hear the question in that, but I acknowledge that Mr Coburn speaks for the 40%. I speak for the 60% in Scotland who voted in favour of remaining within the European Union. Can I remind the House of another thing that Nicola Sturgeon has said recently? That is the fact that the United Kingdom, which Scotland voted to remain a part of a couple of years ago, no longer exists. People like Mr Coburn and the others on the Unionist side of that argument promised that, if Scotland voted to remain part of the UK, our EU membership would be safeguarded. Now it is at risk.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: Madam President, colleagues, I was really surprised by the European Council's approach, my approach to Brexit. The question, which is the cornerstone of Europe today, is limited to listening to information. Does this mean that the decision of the citizens of one Member Community to leave that Community to the leaders of other countries does not give rise to any questions and debates? Dear, Brexit did not start yesterday, and it began when we easily cut off the Christian roots of Europe with an easy hand in the european Constitution that did not enter into force. And when European politicians did not hear the voice of either French or Dutch citizens in 2005, rejecting that Constitution. It has been replaced bureaucratically by the Lisbon Treaties. Even later, the Greek financial crisis, the migrant tsunami, etc., but nothing has actually been done to hear the British voice, to change the European Union, to make it more democratic, so that all countries are equal, that all voices are heard, that collective decisions are taken, that we have national states, otherwise it will be bad. Dear, the British didn't betray anything. They provided a last chance to change the policy of the European Union. From globalisation and federalisation towards free states and peoples towards Europe. Who are we today if we are left behind by a country that lives within the oldest western policy rules and highest standards? In order to answer the fundamental question, what will be the future of Europe: the commonwealth of equal states or the dictatorship of Brussels? –It is necessary to convene a pan-European Convention of States to draw up new guidelines for the European Constitution and to make a new real impetus for the unity of nations on the road to a prosperous Europe.

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF).
text: – Madam President, the UK is a bit like Belgium was a few years ago. We are doing OK without national leaders.  I would like to address Mr Tusk. This is directly to you, Sir. I am not here to gloat but to say that I came into politics to get my country out of the European Union and vote Brexit – and they did. I am the 52%. I believe the victory of national democracy will encourage my friends in other nations to fight for their right to determine their own national interests. And of course we condemn all the attacks on European citizens. They are most welcome and particularly the Polish. At home we have had scaremongering by our own Prime Minister and Chancellor. They deliberately talked our economy down. That caused a little ripple in the financial markets last Friday, but luckily the FTSE has reasserted and corrected itself and the pound is now finding its true level. European businesses will recognise that they need to continue to trade with us. After all, over EUR 288 billion of EU trade is with the UK. Our Commonwealth partners, the US, South Korea and others are queuing up to do free trade deals with us. Don’t be left behind.  That is why it is imperative that Mr Juncker and the Commission take no part in this negotiation process, which my group called for last week. I actually put that motion down and my group agreed with it. Jobs and business matter, not political retribution. He has also proved over the past few weeks that he is unable and unfit to lead these negotiations. Therefore I would like you, Mr Tusk, to head up the negotiations, along with the other 27 European Heads of Government: they recognise trade. Let us take this divorce forward. Let us make it amicable and make it mutually beneficial to both my country and the European Union.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President, dear colleague, you have made a shocking statement, at least for me, that you entered the European Union to fight to dismantle it. It's absolutely unnatural.  I ask you, I find it naïve, do you think one is stronger than 28? Do you think you can influence the European Union by leaving the European Union?

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF)
text: blue-card answer. – I was elected to take us out of the European Union. I am the 52%. I do not know what some of you do not understand about democracy in this place. The 52% voted. We are going and actually the United Kingdom has the Commonwealth. Our Queen is the Head of State of many countries. You do not have that; maybe that is why you need to be part of this sclerotic Union.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – In 1918 Poland came out of the occupation of three powers, there was a mess, the Regency Council declared independence, then handed over power to Piłsudski, he dissolved the kingdom, then there was a coup, but in the end Poland regained its independence. Today, the United Kingdom, which currently has the status of sultanate in Malaysia, is fighting for liberation from the occupation of the European Union. The mess is much smaller than in Poland in 1918. I am convinced that the UNITED KINGDOM will regain its independence. And to the socialists who want to extend social rights to the whole of Europe, and to Mr Juncker, who wants to talk about Europeans, I want to remind you that the great European philosopher Lord Acton has said that every socialism must end in national socialism. If you are talking about a European nation, Euroso-socialism becomes national socialism. We must defend Europe against national socialism, we must defend Europe against you. That is why I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It seems to me that we have all taken it seriously, with a takeover, but we have also regrets the decision expressed in the referendum that the UK is leaving our community. It seems that even the British themselves seem surprised by their decision, and also a little worried. But I must say that there is often such a temptation to blame a distant Union for national problems, because it is easier to say that Brussels has done so. On the other hand, we do so for the purposes of the national debate. As a result, we expect effects such as Brexit, but also effects such as the Dutch referendum. This is a Ukraine that we could help by accepting this association agreement and the free trade area, and at the moment it cannot take full advantage of it, because it has been blocked in the Netherlands. Sometimes we say that it is not us, but the Union, that it was not the authorities of the Member States that took part in this decision, but some distant Union. In fact, without this decision by the Member States, none of these decisions taken here can be implemented, so we would like, on the one hand, respect for the principle of subsidiarity, but also, on the other hand, so that we can participate in those decisions that citizens reasonably adopt. So let us not focus on trifles, but on strategic decisions. The UK must take the next step: to implement Article 50, but also on the UK side, if it wants to benefit from the single market, there is also a safeguard of four freedoms. On the side of those who were in favour of Brexit, there is also the safeguarding of the rights of citizens of countries such as Poland. You can't call our citizens - and there are about 800,000 of them in the UK - rubbish. After all, it is also appalling. The issue of the agricultural crisis. This is also one of the great topics. It is good that the Council has taken up this issue of the crisis in the agricultural markets, because it is also an issue that is very worrying for citizens. Here together we can help each other, together in the Union, not individually.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL)
text: Blue card question. I would like to ask my colleague something. As is the case when a national government, which must have the support of Parliament, goes to Brussels and, as Prime Minister Monti said at the time, and declares: 'If I followed the opinion of the Italian National Parliament, I would not be able to decide jointly with my colleagues in the Union'. Should national governments ignore their parliaments in order to reach a European decision? It's a candid question I'm asking you.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – It seems to me that this cooperation between the European institutions and the Member States, but with national parliaments in particular, should be closer. We have seen this role of national parliaments in a real way in the Treaty of Lisbon. But it seems to me that this is not enough to understand together those expectations, which are between the Member States and the representatives elected by the citizens of the Member States in national parliaments and the European institutions, including the European Parliament. This debate needs to be really deepened in order to understand the essence of subsidiarity, in order to understand the essence also of the policies that we are taking in the name and for the benefit of the citizens of the European Union. Then we will get the desired effect.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: – Madam President, you have split British society in half; has profoundly divided its country by generations and territories; has jeopardized — perhaps irreversibly – the continuity of the United Kingdom as such; has awakened political cannibalism in its own party; has weakened the European Union and ended its political career, although deferred. This is the legacy of Mr Cameron's political adventurism and these are the first fruits of the Europhobics' first success. In the face of this, the European Council has dispatched the matter online and a half, with a timid applause dismissed Mr Cameron and called himself in for two and a half months to try to address the matter. This is not what we need. We need to get Article 50 up and running quickly and start negotiating for a new relationship between the UK and the European Union. We need the European Commission to lead this negotiation and not fall into the hands of governments bilaterally. We need a good agreement, satisfactory for both sides, but it cannot be that the one who leaves will maintain the advantages of those who are left without making any of the commitments. We need predictability and clarity, not confusion. Mr Juncker said in his speech that the truth will not come out of paraphrase or repetition and I remind him of what the philosopher Bacon said, by the way, British: "Truth arises more easily from error than from confusion." And right now we're in a confusing phase. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I have been a clear supporter of The United Kingdom remaining in the European Union and I wish the European Union and the United Kingdom a good relationship. And why do you, Mr President, propose a policy of demonstrating strength, of putting pressure on The United Kingdom to notify the will to leave the European Union very quickly? After all, this is irresponsible from the point of view of responsibility for Europe, and bacon certainly would not be on your advice.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Ujazdowski, yes, I believe that irresponsibility comes from those who have set in motion this diabolical process, but in any case I have not said in my speech that we should not reach a good agreement with good relations: I stressed that this cannot be at the expense of the European Union.  It is demonstrated by this referendum that we can get out, but now it remains to be shown that the 27 of us can and must move forward, and that is what needs to be done.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for In divorce law, there is the principle of disruption: both spouses bear responsibility for the fact that a marriage is broken or that it is not. I would like to put the question to the President of the Commission: where is the real responsibility of the European Commission and the European Union for the disruption of the relationship between the EU and the United Kingdom? There is a lot of talk about what the British have now made the wrong decision, who is to blame and who has spread lies and things like that. But who, Mr Juncker, bears responsibility for the state of the European Union, which is so deplorable that even Mr Verhofstadt suddenly says: 'We urgently need EU reform'? Mr Juncker, I have not heard anything from your speech that somehow indicates your political responsibility, but I would like you to take a position on this. With your vision of Europe, which has been rejected by the British and which is also rejected by many other people in Europe, are you still the right man to lead the European Commission? Or should you not draw the consequences, stand by your political responsibility and resign? (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: the blue card. - I would like to ask one question. For seven years, I have had to be in this Parliament and watch the anti-Eurosceptics all their behaviour, and today I also have to say that they are very strangely upset and lost. How do you think they honestly did not understand and did not expect, or whether they only pretended that there are certain rules in the world, that no one will allow products into their market, because these are additional jobs and so on. And now with that bad Europe, they want to make friends very sincerely, communicate and sell their goods. As? What do you think they really honestly did?

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure.  I am not speaking for the Eurosceptics here, but I myself take a critical view of the development of the European Union. And I am not only sad denying the outcome of the British referendum, although I regret it. However, I also see it as an opportunity to reform the European Union. And what I regret is that, although I hear from many quarters in this House that this reform is necessary, no majority group, including the European Council, has any concrete ideas about how to reform the European Union. These concrete ideas – more sovereignty for the nation states, a free European Union – do indeed come from the Eurosceptics, and I am proud of that.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I wanted to speak to the 52% but I am afraid that probably they have already resigned by now, so I have to skip that part and say the following: the outcome of the referendum is clear. We need to accept it and I think that whether Johnson did this, Farage did that, or whatever, they will be held responsible. It is none of our business. We have no influence. Also, the UK will have less and less influence on how the EU will evolve and one day it will have zero influence. I do regret it, but it is a matter of fact. We need to have a good agreement, but I am still waiting for the message. What is it? We hear of a free-trade agreement, we have the internal market and the two things are different: free trade is free trade and the internal market is the internal market. Full freedoms with the acquis. I think that this needs very much to be clarified, because we, the EU, have issues at stake. One remark concerns the European Council. We have now a lot of thoughts. We have got blame towards the Commission. The European Council leaders clearly had no responsibility. We are, here again, intergovernmentalism, federalism, whatever. We do not see a message, we do not see a signal, we do not see a direction, we do not see the issues that are on the table:  five, six imminent; five, 10 less imminent for the future. The conclusions, the resolutions of those. Some of them may lead to more integration; some less. That debate is the debate of the past. That discourse belongs in the past. We need the issues and here we need the solutions. We need quick resolution and quick implementation. That is what the European Council is for, and I think that this is what we expect. Of course, the Commission has to play this role. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Vicky Ford (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – In the past few weeks I must have spoken to thousands of voters in the UK. Those who voted remain voted for economic and political stability and recognise that there have been many mutual benefits from working together. Those who voted leave did so because they felt the EU was out of touch and undemocratic; they were concerned about the five presidents making decisions that they felt they were not in contact with. They saw the unemployment on the edges of the euro and were scared. They were fearful about migration. They won, and we need to listen to them. I hope we can have a mutually beneficial agreement for the long term, but we need to take time. So please, will you be calm. Take time.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – The question was directed at me, but I am calm and I am one of the strongest advocates of an ever-closer relationship between the UK and the EU. But two things have to be said. The first is that we need to understand what the UK really wants and I am getting mixed messages on that, so I am really at a loss. The closer the relationship the better, but it has to be balanced. The second issue is reform. We are now all reformists, we all speak of reforms, but this is what we really need. I mean we need a change but we need concrete proposals. We cannot be debating a European Border and Coast Guard for a year. I am sorry, but this is political impotence.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I speak directly to Presidents Tusk, Juncker and Schulz. Brexit will damage the North of Ireland more than it will damage anywhere else, and if anyone tells you otherwise, they are living in cloud—cuckoo-land. We have farmers, SMEs, women’s groups, the community and voluntary sector, universities, foreign direct investment, construction workers and 23 000 cross-border workers and students who cross the border every day. Brexit will turn the North into an economic basket case: 1.2 billion worth of trade every week across Ireland.  The Democratic Unionist Party’s Leave campaign was reckless and it was wrong, and the political football was set up in order to get stronger links with Britain, harder borders and damage the all-Ireland economy. I say to you: the people of the North of Ireland voted to remain, and they want that accepted and to be respected.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, during the referendum campaign, I argued that the European Union has played a vital role in underpinning stability and democracy across our continent. We should not take our democratic rights for granted and I am shocked by the instability and divisions that the vote to leave, and the campaign itself, have caused in my country. Many of those who voted for the UK to leave the EU did so for principled reasons, some of which I agree with, but I think it would be dangerously politically naive to ignore the fact that, within the current wave of inarticulate hostility against the European Union, there are forces whose intention is not to reform our institutions, but to undermine democracy itself. As a result of the vote to leave the EU, my country is left without a government or opposition and with a frightening increase in the number of racist attacks. I have no doubt that we will return to a state of stable democratic governance but, in the meantime, I offer some reassurance to those who are unsettled by recent developments. As individuals, please wear the safety pin, to show that we stand together against the tiny minority of racists, whether you voted to leave or to remain. As Greens, we will fight to ensure that EU citizens already living in the UK will be allowed to stay and we insist that they are treated respectfully. We will also do our utmost to achieve an electoral system in which votes are translated into seats fairly, so that nobody feels their voice is unheard and politicians act as true representatives. Finally, we will ensure that our decision to leave the EU is not used as an excuse to launch a race to the bottom in terms of environmental standards, taxation and workers’ rights.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Richard Corbett (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – You were right to point out that not all leave voters are racist. Of course not. Do you agree, nonetheless, that most racists did vote leave and the leave campaign organisers went after that vote with some notorious posters seeking to get support from the extremes on the right wing fringe?

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – I do agree that there was some entirely reprehensible language used about other Europeans and this has led to racist attacks against people in my country. I do think that came from one side. I think there was a mobilisation of racism by some elements of the Leave campaign. I also believe it revealed how thin the veneer of civilization is in all our communities and how we must all stand up against racism and fascism as soon as we see it and give it absolutely no houseroom.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, please be aware of one thing, regardless of your political parties. The British referendum has given people hope that democracy is not yet lost, that the vote can make a difference. Nigel Farage, whether you like him or not, has given people hope that an ordinary man not involved in the brotherhood of ruling parties can change the course of history and this rigid institution from the bottom up. Although Farage is not in the British Parliament, he can force his country into independence by force of speech, by force of argument. And for that, he deserves credit. And I understand that your swearing is actually a sign of that appreciation. So, Nigel, thank you, you have given us hope, and that is why we will lead the czexit movement in the Czech Republic so that we have a safe, prosperous and free Czech Republic willingly cooperating with other peoples of Europe.

name: Marcel de Graaff (ENF).
text: – This EU, this evil Union must be broken off. It is a Union that cannot reform itself.  The elite that governs this Union has made a mess of it and is increasingly turning against the peoples of Europe. Nowhere is the distaste for democracy as evident in the call for referendums. The Ukraine referendum, the Brexit referendum, the referendum in France and the Netherlands on the EU constitution, it is clarion call that this evil Union must stop. They are hard evidence that this evil Union no longer has any democratic legitimacy.  I want an orderly dismantling of the EU before it is too late, before people after nation unleashes a democratic revolution and rejects it. That is why I am calling on Mr Juncker again: step up! Now make way for a liquidator who can liquidate the estate.  [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: "blue card" question. Mr De Graaff, I am ashamed in your place that you are so afraid to say here: I want to tear this Europe down. You will eventually do the same as Mr Farage: when the time comes, you will leave the sinking ship!  How do you think you can cope with the challenges as a country alone, the asylum and migration crisis, defence? The eurobarometer makes it very clear that our citizens want a better, a different Europe! Please have your opinion.

name: Marcel de Graaff (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. – Apparently Mrs Vautman's clairvoyant has gifts about what I will do. I'm not going to go into that, that's up to her. I do not know that crystal ball, but I do know that before we had this European Union, things did not go badly in Europe at all. We had no financial crisis, no banking crisis, no migration crisis. Should I continue? In this respect, I look forward to cooperation between European countries, economic cooperation as we knew it, but without this politically monstrous overhead on top of it.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Tusk, what did you actually do at the meeting? We have heard here today that the 27 states are moving closer together, and that NATO, which is not continental, is to be more closely involved. The only concrete thing about the meeting was that you spoke of it, there are now only 50 illegal border crossings instead of the previous 7000 a day. But that is not your merit, that is the merit of the nation states, which have single-handedly restored border security. Why do you say nothing about the restoration of the external borders of Schengen, why nothing about the redistribution and repatriation of migrants? Why do you say nothing about the implementation of the quota system, nothing about CETA and TTIP, nothing about activating finances for the many EU decisions that have still not been implemented? Why do you say nothing about the main problem of youth unemployment and unemployment throughout Europe? It is precisely in your model countries, Portugal and Greece, that unemployment is greatest.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: Madam President, I regret to see that in preparing for the consequences of a Brexit, our three institutions have been seriously failing. In political life, there are unpredictable events and we have not missed them, but there are also predictable events. There was a chance, or rather a risk, of two that the British referendum would lead to Brexit. We had a duty to prepare for this to deal with the many problems posed to each of our institutions by the departure of a Member State. Some of us have proposed it, to no avail. So today we have to deal hotly, emotionally, with problems that are very delicate, because they concern people, colleagues, friends. Example: Can we find ourselves in a situation where a family member would chair family reunions? Can we accept that a European law, which will not apply to the country leaving us, should be adopted by a majority obtained by the representatives of that country against a minority of countries to which the law will apply? What is the legitimacy of a Commissioner appointed by the country leaving the Union? Jonathan Hill responded with great elegance, but he will have a successor. And finally, we leave the decision to the personal conscience of each of the interested parties. It's very unpleasant for them and it's unpleasant for us. What about the civil servants? 1,900 British agents work in our institutions. They obviously keep their place with us. But what will be their future? Can they be promoted to positions that they would only occupy for a few months? They have legitimate rights, but so do their colleagues and, of course, it is the interest of the Union that must prevail. It is urgent that our three institutions agree to find a common answer to these questions, and it is up to us, without waiting for the decisions that depend on London.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – The European Union is not business as usual today and we are all aware of this, that change is necessary. I must say that, after a long time, I am pleased with the unity and, above all, the intransigence that European leaders have shown in the final decision that the UK leaves us. We have informed the British people that, we are sorry, but this time there will be no additional British rebates. There is no way back, and cameron should take responsibility in front of the people. Or otherwise: the cake can be whole or started, but it can't be both at the same time. We now fear that the referendum wave will engulf another member. Why are we afraid? Because we are aware that part of the responsibility for British cuisine is also in the past conduct of the European Union. We know, and it's been a long time since we've been here, what's been wrong. I therefore propose that we stop discussing so much at the principle level: we should, we should, should – and preferably in a back. People are fed up with this and fed up and don't want to listen to us anymore. Let us not only discuss crisis topics or the conclusions of the previous Council, but let us prepare for the future. I personally propose three urgent points: the immediate unfolding of plans and the consideration of citizens' votes where they have already clearly expressed it (e.g. the right to water, the cessation of secret negotiations on trade agreements); – a pan-European debate with citizens, where concrete proposals will enable them to co-shape the union's future institutional structure and set out the content relevant to their daily lives; and perhaps – the possibility of co-decision for young people, perhaps at the age of 16 (at least for the European elections) if we want young people to participate. Not until tomorrow, let us start today to take completely concrete steps towards the path of the future.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: – For the first time in its history, the European Union will be shrinking The British voted. The results were clear: they want out. I will say even more: I also understand why they want to leave. This European Union has become a symbol of crisis. We had the euro crisis. We had the security crisis. We have the asylum crisis. The British referendum was therefore a wake-up call.  Only I note that many on the European continent are still sleeping. We have just heard Mr Verhofstadt, for example. The referendum may have been an alarm signal for him, was an alarm clock, but in the meantime he has already pressed the snooze button. And he is already dreaming of his European taxes, of his European government, of his European transfers, of his European superstate. These euro-federalists still have not understood. This debate should be about tackling migration, about increasing security. It has to be about identity, about working together with respect for sovereignty, and these are the ideas that we need to debate here. These are also the ideas and common sense that Mr Tusk should bring to the European table.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, reading the Council conclusions one may think: 'What world do you live in in the Council?' A half-line for brexit and the word "refugees" has disappeared, but not the problem. Hungary has just announced a referendum in October on the relocation of refugees, that is, one more storm. The Council is naked, Mr Tusk. National selfishness and fear of populism have led the Council to paralysis. Mr Verhofstadt has said that either the European Union changes, or it will sink. I will specify: either the Council changes, or the European Union will sink and all nations will, piece by piece.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the Brexit vote has set the alarm bells ringing across Europe but the message from the British people is not just for their own government. It is for the EU, for the Council, for the Commission and for you, Mr Juncker, especially. It is good to see you are listening. The EC that we joined with Britain back in 1973 was a worthy project, bringing peace and prosperity to Europe. The EU, with the euro to the fore, is a catastrophe undoing all that good. Look at how this so—called Union is treating Ireland. We were blackmailed and bullied into taking on debt that was not ours and given loans to the tune of EUR 67.5 billion to bail out the European banks. Most of our own banks were already dead, zombies. As a direct result of that, we are now in the process of borrowing money to destroy EUR 2 billion last year alone. Look at what the EU and its euro did to Greece, to Spain, to Portugal and to Italy. There is a saying, Mr Juncker, ‘don’t hold on to a mistake just because you spent a long time making it’. I say here: undo this union, starting with Lisbon and Nice, or else, Mr Juncker, ask not for whom that bells tolls. It tolls for you. Listen for a change.

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Mr Tusk, we are at a time when Europe is putting its very survival at stake. You come after a European Council, and three-quarters of your speech is devoted to the issue of economic migrants - hardly a word about Brexit. You are acting directly, in reality, as the gravedigger of this Europe. Intergovernmental logic has failed and continues to fail. You made corridor agreements with Mr Cameron, and we saw where that took us. So please, for the good of Europe, let the Commission do it, let the European Parliament do it for these negotiations. I do trust those who defend the general European interest, not the interests of the States. Mr Monnet said: "Europe is there to connect people, not to coalesce states." Think. I'll just finish. Mr Juncker, I trust your will to get Europe out of this crisis and defend the 27 against the uk's interests alone. Just a word to ponder: Mr. Einstein said - I know you have a sense of humour - that madness is about hoping, by always doing the same things, to get another result. Think about that and try to get out of the public policies that we are currently implementing.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear from today's debate that there is a desire to cut the cord that still binds us to the United Kingdom as soon as possible, waving the usual excuse of market uncertainty that would penalise us all, the usual excuse of the markets to hide the only real truth that you really care about: to hope that the United Kingdom will go to the bottom of Brexit as a lesson to every other Member State that comes to mind to do the same.  However, it would be enough to admit one's faults: as when it was decided to bail out the banks at the expense of the citizens without launching a real reform of the banking and financial system; as when the shameful austerity policies were applied but the migrant crisis could not be resolved; as when we allowed the minimum levels of health care not to be guaranteed in Greece either!  Someone in here says we need more Europe, someone else says we need less Europe. We say that it takes different and to have it the only way is for people like Merkel, Hollande, Renzi, Juncker and Tusk to all go home.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. A few clarifications: the first thing that is important to me is the inviolability of democratic popular decisions. How can you come up with the idea of undermining a democratically judged judgment of the British people here, not wanting to acknowledge it or, as Elmar Brok has done, saying that it would only be advisory. By no means. It is not consultative, it is decisive. Even if 10,000 are now taking to the streets and shedding crocodile tears for Britain to make its way out of the European Union here, you note that more than 17 million Britons voted to leave. If you are a democrat, you have to take note of that. The second thing I would like to give you here is not to meet the British with resentment or with a desire for revenge. No, the British are part of the European family of nations. The British will remain, and now we have to identify a treaty at bilateral and multilateral level that will benefit the citizens on both sides. The last thing: Don't learn the wrong lessons. Now not, as Schulz is doing here, to call for a European central government or, as Juncker does, TTIP and CETA past parliaments. Give back rights to parliaments and the Member States, then European cooperation will have a future.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we cannot pretend that nothing has happened: brexit is very serious. We cannot go forward and start the European accelerator.  The UK and Europe are now projects that will walk in parallel. The negotiation that opens must be transparent and fast. We cannot give the feeling that we are unable to make difficult decisions with a very slow negotiation, with a very long negotiation. A bureaucratic negotiation would confirm all the arguments of brexit. We cannot allow the UK to use this negotiation to obtain better conditions with which to hold another referendum, or better conditions outside the European Union than within the European Union.  The future of the European Union is not a replica of the United Kingdom. That is why more Europe is not yet the answer: more Europeanism is the answer. Without Europeanism there is no Europe, as without patriotism there is no homeland.  We cannot accept that the British were lied to during the referendum campaign; but it is true, too, that we were silent during the referendum campaign. The Council, the Commission and Parliament did not say anything to the British during the election campaign.  There is no divorce in which the blame is 100 percent of one of the parties. In this case, the European Union will also have to accept its share of responsibility.  We cannot help but do self-criticism: governments that use Europe to justify unpopular decisions fail and institutions fail when they make cruel decisions without looking into the eyes of Europeans.  We must make the UK the last to leave the European Union, not the first, and for that what we have to build is a better Europe, which in my opinion is a Europe with a heart.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Brexit has been a decision of the British people. We regret this, but our work is primarily focused on the people who are becoming increasingly sceptical about what we are doing in the European Union. What makes these people so dissatisfied? It is not primarily about institutions, it is about content. I am asked: 'Where is the financial transaction tax that we all talked about after the big banking crash?' I am asked: 'Where are the jobs in Greece for young people, or do you still think that saving is enough?' I am asked, "Are you really not able to accommodate one or two million refugees together and take care of them?" I am asked: 'What are you actually doing to address the causes of this flight? Why do you create a development cooperation fund and then not pay in? When will you finally stop the cheap exports to Africa that make it so difficult to run there?" That's what the people who talk to me are all about. We are certainly not short of good ideas, but there is a lack of implementation– for the most part at least. As a rule, this is not the commission's fault, it is not usually Parliament's fault. Now the German Finance Minister gave an interesting interview last Sunday. He says, among other things, that the institutions should take the initiative in solving these problems, and if they do not succeed, we will solve these problems outside the institutions between governments. However, we know very well that most of the concrete proposals in the backrooms of the Councils have been smashed by the Member States and not by this Commission and not by this Parliament. And that is why this is a mistake that we must not follow.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Madam President, can I say, first of all, that now is not a time for recrimination? As Mr Juncker said, where is the plan? The truth is they never expected to win, and the truth is, neither London nor Brussels had a plan, has a plan, and they now have to go and construct that plan.  While Northern Ireland voted to remain within the European Union, I have to say I respect the United Kingdom as a whole, as a nation-state. We stand by that. There is no question of anything else for Northern Ireland, difficult though it will be for us. The UK decision must, in my opinion, be respected. There will be many twists and turns on the rocky road ahead that we now have to travel. I have to say to you, Mr Tusk, that you have a massive responsible role to play here. Mr Juncker, to date, your comments and actions have not been helpful and, Sir, you are part of the problem and maybe not part of the solution. Can I say to this House that it was a massive mistake to send David Cameron back to fight the referendum with one hand tied behind his back? Do not make that mistake again.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE).
text: Madam President, the cowardly abandonment of the Brexit leaders, refusing to face the situation they themselves created, speaks volumes about the significant threats now facing Britain. But I mean that there are also significant risks that threaten those who remain - risks of crime, of stalemate, of break-up - if we are not able to change what needs to be changed, to take initiatives, to rethink Europe, its objectives, its rules and its functioning. What the peoples of Europe expect is a vision, it is a perspective, not just that of the market, because we do not give life to the market, but that of a political Europe, effective, useful, refocused on the essential, that of a democratic Europe, in which citizens will finally be involved in the decisions that are taken on their behalf. It is to this awareness that I call on all European leaders, before it is too late. There's a real urgency.

name: Rina Ronja Kari (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President! The British people have resigned. It may not be as nice or equally pleasant for everyone, but they have done so. In particular, we should note that it is the most disadvantaged groups that have said stop. They think the price is too high. They are also experiencing massive problems of social dumping, for example. Not because workers come in from other EU countries, but because companies use the EU and the EU's single market to squeeze pay and working conditions. They play the workers off against each other. But we must recognise the British elections. They want to leave the EU, but they also want to work together and continue to trade. Of course, we must ensure a good and orderly exit and ensure that no one is isolated, but that we cooperate. There is also cooperation outside the EU. And then we have to look at the fact that the citizens of other EU countries should also have the right to be heard. We should not be afraid of the voice of the citizens, but instead listen to it, and it is high time to ask them.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (ENF).
text: – Madam President, President Tusk, President Juncker, as you can see, these debates are almost taken down by the two institutions you lead. Everyone, regardless of their party and their political group, says that we need a reform of the European Union. Otherwise, the European Union, as it was conceived, will be destroyed. I hope today will be the last time you do not take into account what all the political groups have said here. Otherwise, the Council debated chronic issues of migration, stimulating economic growth, improving security at European Union level. All these problems have somehow become routine and, frankly, I don't expect spectacular action. The European Union is, unfortunately, experiencing an acute identity crisis. We are not in a position to make long-term forecasts, but we can say that the leaders of the European Union cannot present to the citizens at the moment a project that unites European nations through attractiveness and feasibility.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Brexit: this result was a shock. Now, however, we need clarity and foresight. Of course, the referendum is not selective. 'No' is 'no' and there can therefore be no à la carte single market: those who want free access to the market, as has been said, must respect the four freedoms, including freedom of movement. Having said that, however, our problems are the same because this Europe is in the middle of a ford, with incomplete integration but sufficient to lead to considerable interdependence and in the middle of the ford, as we know, you suffer. We must have the courage to get out of the ford quickly.  Eurobarometer tells us that the citizens want change above all. Why, how do they see this Europe? How is it perceived? They see it weakened by the economic crisis, shaken by the massive migratory phenomenon, afraid of terrorism, a spectacular and not a protagonist of what is happening in the world, even when it happens in neighbouring geographical areas. We must change what needs to be changed in order to return to growth and guarantee social well-being for Europeans. Peace and prosperity were the promises of this Europe and we must strengthen the political dimension in order to prevent technical drift. That is why we need strong initiatives; we must relaunch the dream of the founding fathers on a new and concrete basis. But as an Italian, dear President Tusk, let me tell you, I am pleased with the results on the Eastern Mediterranean, even though the Central Mediterranean is waiting for equally rapid, rapid and definitive responses, if not this is an image of an asymmetrical Europe. And a ruling class, if there is one, that loves the European dream, can no longer afford it thanks.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the way to deal with the UK after the British referendum has already been clearly defined by both Parliament and the European Council so we are here today to discuss the more general implications of the Brexit in terms of a European direction. The starting point is the concern expressed by European citizens when they ask how we can get control of our lives, and in fact there is a choice to be made about this. The choice I see is clear: it should be based on better European solutions because, in the face of larger migration flows, we cannot go back to national borders. We need instead to build up a real European border, to host refugees and to manage migration with the origin countries. In the face of the problems we have regarding global challenges, we cannot just play with our little economies. We need to build up a more effective European trade policy and global strategy; and, in the face of poor recovery and job creation, we need to make the best of the European scale. This means the single market and the eurozone, provided they are really able to deliver quality jobs and more economic and social convergence. So what we need is not to go back to national borders. What we need is better European solutions, and better European solutions can only be defined by the Community method, with the Commission proposing, the European Parliament discussing and then with ongoing interaction with the European Council, the Council and the national parliaments. Tomorrow the European Parliament will deliver an initial contribution to the road map which we need to define and implement.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR). –
text: The British leave and get all the blame. Group chairman Weber went further and said that it was all up to the populists. That shows the blindness that reigns here in the house. Let Mr Weber talk to a German lorry driver who is sitting on the sofa at home because an Estonian colleague is now doing his job for a quarter of the price. Let him talk to a fisherman who is now obliged to bring all the fish to the smallest stamp on land. And what happens to that fish? It is then ground into a commoner. And that fisherman has extra costs!  The distaste for Europe is not just down to the populists. What's next? Self-reflection and humility, that's what it's all about. Let the next summit be held in a monastery so that everyone thinks and wonders: what was my part in this disaster? Because if the European house is built in full, then others will follow, and it will not just be the British who will be alone. Then there will be more referendums. It's renovating or destruction.  Never waste a good crisis.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to express my full agreement with the main lines of President Schulz's speech at last week's summit. To decide to leave is to leave, and to stay means to really bet on unlocking the full potential of our Union to economic relaunch, employment and investment and to really move towards a political union that my party, the Basque Nationalist Party, supports since the first decades of the twentieth century, as you can see in this poster, which is from 1933 (she showed an electronic tablet with the image of a poster) , or checking the role played by our first Lehendakari in the new international teams or at the Hague Congress in 1948. This week we have heard many reproaches from Europe for the decisions taken in the face of our great crises. What was tremendous is that those who formulated them were the same ones who take them from the Council, States that hide their fears and evade their responsibilities by pointing out one culprit: Europe. We need to change attitudes and the best way to defend the interests of one state or another here is to assume that what is good for that common project is good for all its members.

name: György Schöpflin (PPE).
text: – It is indisputable that the referendum in Britain is primarily about British domestic political circumstances, but it would be a mistake to narrow the result of the vote to the British process. The negative result also gave opinions to Brussels, the European Union and the exercise of power and power accumulated in Brussels. Let's accept that there is no perfect administration, to err is human. But that does not mean that those who exercise power in Brussels have not made any more serious mistakes. Restrictive economic policies, over-regulation and, most recently, the management of migration and immigration all point to a one-sided position of power. Looking back at the past few years, it looks like the integration process has lost its way somewhere. If a closer bilateral relationship between the Union and its citizens is not established, this growing distance will eventually lead to an even greater crisis than it is now.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr Tusk, Mr President Juncker, ladies and gentlemen, the British have spoken and have decided to leave the Union. If we regret this decision, it is a must and must be respected by all. We must draw the consequences and approach this departure with reason and general interest as compasses. We have, of course, a historical responsibility, that of restoring meaning, of building a new European horizon that is not reduced to the market. The coming months will be devoted to this re-foundation, I hope. But we also have immediate responsibilities, including the fiscal consequences of the UK's departure. The Commission must quickly assess the budgetary implications of the departure of our British friends, with the question of its cheque and that of rebates, without waiting for the activation of Article 50. We need to prepare the budgetary scenarios that will be used in the negotiations. Parliament must be informed in real time and be fully involved in this work throughout the proceedings. But, regardless of these UK exit negotiations, these warning shots demonstrate our inadequacies and, first of all, our budget, "budget rump", without ambition, not really serious and not really sincere. Not really serious because we cannot go on any longer with a budget that relies almost exclusively on the contributions of the Member States, which lead us to budget shortages. We need to open up the process of setting up our own resources. Not really sincere: youth unemployment, the migration and refugee crisis, COP 21, agricultural crises, internal security, growth, employment and territorial and social cohesion, all these priorities are known and shared by all and, yet, the means are not there. The European Union needs a budget that lives up to its ambitions. If we don't do that, it will be piece-by-piece disintegration.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR).
