text: – I am surprised by the great concern of a number of European Union leaders about democracy in the United Kingdom. There is an urgent need for Brexit and the start of the Article 50 negotiations. Where were these leaders when France voted against the Constitutional Treaty of the European Union, which many countries had already ratified at the time? Noone then said that we would continue to build the new Europe, but France and the Netherlands can go out. Why is it different now? Because there is a clear desire to split, for example, the City's financial pie in favour of Paris or other cities on the other side of the English Channel and, in other words, to take everything most valuable and fast from the fallen. This is even evidenced by the fight against Commissioner J. L. B. the division of Hill's portfolio into the European Commission, which does not indicate a Community approach. And those left-wing politicians who are now urging a referendum on a whole Europe that will cause problems for the constitutions of a Member State, with the same aim, to get a genuine European government, instead they will receive a collapsed, fragmented European Union. Don't do it!

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE).
text: Madam President, once it is not customary, it will have taken critical days like these for Europe to be taken into account in national public spaces. For 27 Member States, the result of the British referendum is a wake-up call. For the UK, it is a live bullet, and the resulting injuries are already visible. Those who have promised more sovereignty, who have built their arguments on the theme of a technocratic Europe, are now proving to be pale democrats who are powerless and irresponsible about the fate of their country. But as the Council has made clear in its conclusions, Europe faces many other challenges - in terms of migration, economics and security - which we cannot fall further behind. To remain united is to work towards the construction of the Union of Citizens, of a stronger democratic union. We cannot do this without responding to what people are concerned about on a daily basis. Two points on Brexit: first, the red line that has already been drawn by the presidents of the European institutions will have to be respected, regardless of the agreement reached with the United Kingdom: no discounts on the conditions for access to the single market, especially the four freedoms, including and in particular the free movement of people. Equal treatment is a necessary basis for a true union of citizens. Secondly, it is up to us pro-Europeans, to make this crisis an opportunity and, in this context, beware of the reflex of retreating into old methods. Yes, we need leadership, yes, we have fundamentals, but let us not create divisions between ourselves where there are none. The heart of Europe beats in every citizen who believes in Europe and peace, democracy and tolerance, whether in Berlin or Paris, Sofia or Bucharest.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: Brexit victory is bad news for Europe and bad news for the UK. The first consequences are already visible: the economic downturn, the political chaos, and, of course, the disillusionment, the realisation that we made the wrong decision. But there's something else we need to talk about. It's about the brexit victory being the result of lies, fear-monetising, xenophobia. Brexit leaders have grossly, vilely deceived the electorate. And now, when they have achieved their goal, led the UK to a dead end, they are now backing down. Of course, It is easier for Mr Farage to sit here than to look the duped electorate in the eye. But this referendum is also a testimony to the fact that populist, anti-European forces have no real arguments. They can only win if people give credence to their lies, their loud but unfounded promises. Today we all need to know: Europe has no alternative! All those who play around with the idea of quitting after Brexit are the biggest enemies of their own country. Today, Europe faces challenges and conflicts that cannot be resolved within the framework of the Member States. We do not need a stupid policy of locking up, fences, but responsibility, common solutions, a common European policy. The experience of the referendum is that indecision, concessions, equivocation do not stop populist lying, anti-Europeanism.  Today I think we have a three-way. On the one hand, the exit process must be carried out in such a way that European core values and principles cannot be discussed. On the other hand, we must fight populism and anti-Europeanism much more decisively and more committedly than before. Thirdly, we must take this opportunity to take decisive action to complete the European project, a European Union with a strong and federal basis.

name: Николай Бареков (ECR).
text: – Mr Juncker, we have listened to empty talk from your pets in the centre of the hall. The bell in Europe has been ringing for a long time, but you were playing deaf. Well, the English put the megaphone in front of the Brexit bell, and now you understand that this European formula is really over. We need reforms, not burying heads in the sand like ostriches. Don't waste your time with pointless and petty bureaucratic setbacks. Where's your action plan?  The problem comes from the fact that the European Union is the sum of some rich and other very poor countries that are corrupt at the same time. England and Bulgaria are on both sides of the funnel. One gets more, the others give more. The result is zero, since both peoples are desperate and do not care about the free movement of goods and capital.  The European Union is a bureaucratic machine that does not like change. The Bulgarian political elite was corrupt before membership in Europe, but now it is dozens of times more corrupt and richer with the huge funds you poured into Bulgaria and they were massively robbed by several people and the oligarchy. Europe has only one time, Mr Juncker, change or death.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it has been a really difficult and complicated week. We have a lot of things ahead, and obviously there is a slightly different agenda for our British friends than for our group of 27 if the UK decides to leave. It will take time to sort things out. I call for us to stay calm and behave correctly in the meantime and to respect the Treaty. Our colleague from UKIP has said that he is looking for a relationship on trade like that of the US, China or Russia. If this is so, he should bear in mind that, when we negotiate such treaties, we are strongly defending the interests of European citizens and not the interests of our counterparts. There are many issues on which Europe can be made better for our citizens and these should be our priorities. I am very happy that the Council was actually debating some of these issues. Let me stress just a few of them. A sustainable economic policy is a precondition for economic growth, and jobs and growth are our key priorities. That is why the European Semester recommendations should be respected. We should improve the functionality of the single market, for example in the digital field and in services. Lastly, let me say that I appreciate the progress made in the area of taxation, thanks to the ability of the Council to find common ground.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, faced with Brexit and other evidence of the removal of citizens from the European project, a start is required, the abandonment of ultra-liberal austerity, a refounding path for the Union. Instead, the Council is in denial of reality. It seems that there are no more asylum duties, human rights, not even refugees, have evaporated, thanks to the EU-Turkey negotiation, replicated with oppressive African regimes.  The focus of the Council's conclusions is on the return of migrants and border control. The Council thus lets the xenophobic far right make the agenda, just as Dr Schäuble lets intergovernmental drift, now instigating unfair and immoral sanctions against Portugal and Spain. A Dr Schäuble, Dr Strangelove, who could end up ruining the Union if the Council and the Commission do not agree and quickly chill their way.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, I would first like to say that, of course, as Portuguese, Portugal is the country with the oldest Treaty of alliance and cooperation with the United Kingdom. It dates from 1386. Of course this was a decision seen with great apprehension.  I must, however, say that we must be shaded on some principles. The first principle is that we should give the United Kingdom some time to organise its proposal since, incomprehensibly, it had nothing prepared, and indeed, all those who had responsibility on leaving have fled the ground. The second idea, which I think is very important, is to be very firm with the UNITED KINGDOM: if you want access to the single market you have to fulfil the four freedoms, if you want another kind of agreement you will have another kind of agreement, but you certainly will not have a better situation than you had today. This is absolutely essential to maintain this principle. And thirdly, I think it is essential to maintain the best possible relations, the best possible deal with the UK.  Obviously we look at the British with great, say, sense of common belonging. We feel that we belong to the same civilization and to the same community, so we have every interest in having a good deal with the British. Now it cannot be at the expense of these principles. Finally, I would like to urge the Member States, and in particular the governments and the Council, to understand important progress in terms of integration into the Union, because that is the best response we can give, in terms of globalisation, to this sad news we had on 23 June.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Madam President, those of us who feel Europe in our souls are hurt to see when we are. With respect, as could not be otherwise, to the decision of British citizenship, we are free to show our concern, but also to be firm in the decisions we have to make at the moment. Of course, Europe must change, of course there is a large part of the citizenship that today feels let down, but the solution cannot be an a la carte Europe, where everyone decides how they want to be part of it, where only the particular benefits are shether and not the common well-being are shether they are solving. Freedom of movement of goods cannot be defended while rejecting the free movement of citizens. This Parliament's message must be resounding. The Union has to change, of course, but the solution cannot be to break with the values that made our project created: more common policies, a more social and inclusive Europe, leaving behind selfishness. Together. United in diversity.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Politics is not a game, and so I demand more seriousness, more sincerity, more prudence and more determination. Europeans, let us be deceived, deceived, deprived of our future by the opponents of the EU, the nationalists, the culprits, the cowards, the deniers of the future, the populists. Let us stop letting them set the agenda. Let us finally stand up for the European ideals! Let us continue to build the House of European Union together! Politicians, let us stop blaming them! Let us stand by our responsibility for the future of Europe and our shared responsibility for the current state of affairs! Let us stop playing party political, tactical games at the expense of cohesion in the European Union! Today, populism only strengthens nationalism. Let us make the citizens involved! Let us not leave them alone with their worries, fears, questions and hopes! If we take citizens and their questions seriously, we must reach out to them sincerely, fight for European democracy and make the EU more effective, efficient, transparent and the spokesman for the continent in the world, better – we, the citizens of Europe.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Lessons learned from Brexit? The European Union was created as a common instrument of sovereign states to jointly create major challenges for all of us. But not only Mr Cameron is gambling with democracy and with the interests of countries.  Financial market crisis, unemployment, impending poverty – too many people no longer feel represented. The anger seems to be directed against the EU, but it is also directed against our governments and too often finds a valve in the rejection of refugees. Now finally show a clear edge? Misreporting. Legal tax avoidance, weakening social systems, building fences, outsourcing responsibility, development aid for preventing flight – we continue to refuse solidarity with people. Lessons learnt. Shortly before the holidays, the transfer is in danger. Stop gambling. Take responsibility.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: - Madam President, two topics have dominated this Council: one is migration, the other is Brexit. Speaking of migration, it is obvious, as Mr Tusk said, that with 7,000 migrants crossing the Greek-Turkish border daily, we have come to 50 today and it is obvious that the European response is the only solution.  Another topic is Brexit: I must express regret that this has happened, but at the same time I express my joy that the 27 states have agreed and stood resolutely in defence of a common Europe. It's something that pleases us, I believe we will continue to work together.  When it comes to Britain and their way of doing Brexit, I agree with those who say: "The EU is not the menu from which they will choose." If they want access to the single market, then they must respect all four freedoms including freedom of movement, which is one of Europe's basic freedoms. I believe that we will remain persistent in this and that we Europeans will resort to a new culture of responsibility for the future of Europe. I agree with all those who say that we have good regulations, but we need to start implementing the regulations, i.e. implementing them and we need to make sure that we know how to apply them and that our heads of state do not speak one thing at the European Council and the other when they come to national countries. I agree that Europe is the answer, I agree that there are myths about Europe as our Manfred Weber said, and these myths are that Europe is not democratic. Europe is democratic, it is the answer and we need to stay together, concentrate on growth and jobs, as you said and continue with the investment plan.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Madam President, I wanted the United Kingdom to be in Brexit and it is now in Brexit. I believe that, as a European institution, our responsibility is to deal with this matter as soon as possible and to reduce this uncertainty which leaves a doubt floating, a floating that undermines the foundations of any relaunch of the European project. It is in the interest of the British and the interests of the Twenty-seven. I am counting on you, both presidents, to do so. Mr President Donald Tusk, Mr President Jean-Claude Juncker, you are two of the five presidents who wrote a report on the future of the eurozone before Brexit. I hear some people say that after Brexit, we should avoid exacerbating the divisions in the European Union and therefore we cannot deal urgently with the eurozone issue. If you do not take care of it, there will be no more Europe because there will no longer be that absolute base that is an economic and monetary union around the euro. I look forward to swift proposals from you to revive and implement the proposals in the report of the five presidents, of which you are the authors.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – UK citizens have chosen their own path with a weak majority. We have to respect the decision. The economy shrunk immediately as markets reacted negatively. How will they react until the UK implements Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon? The economy doesn't like uncertainty, but it can't stand loneliness even more. However, now is the time to stand together and start working for a better Union. However, one thing is certain: no one can re žete the fruits of the European Union without respecting its values, principles and commitments. There is undoubtedly a time of self-reflexion before the European Union, although I am not a follower of the fact that every time there is a crisis... to ask about the relevance of community living. However, I believe that we will find a path to a better Union that should be large and effective in the great challenges and small and invisible in the small ones. Eurosceptics have smelled blood all over Europe since Brexit. But citizens realise that their cheap solutions to complex challenges are the wrong way to go. Even more so, positive sentiment or support for the Union has risen in most countries, which is a bad message for the protagonists of Brexit. Despite Brexit, we must pay particular attention to young UK citizens who are open and friendly to the Union.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D). Madam President, Euroscepticism has been part of the political reality in Britain from the outset, but this is a thing of the past. When a country leaves, this is a failure of all of us, but it is also a failure of the leadership of the European Union itself, which today, quite rightly, says that we need to change something. But what do we have to change? I often hear generalities, that we need to reorient the European Union, we need to redesign it.  But these are generalities. In my opinion, we will have to answer some excruciating questions and I am particularly addressing both Mr Tusk and Mr Juncker: how much credibility do we have if we want to tackle Euroscepticism in the other 27 Member States when we implement the banking Union, but the third pillar remains unclear when it will be implemented and is it about the bank guarantee? How much credibility do we have when we close an agreement with Turkey and Erdoğan, but are we silent in the face of Erdoğan's crimes against the Kurds and Cyprus?

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the United Kingdom has contributed strongly to the Europe of today, and for as long as the United Kingdom is a member of the European Union, it should be respected as such. We are a legal union and I hope that the Commission, as well as everybody else, will act accordingly. But looking at the United Kingdom today, I see a governmental crisis, a political crisis, a constitutional crisis, an economic crisis, and a financial crisis. Dear colleagues, it is not a very impressive success story – to put it mildly – and I wonder which other country would like to dive into that cause. There is, however, one thing that unites all the Brexiters: either they have resigned or they are still disoriented. They are united in one thing: they want to be as close to the internal market as possible, and the internal market would not have been possible without the European Union, so they are dreaming and hoping to be as close as possible to the internal market, because of its fundamental importance. They are giving up control over its development. In Swedish there is a phase which says: you sold the butter and lost the money.  Now we need to do the best thing and that is to avoid divisive conflicts. Be proud of what we have achieved, a reunited Europe, an internal market, a common policy on climate, energy, and the environment: that is what we are, that is a good delivery. We can do better, but that is up to politicians, not to the Union. But the Union is strong.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Few really expected Brexit. Many rejoiced and cheered, but many were dismayed and unsettled, and every day it is becoming more so because they see how they have been deceived and deceived, and that the brexiteers had no plan and simply made themselves out of the dust. Yes, it is a dramatic situation, with an uncertain outcome. But there is no reason to lose your nerve, no reason for schadenfreude and certainly not a reason to pay old bills. It is time for prudence and thoughtful action. Europe is not dead, as the Dutch Presidency's record shows. But it is time for fundamental reforms, that is the message of this referendum, it is time for more community Europe. First of all, however, the ball is in the UK's court. It has a responsibility to provide clarity and we cannot afford to be uncertain in this situation. Firstly, we need a quick and clear answer on the intention to leave. This is fair to the existing partners, but also to Scotland and Northern Ireland. Secondly, it must be clear to everyone that there can be no Europe a la carte. The single market means the free movement of people, and it is precisely the United Kingdom that has benefited from this. Thirdly, above all, the millions of EU citizens in the United Kingdom must not become victims of this crisis, the rise of xenophobic attacks is worrying, and people have a right to carry out their life plans, as do the millions of British expats in the European Union. We have a responsibility to ensure that in this crisis people are not played off against people and that a negative cycle is set in motion that we all do not want.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). Madam President, we fully and unconditionally respect the British referendum and we certainly regret BREXIT, but we will not eliminate the fact that BREXIT was the result of extreme populism, as well as many lies that were tested on the British people. Nevertheless, we must not ignore the fact that our own family, the European one, has and is facing too many problems, and we must be in favour of it in order to stop Euroscepticism.  However, I must note that there is no proper information and enlightenment about the work that the European Union is doing. The European Union cannot identify only with austerity, troikas and memoranda, when at the same time there are programmes important for young people, there is Horizon 2020, and the European Union every year distributes EUR 145 billion in various areas, and this work is being zeroed in and the Eurosceptics are effectively left to grind, as has been the case in Great Britain. Another major problem for us is bureaucracy. I am tired of hearing young people tell me that they are giving up trying to get money out of the European Union because there is bureaucracy, hearing the same from entrepreneurs, hearing the same from farmers. I see that, in recent times, my country has suffered two major disasters, one from fire and one from drought, and at the moment no one knows how we can get compensation. In conclusion, Madam President, I must say a big thank you and acknowledge the struggle that the European Commission and the President, Mr Juncker, are fighting to tackle the small and large problems, but also the President of the European Council, Mr Juncker. Tusk, because we really are devotees of the European idea and together we will fight for a better Europe.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, to the unjustified fears that the Brexit campaign has fuelled, Europe must give strong and concrete answers on social justice, fairness, youth unemployment and better management of migration. Migration is not a global problem but a global phenomenon and, as such, should not be solved or combated but managed in all its components. Reading in your conclusions that the success of a migration policy is measured in terms of returns and readmission only moves us away from an idea of common and global management that this Parliament voted on less than three months ago; but perhaps even more worrying is the reference to the model to be followed: the EU-Turkey agreement, thanks to which we remember that the crossings from Turkey to the Greek islands have now almost stopped! I call on the Commission to take back the true content of the external dimension of migration policy, including through the preparation of real development policies and public investment with the centrality of the person.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have only three observations to add. First, it was not a victory for Brexit as such. It was rather a victory of a campaign of disinformation and lies about the EU, which was presented in an absolutely distorted way, like a Loch Ness monster. The result, sadly, is more confusion. Actually it is a limbo. The country remains divided. But we cannot continue in the same style. We need to address the fears and uncertainties of millions of our citizens and provide clear answers to questions about their identity, cultural continuity, economic justice and defence.  Second, now it is especially crucial to keep together in the issues that remain and one of them is mutual defence. The UK continues to be our ally in NATO. The Council plan for accelerated practical cooperation with NATO is to be welcomed. In the new situation it is especially important to remain united in our common approaches toward Russian aggression in defending the credibility of our own values. Third, our best practical answer to the crisis is completing the digital single market. This means implementing, in two years’ time, the eGovernment Action Plan, which will reduce red tape in bringing these public services to citizens. Digital by default, digital cross-border and interoperability by default should become cornerstones of an open and connected Europe.

name: Peter Simon (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Verhofstadt was right to point out earlier in which areas the citizens of Europe expect us to offer them European solutions. But people see that these European solutions are not coming, and if we look at all these areas, these are the areas in which the Member States alone continue to have the power to act. It is important to us to point out that it is not Europe that is no longer getting things baked, but the Member States are not getting it. And anyone who calls for more Member State responsibility in this situation is calling for more bad medicine. Helmut Schmidt, speaking to us in his last speech to the Socialist Group here in the Brussels Parliament, told us that we MEPs must stand up, we should , literally – 'take the revolution against the Member States' because europe would be destroyed. I believe that we are entering the age of taking him at his word.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We heard from Prime Minister Cameron that the British referendum was a great victory for democracy. A few more such victories of democracy, and the achievements of several generations, which, after the disasters of the 20th century, built a European space without conflict, without wars, without borders and without national prejudice, can be ruined. A few more politicians such as brexit stars, with Nigel Farage at the helm, and it may be that dispersed and diversified Western democracies will be helpless in a global world that does not recognise our value system. Democracy wins when a political dispute serves to educate people about public affairs. But the triumph of populism, artificially aroused fears and prejudices, is hard to call a victory for democracy. The victims of this campaign were also Polish immigrants, who for the most part are going to work hard to multiply their belongings and work for the belongings of the British Isles. It must not be the case that they may be the victim of heinous incidents at the moment. Their interests must also be protected in their discussions with London. There will be no agreement on an open European market, on goods, on services and capital without an open English market for continental Europe, on the movement of labour, on job seekers.

name: Jo Leinen (S&D).
text: Mr President Juncker, President Tusk, I would like to thank Mr Juncker for his work on the We should also see the British referendum as an opportunity, an opportunity for a great debate with the public, the citizens about this Europe, about this European Union. We have to leave the national silos. The same thing is being talked about in Paris, in Berlin, in Rome, in Bratislava, even though we have the same problem. We urgently need European platforms for this European debate. The European Council in September is not enough. We must involve the national parliaments, the national governments, but also civil society. I still believe that we need a Convention, and I hope that this Parliament will also take action in this direction and exercise the right of initiative. We need a new consensus on where the journey is headed. For forty years, the mantra was peace. The new mantra is security, security in all relations, and that cannot be done with less Europe, not with an intergovernmental Europe, but only with a better, more effective Europe, with the Community method in the EU.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work and for his excellent work. Many speakers today in the debate following the British referendum have stressed that we need reforms, that there must be no 'continued'. But opinions on what these reforms should look like vary widely. Some want more powers for the Commission, others less, others are calling for powers to be shifted back to the nation states. I always wonder what people expect in our individual Member States. All I can say is that my people at home want to live in safety and have a job. What we all have to do is do just that: to give them that security and to ensure that they can do their job, or to give young people the prospect of work in the first place.  That is where we are called upon, and we have to deliver. We do not need a Convention, Mr Leinen, and we do not need ideological debates, but we must deliver. I am particularly pleased that we are delivering tomorrow, because tomorrow the new mandate for Frontex will be adopted here in the European Parliament. Strengthening internal security, border protection and external controls: that is where we are called upon, and that is what we will deliver tomorrow. Now we just have to communicate that to the people and bring it over, then I am confident that we are on the right track.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I had hoped that with the trauma of Brexit, European leaders would also become aware that we need a radical change, a step forward in the process of European integration, which has been stuck in half, realizing that if we do not complete the plant, it is not only ineffective but in many ways counterproductive. That does not seem to me to be the case. I read an interview with Mr Schäuble who has the extraordinary talent to propose the cause of the problems as a solution. If we are in this disaster, it is precisely because of the predomination of the intergovernmental method and national self-interest, which have prevented the Union from carrying out and functioning, on migration, fiscal, foreign and social policies.  In Brexit, we paid for years in which governments gambled to nationalise the Union's successes and blame it for every problem, along with the inability to respond to the inequalities and uncertainties that have grown with the crisis. As the Lions of Leave beat in cowardly retreat in the face of the consequences of the lies with which they spoiled the debate, it is necessary, with sorrow, to take note of the vote and move forward, because uncertainty hurts both sides. And if the Council is going to put the Commission and Parliament and the citizens of Europe on the sidelines, it must find our fiercest opposition.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it has been rightly said that Ireland has more at stake than any other Member State because of our close relationship with Britain. They are our best allies and also our biggest trading partner. Allied to that, we have the border and we do not want under any circumstances to see a hard border restored because that would lead us into the hands of the extremists once again. Having said that, Ireland is fully committed to the European Union, a European Union of equals, and that is why we have to ensure that there are no more special meetings of the original six.  I also want to say that calls for the United Kingdom MEPs either to step down or to resign from their positions or from their portfolios within the European Parliament are incorrect. They are as legitimate as any of us and they are entitled to stay until such time as the United Kingdom actually leaves the European Union. Finally, I just want to say that I welcome Mr Nuttall’s conciliatory tone this morning, but we have a dilemma. If the United Kingdom is seen to be better off outside the European Union, why would any member stay within it?

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: Mr President, by lying and saying anything about the European Union, the Farages, Johnsons and a few others have achieved a victory which they do not know what to do today. They leave the ship shamefully. Even to get elected, Mr Cameron should have known that this type of referendum was risky, because it crystallizes all discontent. We have seen others who have experienced the same fate. These discontents are, in part, linked to the functioning of the European Union, sometimes rightly, but the main refusal is that of social misery, deregulation of work, poverty in the rural world. From this point of view, the "no" map is quite edifying, especially in England. It was therefore in part to the British government that the "no" side addressed. It does not absone the European Union of its responsibilities, and quick decisions must now be taken to restore people's confidence, give perspectives and, as Mrs Thomas said earlier, also give a budget that effectively allows policies to be put in place.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, those in the gallery too! What we have seen in these last ten days is similar to a drama by Shakespeare. Those who have campaigned for Brexit with lies and false promises, many of them for the destruction of the European Union, who have rubbed the sand in the eyes of the people of Britain because they have meant it, then the good old days, which were supposedly so good, will no longer be able to look into the eyes of those who have deceived them. They deny responsibility and resign.  Mr Johnson, Mr Farage, that is what you have done. That is the principle of right-wing populists. First lie and cheat and then take no responsibility. It must not be allowed to happen. We stand for a Europe that must become stronger, including more socially, politically and ecologically. To this end, we need a new Convention with the broad participation of civil society and citizens. Only in this way will we be able to strengthen the Europe that we have created and that people will believe in it again.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, BREXIT was a democratic victory for the British people who went to the polls en masse and denounced the European Union of bureaucracy and bankers, austerity and multinationals. Unfortunately, the way in which the outcome of the referendum is dealt with by some incurable, so-called Europeans, is unacceptable, as they not only refuse to give up austerity, but above all because, on the margins of the European Council meeting, an unprecedented attack was attempted on the United Kingdom, which was only aimed at overturning the referendum.  But both the Scots and the Irish are well aware that the so-called solidarity suddenly expressed by the European bureaucracy is nothing more than crocodile tears, because when there was a referendum in Scotland in 2014, no Europeans were involved. It is simply that the Ukrainianisation of Britain has now been launched by various circles, both there and there. However, the attempt to undermine the Republic will be defeated, both in Britain and in Greece, but also in the rest of Europe.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: – Today, the Brexit camp is talking about the pressure being exerted, about the supposedly ignored will of the British people. There is nothing like this and cannot be in this House. It is clear that Britain's political leaders are under such pressure from their own citizens, I stress - from British citizens that no leader dares to take responsibility for the referendum result and start Brexit negotiations. There is no longer a majority in the British Parliament to legitimise the outcome of the referendum and give the government a mandate to apply to the European Union for the triggering of Article 50 of the Treaty. I am convinced that, because of the British decision, we will not be divided into national cages. The slogans of patriotism have been accompanied by nationalism, the destruction of the European Union from within and is a nationalism whose lessons Europe has already learned. The best solution and our best response is a strong and united European Union.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has We have heard a lot about Brexit today. The majority of those present in this room do not enjoy the decision of the British people. However, I believe that what we must do from today is not to blame each other. I have seen this again today in this House. We always find culprits, rather than thinking that this strengthened, united Europe can only work if we feel responsible for this common Europe at all political levels – as MEPs as well as as representatives of the Council, but also as representatives of the regions and municipalities. I therefore hope that– much more than we already do , we will also live this common Europe by having meetings, not only of the national parliaments and Members, but also – much more intensively than in the past with the representatives of the local authorities, but also with the representatives of the NGOs. It is only if we are prepared to take joint responsibility for this Europe, to transport it, where it really is in the interests of the people, that this European added value can be brought to bear, then we can help to ensure that we are not divided, but that we grow together.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Dear President, Brexit has happened. That's a fact. And we should take into what the people of Great Britain have said.  But UK citizens need to be aware that this Brexit has largely happened based on many lies. That's why Johnson and Farage went because they're aware that they got a positive result on lies. I'm sorry about that, but the fact is that the UK, if it still wants to go along with us, must respect the four freedoms of the European Union.   However, we should look in the mirror ourselves. The European Union needs to be more, we need more of the European Union when we talk about the energy market, about the digital market, about the banking union. But that's not enough. It's not enough just anymore, we need a better Europe. It is these words: a better Europe. I believe that and I hope that we will create a better Europe together.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, for reasons I ignore I have been listening to the German translation for four and a half hours so I am in a German mood.   Mr. President! I have listened carefully to this debate. She was very interesting, very often moved, sometimes moving, and yet had only indirect to do with the Brexit issue. Many people , including myself, have said today what they have always wanted to say, and they are using the decision of the British people as the reason to say exactly what they wanted to say anyway. You have to see what Brexit was all about. You don't come to me with new lies! The UK vote, which we respect – no one here needs to throw themselves in the ring in a sweaty way to convince us that we have to respect this vote – was not about the euro and the so-called, sometimes actual euro austerity policy. The majority of the British did not vote against the European Union because they had problems with Schengen, because Schengen does not apply in The United Kingdom. The British did not vote against Europe because they would be against the European Defence Union, because there is no European defence union. The British did not vote against a European army, because there is no European army. So you shouldn't reinterpret the British vote to end up in the target area where you always wanted to land. (Applause) I am listening to the message that we should modernise the European Union. Yes, are we doing something else? This Commission is, after all, a reform commission, acting within the framework of a mandate it received from the European Council. This mandate has been called the reform agenda, and this Commission is acting on the basis of a programme which the European Parliament overwhelmingly felt was the right one. This is being implemented piece by piece, and I will not be persuaded that what we have agreed together is now suddenly going to be wrong because the British voted for Brexit for reasons that are not linked to the euro and the social union.  I tell you why the British voted for Brexit: anyone who has been telling for forty years – politicians of all parties, and no government has crept into the hearts of the people through particular European courage – that the European Union would be nothing if it were nothing, if the British were to limit their desire for freedom, if it were an invention against the peoples of the European Union, it would be a fighting machine of international big business. , and there are no social rights, he should not be surprised if, at the end of the day, many believe this and cast their vote accordingly. It has been lied to for decades, and the result is now there. (Applause) And that goes on. I read , not only in British newspapers – what new inventions are being devised. I read that the Commission – usually the President of the Commission – would be thinking of introducing the euro in all the Member States of the European Union the day after tomorrow. I am not thinking about it, and those who are concerned are not thinking about it, by the way. I read that I had asked the Scots to declare themselves independent of the United Kingdom. I didn't do that. The British know how to solve internal British problems, as was noted on 23 June. They will also solve the problem. I read – not only in British newspapers – that Juncker wants to abolish the nation state. I don't want that at all! You have never heard me say that I have advocated the Causa United States of Europe. I believe that Europe cannot be put on the right track against the nations and not without the nations. Nations are not a provisional invention of history, they are permanently established, and Europeans must respect that. And that, by the way, is far from contradictory – nations and the European Union go together! I therefore warn against simplifying the debate. We must do what we set out to do. I am not advocating major institutional reforms. I am also opposed to treaty reforms at this moment, because I am opposed to digging up divisions rather than filling the gaps. But the fact that some are developing long-term projects must not be prohibited! I am not going to develop such projects, because I am responsible for the short term. We had planned to be big and small in small. That is what we are doing. The Commission has withdrawn more than 100 draft laws and is launching only 23 new initiatives per year. Is this de-bureaucratisation, or is it not? It's de-bureaucratization! The Commission is held liable for many things which are not at all a matter for the Commission Is. Take a look at the decision-making channels in the European Union. Very often it is the Member States, sometimes even Parliament, which is small and small, not necessarily the Commission. Do we need to change these rules, or do you think it is normal for the Commission to have to take a decision on glyphosate when there is no clear majority in the Council of Ministers? That is not normal! This is undemocratic. The Commission should not have that many rights at all. I would like to give up the rights that are not democratically based, and I think there is a long list of them. (Applause) I would like to say a word about CETA. Mrs Zimmer, you should not talk to yourself in zeal. We have a summit with Canada on 27 October, where the CETA agreement is to be signed. The President of the Commission may ask the European Council whether all the Member States still stand by this agreement. All the Member States say that the European Union has never concluded such a good and successful trade agreement with third countries. And I must be able to point out – where are we that we can no longer do this – that it is the Commission's legal position that this would be an EU-only agreement! And I say the following to you: the Commission is discussing this today, I am not stubborn and have said this on several occasions, but anyone who here in this House pretends that the European Parliament, directly elected by the citizens of Europe, is not a democratic body that is likely to decide, should consider whether it is in the right place here. (Applause) Now we are listening to the debate situation in the Member States – I am not deaf, I am hearing what is being said – and the Commission will be working definitively on this issue these days. The long speech is short-term: we should not continue as before, but the European Union cannot solve the problems that the Member States are unable to solve. We need the European Union, the Commission, Parliament and the Member States. Incidentally, because Mr Lucke has reappeared: if I have understood you correctly, I should resign. I do not take the blame for the fact that the Commission was to blame for the outcome of the British referendum. (Applause)

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the honourable Members for their contributions to today’s debate. It is fully understandable that the events of the past days have produced a lot of negative emotions, but we cannot give in to these emotions. We have to preserve the ability to make sober assessments and rational decisions. First, I would like to stress that the EU is ready to proceed with an amicable divorce with the UK even today. In this process we will stand firmly on the grounds of the Treaties, which have prepared us for such a situation. And one thing must be clear: the Treaties have left the decision on the initiation of the divorce proceedings to the Member State that wishes to leave the EU. In other words, we cannot effectively force this decision on the UK. Secondly, before launching the divorce proceedings we will not undertake any negotiations on the future shape of relations between the EU and the UK. Future relations will be based on a balance of rights and obligations. I would like to reassure you that, wherever there may be a conflict of interest, we will act in the interests of the EU and we will do so effectively. Thirdly, today we have heard a lot of severe and critical comments aimed at Member States. I want to tell you that in our talks with the leaders of Member States I always repeat that there is no EU without the EU institutions. In the current situation, attacks on the EU institutions, including the Commission and Parliament, can only deepen the confusion. The national capitals must make an effort to stop accusing the EU and its institutions of weaknesses and failures. (Applause) The referendum in the UK was lost in part because the political elite have for years been building a negative and often unfair vision of the EU. But there is no EU without the Member States either. It is impossible to solve serious problems in the EU against the will of the Member States. Taking responsibility for one’s own words applies also to the representatives of EU institutions. Today, we must combine all our efforts to agree on what our common interest is, as opposed to constantly demonstrating our individual importance in some kind of perpetual Vanity Fair.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Brexit has created a political earthquake that has spread across Europe. Europe today needs to be reformed, with a new vision to be presented to its worried citizens, yet there is not enough recognition of this in the Council. European citizens are not against the European Union, they are tired and dissatisfied with the lack of action of the current European Union. The European Union currently gets caught up too much in the little things, whereas it needs to focus more on the big issues such as the migration crisis and terrorism. We must respect the decision of the British people and move forward and let Britain figure out how to pull itself out of this crisis. The new British Government must immediately activate Article 50 and make clear the direction they plan to take. The remaining 27 EU countries need to look forward and move towards a stronger and more interconnected union that can offer more to its citizens.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. – The referendum, brexit and continuity of the United Kingdom as such has awakened political cannibalism in David Cameron's party, weakened the European Union and ended his political career. This is the legacy of Mr Cameron's political adventurism and these are the first fruits of the Europhobics' first success. In the face of this, the European Council has dispatched the matter online and a half, with a timid applause dismissed Mr Cameron and called himself in for two and a half months to try to address the matter. This is not what we need. We need to get Article 50 up and running quickly and start negotiating for a new relationship between the UK and the European Union. We need the European Commission to lead this negotiation and not fall into the hands of governments bilaterally. We need a good agreement, satisfactory for both sides, but it cannot be that the one who leaves will maintain the advantages of those who are left without making any of the commitments. We need predictability and clarity, not confusion. And right now we're in a confusing phase.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. – As a European is in favour of keeping the United Kingdom in the European Union. While Portuguese even more, given the ancient alliance and the same Atlantic vocation. The outcome of the referendum, however, cannot be ignored by the European Union. Although legally not binding on the British parliament, this was a sovereign decision of the British people. So its impact on the European Union is not of any importance. The Union is required to act in accordance with the Treaties. In other words, wait for formal notification to - and only there - start exit negotiations with the UK. Of course it will not be an easy process, but it does not have to be litigious. The United Kingdom remains a European country and will be a privileged partner of the Union. However, any future relationship cannot call into question fundamental principles: the internal market is not a la carte and if trucks with Port wine can enter freely, Portuguese workers will also have to be able to freely access the English labour market. This will also be a crucial point: to guarantee the rights of the Portuguese community living in the United Kingdom. And it is up to the EU to respond to citizens' fears and not to reopen institutional redevelopments.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. The meeting between the Heads of State or Government on 28 and 29 June was the first since the referendum on 23 June, which enshrined the will of the British people to leave the Union. On the one hand, we can appreciate the progress made on key issues such as the management of the migration crisis and the creation of a single market, and on the other hand it is worth noting the still insufficient response on the Brexit front. The Union's priority today is to manage this phase clearly and on the basis of a precise timetable, avoiding generating a period of uncertainty that would have very heavy costs for both sides. The next step must be to initiate a process of reform and relaunching the project of European integration: a path that must be mapped out in a new pro-European spirit, with the aim of greater economic and monetary, social and political integration. On the rubble of Brexit, the time has come to rebuild a Union that is more social and close to its citizens. We can no longer wait, those who, without a sense of responsibility, reason only on the basis of purely national logic and interests.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – The outcome of the UK referendum on 23 June clearly showed that European policies and the way the European Union is governed are wrong, and that is what prompted the British people to make the democratic decision to leave the European Union.  The culprit for what happened is neither Cameron nor Boris Johnson, nor the 17 million Britons. The only person responsible for everything is Jean Claude Juncker, the President of the European Commission, who will go down in history in that, with his arrogance and inability to listen to people's problems and respect the interests of individual Member States, he has led to the loss of one of the most important political and economic countries in the EU.  In the face of many global crises and problems, Juncker has not only failed to bring the EU together and united, but with his actions and the apparent advocacy of the intra-party interests of the European People's Party, the Party of Socialists and Democrats and the Liberal Alliance, a disintegration and opposition has begun between Member States.  European leaders must undertake EU reform in order to return to the idea of a Europe of nations, respect for and protect the interests of all Member States and ensure full respect for the principle of subsidiarity, otherwise not only Brexit will follow, but also Brexit, Speisit, etc.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. – What has been heard today as the conclusions of the European Council's meeting proves a great truth. Eu leaders have not grasped the real causes of BREXIT. Most focused on the problem in the financial sector. But it's not an economic issue. It's political. It is the restriction of the functioning of nation states, so that there is economic impoverishment of the peoples, that all notions of welfare for the people have been destroyed, that there is an uncontrolled invasion of hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants that threaten the existence of European states. That is why many states are turning their backs on the Schengen Treaty and closing their borders. It is the removal of the EU from the principles of its creators who provided for the cooperation of equal and sovereign nation states working together to promote the interests of its peoples. This has now been replaced by Germany's dominance, with the result that we are heading for a two-speed Europe. It is the removal from the principles and democracy, no matter how much you do not admit this. It is the destruction of a country, Greece, in order to save the Euro, which no one accepts. So you are leading the EU on the right track to continue to exist. Otherwise set aside! You've been marginalized by history.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Looking at the conclusions of this European Council, it is easy to conclude from what the statements that followed Brexit about the need for an alleged refoundation of the so-called (evil) so-called 'European project': we are facing a blatant flight forward, which seeks to go over deep contradictions that are deepening, deepening the most negative aspects of EU policies and taking further the concentration of power within it.  Evidencing - even for those who still had doubts - the unreformable nature of European capitalist integration.  Migrations. In the face of the tragic consequences of the EU-Turkey agreement, the EU is now proposing to conclude similar agreements with other countries, notably in Africa. Blackmailing them into agreeing to submit to eu migration policy and doing the dirty work of retaining migrants (or accepting those the EU decides to expel).  European Semester. The procession of impositions - in all similar to those of previous years - is continuing, which are deeply contrary to the interests of the peoples and in which the crisis in which several Member States have plunged.  Juncker Plan. Five major countries concentrate more than 90 percent of investments (in public-private partnerships). For 22 Member States, Portugal included, not a cent. It's all said.  "New impetus in EU-NATO cooperation". That is, new steps in militaristic strategy and war.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D)
text: Writing. – The VOTE in the United Kingdom has shown that cynical politicians have seen an opportunity to exploit public concern about very specific issues in order to promote their own careers. But that backfired. You have simply turned a very complex issue into a yes/no referendum, which has been understood by very few people. These questions are too important to engage in a fire-hazardous game, as has happened in the United Kingdom. Getting to grips with technological change, globalisation and the climate is a huge challenge to the political system, but also, of course, to the population, which must be brought to this upheaval with appropriate measures in the field of education and training. Now we see that in Britain these politicians have left a mess, they have resigned rather than taking responsibility. Moreover, I am no longer so sure that Brexit will actually happen. The Constitution makes such a step incredibly difficult, let us just think of the vote in Parliament or how the Scottish Parliament should and must be involved in this decision.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. Last week's European Council had to address issues that are crucial for Europe. In the aftermath of Brexit, it was clear that the debate and attention would be catalysed by the drastic choice of Britain that we have to accept and that needs to be followed up as soon as possible. What is most surprising is that no one, not even those who set up that referendum, were really prepared for Brexit and, after the decision, came before the 27 Member States - and even more so before the British people - with an action plan for the reconstruction of the post-European Union United Kingdom. But while it was clear that the British case could not be resolved or even clarified at a meeting of the 28, this European Council must continue to make great strides in resolving other crucial issues affecting the Union. Brexit or not, this Council has finally begun the implementation phase of the migration compact. This is a fundamental step because, unfortunately, the agreement with Turkey has not affected the Mediterranean routes and has not reduced the number of victims at sea, let alone landings. That Brexit has paralysed Britain is a fact, that it also does not paralyse Europe is a necessity

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. – President Tusk, President Junker, you said that the first concern is growth and employment. I totally agree, but we have to be careful how we do this. We can have concentrated growth and employment in several countries and a share that would lead to increased regional disparities. This would lead to the righteous discontent of the citizens of the same Europe and the Brexit phenomenon can be repeated, although it is not good! That is why, Mr Junker and Mr Tusk, I wish, on behalf of the citizens of the country I represent, that we no longer have two Europes with Schengen countries and non-admitted countries without good reason, to stop dividing the ISF on criteria that are not anchored in Europe's concrete investment needs. You cannot continue to treat countries in two different ways. Concrete changes are needed in the way of action, but also in the structure of measures. More transparency, communication and fairness in the transposition of measures are also needed.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – The referendum, brexit and continuity of the United Kingdom as such has awakened political cannibalism in David Cameron's party, weakened the European Union and ended his political career. This is the legacy of Mr Cameron's political adventurism and these are the first fruits of the Europhobics' first success. In the face of this, the European Council has dispatched the matter online and a half, with a timid applause dismissed Mr Cameron and called himself in for two and a half months to try to address the matter. This is not what we need. We need to get Article 50 up and running quickly and start negotiating for a new relationship between the UK and the European Union. We need the European Commission to lead this negotiation and not fall into the hands of governments bilaterally. We need a good agreement, satisfactory for both sides, but it cannot be that the one who leaves will maintain the advantages of those who are left without making any of the commitments. We need predictability and clarity, not confusion. And right now we're in a confusing phase.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – Loses a member for the first time in its history after the European Union. This vote has upset the whole of British political life, but it has, on appearances, done no greater damage in Europe. Together and individually, the Members of the European Council pretended that nothing unexpected had happened, or at least nothing they could not handle. This composure is more like paralysis. In terms of responsibility, the pointing of fingers has also begun in Europe. In addition to Cameron's political myopia, Farage's lies, Juncker's ineptitude has also emerged. But with this finger pointing, they're just covering up that no one has any idea how to move forward. Merkel met with the founding six over the weekend, but it seems only to assess who is unwilling to do what about EU reform. And the European Council's response so far has been insufficient. Today, only heads of state or government can decide on the future of the EU. They have to reform the EU. If they don't start urgently, sooner or later the roof could fall on us. Action must be taken quickly and decisively, especially since there are still a majority of people in Europe who believe in cooperation. Especially young people. And we really need Europe! Two claims are certain: the current Europe is not capable of deal with a crisis situation, but without Europe, it is not possible to provide effective, future-proof responses to a crisis situation on the continent.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – On 23 June, 52 percent of Britons voted to leave the EU. This popular decision has far-reaching locational consequences and is dealt a major blow to Europe's second-largest economy. Leading indicators already point to a recession. In June, construction activity in the UK shrank at the most since the financial crisis. Credit rating agencies have lowered their credit ratings and the targeted budget surplus will not be achieved by 2020. The referendum has a negative impact, particularly on the stock market values of British banks and airlines. The exchange rate of the pound fell to its lowest level in 31 years. Two weeks after the referendum on the euro, the pound lost nine per cent and the dollar 11 per cent. In total, EUR 5 000 billion of market capitalisation was wiped out worldwide following the British vote, which is twice the UK's economic output. Experts estimate that 80,000 jobs will be lost in London's financial sector, and the European Banking Authority will also give up its headquarters in London. Other EU Member States see relocations away from London as an opportunity for their own business location. According to the European Central Bank, the vote has a massive impact on economic growth across Europe. ECB economists expect growth to flatten by up to 0.5% over the next three years.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. – The referendum, brexit and continuity of the United Kingdom as such has awakened political cannibalism in David Cameron's party, weakened the European Union and ended his political career. This is the legacy of Mr Cameron's political adventurism and these are the first fruits of the Europhobics' first success. In the face of this, the European Council has dispatched the matter online and a half, with a timid applause dismissed Mr Cameron and called himself in for two and a half months to try to address the matter. This is not what we need. We need to get Article 50 up and running quickly and start negotiating for a new relationship between the UK and the European Union. We need the European Commission to lead this negotiation and not fall into the hands of governments bilaterally. We need a good agreement, satisfactory for both sides, but it cannot be that the one who leaves will maintain the advantages of those who are left without making any of the commitments. Northern Ireland, an integral part of the United Kingdom, must unequivocally leave the EU to materialise Brexit.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – The results of the REFERENDUM in the United Kingdom are the result of a victory for egotism, deception and the personal interests of politicians over the interests of the citizens and the countries they represent. The facts of recent days show that populism and extremism, in addition to negativity, scepticism and criticism, have no real solutions to existing problems. On the other hand, we cannot ignore the 51.9% of the participating Uk voters who voted to leave the Union, expressing their dissatisfaction with the status quo and the lack of solution to their real problems. This is reason enough for the governments of the Member States and the Union authorities to start listening more to their citizens, to analyse more thoroughly the reasons for their countries' dissatisfaction and problems, and to start addressing them in a genuine and urgent way.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – On 23 June, British citizens decided to leave the EU and end their 43-year membership. Meanwhile, the leaders of the Brexit campaign decided to withdraw and showed they had no plan of action.  However, this is not at all surprising. Indeed, the debate on the pros and cons of the UK's membership of the Union has been completely replaced by the topic of migration. Residents who voted to leave the EU have actually expressed concern about the lack of an adequate European migration policy.  Let us not forget that a few years ago bulgarian citizens were also the subject of a targeted campaign by these same opponents of the European project. The result of the referendum also clearly outlined the generational dividing line. The majority of young people voted against Brexit. Their votes, however, did not prevail.  We live in democratic societies and the decision of the British people must be respected. The lesson is that European integration can only be successful if we listen more to the fears of our citizens.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. – The choice of the British people largely reflects the increased dissatisfaction with the EU's unpopular policy, but it is necessary to disengage itself from the aspirations of sections and parties of the bourgeoisie, reactionary and dangerous forces and to acquire a radical anti-capitalist character. Both Brexit and the summit's decisions are being used to blackmail the Greek people into coming to terms with the barbaric measures, in the name of EU cohesion, the goal of capitalist recovery, and threats are already being launched against the peoples of Spain and Portugal. The EU cannot be corrected, it can be made pro-grassroots. It serves the capital and for that only worse for the people can be done. The working class and the other poor grass roots have the only way out with their struggle to target capitalist property and power and to impose in their interest the release from the EU, NATO and any other alliance of capital

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE)
text: Written. – All the voices after the Brexit vote agree that the EU needs to reform. According to some, a large part of the regulation of the EU internal market would somehow be unnecessary, and the EU should return to a strict 'economic union'. If we think beyond the free movement of goods and services, it becomes clear the absurdity of the argument: products and services sold in a single internal market must be subject to uniform standards, otherwise the functioning of the internal market as a whole will fall to the bottom.  In a time of economic cooperation, people have been forgotten, and this is partly where the current crisis comes from. Jean Monnet, a founding member of the EU, said at the time that the EU must become a union of people, not states. Article 2 of the Treaty of Lisbon states that the Union's objective is to promote peace, its own values and the well-being of its peoples. The European Union must therefore be, just like the state and the municipality, for the well-being of its citizens. Instead of being voluntary, these rights deserve the same legal protection as, say, agricultural subsidies. It is a matter of principle, but also of the fate of the future of the community as a whole.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. – The referendum, brexit and continuity of the United Kingdom as such has awakened political cannibalism in David Cameron's party, weakened the European Union and ended his political career. This is the legacy of Mr Cameron's political adventurism and these are the first fruits of the Europhobics' first success. In the face of this, the European Council has dispatched the matter online and a half, with a timid applause dismissed Mr Cameron and called himself in for two and a half months to try to address the matter. This is not what we need. We need to get Article 50 up and running quickly and start negotiating for a new relationship between the UK and the European Union. We need the European Commission to lead this negotiation and not fall into the hands of governments bilaterally. We need a good agreement, satisfactory for both sides, but it cannot be that the one who leaves will maintain the advantages of those who are left without making any of the commitments. We need predictability and clarity, not confusion. And right now we're in a confusing phase.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Today, we are again debating the situation created by the referendum on Britain's exit from the EU. I am very pleased that on Friday the European Council resisted British blackmail and strongly spoke out about access to the single market, which is strictly conditional on the non-restriction of the freedom of movement of persons. This is a time when we must remove all fears and rethink the European project in order to meet the great challenges of our day. We need political leaders who take responsibility for their decisions, and from now on, when populist leaders hide their own failures by blaming the Union for everything that doesn't work in their countries, we will have to stand up and tell the truth. The European Union must become the Union of Europeans, and reform must not be delayed. Now, more than ever, citizens need a united Europe, strong and capable of facing challenges such as youth unemployment, terrorism, the limitation of natural resources, conflicts in the Middle East and instability on the Eastern border.

name: Algirdas Saudargas (PPE)
text: Writing. – The referendum in the United Kingdom has shaken Europe. However, such a state of shock, if properly responded to, can also bring long-term positive consequences. European unity will not depend on the sound thesis on the need for further integration or on naïve proposals to move towards a federal Europe. We must respect the decision taken by the British, but in no case can we encourage them to distance themselves from Europe as quickly as possible, as some senior officials have done. Because we cut the branch we're sitting on. At the last meeting of the European Commission and the European Council, it was decided to strengthen EU-NATO cooperation both in the field of continental security and missions outside Europe. This is a serious positive step, because despite all the crises that are devastating for Europe, geopolitical and 'hard' security remains the most important issue. Firstly, we need to understand that, without the active involvement of the United Kingdom, this objective is unenforceable. Therefore, especially in the face of the political chaos in London, we must not blame the wedge, but build our hand and look for the best life model for both sides after Brexit. Secondly, EU-NATO cooperation must not become an increase in the EU's 'hard' security powers. NATO must remain the main security umbrella in Europe, because that is the only way we will maintain the necessary close transatlantic link. The EU can and must play a greater role in expeditions, peacekeeping missions outside the continent.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – Regardless of the instability and uncertainty created by the UK referendum, we must not forget to deal with other pressing matters of crucial importance, such as energy security of supply. We should not increase our dependency on Russian gas by doubling the capacity of the Nord Stream pipeline. Doing so would be extremely detrimental to our energy security since Russia has demonstrated on countless occasions that it is not a reliable partner to the European Union, and that it does not hesitate in wielding energy as a political weapon. Now more than ever, we need greater unity among the remaining Member States. For instance, we would have more bargaining power if we negotiated as a unified block, rather than individual states. The Nord Stream pipeline is currently used at only half of its capacity, and therefore the only logical reason to double the capacity is to be able to reroute all the gas that is transiting through Ukraine. Currently we do not have sufficient interconnectors to send enough gas from Germany back to eastern Member States. Therefore, unity and solidarity amongst ourselves are our best tools if we are to avoid putting eastern Member States in a precarious position.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The statements that followed Brexit about the need for an alleged refoundation of the so-called 'European project' show that we are facing a blatant flight forward, which seeks to go over deep contradictions that are worsening, taking the most negative aspects of EU policies and taking the concentration of power within it further. For us, it is even clearer the unreformable nature of European capitalist integration. In the face of the tragic consequences of the EU-Turkey agreement, the EU is now proposing to conclude similar agreements with other countries, notably in Africa, blackmailing them into agreeing to submit to the EU's migration policy and doing the dirty work of retaining migrants (or accepting those that the EU decides to expel). In the context of the European semester, the procession of impositions - in all similar to those of previous years - is deeply contrary to the interests of the peoples and in which the dragged down crisis in which several Member States have plunged.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. – The result of the British referendum was disappointing, but an even more unfortunate surprise was that the LEAVE campaign, which called for Britain to leave the EU, had no plan for the future. This is a terrible situation for the voters who believed in them. The situation is now still two weeks after the vote that Britain is in a state of complete confusion: the Prime Minister has announced his resignation and leave campaigners have left their seats. No one takes responsibility for the result.  Britain must now decide whether or not to follow the advice of the referendum. The further the uncertainty drags on, the more harmful it will be to both the EU and, above all, Britain itself. Apparently, however, there is not a solution very quickly. The country must first have a new leadership, and the prime minister-designate seems to have very different views on how to implement the difference. Negotiations between the EU and the UK can only begin when the country submits a formal notification of withdrawal.  EU27 leaders said last week that if Britain wants continued access to the EU's internal market, it will mutually require the realisation of all four fundamental freedoms of the EU, including the free movement of labour. This is a good and clear policy. Now we are waiting for the UK to resign. If Britain leaves the European Union, it will continue to be an important and close partner for us. It is clear, however, that it cannot obtain a better agreement outside the EU than at present.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. – The choice of the British people largely reflects the increased dissatisfaction with the EU's unpopular policy, but it is necessary to disengage itself from the aspirations of sections and parties of the bourgeoisie, reactionary and dangerous forces and to acquire a radical anti-capitalist character. Both Brexit and the summit's decisions are being used to blackmail the Greek people into coming to terms with the barbaric measures, in the name of EU cohesion, the goal of capitalist recovery, and threats are already being launched against the peoples of Spain and Portugal. The EU cannot be corrected, it can be made pro-grassroots. It serves the capital and for that only worse for the people can be done. The working class and the other poor working classes have the only way out with their struggle to target capitalist property and power and to impose in their interest the release from the EU, NATO and any other alliance of capital.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Undoubtedly, the most important event of recent weeks was the outcome of the British referendum on the country's exit from the EU. I regret the democratic decision of the British people to leave the EU, but it must be respected and implemented as soon as possible. A prolonged state of uncertainty is not in the interest of either party. Instead, the remaining 27 Member States should find better solutions to common problems such as the migration crisis and youth unemployment. I therefore welcome the EU's global strategy presented by High Representative Federica Mogherini.
