When preparing a foreign policy strategy, we must first of all remember that preventing in the future similar problems that we face today must start with the specific foreign policy that we are shaping today. Therefore, the EU's global strategy must, above all, be up-to-date, coherent in all its elements and involve tasks with accountability and funding. Moreover, in the context of foreign and security policy, it is impossible not to mention the NATO summit, which will start in a few days' time in Warsaw. The location of the summit draws attention to our eastern neighbourhood – the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, the upcoming parliamentary elections in Belarus. Strengthening cooperation between the EU and NATO in key areas will be necessary to effectively achieve our common objectives.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes).

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the indication on the screen was misleading. It said that we were voting on Recital C while we were still voting on paragraph 18. So I think this has to be corrected.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr Bütikofer, this is not an error because, since the first part of paragraph 18 was rejected, the second part lapsed, which is why the nominal appeal did indeed concern recital C.

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
text: What Mr Bütikofer said is that everyone thought they were still voting on paragraph 18, but in reality they voted on recital C, and that recital C should be voted on again because the vote was accidentally wrong.

name: Presidente. –
text: All clear. Anyway, if you want to revote, let's revote. We shall therefore vote on recital C.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Britain voted to leave the European Union. We in Parliament have made it clear what needs to be done now: no hesitation, no hesitation; the positions are clear, at least as far as we are concerned. Let everyone choose their future. Britain chose it by saying out, we respond in, but we are talking about growth, stability and social justice, true integration, common values.  We are talking about a Europe which, since this historic and unfortunately bitter decision, must now start again in order to move forward in a Way that is truly at the side of its citizens. A strong and clear response must be given immediately and without hesitation, in order to oppose those who, under the blows of electoral populism alone, want to destroy Europe and want to mortify the will of so many young people who believe in Europe and who look to Europe as their future. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution and I call for it to be continued, quickly and united, because from here we are starting again for a better Europe.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – Prince Bismarck said that there are three types of people: the first to learn from the experience of history; others who learn from the experiences of their own lives, and there is a third kind – people who will never learn anything from anything. And this third kind of european union is leading today. The BRITISH referendum should send a signal to us that the necessary changes are needed. Unfortunately, it has only become a signal of attacks on Europeans who do not agree with the policies of the current Authorities of the European Union. Today, the Commission's leadership leads us nowhere and only their dismissal can restore the principles of political responsibility and the public good in European politics.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE).
text: Mr President, we take note of the decision of the British people - sovereign decision - and we deplore it. Personally, I deeply regret it, but what is done is done, what is voted is voted on. So, after Brexit, what do we do? First of all, we are trying to remain faithful, coherent, to fully respect the decision of the sovereign British people, and therefore to move quickly, within a reasonable time frame, towards, indeed, the commitment of a withdrawal procedure, a negotiation in which we will have to work to build a new relationship between the United Kingdom and the European Union - a healthy, friendly, balanced relationship based on mutual benefit. , but uncompromising. So no small arrangements, no small accommodations, no procrastination or procrastination, no cherry picking, no Europe à la carte. We need clarity, firmness, but also stability and, above all, we need to think about reviving, renovating and re-founding the European project. The task is immense. It requires lucidity, courage and determination.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, I voted against the resolution on BREXIT because it supports the powers of the nomenclature of banks and the Brussels bureaucracy, those forces, which, as they did not tolerate the 'no' vote of the Greek people in last year's great referendum, do not tolerate the decision of the British to leave the European Union and take their own historic path. It is obvious that the United Kingdom is under an unprecedented attack in its history, with the aim of overturning the democratic will of its citizens.  At the extraordinary plenary session of the European Parliament last Tuesday, the vindictive attitude of various sides against Britain and the launch of the Uk's Ukrainianisation were evident. It seemed unrepentant that the old political world of Europe continues the "business as usual", continuing the policy of merch austerity, violent fiscal adjustment, support for banking and TTIR.  But the citizens of Europe are reacting and calling for another Europe, a Europe of solidarity and social justice, a Europe that respects the national independence of the states and the sovereign will of the peoples.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, last week we voted to urge the United Kingdom to let us know as soon as possible how they might implement and respect the vote of their citizens, but we clearly know now – because events have unfolded – that this may take some time. What I am concerned about is to reassure citizens in my constituency of Midlands North-West, which borders with Northern Ireland, that, until there is change, everything remains the same, although we know that uncertainty causes deep concern. Community groups, businesses, schools and colleges throughout the region are deeply disturbed by what might result from the United Kingdom’s leaving the European Union. So we must ensure that, in what happens when there is a new Prime Minister, the current arrangements are respected. We will have no borders again between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. We want trade to continue, but we must respect the four freedoms and we want to ensure that the UK continues to understand the importance of the relationship with the Republic of Ireland and build on it.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I signed up to this explanation because I did not support the resolution that was adopted at the last meeting in Brussels.  I regret the British decision to leave the European Union, but I fully respect it, and I felt at the last meeting that perhaps it was preferable to let emotions cool down a little and act more matter-of-factly. This is also the main reason for my non-support for this resolution, because even from the various parts of the resolution there are simply certain emotions without discussing in fact how to set up relations between the European Union and Britain in a way that is beneficial for both sides in the future.  That is why I have also abstained, and I add that we can call on Britain to start the withdrawal process quickly, but as we know, it is entirely up to it under the Treaty of Lisbon and its government must decide when it will start the process of ending its membership of the European Union itself under Article 50.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, you say that you intend to take note of England's departure from the European Union and that this must be done now, very sadly, to reform Europe, but you are careful not to say how you intend to do so. The only thing we have heard so far is Mr Schuble telling us that for him, the future development of Europe is a further tightening of control over the budget of nation states and an increasingly rigid control over the social rules that are destroying our societies in favour of capital. I believe that the Europe that has been built is a Europe of social violence, as we see in every country every time a seconded worker arrives, who steals his bread from the workers who are there, a Europe of political violence, as we have seen applied to Cyprus and Greece, and a Europe of warlike violence , like the one you're preparing for against Russia.  All this is madness and, I tell you, this Europe - the peoples keep telling you - either you change it in favour of human beings, or we will all leave it, because no one wants to live in such a space that opposes the slightest effort made by our citizens for their own development and that of their children.  In the meantime, the truth is that we either change it or we leave it. And this lesson, you must hear it. No, Britain is not made up of racist and xenophobic citizens; no, the "no" vote is not a vote for war and against Europe. It is quite the opposite: the vote of the English, like that of my own country, is a vote for the union of peoples, for peace and for social coordination, but you do not want it.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, everybody has a different reason for Brexit. For some, it is globalisation, too much trade; for others, we need more trade, we need to open more markets. For some, it is the democratic deficit; for others we need ever-closer union. For some, it is all those rules from Brussels which hamper business, disrupt agriculture and annoy citizens; for others, we need more rules to protect the environment. We need to enhance health and safety at work, and we need to clamp down on tax evasion by multinationals. In truth, it is a combination of all of those things, but if there is a common thread, it is that, for one reason or another, people in the UK were not convinced that the EU was a positive project that they wanted to be part of. There are no easy answers, but that is our challenge in the EU. In my opinion, we can reconnect to citizens if we put Social Europe and Economic Europe side by side, and if the EU is seen as a lever that will reduce inequalities, both between and within Member States. Now, more than ever, we sink or we swim together.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: Mr President, Britain voted against the bureaucracy of the European Union. The United Kingdom did not vote against Europe. We are not leaving our allies. We remain committed to the security, prosperity and success of this continent. It must be understood that of the more than 17 million citizens who voted for the exit, barely a quarter support UKIP. Most of them want to preserve close trade, diplomatic and military relations with our friends. They simply want to regain the right to decide their own laws. I very much hope that as the United Kingdom forges links with more distant continents, we will remain committed to our European partners in their vital economic success. You're going to lose a bad tenant, and win a good neighbor.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: There are many ways to think about Brexit, but one fact: the British have made history. And this historic moment, this historic situation, is the duty of other nations, other countries, other states. For example, for us Hungarians to learn the lesson that we have been the victims of a deception after 12 years, our accession treaty must be rethought. We need to come to the table and renegotiate these conditions, especially on the issue of land. The farmland, the Hungarian soil must remain in Hungarian hands! Our accession must be re-regulated with the content that a foreign EU national or any other national cannot acquire land in Hungary under any title. We are now seeing the consequences of poor accession conditions, the fact that entire counties have been taken into foreign hands – this must be prevented. We thank the British people for creating a situation where we can shape our own history.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I voted against that resolution and it was shocking to see that, three days after this referendum, part of this House was quick to tell Britain to get out of the European Union as soon as possible. I recall that the UK is the only one who decides when to submit and whether to apply for an exit. Decisions on the basis of emotion must not be made, as the Council representative very well said when we discussed the resolution, but we must wait for the minds to clear up, the people of the United Kingdom to negotiate, I repeat, with clear and clear minds, so that they stay together, because it is a drama that is happening. It broke into four to five pieces Great Britain – I am now referring to the other countries, Ireland and the others. What is important is the signal of the voters. Voters have told us, not just in the UK. We know very well that we have people from all over the European Union whose confidence in the Union has greatly declined. Why is that? Because we are many institutions, because we have excessive bureaucracy, because we do not have answers to crisis situations. That is what we need to reform, not, for example, President Schulz's proposal, which says, "in addition to this Parliament, let us make another one, made up of national parliaments." Let's cut, not multiply.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is strongly committed to the establishment of better economic, trade and political relations with the territory of Peru. In conditions of reciprocity, therefore, ensuring visa-free travel for short stays is an important step forward for the subsequent and gradual rapprochement of the two cultures. Given that Peru does not pose any threat in terms of security and public order, such an exemption will certainly make it easier for European citizens to stay in the country for work or tourist reasons. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on visa waiver for short-term stays, as this is a very satisfactory agreement by which the Spanish Socialists have worked for a long time. The Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the Union and Peru, as well as being a supplementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  In this way, the Agreement will strengthen regional coherence, as Peru is part of a minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa. Peru is a relatively stable democracy that defends, like the European Union, the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law, and remains an important partner in this area in Latin America. Human rights and democracy are essential elements of the relationship between the European Union and the Andean country.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against giving consent to this agreement. UKIP is opposed to the EU negotiating visa agreements with third countries.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this agreement in line with our position in favour of visa waiver. Despite disagreeing on how the negotiation procedure has been carried out, in an un transparent manner and without including democratic institutions such as the European Parliament therein, I agree with the proposed measures, which facilitate the freedom of movement of both Peruvian citizenship towards the European Union and European citizenship towards Peru , thereby reducing the restrictions that still exist on freedom of movement.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement with Peru on visa exemption for short-term stays.  If in this report the liberalisation of visas for short-term stays is presented as an opportunity to boost tourism and strengthen relations in the field of trade and investment, I consider that at present it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude such agreements.  Faced with a growing terrorist threat and European mass immigration policy, these agreements seem inappropriate to me. Indeed, even if Peru does not pose a direct threat, I do not consider it appropriate to make such an agreement in the current context, regardless of the country concerned.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour this agreement, which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Peru when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special-passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I have expressed my support for this agreement, which is a step forward in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru. This agreement will be an additional tool for the EU in the intensification of economic and cultural relations and political dialogue with Peru, particularly on the issue of human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Peru Agreement on the short-stay visa waiver which was signed on 14 March 2016 in Brussels. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the EU and for the citizens of Peru when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. The Agreement has also many other important aspects. This implementation of this agreement will bring closer the people of the EU and Peru, it will boost tourism and increase trade and investment relations. The EU is already one of the main trade partners and foreign investors for Peru. Moreover, the Agreement contains a joint declaration on cooperation on illegal immigration and will help Peru to become an important partner for the EU in the fight against organised crime, including human and drug trafficking. Respect for human rights and the values of democracy are indeed an essential element of EU-Peru relations.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU agreement with Peru on short-stay visa waiver, which marks an important milestone in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and is an additional instrument for accelerating economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues , including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. In order for a country to be included in the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from visa requirements in the EU, this must meet specific criteria, which the Council then reviews. The Commission then authorised the Commission in 2015 to enter into a bilateral agreement with the Republic of Peru, which was then signed in March 2016. Since then, it has been applied provisionally, pending parliament's approval. The exemption is valid for a period of 180 days, for a maximum of 90 days and for all groups of persons. Peru is one of the few countries in Latin America that is still subject to the visa requirement for the Schengen area. This is due to the fact that in the past the country has been affected by domestic conflicts and has suffered mainly from high levels of violence, drug production and drug trafficking. Although Peru still has some problems, other neighbouring countries, where this problem cannot be ruled out, are already exempt from the visa requirement. Since the economic and general situation in Peru has improved considerably in recent years and it would also be inconsistent to exclude Peru, as one of the few countries in Latin America, from the visa waiver, I agreed.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because if the rapporteur invites the European Commission to look at possible developments in the criteria for illegal immigration, public order and security, it shows that there are considerable problems. In the context of illegal mass immigration, we oppose any visa liberalisation.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs vote against these issues when they come before the European Parliament due to a belief that it should be a matter for Member States to deal with issues such as visa waivers.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation, which aims to facilitate (particularly through the extension of the validity of the visa) the obtaining of visas for Peruvian citizens who intend to travel to Europe.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for an agreement between the EU and the Republic of Peru on visa waiver. This agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short-stay stays is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and an additional instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural ties and promoting political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This agreement will help to strengthen the cohesion of the region, as Peru is one of the few Latin American countries whose citizens are still subject to visa requirements and will be a rather important factor for the peoples of Europe and the peruvian population.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text to approve a report signed between the EU and Peru on 14 March, which grants visa exemption to any citizen of one of the two contracting parties travelling to the territory of the other. Apart from the arguments used to justify this agreement, this policy of exemption from all-out visas is a real scandal in the context of the terrible migration crisis that Europe is going through.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved this agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas of up to 90 days over any 180-day period for Peru, a democratically stable state.  This will not only strengthen economic and cultural exchanges, but also promote political dialogue on issues of human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this agreement which will allow Peruvian citizens to travel without the need to have a visa to thirty European countries.  A decision that will have a direct impact on many citizens and will undoubtedly bring them even closer to two continents aimed at increasing their collaboration in the coming years.  That Peruvians can travel around Europe without a visa demonstrates good bilateral relations with a reliable and secure partner such as the Republic of Peru.  Trade-based relations, in which the Union is Peru's second export destination market and the fifth source of its imports. Data that, following the entry into force of the Trade Agreement in 2013, is increasing. On the political side, the European Union's recent Election Observation Mission on the occasion of the presidential elections, and its good reception by the Peruvian authorities, is another indicator of the state of such relations.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Gabriel report on the EU-Peru agreement on visa-free travel for short stays. The text establishes an exemption for CITIZENS of the Union and for citizens of Peru who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons regardless of the reason for the stay, provided that this is not linked to the performance of a paid activity. Peru is a key partner in the fight against organised crime.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to initiate negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and Peru, inter facilities, whose purpose is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Short-Term Visa Waiver Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and these countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  I voted for it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which strengthens the Association Agreement already signed with Colombia and Peru. This short-stay visa waiver is a new achievement in deepening EU-Peru relations as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This will strengthen regional coherence.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this agreement between the European Union and Peru on the exemption of short-stay visas. This text provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Peruvian nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. The policy of liberalisation that the Commission is constantly trying to impose on us in the context of the current migration crisis in the European Union seems to me to be completely irrelevant. The Commission argues that the fight against organised crime, including drug trafficking and human trafficking, will be greatly strengthened. On the one hand, I do not see any substantial benefit on these aspects through this agreement. On the other hand, I am concerned that the Commission may, despite a lucid observation on the risks posed by such an agreement, persist in wanting to open the borders of the European Union.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text on the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on short-stay visa waiver is well structured and has no problems, which is why I wanted to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on visa waiver for short-term stays, as this is a very satisfactory agreement by which the Spanish Socialists have worked for a long time. The Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the Union and Peru, as well as being a supplementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  In this way, the Agreement will strengthen regional coherence, as Peru is part of a minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa. Peru is a relatively stable democracy that defends, like the European Union, the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law, and remains an important partner in this area in Latin America. Human rights and democracy are essential elements of the relationship between the European Union and the Andean country.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation, in which the European Parliament approves the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on visa-free travel in the case of short stays. This agreement is the result of the development of relations between the EU and the Republic of Peru and an additional instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and promoting political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This agreement will help to strengthen the cohesion of the region, as Peru is one of the few Latin American countries whose citizens are still subject to visa requirements and will be a rather important factor for the peoples of Europe and the peruvian population. As regards the political and institutional situation, the Republic of Peru is a country of relatively stable democracy, as is the European Union defending the principles and values of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law, and which remains an important latin American partner in this area. Human rights and democracy are key elements of relations between the European Union and this Andea country. Strengthening democracy and human rights remain one of Peru's priorities, and the visa liberalisation agreement will help to continue a balanced, continuous and comprehensive political dialogue on human rights and on specific issues such as the situation of women.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The visa waiver agreement for short-stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, which is of great political importance, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. With regard to mobility, the available data show that the reliability of visa applicants is high and there are few applications rejected. The country poses no threat to irregular migration, security or public order. I also consider it important that the visa waiver is not a negligible means of eddation between the people of the European Union and the citizens of the country concerned. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the partnership in a full, cheaper and simpler way.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposed recommendation relating to the EU-Peru Visa Waiver Agreement. This agreement is the result of deepening EU-Peru relations and, at the same time, a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations between the two partners. I am also convinced that, following the adoption of the agreement, the situation in tourism and trade exchange will improve. The EU is Peru's third trading partner in the field of imports of machinery and transport equipment and its most important export partner for agri-food and mining products. Tourism is under strong growth in Peru, and since 2012 this sector has been the second most important economic sector in the country. I would also like to raise the issue of human rights, in which I believe that the visa liberalisation agreement will allow for a balanced political dialogue in the area of human rights, which is one of the fundamental postulates for the EU. Peru may also eventually become an important partner in the fight against organised crime, in particular drug trafficking and trafficking in human beings. At a time when the exchange of information on organised crime is extremely important, Peru's interest in concluding a strategic cooperation agreement for Europol is a very positive sign that could represent significant progress in strengthening EU-Peru cooperation in the fight against organised crime.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour this agreement, which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Peru when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special-passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this REPORT on the EU-Peru agreement on the abolition of short-stay visas. This is a significant step in deepening relations between the EU and Peru, and another way to accelerate economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. In view of the mass immigration faced by European states, I am opposed to any visa liberalisation. I therefore voted against this text.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support the new agreement between the European Union and Peru on short-stay visa waivers, as a privileged instrument to promote economic trade and promote the development of tourism in both territories. Peru is in fact one of the main emerging countries in Latin America, with stable and steady economic growth over the last ten years and a relatively solid democracy. For its part, the European Union is Peru's third largest trading partner in terms of imports, the main recipient of its exports, and the main foreign investor in that territory, particularly in the banking and extractive industries. I believe that this new mechanism will also make it possible to strengthen cultural relations between the two areas and to step up cooperation on a large number of issues, not least on the protection of human rights and the fight against drug trafficking.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The agreement of 14 March 2016, provisionally implemented pending approval by the European Parliament, provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Peruvian nationals for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. This visa exemption will benefit all categories of individuals except those engaged in paid work. The agreement is expected to boost tourism and help strengthen trade relations between the two sides. Although the situation has improved with regard to illegal migration from Peru, it seems to me quite inappropriate to conclude such an agreement at a time when the Member States of the European Union are experiencing an unprecedented influx of migrants. Therefore, I consider it essential that Peru remains a key partner in the fight against organised crime without liberalising visas in favour of their nationals. I therefore objected to this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU-Peru Agreement on short-stay visa waiver scans is a success for both the EU and Peru in deepening relations between the two sides, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and enhancing political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This agreement will contribute to the boosting of tourism, but also to strengthening trade and investment relations. Among all this, the opportunity for this agreement also lies in the possibility of a key partnership between the EU and the Republic of Peru in the fight against organised crime, in particular against drug trafficking and trafficking in human beings, which may be important areas of cooperation. All these arguments mentioned above led me to vote in favour of the report in question.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on visa waiver for short-term stays, as this is a very satisfactory agreement by which the Spanish Socialists have worked for a long time. The Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the Union and Peru, as well as being a supplementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  In this way, the Agreement will strengthen regional coherence, as Peru is part of a minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa. Peru is a relatively stable democracy that defends, like the European Union, the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law, and remains an important partner in this area in Latin America. Human rights and democracy are essential elements of the relationship between the European Union and the Andean country.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation today because I believe that the short-stay visa waiver agreement is an important stage in the process of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru. This measure is not only useful for strengthening economic and cultural relations, but also intensifies political dialogue on sensitive issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms. The agreement will boost tourism and help strengthen relations in the area of trade and investment. Peru, remember, with 5% in 2013 and 2.4% in 2014, recorded the strongest economic growth in Latin America. As far as trade is concerned, the EU is Peru's third largest trading partner for imports and the main recipient of its exports, mainly through agri-food and mining products. The Republic of Peru supports a number of investment projects, in particular in water infrastructure. The driving force is still the mining sector, but major diversification efforts are being made to launch tourism as much as possible. The tourism sector is experiencing a very strong expansion, becoming since 2012 the second sector of the Peruvian economy.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour this agreement, which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Peru when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special-passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of the agreement that allows visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and of the Republic of Peru on short-stay visits. I believe this will intensify the relationship between the EU and Peru and will effectively promote cultural communication, business collaboration and political dialogue.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Short-term visa waiver has political significance and marks an important stage in the EU's relations with other countries. It is also an instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Peru has met the requirements to access it.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru have strengthened considerably over the last decade to the point that the EU is now the main recipient of Peruvian exports as well as being the largest investor in the country. Political and economic stability are at the heart of the conditions which have made it possible to grant Peruvian citizens visa-free entry conditions into the territory of the Member States for short stays.  The visa agreement will make it possible to further strengthen relations between the two parties and to give new impetus to trade and the tourism sector, which has now become the second largest sector of the Peruvian economy. Cooperation with that country on the fight against organised crime, and in particular drug trafficking and trafficking in human beings, will be equally important. It bodes well for the signing of the strategic cooperation agreement between Peru and Europol.  I voted in favour of the mandate to conclude the EU-Peru agreement because I believe that there is no risk of illegal migration by Peruvian citizens, not least because the Peruvian Government's information campaign on visa provisions protects the EU from such phenomena.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. – We support the report as we believe that the agreement will, on the one hand, strengthen regional cohesion and, on the other, remain a not insignificant instrument for the mutual rapprochement of European and Peruvian citizens.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted today on the recommendation for the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on the short-stay visa waiver. Such moves contribute to the development of relations between the two sides and I believe that they work for the benefit of the citizens. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an 'Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on short-stay visa waivers', because I believe that the agreement could be an instrument for increasing economic, cultural and political relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and an instrument for strengthening relations in the field of trade and investment.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement with Peru comes after several others on visa waivers for short-stay stays. I agree with this proposal because I am convinced that giving greater freedom of movement can benefit both European citizens and the citizens of Peru. Having a better chance of travelling, without incurring long and complicated paperwork, will, in my opinion, greatly facilitate both the influx of tourists to Europe and the movement of entrepreneurs who are forced to travel often for work. Therefore, since the Republic of Peru is a stable democracy and an important partner in Latin America, it deserves equal treatment. For these reasons, I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report and had no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union carries out a visa policy, in particular with regard to the exemption of short-stay visas. This exemption is defined at European level as it is valid for all Member States except the United Kingdom and Ireland. Moreover, the various requirements for the conclusion of the agreement include reciprocity. In other words, European citizens also no longer need a visa.  It is up to the European Parliament to give its consent to the agreement for its establishment, which is thus given. For all this and because this Agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations with the Republic of Peru, I vote in favour of its celebration.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The conclusion of the bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru is a useful tool for strengthening economic, political and cultural relations. Furthermore, this result is positive for the intensification of dialogue on the issues of respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted in favour of the agreement, which also allows the harmonisation of the visa regime for the state of Peru with the other Latin American countries that have already liberalised the visa for short stays in third countries. The agreement will boost tourism and help strengthen trade and financial relations between the European Union and Peru. In addition, Peru can become an important partner in the fight against organised crime by cooperating strategically with the European Police Office.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Short-stay visa waiver agreements enhance cooperation with third countries, facilitating the movement of persons and trade. Once the established criteria are fulfilled such agreements are beneficial to the EU and its citizens. This vote will enhance political dialogue and strengthen the assessment needed for the opening of negotiations on bilateral visa waiver agreements with Peru.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this agreement in line with our position in favour of visa waiver. Despite disagreeing on how the negotiation procedure has been carried out, in an un transparent manner and without including democratic institutions such as the European Parliament therein, I agree with the proposed measures, which facilitate the freedom of movement of both Peruvian citizenship towards the European Union and European citizenship towards Peru , thereby reducing the restrictions that still exist on freedom of movement.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament has today given its consent to the conclusion of the EU-Peru Agreement on exemptions from short-stay visas. Peru is one of the few Latin American countries whose citizens need a visa to join the EU. The visa waiver agreement for short-stays could at the same time mean deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru, as well as a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue. The EU is Peru's third largest trading partner and the most important recipient of Peruvian exports. The EU is the largest investor in Peru, with more than half of foreign direct investment coming from the EU. It is important that the agreement contains a joint declaration on cooperation on irregular migration, in which the EU and Peru recall their commitment to take back their own irregular migrants. Last but not least, Peru could become a key partner in the fight against organised crime, such as drug trafficking and trafficking in human beings. This may also be a sign that the country is interested in signing a strategic cooperation agreement with the European Police Office.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Peru has seen economic growth of more than 80% in the last 10 years, making it one of the 10 fastest growing countries in the world when it comes to trade. Moreover, the EU remains the largest investor in Peru, which highlights the importance of this agreement in terms of continuing to support such market opportunities. In March this year, the EU concluded an agreement with the Republic of Peru on the short-stay visa waiver. This new visa regime allows Eu citizens to travel visa-free to Peru and peruvian citizens to travel visa-free to the EU for a period not exceeding 90 days in any 180-day period. In order to travel visa-free travel, Union citizens and Peruvian citizens must hold a valid ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport. However, the abolition of short-stay visas does not apply to persons travelling for gainful employment. This agreement is already in force on a provisional basis, as it has received unanimous support from the Governments of the Schengen States in the Council, but its final conclusion requires the prior consent of the European Parliament. The provisions of this agreement will not apply to the United Kingdom and Ireland, as their visa regimes are subject to national legislation. With this in mind, I voted in favour of the document.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this agreement, which represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement will open up opportunities and advantages for EU citizens too and could have positive effects by simplifying travel for businesspeople, facilitating investment and boosting tourism.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as it relates to the visa regime operated by Schengen Member States, from which the UK has opted out. However, I welcome the potential commercial and tourism benefits of this agreement.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today, the European Parliament issued a recommendation to the European Commission on the implementation and monitoring of the agreement signed on 9 June 2015 between the EU and the Republic of Peru on short-stay visa waivers. This agreement is an important element in the deepening of relations between the European Union and Peru, making it possible to further intensify economic, social and cultural relations between the two continents and to promote their political dialogue.  Through this recommendation, the Commission is today being asked to keep a close eye on possible developments in the criteria which made the agreement possible. These criteria include not only security, public order and the control of illegal immigration, but also the Union's external relations with the third country concerned, including in particular issues relating to respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. The measure also urges the Commission and the Peruvian authorities to ensure full reciprocity of the visa waiver in order to allow equal treatment of all citizens, in particular all CITIZENS of the Union. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This non-legislative report is a consultation with the European Parliament on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru. It aims to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas and provides for a visa-free travel regime for European and Peruvian citizens travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days.  Considering that this agreement between the European Union and Peru will strengthen their economic and cultural relations as well as intensify the political dialogue between the two sides, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against giving consent to this agreement. UKIP is opposed to the EU negotiating visa agreements with third countries.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and Peru on the exemption of short-stay visas. This agreement will deepen economic and cultural relations, as well as political dialogue between the European Union and the Republic of Peru. It was important, however, that this agreement be accompanied by the joint declaration on cooperation on irregular immigration in which the EU and Peru recall their commitments to readmission of their irregular migrants.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on short-stay visa waiver to strengthen economic, political and cultural relations between the European Union and Peru. The agreement will facilitate European trade in the Peruvian state where the EU is already present with numerous investment projects, in particular in water, transport and energy infrastructure. From a cultural point of view, greater movement of Peruvian citizens will help to promote tourism within the EU.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on the exemption from short-stay visas. The text gives a positive opinion on this agreement which will allow Peruvians to travel to the EU and European citizens to travel to Peru without the need to apply for a visa for any stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period. The exemption applies to all citizens with a valid ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport, travelling for any legitimate purpose except to perform a paid activity. For the latter, each Member State may individually decide whether to impose or withdraw the visa requirement for Peruvian citizens and Peru may choose to do the same for the citizens of each Member State. Peru was previously one of the minority countries in Latin America still subject to visa requirements. I hope that this visa exemption can deepen economic and cultural relations but also intensify the political dialogue including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The agreement signed on 14 March 2016, applied on an interim basis pending approval by the European Parliament, provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Peruvian nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for up to 90 days over any 180-day period. Visa exemption benefits all categories of people, except for paid work.  It aims to boost tourism and help strengthen trade and investment relations. Peru can also become a key partner in the fight against organized crime, including drug trafficking and human trafficking. However, cooperation in this area does not require visa liberalisation, but the opposite. In any event, being opposed to any visa liberalisation, I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation made by colleague Gabriel on visa-free travel for Union citizens and citizens of Peru. But I would like to express my great regret at the fact that the Commission has once again allowed myself not to include Parliament in the Joint Committee. After all, we, the representatives in Parliament, are chosen by the citizens to defend their views and desires.  I would like to address a rhetorical question to Mr Juncker and the Commission he led: Mr Juncker, if we had not today supported Mrs Gabriel's recommendation, what value would the EU-Peru agreement signed on 14 March 2016 ?!?

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Peru, unlike the other countries of the "Koton Agreement", but also other South American countries, does not represent any threat to the EU, either in terms of illegal immigration or in terms of security and public order. The low rate of rejections on VISA visas shows that there is a high degree of confidence in visa applicants. Finally, the short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and is a complementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Peru travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. This Agreement will boost tourism and help to strengthen trade and investment relations. Peru recorded one of the largest economic growth in Latin America (5% in 2013 and 2.4% in 2014). The country has experienced continuous growth of more than 80 % in the last ten years, placing it among the top ten countries in the world with the highest growth rate in the reference period. In addition, the EU remains the largest investor in Peru, accounting for more than 50% of total foreign direct investment in sectors such as the extraction industries, banking and finance.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: in the context of illegal mass immigration, we oppose any visa liberalisation.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of Member States of the European Union and for citizens of Peru travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. As in the case of other similar agreements recently approved, moving away from the rapporteur's instrumental view (focused on promoting business) we are not opposed to this facilitation of the movement of people, which is why we voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the EU and Peru. This instrument is essential to give a boost to the tourism sector, to trade and, more generally, to the European economy. The removal of visas will simplify economic and business relations between the EU and Peru, a country capable of offering legal security and political stability, essential guarantees for small and medium-sized enterprises. Cooperation between the two countries will not be limited to strengthening economic relations: Peru is a key partner in the fight against organised crime, in particular drug trafficking and trafficking in human beings, which are very important aspects for effective cooperation.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I support Visa—free travel in this case.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Taking into account in principle the positive assessment of May 2015, the Council adopted a decision on the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the EU and the Republic of Peru. The signed agreement allows EU citizens as well as Peruvian citizens to travel without a visa to the territories of both Parties for a period not exceeding 90 days. The visa waiver decision in question applies to all persons and travellers, with the exception of the pursuit of a paid activity. In particular, the EU expects this agreement to strengthen trade and investment relations, but also to increase tourism dynamism.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the short-stay visa waiver agreement.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the agreement because Peru, unlike the other countries of the 'Cotton Agreement' and other South American countries, does not represent any threat to the EU, either in terms of illegal immigration or in terms of security and public order. The low rate of rejections on VISA visas shows that there is a high degree of confidence in visa applicants. Finally, the short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and is a complementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas marks a significant milestone in the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The agreement will strengthen regional coherence, given that Peru is one of the minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa, and will have a significant impact on rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and Peru. I therefore voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement to provide visas for EU citizens for short stays. The agreement represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and another means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues. It would also strengthen regional coherence, as Peru is one of the few Latin American countries whose citizens need a visa and would thus make a major contribution to the convergence of European citizens and Peruvians. The agreement will strengthen trade and investment. The EU is Peru's third largest trading partner (mainly machinery and means of transport) and the most important importer of Peruvian exports (agri-food and mining products). In addition, the EU remains the largest investor in Peru, with more than 50% of foreign direct investment coming from the EU. Strengthening democracy and human rights remains an important issue for Peru, and the agreement on visa liberalisation can contribute to a balanced and in-depth political dialogue on human rights and specific issues such as the situation of women.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the decision establishing a visa-free travel regime for Citizens of the Union and nationals of Peru when the stay does not exceed 90 days for each 180-day period. I hope that the elimination of the need for a visa will further strengthen Peru's ties with the Union. Similarly, the Agreement will strengthen regional coherence, as Peru is part of a minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the EU-Peru Agreement on Visa Waiver for Short Stays, as this is a very satisfactory agreement under which the Spanish Socialists have worked for a long time. The Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the Union and Peru, as well as being a supplementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  In this way, the Agreement will strengthen regional coherence, as Peru is part of a minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa. Peru is a stable democracy that defends, like the Union, the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law, and remains an important partner in this area in Latin America. Human rights and democracy are essential elements of the relationship between the Union and the Andean country.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on visa waiver for short stays, as this is a very satisfactory agreement by which the Spanish Socialists have worked for a long time. The Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the Union and Peru, as well as being a supplementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  In this way, the Agreement will strengthen regional coherence, as Peru is part of a minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa. Peru is a relatively stable democracy that defends, like the European Union, the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law, and remains an important partner in this area in Latin America. Human rights and democracy are essential elements of the relationship between the European Union and the Andean country.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as I believe that its implementation will be mutually beneficial to the EU and Peru. In terms of economics, it will be easier for tourists to travel between Peru and the EU and it will serve to improve the trade and investment relations between us. The agreement will also serve to improve the EU’s political dialogue with Peru and it will help us cooperate in areas where we share common interests such as fighting organised crime and trafficking.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on visa-free travel for short stays. This agreement represents the final step in a process aimed at strengthening diplomatic, cultural, social and economic relations between the EU and Peru and will give a stronger boost to the process of strengthening democratic institutions and the rule of law in the Andean country.  The agreement provides for visa-free travel for EU and Peruvian citizens travelling to Peru and the Member States of the European Union respectively for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. This exemption will be applied regardless of the reason for the stay, unless it is a paid activity that requires normal procedures. Finally, it helps to give a strong boost to tourism, trade relations and economic growth, and to greater vigour in relations with Peru. Nevertheless, it can facilitate and make more effective the fight against organised crime, in particular drug trafficking and trafficking in human beings in the territories of both contracting parties.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. The EU-Peru Visa Waiver Agreement is one of many newly concluded in recent weeks. This is the simplified issue of short visas, such as those needed for holiday or business stays. I think that such a form of simplification makes sense and have therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the visa-free regime between the European Union and the Republic of Peru. It will apply to all groups of people and all travel purposes, except for for stays for profit. The visa waiver is valid for a maximum of 90 days in a period of 180 days.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this agreement, which will allow visa-free travel between EU Member States, other than the UK, and Peru. The agreement would not affect the UK, which has its own national visa agreements with this country.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to initiate negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and Peru, inter facilities, whose purpose is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Short-Term Visa Waiver Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and these countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on the short-stay visa waiver.  The agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is essential for deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru. It will strengthen economic and cultural relations and deepen political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The agreement can also provide an opportunity to improve regional cohesion – as Peru is one of the minorities of Latin American countries whose citizens still need visas – and is a significant factor in the rapprochement between Europeans and Peruvians.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Although this agreement will not affect the UK because it has its own national visa agreements with Peru, I support the move to enable visa-free travel between other EU Member States and Peru – promoting further economic and cultural relations.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The new visa regime provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens when travelling to the territory of Peru and for citizens of Peru when travelling to the EU, for a period of stay of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on visa waiver for short-term stays, as this is a very satisfactory agreement by which the Spanish Socialists have worked for a long time. The Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the Union and Peru, as well as being a supplementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  In this way, the Agreement will strengthen regional coherence, as Peru is part of a minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa. Peru is a relatively stable democracy that defends, like the European Union, the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law, and remains an important partner in this area in Latin America. Human rights and democracy are essential elements of the relationship between the European Union and the Andean country.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the agreement on a visa waiver for short-stay peruvian citizens. However, we are critical of the chosen procedure which leaves Parliament out and is simply asked for approval by it.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement although the United Kingdom and Ireland will not participate in the agreement and are therefore not subject to its provisions. This agreement on a waiver of short-stay visas marks a significant milestone in the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The agreement will strengthen regional coherence, given that Peru is one of the minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa, and will have a significant impact on rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and Peru.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement as I have no objections to the agreement’s effects.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution provides for a reciprocal exemption from the short-stay visa requirement, up to a maximum of 90 days within a 180-day period, between the EU-Schengen states and the Republic of Peru. Since this visa waiver applies only if the traveller or travellers will not carry out a paid activity in the destination country during their stay and an official identification document must be available, there is no risk of irregular labour migration. On the contrary, this agreement simplifies travel, establishes personal contacts and strengthens the tourist economy. I voted in favour of the agreement for these reasons. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I have decided to approve the implementation of the agreement between Peru and the European Union on the exemption of the short-stay visa requirement because analyses have shown that the risk of irregular immigration from that country has fallen sharply and the provisions of this agreement do not apply to French Guiana. In addition, the Peruvian authorities have committed to facilitating the readmission of their irregular migrants. The agreement, which was already signed in March but was due to be submitted to the European Parliament as part of the consultation procedure, provides for a reciprocity regime. Thus, the visa exemption will also apply to European citizens travelling to Peru for up to 90 days over any 180-day period.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. In favour of this document, it favours the exemption of visas for short-term stays and is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that this agreement will deepen the relationship between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and that it is also a way of stepping up economic and cultural relations. I also believe that political dialogue should be intensified on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on the waiver of short-stay visas on the basis that it deepens relations between the two countries. Staying on the territory of another contracting party without a visa will allow to strengthen economic and cultural relations, tourism, and trade and investment. The Union is the largest investor in Peru, and the conclusion of this agreement is of utmost importance in order to strengthen regional coherence, cooperation on irregular migration, and dialogue on fundamental freedoms and human rights. I therefore support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The agreement - signed on 14 March 2016 and applied on an interim basis pending approval by the European Parliament - provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Peruvian nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for up to 90 days over any 180-day period.  Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official, or special) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity. At a time when Europe is suffering from uncontrolled immigration, it seemed only natural to me to be against visa liberalisation.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on visa waiver for short-term stays, as this is a very satisfactory agreement by which the Spanish Socialists have worked for a long time. The Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the Union and Peru, as well as being a supplementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  In this way, the Agreement will strengthen regional coherence, as Peru is part of a minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa. Peru is a relatively stable democracy that defends, like the European Union, the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law, and remains an important partner in this area in Latin America. Human rights and democracy are essential elements of the relationship between the European Union and the Andean country.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of an agreement between the EU and Peru that will allow visa-free travel for citizens of both parties on short stays of a maximum of 90 days. This agreement is a milestone in the deepening of relations between the Union and the Peruvians. Peru has one of the fastest economies in Latin America, and EU countries are among the biggest investors. I believe that granting visa-free travel will promote tourism and lead to even more intensive trade relations and more investment. Visa-free travel will also make life easier for students, tourists or diplomats. It is also another way to intensify cultural relations and strengthen political dialogue with Peru, including on human rights and fundamental freedoms, good governance and the rule of law.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposed exemption on the visa requirement for Peruvian nationals. This text concludes an agreement with the Republic of Peru to simplify the process and facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas for Peruvian and European nationals. This is a visa-free travel scheme for a stay of up to 2 months over a period of 4 months. This will strengthen cultural exchanges between Europeans and Peru, allowing for increased circulation and mobility. This exemption proposal was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the conclusion of an agreement with the Republic of Peru to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of my colleague's report as the short-stay visa waiver agreement completes the deepening of the European Union's relations with the Republic of Peru, and is a complementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report deals with the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on the visa waiver for short stays. However, as cooperation between the EU and Peru on irregular migration should be stepped up and the competences of a visa waiver for short stays for Peruvian citizens should remain with the Member States, I do not believe that there is currently any need to agree to this exemption.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as I support this agreement to enable visa-free travel between EU Member States, other than the UK, and Peru. The agreement would not affect the UK, which has its own national visa agreements with this country.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. This agreement will make it easier for both tourists and businesses to travel between and the EU and Peru, further opening up access to one of the fastest growing economies in the world over the last 10 years. At the same time, it is ensured that there are satisfactory controls on arrivals from Peru to the EU. At the same time, more formalised cooperation has been established between the Peruvian authorities and Europol for cooperation in the fight against organised and cross-border crime. Against this background, I have chosen to support the agreement.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing.
