The European Parliament resolution provides for a reciprocal exemption from the short-stay visa requirement, up to a maximum of 90 days within a 180-day period, between the EU-Schengen states and the Republic of Peru. Since this visa waiver applies only if the traveller or travellers will not carry out a paid activity in the destination country during their stay and an official identification document must be available, there is no risk of irregular labour migration. On the contrary, this agreement simplifies travel, establishes personal contacts and strengthens the tourist economy. I voted in favour of the agreement for these reasons.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 This Recommendation deals with the adoption of the bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru, which provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of Peru when travelling in the territory of the other Contracting Party. Deepening the Union's relations with third countries, in this case the Republic of Peru, can benefit the tourism, trade and investment sectors and promote political dialogue on the protection of human rights in the country. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Although the rapporteur for this report insists that visa waiver is justified in order to facilitate the soon-to-be-soaring economic and trade relations, I do not see any realistic chance of this in the light of Peruvian products and services. It is much more likely that certain lobbying interests are behind it. In fact, neither business nor personal relationships are hindered by the current system. It is also not insignificant that crime statistics relating to Peruvians are not rosy either.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on behalf of the European Parliament to conclude an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on the abolition of short-stay visas providing for visa-free travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a period not exceeding 90 days within any period of 180 days covering all categories of persons travelling for any purpose, with the exception of the pursuit of a lucrative activity.  This Agreement deepens the relationship between the Contracting Parties and is an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural ties, intensifying political dialogue on key topics, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The main objective of enhanced cooperation is the partnership with Peru in the field of combating organised crime, in particular trafficking in human beings and drugs.  The agreement will help strengthen trade and investment relations and also have an impact in the tourism sector, which is second in importance to the Peruvian economy. At the same time, it contains a clear commitment to readmission of illegal immigrants and thus constitutes an additional means of combating irregular migration.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Peru is an important political and economic partner for the EU in Latin America. The agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas is an important step in deepening EU relations with Peru, which are built on political dialogue, trade and development cooperation and cover a wide range of bilateral, regional and multilateral issues. Тhe visa waiver will deepen trade links among businesses and will facilitate investment. In particular, visa liberalisation is likely to further increase tourist flows between the EU and Peru. Nevertheless, there are concerns that visa liberalisation will increase the level of irregular migration and human and drug trafficking. In order to prevent this from happening, the EU should further enhance and strengthen cooperation with Peru in the fight against irregular migration and organised crime. In that regard, the EU should welcome efforts made by the Peruvian Government in conducting an information campaign that explains to Peruvian citizens the key provisions of the visa waiver agreement. I supported the EU-Peru agreement on the short-stay visa waiver because it will deepen political and economic relations between the EU and Peru.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. This agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru is another instrument aimed at strengthening mutual economic and cultural relations and increasing political dialogue on various aspects, such as human rights and fundamental freedoms. The agreement is capable of providing a strong boost to tourism and will help to strengthen relations in the field of trade and investment; This has enabled Peru to experience the strongest economic growth in Latin America in the last ten years. With regard to trade, the EU ranks as Peru's third largest trading partner in terms of imports and the main recipient of its exports. Peru can become a key partner in the fight against organised crime, in particular drug trafficking and trafficking in human beings, which can be important aspects of cooperation.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement between the European Union and Peru on the exemption of short-stay visas. The rapporteur calls on the European Commission to look at possible developments in the criteria for illegal immigration, public order and security, confirming, in a clear way, that there are many important problems.  The report also mentions that Peru could become a key partner in the fight against organized crime, including drug trafficking and human trafficking, which can be important aspects of cooperation. This is a bit of a bizarre observation, because cooperation in this area does not require visa liberalisation, on the contrary. Rather, visa exemption is likely to widen the problems. Furthermore, in the context of illegal mass immigration, I oppose any further visa liberalisation.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The text validates the agreement signed on 14 March 2016 by the European Union and Peru. It allows citizens to travel to both countries without visas, for a maximum of 90 days, over a total period of 180 days (outside of paid work). Although the rapporteur stresses the benefits to be derived from it, such as strengthening the fight against organised crime and drug trafficking, the report is a way of amplifying them, not countering them. Of course tourism could benefit, but I believe that the situation of massive migration crisis in which Europe is plunged will not improve, on the contrary. So I voted against it.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on visa waiver for short-term stays, as this is a very satisfactory agreement by which the Spanish Socialists have worked for a long time. The Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the Union and Peru, as well as being a supplementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  In this way, the Agreement will strengthen regional coherence, as Peru is part of a minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa. Peru is a relatively stable democracy that defends, like the European Union, the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law, and remains an important partner in this area in Latin America. Human rights and democracy are essential elements of the relationship between the European Union and the Andean country.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on visa waiver for short-term stays, as this is a very satisfactory agreement by which the Spanish Socialists have worked for a long time. The Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the Union and Peru, as well as being a supplementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  In this way, the Agreement will strengthen regional coherence, as Peru is part of a minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa. Peru is a relatively stable democracy that defends, like the European Union, the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law, and remains an important partner in this area in Latin America. Human rights and democracy are essential elements of the relationship between the European Union and the Andean country.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this agreement in line with our position in favour of visa waiver. Despite disagreeing on how the negotiation procedure has been carried out, in an un transparent manner and without including democratic institutions such as the European Parliament therein, I agree with the proposed measures, which facilitate the freedom of movement of both Peruvian citizenship towards the European Union and European citizenship towards Peru , thereby reducing the restrictions that still exist on freedom of movement.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. Since 14 March 2016, this Agreement, which has so far been provisional, allows nationals of the Republic of Peru not to need a visa to cross the external borders of the Member States, and therefore needs to be approved as soon as possible, as it is an advantage for both, since the relationship between the Union and Peru already has settled roots. Peru is one of the fastest growing Latin American countries, with a 5% increase in 2013 and 2.4% in 2014, but not only in Latin America, but one of the ten fastest-making countries in the world; in 10 years it has had a continuous growth of 80%. This agreement is a fundamental pillar for tourism, trade, investment (the Union is Peru's main investor), Peru's strengthening of human rights and fundamental freedoms, and generally benefits economic and cultural relations. For all this and because it can be an approach to Peru being our main partner against organized crime, in terms of drug trafficking and trafficking in human beings, I vote in favour.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution provides for a reciprocal exemption from the short-stay visa requirement, up to a maximum of 90 days within a 180-day period, between the EU-Schengen states and the Republic of Peru. Since this visa waiver applies only if the traveller or travellers will not carry out a paid activity in the destination country during their stay and an official identification document must be available, there is no risk of irregular labour migration. On the contrary, this agreement simplifies travel, establishes personal contacts and strengthens the tourist economy. I voted in favour of the agreement for these reasons.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of allowing a visa waiver for Peruvian and European Union citizens when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for periods of less than 90 days. Due regard has been given to non-Schengen Member States.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I usually vote in the case of visa-free travel in the case of nearby or trouble-free countries or where the rate of visa refusals has been low in the past. In the case of Peru, the ratio of rejected applications was relatively high (6.1% in 2014), and the Zika virus is now at risk of spreading from this Latin American country.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EU is Peru's third trading partner when it comes to imports (mainly machinery and transport equipment) and its main export partner (agri-food products and ores). In addition, the EU remains the largest investor in Peru and is responsible for more than 50% of all foreign direct investment in sectors such as banking and finance. The Republic of Peru has a relatively stable democracy and in this regard is an important partner of the Union in Latin America.  The short-stay visa waiver agreement will deepen relations between the EU and the Republic of Peru and further strengthen economic and cultural relations and political dialogue on human rights and fundamental freedoms. It will also allow for strengthening regional coherence, as Peru is one of the few Latin American states whose nationals still need a visa. The agreement also contains a joint declaration on cooperation on irregular migration, so Peru can become a key partner in the fight against organised crime, in particular drug and human trafficking. In my view, the abolition of a short-term stay visa is a necessary factor in the EU-Peru rapprochement process, so I supported this recommendation.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement signed on 14 March 2016 provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Peru when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. In my view, the agreement marks a significant milestone in the deepening of relations between the European Union and Peru and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The conclusion of this Agreement abolishes visas for Peruvian citizens for short stays when crossing the Borders of the Union for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. This right applies to all persons other than those travelling in the exercise of a paid activity.  Peru has seen the strongest continuous economic growth in Latin America in the last ten years, at more than 80%, making it one of the top 10 countries in the world. The agreement will strengthen mutual trade and investment, expand tourism and help consolidate and stabilise democracy in Peru.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the Recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on the short-stay visa waiver, because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report.  This report relates to an agreement signed on 14 March 2016 which provides for a visa-free regime for citizens of the European Union and Peru for short-term stays (maximum duration of 90 days over any 180-day period).  Peru is a relatively stable state whose nationals have little difficulty obtaining Schengen visas. Nevertheless, given the real dangers of drug trafficking in Peru, we cannot approve this agreement.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – Regarding the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on the short-stay visa waiver, I voted in favour, as the implementation of this agreement will undoubtedly strengthen the rapprochement between the European Union and Peru. The Republic of Peru is a democratic country and supports equivalent values to those of the European Union. Its economic growth rate has been more than 80% for the past 10 years, one of the highest rates of growth in Latin America. Around 43% of applicants received multiple-entry visas in 2014, and the visa rejection rate in 2015 was only 3%. All above, this proves the need to implement the agreement on the short-stay visa waiver.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a draft report that would break the visa requirement between the EU and the Republic of Peru for short stays. I see this agreement as a step towards deepening EU-Peru relations, as well as a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and deepening political dialogue on a number of different issues. This agreement will certainly also contribute to strengthening trade and investment relations. The EU is Peru's third most important trading partner and largest investor. I supported the deal.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is the vote on the short-stay visa waiver agreement with Peru. In my view, however, this measure is incomprehensible. On the one hand, Peru still has problems in the area of human rights, and on the other hand, this decision should be left to the nation states themselves.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. When cooperation with certain third countries permits, a reciprocal short-stay visa exemption (mainly for tourism) is negotiated. The Council, representing the states, decides. The criteria observed are as much the political situation, respect for human rights, as the absence of "risk of irregular migration". This is Peru, with which the EU has signed specific free trade and readmission agreements (return of migrants).  Considering, however, that Peru is one of the only countries in Latin America whose citizens do not yet have a short-stay visa exemption to travel to the EU, I vote in support. I also voted in favour of this exemption for Colombia in the previous voting session. I stress, however, that Parliament's request for consent is again indicative of the EU's pantomime of democracy, since the agreement has in fact already been in force since last March.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because the rapporteur only invites the European Commission to observe possible developments with regard to the criteria for illegal immigration, public order and security, when the problems are enormous. In the context of illegal mass immigration, we oppose any visa liberalisation.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Peru travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days.  In order to ensure equal treatment of all EU citizens, a provision has been included in the agreement under which Peru can suspend or denounce the agreement only for all Member States of the European Union and, conversely, the Union may suspend or denounce the agreement for all its Member States. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Peru when travelling in the other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I supported this resolution as it is an opportunity to deepen economic relations and develop tourism.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I am pleased that Peru is now one of the third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to travel within the Schengen area. Following the positive assessment of the situation in Peru, the agreement between the UNION and the Republic was signed on 14 March 2016. This agreement represents a further step towards increased cooperation between the two sides in areas such as trade, investment and tourism.  I am also pleased that, under this enhanced cooperation, the Union and Peru can become partners in the fight against organised crime, including human trafficking. More broadly, I welcome the strengthening of the coherence of our policy towards the South American continent, since thanks to this agreement, Peru is leaving the minority of countries on the continent whose nationals are not exempt from visas.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The agreement on short-stay visa waiver is the result of the successful completion of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Peru, as well as a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The agreement in question will bring dynamism to tourism and will contribute to strengthening trade and investment relations. The Union is the largest investor in Peru, representing more than 50% of all foreign direct investment in sectors such as mining, banks and finance. Peru supports many investment projects, in particular in the areas of infrastructures in the water, transport or even energy sectors. Human rights and democracy are key elements of the relationship between the European Union and Peru. The consolidation of democracy and human rights remains a priority for Peru, and the visa liberalisation agreement will allow a balanced, regular and intensified political dialogue on human rights and on specific topics such as the situation of women to continue. I therefore express my support for this proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement, which will be a step forward in the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru. It represents an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council adopted a decision on 19 May 2015 authoring the Commission to enter into negotiations with a deal to conclude a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on the exemption from short-stay visas. Negotiations began on 20 May 2015 and the parties corked the agreement on 9 June 2015. The Council adopted a draft decision on the ratification of the agreement, but it must also obtain Parliament's consent. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs points out that the Republic of Peru is a relatively stable democracy that, like the European Union, stands by the values and principles of democracy, good governance, human rights and the rule of law. The vast majority of Schengen visa claimants also receive short-stay visas, with the rejection rate around 6.1% in 2014 and around 3.0% in 2015. In 2014, 43% of applicants received multiple-entry visas. On this basis, the report recommends that Parliament agree with the Council's draft decision. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The agreement was signed on 14 March 2016 and applied on an interim basis pending approval by the European Parliament.  It provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Peruvian nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.  Even if Peru is not a country of origin of the majority migration flows in France, in the context of illegal mass immigration, we oppose any visa liberalisation and vote against this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Agreement is part of the effort to deepen the European Union's relations with the Republic of Peru. As regards trade relations, the EU is Peru's third largest trading partner in terms of imports and the main recipient of its exports. This agreement could have a strong impact on the tourism sector as it facilitates the entry and exit of citizens, helping to strengthen economic, investment and cultural relations between the two continents. The agreement concluded between the Union and Peru provides for visa-free travel for both Union citizens and citizens of Peru, who travel to the territory of one of the Contracting Parties for a period of not more than 90 days for each period of 180 days. However, Member States which do not fully implement the schengen area acquis communautaire are excluded from the application of this agreement.  In this regard, I am voting in favour, because I believe that this agreement will strengthen relations between the Union and the Republic of Peru.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. In a context of mass immigration, I oppose any visa liberalisation and therefore this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support this agreement to enable visa-free travel between EU Member States, other than the UK, and Peru. The agreement would not affect the UK, which has its own national visa agreements with this country.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides, in a reciprocal manner and for short-term stays, a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Peruvian nationals. This agreement will strengthen the economic and cultural ties that bind Peru to our continent.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mariya Gabriel's report. The European Parliament had to give its approval to the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru, which has already been negotiated between the Republic of Peru and the European Commission. According to the approval procedure, the LIBE Committee could make procedural changes only, not relating to the content of the agreement, but it only adopted a favourable recommendation for the plenary to approve the conclusion of the agreement.  The aim of the proposal is to reach an agreement with the Republic of Peru to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas. The agreement takes into account the situation of Member States that do not apply the Schengen acquis in its entirety. It provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and nationals of the Republic of Peru who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over the entire 180-day period. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official, or special) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on short-stay visa waiver is another tool for strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on the exemption from short-stay visas will facilitate closer cooperation between the two areas. Peru is one of the countries on the South American continent where we have seen a dynamic expansion of economic growth in recent times. In addition, the agreement will have a positive impact on tourism, investment and trade. Furthermore, Peru could become a key partner in the fight against organised crime. I wished to contribute to this by voting.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement, which will provide for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Peru when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum stay of 90 days in any 180-day period. The agreement will also improve economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on issues including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour this agreement, which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Peru when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special-passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because I believe that there is no need for a short-stay visa waiver and that the powers should remain with the Member States.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Visa waivers will help to promote economic, political and cultural relations between the EU and Peru.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The adoption of this Visa Waiver Agreement for short-term stays is a major step in deepening relations between the European Union and Peru.  There is no doubt that the Agreement will be accompanied by increased trade between the two partners as well as dialogue on political and fundamental rights issues, so I can only rejoice and welcome it.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I welcome the conclusion of this agreement. In particular, this agreement will enable the development of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and the strengthening of economic and cultural relations, as well as political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. It should be noted that Peru is one of the few Latin American countries whose citizens are still subject to visa requirements, so this agreement will also be one of the factors that will help to strengthen the cohesion of the region in order to facilitate the integration of individuals. The visa waiver agreement will promote tourism and contribute to strengthening trade and investment links. It should be noted that the agreement includes a joint declaration on cooperation in the field of irregular migration.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against giving consent to this agreement. UKIP is opposed to the EU negotiating visa agreements with third countries.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of my colleague's proposal because I believe that the extension of the short-stay visa waiver to the Republic of Peru contributes to the marked improvement of political, economic and trade relations between the EU on the one hand and the Republic of Peru on the other. The sharing of the Union's values, the principles of democracy and the rule of law make Peru an essential partner for the European Union. Similarly, the strong trade relations that have long linked us to this country lead me to welcome this proposal. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Peru is one of the few Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa to enter EU countries. If the European Union wants to deepen relations with the Republic of Peru, it must start leading a dialogue that will go towards strengthening economic and cultural ties and abolishing visas.  The EU is Peru's third trading partner when it comes to imports (mainly machinery and transport equipment) and its main export partner (agri-food products and ores), so signing this agreement is very important as it will intensify trade and mutual investment even further. Peru is a country based on democratic principles, so visa liberalisation will also allow for political dialogue in the field of human rights.  Peru can also become a key partner in the fight against organised crime, in particular drug and human trafficking, which can be an important part of cooperation. I am firmly convinced that the signing of this agreement will contribute not only to enhanced mobility, but also to our better cooperation with each other, and that both parties to the signatory will benefit from this.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. I regret that the Schengen agreements prohibit France from deciding which countries it wants to grant this kind of provision or not. In the current context of mass immigration to Europe, I am also opposed to any visa liberalisation. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The agreement on the abolition of short-stay visas is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This Agreement will also allow for strengthening regional coherence, as Peru is one of the few Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa and is a non-negtiable factor in the process of bringing european and Peruvian peoples closer. Peru can become a key partner in the fight against organised crime, in particular drug and human trafficking, which can be an important part of cooperation. The interest expressed by this country in signing a strategic cooperation agreement with Europol is a positive sign and can mean important progress in strengthening EU-Peru cooperation in the fight against organised crime. The multitude of common challenges of the European Union and the Republic of Peru shows that it is important and necessary to strengthen their cooperation through the Agreement on the abolition of short-stay visas, and I will therefore vote positively on this decision.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Peru who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. For the above, the vote in favor.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and Peru, as I consider it to be a very important milestone in mutual relations. It opens up space not only to strengthen economic and cultural cooperation, to a deeper political dialogue on the protection of human rights and freedoms, but also to improve cooperation in the fight against organised crime and drug trafficking. It should also be noted that there has been a clear improvement in recent years in asylum applications, forced returns and unregulated migration from that country, with only 3% of visa applicants rejected in 2015. Peru has signed a strategic cooperation agreement with Europol.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The signed agreement establishes visa-free travel for EU citizens and peru citizens travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of stays aimed at carrying out a paid activity. I would like to point out that Peru recorded the strongest economic growth in Latin America (5% in 2013, 2.4% in 2014). As far as trade is concerned, the EU is Peru's third largest trading partner in terms of imports (mainly machinery and transport equipment) and the main recipient of its exports (agri-food and mining products). I am convinced that this agreement can foster cooperation between the EU-Peru and create more opportunities for growth for both sides. I therefore voted in favour of adopting this agreement.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In March, the EU concluded an agreement with the Republic of Peru on the short-stay visa waiver. This new visa regime allows Eu citizens to travel visa-free to Peru and peruvian citizens to travel visa-free to the EU for a period not exceeding 90 days in any 180-day period. Peru has seen economic growth of more than 80% over the past 10 years. In terms of trade, the EU is Peru's third largest trading partner in terms of imports and the main destination for exported goods. Moreover, the EU remains the largest investor in Peru, which highlights the importance of this agreement in terms of continuing to support such market opportunities. Peru has also expressed an interest in signing a strategic cooperation agreement with the European Police Office (Europol), which would mark significant progress in strengthening cooperation between the EU and Peru in the fight against organised crime. The ECR recognises all the more the importance and necessity of further stimulating and strengthening this cooperation through the short-stay visa waiver agreement. Such agreements are one way of stimulating people-to-people contacts with the citizens of the countries with which they are concluded, increasing trade opportunities through increased tourism and promoting the popularisation of business relations between the EU and these countries. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved the agreement signed between the European Union and Peru to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas for European and Peruvian citizens. Nationals of both zones will now be able to travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Agreement was signed on 14 March 2016 and applies provisionally, depending on the approval of the European Parliament. It provides not only for the simplification of the procedure for issuing short-stay visas between the Contracting Parties, but also for visa-free travel for CITIZENS of the European Union and citizens of Peru for short stays.  In fact, I believe that the adoption of this Agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru. This will also be a means of strengthening cultural and economic relations between the parties, with the Peruvian economy being one of the fastest growing in South America.  At the same time, the Republic of Peru is a stable democracy, as the agreement will also allow political dialogue to be intensified on issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms.  On illegal immigration, the agreement contains - and well - a declaration of joint cooperation, in which both sides recall their commitment to the readmission of undocumented immigrants. For the foregoing, I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against giving consent to this agreement. UKIP is opposed to the EU negotiating visa agreements with third countries.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on the short-stay visa exemption, signed on 14 March 2016 and provisionally implemented pending approval by the European Parliament. As a result of this agreement, EU citizens and Peruvian nationals will no longer need a visa to travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period. The visa exemption applies to all citizens holding a valid passport, regardless of the reason for the trip, other than paid activity.  This agreement is a good step forward in deepening relations between the Union and Peru. It will boost tourism and help strengthen trade and investment relations. It will also allow for a regular and in-depth political dialogue on issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms. Finally, cooperation between the EU and Peru will be beneficial in the fight against organised crime, including drug trafficking and human trafficking.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and is an additional and essential means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on visa waiver for short-term stays, as this is a very satisfactory agreement by which the Spanish Socialists have worked for a long time. The Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the Union and Peru, as well as being a supplementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  In this way, the Agreement will strengthen regional coherence, as Peru is part of a minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa. Peru is a relatively stable democracy that defends, like the European Union, the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law, and remains an important partner in this area in Latin America. Human rights and democracy are essential elements of the relationship between the European Union and the Andean country.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report which gives the European Parliament the approval of the agreement between the EU and Peru on the short-stay visa exemption signed on 14 March 2016. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Peruvian nationals in the territory of the other contracting party. The stay is for up to 90 days over the entire 180-day period. I voted in favour of this visa exemption in particular because Peru is a relatively stable democracy that, like the European Union, defends the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because, as early as October 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a directive on the protection of the environment and the environment. The European Commission has adopted a report detailing Peru's compliance with the criteria for granting visa-free travel to this country. In view of the positive results of the evaluation, in May 2015 the Council, by decision, authorised the Commission to open negotiations on the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the EU and Peru. The agreement was signed in March 2016 and has so far been applied provisionally, pending its approval by the European Parliament. The visa-free regime shall allow those travelling to the territory of a Contracting Party to be present for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement will strengthen economic and cultural relations between the EU and Peru, promote political dialogue, tourism and contribute to strengthening trade and investment relations.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After a comprehensively positive assessment, the Commission initiated negotiations for a bilateral agreement between the European Union (EU) and the Republic of Peru on visa-free travel in May 2015. Signed in March 2016, the agreement was applied provisionally pending approval by the European Parliament.  The agreement provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of Peru, who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party, for a maximum period of 90 days for each total period of 180 days. This agreement results from the deepening of relations between the EU and Peru following the Trade Agreement and is an additional means of intensifying political dialogue.  Peru recorded one of the largest economic growth in South America, with continuous growth of more than 80 % in the last 10 years. In addition, it is a country that has shown a relatively stable democracy, linked to the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law.  As this is an important partner in Latin America, with which balanced political dialogue will be strengthened on a regular basis, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and Peru on the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Peruvian nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the parliamentary majority, I voted in favour of the recommendation on the conclusion of the EU-Peru agreement on short-stay visa waiver. The European Union is not new to making agreements of this kind, in fact, during the June plenary session the European Parliament was called upon to give its approval to a series of agreements aimed at exempting visa-free citizens from third countries who travel to Europe for short periods. I welcome this type of simplification, which seems to me to be in line with one of the pillars on which the EU itself is founded, namely the right to free movement. At a very gloomy time for the Union, when nationalist pressures have produced the results we are all aware of, this administrative simplification seems to me to be an important sign of Europe's openness to the outside world and an interesting move from an economic point of view as well. That is why I voted in favour of the text before us.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to initiate negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and Peru, inter facilities, whose purpose is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Short-Term Visa Waiver Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and these countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the EU-Peru Agreement: Visa Waiver for Short Stays. It allows EU and Perun citizens to stay in the other country for 90 days without a visa. However, this does not apply to employment.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement, which provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Peru – who I know have been looking forward to this moment – when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons, from ordinary to official, travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I firmly believe that this agreement is a significant step in the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru. I feel confident that it will simplify the lives of many, strengthen economic and cultural relations, and help in improving the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this agreement in line with our position in favour of visa waiver. Despite disagreeing on how the negotiation procedure has been carried out, in an un transparent manner and without including democratic institutions such as the European Parliament therein, I agree with the proposed measures, which facilitate the freedom of movement of both Peruvian citizenship towards the European Union and European citizenship towards Peru , thereby reducing the restrictions that still exist on freedom of movement.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Through the recommendation adopted today, the European Parliament has come out in favour of the visa waiver agreement for EU citizens and peru citizens travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The Republic of Peru is an important trading partner for the European Union in Latin America: the country has experienced steady growth over the last ten years of more than 80%, which places it among the top ten countries in the world that have experienced the strongest growth in that period. In addition, the EU continues to be Peru's largest investor, accounting for more than 50% of total foreign direct investment, in sectors such as mining, banking and finance. Since this agreement is an important instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations between the two countries, I have decided to vote in favour of this recommendation.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against giving consent to this agreement. UKIP is opposed to the EU negotiating visa agreements with third countries.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ While this agreement will not affect the UK, as it has its own national visa agreements with Peru, I support this agreement which will enable visa-free travel between other EU Member States and Peru.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the signed agreement allowing European Union citizens and Peruvian citizens to travel without a visa to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not actually reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the agreement on short-stay visa waiver between the EU and Peru, as it is one of the important means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue. A positive assessment of Peru's progress has persuaded the Council to authorise the Commission in May 2015 to open negotiations on the conclusion of this bilateral agreement. Negotiations progressed relatively quickly and an agreement was signed in Brussels as early as March 2016. The agreement provides for the opening up of the possibility for Union citizens and Peruvians to travel without a visa to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. This visa waiver applies to all categories of persons except those made for the purpose of paid activity. I am convinced that the agreement will contribute to the convergence of the European and Peruvian populations, but above all it will bring dynamism to tourism and contribute to strengthening trade and investment relations. Peru is currently experiencing one of the highest economic growth rates in Latin America, with the country growing more than 80% in the last ten years. At the same time, the EU is Peru's third trading partner in imports and the main beneficiary of its exports. Most of the investment in Peru comes from the EU, so I believe that new opportunities are opening up opportunities for both sides in this area.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution provides for a reciprocal exemption from the short-stay visa requirement, up to a maximum of 90 days within a 180-day period, between the EU-Schengen states and the Republic of Peru. Since this visa waiver applies only if the traveller or travellers will not carry out a paid activity in the destination country during their stay and an official identification document must be available, there is no risk of irregular labour migration. On the contrary, this agreement simplifies travel, establishes personal contacts and strengthens the tourist economy. I voted in favour of the agreement for these reasons.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the Council's decision to lift the visa requirement between the EU and Peru for short stays. Peru has taken a significant step in the field of human rights. This agreement will send a clear political signal of strengthening EU-Peru relations. The agreement can also have beneficial economic impacts by strengthening the various economic sectors as well as by simplifying investment.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support this agreement to enable visa-free travel between EU Member States, other than the UK, and Peru. The agreement would not affect the UK, which has its own national visa agreements with this country.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and Peru on the short-stay visa waiver.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Regulation (EU) No. 509/2014 The European Parliament and the Council replaced Regulation (EC) No 509/2014. 539/2001, and the Republic of Peru has been relocated in Annex II, which contains a list of countries whose nationals may cross the external border of the Member States without a visa. The amended Regulation applies in all Member States of the European Union, except Ireland and the United Kingdom. The situation in the Republic of Peru has been thoroughly reviewed and all possibilities that may come from visa liberalisation have been assessed. On 19 May 2015, the Council adopted a decision authoring the Commission to conclude a bilateral agreement, as it received a positive assessment following a further evaluation of the situation in Peru.  The agreement was signed on 14 March 2016 in Brussels. The agreement guarantees citizens of the European Union and Peru visa-free stay on the territory of another party for a maximum of 90 days. I support this recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on the waiver of short-stay visas, as I consider that Peru has met all the conditions for visa liberalisation and I consider this Agreement to be in favour of the free and smooth movement of people between the two parties to the Agreement.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on the short-stay visa waiver. Following a positive assessment of the situation in Peru by the Commission, which assessed the potential risks of visa liberalisation, they thus opened negotiations on the agreement signed in Brussels in March this year. I support the signed agreement, which will allow citizens of the European Union and Peru to travel for up to 90 days without visas. This will also strengthen bilateral relations between the EU and Peru, both in the area of the economy and in the area of political dialogue on various important issues.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the european parliament's agreement today to conclude the EU-Peru Agreement on the abolition of the short-stay visa requirement. This is the same situation as the introduction of a visa-free regime for Colombian citizens. Thus: the European Parliament's consent is granted after the Member States, which are the only ones able to assess the security aspect, have agreed to introduce a visa-free regime with Peru and after an agreement on visa waiver has been concluded between the EU and Peru to ensure equal treatment of all EU citizens without distinction. The European Parliament is therefore now giving its consent to the conclusion of this agreement after the need for a visa-free regime has already been assessed by the Member States.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Peru, unlike the other countries of the "Koton Agreement" and other South American countries, does not represent any threat to the EU, either in terms of illegal immigration or in terms of security and public order. The low rate of rejections on VISA visas shows that there is a high degree of confidence in visa applicants. Finally, the short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and is a complementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the recommendation on the agreement between the EU and the Republic of Peru on the exemption from short-stay visas. In my decision, I have taken into account that the adoption of the visa-free travel agreement will greatly help to deepen relations between the two parties, both economically and culturally, while also significantly strengthening regional coherence. In terms of political and institutional situation, Peru is a relatively stable democracy that, like the EU, stands by the values and principles of democracy, human rights and the rule of law, and is an important partner in Latin America in this regard. The agreement will dynamise tourism and strengthen links in trade and investment. Moreover, Peru could also become a key partner in the fight against organised crime. In terms of mobility, the return rate has steadily improved since 2010 and the Peruvian Government is also making further efforts to reduce this number.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's relations with Latin American countries have seen an upward trend in recent years, which has enabled the development of collaboration in the economic, cultural and political fields with this important region of the world.  In this context, the EU has concluded exoneration agreements on the obligation to hold short-stay visas for citizens of most of those states. Peru is one of the few states that had not concluded such an agreement by March this year, when the Commission signed that document, and Parliament would ratify this step.  The signing of the agreement has been facilitated by Peru's remarkable progress in recent years in respecting the values of democracy, good governance, human rights and the rule of law, as well as strong economic growth and strengthening tourism as the country's second economic sector.  Furthermore, the fact that the EU is Peru's third largest trading partner and investor, as well as the country's first export destination, are further arguments for deepening the bilateral relationship. Ratification of the agreement will enable cooperation to develop in sensitive areas, such as the fight against organised crime, drug trafficking and trafficking in human beings. I support the adoption of this recommendation.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the agreement. The signed agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Peruvian nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.  Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Peru Agreement, which will provide for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Peru when travelling to each other’s countries for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period, as this represents a milestone in the deepening of relations between Europeans and Peruvians. Peru has recorded one of the highest rates of economic growth in Latin America and the EU continues to be the biggest investor in Peru, which is why I am confident that this agreement will also intensify trade and investment relations, and boost tourism. Finally, the agreement will allow us to pursue a strong political dialogue on democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law, and to increase our cooperation on illegal immigration.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the amendment of the resolution of the European Parliament and of the Council on the exemption of Peruvian citizens from the obligation to have a visa. The EU-Peru agreement on the abolition of short-stay visas will have a favourable impact on relations between them and will strengthen political dialogue, especially in an important area such as respect for human rights on the South American continent. In addition, the agreement will promote the development of tourism, which will have a positive impact on trade and bilateral investment. This is a very important aspect, because Peru's level of economic growth is one of the highest in Latin America. The EU is also Peru's third largest trading partner, the main export market and the largest investor in the country. Thus, the visa-free regime will bring significant benefits to the European Community.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Short Stay Visa Waiver Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru, as I believe it further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on human rights and fundamental freedoms. The signed Agreement allows visa-free stays on the territory of another Contracting Party of no more than 90 days for any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons whose purpose of the trip does not include the performance of a paid activity.  I believe that this Agreement will revive tourism and will contribute to strengthening relations in the area of trade and investment. I also believe that the Agreement will also affect future cooperation between the European Union and Peru, but also that Peru will become a key partner in the fight against organised crime.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The recommendation aims at concluding an agreement with the Republic of Peru on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement takes into account the situation of EU Member States which do not fully apply the Schengen acquis. It also provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and for citizens of the Republic of Peru in cases of travel to the territory of the other Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official, holders of special passports) travelling for any purpose, with the exception of the performance of paid work. For these reasons, I supported the recommendation for the conclusion of the EU-Peru agreement on the short-stay visa waiver.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to initiate negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and Peru, inter facilities, whose purpose is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Short-Term Visa Waiver Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and these countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report provides for easier travel for Peruvian nationals. Parliament must in fact ratify an agreement signed on 14 March between the European Union and Peru, which provides for a visa-free travel regime for European and Peruvian citizens for up to 90 days (except for paid work). The report adds that attention must be paid to possible illegal immigration, public order or security problems. When I saw the problems facing the EU with regard to illegal mass immigration, I opposed this liberalisation and I will oppose any further visa liberalisation. I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The agreement on the short-stay visa waiver is a major step forward in relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru. This agreement offers an opportunity to boost the tourism economy and hope to strengthen cultural and economic relations. The Republic of Peru has a good reputation in the European Union and we should have a special relationship with our trusted partners, and I therefore voted in favour of this agreement.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays is both a success in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The agreement would strengthen regional coherence, as Peru is one of the few Latin American countries whose citizens need visas and would thus also make a major contribution to the convergence of Europeans and Peruvians. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to initiate negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and Peru, inter facilities, whose purpose is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Short-Term Visa Waiver Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and these countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on the short-stay visa waiver. This agreement marks a significant milestone in the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Peru and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The agreement will strengthen regional coherence, given that Peru is one of the minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa, and will have a significant impact on rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and Peru. Having in mind that Peru has recorded one of the highest rates of economic growth in Latin America, I voted in favour because I believe that the agreement will boost tourism and help to intensify trade and investment relations.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. By this decision, the European Parliament approves the agreement negotiated by the European Commission between the European Union and the Republic of Peru to grant visa waiver for short-term stays to that country. We are talking about a positive agreement that we hope will benefit tourism between the two countries so I think it is necessary to vote in their favour.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on visa waiver for short-term stays, as this is a very satisfactory agreement by which the Spanish Socialists have worked for a long time. The Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the Union and Peru, as well as being a supplementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  In this way, the Agreement will strengthen regional coherence, as Peru is part of a minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa. Peru is a relatively stable democracy that defends, like the European Union, the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law, and remains an important partner in this area in Latin America. Human rights and democracy are essential elements of the relationship between the European Union and the Andean country.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this agreement in line with our position in favour of visa waiver. Despite disagreeing on how the negotiation procedure has been carried out, in an un transparent manner and without including democratic institutions such as the European Parliament therein, we agree with the proposed measures, which facilitate the freedom of movement of both Peruvian citizenship towards the European Union and European citizenship towards Peru , thereby reducing the restrictions that still exist on freedom of movement.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because the aim of this agreement is to boost tourism and contribute to closer trade and investment relations. Peru is one of the countries of Latin America that experienced the strongest growth (5% in 2013, 2.4% in 2014). The country has grown by more than 80% over the past decade, making it one of the 10 countries in the world that experienced the strongest growth during that period. In trade, the EU ranks third as Peru's trading partner in terms of imports (mainly machinery and transport equipment) and firstly as an export destination (agricultural and food products and minerals). In addition, the EU is still the largest investor in Peru, with a share of more than 50% of total direct investment from abroad, in sectors such as mining, banking and finance.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Since last December, the EU has concluded short-stay visa waiver agreements with 19 countries. The Caribbean and Pacific islands were mainly affected for reasons mainly related to tourism activity. At the time, I was already surprised at the choice of the United Arab Emirates given the countless violations of human rights and the rule of law in general in this country, the incubator of international terrorism.  This time, the exemption is for Peru. The entry into force of this exemption agreement has been delayed pending the introduction of biometric passports, a prerequisite for obtaining visa facilitation. That's all there is to it...   I regret that, as with all these agreements, it was put in place as early as March before obtaining the approval of the European Parliament, turning it into a registration chamber.  The GUE/NGL is in favour of the freedom of movement of people and thus the liberalisation of visas, especially short-stay visas. Nevertheless, I continue to question the Choice of Countries which benefit from it by the Commission.  I voted for it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Peru who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report aims to lift the visa requirement for Peruvian citizens during short stays. From the current point of view, however, there is no need for this, and moreover, the competences should remain with the Member States anyway. This agreement must therefore be rejected.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I believe that the agreement on the short-stay visa waiver will strengthen the international economic relations between the Countries of the European Union and the Republic of Peru. This agreement will make it possible to deepen both cultural relations and the importance of many issues, such m.in respect for human rights and the right to freedom. This agreement will certainly ensure stronger regional cohesion between the people of Peru and the citizens of the European Union. The visa waiver will improve the international integration of these two entities. The effects of the agreement will certainly have a positive impact on tourism. Moreover, there will be an increase in trade and an increase in the number of investments made. I believe that Peru has the opportunity to become a key partner of the European Union in the fight against organised crime and, above all, in the area of drug trafficking or trafficking in human beings. By signing a strategic cooperation agreement with Europol, Peru has already shown its willingness to strengthen relations with the European Union. I voted in favour because I believe that cooperation with Peru will be a positive agreement for both sides.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. – Labour MEPs support this agreement to enable visa-free travel between EU Member States, other than the UK, and Peru. The agreement would not affect the UK, which has its own national visa agreements with this country.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This agreement was supported by a large majority of the political forces in the competent committee of the European Parliament. Peru, with increased rates of economic growth, the EU is the country's third trading partner, and is the largest investor in the country. I voted in favour of this vote.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the Visa Waiver Agreement between the European Union and Peru. This agreement has already been signed and is provisionally applied, but it still requires the approval of the European Parliament procedurally. I have long supported this type of agreements where the visa requirement for short stays, i.e. stays of less than 90 days for a period of six months, is abolished. These are agreements that have been concluded after careful consideration of relations with the countries concerned, after examining the percentage of visa applicants who have failed in the past with their application and considering the possible risks arising from them. However, since Peru is an important trading partner of the European Union and is also interested in cooperating with Europol, I believe that this agreement will deepen relations, allow for better contacts between countries and will therefore be a positive step.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Peru on the short-stay visa waiver. The signed Agreement allows citizens of the European Union and peruian citizens to travel visa-free to the territory of the other Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement will, inter alia, give impetus to tourism and help strengthen trade relations, increase investment and promote cooperation in the fight against organised crime, in particular drug trafficking, and trafficking in human beings.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I will speak in my own language for this one simply because I think the issue we are debating goes to the heart of the difference between a single market and the common market. Everyone on both sides in the recent UK referendum is in favour of a common market in the sense of unrestricted trade and opportunities to benefit mutually from commerce with our friends across the Channel, but when we get to regulating issues of this sort – emissions limits for non-road mobile machinery – we realise that, instead of a market that deals with mutual product recognition and cross-border issues , we are entering a single regulatory regime. Every country in the world, pretty much, has access to the EU single market. If you look at what it says on the back of your smartphone, it says ‘designed in California, assembled in China’. Neither of those countries has a trade deal with the EU but, of course, we are still able to purchase their products. What the argument will now be about is the extent to which the UK accepts continuing jurisdiction over the bits of its exports that do not go to the EU, and I hope that those talks will take place in a friendly atmosphere, taking for granted, I hope, our continuing military, diplomatic and commercial ties to countries which, in any dispensation , will remain our friends and our allies.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this regulation, I believe it is beneficial for business.  As I have spoken to the various manufacturers, if there are uniform emission criteria for the whole of Europe, it will be clear for manufacturers of such machines how it is possible to produce these machines and then export them in Europe. So this regulation is certainly not against business, but it is for business, because there will be one uniform regulation for the whole of Europe and not 28, respectively, 27 different regulations in the future. I didn't have time to add one thing to this material yesterday. The material is proof of how, unfortunately, the Commission often puts forward poor-quality proposals for regulations, which then have to be completely revised and completed here in Parliament.  So, on the one hand, it is necessary to congratulate the rapporteur, on the other hand, it must be said that this particular material should be a certain memento for the Commission, which should better process the various legislative texts in the future and not send here mere torso, which must then be reworked.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, this report is for reducing pollution and for a cleaner environment. 15% of all noxious substances and 5% of particulate emissions in the European Union are emitted by machinery used in agriculture or industry, such as the railway industry or even the shipping industry and other industries. The report that we voted on today imposes limits on emissions, even from the approval of the engines of these vehicles. We now finally align European legislation with American and Japanese laws, with their rules, which are much stricter in this area.
