Emergency equipment, for example, such as lifeboats, is exempted from this regulation for a while. It is also important to say that, with the entry into force of this agreement, entrepreneurs will have 20 years to replace polluting engines. It's a lot, it's a little, I don't know. They have time to do that and we're not forcing them to invest large sums of money now. But it should be faster.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm tacaíocht a thabhairt don tuarascáil seo agus is dóigh liom go dtaispeánann sé gur féidir linn a lán rudaí maithe a dhéanamh ar son ár saoránach agus ar son an chomhshaoil.  In particular, the legislation will help to improve our environment and air quality. The engines of hand—held equipment, construction machinery, locomotives and inland waterway vessels are responsible for 15% of nitrous oxide emissions and 5% of particulate-matter emissions. It is important to bring in effective controls on these emissions, as they have significant effects on the quality of air we breathe and, as a result, on our health. The rapporteur and the Dutch Presidency have done a very good job in relation to this. I also welcome some exemptions, especially for narrow tractors and certain locomotive engines that are only used intermittently. Dá bhrí sin, ag deireadh na dála, tá jab maith déanta agus cabhróidh sé leis an gcomhshaol i gcoitinne agus le sláinte ár saoránach.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The category of "non-road mobile machinery" (NRMM) includes a wide variety of engines and tools, generally installed in machines intended for the transport of persons or goods. Their use in Europe is believed to be responsible for the release of 15% nitrogen oxides and 5% of particulate matter. The EU has therefore initiated an interinstitutional negotiation procedure with the aim of revising the emission limits for these substances. During the negotiations, the text of the agreement was significantly amended, providing for a series of concessions, derogations and, by far, reducing expectations, particularly for engines intended for inland waterway navigation. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Air quality control is an essential priority of environmental policy. With the amendments incorporated, the proposal broadens its focus on public health, strengthens Parliament's role in implementing the directive and ensures an improvement over current emissions. That's why I voted for it.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. It proposes to establish a more stringent regulation than the directives in place including stricter standards for most engines already covered by Directive 97/68/EC and to extend its scope to other categories of engine power. Indeed, there is a desire in this text to standardize against a subsidiarity of course. It is also part of the political project to create a transatlantic single market. Finally, it brings an additional difficulty to European industry at a time when the urgent need is to support European industrial production.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report was concerned with emission limits for non-road mobile machinery (NRMM). It addresses type approval for internal combustion engines, given that NRMM engines constitute a significant proportion of the total man-made emissions of certain noxious atmospheric pollutants. In some cities, non-road mobile machinery (which includes construction machines, vessels and railways etc.) is responsible for up to 30% of traffic pollution. The figures indicate that NRMM is responsible for around 7% of airborne particulates and 16% of nitrogen oxides in Europe, causing 400 000 premature deaths each year according to the World Health Organisation. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. Non-road mobile engines contribute significantly to air pollution and are responsible for about 15% of nitrogen oxide (NOx) and 5% of particulate matter (PM) emissions in the EU And their share of total NOx emissions in the EU will increase by 15-19% in the EU at the same time. While emissions standards for road vehicles have become stricter, measures for non-road mobile engines have been delayed. This is why a new legislative framework addressing these sectors is the key to achieving the objectives of better air quality in the European Union.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report concerns the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on emission limits and type-approval for internal combustion engines intended for non-road mobile machinery. The proposal for a regulation, which I voted in favour of, aims to regulate harmful emissions from the engines of so-called non-road mobile machinery. These engines contribute significantly to air pollution and are responsible for about 15% of nitrogen oxide emissions and 5% of EU particulate matter.  As these rates tend to increase over the next few years and because road legislation has become stricter, while the one in this category remains the same, it is necessary to develop a new legislative framework for these areas and contributing to the achievement of the Union's objectives of improving air quality.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal substantially updates the EMNR engine reception system for technical emission requirements. This legislation is generally more restrictive for manufacturers and places a new sector of the industry in greater difficulty. In addition, these rules apply to a considerable number of objects, from lawnmowers to barge engines. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report tightens the limits imposed by the European Commission for the power ranges of many engines. I opposed this report because I believe that it is right for the United Kingdom to set our own energy policy; my vote against was on the grounds of this principle rather than related to the specific proposed standards.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. Emissions from non-road vehicles account for 15% of total nitrogen dioxide (NOx) emissions and 5% of fine particulate matter emissions in the EU. The European Parliament then had to look at comprehensive legislation governing emissions of this type of device. It is with this in mind that I voted in favour of this report, which proposes plans to update the licensing rules and emission limits for non-road engines, including lawnmowers, bulldozers, diesel locomotives and some boats.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Non-road mobile machinery (NCJM) includes a wide range of combustion engines installed in various machinery, from small handheld equipment, construction machinery and generating equipment to drains, locomotives and inland waterway vessels. These engines greatly increase air pollution. The emission limit values for these engines are currently set out in Directive 97/68/EC, but need to be amended. The aim of this proposal is to protect human health and the environment and to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market for non-road mobile machinery engines. The aim is also to take into account competitiveness and compliance aspects. In line with THE EU's air quality policy, the aim is to gradually reduce emissions from new engines placed on the market and, at the same time, to replace older polluting engines over time.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft resolution on requirements for emission limit values and type-approval of internal combustion engines for non-road mobile machinery and equipment, as the machinery covered by the draft regulation is responsible for a significant proportion of nitrogen dioxide emissions, so regulating the area is a priority. Air pollution should be a priority as a serious threat to human health and the environment. Emission limit values for engines covered by the draft regulation are governed by an existing directive. This Directive has been amended several times, but a number of technical reviews have found that the legislation in its current form has shortcomings. Its scope is too limited as it does not include certain categories of engines. New emission phases were last introduced when the Directive was amended in 2004, which no longer reflects the state of the art. In addition, the emission limit values for each engine category are not in line with each other. I consider it particularly important that a compromise has been reached with the Council representing the Member States, as the legislation will take the form of a regulation and thus penetrate national legal systems immediately.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Non-road mobile vehicles (ENMR: agricultural tractors, barges, lawnmowers, etc.) are the source of significant pollution according to the Commission's impact study, resulting in 5% of fine particulate emissions in the EU, among other things. The text therefore provides for stricter emission standards for ENMR engines and to extend the scope of existing regulations to other categories of engine power. This report effectively leads to a standardisation that flouts the key principle of subsidiarity, and is part of the ill-fated transatlantic single market project. Moreover, at a time when it is important to support European industrial production, it is only putting more pressure on an already struggling European industry. So I could only oppose it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Non-road mobile vehicles cover a wide variety of combustion engines installed in devices ranging from small portable equipment to inland railcars, locomotives and boats, construction equipment and generators. These engines are a major source of air pollution and account for about 15% of nitrogen oxide emissions and 5% of particulate emissions in the European Union. I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to protect human health and the environment and to ensure that the internal market functions properly in terms of engines installed in non-road mobile vehicles. It also intends to address compliance and competitiveness issues. In line with the EU's air quality policy, the aim is to gradually reduce emissions from new engines on the market and thus replace older, more polluting engines over time. This initiative is expected to result in a very significant overall reduction in emissions, although the reduction by engine category will vary depending on the level of specific requirements currently in force.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the European Commission, the Union's air pollution involves an annual cost ranging from EUR 330 billion to EUR 940 billion. In addition to these economic costs, there are also those expressed in terms of human lives, caused by poor air quality. The European Environment Agency has estimated that around 72,000 premature deaths are attributable to nitrogen dioxide and a further 403,000 to particulate matter. These are worrying figures, and we need a stronger response from the EU. My vote in favour of the Gardini report is based on this conviction. The proposal for a regulation adopted restricts the limits set by the Commission, but commits itself to maintaining a balance between the competitiveness of companies and environmental protection. In particular, the legislation provides for the definition of different categories and subcategories of engines, establishing emission limits for carbon monoxide (CO), hydrocarbons (HC), nitrogen oxides (NOx) and particulate matter (PM) for each of them, including deadlines for their implementation from 2018.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is intended to reduce the emission of non-mobile combustion engines. It is a very technical, specific report on the characteristics of machinery that do not have specific rolling to move: normally used in agriculture, on some railway tracks, on some cotton farms, machinery such as snow cleaners and specific tractors. The objective was to harmonize their life cycle potential, replacing them with less polluting engines that could drastically contribute to reducing EMISSIONs of CO2 and other pollutants. I voted in favour of the report as the negotiations on the trilogue were positive for the EGUE and the Council and the European Parliament agreed to pay adequate attention to any consequences that replacement could have, as well as to mitigate the economic impact, mainly on the agriculture sector.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Gardini, for agreeing on the Regulation on emission limits for non-road mobile machines. The main objective of this report is to strike a reasonable balance between the concern for health and the environment and the competitiveness of the EU manufacturing industry and the corresponding jobs and know-how. In this sense, this much-needed balance has been achieved in this agreement.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which validates Parliament and Council's proposal for a regulation on emissions limits and type reception requirements for internal combustion engines for non-road mobile devices. Under the guise of technological advances, this draft regulation will further tighten the rules, especially with regard to technical requirements relating to emissions. If the environmental perspective is laudable, it is done here at the expense of the principle of reality, which calls for more flexibility in the transition period. Moreover, the motivations behind this new regulation are well known: it is a question of harmonising European legislation on US legislation from the perspective of TTIP, to the detriment not only of the principle of subsidiarity, but also of the competitiveness of European industry.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text is well structured and has no critical issues. In addition, the drafting of the new legislation on emission limits for non-road mobile machinery has taken account of the difficulties that our companies may encounter in adapting to the new Community provisions. That is why I wanted to support my colleague's report with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. •u2012 Engines installed on mobile machines that do not drive on the road are responsible for approximately 15% of the nitrogen oxide emitted and 5% of the EU's particulate matter emissions.  In September 2014, the European Commission published a proposal for a Regulation with measures to reduce emissions of major air pollutants from the engines of mobile machines that do not drive on the road. This proposal reduces, at the same time, the complexity of the legal framework for the sector. The proposal introduces new emission limits reflecting technological progress and EU policies in the road sector, with a view to achieving EU air quality targets; expands the scope, in order to improve market harmonisation (EU and international) and minimize the risk of market distortions; and introduces measures to simplify administrative procedures and improve compliance, including conditions for better market surveillance. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with emission limit values for non-road mobile machinery internal combustion engines. The main objective of this report, as proposed by the Commission, is to strike a fair balance between health and environmental issues and the competitiveness, jobs and know-how of the EU manufacturing industry. The health and safety of our citizens, especially those who work daily with the machines included in this proposal, and in particular those affected by pollution, are the main issues in this proposal. In view of the competition aspects, the rapporteur considers that SMEs, which create a large number of jobs, may be vulnerable and should therefore be guaranteed certain advantages. Another important objective could be to ensure certainty in long-term planning for industry and a stable regulatory environment. In this respect, this new legislative instrument in the form of a regulation is clearly superior to the directive, which takes time to transpose into national law, and there is therefore a risk of different interpretations.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported that report on the extension of emission limit values to other machinery and non-road vehicles. That proposal thus includes, for example, construction machinery, locomotives and power generators in domestic shipping. In total, such engines produce as much as 15 % of nitrogen oxides and 5 % of PM particulate emissions, so regulation and setting limit values for such engines is necessary. The report strikes a balance between health and environmental issues, on the one hand, and the competitiveness of the EU manufacturing industry, the jobs and skills it brings, on the other. The health and safety of EU citizens, especially those who work with machinery on a daily basis and are particularly vulnerable to pollutant emissions, is put first. I agree with my fellow rapporteur, who welcomes the positive assessment that this issue is being addressed under the regulation, which enables industry to have a more stable regulatory environment, which is crucial for long-term development and production planning. The draft report also reduces administrative obligations and makes reference to the application of the existing internal market information system, which is more favourable than the establishment of a new administrative regime. Caring for a cleaner environment has been one of the EU's priority policies for many years, and the volkswagen passenger car emissions affair is intensifying, and the proposal for a regulation is also a good example of this.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this bill because it will contribute to air quality and public health in the EU. Its application will regulate gases of various types of out-of-court machinery such as locomotives, excavators, riverboats and generators. Operating machinery exhaust is the source of 15% of NOX and 5% of matter particles in the EU. As this is a significant share, it is necessary to impose supranational rules that will be binding on all states.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. If the text of this regulation is in line with a limit on emissions of nitrogen oxide and particulate matter to which I can only adhere, for the combustion engines of non-road mobile vehicles, on the other hand, it has the following very negative characteristics: it provides for harmonization with US standards, as part of the TAFTA negotiations, and it aims to standardising European standards which will hinder a diversity of the supply of these products and competitiveness of European industrialists. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report was concerned with emission limits for non-road mobile machinery (NRMM). It addresses type approval for internal combustion engines, given that NRMM engines constitute a significant proportion of the total man-made emissions of certain noxious atmospheric pollutants. In some cities, non-road mobile machinery (which includes construction machines, vessels and railways etc.) is responsible for up to 30% of traffic pollution. The figures indicate that NRMM is responsible for around 7% of airborne particulates and 16% of nitrogen oxides in Europe, causing 400 000 premature deaths each year according to the World Health Organisation. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mobile non-road engines are responsible for about 15% of carbon dioxide emissions and 5% of particulate emissions within the European Union. With this regulation, an acceptable balance has been struck between the need to protect the health of our fellow citizens and the protection of the environment on the one hand, and that of ensuring the competitiveness of European industry on the other. We hope that this attitude of harmonisation and effort for balanced and sustainable progress will always be the practice for the EU, which must put the protection of the health of its citizens and of the companies that produce and operate on the ground first.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. According to the Commission's impact study, non-road mobile devices account for 15% of nitrogen oxide emissions and 5% of particulate emissions in the European Union. The current limits are defined by Directive 97/68/EC, but the evolution of technologies and their desire to standardise the internal market would, in their view, justify a new regulation. This proposal sets out a much more restrictive legislative framework for manufacturers of non-road mobile devices such as lawnmowers.  On the one hand, the resulting standardization of standards runs counter to the principle of subsidiarity; on the other hand, this new regulation is part of the plan to create a transatlantic single market. On the other hand, it is absolutely counterproductive to toughen the current legislation at a time when our companies are already facing unfair international competition because of environmental dumping by emerging countries. For all these reasons, I objected to this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal on emission limits for non-road mobile equipment contributes to the competitiveness of the European industrial sector by simplifying existing legislation on vehicle type-approval, improving transparency and reducing the administrative burden. This is expected to relieve the pressure on Member States to take additional regulatory measures that could affect the internal market.  At the same time, the aim is to remove obstacles to external trade through harmonised rules and reduce regulatory barriers resulting from divergent emissions requirements. In view of the fact that one of the objectives of this proposal is to protect human health and the environment, as well as to ensure the proper functioning of the internal engine market for non-road mobile equipment, I have chosen to express myself favourably with regard to this report.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Several EU urban areas do not meet air quality standards – and the problem is growing as more people move to cities. Non-road mobile machinery emits 15% of all NOx and 5% of all particulate matter in the EU. Studies have shown that these ultra-fine particles are carcinogenic. There must be stricter standards for more engine power ranges, combustion types and fuels to eliminate loopholes in the legislation and to negate the environmental and health damage they do. Member States should have the power to prohibit the use of combustion engines for reasons of health and safety, particularly in regions of poor air quality. Therefore, I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation to simplify the current legal framework and address the health concern generated by studies on ultra-fine particles. Through this, and by improving the general conditions for enforcement, Member States can protect the health and safety of persons working in the vicinity of machinery, by prohibiting the use of combustion engines.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on emission limits for non-road mobile vehicles. The first objective is to improve air quality. The second objective is the creation of a harmonised market within the European Union and with our main trading partners at the global level. Non-road mobile devices are responsible for 15% of nitrogen oxide emissions and 5% of particulate emissions in the EU. It's about setting stricter standards for engines.  The European Union intends to align itself with US standards when they are stricter than European standards. I call for a reasonable balance between the health and environmental concerns put forward by the Commission and the competitiveness of the Union's manufacturing industry, which is vital for our jobs. We need to ensure a stable regulatory environment for the industry.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this regulation because it will make it possible to overcome the shortcomings that the current Directive 68/97 on emission limits for non-road mobile machinery is currently being implemented due to its limited scope and difficulties in adapting promptly to technological developments in the field of engines. Firstly, I think that the decision made this time to use a regulation, which will guarantee, on the one hand, the immediate application of the provisions to manufacturers, type-approval authorities and technical services, is very appropriate; on the other hand, the rapid and effective updating of these provisions in order to take better account of technical developments. In addition, the extension of the scope in order to promote market harmonisation will make it possible to minimise the risk of (market) distortions, while the planned general and specific transitional periods will allow machine and engine manufacturers sufficient time to adapt to the new constraints. It remains regrettable that we were unable, during the trialogue, to close the door on certain exemption hypotheses which, however, will not affect the proper functioning of this regulation that much.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report was concerned with emission limits for non-road mobile machinery (NRMM). It addresses type approval for internal combustion engines, given that NRMM engines constitute a significant proportion of the total man-made emissions of certain noxious atmospheric pollutants. In some cities, non-road mobile machinery (which includes construction machines, vessels and railways etc.) is responsible for up to 30% of traffic pollution. The figures indicate that NRMM is responsible for around 7% of airborne particulates and 16% of nitrogen oxides in Europe, causing 400 000 premature deaths each year according to the World Health Organisation. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which proposes to regulate emission limits for a list of engines of non-road mobile machinery, as I believe this is beneficial to our environment and public health. As one of the component sectors contributing to noxious emissions, the non-road mobile machinery sector costs the EU a large proportion of the budget for tackling air pollution. A plan for tightened emission limits, along with a reasonable approach, allows the industry to comply with the new rules as soon as possible. This regulation takes advantage of the internal market to simplify the implementation procedure and reduce the burden for manufacturers. We can thus keep a balance between environmental protection and industrial competitiveness.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from this vote because I am dissatisfied with the result achieved during the negotiations with the Council and the Commission on the need to update the emission limits for non-road mobile machinery.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. – We support the report as the Main Aim of the Commission's proposal for a regulation is to contribute, on the one hand, to addressing public health concerns arising from studies that provide evidence of the carcinogenic effect of extremely small particles, and, on the other hand, to the general improvement of air quality and the creation of a market without frontiers, not only within the EU but also in its relations with its main trading partners around the world.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on emission limit requirements and type-approval for internal combustion engines intended for non-road mobile machinery. I believe that environmental protection policies must be a priority for Europe, as we must act immediately before it is too late for the environment. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation on 'emission limits and type-approval for internal combustion engines intended for non-road mobile machinery', as I believe that its effective implementation would bring significant environmental benefit and contribute to the competitiveness of European industry and the proper functioning of the internal market for the sector. , improving transparency and lightening administrative burdens. I believe that the regulation could also remove foreign trade barriers and regulatory obstacles, through the alignment of EU and US emission requirements, also in the interests of the ongoing TTIP agreement between the EU and the US.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Air pollution is a very sensitive issue. I am convinced that a reduction in polluting emissions can greatly benefit the environment around us and in which we live. I agree with the proposal by my colleague Elisabetta Gardini to revisit the current directive in order to adapt it to the technical progress that has taken place and is still taking place. Every year that passes technology makes great strides and therefore, in my opinion, we should use these innovations to have a cleaner and healthier environment. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on emission limits for non-road mobile machinery and had no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The main objective of this report is to strike a balanced balance between health and environmental concerns and the competitiveness of the EU manufacturing industry and job creation.  This aims at establishing stricter standards for most engines already existing under current Directive 97/68/EC, as well as extending to new engine power ranges, combustion types and used fuels, as well as new categories of machinery, with the aim of eliminating legislative loopholes. In addition to environmental and health benefits for citizens, it contributes to the creation of a harmonised internal market for industry and machinery users, which will facilitate trade and competitiveness and strengthen the EU's external trade with other developed industrial economies. With this legislation, we provide the industry with long-term planning certainty and a stable regulatory environment. I support this report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a regulation is positive because it has the dual objective of improving health and environmental protection standards and ensuring the proper functioning of the internal market by abolishing trade barriers for combustion engines. As far as environmental protection is concerned, the implementation of this Regulation would bring a significant benefit by reducing emissions from new engines which, over time, will replace older and more polluting engines. With regard to the competitiveness of European industry, the aim is to reduce the risks of market distortion by simplifying type-approval legislation, improving transparency and lightening the administrative burden. In addition, by aligning eu and US emission requirements, it removes barriers to foreign trade and reduces regulatory barriers. In order to allow combustion engine manufacturers to adapt to changes in production in accordance with the requirements of this regulation, a sufficient degree of flexibility should be introduced, allowing adaptation to new production standards, without hindering the competitiveness of EU companies.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ There are substantive requirements relating to emission limits and EU type-approval procedures for engines to be installed in non-road mobile machinery. In this context, harmonised rules for the EU type approval of engines to be installed in non-road mobile machinery would ensure the functioning of the internal market in the broader context of the ongoing review of Union air-quality policy.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Air quality control is an essential priority of environmental policy. With the amendments incorporated, the proposal broadens its focus on public health, strengthens Parliament's role in implementing the directive and ensures an improvement over current emissions. That's why I voted for it.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Agreement concerns emission limit conditions and type-approval for internal combustion engines intended for non-road mobile machinery. These machines include lawnmowers, doves, railway locomotives and inland waterway vessels; they account for around 15% of total NOx emissions and 5% of particulamin pollution in the EU. The agreement tightens up the existing limit conditions for these emissions, introduces larger power categories for non-road mobile machinery engines covered by the Regulation and generally adapts the limit conditions to the market conditions in the US and Japan, where these values are currently stricter than in the EU. It is extremely important in the document to ensure that rescue equipment, such as lifeboat transport vehicles, which could not meet the new proposed border conditions due to technical non-adaptation, can be excluded from the scope of the Regulation because of its social value. This exemption was approved by the Council. In conclusion, I believe that this agreement is a good example of better regulation in action – I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as a new legislative framework is needed to address emissions and achieve the Union’s air quality objectives. This proposal aims to regulate harmful emissions from engines installed in non-road mobile machinery such as inland waterways and construction machinery. It is an important air quality legislation to ensure that Member States meet the national air quality targets. Non-road mobile machinery engines are a significant contributor to air pollution and thus need to be addressed effectively.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Having worked on the Internal Market Committee opinion to this report I am pleased to see that one of the key objectives I supported, the right to put replacement engines on the non-road mobile machinery market, was maintained. This will prevent smaller operators, particularly in the agricultural and construction sectors, from having to purchase brand-new machinery many years before their machinery would be considered to be at the end of its working life (potentially up to 25 years).

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The non-road mobile machinery sector contributes decisively to the pollution of our air, due to its harmful emissions, in the form of gas or particulate matter. According to recent data from the European Commission, this is 15% of all nitrogen oxide (NOx) and 5% of all particulate matter in the Union, with very serious consequences in both environmental and health terms. These reasons made it urgent to revise Directive 97/68/EC. The new regulation adopted today provides for the introduction of stricter limits on pollutant gas emissions for vehicles and defines a 'staggered' approach, i.e. differentiated according to engine size and machine types. A reasonable choice because it allows the gradual introduction and the sector affected by the new requirements and takes into account the wide variety of machines and engines that are produced. I believe that the effective and rapid implementation of the rules laid down in this regulation will help to improve the impact on air quality of non-road mobile machinery, with considerable benefits to our citizens both in terms of the environment and in terms of health. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this legislative report is to introduce a limit on the number of particles emitted by non-road mobile vehicles (trains, cranes, combine harvesters, tractors, etc.). The political agreement reached with the Council proposes ambitious reduction targets but also exemptions for certain sectors in order to give them time to comply with the proposed new standards. I have also been particularly involved in adapting legislation to the particular case of locomotives whose return on investment time requires more than 15 years, and agricultural machinery.  Considering that these new provisions are balanced in relation to the emission reduction targets, the technical and economic constraints faced by the various sectors, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP objects to new EU legislation in this field. We believe that the UK should make its own energy policy, and exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on emission limits for non-road mobile vehicles. As the non-road mobile vehicle sector is one of the many sectors that contribute to the emission of gases or harmful particles, this report presents a balanced trade-off between health and environmental concerns on the one hand and the competitiveness of the EU's manufacturing industry and jobs on the other.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. Improving air quality is absolutely essential for the protection of human health and the environment. This is one of the reasons why I supported the GARDINI report, which aims to increase emission limits for non-road mobile vehicles (EMNRs) and extends the scope of these emission limits to new categories of gear and new pollutants.  I welcome the balance of this work, which takes into account the economic and technical constraints of limiting emissions for sectors using MNRMs. It is essential that they have sufficient time to modify the designs and manufacture of engines and machinery, and thus to bring themselves up to the new standards. I therefore fully support this balanced and reasonable report, which aims to protect the health of citizens and the environment while preserving the economic viability of the sectors affected by the use of MNRAs.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. 'The N-VA delegation supported the agreement reached between Parliament and the Council on emission limit values for 'non-road mobile machinery'. The emissions of engines from such machines (such as inland vessels, locomotives and construction equipment) have a 15% share of NOx emissions and 5% in particulate matter emissions. If no action is taken now, emissions risk increasing in the coming years.  The agreement puts stricter emissions standards first and thus contributes to improving air quality and protecting public health and the environment. In addition, the agreement also ensures legal certainty and less administrative burden by aligning European standards with international standards (including the US and Japan).  One caveat we place in the agreement is that the level of ambition for inland navigation engines could be higher: this would valorise the green lead of the sector and stimulate innovation. Stimulating policies to give the cleanest engines every opportunity remains a focus for us. In this context, it is important to address the existing discrepancy between the engines recognised by the Central Commission for the Navigation of the Rhine (CCNR) and the new EU standards.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on 'emission limits and type-approval for internal combustion engines for non-road mobile machinery' because I agree with EU air quality policies aimed at protecting health and the environment. The motion for a resolution provides for a progressive reduction in emissions and the replacement of the old most polluting engines, thus representing a common regulation for all Member States aimed at the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report to update the licensing rules and emission limits for non-road engines (including lawnmowers, bulldozers, diesel locomotives and some boats). Emissions from these non-road vehicles are far from innocuous. They account for 15% of total nitrogen dioxide (NOx) emissions and 5% of fine particulate emissions in the EU. There is a need to adapt regulations, simplify procedures and set emission limits for these engines while maintaining a reasonable and balanced approach between environmental protection and competitiveness.  I note with satisfaction that a new control system is planned, which should help to overcome the gap between the values observed in laboratory tests and those observed in reality. On the other hand, I am also satisfied with the proposed revision clause, which should allow for a review of emission thresholds and to stimulate innovations with a view to continuously improving emissions.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text proposes to establish, in the form of a regulation, which is more binding than the directives it replaces, stricter standards for most engines already covered by Directive 97/68/EC. It aims to extend its reach to other power categories of the engines, types of combustion and fuels used, as well as to a number of additional vehicle categories.  According to the Commission and the rapporteur, technological progress justifies the strengthening of legislation. However, the latter puts a sector of the industry in difficulty. I was opposed to the desire to bring European legislation closer to US legislation, as well as the standardisation of the internal market and a form of programmed obsolescence that excludes a large number of valid engines beyond the transition period.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This Regulation seeks to establish harmonised rules for THE EU type-approval of engines fitted to non-road mobile machinery, with a view to ensuring the functioning of the internal market for air quality. We are voting in favour of the proposal because the health and safety of European citizens is a priority. We agree that new emission limits should be introduced, which should also apply to agricultural vehicles, reflecting technological progress and ensuring convergence with Union policies in the field of road transport, in order to achieve air quality targets and reduce emissions from non-road mobile machinery and agricultural vehicles. , resulting in a more proportional proportion of emissions from machinery than emissions from road vehicles.  Finally, the scope of legislation in this area should be broadened with a view to improving market harmonisation and minimising the risk of market distortions and adverse health effects.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Emissions from non-road mobile machinery (broad category of engines, from smaller motorized hand tools to locomotive engines) are estimated to account for 15% of the release of nitrogen oxides and 5% for particulate matter and their use, particularly in urban centres where their concentration becomes a significant source of air pollution. The revision of the current legislation, in order to establish stricter limits that took account of technological advances, was necessary. The negotiation of the dossier, after extensive concessions to the Council, has undergone major changes aimed at extending both the categories to which derogations should be granted, and their length of time, delaying the implementation of the legislation and reducing the level of ambition for both NOx and particulate reduction and, finally, a lack of commitment to ensuring retrofitting interventions on existing machinery. The only positive note of the negotiations is that it has ensured that important technical details have been defined through delegated acts rather than implementing acts. I therefore abstained in the final vote.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: we are blaming this text for bringing an additional difficulty to European industry at a time when the urgent need is to support European industrial production.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In its handling of the issue of emission limits for non-road mobile cars, Parliament aimed in particular at achieving a reasonable balance between health and environmental concerns and the competitiveness of the European manufacturing sector, the jobs and skills it generates. As a result of the interinstitutional negotiations, we can say that this objective has only been partially achieved. We agree with the need to update the emission limits for these machines, but unfortunately the result achieved is unsatisfactory, especially because of the lengthy implementation extensions granted.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Despite some recent improvements, air pollution in Europe remains a cause for concern. In September 2014, the European Commission submitted a proposal for a revision to the approval of emission limits allowed in non-road mobile machinery, covering a wide range of machines with internal combustion engines that contribute to air pollution. This is one of the sectors that is important to regulate, despite being responsible for a minority share of emissions. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety has introduced some amendments to the initial version. Among others, the list of exemptions was extended. The implementation dates for engines used in river vessels have been modified.  We agree that Member States should be able to ban the use of combustion engines for health and safety reasons at work, in particular in nerve points where air quality is poor. The rapporteur made a point of introducing her concerns about the possible distortion in the internal market. However, we agree, with the aim of simplifying administrative procedures and improving the general conditions of implementation, we do not follow the rapporteur's considerations regarding the internal market. Concerns should focus on protecting the environment and the health of populations. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report for two reasons. Firstly, smaller operators are protected by guaranteeing them the use of the machinery up to the deadline for their duration of use. Secondly, stricter emission limits are set for non-road mobile machinery, bringing them into line with the values in force on the US and Japanese markets.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The present proposal aims to improve the regulation of harmful emissions from engines installed in so-called non-road mobile machinery, which include a wide range of machines such as construction machinery, inland waterway vessels and others. The emissions in question contribute a small part to air quality in the European Union and must therefore become an important part of air quality legislation at European Union level and help Member States to achieve national air quality targets.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report that allows Italian producers to adapt promptly to industrial competitiveness.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the proposal as the health and safety of European citizens is a priority. I agree that new emission limits should be introduced, which should also apply to agricultural vehicles, reflecting technological progress and ensuring convergence with Union policies in the field of road transport, in order to achieve air quality targets and reduce emissions from non-road mobile machinery and agricultural vehicles. , resulting in a more proportional proportion of emissions from machinery than emissions from road vehicles.  Finally, the scope of legislation in this area should be broadened with a view to improving market harmonisation and minimising the risk of market distortions and adverse health effects.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the non-road mobile machinery proposal, which aims to regulate harmful emissions from engines installed in so-called non-road mobile machinery (NRMM) – a term covering a wide variety of machinery such as construction machines, inland water vessels, trains, chainsaws and generator sets. Emissions from NRMM engines represent a significant part of the EU’s total emissions of NOx and PM: 15% of total NOx emissions and 5% of total PM emissions. This is thus an important piece of source-level air-quality legislation to ensure Member States meet their national air quality targets. Establishing stricter limits on NRMM emissions is an essential component of the EU’s air-quality policy framework and will help Member States achieve the required emission reductions, as proposed in the NECD and the Ambient Air Quality Directive. The share of total NOx emissions in the EU accounted for by NRMM engines is predicted to grow to 19% in 2020. At the same time, whilst emissions standards for road vehicles have become more stringent, equivalent measures for NRMM have lagged behind. This is why I believe a new legislative framework addressing these sectors is key in order to achieve the Union’s air-quality objectives.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Gardini's report on emission limit values, which together aim to protect the environment and ensure the proper functioning of the internal market for engines of non-road mobile machinery and equipment. We have already delivered an opinion on the report in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, which is to ensure that manufacturers are able to meet environmental standards in a way that does not impede the competitiveness of the Union. It is necessary to help manufacturers adapt to new environmental standards without easing them. The main element of the proposal is the health and safety of citizens, especially those who work every day with the machines that are covered by the proposal. In particular, I support the rapporteur's belief that, on competition aspects, the rapporteur believes that SMEs, the creators of many jobs, may be in a sensitive situation and that certain advantages should be allowed to them. As non-road mobile machinery and equipment are responsible for 15% of all NOx emitted in the European Union, the problem needs to be remedied. That's because we've measured NOx values that exceed the limit in real-world driving conditions in the case of the VW Diesel scandal. In order to safeguard trade and competitiveness, the Commission should develop standards that bring environmental and health benefits to citizens.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation convinced of the need to legislate to help address the public health problem raised by studies that attribute carcinogenic properties to ultra-thin particles, improve overall air quality and create a barrier-free market not only within the EU but also with our main trading partners around the world. Similarly, I have taken into account that, thanks to technological advances, regulations can be tightened without imposing an excessive burden on the manufacturing industry.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank Mrs Gardini and congratulate her on reaching agreement at first reading. I voted with conviction for the amendments to the proposal for a regulation, because I believe that the effort to combat climate change must be truly horizontal and must be conducted consistently: with today's vote we are going to regulate a sector – that of non-road mobile machinery – that contributes significantly to emission allowances. I therefore consider it very important to step up the reform of European environmental policies, in order to direct our production more and more towards criteria of sustainability, effectiveness and excellence.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the requirements for emission limits and type-approval for internal combustion engines intended for non-road mobile machinery, because reducing emissions of such equipment is a key element if we are to guarantee clean and healthy air for all European citizens. The category of non-road mobile machinery includes a wide range of equipment and vehicles, including inland waterway vessels, which represent an important source of air pollution and generate about 15% of total NOx emissions and about 5% of total PM emissions. The EP supported the Commission's initial choice to create the conditions for even limited harmonisation between the legislation and requirements for non-road machinery and the legislation on vehicle emissions, including with regard to the establishment of a national control authority. The result of the agreement between the Council and the EP, thanks in part to the action of the S&D Group, is broadly balanced in relation to the ambition shown in setting the reduction targets and the problem of the equipment currently in use. A transitional period is provided for.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on emission limits for non-road mobile machinery. This rather technical dossier regulates necessary "updates" in the emission control of these vehicles – including construction site vehicles or vehicles for in-house operation.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The new emission limits were necessary as mobile machinery and equipment not intended for road transport are responsible for 15% NOx across the EU. We have succeeded in striking a balance. The limit values have been tightened to protect our environment and health. Nevertheless, we are confident that the requirements are proportionate and that the industry can meet them within a short period of time. In addition, small and medium-sized enterprises in particular will be given additional time to achieve their objectives.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Currently, 15% of total NOx emissions and 5% of total particulate matter emissions in the EU are caused by non-road mobile machinery (NRMM). I voted in favour of this report, which will set strict emission limits for NRMM engines on the EU market from 2019. By doing so, this report encourages industry to produce progressively cleaner engines for these machines – and that will, in turn, have environmental and health benefits for citizens.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. According to the Commission, mobile non-road vehicles (MNREs), such as cranes or mowers, are responsible for 15% of nitrogen oxide emissions and 5% of particulate emissions in the European Union. These emissions are limited in Directive 97/68/EC, last amended in 2004. Over time, technological developments are increasingly strict in the area of energy savings, which can have a positive effect on the competitiveness of industries. However, this legislation is generally binding on manufacturers. It imposes additional constraints on the industrial sector, already weakened in Europe, at a time when there is an urgent need to support European production. I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is intended to reduce the emission of non-mobile combustion engines. It is a very technical, specific report on the characteristics of machinery that do not have specific rolling to move: normally used in agriculture, on some railway tracks, on some cotton farms, machinery such as snow cleaners and specific tractors. The objective was to harmonize their life cycle potential, replacing them with less polluting engines that could drastically contribute to reducing EMISSIONs of CO2 and other pollutants. I voted in favour of the report as the negotiations on the trilogue were positive for the EGUE and the Council and the European Parliament agreed to pay adequate attention to any consequences that replacement could have, as well as to mitigate the economic impact, mainly on the agriculture sector.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on emission limit requirements and type-approval for internal combustion engines intended for non-road mobile machinery. The objective of this proposal is to protect the environment and ensure the proper functioning of the internal market by introducing emission limits and type-approval for internal combustion engines intended for non-road mobile machinery, i.e. lawnmowers, bulldowers, railway locomotives or inland waterway vessels. This agreement tightens the current limit conditions for these emissions, so that it has the potential to bring significant benefits by reducing emissions to the environment.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Currently, 15% of total NOx emissions and 5% of total particulate matter emissions in the EU are caused by non-road mobile machinery (NRMM). I voted in favour of this report, which will set strict emission limits for NRMM engines on the EU market from 2019. By doing so, the report encourages industry to produce progressively cleaner engines for these machines and will bring both environmental and health benefits for citizens.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text.  It helps to increase emission limits for non-road mobile vehicles, a major advance for the health of those who work with these machines every day.  It also extends the scope of emission limits to new categories of machinery and new pollutants while simplifying the current legal framework. This simplification and greater flexibility of administrative procedures will benefit SMEs who should not be victims of overly scrupulous and bureaucratic regulations!  Finally, it takes into account the specificity of the agricultural, rail and river sectors, which are such strategic sectors for the development of our economy.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The regulation is very ambitious in terms of environmental protection and public health protection because non-road mobile machinery engines account for about 15% of all NOx and 5% of particulate emissions in the EU.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the changes in the text and the promotion of less environmentally harmful emissions, we agreed and voted in favour of the report in the context of the codecision that Parliament and the Council had on the subject.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which outlines the substantive requirements relating to emission limits and EU type-approval procedures for engines to be installed in non-road mobile machinery (NRMM). NRMM covers a large variety of machines ranging from small handheld equipment, construction machinery and generating sets to railcars, locomotives and inland waterway vessels. NRMM combustion engines contribute to air pollution and currently account for roughly 15% of the nitrogen oxide (NOx) and 5% of the particulate matter emissions in the EU. The emissions limits set out in Directive 97/68/EC no longer reflect the current state of technology and do not comprehensively cover all engine categories. This regulation will repeal and replace the current directive, protect human health and the environment, and ensure the proper functioning of the internal market for engines in NRMM.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as I believe it represents a balanced approach between the protection of our environment and the protection of competitiveness in EU industry.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. This report on non-road mobile machinery (NRMM) that is not intended for road use is not controversial. It is compatible with economic expertise. Adapting to the emission limits existing on US and Japanese markets makes perfect sense from a trade policy point of view. This new regulation replaces the existing directive. All types of internal combustion engines, including small portable appliances, have been integrated into the new performance ranges in this Regulation. The report strikes a balance between environmental protection and the protection of the competitiveness of European industry. That is why I followed the ECR line and voted in favour of the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this report which has as its main objective to strike a reasonable balance between, on the one hand, concern for health and the environment, as proposed by the Commission, and, on the other hand, the competitiveness of the EU manufacturing industry and the corresponding jobs and know-how.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ New data shows that non-road mobile machinery engines contribute significantly to air pollution and are accountable for 15% of the nitrogen oxide and 5% of the particulate matter emissions in the EU, while their share of total emissions in the EU 15 is predicted to grow to 19% in 2020. Taking this into consideration, a new legislative framework addressing these sectors is key in order to achieve the Union’s air quality objectives.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒in 2012 I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Regulation by Parliament and the Council on emission limit requirements and type approval for internal combustion engines for off-board mobile machinery on the ground that such machines contribute significantly to air pollution. This Regulation will align the European regulatory framework with the current development of technology and ensure better protection of human health and the environment. It will also improve market surveillance and ensure the well-functioning of the internal market. In addition, only engines in accordance with the requirements of emission limits and type-approval will be able to be present in the internal market. In this context, I consider it necessary to provide flexibility for manufacturers, and therefore I support the extension of the transition period proposed by the Commission and the provision of replacement engines for a certain period of time in order to gradually remove outdated engines from the market.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The final text proposes to establish, in the form of a regulation (by nature more restrictive than the directives it replaces), stricter standards for most engines already covered by Directive 97/68/EC and to extend its scope to other categories of engine power, types of combustion and fuels used, as well as to a number of additional gear categories. According to the Commission and the rapporteur, technological advances justify the strengthening of legislation, which, through a virtuous circle, improves the competitiveness of the industry.  This ideal view is always denied, and I reproach this text: to make a standardisation against a subsidiarity of course; to be part of the political project to create a transatlantic single market; to bring an additional difficulty to European industry at a time when the urgent need is to support European industrial production; a form of programmed obsolescence to banish a large number of valid engines beyond the transition period.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of limiting emissions of non-road mobile vehicles, such as construction machinery, locomotives or small inland vessels, which make a significant contribution to air pollution. This adjustment will ensure that only machines with engines in accordance with the new emission limits are placed on the common market. We must remember that machines that are not intended for road transport are responsible for up to 15% of all nitrogen emissions into the atmosphere, which is really not enough. I believe that an agreement has been reached that balances well the need to protect the environment and the health of Europeans and the competitiveness of European companies. I also appreciate the objective of simplifying the current legal framework and simplifying administrative procedures to reduce administrative burdens, which is in line with our long-term objective of better regulation in the EU.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Elisabetta Gardini's report on the proposed regulation on "emissions limit and reception by type requirements for internal combustion engines for non-road mobile vehicles". Considering that the latter are responsible for about 15% of nitrogen oxide emissions and 5% of particulate matter, it is imperative to strengthen the emission limits applicable to these devices and to extend the scope of emission limits to new categories of machinery and new pollutants. Such measures are, in my view, essential to ensure a gradual reduction in polluting emissions from fossil fuels. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which strengthens the emission limits for non-road mobile vehicles and extends the scope of emission limits to new categories of machinery and pollutants. The text aims to ensure a balanced approach between the competitiveness of European industry and environmental protection, even though these devices account for almost 15% of nitrogen oxide emissions and 5% of fine particulate emissions in the EU.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on requirements relating to emission limits and type-approval for internal combustion engines for non-road mobile machinery, as it addresses adequately the public health concern created by studies indicating ultra-fine particles as a carcinogenic substance. Today, several EU urban areas do not fully meet the air quality standards. This issue is growing as more people are attracted to life in urban conglomerations. The report is trying to solve those problems.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This is a technical report dealing with the emission of ultrafine, carcinogenic particles from internal combustion engines and overall air quality. Those internal combustion engines that are not installed in motor vehicles and combustion plants and are not treated within the framework of industrial emissions are at fault for around 15% of all NOx emissions and 5% of all particulate emissions in the EU. The Commission is now proposing stricter standards based on US standards. With regard to the new limit values, it should be noted that many EU international producers are already voluntarily complying with these limits in order to gain access to the US market. However, the period between the establishment of the test procedure (end of 2016) and the entry into force of the new limit values (2019) set by the Commission is extremely tight, so it is questionable whether there is sufficient time to develop new engines. Given that many SMEs are affected by this regulation and that the emission savings are not specifically put forward in the impact assessment, I am abstaining on this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as it will ensure industry is manufacturing progressively cleaner engines for these machines and will bring both environmental and health benefits for citizens.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. This report on non-road mobile machinery (NRMM) that is not intended for road use is not controversial. It is compatible with economic expertise. Adapting to the emission limits existing on US and Japanese markets makes perfect sense from a trade policy point of view. This new regulation replaces the existing directive. All types of internal combustion engines, including small portable appliances, have been integrated into the new performance ranges in this Regulation. The report strikes a balance between environmental protection and the protection of the competitiveness of European industry. That is why I followed the ECR line and voted in favour of the report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 5 July 2016, in the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, we voted on a proposal for a regulation on the requirements applicable to emission limit values and type-approval of internal combustion engines in non-road mobile machinery. European legislation has always focused more on emissions from transport and cars in general. Personally, I am not a big fan of the fact that, in terms of emissions emitted, agriculture, for example, unlike other sectors, is constantly receiving a number of substantial exemptions from the emission ceilings. In doing so, however, it contributes greatly to the quality of the air we breathe. Therefore, I was glad that this time it finally came to vehicles and standing ups that are not intended for transport on roads, such as lawn mowers, bulldozers, diesel locomotives or combine harvesters, etc. On the other hand, it should be admitted that these types of means of transport /machines require a significantly different approach than normal passenger cars. This is only in the context of the fact that their real life span is much longer, including for decades. The regulation presented is a sensible compromise between protecting the environment and protecting the competitiveness of the affected sectors. I am therefore glad to be able to support this text.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a technical proposal relevant to the EU’s efforts to strike a reasonable balance between industrial competitiveness and health and environmental concerns, and more particularly to address public health concern about air quality. The choice of a new legal instrument, in the form of a regulation, offers the possibility of harmonising provisions on the potential end of life of some categories of machinery that have no independent wheels, by replacing them by less pollutant engines. This could contribute to a drastic reduction in emissions of CO2 and other harmful pollutants. Therefore, I voted in favour.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on emission limits for non-road mobile vehicles. According to the Commission's impact assessment, non-road mobile vehicles are the source of significant pollution: 15% of nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions and 5% of particulate emissions in the EU. The evolution of technologies that allow the production of less polluting engines, the desire to bring European legislation closer to us legislation and the desire to more uniformize the internal market are the reasons for this new text.  The rules apply to a considerable number of objects, from lawnmowers to barge engines. This text makes a standardization against a subsidiarity of course. It is part of the political project to create a transatlantic single market. It brings an additional difficulty to European industry at a time when the urgent need is to support European industrial production. In addition, it introduces a form of programmed obsolescence to banish a large number of valid engines beyond the transition period.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The report tends to make major changes to Directive 97/68/EC that regulates engines. Indeed, the evolution of technologies brings new types of engines to the market, less polluting and more efficient. On the basis of this observation, the rapporteur proposes to strengthen and extend the standards and technical requirements that apply to them. These legislative developments clearly demonstrate a willingness to move closer to U.S. legislation and to standardize that market.  However, I believe that progress does not justify the increase in binding rules. The Commission's study, which seems to show that non-road mobile devices (MNREs) are the source of greater pollution, i.e. 5% of particulate emissions in the EU, does not authorise it to schedule their end through stricter regulation. This project puts European industrial production in difficulty and is part of the idea of a transatlantic market. I strongly opposed it by voting AGAINST.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because this report sets stricter emission limit values for internal combustion engines installed on non-road mobile machines. At the same time, it lays down harmonised standards for the marketing of such engines on the EU market. In addition to improving air quality across the EU, the new proposal provides the sector with a predictable and stable regulatory framework. This ensures a level playing field for European industry and avoids unfair competition from low-cost imports of unregulated machinery. On this basis, the new proposal includes the following main axes: the introduction of new emission limits reflecting technological progress and EU policies in the road sector, with a view to achieving EU air quality targets; broadion of the scope, in order to improve market, EU and international harmonisation, and minimize the risk of market distortions. Introduction of measures to simplify administrative procedures and improve compliance, including conditions for better market surveillance.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Air quality control is an essential priority of environmental policy. With the amendments incorporated, the proposal broadens its focus on public health, strengthens Parliament's role in implementing the directive and ensures an improvement over current emissions. That's why I voted for it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposal by the European Parliament and of the Council on the requirements relating to limits and type-approval of internal combustion engines for mobile machinery, with the exception of road machines, is based on the report analysed by the Commission on 20 November 2013 on the economic and environmental advantages and disadvantages and the comparison of possible options.  I believe that it is essential to promote these legislative initiatives, which are intended to ensure air quality, and the health and environmental responsibilities that the Union has with its citizens.  The aim is for this Regulation to reflect the technological advances that the European Union has in terms of emissions, environmental protection and public health. That's why I vote for it.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. This report on non-road mobile machinery (NRMM) that is not intended for road use is not controversial. It is compatible with economic expertise. Adapting to the emission limits existing on US and Japanese markets makes perfect sense from a trade policy point of view. This new regulation replaces the existing directive. All types of internal combustion engines, including small portable appliances, have been integrated into the new performance ranges in this Regulation. The report strikes a balance between environmental protection and the protection of the competitiveness of European industry. That is why I followed the ECR line and voted in favour of the report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to streamline requirements for manufacturers across Europe and protect the environment. This will help to maintain our commitment to the Paris COP21 agreement by reducing our emissions.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the EU regulating the emission limits of tractors or lawn mowers. National legislation will suspose.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Off-test mobile machinery includes a variety of internal combustion engines installed in machines ranging from small handheld devices, construction machinery and generators to motor wagons, locomotives and inland navigation vessels. These engines contribute significantly to air pollution and emit around 15 % of nitrogen oxide (NOx) and 5% of eu particulate matter. The aim is to gradually reduce emissions from new engines placed on the market, replacing old, more polluting engines over time. This is expected to result in a significant overall reduction in toxic air emissions, which will protect human health and the environment. Pressure will also be reduced on Member States to take additional regulatory measures that can disrupt the internal market. Also, harmonised rules and reducing regulatory barriers will remove barriers to foreign trade with the intention of reducing the gap between EU and US requirements.  This regulation will not only have a positive impact on the environment and human health, but this agreement will allow SMEs more time to adapt to the new provisions as part of this agreement, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this proposal is to protect human health and the environment, and ensure the proper functioning of the internal market for engines in non-road mobile machinery. The regulation should aim to simplify the current legal framework, including measures for simplifying administrative procedures, and to improve the general conditions for enforcement, in particular by strengthening the rules on market surveillance.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Environmental and air protection is a continuous process that must respond flexibly to technological development and the associated potential threat. Non-road mobile machines produce around 15% of nitric oxide (NOx) and 5% of particulate emissions within the EU. The motion for a resolution tabled follows the introduction of new emission limits in order to achieve the EU's air and public health policy objectives.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on emission limit requirements and type-approval for internal combustion engines intended for non-road mobile machinery, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 4/7/2016, and because this Report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This report consists of a proposal for a regulation on emissions from non-road mobile vehicles. Non-road mobile devices, which account for 15% of nitrogen oxide emissions and 5% of particulate emissions in the European Union, are partly covered by Directive 97/68/EC.
