In addition to the regulation being more binding than a directive (which requires prior transposition into Member States' law), the proposed regulation introduces more stringent emission limits than the above directive. It also extends its scope to additional categories of engines and engines. We disapprove of this draft regulation both on its very principle and on its provisions. American-inspired, it is another step in the standardisation of the European automotive market. Its strict provisions are causing additional difficulties for the European automotive industry, which is currently in the grip of an unprecedented economic crisis. Finally, too many valid engines are deemed obsolete beyond a deadline.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. Air quality is of vital importance for the protection of both the environment and the health of our citizens. Reasonable emission limits protect people operating with these machines, while ensuring the vitality of the manufacturing industry in Europe.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. It is necessary to update the approval standards and emission limits for internal combustion engines of some machines such as lawnmowers, excavator machines, diesel locomotives and inland navigation. That is why I support the proposal adopted by this Parliament, in which we have sought a balance between environmental protection and the competitiveness of businesses.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This proposal deals with air pollution from non-road machinery. Of course, this area should also be regulated within the framework of emission directives. However, bearing in mind that a large part of the limit values are already being complied with and that the required test cycles and test procedures for practice are far beyond the objective of what is necessary, I must abstain, despite the basic agreement.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The proposed regulation aims to reduce polluting emissions (particularly ultrafine carcinogenic particles) from non-road mobile devices. Specifically, it is a question of putting a stop to the air pollution of tractors, lawnmowers, bulldozers, locomotives, inland navigation boats... which cause about 15% of NOx emissions and 5% of particulate emissions in the EU.   The Commission proposes to set stricter standards for engines already covered by Directive 97/68/EC and to extend its scope to other power categories of engines, types of combustion and fuels used, as well as to a number of additional categories of machinery, in order to fill any gaps in legislation. The regulations set stricter emission limits for nitrogen oxides (NOx), hydrocarbons (HC), carbon monoxide (CO) and particulate emissions to adapt them to new technologies. In addition, the report proposes a new monitoring system to assess engine performance in real life to close the gap with laboratory testing. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal substantially updates the EMNR engine reception system for technical emission requirements. This legislation is generally more restrictive for manufacturers and places a new sector of the industry in greater difficulty. In addition, these rules apply to a considerable number of objects, from lawnmowers to barge engines. So I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. Non-road mobile machinery (NRMM) covers a wide range of combustion engines installed in machinery, ranging from small portable equipment, construction machinery and electrogen groups to self-propelled, locomotives and inland navigation vessels. These engines contribute significantly to air pollution and account for around 15% of nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions and 5% of particulate emissions in the EU. This proposal aims to protect human health and the environment and ensure the proper functioning of the internal market for engines installed in NRMM. It also seeks to address aspects of competitiveness and compliance. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as it provides a balance between necessary measures to protect the environment and fair regulation of the single market. It is essential that our environment is protected for the next generation, and this resolution is another step in the proper direction, while not placing an undue burden on producers.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Air quality in our European cities and conurbations does not yet meet the desired standards. Too high a concentration of fine dust particles and excessive emissions of NOx reduce air quality. Last year's VW debacle showed that there is only one remedy in place to put the house back in order: only clear rules, respect for legislation and proper controls can restore consumer confidence and ensure better air quality.  After parliament set new standards for combustion plants and industrial emissions earlier this year, it has now also adopted a new framework for emissions from non-road mobile machinery, such as generators or yard vehicles. 15% of all NOx emissions in Europe come from these engines. A significant reduction in emissions will result in environmental and health dividends. A transitional period has been built in for manufacturers and users so that they can comply with the new regulations.  In this dossier, the Commission has already remembered one important lesson from the VW debacle: in order to guarantee access to the markets, it is better to align European standards with American standards when they are stricter and more ambitious.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – This proposal covers a wide range of internal combustion engines installed in machines ranging from small hand-held equipment, construction machinery to assemblies to railway wagons, locomotives and inland vessels. All these engines account for approximately 15% of nitrogen oxide and 5% of particulate emissions in the European Union. The new rules will simplify the implementation phase for the introduction of new emission levels and type-approval procedures in order to reduce the burden on manufacturers. A new service has also been set up in an engine performance assessment monitoring system to fill the gap between laboratory engine testing and real global emissions. A few exceptions will be provided for addressing specific needs relating to certain important sectors, such as agriculture or railways (narrow tractors, engines built into locomotives with a power range greater than 2000 kW, as well as engines built into locomotives that are part of an advanced development project). In view of the above, I support the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Non-road mobile machinery engines contribute significantly to air pollution and are accountable for roughly 15% of the nitrogen oxide (NOx) and 5% of the particulate matter (PM) emissions in the EU while their share of total NOx emissions in the EU 15 is predicted to grow to 19% in 2020. At the same time, whilst emissions standards for road vehicles have become more stringent, equivalent measures for NRMM have lagged behind. That is why a new legislative framework addressing these sectors is key in order to achieve the Union’s air-quality objectives to better protect human health and environment. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on requirements for emission limit values and type-approval of internal combustion engines for non-road mobile machinery and equipment. In its report, the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety recommends that Parliament support the Commission's proposal at first reading with the adoption of 44 amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposal substantially updates the system for receiving non-road mobile engines by type with respect to technical emission requirements. This legislation is generally more restrictive for manufacturers and places a new sector of the industry in greater difficulty. Note that these rules apply to a considerable number of objects, from lawnmowers to barge engines.  According to the Commission and the rapporteur, technological advances justify the strengthening of legislation, which, through a virtuous circle, improves the competitiveness of the industry. This vision is always denied, and we reject this text to make a standardisation that goes against a well-understood subsidiarity, to be part of the political project to create a single transatlantic market, to bring an additional difficulty to European industry at a time when the urgency is to support its production, and to promote a form of programmed obsolescence by banning a large number of valid engines beyond the period. Unfavorable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Environmental sustainability is also key to achieving the climate targets outlined at the Paris Summit in December 2015, as well as reducing the European Union's dependence on energy imports.  This proposal for a Regulation has objectives outlined by the Union on environmental matters by marking the emission limits and approval procedures of the European Union for engines intended for mobile non-road machinery. The proposal for a Regulation introduces some measures which, to be implemented correctly, can contribute decisively to reducing the environmental impact caused by this equipment, including by promoting the use of more efficient equipment and reducing the use of fossil fuels, channelling funding routes to innovative projects that reduce exhaust emissions, promoting the use of portable emission measurement systems , control of the type of imported engines entering the EU market, among other measures. To this end, I vote in favour of this proposal, as I consider it essential for the EU to set common rules on emission limits for engine type-approval for mobile machinery for non-road use.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is part of the political project to create a transatlantic single market. In addition, it will bring an additional difficulty to European industry at a time when the urgent need is to support European industrial production. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of strict emission limits for non-road mobile machinery (NRMM) placed on the EU market from 2019. 15% of total NOx emissions and 5% of total PM emissions in the EU are caused by NRMM, mainly due to construction sites and machinery. This report will ensure that industry is manufacturing progressively cleaner engines for these machines and will bring both environmental and health benefits for citizens.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the emissions limit and reception-per-type requirements for internal combustion engines for non-road mobile vehicles. This report allows for a balanced compromise between the requirement of environmental protection and that of not harming the competitiveness of businesses in the European Union.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr McDerman's report. Gardini on emission and type-approval limits for internal combustion engines intended for non-road mobile machinery. In principle, the proposal for a regulation aims to help address the public health concerns raised by some studies, to improve air quality in general, and to create a barrier-free market, not only at EU level, but also with our main trading partners around the world. The health and safety of our citizens is a key aspect of this proposal, especially for those who work with these machines every day because they are particularly exposed to polluting emissions.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union currently applies the strictest rules on emissions. It is very important that we formulate harmonised rules. Our aim is to further improve the quality of the environment and thereby improve the health of European citizens. Predictability is important in order to maintain the competitiveness of industry, which can increase employment. I supported this report, which seeks to strike a reasonable balance between health and the competitiveness of the European Union.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report, which will generally improve air quality following the public health concern created by studies indicating that ultra-fine particles are a carcinogenic substance. The report will strike a reasonable balance between health and environmental concerns and the competitiveness of EU manufacturing industry, with the jobs and know-how it entails.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the approval of emission limits for internal combustion engines, which affects a wide range of machines from chainsaws, lawn mowers, bulldozers to ships and locomotives. The approved limits apply to newly produced machines and a sufficiently long transitional period has been adopted to allow all manufacturers to prepare for the new situation. The new legislation will not directly affect users of these machines, gardeners, of course, will not have to go with their cutchaulets to any emission controls. A legitimate reason for its adoption is, on the one hand, the unification of previously fragmented national regulations, which will improve the functioning of the common market, and, on the other hand, the improvement of air quality, since, according to the analyses carried out, non-road machinery accounts for up to 15% of all nitrogen emissions into the atmosphere and 5% of particulate matter emissions. I believe that, in today's state of technological development, there is no excuse for tolerating excessive discharges of poisons into the air.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report was concerned with emission limits for non-road mobile machinery (NRMM). It addresses type approval for internal combustion engines, given that NRMM engines constitute a significant proportion of the total man-made emissions of certain noxious atmospheric pollutants. In some cities, non-road mobile machinery (which includes construction machines, vessels and railways etc.) is responsible for up to 30% of traffic pollution. The figures indicate that NRMM is responsible for around 7% of airborne particulates and 16% of nitrogen oxides in Europe, causing 400 000 premature deaths each year according to the World Health Organisation. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report, as a large number of SMEs will be affected by this regulation. Furthermore, the emission savings cannot be put forward in concrete terms in the impact assessment.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Directive will be supplemented with new technologies in mind, in particular with a view to protecting human health and the environment.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. Non-road mobile machines include a wide variety ranging from gardening tools to heavy or agricultural construction machinery, and are responsible for approximately 15% of the nitrogen oxide emitted and 5% of the Union particles. Let's remember that these particles have carcinogenic properties, so we're talking not only about an air quality issue but also about public health.  This Regulation will replace the various national legislation on the subject, giving the industry a unique opportunity to market these engines on the Union market, increase competitiveness and information for users. We are finally looking at a text that strikes a proportionate balance between the concern for health and the environment and the competitiveness of the sector itself, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the draft regulation tabled. It is essential that the free movement of goods, persons, services and capital is ensured in the internal market. It is therefore essential that the EU is subject to transparent, simple and consistent rules that ensure legal certainty and clarity, which would benefit both businesses and consumers. In order to reduce motor emissions in a sustainable capacity, direct cooperation between manufacturers and related undertakings and reliable research institutions needs to be continuously strengthened. Such cooperation is important for the development of new products and technologies with a positive impact on air quality. It should be noted that, in order to reduce the risk of market distortion and, at the same time, adverse health effects, the emission limit values for certain engine categories must be harmonised. In addition, manufacturers must be able to properly fulfil their warranty obligations and ensure that such engines are available on the market.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP objects to new EU legislation in this field. We believe that the UK should make its own energy policy, and exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is no doubt that, in the field of public health, the non-road mobile machinery sector causes significant harmful emissions. Although it accounts for a small percentage of the sector, non-road mobile machinery emits as much as 15% of all nitrogen oxide and 5% of particulate matter produced in the European Union. In the belief that more stringent measures are needed in this area, I believe that the amendments tabled by my colleague to the Commission's proposal for a regulation are to be welcomed, inso far as they review the categories of machinery affected by engine replacement, in line with the provisions of Directive 97/68/EC, and opt for a reduction in administrative obligations. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I supported the resolution in view of the need to adopt a separate set of rules, thus fully respecting the specific requirements related to engines for non-road mobile machinery following the new regulatory approach for engine type-approval. The resolution lays down the basic provisions on emissions of gaseous and particulate pollutants and the type-approval of internal combustion engines for non-road mobile machinery. In this way, harmonised rules for EU type-approval of engines for non-road mobile machinery will ensure the functioning of the internal market in this area and will follow commitments to reduce emissions and ensure air quality, thus limiting the harmful effects.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Reducing air pollution remains one of the European Union's most important political priorities. A thematic strategy on air pollution to reduce the adverse impact of air pollution on human health and the environment for the period up to 2020 sets legally binding limits on total permissible emissions at Member State level for several air pollutants. However, these limit values exceeded 12 Member States and I consider that stricter requirements for internal combustion engines in off-road transport would contribute favourably to the objectives of these policies.  We must take care of the quality of the air we breathe and there must be no lack of political will to take care of our environment, and therefore directly about people's health.  Air pollution is a global problem, and our task is to achieve air quality that will not threaten human health, and we can do so by adopting Regulations like this that will regulate emissions for out-of-court mobile machines. Nevertheless, we must show more will than the adoption of the regulations itself. Each of us should, through our engagement for the environment, show an example of preserving the environment as our common house and take care of generations who are still waiting to experience the benefits of this country.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. I criticise this text: to standardize against a subsidiarity of course; to be part of the political project to create a transatlantic single market; to bring an additional difficulty to European industry at a time when the urgent need is to support European industrial production; a form of programmed obsolescence to banish a large number of valid engines beyond the transition period. I obviously voted against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the proposal for emission limits for off-screen mobile machines aimed at regulating harmful emissions from engines installed in so-called off-screen mobile machines. These engines cover a wide range of machines such as construction machinery, trains, chainsaws, generators, etc. Emissions from engines in off-test mobile machinery contribute a significant share of total EU emissions. It is therefore important to improve air quality in this way to ensure that Member States meet their national air quality improvement targets. Setting stricter emission limits for non-test mobile machinery is an essential part of the European Union's air quality improvement policy framework and will help Member States reduce the required emissions, as proposed in the Ambient Air Quality Directive. While emission limits for road vehicles are getting higher and higher, equivalent measures for off-road mobile machines are lagging behind. This is why the new legal framework on emissions of out-of-plan mobile machines is key in achieving the objectives of improving air quality in the European Union.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I decided to support the proposal to introduce emission limits for machines powered by internal combustion engines that are not intended for transport on the roads. For example, motor boats, lawn mowers, bulldozers, diesel locomotives or diesel generators. Fumes from these machines account for around 15% of total NOx emissions and 5% of particulate matter emissions, and their share is estimated to rise to 19% by 2020, so it was necessary to address this issue. I believe that the new emission requirements are intended to correspond to technological progress, but also to stimulate this progress. Another important part of this proposal was market harmonisation, which will contribute to the increased competitiveness of European products on international markets.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation presented by the Commission aims, firstly, to help address public health concerns, improve air quality and create a barrier-free market, not only at Union level, but also with its main trading partners around the world. Non-road mobile machinery is one of the many sectors that contribute to harmful emissions in the form of gas or particulate matter. In order to solve this problem, the Commission proposes to set stricter standards for most engines already covered by existing Directive 97/68/EC and to extend this scope to new engine power ranges, combustion types and new fuels, as well as to a number of new categories of machinery, with the aim of eliminating gaps in the legislation. The Regulation therefore lays down new limits for emissions from engines installed in non-road machinery such as construction, agricultural machinery, locomotives and inland waterway vessels. It is certainly a piece of legislation that increases protection for the health of citizens and contributes to the fight against global warming. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the adoption of this regulation.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The first reading agreement concerns emission limit conditions and type-approval for internal combustion engines intended for non-road mobile machinery. These machines include lawnmowers, doves, railway locomotives and inland waterway vessels; they account for around 15% of total NOx emissions and 5% of particulamin pollution in the EU.  The agreement tightens up the existing limit conditions for these emissions, introduces larger power categories for non-road mobile machinery engines covered by the Regulation and generally adapts the limit conditions to the market conditions in the US and Japan, where these values are currently stricter than in the EU. This agreement is a good example of better regulation in action, which reflects the principle of small-scale thinking, while ensuring rules that are appropriate for both environmental and economic objectives. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Some non-road mobile vehicles, such as some boats or diesel locomotives, account for 15% of total nitrogen dioxide (NOx) emissions and 5% of fine particulate emissions in the European Union. I voted in favour of rules that will limit these emissions but which will not call into question the competitiveness of our European companies in the sector, which will be able to quickly comply with the European regulation.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on a proposal covering a wide range of combustion engines that can be installed on a wide range of machinery, from small manual equipment to locomotives and vessels. Within the European Union, this range of machinery accounts for around 15 % of NOx emissions and 5 % of particulate emissions. I consider it important to note that this proposal enshrines, with regard to the reduction of these emissions, a set of highly satisfactory measures, such as the increase in the transition period granted to companies for the replacement of their machinery, the simplification of the implementation phases of projects for the introduction of new emission levels, the possibility of replacing old mills with new devices with better environmental performance , a new monitoring system that will ensure compliance of emissions tested in laboratories with those registered in the real world and, last but not least, the relevant role given to the European Parliament in this area. I am of the view that the Union hereby acts to restore confidence to European citizens in complying with the obligations imposed on undertakings in environmental matters. To that end, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP objects to new EU legislation in this field. We believe that the UK should make its own energy policy, and exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on emissions limit and type reception requirements for internal combustion engines for non-road mobile vehicles, such as lawnmowers, bulldozers, diesel locomotives and some boats.  These devices are responsible for 15% of nitrogen oxide emissions and 5% of fine particulate matter emissions in the EU. It was therefore necessary to update the current legislation in order to adapt it to technical developments.  In particular, we have tightened emission limits for many types of engines, extended legislation to other categories of engines, simplified administrative procedures or strengthened market surveillance rules. The Commission should also implement monitoring programmes to determine the gap between measured and actual emissions. It seems to me that the text strikes a good balance between protecting the environment and health on the one hand, and the competitiveness of European businesses on the other.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. Mobile non-road machinery, according to Commission data, emits 15 % of all NOx and 5 % of all polluting particles in the EU. In order to address this problem, the Commission should indeed set stricter standards for most engines already existing under current Directive 97/68/EC, as well as their extension to new engine power ranges, combustion types and used fuels in order to eliminate loopholes in legislation.  In addition to the obvious and desirable environmental and health effects for our citizens, this has the advantage of creating for industry and machinery users a harmonised internal market and facilitating trade and competitiveness, while finally making environmental legislation a commercial opportunity. We must try to strike a balance between health and environmental concerns, as proposed by the Commission, the competitiveness of the EU manufacturing industry and job creation.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. •u2012 Engines installed on mobile machinery that do not drive on the road are responsible for approximately 15% of the nitrogen oxide emitted and 5% of eu particulate matter emissions.  In September 2014, the European Commission published a proposal for a regulation with measures to reduce emissions of major air pollutants from the engines of mobile machines that do not drive on the road. This proposal reduces, at the same time, the complexity of the legal framework for the sector. The proposal introduces new emission limits reflecting technological progress and EU policies in the road sector, with a view to achieving EU air quality targets; expands the scope, in order to improve market harmonisation (EU and international) and minimize the risk of market distortions and introduce measures to simplify administrative procedures and improve compliance, including conditions for better market surveillance. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Lawnmowers, bulldozers, tractors, diesel locomotives, inland navigation boats and other non-road motor vehicles are vehicles that have significant impacts, particularly in terms of air pollution. Therefore, it was important for the European Union to adopt legislation to severely limit the polluting emissions of these devices for environmental and public health reasons.   I can therefore only welcome the adoption by a very large majority of the inter-institutional agreement on this new regulation. Once the Commission approves this agreement, the industry will need to comply quickly with this new regulation. This is great news for the health of our European citizens and for the environment.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, despite the fact that it is not as ambitious as I would like. It should be noted that these engines contribute significantly to air pollution and are responsible for approximately 15% of nitrogen oxide and 5% of particulate emissions in the European Union.  However, this report is a step forward in its efforts to limit air pollution. I am pleased that this report proves that air pollution is being looked at more widely. Efforts are currently being made to reduce pollution in all sectors , and therefore to non-road mobile machinery for internal combustion engines.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deals with a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the requirements for emission limits and approval of internal combustion engines, non-road mobile machinery. There are several urban areas in Europe that do not fully comply with air quality standards and to some extent this quality is called into question by the contribution of harmful emissions given by the NRMM (mobile non-road machinery) sector, in the form of gases or particles, to the atmosphere, with serious damage to public health. Unreserved support, therefore, the Commission's proposal for the establishment of stricter standards for most existing engines, as well as their extension to new engine power ranges, combustion types and used fuels, as well as new categories of machinery. For the sake of air quality, the environment and citizens' health, I voted in favour of this report which will also bring advantages in terms of harmonisation of the internal market, trade facilitation and strengthening competitiveness for the Manufacturing Industry sector of the European Union.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on emission limit requirements for non-road mobile vehicles. This text aims to broaden the scope of EU legislation in the field of non-road engines with the aim of harmonising the market and reducing distortions on it. The purpose of the regulation is to simplify the current legal framework and administrative procedures.  The primary purpose of this report is to ensure the protection of the environment and the health of people who work near the devices and are therefore particularly exposed to emissions. In particular, the report recommends giving Member States the ability to ban the use of combustion engines for health and safety reasons at work. Internal combustion engines are an important source of greenhouse gas and fine particulate matter emissions that are particularly harmful to human health and the environment.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the parliamentary majority, I voted in favour of the report by Mr Gardini, EPP, on emission limits for non-road mobile machinery. The ENVI Committee has worked to set stricter emission limits, with the aim of safeguarding not only the environment but also the health of workers using this type of machinery, such as construction machinery or agricultural equipment. As a member of the Committee of Inquiry into The Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector (EMIS), I have been able to get to know this issue more closely. That is why I welcome the ambitious project presented by the rapporteur, because engines of non-road mobile machinery make an important contribution to the problem of nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions. I would also like to stress that the focus is also on industry, because the limits and modifications provided for the engines in question can be made in a reasonable time, and especially for SMEs, which have more time to comply with the new standards laid down.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is intended to reduce the emission of non-mobile combustion engines. It is a very technical, specific report on the characteristics of machinery that do not have specific rolling to move: normally used in agriculture, on some railway tracks, on some cotton farms, machinery such as snow cleaners and specific tractors. The objective was to harmonize their life cycle potential, replacing them with less polluting engines that could drastically contribute to reducing EMISSIONs of CO2 and other pollutants. I voted in favour of the report as the negotiations on the trilogue were positive for the EGUE and the Council and the European Parliament agreed to pay adequate attention to any consequences that replacement could have, as well as to mitigate the economic impact, mainly on the agriculture sector.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Poor air quality is the number one environmental cause of premature death in the EU. It causes millions of premature deaths each year worldwide. It has been rightly described as an ‘invisible killer’ - causing heart attacks, strokes, lung cancer, and respiratory disease. We have passed legislation in this Parliament to reduce air pollution from major sources, such as road traffic and industrial installations. These legal limits deliver real reductions in pollution and help Member States reach their national air quality targets. But the investment needed to improve air quality cannot be made by one or two sectors. Cleaning up our air means higher standards in all sectors, including non-road mobile machinery. If the short-term economic costs are shared, the long-term health and social benefits will be much greater. This legislation is another important step in cleaning up our air, to improve our environment and ensure people live longer, healthier lives.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the requirements relating to emission limit values and type-approval for internal combustion engines for non-road mobile machinery. We are talking here about new emission levels for construction vehicles, ships and locomotives.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Air quality control is an essential priority of environmental policy. With the amendments incorporated, the proposal broadens its focus on public health, strengthens Parliament's role in implementing the directive and ensures an improvement over current emissions. That's why I voted for it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new regulation aims to update European type-approval standards and emission limits for internal combustion engines for non-road mobile machinery, such as lawnmowers, bulldozers, diesel engines and inland waterway vessels. According to a Commission study, non-road mobile machinery emits 15% of all nitrogen oxide (NOx) and 5% of all particulate matter in the Union. This text provides for a 'staggered' approach in such a way as to allow the gradual introduction of new engines in the sectors covered by the new requirements. Given that the agreement reached aims to ensure a reasonable balance between health and environmental concerns and the competitiveness of the European manufacturing sector, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it leads to new EU legislation.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the voting session today I voted in favour of this legislative report as it will introduce strict emission limits for non-road mobile machinery placed on the EU market from 2019. Currently, 15% of total NOx emissions – and 5% of total particulate-matter emissions – in the EU are caused by non-road mobile machinery. This report will ensure that industry is manufacturing progressively cleaner engines for these machines and will bring both environmental and health benefits for citizens.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this legislative resolution. In line with EU air quality policy, the objective is to gradually reduce emissions from engines that are placed on the market, thus replacing more polluting old engines over time. In general, limit values will be leveled with those in the US and Japanese markets whose limits are currently stricter than in the EU.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒I supported the Report on the Proposal for a Regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on emission limit requirements and type approval for internal combustion engines for off-road mobile machinery, as the Commission's proposal for regulation to improve air quality and create barrier-free markets, not only within the EU, but also to the bulk of trading partners worldwide. The selective approach, which distinguishes between engine size and type of machinery, provides a good introduction to meeting these goals. The primary objective of this report is to strike a balance between health and environmental care, as well as increasing the competitiveness of the European manufacturing industry. Also, long-term safety planning and a stable regulatory environment in the industry and in this sense the new regulatory proposal will have better effects than previous directives that are subject to various interpretations, and practice has shown that the time period for implementation of directives is too long. Given the aspects of competition, SMEs, generators of many jobs, could be vulnerable to the new situation and therefore some benefits should also be granted. It is also recommended that administrative obligations be kept to a minimum. Laws and formalities must evolve according to the digital age.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution because I believe that the sustainable achievement of the Union's air quality and air protection targets from now until 2020 and later requires the adopting of additional emission limits also for non-road mobile machinery. I agree that the new emission limits should also apply to agricultural machinery and vehicles, which should make the share of non-road mobile machinery in emissions more appropriate in relation to road vehicles. I expect that the proposed measures will not only extend the scope of Union legislation in the area of market harmonisation, but also simplify the current legal framework, including measures to simplify administrative procedures and improve general enforcement conditions. I approve that, in order to reduce emissions from non-road mobile machinery, we should step up direct cooperation between manufacturers and other related enterprises, on the one hand, and well-established scientific research institutions, on the other. I believe that, if there is better cooperation in the development of new products and technologies, the area of air quality will also be improved and emissions from non-road mobile machinery and agricultural vehicles will also be reduced.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation on the requirements applicable to emission limit values and the type-approval of internal combustion engines in non-road mobile machinery. The resolution approved by Parliament contains amendments and additions to the commission's original proposal, which have been informally negotiated with the Member States. The Council has yet to formally confirm this Regulation, which will then enter into force. The Regulation replaces the 1997 Directive. On the one hand, it will unify the existing 28 legal regimes into one, which is particularly welcomed by engine manufacturers. On the other hand, it will modernize the somewhat outdated design. In principle, the new regulation lays down the same rules for all internal combustion engines, from those in locomotives to those in large construction machinery to those in chainsaws and presses. Emission limits for the future limit the discharge of harmful nitrogen compounds (NOx) and hazardous particulate matter by these engines. Colleagues from the ENVI and IMCO committees have succeeded in improving the Commission's initial proposal and ing it into a form that is acceptable to both Member States and industry representatives. I must stress in particular that the new limits will only apply to newly produced engines placed on the market. For consumers, nothing changes except that in the future their garden machines will emit less unhealthy exhaust gases.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal sets conditions in relation to emission limit values and type-approval for internal combustion engines for non-road mobile machinery. The legislation covers many different engines, which largely contribute to air pollution and are responsible for around 15 per cent of nitrogen oxide and 5 per cent of particulate matter emissions in the European Union. Compared to existing legislation, this proposal introduces new limit values that better reflect technological advances, as well as the European Union's road policies. Although the report is less ambitious than the original proposal to limit nitrogen oxide for inland waterways, it still represents a major step forward towards limiting pollution by engine categories. For this very reasons, I voted in plenary to adopt a report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on requirements relating to emission limit values and type-approval for internal combustion engines for non-road mobile machinery.

name: Renato Soru (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 As is often reported in the news, in many urban areas of the Union air quality levels are such as to pose risks to man and the environment: there would be 72,000 premature deaths attributable to nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and 403,000 to particulate matter (European Environment Agency data), at an estimated annual cost of hundreds of billions of euros. That is why I voted in favour of the regulation updating emission standards and limits for non-road machinery, such as bulldozers, agricultural and construction machinery and inland waterway vessels, which account for around 15% of European nitrogen oxide emissions and 5% of particulate emissions harmful to health. The aim is to address public health concerns emerging from studies showing the likely carcinogenic nature of ultrafine particulate matter, to improve air quality, while maintaining the competitiveness of European companies in the sector through the gradual and diversified introduction of these new standards. Indeed, I believe that, in the face of these concerns, the text adopted today translates a reasonable balance between the objectives of protecting public health and the environment and the competitiveness of the European manufacturing sector, the jobs and skills it generates.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. This report on non-road mobile machinery (NRMM) that is not intended for road use is not controversial. It is compatible with economic expertise. Adapting to the emission limits in the US and Japanese markets makes perfect sense from a trade policy point of view. This new regulation replaces the existing directive. All types of internal combustion engines, including small portable appliances, have been integrated into the new performance ranges in this Regulation. The report strikes a balance between environmental protection and the protection of the competitiveness of European industry. That is why I followed the ECR line and voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the fact that greenhouse gas emissions are also heavily influenced by machines, the environment must also be taken into account in this regard. The proposed regulation has two objectives: reducing emissions and cutting red tape. Such an adjustment can have a positive impact not only on citizens' health, but also on the business environment and competitiveness in Europe.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of strict emission limits for non-road mobile machinery (NRMM) placed on the EU market from 2019. 15% of total NOx emissions and 5% of total PM emissions in the EU are caused by NRMM, mainly due to construction sites and machinery. This report will ensure that industry is manufacturing progressively cleaner engines for these machines and will bring both environmental and health benefits for citizens.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I do not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on emission limits for non-road mobile machinery. This regulation regulates the exhaust emissions of all types of equipment. The rationale is that the internal market should be based on uniform rules, because businesses and consumers alike can benefit from them. This – the justification for most internal market regulations – is simply wrong. Consumers take advantage of competition for the best devices. With uniform rules, this is no longer possible to the same extent, because the best device for consumers becomes illegal through regulation. We are not dealing with consumer-friendly regulation, but with consumer-damaging harmonisation. Europe must be diversity, also and especially through different regulatory approaches. This is the competition that we need and to which we must expose businesses to the benefit of consumers.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Today, a large number of urban areas of the Union do not fully meet air quality standards. The primary objective of this Report is to strike a balance between health and environmental care. The health and safety of our citizens, especially those who work every day with machines, are key elements of this proposal as they are particularly exposed to pollutant emissions. Another goal is to offer the industry long-term certainty and a stable regulatory environment. I support the proposal for this Regulation as I believe it will contribute to improving air quality and create a barrier-free market, not only within the Union, but also with our main trading partners around the world. The choice of this new legislative instrument in the form of regulations offers a clear advantage over directives that take time to transpose into national law.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on requirements relating to emission limit values and type-approval for internal combustion engines for non-road mobile machinery. Non-road mobile machinery is one of the factors contributing to harmful emissions in the form of gases or particles. It is important to remember that today several urban areas in the European Union do not fully meet air quality standards. I also support the amendments to the regulation, in particular the amendment, which stresses that, in addition to reducing market distortions, the purpose of this regulation is to simplify the current legal framework, including measures to simplify administrative procedures.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This Regulation seeks to establish harmonised rules for THE EU type-approval of engines fitted to non-road mobile machinery, with a view to ensuring the functioning of the internal market for air quality. The health and safety of European citizens is a priority. We agree that new emission limits should be introduced, which should also apply to agricultural vehicles, reflecting technological progress and ensuring convergence with Union policies in the field of road transport, in order to achieve air quality targets and reduce emissions from non-road mobile machinery and agricultural vehicles. , resulting in a more proportional proportion of emissions from machinery than emissions from road vehicles.  Finally, the scope of legislation in this area should be broadened with a view to improving market harmonisation and minimising the risk of market distortions and adverse health effects.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 We all agree that we need to reduce emissions and that this can be achieved by imposing strict limits. The majority society also agrees that we need to tighten not only the emissions of internal combustion engines moving on public roads, but also emission limits for non-road machinery and equipment. The latter machines and equipment are responsible for 15% of all NOx emitted by the European Union and 5% of air pollutants. The report is an important part of the Eu's air quality and protection strategy and I agree with its findings and voted in favour of it. In addition to the main objective of reducing emissions here, this obviously also means market harmonisation, the de-eminent elements of the market and the simplification of administration. Put simply, it can stimulate innovation and create jobs. I believe that the companies and cities concerned understand all this and will achieve the necessary emission reductions with financial incentives. In my speech on this subject, I said that this is a good example of the environmental and health benefits of the common market and that air pollution does not stop at the borders of the European Union. That is why this regulation also affects post-Brexit Britain, whether it is inside or out: border cooperation and rules between European countries will always be important!

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Reducing pollutant emissions is one of the European Union's key aims in terms of its environmental policy. A significant part of these emissions comes from internal combustion engines for non-road mobile equipment. This category includes construction equipment, river vessels, trains, chainsaws and electricity generators. In order to achieve EU air quality targets, certain limits at Member State level need to be observed. The Commission's proposal to this effect aims to introduce new emission limits reflecting technological progress, extending targets towards harmonising domestic and international markets, simplifying administrative procedures and supervising markets, as well as transitional periods to allow manufacturers of such engines to adapt their models to the new requirements.  Transitional periods shall cover in particular the emission limits of river vessels and the obligation to replace transport fleets in urban areas; therefore generous time limits have been set, which also reach 20 years. I believe that these are necessary regulations, which take into account the progress made in the area of limiting road pollution and which aim to improve the living conditions of European citizens. For this reason, I support the current report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on emissions limits and type reception requirements for internal combustion engines for non-road mobile vehicles

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of limiting emissions for non-road mobile machinery, such as small equipment, construction machinery, locomotives and inland waterway vessels, which contribute significantly to air pollution. This regulation will ensure that only engines in compliance with the new emission-limits requirements will be allowed to be placed on the internal market. In addition to protecting human health and the environment better, it will ensure the proper functioning of the internal market for engines in non-road mobile machinery by improving the general conditions for enforcement, in particular through stronger rules on market surveillance. I am particularly supportive of the aim to simplify the current legal framework and simplify administrative procedures, which is in line with my commitment to bring better regulation to the EU.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Gardini's report because I am convinced that it is all the more necessary to help ensure, through a fairer and more integrated single market, the protection of the environment and health. This regulation aims to reduce emissions and bureaucracy by setting stricter limits for pollutant emissions from engines installed on non-road mobile machinery and by establishing harmonised standards for European markets in line with international standards. These objectives are certainly good for environmental protection and contribute to the growth and increase in the employment rate. Support for this proposal is a clear sign of the desire to significantly reduce air pollution, improve the health of citizens and increase the competitiveness of businesses, thanks to increased investment and legal certainty.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒in 2012 I voted for the Report on the Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on emission limit requirements and type approval for internal combustion engines for out-of-plan mobile machinery, as this Regulation will lay down harmonised rules for EU type-approval to ensure the functioning of the internal market in the broader context of the ongoing review of the Union's air quality policy. The primary objective of this Report is to strike a balance between health and environmental care and offer industry long-term safety planning and a stable regulatory environment. I would also like to point out that administrative burdens will be kept to a minimum and take advantage of the already existing internal information system market, which takes precedence over the development of a new administrative system in order to avoid additional costs.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the proposal for a Regulation on requirements relating to emission limit values and type-approval for internal combustion engines for non-road mobile machinery. The aim of the proposal is to set new requirements for reducing emissions of harmful substances from engines installed in non-road mobile machinery. The proposal covers many different types of internal combustion engines, which are responsible in the EU for the release of around 15 % of nitrogen oxide and 5% of particulate emissions and introduces new emission limit values. There are rather sharp restrictions, but they are still reasonable enough so that the industry can operate in line with the new requirements. The regulation maintains a balanced approach between environmental protection and safeguarding the competitiveness of EU industry. The new rules will simplify the implementation phase of the introduction of new emission limit values and type-approval procedures with a view to reducing the burden on manufacturers. The exchange of data and information through the use of the Internal Market Information System will also be simplified. The proposal for a regulation also allows for the possibility of replacing defective old engines for non-road mobile machinery with engines of the same type within a specified period, where the replacement using a new and better engine type is incompatible with the older model.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is intended to reduce the emission of non-mobile combustion engines. It is a very technical, specific report on the characteristics of machinery that do not have specific rolling to move: normally used in agriculture, on some railway tracks, on some cotton farms, machinery such as snow cleaners and specific tractors. The objective was to harmonize their life cycle potential, replacing them with less polluting engines that could drastically contribute to reducing EMISSIONs of CO2 and other pollutants. I voted in favour of the report as the negotiations on the trilogue were positive for the EGUE and the Council and the European Parliament agreed to pay adequate attention to any consequences that replacement could have, as well as to mitigate the economic impact, mainly on the agriculture sector.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The non-road mobile machinery (NRMM) report aims to bring European standards into line with emission limit values standards in THE US and Japanese markets. All types of internal combustion engines, including small portable appliances, have been integrated into the new performance ranges in this Regulation. The report strikes a balance between environmental protection and the protection of the competitiveness of European industry. That is why I followed the ECR line and voted in favour of the report.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this text because it is in line with the EU’s air quality policy, the objective is to progressively reduce the emissions from new engines being brought on the market and, thereby, replace the old, more polluting ones over time. The proposal is also expected to alleviate the pressure on Member States to take additional regulatory action that could hamper the internal market. Finally, the proposal seeks to remove obstacles to external trade through harmonised rules and by reducing the regulatory barriers that result from diverging emission requirements. In particular with a view to bringing EU and US requirements closer together. We should focus primarily in urban conglomeration where there is a higher concentration of people that are affected by air pollution.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Non-road mobile devices account for 5% of EU particulate emissions. The text thus seems to be moving in the right direction by proposing a harmonisation of standards at eu-wide in order to reduce these particulate emissions.  The fight for the preservation of the environment is the responsibility of all of us. However, the report presents dangerous points for our automotive industry. Manufacturers are investing to make their engines less polluting and are successful in limiting emissions. The regulation therefore seems too harsh in the face of the current crisis facing the automotive sector.  In addition, this report is politically involved in the creation of the transatlantic single market with the United States.  Finally, it indirectly advocates a form of programmed obsolescence of engines that are still valid. Constitutionally this text is a binding regulation for the Member States, a common EU procedure that I denounce every day. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This regulation is an update of the 2004 Directive, which has lost its validity in recent years as a result of technological progress. I believe that divergences in emissions should be regulated on an ongoing basis. Furthermore, in line with the European Union's air quality policy, this will gradually reduce emissions from new engines placed on the market, thereby replacing old, more polluting air over time, thereby contributing to the protection of health and the environment.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The rapporteur welcomes, in principle, the Commission's proposal for a regulation aimed primarily at addressing public health concerns raised by studies that classify ultrafine particles as carcinogens, to improve air quality in general and to create a borderless market within the European Union and with our main global trading partners. The intermittent approach, which discriminates by engine size and machine type, will allow for the smooth introduction of the Regulation for industries affected by the new specifications, taking into account the diversity of engines and machinery. I followed S&D's position in the vote.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is intended to reduce the emission of non-mobile combustion engines. It is a very technical, specific report on the characteristics of machinery that do not have specific rolling to move: normally used in agriculture, on some railway tracks, on some cotton farms, machinery such as snow cleaners and specific tractors. The objective was to harmonize their life cycle potential, replacing them with less polluting engines that could drastically contribute to reducing EMISSIONs of CO2 and other pollutants. I voted in favour of the report as the negotiations on the trilogue were positive for the EGUE and the Council and the European Parliament agreed to pay adequate attention to any consequences that replacement could have, as well as to mitigate the economic impact, mainly on the agriculture sector.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on requirements relating to emission limits and type-approval for internal combustion engines for non-road mobile machinery. The regulation aims to help address the public health concern created by studies identifying ultra-fine particles as a carcinogenic substance, to generally improve air quality and to create a market without barriers not only within the EU but also with our main trade partners around the world. Today, several EU urban areas do not fully meet the air-quality standards and the problem is growing, as more people are attracted to live in conglomerations. I voted in favour because I believe that technological progress can justify stricter regulation without putting undue pressure on the manufacturing industry.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a proposal that will undoubtedly contribute to improving air quality and, from an industrial point of view, will make the manufacture of the machinery to which it is applied more technologically advanced in order to meet the emission limit values established in the expected periods. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Air quality control is an essential priority of environmental policy. With the amendments incorporated, the proposal broadens its focus on public health, strengthens Parliament's role in implementing the directive and ensures an improvement over current emissions. That's why I voted for it.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted for this report out of concern about clean air for future generations. The purpose of this Regulation is to harmonise the rules for EU type-approval for engines of non-road machinery. The European Union is taking the lead on the ongoing review of air quality policy. To this end, new emission limit values should be set, which should also apply to agricultural machinery, among other things. The purpose of this Regulation is to simplify the current regulatory framework and administrative procedures and to improve the general conditions for enforcement.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Air pollution in Europe remains a cause for concern despite improvements. This is one of the sectors that is important to regulate, despite being responsible for a minority share of emissions. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety has introduced some amendments to the initial version. Among others, the list of exemptions was extended. The implementation dates for engines used in river vessels have been modified.  We agree that Member States should be able to ban the use of combustion engines for health and safety reasons at work, in particular in nerve points where air quality is poor. The rapporteur made a point of introducing her concerns about the possible distortion in the internal market. But we agree with the aim of simplifying administrative procedures and improving general conditions of implementation, we do not follow the rapporteur's considerations regarding the internal market. Concerns should focus on protecting the environment and the health of populations. We voted in favour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposal for a regulation deals with air pollution caused by non-road mobile machinery (NRMM). The existing emission guidelines for mobile machinery and equipment are necessary. Many EU manufacturers of NRMM engines are already voluntarily complying with the limit values due to international trade. The period between the definition of test cycles and the test procedure (end of 2016) and the entry into force of the new limit values (2019) is simply far too small for the development of new engines. Many SMEs would also be affected, and the emission savings in the impact assessment have not yet been put forward in concrete terms. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. – The proposal aims to regulate harmful emissions from engines installed in so-called non-road mobile machinery (NRMM), a term which covers a wide variety of machinery such as construction machinery, inland water vessels, trains, chainsaws and generator sets. Emissions from engines in NRMM contribute significantly to the EU’s total polluting emissions. This is therefore an important piece of source-level air-quality legislation to ensure that Member States meet their national air-quality targets set under other EU legislation. I voted in favour of the report as I believe it will bring both environmental and health benefits by reducing pollutant emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx), hydro-carbons (HC), carbon-monoxide (CO), and particulate matter (PM) from engines fitted in NRMM. In addition, my S & D Group colleagues managed to include important provisions on the protection of workers’ health and safety and for the retrofitting of machines already in use.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation because I deem it necessary. We have been working for a long time on the creation of frameworks that aim to reduce emissions. The most well-known ones are those that apply to cars. However, they are not the only polluters. For non-road mobile machinery (NRMM) we also need to strive towards emission reductions. Before this regulation, NRMM was regulated by a number of directives. I welcome the Commission proposal because this regulation aims to improve our environment and the health of our citizens, while at the same time enhancing the functioning of our internal market with regard to NRMM by ensuring a level playing field and remedying unfair competition.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report concerns the Regulation on a wider variety of combustion engines fitted to articles such as, inter alia, construction machinery, inland waterway machinery and tractors. The rapporteur's proposals cover both environmental objectives and the needs to support the economy and the competitiveness of relevant sectors in the EU.  An opinion has been submitted by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection in which I am a member. The report was voted on by a large majority in the committee responsible for the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. I voted in favour.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation to regulate emission limits for non-road mobile machinery. Non-road machines, such as cranes or other construction machinery, trains, snowmobiles or even lawnmowers, can make a significant contribution to air pollution, resulting in, among other things, a number of health problems for the people of the European Union. The aim of this proposal was therefore to introduce uniform conditions for emission limits or for the granting of permits for these machines, thereby replacing the current legislation represented by a directive according to which one but 28 different systems did not work. The new regulation introduces not only a uniform system, but also stricter emission limits that are close to japanese or American limits, thus unifying international standards. In addition to the environmental and human health benefits, the regulation will thus also have a share in increasing competitiveness for European industry in these sectors, as European producers will have lower costs, lower administrative burdens resulting from uniform requirements and thus easier access to third-country markets.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Gardini report for agreeing with the substantive requirements set out with regard to emission limits and engine approval procedures to be installed on non-road mobile machinery (NRMM). NRMM have a significant very negative impact on air pollution, with about 15% of nitrogen oxide (NOx) and 5% of particulatematter in the calculation of total EU emissions. While the rules governing emissions from road vehicles have become stricter, so has the same in the NRMM. A new legislative framework for equivalent measures is therefore indispensable to achieve the air quality objectives proposed by the EU. As a full member of the EMIS Committee of Inquiry I have advocated transparency in the approval process. I therefore welcome with particular satisfaction the amendments tabled to that effect, in particular the obligation for manufacturers to make available to the public the value of CO2 emissions determined during the type-approval process.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, every day the Union is put to the test by the human pressure that the migration crisis exerts on its borders and, in particular, on the Shores of Europe. The outcome of the British referendum is one of the institutional consequences of this exodus to the old continent of millions of people fleeing war, disease and hunger.  I join the rapporteur in stressing the importance of the point of view of creating employment opportunities for refugees, not only to guarantee them an income and therefore not to be of weight to the Social System of the Community and individual countries, but above all to avoid that horrible phenomenon that social dumping. The figures on youth unemployment in Europe are alarming: the average age of those arriving on our shores is very low. The growing number of unaccompanied foreign minors is a very strong signal.  The principles of equal treatment and equal opportunities, as a compass for social inclusion and integration policies, must therefore be borne in mind. At the same time, however, we must avoid any kind of competition between the most disadvantaged groups in our society.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: It's one of the most amazing reports, and it's a tough competition. Some quotes: "Successful integration of refugees requires not only integration into the labour market, but also the availability of language courses upon arrival, as well as housing, education, training, social protection and health care," writes point (k). Point (n) then, as a provocation, writes the truth that 24.4% of the total population of the European Union is at risk of poverty and social exclusion and almost 10% are suffering from severe material deprivation. What follows for the EU? That legal migration channels need to be further developed, i.e. more migrants are needed. A permanent relocation mechanism should be introduced for all Member States. There is an urgent need to establish a common asylum system. It also expresses concern in point 38 the decision of some Member States to close their internal borders. I'm a citizen of a country like this, and I'm proud of it.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I did not support this report and i therefore want to give an explanation. The very subject that is to be the main subject of the report, the application of refugees in the labour market, is correct and it is good that we are debating it in Parliament.  On the other hand, I regret that a number of other provisions finally appeared in the text itself, which are not directly related to the application of refugees in the labour market and their integration in society. That is why I could not support this report, because, in short, I have a problem with the considerations that concern the single common asylum system, I have a problem with the creation of a permanent redistribution mechanism, the so-called quota.  These are the strong political issues that divide this House. There are different perspectives on this, and it is a bit of a shame that the point that should really have been about helping refugees and better integrating them and getting them to work contains politically difficult to accept specific provisions.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – I support the search for solutions to migration-related problems, especially for those fleeing war and violence. At the same time, however, I insist that we continue to make a consistent difference between those who come to Europe looking for work and better conditions for life and those who qualify for asylum.  Both one and the others are as human as we are and it is our duty to respect their dignity. But the policies that will deal with their situation must be different. I am afraid that this report does not sufficiently distinguish between the two groups of migrants. And I consider the distribution of migrants among the Member States on the basis of a formula that does not take into account the significant differences between them, as this report calls for, to be the wrong move. That is why I could not support it.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, social inclusion and integration into the labour market are crucial aspects of immigration and, in the case of the European Union today, the integration of the great number of refugees we have seen come over the past few years, fleeing wars and atrocities. Integration is a challenge one way or another. We have to have our hearts open to those fleeing wars, but our national and European systems also need to be ready for a great number of refugees. This is the responsibility of both Member States and the EU. As Europeans, we cannot and will not turn our back on our moral and international legal obligation to those who need it. Professional integration is a major stepping stone towards social inclusion. It is a two-way street, and the effort needs to be made as well by those who are being integrated. First and foremost, it has to be a humanitarian but also sustainable approach to tackling the issue of increased migration, and in that regard I think that the European Commission, especially led by President Juncker, have done an awful lot to give leadership and to help solve this unprecedented problem.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have supported this report because I think that access to work is the highway to integration, social inclusion and dignity for refugees and asylum seekers. I think, too, that asylum seekers should not live on subsidies, but should have the right to work in accordance the Qualifications and Reception Conditions Directives, which should be law in the Member States and should be enforced there. At the same time, let us be clear: the labour market is a national competence and we should respect the fact that the way the labour market is organised is decided by the Member States. I also think it is important to make the distinction between access to the labour market and general access to other social benefits: and here we cannot give equal status to refugees who have obtained international protection and all the asylum seekers who might also be economic migrants and persons not entitled to international protection. It should be up to the Member States to decide what social protection – what level of social security – should be given to them.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the report, in order to promote the social inclusion and integration into the labour market of people seeking refuge in Europe in the face of war or threat in their country of origin, because it is urgent to seek solutions to face with more guarantees a situation for which we were not prepared, but for which we cannot close our eyes.  Immediate action must therefore be taken, always applying the principles of solidarity and equitable sharing of responsibility necessary to address this problem common throughout Europe and which therefore requires a common response from across Europe.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The deep migration crisis that Europe is experiencing makes it urgent to find solutions in harmony with european principles of solidarity and respect for human rights. Setting up a common asylum system, standardising recognition procedures, managing and legalising migratory flows are just some of the proposals that have been put forward. In fact, promoting the process of social inclusion and the integration of refugees is of prime importance, not only to support the Member States most affected by the phenomenon, but above all to avoid further social tensions. For these reasons, considering the migration emergency to be a European problem, I voted in favour, calling for a clear and decisive commitment on the part of all member states.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that respect for human rights and international laws should be accompanied by worthy integration of refugees and asylum seekers into our societies.
