In this sense, we are convinced that social and labour integration is the spearhead for achieving this.  In this regard, the report calls for an increase in the Union's investment in social and labour policies, in order to tackle this situation, preventing this from being detrimental to those European citizens who are already in a vulnerable situation in our countries. It therefore calls for an increase of the European Social Fund's participation in the Structural and Investment Funds to 25%. It requires that the maximum time be reduced so that a refugee can acquire the right to participate in the labour market of the host country to as little as six months. And that their access to training, housing, health, education, as well as recognition of their skills and family reunification can be ensured.  A comprehensive and robust report with recommendations that can be key to managing the crisis we are experiencing in the long run.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. It included calls for more EU interference and rules on asylum and immigration policy. The report also criticised Member States that have tried to control their borders externally and internally in the Schengen area. The only people who should take decisions on these things are elected national governments in compliance with the 1951 Geneva Convention on refugees. None of this should be decided on or dictated by unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report aims to make a number of recommendations to facilitate the inclusion of refugees in the workplace. This is a good way to end the precarious situation in which most refugees live in the European Union, as well as to fight for their empowerment and xenophobia that is still spreading across the continent. That is why I voted in favour of the report, which contains a number of elements which we value very positively, such as the claim to access to rights such as housing, health care, education, or involvement in the process of social organisations and trade unions. In addition, refugees are required to have access to the labour market after a maximum of six months in the Union and to have the same minimum wage applied to them as the rest of the population. These are two central elements for the revision of Directive 2013/33/EU on the reception of asylum seekers, one of the main European regulations to be amended to ensure that refugees living in our society enjoy effective equality.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the integration of "refugees" into the labour market. There are several problems with this text. First, it makes no distinction between refugees and economic migrants, whereas this distinction is paramount in a context of migration crisis. The second problem is based on the EU's strategy for the professional integration of refugees: Brussels wants to put everything in place to find them a job within 6 months, when it has been unable to offer this to European citizens. Finally, it should be noted that the arrival of migrants is presented as a "chance" for European citizens, but the security risks that these flows can engender at any time.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which provides a good starting point for a process to assist refuges in integrating better, and also in participating in the basic human right to work. Moreover, the report contains references to facilitating refugees and asylum seekers in having access to housing, health care, education, social protection and family reunification. For the majority of refugees in Europe, integration is the most relevant durable solution, and EU Member States have a responsibility to ensure that there are programmes and associated support available to facilitate immigrant integration, and also to identify effective practice. Employment is often the key concern for refugee respondents. Regarding entering the labour market, specific barriers exist for refugees in addition to the challenges that other migrants face. Challenges often include loss of identity documentation and qualification certificates, non-acceptance of qualifications or educational attainment, trauma and uncertainty, anxiety over family separation, the long period of inactivity in the asylum system, and limited social networks. It is, therefore, very positive that this report provides such a compassionate and empathetic approach to the needs of people who are fleeing war.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. We welcome the Commission's work for a common approach to promote the integration of refugees into the labour market and greater social inclusion of refugees. We call on Member States to implement effective integration policies without delay and to provide sufficient financial resources to ensure the rapid and full integration of refugees into the labour market and their social inclusion, in accordance with the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the social inclusion and integration of refugees into the EU labour market. The humanitarian crisis represented by the arrival of refugees constitutes one of the main challenges the European Union has to face today. In 2015, a new European Agenda on Migration was adopted with the aim of addressing the difficult management of an unprecedented influx of people. In this regard, cooperation with third countries, humanitarian aid and development aid are some of the main tools available in addressing the root causes of migration (e.g. conflicts and poverty). This crisis has been made more complex by the high number of children, including unaccompanied children, who are involved. Moreover, the crisis is occurring at a time of severe economic conditions in many EU countries, including high unemployment rates. The aim of the report is to outline the issues connected to the refugee crisis and to provide some proposals, recommendations and suggestions for achieving the objective of social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market of the EU.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on refugees, on social inclusion and their integration into the labour market, because such policies are necessary to ensure their equal treatment without discrimination.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Vocational integration also promotes social inclusion. It is precisely for this reason that it is necessary to give refugees and asylum seekers the opportunity to participate actively in the labour market. It is important not to create a special labour market specifically for refugees. Language support is also important, because language is one of the biggest hurdles that keep them from working. Education is another important issue. Most children and young people from crisis areas were unable to attend school for a long period of time, or not at all. It is important to assist them at the beginning of their arrival and to give them the opportunity to educate. The report addresses important points of social inclusion and integration in the labour market, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the whole report because it is sprinkled with gender theory (protecting refugees because they are more at risk, they are more threatened, they are more difficult to find a job...) and anti-extreme (the report notes the rise of xenophobic rhetoric, ambient racism and anti-migrant behaviour). On the other hand, nothing is said about security risks: we never talk about the risks that migrants pose to European citizens, nor about the terrorist threat. Worse, the report supports the Commission when it condemns Member States that have not (pu) put in place the arrangements for welcoming migrants.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the final resolution, essentially because there were too many calls for the European Commission to take action: issues relating to immigration and asylum should be the responsibility of the Member States. Many of the individual roll-call votes made little, if any, distinction between those who have claimed asylum, and those who have been granted asylum. I believe that there is a substantive difference between the two.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls on Member States to promote the social inclusion of refugees through their integration into the labour market. I note that work and the best way to learn a language and culture of the host country. However, I am sounding the alarm about the use of refugees as cheap labour (particularly in the agri-food and construction industries). This is an unacceptable social dumping which must be denounced and solved by the establishment of a European law of asylum seekers.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The response to the refugee crisis facing Europe needs to be answered at various levels: on the one hand, the European Union must strive to contribute to the political stabilisation and social and economic development of countries of origin; on the other hand, Europe must implement the agreed relocation agreement and create conditions to integrate within its boist the thousands of human beings fleeing war, terror and death.  By snaantising myself to the issue of social and labour integration, it is important that the European Union and its Member States allow refugees access to social protection systems (e.g. housing, health, education, social protection and labour protection policies), ensuring conditions for learning the language and culture of their new country and accompanying the processes of social integration in the community. It is also important that at the same time awareness-raising actions be promoted among the communities that welcome them in order to prevent and disprove any kind of discrimination, xenophobia and racism. The report was in my favour because I believe that all these concerns and proposals are in it.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ With the great numbers of refugees arriving in Europe, there is a tremendous need for an appropriate framework for their inclusion in the labour market. We should spare no effort to ensure their social, cultural and economic integration: those migrants who were forced to leave their homes usually suffer from physical and psychological trauma and must be helped. A sense of humanity is crucial and an appreciation of the hardships that migrants have to go through. Secondly, with due regard to high rates of unemployment, refugees should be allowed to contribute to the process of reviving the labour market, and here they can be of great help. If refugees are properly trained and educated, demand and supply on Europe’s labour market will be met. It is clear that the refugee inclusion process is vital for both migrants and their host countries, and therefore their integration must be properly effected and immediate.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market. I agree that the refugee crisis is primarily a humanitarian crisis on a global scale, but it is also a political crisis, and policy-makers must take urgent decisive action and long-term measures that meet the needs of society and the labour market. In particular, it is essential that EU external policies, such as cooperation with third countries, humanitarian aid and development aid, make it possible to eradicate the root causes of migration: conflict and poverty. It is important to establish an immediate common asylum system in order to improve recognition procedures while ensuring the highest level of security for refugees and EU citizens. I agree that the possibility for refugees to work would not only help restore their dignity, but would also be cost-effective by providing themselves, paying taxes and reducing the cost of maintaining refugees. I also support the calls for refugees to offer language and guidance courses. It is necessary to assess in good faith, transparent and free of charge the formal and informal skills of refugees and asylum seekers and to recognise and confirm their qualifications.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. On Tuesday 5 July, by adopting by a large majority a resolution on the "social inclusion and integration into the labour market" of "refugees", the Euro-globalists who preside over the destinies of our adrift Old Continent once again confirmed Murphy's Law: with them, the worst is always certain.  This is a text which, among other things, promotes the development of voluntary associations and Community aid services(-18), calls on Member States to "ensure that asylum seekers are treated in the same way as EU nationals" in their access to the labour market, "underlines the positive effects of refugee mobility" (-36)... and "is concerned by the decision of some Member States to close their borders" to these generous migrants who would be a "chance" for our growing population. A text which, of course, constantly confuses "refugees" and "migrants" in order to better establish them permanently in our territories and this is the directive of seconded workers extended to all migrants of today and tomorrow.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for measures to ensure that refugees and asylum seekers have access to housing, health care, education, social protection and the labour market in order to restore their dignity and promote their integration. MEPs stress that labour market conditions in host countries are one of the determining factors in the successful and sustainable integration of refugees. In this regard, the report reiterates the importance of full and rapid integration into the labour market in accordance with the principle of equal treatment and rapid, easy and equal access to training. To this end, it calls on the European Commission to consider a targeted revision of the Reception Conditions Directive to ensure that people seeking international protection have access to the labour market as soon as possible and no later than 6 months after their application is submitted.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. As established by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, everyone has the right to work.  Work, in addition to a right, is the fundamental instrument for the integration and development of anyone. The Union must not only comply with the Common Asylum Policy by allowing refugees to be welcomed, but must also facilitate their inclusion in the labour market as the necessary means of their full integration into our society. This report contains a large number of measures aimed at achieving this objective. It also pays special attention to vulnerable groups such as women or minors.  I think it is positive that it denies the situation in refugee camps, stresses the importance of education as a vital factor for integration and access to the labour market, and aims to avoid any discrimination against asylum seekers. Since the beginning of the refugee crisis, I have always advocated the need to give a solidarity response to it as well as the implementation of the Common European Asylum System. I believe in a Europe where there is room for those who suffer the conflicts and misery that plague their countries. That's why I voted for it.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European economy, still suffering from a serious crisis, sees the persistence of high rates of unemployment, particularly among young people. In this difficult environment, the presence of an exceptional number of refugees and asylum seekers risks triggering, if not properly managed, processes of social disintegration and conflict. The report on the social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market, which I have drawn up, aims to provide an up-to-date analysis of the situation, proposing policies and good practices for their integration into the labour market and into society. The text stresses, firstly, the need to restore human dignity and self-esteem to them by allowing refugees to gain economic independence. Integration measures must not take away financial resources already allocated to programmes for other disadvantaged groups, but instead require additional social investment. The European Social Fund must be brought back to 25% of the cohesion budget, including by amending the reception conditions directive, allowing faster access to the labour market; we need to increase the public investment available and provide additional financial resources for local, regional public administrations and civil society and voluntary organisations.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is a first step in improving policies for social inclusion and integration of refugees. The text talks about ensuring access to housing, education and training, social protection, health and family reunification, all of which are the indispensable rights of people applying for international protection and which our delegation advocates.     Increasing public investment with an increase in the ESF, as the report shows, is good news, as is ensuring that refugees can access the labour market no later than 6 months after the application and that they have a minimum wage equal to other nationals, avoiding dumping and exploitation of the most vulnerable people. In the blue card paragraph, however, I voted against it as we must avoid rewarding some refugees against others on grounds of origin or training. However, as a whole it is a positive report and in that regard I voted.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work in this report on social inclusion and integration into the refugee labour market. I voted differently from my group in relation to paragraph 79, which discusses the recommendation that additional language classes be provided for minors in the language of their country of origin. Similarly, I have also supported the recital which refers to the inhumane conditions in which refugees live in camps, without access to sufficient quality resources and services to meet their basic needs. I am glad that this report has been adopted by a large majority.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. As I had done in the Culture Committee, which gave an opinion on this text, I vehemently opposed this report on the social inclusion of refugees and their integration into the labour market. First of all, the rapporteur's voluntary confusion between the terms refugees and migrants - the first to be used for a simple temporary stay due to conflict. This report maintains the amalgamation in order to advocate for ever more legal immigration, and this, to the detriment of the European populations: we prefer to use immigration to respond to the demographic issue rather than to put in place intelligent birth policies. While the European Union already suffers from around 10% unemployment, the text calls for everything to be put in place (language courses, social assistance, supported jobs) for the integration of migrants into the labour market, which shows once again that the proponents of globalism always prefer the 'other' to themselves, our unemployed having, for their part, only to continue to be poor. Finally, the report is based on an alleged humanism on the precarious situation of migrant women, but nothing is mentioned on security issues or problems of reception capacity for Member States.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are 22 million unemployed citizens and 122 million poor people in Europe. There is no need for a new workforce in Italy and Europe. In the Benifei report, on the other hand, the fake goodness of the left prevails, which in no way underlines that real refugees, real refugees, are only 30% of illegal immigrants arriving in Italy. Furthermore, the term 'refugees' means that these are people who are not destined to remain in Europe but who will return to their country of origin once the ongoing conflicts are over. That is why the discussions on long-term integration are pointless. The truth is that the business of immigrants is playing into the hands of multinationals: so much new cheap labour that will reduce the wages of our citizens even further. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that respect for human rights and international laws should be accompanied by worthy integration of refugees and asylum seekers into our societies. In this sense, we are convinced that social and labour integration is the spearhead for achieving this.  In this regard, the report calls for an increase in the Union's investment in social and labour policies, in order to tackle this situation, preventing this from being detrimental to those European citizens who are already in a vulnerable situation in our countries. It therefore calls for an increase of the European Social Fund's participation in the Structural and Investment Funds to 25%. It requires that the maximum time be reduced so that a refugee can acquire the right to participate in the labour market of the host country to as little as six months. And that their access to training, housing, health, education, as well as recognition of their skills and family reunification can be ensured.  A comprehensive and robust report with recommendations that can be key to managing the crisis we are experiencing in the long run.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which examines the situation of refugees and their integration into the labour market. Managing the refugee crisis is one of the most important challenges facing the European Union and its society today. This is not only a humanitarian crisis, but also a global political crisis. The new European Agenda on Migration has been adopted to overcome the challenges of managing the influx of arrivals, which requires further strengthening of border management, search and rescue operations and the renewal of the Common European Asylum System. Efforts are also needed to integrate asylum seekers and refugees into society. A holistic approach to migration requires that eu external policies can address the deep causes of migration and that internal policies are open and coherent. Another set of factors in the complexity of the social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market relates to the current macroeconomic situation of the European Union. Record unemployment, poverty, labour market fragmentation and slow economic recovery show that this could be an obstacle to the integration and inclusion of refugees. According to the data, a healthy labour market in the country of arrival is one of the drivers of successful and long-term integration of refugees. By the time of reference, the reduction of social assistance measures or other support measures would have negative social and political consequences.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I would like to stress that education promotes social inclusion and integration into the labour market. All legally recognised refugees, in particular girls and women, should have access to school-based education, informal learning and out-of-school education, as well as lifelong training linked to work experience. It is also necessary to implement reliable and transparent procedures for the recognition of qualifications acquired abroad, outside the European Union. Member States should develop language training in which the teaching of general and professional languages is closely linked. However, because of some of the wordings concerning economic migrants in the report, I voted in favour of the adoption of the report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the proposed report. From the very beginning of the refugee-migrant crisis, I have been reminded of Europe's absorption capacity in relation to refugees, particularly in terms of their integration into society and integration into the labour market. In the current trends of unemployment throughout the EU, tracking is all the more important and we need to drink clean wine on these issues. The report is, in my view, an appropriate compromise between rights, responsibilities and solidarity. Among the objectives, the report sets out the following: clarify the content under consideration, define exactly what it means to be a refugee, and take into account the main elements of the current debate; draw attention to the most important problems, challenges and opportunities brought about by the integration and integration of refugees into society and the labour market; examine the development and impact of recent actions, activities and practices at Union and Member State level to adapt integration and inclusion to our society, etc. In the long term, the problem of excessive migration processes will only be solved by an adequate foreign and security policy of the EU and other global players, the aim of which must be to restore peace in the areas from which migratory pressures are greatest. Cooperation with third countries, humanitarian and development assistance, investment, security and defence policies is important. At the same time as reducing migratory pressures into normal frameworks, other policies such as employment, education, social welfare and health policy will need to be adapted.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The refugee crisis we are witnessing every day must not only be seen as an unprecedented challenge, but also as an opportunity, both for refugees themselves and for our societies. The economic situation in Europe is still very fragile, with very high levels of unemployment and sluggish economic growth. In this particularly complex situation, the integration of refugees is crucial: from education to language learning, from access to the health service to access to the labour market, from full recognition of their rights and the rights of their family members to the recognition of their skills to the definition of their duties. In this respect, I agree with Mr Benifei's report, which identifies the means of achieving these objectives, in particular investments at European level with wider use of the Structural Funds, the updating of the relevant directives to prevent the exploitation of these people with unleamp work and to guarantee them legal access to the labour market, the increased participation of the social partners in the definition of integration policies at European level. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this Report on the inclusion of refugees in society and their integration into the labour market. I welcome the Commission's work on a common approach to labour market integration and the social inclusion of refugees.  I also call for effective integration policies, the provision of funding to ensure the swift and full integration of refugees in the labour market and their social inclusion in line with the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. While I am in favour of ensuring a proper welcome for real refugees, this report too often confuses these real refugees with migrants who are most often motivated by economic reasons. On the other hand, how can we provide employment for all these migrants when we are not able to provide sustainable jobs for our own young people? I also read in this report that this mass immigration would be an opportunity for France, while the settlement of these populations on the territory weighs heavily on the financial balances of our public accounts. Finally, the argument of demographic advantage could be advantageously replaced by an incentive birth policy. Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which provides a good starting point for a process to assist refuges in integrating better, and also in participating in the basic human right to work. Moreover, the report contains references to facilitating refugees and asylum seekers in having access to housing, health care, education, social protection and family reunification. It is, therefore, very positive that this report provides such a compassionate and empathetic approach to the needs of people who are fleeing war.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The management of the refugee crisis is one of the elements that has most affected public opinion in recent years. It is a real problem that affects millions of lives in the Mediterranean, an historic fact that cannot be solved by individual states but that must be tackled by the Union as a whole: it affects everyone, not just the countries of southern Europe, and only if we all cooperate can we overcome it. We need a comprehensive approach to immigration focused on the EU's external policies, such as cooperation with third countries, humanitarian and development aid, trade, investment and security and defence policies, in order to address in an integrated way the root causes of migration: conflicts, poverty, lack of freedom, inequalities, extreme environmental conditions; subsequently, the new thematic agenda to be provided by the EU must ensure that internal policies, such as employment, education and health care, are accessible, harmonious and flexible enough to transform the challenges posed by migratory pressures into a resource for the economic and cultural development of our societies. Migrants can be a resource, not just a problem, both for host countries and for transit and areas of origin.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. At a time when EU Member States are experiencing an unsustainable influx of migrants, the report considers the arrival of these illegal migrants to be an economic and cultural opportunity for our Western societies. The rapporteur goes so far as to explain that their social inclusion and economic integration would help to remedy the European demographic crisis, characterized by an ageing population resulting in particular from a decline in fertility.  It is truly scandalous that the European Union prefers to focus on integrating these illegal migrants professionally rather than combating the mass unemployment of millions of our fellow citizens. In fact, the European Commission is using this humanitarian crisis as a pretext to satisfy the demands of the big employers who see this human tragedy as an opportunity to bring in low-cost labour. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the refugee report: social inclusion and integration into the labour market, given that even this time no account is taken of the ability of states to take in refugees and more, I appreciate that it was mainly necessary to intensify efforts in conflict zones so that the phenomenon could be stopped. I would also like to point out this time that account must be taken of the ability of Member States to fulfil their obligations objectively when bringing into question the relocations of refugees and mandatory quotas. I also consider it necessary to concentrate efforts in the countries supplying immigrants in order to eliminate the causes that generate this migrationist phenomenon, because the quota system, whether voluntary or compulsory, is only a temporary solution that only cushions the avalanche for a short period, which is not the final solution to deal with the atrocities of war waged outside the EU's borders.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that respect for human rights and international laws should be accompanied by worthy integration of refugees and asylum seekers into our societies. In this sense, we are convinced that social and labour integration is the spearhead for achieving this.  In this regard, the report calls for an increase in the Union's investment in social and labour policies, in order to tackle this situation, preventing this from being detrimental to those European citizens who are already in a vulnerable situation in our countries. It therefore calls for an increase of the European Social Fund's participation in the Structural and Investment Funds to 25%. And that their access to training, housing, health, education, as well as recognition of their skills and family reunification can be ensured.  A comprehensive and robust report with recommendations that can be key to managing the crisis we are experiencing in the long run.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on refugees: social inclusion and integration into the labour market, because the European Union must first of all take responsibility for guiding and supporting safely, with respect for human rights and international agreements, those entering the European political and legal area and at the same time launching cooperation programmes aimed at reducing the causes of immigration. Those fleeing poverty and persecution cannot be seen as just people who will weigh on our economy. There are studies showing that migration also generates new wealth, and new opportunities for development. The working-age population in the EU will decrease by 7.5 million by 2020, and the influx of immigrants into Europe, if properly managed with a global and long-term vision, can also be seen as an opportunity. The Member States must facilitate the integration of refugees into the economic field, for example by reducing restrictions on the labour market, by recognising and enhancing the professional skills of asylum seekers so that they can respond to the needs of our economic system.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report provides a good starting point for a process to assist refuges in integrating better, and also in participating in the basic human right to work. Moreover, the report contains references to facilitating refugees and asylum seekers in having access to housing, health care, education, social protection and family reunification. It is, therefore, very positive that this report provides such a compassionate and empathetic approach to the needs of people who are fleeing war.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which addresses challenges related to the refugee crisis in Europe, especially the social inclusion of refugees and their integration into the labour market. The report proposes a scheme that invites both refugees and host countries to exercise their rights and duties in order to ensure smooth and effective integration. I would like, for the purpose of cost-effectiveness, to encourage the use of existing financial instruments to provide support to regions with difficulties. Also, there must be a proper waiting period for a work permit before entry to the labour market, so that refugees can receive enough training and host countries can assess their abilities.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report, clearly clarifying the terms of the issue and the problem as it presents itself today, comprehensively addresses the opportunities and challenges of social inclusion and integration into the refugee labour market, and ends with the submission of proposals and recommendations. These include the need, upstream, for a reform of the Dublin Regulation and for actions to support Those Member States that – geographically – are most engaged in reception. The imprint of the report is entirely acceptable, as are the suggestions for action. I certainly voted in favour.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Although I believe it is necessary to help people in need who are eligible for humanitarian aid and who are considered as refugees under international law, I could not support this resolution. The quotas for sharing refugees are regarded by many Member States as invalid – and I do not agree with them in principle. The answer to the crisis must be found at EU level but we need to concentrate on measures which really help individuals.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe's response to the migration crisis cannot be limited to emergency measures for managing flows, but must include equally important issues such as social inclusion and integration into the refugee labour market. It is essential, in fact, to respect the principle of non-discrimination in all aspects that characterise the lives of refugees once they arrive in Europe, from education to entry into the labour market. For this reason, it is necessary to help refugees to learn the language and customs of the host country from their arrival, so that they can express their skills and competences, integrate in a dignified way and contribute to society. In order to do this, all the guarantees provided for the protection of international workers must be applied, preventing all forms of exploitation and unleamped work. The issue of migration can no longer be seen merely as a problem, and indeed as an opportunity, only if the Union is able to take the necessary measures to implement an integration project that dignitys refugees and values their contribution to European society. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. – We support the report and stress that even greater efforts are needed to find quick, effective and fair ways to create the necessary conditions for the integration of asylum seekers and refugees into our society.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on refugees, their social inclusion and integration into the labour market is a good effort to safeguard and strengthen the rights of refugees in Europe.  As the massive flow of refugees is an unprecedented phenomenon for Europe, we must take action to ensure social balance and opportunities for all. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted negatively because I believe that a subject of such complexity deserves further study and a wider phase of discussion between the groups.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I think the refugee crisis is one of the most difficult issues facing the European Union at the moment. I think it is right to commit ourselves to helping asylum seekers because, once they have fled their country, they face many difficulties in a new place with different lifestyles and cultures. However, the European Union is facing a serious economic crisis which, in many countries, results in a high rate of unemployment and poverty. As far as Italy is concerned, for example, a very large number of young people emigrate every year in search of opportunities that their country cannot offer them. Therefore, I agree to help asylum seekers, but this must take place within a broader framework of economic recovery and with respect for priorities that must necessarily favour taxpayers over third parties, to whom we must humanly recognise the need to live. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote against this proposal.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on integrating and promoting the inclusion of refugees in the labour market.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The process of welcoming a refugee can be characterised in three stages: receipt of the application, the granting of refugee status and, finally, its integration. Despite the temporary nature of refugee status, this status can extend widely in time and even become a more permanent bond, which increases the importance of good integration.  Given the state of the conflicts in our neighbourhood - and their likely prolongation in time - as well as the number of refugees and asylum seekers arriving on our territory, the integration component is even more important in the European context. It should be noted, in any event, that the Member States here are primarily competent and that the Union can only provide support. In this context, the resolution presents a set of measures. The reorientation and strengthening of funding to Member States, the revision of the Reception Conditions Directive or the expeditious functioning of the relocation mechanism should be underlined. On the other hand, it lists a set of good practices, such as the expeditious treatment of applications for international protection - without neglecting the individual nature of each case - and access to teaching, in particular language. I therefore support this resolution.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because we need to find solutions quickly to integrate refugees into the labour market and thus also to integrate them socially. I therefore warmly welcome the increase in the EFS's funding. I also believe that the compulsory introduction of language courses is a good way of making it easier for refugees to enter the labour market.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Significant differences still exist in the modalities of processing requests for international protection in Member States. This report indicates that slow and excessively bureaucratic procedures may hinder refugees and asylum seekers’ access to education and training, employment guidance and the labour market and consequently their integration. These shortcomings increase the refugees and asylum seekers’ vulnerability to undeclared work and precarious working conditions. The report thus calls for an integrated approach to EU migration policy and for greater emphasis on culture, education and training in those operational measures undertaken as part of the European Agenda on Migration. Member States need to show more commitment in developing initiatives that facilitate integration through the use of language, education, social and cultural programmes and the recognition of refugees’ competences.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report sought to clarify the issue of social inclusion and the integration of refugees into the labour market by examining the main elements of the ongoing discussions on this issue. The aim was to propose recommendations and suggestions for maximum social inclusion and integration of refugees. With the amendments we have tabled, we have wanted to highlight a number of urgent actions, including the need to establish a common asylum system, the need to have adequate support actions for the Member States most involved in primary reception, actions to achieve the host countries in a safe manner, better management of applications for international protection, a system for acting in relation to the different needs of the member states. , distinguishing between emergency and medium- or long-term ones. We also believe it is essential to use public investment for integration into the European labour market. The report is not very critical, which is why I am voting in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report aims to make a number of recommendations to facilitate the inclusion of refugees in the workplace. This is a good way to end the precarious situation in which most refugees live in the European Union, as well as to fight for their empowerment and xenophobia that is still spreading across the continent. That is why I voted in favour of the report, which contains a number of elements which we value very positively, such as the claim to access to rights such as housing, health care, education, or involvement in the process of social organisations and trade unions. In addition, refugees are required to have access to the labour market after a maximum of six months in the Union and to have the same minimum wage applied to them as the rest of the population. These are two central elements for the revision of Directive 2013/33/EU on the reception of asylum seekers, one of the main European regulations to be amended to ensure that refugees living in our society enjoy effective equality.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The refugee crisis is first and foremost a humanitarian crisis that has long-term repercussions on the labour markets and civil society of the countries of origin as well as the countries of destination and which, therefore, requires lasting and effective responses to ensure social cohesion and the effective integration of newcomers into our societies. I voted in favour of this resolution, because I agree with the proposed approach of not creating special labour markets for refugees, but including them in host societies with effective measures at local level that address fundamental issues such as: the various forms of discrimination, language barriers, access to housing, education and the health system, the right to family reunification. In this respect, in line with the resolution, I find it unacceptable that there are still substantial differences between Member States in the timing and manner in which requests for international protection are being treated; differences that prevent the recognition of refugee rights in the areas identified above. Therefore, I believe that the starting point for effectively including refugees in European societies is the implementation by Member States of the country-specific recommendations set out in the framework of the European Semester.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament today approved an own-initiative report making recommendations on the social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market. It is a fact that addressing the refugee crisis is currently one of the main challenges facing the European Union, in terms of size, complexity, pace and complexity of its social, political and economic impact. It is primarily a humanitarian crisis on a global scale, but also a policy crisis that the European Union was not prepared for. It is beyond dispute that the migration crisis, including refugees in the EU, needs to be addressed. It is also a fact that the current situation, which creates untenable and unnecessary tensions, urgently needs to be addressed. However, the reporter made a number of recommendations which I could not support with my vote. some of them went against the principle of subsidiarity, while others disagreed.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report addresses a number of issues, m.in. such as ensuring a holistic EU approach, cooperation with third countries, EU funding through the ESF, ERDF and humanitarian aid, definitions, processing, recognition of qualifications, access to EU labour markets and social inclusion (including housing, healthcare and social protection). The report first outlines the political and strategic context and then outlines a number of recommendations, including a call to increase the ESF budget, the creation of a single Common European Asylum System and the revision of the Reception Conditions Directive and the Blue Card Directive. Since the beginning of the process, there have been some concerns about the direction of some proposals, in particular the linking of legal migration policies with policies aimed at solved the current crisis. The ECR Group tabled a number of amendments calling for a greater focus on the implementation of existing measures, the EU's relations with third countries and the fight against trafficking in human beings and discrimination. The ECR Group also called for a clear distinction between legal migration, asylum seekers and refugees in order to avoid any confusion between the different categories, using the revision of the Blue Card Directive as a potential solution (which means that more legal migration, especially for highly skilled workers with a blue card, will not solve the migration crisis). Unfortunately, due to the uncompromising attitude of the S&D Group, which did not intend to take into account the most important demands of the ECR Group, I voted against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Increasing the European Social Fund share in cohesion policy is an important basis to really and truly integrate refugees in our societies. A common approach to labour market integration and social inclusion of refugees is required in order to have effective integration. This approach is in accordance with the principle of equal treatment and non—discrimination, which shall be safeguarded in all scenarios. I voted in favour of this report as it takes into account the current realities and seeks to address them positively whilst safeguarding human rights.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to provide answers to the challenge of social integration of refugees in the context of the migration crisis, as well as their integration into the labour market and education. In particular, the report calls on Member States to ensure full and rapid integration into the labour market and social inclusion of refugees, in line with the principle of equal treatment, but also with the national labour market situation and national and European legislation.  It calls for their integration for the time of their stay in Europe through access to public services, including housing, health care and social protection, integration courses, as well as language learning modules and other education and training measures.  Finally, within the framework of the European budget, it calls for the mobilisation of a new financial instrument for the integration of refugees.  Considering that this integration of refugees into the labour market is a key condition for their social inclusion, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. It included calls for more EU interference and rules on asylum and immigration policy. The report also criticised Member States that have tried to control their borders externally and internally in the Schengen area. The only people who should take decisions on these things are elected national governments in compliance with the 1951 Geneva Convention on refugees. None of this should be decided on or dictated by unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, with no binding legislative value, on social inclusion and integration into the labour market for refugees. It is essential to distinguish between refugees, who must be able to integrate into our societies through education and access to employment, and economic migrants, whom we can no longer welcome in Europe and who must be taken back to their countries of origin.  Because refugees must be able to access the labour market and not be a financial burden for the host country, I am particularly in favour of having access to adequate training, learning modules and language courses that are essential for their integration.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I have decided to abstain on the vote of this report because too many points are problematic for me. First, the terms "refugees," "asylum seekers" and "economic migrants" are not clearly differentiated, which can distort the interpretation of the text. Moreover, while I am of course in favour of social inclusion and integration into the labour market of refugees, I do not think that courses taught in their mother tongue are beneficial: on the contrary, this could represent a serious obstacle to the integration of these populations, which is the aim of this report! I am also not in favour of the revision of the regulation on the reception of migrants: it has already been revised in 2013 and it is up to the Member States to implement it!

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the resolution facilitates access to the labour market for refugees and restores human dignity and economic independence to them. Furthermore, this resolution promotes social equality and does not affect the weak groups affected by the economic crisis, but provides for additional social investments and provides additional financial resources to be allocated directly to local, regional and voluntary public administrations. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the resolution.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Employment Commission's report on refugees on their social inclusion and integration into the labour market.   The text stresses the need to provide refugees and asylum seekers with real access to housing, health care, education, social protection and the labour market. Access to the labour market will enable them to become economically independent and contribute to the society that welcomes them. This will not only reduce the burden on public budgets but will also help restore their dignity and self-esteem. It is therefore crucial to assess their skills quickly and fairly, as well as to recognise and validate their qualifications, in order to enable them to work as quickly as possible. The resolution also insists that assistance to refugees and asylum seekers is not funded by resources for programmes targeting other disadvantaged groups and that additional investment is therefore provided. It also opposes the idea of creating job markets specifically for refugees and is in favour of making the respective minimum wages of states applicable to them.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. It is necessary to harmonise administrative and judicial procedures between Member States so that all asylum applications in the EU are dealt with in the same rules and within the same time frame.  This harmonisation is also desirable with regard to the access to the labour market of refugees granted asylum in Europe. To promote their integration, it is necessary to assess their skills quickly and fairly, as well as to recognize and validate their qualifications.

name: Martina Dlabajová (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome my colleague Benifei's efforts to contribute to the effective integration of refugees into the EU labour market. The report contains many important recommendations and proposals. These include, for example, the promotion of language and vocational education and literacy, the equal rights of refugees to wages in a given state, the involvement of civil society and voluntary organisations, etc. However, I could not support this resolution because it contains fundamental points of contention that I do not identify with. This is mainly the adoption of a system of permanent redistribution quotas. I believe that neither the permanent relocation mechanism nor the proposed asylum system are appropriate instruments to provide a lasting and acceptable solution to the migration crisis, nor will they contribute to the labour and social integration of incoming refugees.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text combines the terms "refugee" and "migrant." However, the concept of "refugee" presupposes a return to the country of origin at the end of the conflict. Moreover, the EU presents the arrival of migrants as a "chance" for our societies, in terms of socio-cultural openness and as a solution to the demographic crisis and the ageing of the European population.  In addition, Brussels wants to offer a job to refugees within 6 months of their application, with language training, social assistance, supported jobs and interpretation in the workplace. Finally, the report is polluted by gender theory when, at the same time, terrorist risks are ignored. He goes so far as to support the Commission when it condemns Member States that have not put in place the arrangements for welcoming migrants. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I was working on the opinion that the Committee on Culture and Education presented, but both in my committee and in the main committee, mine and the amendments of my colleagues from the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists were not adopted. It was very important for us to distinguish between the concepts of refugees, legal immigrants and asylum seekers, and this was not accepted by other groups.  Such an undistinguished concept can lead to very large errors in the current crisis situation. The outcome of this situation is difficult, and this report does not help with anything, I can even say that it can only harm. That's why I voted against this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Knowing that the Geneva Convention was created solely for the protection of European refugees after World War II and taking seriously, that 24.4% of the total population is on the verge of poverty and at risk of social exclusion, while 10% are facing severe material deprivation, we are voting against the report and opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education on refugees, concerning social inclusion and their integration into the labour market. It is a fact that the unprecedented number of asylum seekers in Europe, but above all the vulnerability of refugees to undeclared work, will not only burden the EU fiscally, but will also increase the youth unemployment rate. The Commission and the Member States must give priority to political investment and jobs for EU citizens, with particular emphasis on the most vulnerable people. Undoubtedly, adapting social inclusion and integration policies to the specific needs of refugees will create serious problems in the state concerned, because in addition to involving a heterogeneous group of people who are unable to integrate with the European element, it requires immediate financial support, at a time of economic crisis, where health care, social protection, education and, above all, the labour market are threatened by the migration problem. , which like a Damocles saber hangs over the head of the EU.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The report stresses the need for the Union to base its immediate response to the situation on solidarity and equitable sharing of responsibilities, as indicated in Article 80 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), and on a comprehensive approach that takes into account the need for improvement of legal and safe immigration channels. It stresses the need to streamline excessive bureaucratic procedures that may impede asylum seekers' access to education and training, employment guidance and the labour market.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the call for the establishment of a common asylum system, as well as the improvement of safe and legal migration channels. My constituents in Wales have persistently expressed their concern over the refugee crisis, and will be pleased to see the promotion of social protection standards and support for those who need it most.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The challenges facing the EU today, and in particular that of refugees, require greater commitment on the part of all Member States, while respecting the essential application of the principles of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibility. The report reports on the challenges and opportunities that social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market entail, both at Community level and at the level of individual Member States. Some of the proposals put forward by the 5-Star Movement were accepted in the report, including the urgent need to establish a common asylum system and legal access routes, a fair mechanism for the distribution and distribution of migrants, appropriate support actions for those Member States most engaged in primary reception for geographical reasons, but also the need to adopt further programmes , funded by the EU, and increased public investment to facilitate, first and foremost, the integration of European citizens into the labour market, also to avoid social tensions, especially where the unemployment rate is highest. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I have chosen to vote against wordings to earmark 25% of the European Social Fund budget for efforts to integrate refugees into the labour market. It is important to allocate money for this purpose, but the exact amount must be decided in the ordinary budgetary process.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a global human crisis, but more specifically, also a political crisis for which the European Union was not prepared and which therefore requires policy makers to take urgent and decisive measures, as well as long-term measures that meet the needs of society and the labour market. All humanitarian migrants, as asylum seekers and refugees, leave their countries abruptly and are therefore the most vulnerable group among all migrants, often suffering from serious health problems and psychosocial disorders and post-traumatic stress or evidencing certain forms of disability.  Then what makes the issue of social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market complex is the current macroeconomic situation of the European Union.  Finally, what makes the adoption of effective social inclusion and integration measures more problematic is linked to their nature often unpopular in the public eye.  That is why I voted in favour of the contours in the report.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: utopian plan to offer refugees employment within 6 months without taking into account millions of unemployed Europeans and amalgamation between refugees and migrants.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The implementation of a concrete process of social inclusion and integration of refugees is a complex and demanding challenge, to be based on the principles of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities between Member States, since it requires a gradual path that involves interconnected aspects of an economic, social and cultural nature. While aware of the serious period of crisis in the European economy and the high unemployment rate in some areas, access to the refugee labour market, through additional resources, which must not be taken away from programmes and objectives relating to other disadvantaged groups, can reduce the costs of reception and the negative social consequences of dependence on purely welfare measures. It would also help to combat irregular work, to have training and to acquire professional skills that would create the best conditions and opportunities for reintegration once they return to their country of origin and to contribute to the economies of the host countries.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report reflects the need for the inclusion of refugees in Member States which necessarily involves integration into the labour market. We have tabled amendments to the report focused on improving working conditions and social protection, rejecting the criteria for qualifications as an exclusionary factor, rejecting existing legislative and institutional frameworks (Dublin Regulation, Blue Card Directive, EU-Turkey Agreement), and defending the extension of support and integration strategies not only for refugees and asylum seekers, but also for migrants. Unfortunately, these proposals have not been accepted. The report thus presents some limitations, such as being uncritical of the criteria with which the EU proposes the "distribution" of refugees (calls for a revision of the Dublin Regulation, but does not address the reasonableness of such "distribution"); calls for a distinction between refugees and migrants, not mentions those responsible for conflicts in countries of origin, the inhuman conditions of detention camps or the cruelty of repatriation. Nevertheless, the general ity of the document contains guidelines which, to be implemented, would have positive consequences, in particular in promoting the social inclusion of refugees.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Immigration is a huge and complex phenomenon, capable of changing the face of a society. If for the better or for the worse, it is up to us to decide. The "phenomenon" of immigration, in fact, has significant economic, social, cultural and public order implications. I voted against Mr Benifei's report because I believe that it does not take into account the fundamental issues for the viable social inclusion and integration of migrants into the labour market, such as the clear distinction between refugees and economic migrants, legal and illegal migration. Furthermore, the report does not take into account the significant differences between Member States on bureaucratic delays and the way in which applications for international protection are treated, creating a paradox in migrants' access to the labour market. We need a more realistic approach, capable of tackling the problem as a whole.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE)
text: Written. "For us Conservatives, it goes without saying that EU Member States should have effective legislation that gives refugees a good chance of integration into the labour market. Many of the proposals highlighted here are both reasonable and good. However, we are opposed to attempts to transfer power over these issues to European level. The situation is different in different Member States, and therefore there should be scope for EU countries to adapt their integration tools to their national circumstances. Nevertheless, we have chosen to support the report.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because it clarifies what it means to be a refugee and highlights the most relevant issues, challenges and opportunities that the social inclusion and integration into the labour market of refugees bring along.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tackling the refugee crisis is likely to be one of the main challenges for the European Union, its institutions, but also for society as a whole, as there are complex impacts in the area of social policy or the economy. Most humanitarian migrants, asylum seekers and refugees, have had to leave their countries forcibly, often with serious health problems. They suffer from various stress disorders or forms of disability and are therefore the most vulnerable group of migrants. A particularly worrying and serious aspect is the high number of children, as well as unaccompanied children, who need urgent assistance and must be taken care of as a matter of priority. It is also essential to take into account the gender dimension of the refugee crisis. All these facts are important for the issues of social inclusion and the integration of refugees into the labour market. The European Union is in the process of overcoming the most serious economic crisis and, moreover, is struggling with high unemployment, which can create obstacles to the integration and integration of refugees into the European Union's labour market if this problem is not comprehensively addressed.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report as it only helps migrants and does not take into account the 22 million unemployed citizens. Once again our citizens come later.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report and the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education on refugees, on their social inclusion and integration into the labour market. It is a fact that the unprecedented number of asylum seekers in Europe, but above all the vulnerability of refugees to undeclared work, will not only burden the EU fiscally, but will also increase the youth unemployment rate. The Commission and the Member States should give priority to political investment and jobs for EU citizens, with particular emphasis on the most vulnerable people (DISABLED). Undoubtedly, adapting social inclusion and integration policies to the specific needs of refugees will create serious problems in the state concerned, because in addition to involving a heterogeneous group of people who are unable to integrate with the European element, it requires immediate financial support, at a time of economic crisis, where health care, social protection, education and, above all, the labour market are threatened by the migration problem. , which like a Damocles saber hangs over the head of the EU.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the call for the swift and full integration of refugees into the labour market and into European societies. I welcome the Commission’s work on the common approach to labour market integration and the social inclusion of refugees and I support the call for effective integration policies to be put in place without delay. Sufficient financial resources must be allocated in order to guarantee the swift and full integration of refugees into the labour market and their social inclusion in accordance with the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination. Integration policies must be part of a holistic approach to migration, improving safe and legal migration channels and ensuring respect for fundamental rights. A common European approach must address key issues such as non-discrimination, access to education and training, housing, health care, labour market and social protection, recognition of qualifications and the validation of skills, as well as family reunification and the situation and needs of vulnerable groups. These are essential measures for restoring the human dignity of refugees, as they enable them to gain economic independence and contribute significantly to their successful integration in the host societies.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report convinced that the management and integration of refugees are one of the biggest challenges that we must respond to as a society. It is that the Union is not responding to the expectations of its values. There is and will not be integration of refugees if they cannot access the labour market. All this, however, must be possible without undermining the combat we are carrying out to reduce unemployment in all European countries, also youth unemployment, especially in Catalonia and Spain. The report opens doors to act in a good way, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that respect for human rights and international laws should be accompanied by worthy integration of refugees and asylum seekers into our societies. In this sense, we are convinced that social and labour integration is the spearhead for achieving this.  In this regard, the report calls for an increase in the Union's investment in social and labour policies, in order to tackle this situation, preventing this from being detrimental to those European citizens who are already in a vulnerable situation in our countries. It therefore calls for an increase of the European Social Fund's participation in the Structural and Investment Funds to 25%. It requires that the maximum time be reduced so that a refugee can acquire the right to participate in the labour market of the host country to as little as six months. And that their access to training, housing, health, education, as well as recognition of their skills and family reunification can be ensured.  A comprehensive and robust report with recommendations that can be key to managing the long-term crisis we are experiencing.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that respect for human rights and international laws should be accompanied by worthy integration of refugees and asylum seekers into our societies. In this sense, we are convinced that social and labour integration is the spearhead for achieving this.  In this regard, the report calls for an increase in the Union's investment in social and labour policies, in order to tackle this situation, preventing this from being detrimental to those European citizens who are already in a vulnerable situation in our countries. It therefore calls for an increase of the European Social Fund's participation in the Structural and Investment Funds to 25%. It requires that the maximum time be reduced so that a refugee can acquire the right to participate in the labour market of the host country to as little as six months. And that their access to training, housing, health, education, as well as recognition of their skills and family reunification can be ensured.  A comprehensive and robust report with recommendations that can be key to managing the crisis we are experiencing in the long run.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Looking at the migration phenomenon no longer only as a pressing difficulty to be able to face but also as an opportunity: this is the challenge proposed by the excellent work of the report that Mr Benifei has carried out excellently and which I gladly supported. A forward-looking and broad look at migration and the urgent need for the Union to reaffirm its identity as guarantor of human rights and dignity, a Europe of solidarity and responsibility, which makes social inclusion its strong point by transforming fragilities into potential, development and growth.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's non-legislative resolution on social inclusion and integration into the refugee labour market, because introducing this perspective, which has not been sufficiently important so far, may be the next step in moving from the emergency of reception to the recognition of their dignity. Furthermore, by turning refugees into taxpayers, it will be possible to reduce the burden on public budgets and promote economic growth. Social inclusion policies are therefore needed, which recognise refugees' rights to health care, housing, education, and policies aimed at integrating them into local realities, labour markets without producing wage dumping. These policies should be functional to the management of the wider migration problem, in order to strengthen both the channels of legal and safe migration and respect for fundamental rights. In order to tackle the migration emergency effectively, safely and in solidarity, it is necessary to put in place new funding to support programmes for the inclusion and social integration of refugees, so as not to create competition between them and other disadvantaged groups present in European society and, above all, special labour markets for refugees must not be created, through the recognition of the national minimum wage.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the report on "Refugees – Social Inclusion and Integration in the Labour Market". It is true that my colleague Helga Stevens has succeeded in providing important impetus for a realistic policy to integrate refugees into the labour market. Overall, however, the text misses the real-world assumption: it is simply not true that a large proportion of the refugees are highly trained and could be used immediately in all positions. Even if they are, language barriers and the lack of recognition of their level of education are definitely aggravating hurdles.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the draft report on the social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market. We need a clear perspective for these people as soon as possible. Access to education is one of the fundamental social keys to effective integration.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. This report deals with the integration and inclusion of "refugees", an inappropriate term in this case, since a refugee is in principle supposed to return to his country once the conflict has been resolved. In fact, the text refers to migrants, which the Commission considers to be an opportunity for The Member States, because they would be the miracle solution against the demographic crisis and the ageing of the population. The Commission prefers to take in millions of migrants, regardless of whether they will integrate and, above all, to assimilate, rather than to develop birth control policies.  The Commission also claims to put in place provisions to offer employment to refugees within 6 months of their application, when most European countries are in crisis and unemployment persists, especially for young people. For these reasons, our group has tabled an alternative motion for a resolution and of course I have voted against this report.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the Benifei report. It proposes nothing more or less than a generalized priority in access to housing, employment, vocational training, the facilitated recognition of diplomas or qualifications... refugees, while maintaining confusion between refugees and ordinary immigrants. I can understand that people forced to leave their country to take refuge in another need special help to facilitate their stay, necessarily temporary, and not to live on the hooks of the society that welcomes them. But in the context of mass unemployment, especially among young people, budgetary restrictions and especially the massive arrival in Europe of hundreds of thousands of migrants, this priority for the latest arrivals is more than criticised, it is indecent. We do not have to collectively suffer the choices that Germany has made because it is afraid that its demographics will end up killing its growth and economic supremacy. Continue to vote for this kind of report: you will end up convincing even the most Eurobeat citizens that your policies are crazy and that it is time to leave the European Union.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is a first step in improving policies for social inclusion and integration of refugees. The text talks about ensuring access to housing, education and training, social protection, health and family reunification, all of which are the indispensable rights of people applying for international protection and which our delegation advocates.     Increasing public investment with an increase in the ESF, as the report shows, is good news, as is ensuring that refugees can access the labour market no later than 6 months after the application and that they have a minimum wage equal to other nationals, avoiding dumping and exploitation of the most vulnerable people. In the blue card paragraph, however, I voted against it as we must avoid rewarding some refugees against others on grounds of origin or training. However, as a whole it is a positive report and in that regard I voted.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because it is an important step in managing the flow of people arriving on the European continent, by implementing measures that take into account both the needs of society and the labour market.
