Identifying effective and fair ways of creating the necessary conditions for the integration of asylum seekers and establishing a European resettlement and relocation mechanism are pressing and extremely important long-term issues. The urgency and the need to find a solution, together with the application of the principles of solidarity and the fair sharing of responsibility, are necessary steps to combat this common European problem, which requires a common European solution.  All these measures must take into account full respect for international law and human rights, in particular with regard to vulnerable groups of migrants - refugees and asylum seekers - in order to ensure better social inclusion and their integration into the labour market.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which calls for the full integration of refugees into the labour market and for improved safe and legal migration channels. It addresses the need for a common asylum system to improve recognition procedures as well as ensuring decent conditions upon arrival, with facilitated access to housing, health care, education, social protection and the labour market. Any approach, European or otherwise, must ensure that families are able to reunite and that vulnerable groups (particularly those with disabilities, women and children, and especially unaccompanied children) are protected. We must have a strategy which will restore and secure the human dignity of refugees: they must be allowed to gain economic independence and significantly contribute to their successful integration into the host societies.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I think it is essential to encourage access to the labour market for refugees, which should not be confused with economic migrants! On the one hand so that they can quickly integrate through work, and on the other hand so that they do not become an additional burden for our unemployment compensation systems. However, I have spoken out against an additional transfer of 23% to 25% of the allocations of cohesion funds to the European Social Fund. It seems to me unacceptable to take from the development budget of our territories the funds for the integration of refugees.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that respect for human rights and international laws should be accompanied by worthy integration of refugees and asylum seekers into our societies. In this sense, we are convinced that social and labour integration is the spearhead for achieving this.  In this regard, the report calls for an increase in the Union's investment in social and labour policies, in order to tackle this situation, preventing this from being detrimental to those European citizens who are already in a vulnerable situation in our countries. It therefore calls for an increase of the European Social Fund's participation in the Structural and Investment Funds to 25%. It requires that the maximum time be reduced so that a refugee can acquire the right to participate in the labour market of the host country to as little as six months. And that their access to training, housing, health, education, as well as recognition of their skills and family reunification can be ensured.  A comprehensive and robust report with recommendations that can be key to managing the crisis we are experiencing in the long run.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The swift integration of refugees through their participation in the labour market and social inclusion will bring benefits for the refugees (economic independence and a sense of belonging and usefulness) and for society as a whole.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that respect for human rights and international laws should be accompanied by worthy integration of refugees and asylum seekers into our societies. In this sense, we are convinced that social and labour integration is the spearhead for achieving this.  In this regard, the report calls for an increase in the Union's investment in social and labour policies, in order to tackle this situation, preventing this from being detrimental to those European citizens who are already in a vulnerable situation in our countries. It therefore calls for an increase of the European Social Fund's participation in the Structural and Investment Funds to 25%. It requires that the maximum time be reduced so that a refugee can acquire the right to participate in the labour market of the host country to as little as six months. And that their access to training, housing, health, education, as well as recognition of their skills and family reunification can be ensured.  A comprehensive and robust report with recommendations that can be key to managing the crisis we are experiencing in the long run.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Benifei report is one of the most balanced reports that has passed through the plenary in recent times on refugees. It is a socially sensitive report, in which, despite the obvious compromises made by the rapporteur, the text remains far from market obsessions and entrepreneurship. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. European integration has been tested in recent months because of the refugee/migration crisis. Refugees should be integrated successfully into the European labour market to help ensure their economic security and to contribute to the economics of the host Member State. I believe that public spending investing in social inclusion and labour-market integration measures and programmes is likely to have a positive effect on national GDPs. With active, large-scale support from microenterprises and small and medium-sized enterprises in the EU, the integration of refugees into the labour market can be successful. I agree with the provision that supplementary language classes be provided for refugee children in their home-country languages, and therefore I support the role of teachers in integrating refugee and migrant children and young people into the education system. The benefits of integrating refugees into the labour market are self-evident and I believe that this would help to secure further unity through the Member States at a time when it is badly needed.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as I believe understanding the current situation is a necessary step to managing today’s immigration crisis.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. This report by Italian S&D Euro MP Brando Benifei makes broad calls for better integration of refugees and asylum seekers in the European Union. The text states, quite literally, that successful integration is not only integration into the labour market, but also means full access to language courses, accommodation, education and training, social security, health care and mental health support, which is why the Commission and EU Member States should ensure the appropriate framework conditions for this. Family reunifications should also be facilitated. These demands sound good, but they are completely unrealistic, not to mention other EU countries with far less economic power than Germany, given the coffers in cities and municipalities in Germany. It also does not call for taxable ceilings on the reception of refugees and asylum seekers. On the contrary, the report is marked by a culture of welcome that is being promoted, which ignores existing rules such as the Dublin Regulation and the Schengen acquis and wants to open the door to economically motivated migration to Europe, despite major social problems in Europe, with sometimes high unemployment in the individual EU Member States. That is why I have clearly rejected the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I have decided to abstain on this catch-all text, which in turn refers to refugees, migrants and asylum seekers.  I am very much in favour of social inclusion and integration into the labour market of refugees in accordance with national regulations. I also believe that a working refugee is a lower cost to public finances and that the establishment of language proficiency courses in the host country and training or apprenticeship programmes can promote integration. On the other hand, I reject all proposals that hinder a Member State's ability to strengthen the conditions and modalities of family reunification, the assertion that the re-establishment of internal border controls is necessarily wrong, the injunctions to review the regulation on the reception conditions of migrants when it was revised in 2013 and should only be properly implemented by the Member States and the recommendation to organise additional courses in the language of the language countries of origin for refugee children, which would hinder their integration and increase public spending if courses were to be taught in tigrinya or afar...

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report correctly notes the legal and moral duties that the EU and its Member States have with regard to refugees. It is vital that people with refugee status are able to integrate fully into the labour market at the earliest opportunity. The UK’s recent referendum saw the Leave side using refugees as part of the wider racist discourse against the EU. This report shows a sharp contrast to those attitudes and I was happy to support it.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this report which seeks to highlight the complexity and multifaceted nature of the need for social inclusion and integration into the refugee market and, on the other hand, the urgency and need to find a solution, always applying the principles of solidarity and equitable sharing of responsibility, necessary to address this problem common throughout Europe and which requires a common European response.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission’s work on the common approach to labour market integration and the social inclusion of refugees should be encouraged. There is a need for effective integration policies to be put in place without delay. This will include sufficient financial resources in order to guarantee the full integration of refugees into the labour market in accordance with the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the refugee report: inclusion in society and integration into the labour market (2015/2321(INI)), as this report seeks to clarify a very complex existing problem and offer solutions to the inclusion of refugees in society and the labour market. The refugee problem is very layered and is being tackled by the EU at a time when itself has problems with unemployment, especially for young people, and a decline in the social standard of the most vulnerable groups of citizens. On the other hand, the EU faces fears and strengthening xenophobia. Therefore, the issue of inclusion in society and the labour market is a problem that needs to be addressed quickly. In this regard, I believe that it is necessary to include cities and regions, i.e. local environments that know best the needs of the market, the needs of primarily small and medium-sized companies, and can best respond to the challenges of integration. Despite high unemployment, there are many sectors where labour shortages are felt and have depended on migration for decades. In addition, there are occupations for which there is a decline in interest in local domestic population. Particular attention should be paid to the rapid adoption of languages and education of the youngest as well as the acceptance of local customs.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The report as a whole is based on the idea of gender (protecting refugee women because they are more at risk, they are more threatened, they are more difficult to find a job...) and anti-extreme (the report notes the rise of xenophobic rhetoric, ambient racism and anti-migrant behaviour). On the other hand, nothing is said about security risks: we never talk about the risks that migrants pose to European citizens, nor about the terrorist threat. Worse, the report supports the Commission when it condemns Member States that have not or have been able to implement the arrangements for welcoming migrants. I therefore oppose this text and that is why I voted against it.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. The key challenge of the refugee crisis is the effective integration of newcomers into the Union, which will not be possible without their integration into the European labour market. I therefore agree with the rapporteur that, in addition to the new European agenda on migration, swift action is needed to integrate refugees and asylum seekers into the labour market. Professional integration is the foundation of social inclusion and without it the latter is unlikely to be possible. There are two challenges in this area that require swift action. The first is the linguistic competence of refugees. The second problem is the recognition of the refugee's education, qualifications and skills. People who come to the Union very often have the qualifications they need in our market, but they are not recognised for legal reasons. It is therefore worth noting the obstacles to this that arise from the European Qualifications Framework. On the other hand, I voted against the permanent mechanism for the relocation of refugees proposed by the rapporteur, as well as the equal treatment of refugees with asylum seekers. Persons who have not completed the asylum procedure should not obtain the full range of rights in the Member States until their situation and identity have been established.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I completely agree that labour market integration and social inclusion are the best ways to contribute to the good integration of migrants in the long term, I voted against the report. It contains certain elements which, in my view, are contrary to the objective of achieving a coherent migration policy. At the moment, I think it is pointless to talk about a permanent relocation scheme mandatory for all Member States and the common asylum system when agreements on a broader framework for addressing migration and asylum policy and the effective organisation of external borders are not yet finalised. Nor do I share the view that the European Parliament should order states to have faster access to the labour market for asylum seekers than the current directive allows. States can do that today, but they should not be ordered to do so.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Benifei report on professional integration and social inclusion of refugees. In the context of the migration crisis we are experiencing, this report makes several proposals to deal more effectively with the political, economic and social challenges facing Europe that we cannot ignore. However, while unemployment rates are high in France and Europe, the issue of the integration of refugees into the labour market cannot be treated lightly.  That is why my political group, the EPP, has ensured that the terms 'refugees', 'asylum seekers' and 'economic migrants' are clearly differentiated. Thus, this report does not concern economic migrants. On the other hand, if action is needed, I voted to ensure that the proposals put forward by the rapporteur do not come at the expense of funds for the development of our territories and SMEs, nor at the expense of the fight against unemployment which affects a large part of our population, especially young people.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which clearly differentiates the terms "refugees," "asylum seekers" and "economic migrants." This report does not concern economic migrants. Moreover, the situation of asylum seekers is differentiated from that of refugees who have been granted status and thus can enter the labour market. This report therefore focuses on the challenges that accompany the social inclusion of refugees in the labour market and aims to improve their integration. In particular, the text calls for integration procedures to place greater emphasis on language learning.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Managing the refugee crisis is without doubt the main challenge facing the European Union and its society over the past year. It is primarily a global humanitarian crisis, but, in particular, a policy crisis, which has found the European Union unprepared and therefore requires policy makers to take urgent and decisive action and take long-term measures based on the needs of society and the labour market.  I voted in favour of the report because it is of the utmost importance to ensure adequate support for measures aimed at social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market, while preventing any form of competition between the most disadvantaged groups in our societies as recipients of this support.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report on social inclusion and integration into the labour market calls for the integration of refugees into the labour market, access to language courses after arrival, as well as to accommodation, education and training, social security and health care. However, there is insufficient reference to current unemployment in the EU, in particular youth and long-term unemployment. This is still at an alarming level and balancing supply and demand in the European labour market continues to be an enormous challenge for the Member States. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament part-session in Strasbourg, I voted against the report on the social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market. I believe that the integration of refugees into society is now a very topical and important issue, but given that the social and economic situation varies greatly in each Member State, I believe that refugee integration policy is a matter for each individual Member State. The labour market and employment are specific to each Member State, so the EU does not apply the same approach to all. The policy for the integration of refugees should be made by each Member State itself, since only the Member State is clearly aware of its internal situation and capabilities.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted today in favour of this report. A European approach must address key issues such as non-discrimination, access to education and training, housing, health care, labour market and social protection, the recognition of qualifications and the validation of skills, as well as family reunification and the situation and needs of vulnerable groups (mostly women, children and people with disabilities, etcetera), as these are essential aspects with a view to restoring the human dignity of refugees and allowing them to gain economic independence and contribute significantly to their successful integration in the host societies.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. This report by Italian S&D Euro MP Brando Benifei makes broad calls for better integration of refugees and asylum seekers in the European Union. The text states, quite literally, that successful integration is not only integration into the labour market, but also means full access to language courses, accommodation, education and training, social security, health care and mental health support, which is why the Commission and EU Member States should ensure the appropriate framework conditions for this. Family reunifications should also be facilitated. These demands sound good, but they are completely unrealistic, not to mention other EU countries with far less economic power than Germany, given the coffers in cities and municipalities in Germany. It also does not call for taxable ceilings on the reception of refugees and asylum seekers. On the contrary, the report is marked by a culture of welcome that is being promoted, which ignores existing rules such as the Dublin Regulation and the Schengen acquis and wants to open the door to economically motivated migration to Europe, despite major social problems in Europe, with sometimes high unemployment in the individual EU Member States. That is why I have clearly rejected the report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on refugees: social inclusion and labour market employment, in particular because of paragraph 39, which 'regrets that the Agreement on the distribution of refugees between Member States of September 2015 is not being satisfactorily fulfilled; stresses that most Member States do not meet the quotas for accepting refugees; calls on the Commission and the Member States to implement the relevant agreements as quickly as possible and to speed up the process of accepting and re-adopting refugees'. I remain convinced that quotas are a step in the wrong direction and that they do not contribute to creating an atmosphere of calm across European society. While the resolution notes that "the refugee crisis is primarily a humanitarian crisis that has occurred, inter alia, by destabilising countries in the EU's neighbourhood", it is already forgetting to name the main culprits of this situation (NATO, and in particular the US). I believe that finding a solution to this situation is not possible without subjecting the actions that led to it to a critical analysis.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The report adopts a practical approach, attempting to clarify the socio-economic facet of the refugee crisis. It is crucial to identify the elements of complexity for the social inclusion of refugees and their integration into the labour market. These elements are mostly connected to the current macroeconomic situation of the Union and the record levels of unemployment, and also to the suspicious stance that the public may adopt towards asylum seekers and refugees who claim access to employment. The report constitutes a good starting point, as it puts forward a series of proposals specifically focused on addressing these aggravating factors, in line with society and labour market needs. Therefore, I voted in favour.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – If we insist that the masses of predominantly young men are not economic migrants but political refugees, then on the one hand we need to think about why they are not trying to protect their loved ones who have remained in their war-fighting country, or even their country. It is also a question of why they are rattling through several safe countries, the green borders, burned their documents on the way. In the light of recent attacks, one will have to think about what percentage of them can be trained terrorists and why they have not been effectively filtered out by the EU authorities so far, or whether they can be filtered out at all with the opportunities available to them. It is also necessary to think about the enormous shock we are causing these poor, poor asylum seekers, who do not know European languages, by forcing them to integrate into a European environment completely alien to them, while, for example, in the rich and same religion and culture countries of the Arabian Peninsula, where vast areas are underused, their chances would be much better. Europe should use political influence and advice to help Saudi Arabia and neighbouring countries in this process and halv asylum seekers.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the report on social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market, I voted against amendments supporting the issue of work permits for those awaiting asylum. The inclusion of migrants in the labour market is obviously necessary, but for security reasons it should not apply to persons just awaiting processing an asylum application, nor should it impose too short deadlines on states, as there are differences in procedures between Member States and, in individual cases, the processing time may take longer. I was also against the deletion from paragraph 1 of the adjective 'European' as regards the values and rights that should be respected by migrants arriving in the EU. Instead, I supported articles and amendments on the need to strengthen the protection of women and children and stressing the importance of language education for the effective integration of refugees into the labour market.  I do not agree with the alternative resolution issued by the ENF, which challenges integration efforts because of the temporary status of refugees. It is impossible to predict how long the crisis situation in the countries of origin will last. The economic independence of those enjoying protection in the EU is crucial not only for their quality of life, dignity and acceptance in local communities, but also for the budgets of social and security services.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the refugee report and their social inclusion and integration into the labour market. Its adoption is of particular importance in ensuring the long-term planning of measures to tackle the migration crisis.  It must be taken into account that it is above all a humanitarian crisis caused by the destabilisation of neighbouring EU countries. All this has long-term consequences in the EU and requires long-term solutions that guarantee social peace and security and meet the expectations of European citizens. Professional integration can help the social inclusion of immigrants. Their skills, knowledge and qualifications could generate positive returns in the countries that accept them. A clear definition of the concept of refugee is of particular importance in order to improve safe and legal migration channels and ensure full respect for existing laws and fundamental European rights and values.  It is particularly important that adequate control measures are taken to limit irregular migration flows. I strongly support a zero-tolerance policy towards radical behaviour and criminal behaviour, including the spread and confession of radical ideologies. Proof of guilt in such cases must lead to expulsion, irrespective of the status of the persons concerned.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, this House is strongly warning Member States to ensure full and rapid integration into the labour market and the social inclusion of refugees. In order to do this, however, national laws need to do more to address certain issues, in particular the fight against all forms of discrimination, the removal of language barriers and the validation of competences. We stress the absolute need to ensure that all refugees, in particular girls and women, have access to formal, informal and non-formal education, as well as to lifelong learning associated with work experience. We call on the Commission to review the Reception Directive as soon as possible in order to ensure that applicants for international protection have access to the labour market as soon as possible from the submission of the application; we call on the Commission to promote upward convergence of social protection rules and the rapid granting of work permits in the Member States. The labour market is unique and everyone must enjoy equal treatment, including pay; we do not accept the idea of creating special status for refugees.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution because refugees’ social inclusion and integration into the labour market should not be further delayed. We should find a common approach and strengthen our efforts to integrate the refugees as soon as possible after their arrival in the EU. That will be highly beneficial for their swift adaptation to the host county and will help their personal development. At the same time integrating refugees into the labour market will generate growth and foster Europe’s competitiveness. I am convinced that the best means to achieve this are through education, training, cultural and sport activities and effective and easily accessible recognition procedures to ensure that refugees will get proper recognition of their prior training and the qualifications they have obtained. Furthermore, they should receive proper pedagogical support, guidance and language courses. It is essential to use the full potential of formal and informal education, training and lifelong learning in order to integrate refugees and asylum seekers fully and in a sustainable way. Our commitment to achieving the swift integration and social inclusion of refugees and asylum seekers must find its reflection in the development of different measures for combating racism, xenophobia and extremism in order to build a more inclusive society, based on our cultural diversity.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. Encouraging real access for refugees to education and the labour market contributes to the success of the integration process, which must work reciprocally between refugees and the host community, involving rights but also duties for each. So I voted this week in favour of the Benifei report for social inclusion and integration into the labour market for refugees. This resolution will allow refugees and asylum seekers to work in their host countries, while also reducing pressure on our public budgets as refugees become taxpayers.  The report also includes the creation of a vocational language training programme, as well as access to guidance courses on European values, culture and fundamental rights. We have therefore responded to the demands of our fellow citizens, including in this resolution that assistance to refugees and asylum seekers is not funded by resources for programmes targeting other disadvantaged groups, thanks to an increase in the European social fund.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on social inclusion and integration into the labour market for refugees. The amalgamation is too often made between "refugee" and "migrant", and the relationship itself passes from one to the other without explanation. It would therefore be necessary to make a difference. The text presents the arrival of migrants in Europe as a "chance" for our societies, an opportunity for our citizens, who will benefit from this cultural and social openness.  Brussels wants to put in place all the provisions to offer them a job within 6 months of their application: language training, social assistance, jobs helped for migrants, interpretation in the workplace... at a time when the EU is experiencing an economic crisis and is not even able to offer all this to European citizens, and in particular to young Europeans entering the labour market. We never talk about the risks that migrants pose to European citizens, nor about the terrorist threat. Worse, the report supports the Commission when it condemns Member States that have not (pu) put in place the arrangements for welcoming migrants.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. In the face of the migration crisis that is overwhelming Europe, the report strives to propose solutions to improve the situation. However, from the outset, it does not distinguish between migrants and refugees. A refugee is a person with temporary subsidiary protection because his country is at war, and is destined to return once peace is restored. This lack of precision in the text shows the EU's break with reality.  The solutions proposed in the report therefore tend to establish migrants, all in a sustainable way, by facilitating their access to the labour market, to the detriment of European citizens. Immigration is presented as an opportunity for Europe to turn around the demographic curve, develop cultural and social openness... In addition, the report is punctuated by ideologies related to gender theory, and ignores the major problem of immigration, namely security.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that respect for human rights and international laws should be accompanied by worthy integration of refugees and asylum seekers into our societies. In this sense, we are convinced that social and labour integration is the spearhead for achieving this.  In this regard, the report calls for an increase in the Union's investment in social and labour policies, in order to tackle this situation, preventing this from being detrimental to those European citizens who are already in a vulnerable situation in our countries. It therefore calls for an increase of the European Social Fund's participation in the Structural and Investment Funds to 25%. It requires that the maximum time be reduced so that a refugee can acquire the right to participate in the labour market of the host country to as little as six months. And that their access to training, housing, health, education, as well as recognition of their skills and family reunification can be ensured.  A comprehensive and robust report with recommendations that can be key to managing the crisis we are experiencing in the long run.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report aims to make a number of recommendations to facilitate the inclusion of refugees in the workplace. This is a good way to end the precarious situation in which most refugees live in the European Union, as well as to fight for their empowerment and xenophobia that is still spreading across the continent. That is why I voted in favour of the report, which contains a number of elements which we value very positively, such as the claim to access to rights such as housing, health care, education, or involvement in the process of social organisations and trade unions. In addition, refugees are required to have access to the labour market after a maximum of six months in the Union and to have the same minimum wage applied to them as the rest of the population. These are two central elements for the revision of Directive 2013/33/EU on the reception of asylum seekers, one of the main European regulations to be amended to ensure that refugees living in our society enjoy effective equality.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. This report by Italian S&D Euro MP Brando Benifei makes broad calls for better integration of refugees and asylum seekers in the European Union. The text states, quite literally, that successful integration is not only integration into the labour market, but also means full access to language courses, accommodation, education and training, social security, health care and mental health support, which is why the Commission and EU Member States should ensure the appropriate framework conditions for this. Family reunifications should also be facilitated. These demands sound good, but they are completely unrealistic, not to mention other EU countries with far less economic power than Germany, given the coffers in cities and municipalities in Germany. It also does not call for taxable ceilings on the reception of refugees and asylum seekers. On the contrary, the report is marked by a culture of welcome that is being promoted, which ignores existing rules such as the Dublin Regulation and the Schengen acquis and wants to open the door to economically motivated migration to Europe, despite major social problems in Europe, with sometimes high unemployment in the individual EU Member States. That is why I have clearly rejected the report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which addresses the challenges faced by refugees attempting to integrate into the labour market and education system in Europe.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the unification of the EU's asylum policy ("there is an urgent need to establish a common asylum system") or the call for a permanent mechanism for the redistribution of migrants ("it is necessary to establish a permanent relocation mechanism within all Member States as soon as possible").

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The refugee crisis is primarily a humanitarian crisis due to destabilisation in the EU neighbourhood. It requires long-term solutions that guarantee social cohesion at local level and the successful integration of new migrants into our society.  This report underlines the importance of solidarity between all Member States in integrating refugees into society and the labour market, as refugees can contribute positively to host societies through economic activity. A holistic approach to migration requires synergies between EU foreign policy and Member States' internal policies, such as employment, education and health care policies. As a stable labour market in the country of destination is a decisive factor for the successful and lasting integration of refugees, policies and investments are needed to create new quality jobs and stimulate economic growth. The aim of this report is to highlight the most important issues, challenges and opportunities posed by the inclusion of refugees in society and the elaboration of measures, procedures and proposals aimed at achieving this. For the effective integration of refugees, the participation of all stakeholders of society and the strengthening of the exchange of best practices in this area is important, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Members rejected the idea of creating special labour markets for refugees, advocating instead that the respective national minimum wage should be valid for refugees as well as other workers. I support the call for measures to facilitate effective access for refugees and asylum seekers to housing, health care, education, social protection and the labour market, in order to restore their human dignity and self-worth.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The refugee crisis and its consequences are currently one of the Union's greatest challenges. Europeans also feel threatened by refugees because of the Union's lack of preparation for this problem. Unfortunately, thanks to the irresponsibility of politicians towards our citizens, we are in a state where we are dealing more with the consequences than the causes. Regional disparities, economic, economic, social and religious, continue to persist in the Union. Nevertheless, effective, rational and effective measures and ways of integrating accepted refugees into society must be sought, with an emphasis on solidarity and the real possibilities of countries. There is a need to fundamentally separate migrants and refugees. The difference is in the reasons for leaving your country. The refugee crisis must not be exploited for speculation by migrants or by political and commercial interests. Law enforcement authorities should step up the detection and analysis of unfair activity when the refugee and migrant crisis becomes the subject and destination of illegal trade. At the same time, the Union must not resign its duty to limit unwanted human migration to Europe. Problems need to be tackled in the countries of origin, we must carefully guard our borders and ensure that illegal migrants return to their country of origin.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Union is facing the largest influx of refugees since the Second World War. The European response took the form in September 2015 of a temporary mechanism for distributing 120,000 refugees in 23 Member States.  This report therefore feeds into the debate on a subject still under-treated at European level: social inclusion and the integration of refugees into the labour market within the European Union.  Among the many proposals contained in this report, this text calls in particular for the definition of a common approach of Member States to non-discrimination and access to education, the labour market, training and social protection. I strongly hope that these women, men and children who are currently fleeing the areas of conflict adjacent to our continent will be an integral part and contribute fully to the economic and social life of European countries. I therefore vote in favour of this text.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the Report on Refugees: social inclusion and integration into the labour market, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 4/7/2016, and because this report is not complete and documented.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the refugee report - social inclusion and labour market integration, because measures to integrate refugees and asylum seekers into the labour market should not be financed from resources for other European programmes and therefore to the detriment of these pre-established programmes. I believe that the labour shortage in some European sectors is not a reason for funding the social inclusion of refugees. European citizens must continue to take precedence in the labour market, as provided for in the principle of Community preference. Moreover, it should not be lost in view that the EU continues to face alarming levels of unemployment, especially among young people, and that a quarter of the total POPULATION in the EU face social exclusion and the risk of poverty. Europe must also focus on social investment for its own citizens, more efficient spending of EU funds and better linking supply with demand in the European labour market.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text on which our group proposed an alternative resolution. This report ticks off the problems on refugees whose massive arrival would help to solve Europe's ageing population. It mixes refugees and economic migrants, even though the concept of "refugee" is an essentially temporary protection status. More seriously, the report urges Member States to adopt strong measures to integrate refugees into the labour market within six months of arriving in the Member States. These measures include training, including language, social assistance and supported employment. We strongly condemn this report both in its ideological assumptions and in the measures imposed on the Member States. This forced immigration policy is all the more reprehensible in view of the high unemployment rates observed in some Member States.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report calls for a common European asylum system. In my opinion, however, this report would mainly contribute to greater centralisation, thereby incapacitating the Member States. In the area of the labour market in particular, demands are formulated here which do not lack any reality. I cannot understand how the demand for the opening up of the labour market for refugees is to be held responsible to the countless unemployed young people in Europe.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report attempts to explain the situation of refugees and asylum seekers in the EU. It focuses on aspects of access to the labour market. The document thus calls for the recognition and validation of "the existing qualifications of refugees", or the guarantee of "quick, easy and equal access to training". Nevertheless, despite the generous emphasis of the text which "calls on Member States to ensure full and rapid integration into the labour market and social inclusion of refugees", it is reasonable to doubt that this objective will be achieved "in accordance with the principle of equal treatment" when one observes the current fate of seconded workers. I vote for this text, without any illusions as to its application.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the whole report because it is sprinkled with gender theory and anti-patrioticism. Furthermore, the report supports the Commission when it condemns Member States which have not put in place arrangements for receiving migrants. Finally, and this is the heart of the matter, the report aims to integrate migrants in a sustainable way, which goes against the will of the peoples and the capacity of States to welcome them.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The management of the refugee crisis is probably one of the main challenges facing the European Union and its society today because of their size, their cadence and the complexity of their social, political and economic implications.  Above all, this is a global human crisis, but more specifically also a political crisis for which the European Union was not prepared and which therefore requires policy makers to take urgent and decisive measures, as well as long-term measures that meet the needs of society and the labour market. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as the social inclusion and labour integration of refugees is important for the well-being of all community members and the efficiency and prosperity of the single market.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The social and professional inclusion of refugees is a fundamental right that every citizen must enjoy but also a necessity if the European Union is to improve the competitiveness of its market in the long term. To ensure respect for the dignity of these refugees, it is essential to move from aid dependency to independence.  The integration of refugees into the labour market is a duty of humanity. It is also a considerable asset for the Union in terms of diversification of skills, knowledge and qualifications. In order for the process of social and professional inclusion to take place in the best possible conditions, it is important to promote initiatives such as language learning that will enable refugees to integrate quickly into our society.  Integration based on equal opportunities must therefore be promoted in order to provide refugees with easier access to health care, social protection, the labour market or education. Finally, a revision of the European blue card will allow them to benefit from better protection against any form of discrimination in employment.  I congratulate rapporteur Benifiei for making this report a plea for the fair and equal integration of refugees.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – One of the main challenges facing the European Union today is the refugee crisis. This is a humanitarian crisis, but also a political crisis that has caught the Union by surprise unprepared and therefore requires policy makers to take urgent and decisive action in line with the needs of society and the labour market. The labour market in the European Union itself entails the need to act in a coma in view of the high percentage of youth unemployment in the Union. This rather complicated situation is exacerbated by the fact that it is necessary to integrate into the labour market also refugees seeking asylum. It is necessary to find rapid, effective and fair opportunities to create the necessary conditions for the integration of Union citizens, especially young people, into the labour market, as well as asylum seekers into our society. This can only be achieved if the external and internal policies of the Union and its Member States are implemented in a workable, complementary and fully and timely manner, based on solidarity and full respect for international law and human rights. A healthy labour market in the country of arrival is a determining factor for the successful integration of refugees, so policies and investments focusing on job quality and economic growth must remain a priority. Weakening social instruments or other support measures targeting disadvantaged groups would have negative social and political consequences.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the common approach to the labour market integration and social inclusion of refugees, which calls for effective integration policies to be put in place without delay, and for sufficient financial resources to guarantee the swift and full integration of refugees into the labour market and their social inclusion, in accordance with the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft resolution of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs draws attention to the need for further, possibly even greater efforts, once the new European Agenda on Migration has been adopted, in order to create the necessary conditions for the integration of asylum seekers and refugees into our society in a rapid, effective and just manner and to take account of the difficulties that stand in its way. Asylum seekers and refugees are the most vulnerable group of migrants. Particular care should be taken to provide assistance to children, in particular unaccompanied adult children. On the other hand, the Union is now facing its worst economic crisis since World War II, and the instruments and programmes available at EU level are not sufficient to cope with this large-scale task. Moreover, social inclusion and integration measures are often unpopular, with people feeling threatened by asylum seekers and refugees, as they see increased competition in access to services or employment, especially in places where unemployment and social conditions are particularly difficult. The report makes proposals, recommendations and comments to achieve better social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market. I supported its adoption.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is fishing in many ways. The amalgamation is too often made between "refugee" and "migrant", and the text passes from one to the other without explanation. It would therefore be necessary to take stock even before these migrants enter the country, which Europe does not seem to be in a hurry at the moment to do.  Secondly, it presents the arrival of migrants in Europe as a "chance" for our societies. On the other hand, nothing is said about security risks: we never talk about the risks that migrants pose to European citizens and European identity, nor about the terrorist threat.  Finally, the report supports the Commission when it condemns Member States that have not been able to implement the arrangements for welcoming migrants. Unfavorable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The high number of refugees is a real test of the Union's ability to respond to emergency scenarios.  In this context, the response to the refugee crisis must be delineated in a coherent and coordinated manner by the Union and its Member States in a spirit of genuine solidarity. In this sense, the strategy for responding to the refugee crisis should cover not only support for arrival, including through food distribution, support for the rescue of shipwrecks, support in the provision of health care, among others, but also on the integration of migrants into host communities. Combating social exclusion and integrating refugees into the labour market are a challenge for which the Union must develop appropriate and timely response tools, and are not to contribute to the increasingly eminent movements of social segregation, such as xenophobic and anti-immigration movements.  In this regard, I am voting in favour of this report, because I believe it is crucial that the European Union has a common and coherent strategy for the refugee crisis.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. In this report, nothing is said about the security risks associated with migrants: for European citizens, and also in terms of the terrorist threat. Worse, the report supports the Commission when it condemns Member States that have not been able or willing to implement the arrangements for welcoming migrants. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which calls for the swift and full integration of refugees into the labour market and for the improvement of safe and legal migration channels, and highlights the need for a common asylum system to improve recognition procedures as well as ensuring decent conditions upon arrival, with facilitated access to housing, health care, education and social protection and to the labour market. Furthermore the report identifies the need to tackle all forms of discrimination to ensure a better integration of refugees. Anti-discrimination policies and also civil society initiatives, sport and culture are identified as offering potential solutions.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the professional integration and social inclusion of refugees. Some provisions are once again a call for air to illegal immigration. This text implies that we can welcome them in Europe with dignity, when the reality shows that we are not in a position to provide them with housing, employment or the means to assimilate properly.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the report on refugees, which has the ambition to deepen the issues of social inclusion and labour market integration. Our group has worked hard to produce a report that will stimulate more debate and that calls for more action from European leaders in the first place. The report stresses the need for this. Social inclusion, the integration of refugees into the European labour market, fair access to education and training, the labour market combined with social protection instruments and associated rights, as well as the use of European health and housing services, when necessary, are all necessary tools to create a state-of-the-art reception system, capable of enabling a gradual and homogeneous process of integration throughout Europe. As has already been demonstrated, successful integration enables states to benefit, especially in fiscal and demographic terms. Our European ambition is to create winning multinational integration models and, in order to do so, we need to be courageous in our choices. That is why I am voting in favour of this report and calling on the European Union to continue along this path.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the parts of the report that strengthen inclusion, i.e. social inclusion. Inclusion plays an extremely important role in the development of a peaceful and inclusive society, since, unlike integration, it focuses not on the integration of groups, but on the individual. Social inclusion and integration into the labour market play an important role in restoring the human dignity and self-esteem of refugees, and it also has a beneficial effect on the economy, as it enables them to become economically independent. It is also a responsible approach to public finances, as it reduces the costs borne by Member States and local authorities, integrating refugees while allowing them to become active taxpayers.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report, examining the challenges and opportunities for refugees during their social inclusion and integration in the labour market. The report also analyses the development and impact of recent measures, actions and practices.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – The new European Agenda on Migration has set a framework for addressing the difficulties of managing the large flow of arrivals. However, we must also consider effective measures to integrate refugees and asylum seekers into both the labour market and our societies.  I believe that for this to happen, more operational measures related to education and training need to be put into the programme. The first barrier to successful integration is overcoming linguistic isolation. The rapid learning and understanding of the language and culture of the host country is of paramount importance for the success of this process. Education is the key to rapid social inclusion and labour market integration. That is why we must ensure robust and transparent procedures for the recognition of qualifications acquired outside the EU.  Here is the place to note that among the refugees who arrived in Europe in 2015 were children who came from conflict zones and for a long period of time did not have access to any form of education. It is also important to say what the alternative would be – the creation of slums and encapsulated communities, unable to fit into the host environment.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained because, together with my faction, I do not agree with some of the points that have not been discarded in a separate vote. This includes, for example, the requirement to allote 25% of cohesion policy funds to the European Social Fund, an issue related to the setting up of the EU budget and should not be addressed in such a report. Some proposals on access to the labour market for asylum seekers are also contentious to me. I consider the willingness of some political groups to include areas in similar reports that are not directly related to their focus, which I consider to be very bad practice, to be a major problem that has affected my approach to the report.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of this report because I consider it particularly important that refugees arriving in Europe are given the right opportunity to find employment in the labour market. The faster these people fleeing war manage to get into work, the earlier they will be able to contribute to the performance of the European economy, and this growth will create new jobs. The more opportunities refugees get to work, the greater the chance of their successful social integration. From the point of view of inclusion in the labour market, I consider it particularly important to fill the gap in education, training and retraining, language teaching, because they enable employment.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which provides a good starting point for a process to assist refuges in integrating better, and also in participating in the basic human right to work. Moreover, the report contains references to facilitating refugees and asylum seekers in having access to housing, health care, education, social protection and family reunification. For the majority of refugees in Europe, integration is the most relevant durable solution, and EU Member States have a responsibility to ensure that there are programmes and associated support available to facilitate immigrant integration, and also to identify effective practice. Employment is often the key concern for refugee respondents. Regarding entering the labour market, specific barriers exist for refugees in addition to the challenges that other migrants face. Challenges often include loss of identity documentation and qualification certificates, non-acceptance of qualifications or educational attainment, trauma and uncertainty, anxiety over family separation, the long period of inactivity in the asylum system, and limited social networks. It is, therefore, very positive that this report provides such a compassionate and empathetic approach to the needs of people who are fleeing war.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because there is enormous youth unemployment within the European Union. Furthermore, the report fails to do any kind of social integration. I cannot vote in favour of this report and I am opposed to refugees having easier access to the labour market.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In the event of a refugee crisis, the social and economic integration of refugees into society is essential as soon as possible. The report supports cooperation between Member States in this area in order to promote equal opportunities, and takes into account the health needs of refugees, different social backgrounds, accommodation needs, the large total number of people with disabilities, the elderly and women, etc. This report calls for the creation of language learning systems, support for the national minimum wage for all and to emphasise the importance of education.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament has pushed for the drafting of numerous initiatives and comprehensive action plans, including safe avenues for refugees not to have to make a living in their need to escape death and try to reach our borders.  This report on social inclusion and refugee integration is essential to identify the early intervention mechanisms needed in supporting the inclusion and integration of refugees, as well as to assess the most efficient way to use the funds that the Union makes available to States. It is not an easy task, but we must be able to articulate a cohesive policy at European level in this area, based on the principles of solidarity and equitable sharing of responsibility. Only in this way, generating proposals and answers, will we be able to solve the problem of integration and face the prejudices of populists and xenophobes.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I do not support the resolution tabled on the social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market. It should be noted that today and without these things almost 25% of people in Europe are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. About 10 percent of them experience severe material deprivation. Nothing has been done to change the situation, and here we are considering what benefits community countries should provide for migrant employment. We must not create labour markets specifically for refugees. Everyone on arrival must obey the order and law of a particular state. Member States should not be subject to the obligation to facilitate the admission of refugee students to educational establishments at all levels or to organise additional language classes in the country of origin. It should be noted that a common mandatory asylum system will not solve existing problems. Any quota policy must be abandoned. It has been, is and will be an obvious incentive for migration to Europe. Because this sends a signal – you are welcome here, you will be taken care of.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. It included calls for more EU interference and rules on asylum and immigration policy. The report also criticised Member States that have tried to control their borders externally and internally in the Schengen area. The only people who should take decisions on these things are elected national governments in compliance with the 1951 Geneva Convention on refugees. None of this should be decided on or dictated by unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the refugee crisis is the main challenge facing the European Union and that the new European migration agenda is aimed at overcoming the difficulties of managing this emergency, that greater synergy between the various European policies would make it possible to manage the problem of migration from the causes that drive thousands of people to leave their country to reach Europe , that unemployment and the financial crisis in the European Union make it even more difficult for refugees to integrate and integrate into our society, and that a better understanding of the phenomenon can be extremely useful for more effective management of the phenomenon, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of my colleague's proposal. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The integration of refugees into the labour force is beneficial for the EU, as asylum seekers would thus have more opportunity to be financially independent, hence requiring less or no social benefits. Furthermore, making refugees part of the labour market will be favourable for national budgets and economic growth. Therefore I voted in favour of the report by Brando Benifei addressing the challenges of integrating refugees into the labour market and into education. However, I have concerns about the proposed lowering of the waiting period for work permits from nine to six months.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report because, given the current situation, it is substantively acceptable and offers a range of options and answers. As the report states, it is first necessary to make a clear distinction between the term refugee and the economic migrant, especially for the purposes of implementing various European and international policies. Education and training, especially linguistic, is important to facilitate social integration, which is of paramount importance for entering the labour market. Integration must be based on the foundations of equal opportunities for all refugees, paying attention to girls and women as a vulnerable group.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The extremely large refugee wave sweeping Europe has caught us all off guard and we have not responded adequately to the demands of the refugee crisis in all segments. Many refugees suffer from many health problems, psychosocial and post-traumatic disorders, many families are separated, and there is a large number of children who came completely alone, unaccompanied. In addition, countries where they are trying to build a new life face manifold problems.  I supported the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the inclusion of refugees in society and integration into the labour market, as I believe that all people who have come to Europe saving their lives and seeking refuge need to be given help and opportunity for a dignified life. We must influence the fear that has trapped our citizens and which has left many refugees facing discrimination, making it difficult for them to integrate into society in the already difficult position they find themselves in.  It is also particularly important to give children access to education and integrate them into the Member States' education system as painlessly as possible, while facilitating the recognition of qualifications acquired outside EU countries to give working-age people the opportunity to find employment so that they can feed their family through their work, thereby gradually returning their lost self-confidence and the hope that a better and safer tomorrow is possible.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report itself highlights the very broad use of the term "refugee." The amalgamation is too often made between "refugee" and "migrant", and the relationship passes from one to the other without explanation. The aim is to put in place all the provisions to offer them a job within six months of their application: language training, social assistance, supported jobs, interpretation in the workplace... All this at a time when member countries are experiencing terrible unemployment rates, especially for young people and seniors, further aggravated by the austerity policies imposed by Brussels. Nothing is said about the security risks, while the New Year's Eve attacks in Cologne and the presence of several terrorists among the migrants have shown the magnitude of the problem posed. This report does not take into account the will or the most basic interests of the peoples of Europe. Of course I'm voting against it.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The reception of refugees arriving in Europe is one of the most challenging challenges facing us and which, if dealt with in the right way, can become a great opportunity, both for refugees and for European societies. The Commission's commitment to a common approach to social inclusion and integration into the labour market of refugees is certainly positive, but we need to act quickly and put all the necessary resources in place. I support this resolution because it clearly highlights the importance and urgency of this issue, provides an accurate analysis of the action expressed so far by the European Union and the Member States, and at the same time presents a detailed picture of the measures to be taken to achieve better social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market. By always guaranteeing the principles of non-discrimination and equal opportunities and avoiding creating further competition between refugees and the most disadvantaged sectors of our societies, in order to prevent refugees from feeling threatened by the (even limited) arrival of refugees, Europe must ensure that refugees have access to vocational education and training, housing, health care, the labour market and social protection. , in particular by protecting the most vulnerable groups such as women, children (especially when unaccompanied) and people with disabilities.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I believe that the EU's immediate response to this situation should be based on solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities, as set out in Article 80 TSC. treaty on the functioning of the European Union and a holistic approach that takes into account the need to improve safe and legal migration channels and which ensures full respect for existing laws and fundamental European rights and values. I underline that in order to manage the influx of refugees and asylum seekers, a permanent relocation mechanism applicable in all Member States should be put in place immediately. I underline the fact that in order to facilitate social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market, it is necessary to develop an approach that prescribes appropriate adaptation and presupposes cooperation and to address a number of serious and multidimensional issues, such as: all forms of discrimination, language barriers as the first barrier to integration, validation of skills, different socio-economic, educational and cultural roots, housing, health needs, including psychosocial support and post-trauma support , family reunification, and a significant proportion of vulnerable groups among refugees, a particularly worrying number of children, including unaccompanied children, people with disabilities, the elderly and women, all need answers tailored to their specific needs.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report reflects the need for the inclusion of refugees in member states that is linked to labour market integration. It has limitations on the necessary but non-existent criticism of the relocation mechanisms and the Dublin Regulation, the distinction between refugees and migrants, or the EU's non-accountability for conflicts in countries of origin, the inhumane conditions of concentration camps, or the criminal return policy. However, we follow some of the concerns and proposals of the report which we highlight: - The increase in synergies between the financial instruments available and the proposal to allocate 25 % of the European Social Fund budget for refugee support; - the protection of vulnerable groups such as children and women, including sexual exploitation and violence; - the labour protection of refugees by opposing undeclared working practices and forms of serious exploitation or discrimination at work; - The effective guarantee of access to housing, health, education, social security and the labour market; - The fundamental role of free public education, language teaching, culture, intercultural and interreligious dialogue, non-formal and informal education, lifelong learning and youth and sport policies in fostering integration and inclusion. We voted for it.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Managing the refugee crisis is one of the main challenges currently facing the European Union and its society. The situation can only be addressed with a comprehensive approach, which is why I consider the report adopted today by the European Parliament to be another important element in the possibility of a holical solution. It is essential that, in the areas of employment, education, social and health care, the challenges arising from migratory pressures are transformed into a source of economic and cultural development for our society. As a Social Democrat, I have decided to support a new European agenda for migration to address the challenges of managing the unprecedented influx of people arriving in the EU. This can only be done if the external and internal policies of the Union and its Member States are co-existing and complementary. I also unequivocally support the strengthened European Social Fund, which could help to integrate refugees into society and apply them to the labour market. In my opinion, this is the right way to help manage the situation in all EU Member States. On the contrary, cuts to the aforementioned funds or the punishment of malusa and such nonsense would only damage Pan-European growth and significantly reduce the management of the situation.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of the report calls for more public resources to be invested to promote the employment of refugees arriving in Europe and calls on the European Commission to examine the desirability of introducing a minimum of 25% of the European Social Fund (ESF) cohesion policy budget in order to ensure the availability of adequate resources for their integration into the labour market. In addition, the report stresses that, in order to ensure rapid allocation under the ESF, Member States should, where necessary, adapt their national rules to ensure that asylum seekers enjoy equal treatment with UNION citizens who have access to the labour market. Although this is a non-binding text, the signal from the European Parliament is strongly negative. Given the youth unemployment rates on our territory, it would be truly paradoxical to send out the message that the EU puts europe's unemployed young people and refugees on an equal footing. There are priorities and our priority must be to provide employment for young Europeans. For all these reasons, I voted against the adoption of this report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The crisis facing the influx of migrants is unprecedented. Not all refugees or asylum seekers can be accepted in our territories. However, it is the duty of Member States to welcome refugees or asylum seekers who have complied with legal procedures in dignified conditions. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which stresses the need to include these people in the labour market, including through the fundamental learning of the language of the host country, in order to enable them to integrate into our societies, to contribute to the economy and, thus, to reduce the pressure on public budgets dedicated to the temporary reception of migrants.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. Today's refugee crisis is a global humanitarian crisis, but it is also a political crisis in which urgent and effective measures need to be taken. This report aims at integrating refugees into the societies, labour market and education systems of their Member States.    In fact, I consider the consecration of the principle of equal treatment in this area to be of the utmost importance. Member States should guarantee refugees access to public services, as well as integration courses, language learning modules and other measures in the field of education and training.   In this regard, the report gives a satisfactory answer in this regard, without prejudice to the proper fair distribution of responsibility, as provided for in Article 80 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU).  Understanding that the basis for the success of the management of the migration crisis is social inclusion and integration that respects equal treatment and equal opportunities, I vote in this report.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's main priority is European citizens. Their safety and well-being must be our main concern. In recent years, the issue of labour market integration has been consistently on the Union's agenda. Entire generations of young Europeans, highly academically trained, are having major difficulties in finding a job for which they are often over-qualified. The political ambition to integrate refugees into a market that cannot provide a job to European citizens is more than an irrational decision, it is an act of indifference to their own citizens and their needs.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. It included calls for more EU interference and rules on asylum and immigration policy. The report also criticised Member States that have tried to control their borders externally and internally in the Schengen area. The only people who should take decisions on these things are elected national governments in compliance with the 1951 Geneva Convention on refugees. None of this should be decided on or dictated by unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of my colleague Brando Benifei's report, which calls for full inclusion of refugees in society and their integration into the European labour market.  Putting in place a common approach to integration involves measures to combat discrimination and promote equal treatment, as well as access to education, training, housing, health care and social protection. It also means ensuring the recognition of the qualifications of third-country nationals and ensuring family reunification. In this context, it is particularly important to take into account the needs of vulnerable groups, especially women and children.  Access to the labour market for refugees is the key to the success of integration policies. Enabling people in need of international protection to be able to benefit from a blue card is a step forward, but it is not enough, because it is necessary to be open to all levels of competence.  Current migration challenges should not be seen as problems. On the contrary, the integration of refugees represents a real opportunity. This is an opportunity for the future, which will help to revive the economy and enrich our societies.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution on social inclusion and integration into the labour market for refugees. It is necessary to offer them the best conditions for integration and inclusion in order to enable them to support themselves, to become economically independent and to participate fully in the activity of our societies. In this regard, the Reception Conditions Directive should be revised to ensure that people seeking international protection have access to the labour market as soon as possible, and no later than six months after their application.
