It is regrettable that this six-month provision has not been accepted. In addition, compulsory language courses should be set up for refugees, both general and professional.  Member States and European societies must show a united and united commitment.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. It is our duty to step up our efforts to find fast, effective and equitable ways of creating the conditions for the integration of asylum seekers and refugees into our society. This is only possible if the external and internal policies of the Union and its Member States are synergistic, complementary, fully and in a timely manner implemented and based on solidarity, equitable sharing of responsibilities and respect for international law and human rights. A holistic approach to migration requires EU external policies to demonstrate that they are able to tackle the root causes of migration, such as conflicts, poverty, the absence of freedoms, inequalities and extreme environmental conditions.  On the other hand, internal employment, education, social protection and health policies must also be open, harmonious and flexible enough to transform the challenges posed by migratory pressures into a resource for the economic, social and cultural development of our societies.  Equal treatment and equal opportunities should always be the guiding principles of policies on social inclusion and integration. The integration of refugees is a challenge, but it can also be an opportunity.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that respect for human rights and international laws should be accompanied by worthy integration of refugees and asylum seekers into our societies. In this sense, we are convinced that social and labour integration is the spearhead for achieving this.  In this regard, the report calls for an increase in the Union's investment in social and labour policies, in order to tackle this situation, preventing this from being detrimental to those European citizens who are already in a vulnerable situation in our countries. It therefore calls for an increase of the European Social Fund's participation in the Structural and Investment Funds to 25%. It requires that the maximum time be reduced so that a refugee can acquire the right to participate in the labour market of the host country to as little as six months. And that their access to training, housing, health, education, as well as recognition of their skills and family reunification can be ensured.  A comprehensive and robust report with recommendations that can be key to managing the crisis we are experiencing in the long run.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. If women and men leave country and family, it is not for pleasure. This is because they are fleeing the dramatic situations in which they are immersed. We must show solidarity and ensure their protection. It is our duty to succeed in this integration, especially in the labour market. It is a question of respect for international rights, a question of humanity but also a question of common sense This debate is too important to pollute it with demagogic statements advocating the rejection of others. We must put in place the necessary provisions to make this integration a success and an added value for society as a whole.  In this regard, I welcome the direction taken by this report, which is not to create a second labour market for refugees. These people must be able to enjoy the same social conditions as our European citizens. It is also important to ensure that the language of the host country is learned from the very first days, that a system of recognition of skills is established and that the necessary means are allocated to ensure their full integration.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which discusses the need for more active work to integrate refugees into the labour market. The report also identifies concrete measures to be taken: the establishment of a language training system, better access to training, faster development of integration plans, etc.  One of the most important work is the need to establish robust and transparent procedures for the recognition of qualifications obtained abroad, outside the European Union. This would allow refugees to make better use of the skills they already have and to apply them in workplaces where they already have some professional knowledge. At the same time, the report makes it clear that refugees cannot be discriminated against or exploited by employers, they cannot be treated less favoured than local people. The report mentions and requires specific efforts to integrate girls and women, in particular through access to formal and non-formal education and informal education. This would speed up integration.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The management of the refugee crisis is one of the main challenges facing the European Union (EU) today because of its size and the complexity of its social, political and economic implications. This is a humanitarian crisis on a global scale, but also a political crisis that requires urgent, firm and permanent measures that also meet the needs of society and the labour market of countries, regions and communities of insertion. The new European Agenda on Migration was adopted with the aim of addressing the difficulties resulting from this extraordinary influx of people and the creation of a European relocation/resettlement scheme. This remains to be intensified, through mechanisms already adopted in this regard, or by making additional and effective efforts to create the necessary conditions for the integration of asylum seekers and refugees.  This report describes the complexity and nature of this reality, underlining the urgency of finding a solution, based on the application of the principles of solidarity and equitable sharing of responsibilities, necessary to address this common problem which also requires a common response.  Because I agree, in the majority, with the measures pointed out by the rapporteur, I voted in favour of it.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Benifei's report deals with social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market. As a Member of the European Parliament and an Italian citizen, I have chosen to vote against the proposed text. Although I am aware of the urgent need to regulate and effectively resolve the integration of people who, for political reasons, find refuge in Europe, I look at the current situation in my country with great concern. Those rights that the European Parliament is calling for today to be extended to refugees are the same rights that Italy cannot guarantee to its own citizens. We are talking about the integration of refugees into the labour market, when our country's unemployment rate is among the highest in Europe and when our own young people are struggling to enter the world of work to which the EU proposes to facilitate access for migrants. That is why I have chosen to vote against the text before us.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is a first step in improving policies for social inclusion and integration of refugees. The text talks about ensuring access to housing, education and training, social protection, health and family reunification, all of which are the indispensable rights of people applying for international protection and which our delegation advocates.     Increasing public investment with an increase in the ESF, as the report shows, is good news, as is ensuring that refugees can access the labour market no later than 6 months after the application and that they have a minimum wage equal to other nationals, avoiding dumping and exploitation of the most vulnerable people. In the blue card paragraph, however, I voted against it as we must avoid rewarding some refugees against others on grounds of origin or training. However, as a whole it is a positive report and in that regard I voted.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market. Existing systems and structures should be developed in order to give refugees a better chance of integration and integration into the labour market and the education system in the long term.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report aims to make a number of recommendations to facilitate the inclusion of refugees in the workplace. This is a good way to end the precarious situation in which most refugees live in the European Union, as well as to fight for their empowerment and xenophobia that is still spreading across the continent. That is why I voted in favour of the report, which contains a number of elements which we value very positively, such as the claim to access to rights such as housing, health care, education, or involvement in the process of social organisations and trade unions. In addition, refugees are required to have access to the labour market after a maximum of six months in the Union and to have the same minimum wage applied to them as the rest of the population. These are two central elements for the revision of Directive 2013/33/EU on the reception of asylum seekers, one of the main European regulations to be amended to ensure that refugees living in our society enjoy effective equality.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. The unprecedented phenomenon of the refugee crisis that is lashing European borders is one of today's biggest challenges. The EU has sought to respond to this humanitarian crisis through enhanced intervention in key areas - economic, political and social - as a means of ensuring the proper integration of refugees into the labour market in order to promote social cohesion and full integration of them into European societies.  A comprehensive European strategy in this area involves respecting European fundamental rights, providing adequate reception and decent living conditions, avoiding the establishment of fragmented communities. It is necessary to invest in education, in particular in access to language courses, and in access to social protection.  In addition, migration may represent opportunities for Europe in terms of economic growth and development and rejuvenation. The resources of the European Social Fund need to be increased as a means of facilitating the full integration of refugees into European societies.  I voted positively because this legislation guarantees the implementation of policies for the social inclusion of refugees and their integration into the labour market, thereby restoring the dignity of those seeking refuge and security on the European continent.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. It included calls for more EU interference and rules on asylum and immigration policy. The report also criticised Member States that have tried to control their borders externally and internally in the Schengen area. The only people who should take decisions on these things are elected national governments in compliance with the 1951 Geneva Convention on refugees. None of this should be decided on or dictated by unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for swift and full integration of refugees into the labour market and for their social inclusion in accordance with the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination. Along with my Labour colleagues I voted in favour of the report, which calls for a much-needed European approach to address key issues such as access to education and training, non-discrimination, health care, labour and social protection, and the recognition and validation of skills and qualifications. Any approach, European or otherwise, needs to ensure that families are able to be reunified and that the situation of vulnerable groups (particularly those with disabilities, women and children, and especially unaccompanied children) is addressed. We must have a strategy which will restore and secure the human dignity of refugees: they must be allowed to gain economic independence and significantly contribute to their successful integration into the host societies. This report goes some way to address these issues and I can support it.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I would like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteur for the report presented on refugees and their social inclusion and labour market integration. Although opinions vary on the current situation of refugees, I see the refugee crisis as one of the main challenges facing the EU and its society today. It regrets that the refugee crisis has not yet been resolved, and many mistakes have been made at various levels of policy in trying to avert it, and as a result of which the refugees themselves who have come to the EU are suffering. On the other hand, however, I appreciate the Commission's efforts to improve the situation and find new possible solutions that could help refugees with social inclusion and integration in the labour market. I supported the resolution because I believe that, thanks to the proposed measures, we will find new, rapid, effective and fair opportunities to create the necessary conditions for the integration of asylum seekers and refugees into our society, which will provide beneficiaries with sufficient opportunities to reach the host country. I believe that Slovakia, as the presiding country in the Council of the European Union, will also be able to pursue a sustainable migration and asylum policy that will benefit not only the citizens of Slovakia, but also the whole EU.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support the resolution on social inclusion and employment in the refugee labour market.  I agree that refugees must be integrated into our societies. In this integration, we must learn from the mistakes of the past and not allow new ghettos to arise and social exclusion leading to radicalisation. The resolution is based on the correct assumption that integration is most effective through the labour market. However, as is often the case with non-binding parliamentary resolutions, sections that disqualify the text as a whole will penetrate into a meaningful text. The resolution calls for the deadline for asylum seekers whose applications have not been decided to have access to the labour market to be shortened. Our PPE Group voted unsuccessfully against this point and we managed to narrowly enforce at least the omission of an explicit call after the six-month deadline. I do not consider such calls to be happy, we should leave any reduction to the Member States, as today's legislation allows. I also cannot support calls for a purposeful increase in the budgetary allocation for the European Social Fund. Changes in the budget require rigorous expert assessment by the European Commission, not politically motivated challenges.  The biggest problem with the text is that it expresses its support for the proposal for a permanent system for the redistribution of asylum seekers. This issue clearly does not belong in the debate on refugees' access to the labour market. Unfortunately, we were unable to remove it from the text.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The refugee crisis is likely to be one of the biggest challenges facing the European Union and its Member States due to the scale, stages of progress and the complexity of its social, political and economic consequences. It is mainly a global humanitarian crisis, but also a policy crisis that has caught the European Union off guard. For this reason, it is necessary for policymakers to take urgent and decisive, as well as long-term, measures consistent with society's needs and labour market requirements. The report aims to draw attention to the most important problems, challenges and opportunities brought about by the integration of refugees into society and the labour market and to examine the development and impact of recent actions, activities and practices at European Union level. The report also contains a set of proposals, recommendations and initiatives to achieve better integration of refugees into society and the labour market. What I particularly like in the report is that it calls for ensuring the safety of those who are entitled to come to the host countries, and thus to improve legal and therefore safe migration channels. The report also calls for the establishment of a language learning system to make it easier for migrants to integrate. The situation of women and the concern for their safety are further highlighted. For this reason, I believe that the report is good and I have supported it.

name: Renato Soru (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the resolution in which Parliament makes some concrete proposals to facilitate the social inclusion of refugees and asylum seekers, through their integration into the labour market, the learning of the local language and culture and the orientation towards understanding European values. I believe, in particular, that enabling refugees to work in host countries, including through the rapid recognition of their professional qualifications, is a fundamental step so that they can regain their dignity and adequate social protection, while participating as taxpayers in the economic system of the host country. In this way, the process of integration into the host country would be characterised by active interaction between refugees and local communities and authorities in which all parties have equal rights and obligations. However, the resolution considers the differences between the various Member States and, in particular, those with extremely high rates of youth and long-term unemployment: in such cases, new financial resources are needed to provide assistance to refugees and asylum seekers while maintaining the funding already provided for programmes aimed at supporting other disadvantaged groups of citizens.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'In today's report on social inclusion and integration into the refugee labour market, the current situation is seen as a humanitarian crisis. The report calls for a common asylum system with a permanent resettlement mechanism and for the improvement of safe and legal migration routes. We also call on the Commission to promote upward convergence of social protection standards, as well as to work for the efficient granting of work permits in the Member States. A slow and long-winded bureaucratic procedure makes refugees and asylum seekers particularly vulnerable to undeclared work and precarious working conditions. The report also calls for account to be taken of existing legislation such as the Qualifications Directive and the Directive establishing standards for the reception of applicants for international protection. This legislation states that asylum seekers and people entitled to international protection have the right to access the labour market and language education. It also stresses the importance of civil society organisations and volunteers strengthening asylum seekers and refugees in their resilience and integration. This has finally become a very constructive report, with an eye for the people themselves, which in turn benefits our entire society. That is why I do politics and that is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. This report by Italian S&D Euro MP Brando Benifei makes broad calls for better integration of refugees and asylum seekers in the European Union. The text states, quite literally, that successful integration is not only integration into the labour market, but also means full access to language courses, accommodation, education and training, social security, health care and mental health support, which is why the Commission and EU Member States should ensure the appropriate framework conditions for this. Family reunifications should also be facilitated. These demands sound good, but they are completely unrealistic, not to mention other EU countries with far less economic power than Germany, given the coffers in cities and municipalities in Germany. It also does not call for taxable ceilings on the reception of refugees and asylum seekers. On the contrary, the report is marked by a culture of welcome that is being promoted, which ignores existing rules such as the Dublin Regulation and the Schengen acquis and wants to open the door to economically motivated migration to Europe, despite major social problems in Europe, with sometimes high unemployment in the individual EU Member States. That is why I have clearly rejected the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The fight against social exclusion and poverty is one of the EU's priorities. Political priority must be given to measures that promote economic growth and the social inclusion of those excluded from the labour market in order to better accept refugees in our society.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on 'Refugees – social inclusion and integration into the labour market'. The report already lacks accurate terms. Refugees do not need to be integrated because they are lucky enough to be able to return to their countries of origin once the reason for fleeing has been removed. It is different for migrants. But migration must not take place under the guise of asylum and refugee law. Moreover, with regard to migrants, it is not the political task to integrate refugees into the labour market. Only companies that provide jobs can do this. In the first place, however, it would be the task of the migrants themselves. After all, integration is a personal achievement that everyone is required to do. Finally, migration law should be regulated by the Member States, so that it should not matter to the EU at all. In the light of all this, I do not even have to resort to the blossoms of the report – such as the demand that art should be better promoted as an instrument of integration and that the participation of refugees in artistic activities should be simplified and supported – in order to reject the report.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Managing the refugee crisis due to its size, pace and complexity is one of the main challenges facing the European Union and European society. The refugee crisis is primarily a humanitarian crisis, having long-term effects on the labour market and civil society. Social cohesion at local level and the successful integration of new migrants into society should be achieved. The integration of refugees into society and the labour market can only be achieved if there is solidarity between all Member States and their societies. I support the proposal for a resolution, as I think it is important for refugees and asylum seekers to gain access to the market so that they can regain their human dignity and self-esteem. The integration of asylum seekers and refugees into our society can only be achieved if the foreign and internal policies of the Union and its Member States are in synergy, are complementary and are fully and timely implemented on the basis of solidarity, fair sharing of responsibilities and in full respect of international and human rights.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on refugees: integration into society and the labour market. The refugee and migrant crisis facing the European Union in recent months has also had a profound impact on the labour market. The European Union must ensure safe and legal migration and respect for the rules in force and European rights and values. Women who face gender-based violence and cultural barriers to accessing the health system are particularly vulnerable. By facilitating refugees' access to housing, healthcare, education, social protection and the labour market, they will become more involved, thus repaid their basic human dignity.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In today's vote on the report entitled 'Refugees: social inclusion and labour market employment', I abstained because I do not believe that it is effective for us to discuss the form of the EU asylum system in the report on the integration and employment of refugees in the labour market. I am aware that, in particular, the debate on the common asylum system touches on the problem of the social inclusion of refugees, but I am of the opinion that the parameters of the future common asylum system are important here. However, we are not talking about these now. As regards the idea of a common asylum system, I a priori do not reject it. Above all, it must be said that the common asylum system does not in any way mean that Member States will be given the competence to consider asylum applications. No one proposes such a change. The debate is only about the rules on which asylum applications will be assessed, but these will still be assessed by the authorities of the Member States, not by any of the EU institutions or agencies. I therefore believe that this debate is legitimate, supported by Article 78 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, which states that 'the Union is developing a common policy on asylum' and, as a result, can contribute to reducing some of the so-called pull-factors that we are now registering within the EU. However, the exact parameters of this system under considered should be further discussed.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is a fact that the unprecedented number of asylum seekers in Europe, but above all the vulnerability of refugees to undeclared work, will not only burden the EU fiscally, but will also increase the youth unemployment rate. The Commission and the Member States should give priority to political investment and jobs for EU citizens, with particular emphasis on the most vulnerable people (DISABLED). Undoubtedly, adapting social inclusion and integration policies to the specific needs of refugees will create serious problems in the state concerned, because in addition to involving a heterogeneous group of people who are unable to integrate with the European element, it requires immediate financial support, at a time of economic crisis, where health care, social protection, education and, above all, the labour market are threatened by the migration problem. , which like a Damocles sword hangs over the head of the EU.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report, which takes a positive approach and a constructive approach, while not masking the seriousness of the problem, one of the most serious challenges facing Europe as a result of the migration crisis. As a Socialist politician, I particularly agree that he treats solidarity in the Member States, the humane treatment of refugees, the need to ensure equal human and labour rights and the obligation to promote cultural, social and labour market integration as a starting point. However, without questioning my support, I have doubts as to the practical feasibility of the principles and the desired objectives and procedures. Indeed, there are Member States that refuse EU solidarity on this issue, where, as part of government policy, they refuse to accept refugees, consider it undesirable or downright impossible to socially integrate people from other cultural and religious contexts, block their labour markets from them and, in some cases, engage in an incitation campaign against refugees and foreigners. In these circumstances, one can only hope that this report or decision can contribute to the EU's ability to reduce such phenomena in the Member States and to successfully address the refugee crisis in terms of employment and the positive impact of an inclusive social environment.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 With regard to this report, I abstained in part because it partly addressed the themes of competence of the Member States. A unified line on the integration of refugees will guide the distribution of refugees evenly between member states, preventing the extra burden on a few Member States. However, it must be up to the Member States themselves to decide how to use, for example, funds for regional development and how integration is most effectively carried out at national level.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The refugee crisis is currently one of the main challenges to the structures of the European Union. The various approaches of the Member States have led to the worsening of the crisis due to discriminatory and protectionist tendencies. On the other hand, at European level, this crisis could be a new opportunity for EU development in all areas if the focus of approaches is shifted from the defensive temptation of Member States to an inclusive approach. This new approach envisages the adoption of integration policies in the labour market within the Union, with a view to supporting legal channels of migration and ensuring respect for fundamental rights and non-discrimination. At the same time, access to education and training, housing, healthcare, social protection, recognition of qualifications and family reunification must be guaranteed. There is also a need to speed up the processing of applications for international protection, in particular with regard to vulnerable groups (women, children, persons with disabilities), but also to highly qualified people, and black work and exploitation, including with the help of civil society, must be combated. Society's hostile attitude towards refugees serves no one and therefore populist forms of exploitation of the fears of the citizens of the Member States should be abandoned and strongly condemned. This document is a fair approach to the problem and has my support.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I spoke out in favour of the report. It aims to achieve the following objectives: to clarify the exact subject for consideration by explicitly recalling what it means to be a refugee and the main elements of the current debate; highlight relevant issues, challenges and opportunities that accompany social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market; analyze the development and implications of recent EU and Member State measures, actions and practices to achieve successful integration and inclusion in our society; and present a series of proposals, recommendations and suggestions to improve social inclusion and integration of refugees into the labour market. The structure outlined in the text tries to reflect this approach.  More generally, the report attempts to outline on the complexity and multidimensional nature of the subject and on the other, the urgency and the need to find a solution, bearing in mind that it is absolutely essential to apply the principles of solidarity and equitable sharing of responsibilities to solve this common European problem which calls for a common European response.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ While I fully agree that participation in the labour market and social inclusion are the best ways to ensure long-term integration for migrants, I voted against the report on the social inclusion and integration into the labour market of refugees. This is because it contains certain elements that are counterproductive to our efforts to achieving a coherent migration strategy for Europe. In fact, agreeing on a permanent relocation mechanism and a common asylum system makes little sense so long as we have not yet agreed on the larger common approach to migration and organised our external borders effectively, and it might even jeopardise our efforts to find compromises on controversial issues.

name: Εleni Theocharous (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to vote in favour of this report since it touches on numerous issues, including providing a holistic EU approach, cooperation with third countries, EU funding including the ESF, ERDF, and humanitarian aid, definitions, processing, recognition of qualifications, access to EU labour markets and social inclusion (including housing, health care and social protection) which are of great importance if we want to deal with the migration crisis. The report first outlines the political and policy landscape and secondly sets out in a clear manner a number of recommendations including calls for an increase in the budget of the ESF, the creation of a uniform Common European Asylum System and a revision of the Reception Conditions Directive and the Blue Card Directive.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully agree with the main objective of the report to integrate refugees into our societies and the labour market, I believe it is important to turn the current migration crisis into an opportunity. The integration of refugees into working life allows people to be given dignity, makes them independent and active members of our societies and capable of contributing to the public budgets of the host country. In addition, as set out in the report, inclusion policies should also include language learning and pay particular attention to local unemployment rates, especially for the most vulnerable groups such as young people, the long-term unemployed and the disabled. Both the European Union and the Member States need more direct financial support for local authorities, civil society organisations and voluntary associations that are at the forefront of reception and integration policies.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the integration of refugees into society and the labour market, as it addresses the challenge of social integration of refugees and their integration into the labour market and into the education system. The refugee crisis is one of the biggest challenges facing the EU today. As a social Europe, we have a duty to provide assistance to those who need it. To find work and become economically independent, this is the best way to integrate refugees into society. In some EU Member States, record levels of unemployment, poverty and a slow economic recovery could hamper the integration of refugees into society. The development of measures to integrate refugees effectively into society is also more problematic due to the frequent unpopularity of refugees in the public eye. Forms of discrimination, xenophobia and racism still exist or even rise, so Europe must be active in combating such phenomena. In order to tackle such a large-scale task, we need to make better use of existing instruments at EU level when planning measures to integrate refugees into society and into the labour market, and above all, we must tackle such a complex challenge in a uniform way. It is true, however, that the desire for integration must be mutual.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is a first step in improving policies for social inclusion and integration of refugees. The text talks about ensuring access to housing, education and training, social protection, health and family reunification, all of which are the indispensable rights of people applying for international protection and which our delegation advocates.     Increasing public investment with an increase in the ESF, as the report shows, is good news, as is ensuring that refugees can access the labour market no later than 6 months after the application and that they have a minimum wage equal to other nationals, avoiding dumping and exploitation of the most vulnerable people. In the blue card paragraph, however, I voted against it as we must avoid rewarding some refugees against others on grounds of origin or training. However, as a whole it is a positive report and in that regard I voted.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. This report makes broad calls for better integration of refugees and asylum seekers in the European Union. The text states, quite literally, that successful integration is not only integration into the labour market, but also means full access to language courses, accommodation, education and training, social security, health care and mental health support, which is why the Commission and EU Member States should ensure the appropriate framework conditions for this. Family reunifications should also be facilitated. These demands sound good, but they are completely unrealistic, not to mention other EU countries with far less economic power than Germany, given the coffers in cities and municipalities in Germany. It also does not call for taxable ceilings on the reception of refugees and asylum seekers. On the contrary, the report is marked by a culture of welcome that is being promoted, which ignores existing rules such as the Dublin Regulation and the Schengen acquis and wants to open the door to economically motivated migration to Europe, despite major social problems in Europe, with sometimes high unemployment in the individual EU Member States. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is well known that having a job is a good way for foreign people to integrate into our societies. It also means that governments should have solved many other areas of their lives, such as learning a new language, having a place to live, health care, education, etcetera, but having access to the labour market is the final proof of the successful integration of refugee people to our countries. I support this resolution because it would help to accelerate this process as much as possible, in order to give an immediate response to the emergency situation of refugee people in European countries.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. What we are currently experiencing and what we call the "migrant crisis" is gradually turning into a serious humanitarian crisis in France and the rest of Europe. In this report, the term migrant is replaced by the term refugee. This means that the vast majority of MEPs consider all illegal migrants to be refugees.  This voluntary amalgamation actually illustrates the european authorities' idea of this crisis: migrants are an opportunity for our European societies, they will allow us to open up to other cultures and replace our ageing populations with young individuals. It seems to me that thinking first of all about our families and a proactive birth policy is paramount. Finally, this report discusses the strategy to be put in place to welcome these young migrants, or how to give them a job in six months while protecting them from extremes.  Nowhere is it a question of national security or public order disturbances, yet our fellow citizens have seen.  I voted AGAINST this ideological report.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I believe that this report is not fully balanced. Yes, we must invest in integration, although integration must also include rights and obligations. I am of the opinion that success can only be achieved if both sides wish to bear responsibility and commitments, and I am therefore opposed to the proposed report. I voted against the document.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is a first step in improving policies for social inclusion and integration of refugees. The text talks about ensuring access to housing, education and training, social protection, health and family reunification, all of which are the indispensable rights of people applying for international protection and which our delegation advocates.     Increasing public investment with an increase in the ESF, as the report shows, is good news, as is ensuring that refugees can access the labour market no later than 6 months after the application and that they have a minimum wage equal to other nationals, avoiding dumping and exploitation of the most vulnerable people. In the blue card paragraph, however, I voted against it as we must avoid rewarding some refugees against others on grounds of origin or training. However, as a whole it is a positive report and in that regard I voted.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I stress the positive impact that refugee mobility would have on addressing labour needs and shortages, as well as the integration of refugees into the labour market, including aspects such as encouraging Member States to allow family reunification; I stress that further efforts are needed to create a truly uniform common European asylum system and a comprehensive and sustainable policy of legal migration in the European Union, in line with the demand for skills in the labour market, including social inclusion and active integration policies.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on refugees: social inclusion and integration into the labour market. Procedures for granting asylum and labour market conditions differ markedly across the EU. In addition, refugees have a wide variety of ages, education, skills and abilities to work. Social inclusion schemes should therefore aim to be a dynamic, two-way process between refugees and host communities, in which all partners have rights and duties, while the process itself adapts to the situation on the ground. I voted in favour because I believe that access for refugees and asylum seekers to the labour market, housing, health care, education and social protection restores their human dignity and self-worth. Moreover, employment enables them to become economically independent and to give something back to society by becoming taxpayers.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that respect for human rights and international laws should be accompanied by worthy integration of refugees and asylum seekers into our societies. In this sense, we are convinced that social and labour integration is the spearhead for achieving this.  In this regard, the report calls for an increase in the Union's investment in social and labour policies, in order to tackle this situation, preventing this from being detrimental to those European citizens who are already in a vulnerable situation in our countries. It therefore calls for an increase of the European Social Fund's participation in the Structural and Investment Funds to 25%. It requires that the maximum time be reduced so that a refugee can acquire the right to participate in the labour market of the host country to as little as six months. And that their access to training, housing, health, education, as well as recognition of their skills and family reunification can be ensured.  A comprehensive and robust report with recommendations that can be key to managing the crisis we are experiencing in the long run.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report aims to make a number of recommendations to facilitate the inclusion of refugees in the workplace. This is a good way to end the precarious situation in which most refugees live in the European Union, as well as to fight for their empowerment and xenophobia that is still spreading across the continent. That is why I voted in favour of the report, which contains a number of elements that we value very positively, such as the claim to access to rights such as housing, health care or education, or involvement in the process of social organisations and trade unions. In addition, refugees are required to have access to the labour market after a maximum of six months in the EU and to have the same minimum wage applied to the rest of the population. These are two central elements for the revision of Directive 2013/33/EU on the reception of asylum seekers, one of the main European regulations to be amended to ensure that refugees living in our society enjoy effective equality.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted today with my EPLP colleagues in favour of this report which calls for a swift and full integration of refugees into the labour market and their social inclusion in accordance with the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination. A European approach must address key issues such as non-discrimination, access to education and training (including an emphasis on language learning from arrival), housing, health care, labour market and social protection, recognition of qualifications and validation of skills, as well as family reunification, the situation and needs of vulnerable groups, mostly women, children (in particular the worrying number of unaccompanied children) , and people with disabilities, etc., which are essential to restore the human dignity of refugees, allow them to gain economic independence and significantly contribute to their successful integration in the host societies.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because I believe that we as Europe should do more to respond to the refugee crisis. The report first and foremost calls for a single European asylum system (a liberal demand). Furthermore, it cannot be the case that we would create a special labour market for refugees. This reminds me of black times in our common European history. The better refugees and asylum seekers are integrated into the labour market, the better social adjustment, and the better the tax receipts are. This report also looks at the plight of unaccompanied minors and the specific needs of female refugees.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted today on the report on 'refugees: social inclusion and integration into the labour market' on a number of points, contrary to the voting line of my ALDE Group. I do not believe that the points made in the report, such as the permanent burden-sharing mechanism and the common asylum system, will solve the refugee problem affecting Europe. Each Member State must be given the opportunity to assume its responsibilities on the basis of its own starting points, which also guarantees the best conditions for the integration of migrants. We need joint coordination, but we don't need dictation. Each Member State itself is also best aware of integration and employment policy issues, where the EU's role must only be to ensure that the EU's fundamental principles are respected.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report reflects the need for the inclusion of refugees in member states that necessarily involves integration into the labour market. The CFP tabled 8 amendments, focusing on improving working conditions and social protection, rejecting the 'qualifications' criterion as an exclusionary factor, rejecting the legislative frameworks on the refugee issue (Dublin Regulation, Blue Card Directive, EU-Turkey Agreement) and extending support and integration strategies not only to refugees and asylum seekers, but also to migrants. These proposals were not accepted in the Commission. The report therefore sets out some limitations, such as being uncritical of the criteria with which the EU proposes the 'distribution' of refugees (calls for a revision of the Dublin Regulation, but does not address the reasonableness of such 'distribution'), to call for a distinction between refugees and migrants, not to mention those responsible for conflicts in countries of origin, the inhuman conditions of concentration camps or the cruelty of repatriation. However, the generality of the document contains information which, to be applied, would have consequences for increasing the inclusion of these persons.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report calls for a common European asylum system that would lead to further centralisation and deprive national states of their right to sovereignty. It also calls for easier access to the labour market for refugees. In the case of Austria, this would mean lifting the six-month deadline. Apparently, the labour market should be open to refugees, while there is still extremely high youth unemployment within the EU. That is why the report must also be rejected.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on refugees: social inclusion and integration into the labour market. The report proposes the fast integration of refugees into society and the labour market through various actions and adequate funding. The most significant actions are more effective integration policies, faster decisions on the eligibility of asylum applications and a European response to issues relating to access to education, the health system and the labour market. In addition, the report proposes to increase public expenditure and, in particular, the financial resources allocated to EU cohesion policies. I firmly believe that these actions are necessary to resolve the refugee crisis as soon as possible and to ensure rapid integration with them.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the excellent work of my colleague Brando Benifei on this report and accordingly I voted in favour of it. The report includes the perspective of the Culture and Education Committee of which I am a member, highlighting the key role played by culture and education. Indeed, education is the key to both the economic and social inclusion of refugees and asylum seekers, in particular young people. That is why the CULT Committee has put forward the notion of ‘education corridors’ and calls for further supporting the cooperation between EU universities and universities in places of conflict, to ensure that children and young people who have to flee their country can still pursue their education. It is not only important for the welcoming countries, who will benefit from the economic contribution of educated newcomers, it is a moral/human duty for European societies to guarantee that those young people have the opportunity of a brighter future. I particularly advocate a proper recognition of the role of informal learning, including lifelong learning, sport, volunteering, culture and the arts which, by providing spaces for intercultural dialogue and exchange, not only facilitate the social inclusion of refugees into their new communities, but also address stereotypes, prejudices and discrimination by the majority.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution. The recent refugee crisis has shown us that something needs to change. The EU needs stronger and more coherent guidelines on how to deal with such a crisis.. It is an EU-wide holistic approach on how to improve migrant integration processes. It recognises that one of the best tools for integration is education. This will enable us to include migrants in the labour market. As a result they will have the opportunity to become an active member of society and contribute to it. In addition, this will enable the most vulnerable groups of migrants, namely children, to pursue a vital part in their development. Finally, I welcome the fact that the resolution recognises the big challenges in this area, such as budget cuts, the aftermath of the financial crisis, and the worrying rise of xenophobic movements.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Refugee is a reality that the EU must face overall and realistically. In countries such as Greece, which has come under the greatest pressure because of its geographical location, the necessary assistance must be given and a sustainable strategy implemented for the benefit of all. This initiative takes into account important parameters with mutual benefits for refugees, host countries and the EU as a whole.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I very much agree with this report, because, in view of the current situation in the Union with regard to the flow of migrants escaping from conflict zones such as Syria, I see it absolutely necessary to consider solutions. To be sure, the integration of these people is key, and I believe that using avenues such as recognition of their qualifications to facilitate their access to the labour market are great ideas for achieving the objective of social inclusion. After all, we must take into account that a large percentage of these people will spend a long period in the Union and, therefore, we cannot let ghettos be created, but that it must be ensured that, through investment and work, the arrival of these people is positive for the Union in the medium/long term.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text because I believe that the reception of refugees cannot be left to spontaneity, but needs a policy based on the combination of rights and duties and effective intercultural and social policies aimed at promoting dialogue and integration between immigrants and the host community. We have duties linked to the values of our civilisation and to international law. Furthermore, the European demographic trend leaves no room for doubt: the working-age population in the EU will decrease by 7.5 million by 2020 and it is therefore very important to have a coordinated immigration policy that sees immigrants as a huge asset to be valued.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support the initiative report on the integration of refugees in the EU, although it also puts pressure on Member States to put in place and comply with redistribution systems. However, in my opinion, these will not solve the refugee crisis. These proposals are already obsolete and do not correspond to the current developments in the situation of migration to the EU.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support Mr Benifei's report on the social inclusion of refugees and their integration into the labour market. The report identified a number of recommendations for the social inclusion of refugees and their integration into the labour market, such as their access to language courses, housing, education, healthcare or the recognition of their qualifications, but also touched on the issue of gender violence, discrimination or the merging of refugee families. On the other hand, however, it contained references to the mandatory redistribution of asylum seekers among Member States on the basis of quotas, or to the single European asylum system, which had nothing to do with the subject of this report, which was supposed to focus on inclusion and integration. That is why, although I believe that, in view of the number of refugees who have crossed the borders of the European Union, the situation needs to be considered and a debate on this subject opened, for the reasons mentioned above, I voted against the report as a whole.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Benifei report because I believe that a common approach to the integration and social inclusion of refugees is necessary. I believe that the integration of refugees should be seen as an opportunity for our society, because integrating them into the labour market is not only important to restore their dignity and self-esteem, but will also bring benefits to the common good, as it allows them to gain economic independence and become active members of our society. I therefore note the need for the EU to base its immediate response to the situation on solidarity and the equitable division of responsibility, as provided for in Article 80 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, as well as on a comprehensive approach that take into account the need to improve channels of safe and legal migration and full respect for European values and fundamental rights.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have our eyes on each other. Public opinion is following our steps carefully and, unfortunately, with increasing scepticism. The European Union is first and most of all a trade Union, but that does not give the impression that we are not always putting rights at the centre of everything. It is now clear to all citizens, businesses and governments the extent of the Union's power of influence on matters of external trade, international relations and regulation within and outside the Eu ropean Union's borders.  I am convinced that the Eu ropean Union's trade policy must be an instrument for promoting the rights, particularly those of workers, women and children, who very often live in the countries of South-East Asia, for example, where manufacturing has shifted the bulk of its activities, but which are experiencing terrible exploitation.  The responsibility of companies, particularly multinationals, is at the 50-year-long focus of the success of the trade strategy for all. The corporate social responsibility instrument is an effective weapon for informing consumers and encouraging businesses and governments to take more account of the social and environmental aspects of their action.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: " There is only one humane and good sentence in this report— article 17/b. It also says that the guidelines drawn up by the un special rapporteur on the right to food should also be enforced. The only problem with this sentence is that it is totally at odds with all the other sentences and phrases in the report. Indeed, this whole report is about free trade, written in its spirit and in accordance with neoliberal economic principles. This particular UN approach, this is based on food self-determination, the essence of which is that every community, every nation, has the right to make its own food. Land and farmland must remain in the hands of the local community and they can produce their own food, while free trade is about transporting food from one part of the world to another in a completely unrealistic way – generating huge profits while destroying and destroying the environment for local entrepreneurs. So there's a total conflict between the two principles. I, for one, support food agency. But since it was only one sentence, in complete contrast to all the others, I could not vote for the report.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – I am very sorry that I was unable to support this own-initiative report. In doing so, I have long been of the opinion that Europe needs a stronger social pillar. Unfortunately, as is often the case in this House, the Committee on Women's Rights has pushed into the text a call for the policies of both the EU and the Member States to be brought into line with the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. This convention is one of the key instruments for the global liberalisation of abortion. However, social policies are based on solidarity between people, and this is only possible if every human life, even the one not yet born, has absolute value to us.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report and, in particular, how trade agreements can play a significant role in upholding social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility. One of the core issues around trade agreements is what the Commission proposed this afternoon on CETA, the Canadian trade deal. It will come forward with its view as to whether Member States’ parliaments can vote on the deal. Personally, I think it is crucial that Member States have a vote just like we have a vote here in the European Parliament. Otherwise, citizens can legitimately say that there is a democratic deficit. This is a great opportunity for the EU to show its connection to citizens and those they elect to represent them in national parliaments. At a personal level, I would vote against CETA if national parliaments are sidelined. There are other issues, such as ISDS, which I do not support, but above all national parliaments, as well as the European Parliament, must have a role in either accepting or rejecting CETA.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, this report is a good thing: it proposes to introduce the standards of the International Labour Organization into international trade agreements. That's fine! Since we are at this point, I have a suggestion: since the European Treaty prohibits social harmonisation, why, for example, could we not say that all the Member States of the European Union are obliged to sign the conventions of the International Labour Organization? This is of great importance for the future, particularly for the TAFTA agreement that we are preparing, because if we put the standards of the International Labour Organization in our international treaties, then we will be forced to ask the United States of America to ratify the main conventions of the International Labour Organization. You may not know this, but the United States has not signed the agreement on freedom of association and the protection of trade union rights, nor the right to organize and bargain collective, nor the agreement on equal pay for men and women, nor the convention on discrimination, nor the convention on the minimum age of employment. Nor did they sign the one on the rights of the disabled, nor the one on children's rights. I will conclude by saying that, since we have set this goal, we must support the UN initiative to establish environmental and social standards in the treaties to impose on multinationals. We must help - instead of deserting the discussion table, instead of voting against it at the United Nations - Mrs Maria Fernanda Espinosa, who is now in charge of this negotiation, and the President, and I would like to salute the courage of her action and that of the government of Rafael Correa.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in this Parliament we have adopted a motion for a resolution asking for the implementation of the recommendations we already made in 2010 on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate civil liability.  In the European Union, we do not have a regulatory framework on how companies should respect human rights obligations and social and environmental standards. But I believe that we all share that the private sector must contribute, together with the public sector, to sustainable development and that companies must act in a responsible way from all points of view, but fundamentally from a social point of view and also , why not say so - ecologically.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trade policies and market liberalisation have a significant impact on respect for human rights and social and environmental sustainability. There is currently a lack of a single, harmonised regulatory framework that links European companies to the implementation and development of such issues. Trade policy, on the other hand, should be concerned with the protection of workers, respect for gender equality and environmental issues, without prejudice to growth factors. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report, trusting that trade strategies can become an instrument for promoting democratic values at international level.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this because we oppose the politicisation of trade by the EU. Trade should be about trade, and not the EU using its financial muscle to force weaker trade partners into obeying its political ideology.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report deals with the implementation of three previous EP reports with recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate civil liability in union trade agreements with third parties. I voted in favour of it because it certainly points out where the deficits are in Parliament's previous recommendations, while going further and introducing new aspects, in my view, extremely positive and important, such as requiring that the human rights clause in those agreements be binding.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report suggests that the EU's trade strategy serves as a standard for the promotion of certain values. To do so, the agreements signed by the Commission should thereby submit binding clauses to the Union's trading partners, such as: strict respect for human rights, the promotion of human rights (according to the unilateral conception of the Union and regardless of the local cultural context) etc. Although goodwill, this report tends to impose a unique vision of the values to be promoted, which do not always correspond to our view of the world or what multilateral agreements should be. So I abstained.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which calls for legally binding human rights and social and environmental standards in the EU’s international trade agreements. It also calls for human rights impact assessments and sustainability impact assessments to become binding, and further highlights the Commission’s recent decision to rubber-stamp the Vietnam EU free trade agreement without having done so. The resolution further calls for the Commission to act within the World Trade Organisation to promote the setting of enforceable rules for the sustainable management of global supply chains by multinational companies. In addition, it insists that countries signing trade agreements with the EU must also ratify and implement the ILO’s core labour conventions, as well as reasserting the need to maintain and strengthen the role of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) in international trade agreement negotiations. It calls for full transparency in the negotiations, which is still lacking in the ongoing negotiations on agreements such as TTIP and TiSA.  Sinn Féin in Europe are committed to ensuring that social and labour rights are protected and are continuing to fight the implementation of the neoliberal agenda. For Sinn Féin, human rights and social rights must always come before profit.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. Standards for social, environmental and human rights in trade agreements have become a major concern for citizens. Through this report, we underline our unwavering commitment to these standards and call on the European Commission to have a high level of ambition in this area. It is essential that these standards be legally binding on businesses and governments that must take into account the legitimate expectations of civil society.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibilities. The report welcomes the Commission decision to carry out ex ante and ex post sustainability impact assessments (SIAs) and declares that the human rights impact assessments (HRIAs) and the sustainability impact assessment should become binding. The report underlines the importance of human rights conditionality in trade agreements and of respect for, and implementation of, the human rights clauses. The Commission and the Council should promote regular in-depth monitoring of the implementation of the human rights clauses in trade and association agreements, which are also to include chapters on trade and sustainable development. Parliament should also be involved at every stage and actively consulted during the drafting, negotiating and implementation of such agreements. The report underlines the importance of corporate social responsibility (CSR) provisions. In this regard, the Commission should be able to carry out investigations into alleged breaches of CSR commitments. The EU should also actively engage with the UN on an international treaty to hold transnational companies accountable for human rights abuses and the violation of the environmental standards.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility, because all of the above have evolved into issues of major interest to European citizens.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Sustainability and corporate social responsibility is an important issue. I have advocated active support for further WTO reforms to establish multinational rules for the sustainable and responsible management of large supply chains. Among other things, health and safety standards and social protection are to be promoted. In general, the EU and the Member States should also promote the issue of corporate social responsibility in trade agreements.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, in its intentions, aims to impose the same conceptions of human rights on the whole planet through free trade. I agree with some of the wishes expressed in this report but very circumspect about how to mix or even impose free trade, human rights, social and environmental standards. I therefore abstained from voting for or against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst much of the text of this report was unobjectionable, I eventually voted against for two reasons. Firstly, it supports the politicisation of trade. Secondly, it deals with matters which should be the responsibility of the Member States.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to send a strong signal to European businesses. A growing number of them are promoting their social responsibility strategies in response to a series of social, environmental and economic pressures. Companies are investing in their future and hope that their voluntary commitment will help increase profitability. This report encourages them to strengthen their efforts on behalf of their employees, investors, consumers, public authorities and NGOs.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which the EP supports in 2010. parliamentary recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility. The EU has the opportunity to contribute constructively through its trade policies to increase respect for human rights and sustainable development throughout the world. I support the calls on the Commission to ensure coordination of development aid and trade policies and to ensure that all stakeholders comply with international standards in the areas of human rights, gender equality, labour law and the environment.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is on the implementation of parliament's recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility in 2010, submitted by the EP's Committee on International Trade. It is based on a Commission material from 2015, which essentially talked about the need for the Union's trade policy with third countries to promoted the values represented by the Union, such as human rights, labour rights, environmental protection and health improvements. Of course, the aim is also to give EU companies a free access to third-country markets. The report considers it essential to join the OECD Declaration on International Investment and Multinational Enterprises. This material is a typical example of eligible objectives (e.g. human rights and labour law claims) mixed with objectives that promote the interests of multinationals rather than the interests of a wide range of societies. Accordingly, I abstained in the vote.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This document is based on the belief that trade policies must contribute positively to respect for social and environmental standards, and, more generally, to "human rights". Thus, the EU's trade strategy should promote democratic values and interests in third countries, for example by suspending a trade agreement in case of non-compliance with democratic values, or by establishing the free trade of ecological goods in the name of sustainable development.  Under the guise of good intentions, this report is in fact aimed at imposing the same political and social views on the whole planet through free trade. I agree with some of the ideas expressed in this report, but remain circumspect about the desire to impose free trade, human rights and social and environmental standards. So I abstained.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Standards for social, environmental and human rights in trade agreements have become major concerns for citizens. Through this report, the Socialist Group has raised concerns about the level of ambition that the European Union must respect in international agreements. We want to see legally binding and enforceable standards that hold societies and governments to account, taking into account the important views of civil society.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has for decades been committed to promoting a mutual strengthening of trade and human rights, focusing on a series of measures that do not exclude the incentives that the business community itself can offer in the field of promoting democracy, environmental standards and corporate social responsibility. The Forenza report, which I supported with my vote, analyses in full the commitments made by the EU to negotiate, and implement, new measures dedicated to the development of global responsibility, the promotion of social justice, environmental sustainability and respect for human rights. The text gives particular attention to trade policy, which is considered to be one of the main elements for promoting the energy transition, promoting the birth and development of renewable energies and the creation of environmentally friendly goods and technologies. A central element of the proposal is support for provisions laying down conditionality on human rights. Parliament intends to support the Commission and the Council in their efforts to include binding human rights clauses in all future trade and investment agreements.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report which sets out the need to make the human rights clauses of trade treaties binding. Other elements that we have welcomed are the granting to the ILO of official observer status in the WTO. Finally, we consider that the call for all parties to multilateral and bilateral agreements in which the Union is involved to ratify and implement the ILO's Fundamental Conventions can be very much in the context of the TiSA and TTIP negotiations (since the US has not now acceded to these Conventions)

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate civil liability. And I have also supported the call for human rights and sustainability impact assessments to be mandatory and to begin at an early stage in order to take them into account in negotiating positions.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility. Of course, this text has lofty objectives such as the promotion of quality social and environmental standards, values that should be taken more into account by the WTO.  However, I doubt that the liberalisation of markets proposed in this text, by standardising standards in the service of free trade at all costs, is the solution to be considered to meet these objectives. The promotion of these values must not in any way result from a market imperialism of which the European Union would be the armed arm. Once again, the good intentions of European parliamentarians are misguided by their globalist choices.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report being voted on is partisan, unbalanced and i do not agree with it. I believe that in order to tackle issues such as all social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility in today's international trade, we must start from a clear criticism of what is the current model, which is creating inequalities and which, in the face of a process of relocation that creates enormous social damage in the West in crisis of values and work Nor does it contribute to real development in the poorest countries that provide labour to be exploited and an environment towards which no rules of respect and protection are implemented. I did not see this in this text, so I voted against it.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the report. The report highlights an important criticism of the eu's current trade policy, which largely does not respect social and environmental standards. Eu trade sometimes also comes at the expense of fundamental human rights. The report proposes a number of important measures to change this, including the importance of respect ing the ILO's eight basic conventions in all trade agreements.  Here and there, however, the report still contains wordings arguing that trade in itself brings about positive changes (e.g. recital C). I stress that trade can only play a positive role if it is surrounded by a framework that requires respect for social and environmental standards. And since the report essentially emphasises this, I have voted in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In order to be effective, the Socialists believe that trade policy should be another tool for sustainable development and, in order to be effective, must be inescapably linked to objectives that are mandatory and fully enforceable in social, labour, environmental and human rights, holding both governments and businesses accountable. This initiative report gives us a new opportunity to remember that it is the responsibility of all, the public and private sectors, men and women, to ensure that international trade benefits the world's population equally, putting the general interest society ahead of any other objective. That is why I voted for it.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament approves the 2010 parliament's recommendations on the implementation of social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility. Parliament stresses the importance of trade and foreign investment and recalls that trade and foreign direct investment contribute to improving prosperity in poorer countries. It is recommended that the EU's trade strategy should be a tool to promote democratic values in third countries. Member States are advised to step up their efforts to eliminate fossil fuel subsidies and states that trade policy could contribute more to a different energy model. The problem of deforestation is also recalled. The European Parliament calls on the Commission and the Member States to include a gender-based approach in their policies, and calls on the Commission to take gender equality into account in the evaluation of the EU trade strategy.
