Calls also on the EU and the Member States to promote binding measures to ensure that companies pay taxes, and recognises that access to common goods, such as water or health care, is a key aspect of the country's ability to guarantee human and social rights. The Commission is proposed to take measures in the areas of trade and investment that encourage socially responsible businesses by giving them special labels, making it easier to conclude EU public contracts.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trade is a means of promoting European values, which can serve as a social and environmental cord in everyday life. Closer cooperation with the International Labour Organisation is needed in the application of the sustainable development provisions. It will also be necessary to monitor the implementation of the human rights clauses entrewed in the European Union's international treaties, in particular the ban on products created by slave labour and violations of fundamental human rights from European markets. The report relies heavily on the application of the human rights and corporate responsibility proposals in the 2010 Parliamentary Recommendation on Sustainable Development, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. Human rights are universal and must be given to every individual, regardless of their origin and place where they come from. We must strive to respect them in all social and trade processes, international cooperation and beyond. In my opinion, the proposed report raises key issues that call for the strengthening of social responsibility, which is why I supported it. The report states, inter alia, that csr and provisions for investigating alleged breaches of commitments should also be included in all EU trade agreements. We also call for efforts to be enhancing efforts to respect social responsibility and labour standards along entire supply chains. The Commission is also invited to take the initiative to reform the WTO trade policy review mechanisms so that they include social and environmental and human rights aspects. Last but not least, in the report, we also emphasise the importance of more responsible management of supply chains at international level and we call on the Commission to pursue similar programmes and measures with other EU trading partners.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this Report on Social and Environmental Standards, Human Rights and Corporate Responsibility. I believe that the standards of social, environmental and human rights in trade agreements have become of great importance for citizens and cannot be ignored.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims for international business practices to incorporate social and environmental values as well as human rights obligations, particularly those of children.  Health issues would also be taken into account. The report argues that WTO rules should be based on them. While I agree with these good intentions, I am surprised, however, that this report continues to advocate the principle of free trade, which is totally contrary to the intended purpose. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which calls for legally binding human rights and social and environmental standards in the EU’s international trade agreements. It also calls for human rights impact assessments and sustainability impact assessments to become binding, and further highlights the Commission’s recent decision to rubber-stamp the Vietnam EU free trade agreement without having done so. The resolution further calls for the Commission to act within the World Trade Organisation to promote the setting of enforceable rules for the sustainable management of global supply chains by multinational companies. In addition, it insists that countries signing trade agreements with the EU must also ratify and implement the ILO’s core labour conventions, as well as reasserting the need to maintain and strengthen the role of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) in international trade agreement negotiations. It calls for full transparency in the negotiations, which is still lacking in the ongoing negotiations on agreements such as TTIP and TiSA.  Sinn Féin in Europe are committed to ensuring that social and labour rights are protected and are continuing to fight the implementation of the neoliberal agenda. For Sinn Féin, human rights and social rights must always come before profit.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the European Union is about to conclude ambitious trade agreements with a view to a global strengthening of the trading system on common and shared standards, it is desirable that these agreements should take into account the non-monetisable components such as respect for human rights and environmental impact. The European Union is the world's leading reality in the fight against climate change and in the promotion of human rights. Trade policy must be pursued in a healthy and transparent manner, both in accordance with the positions that we Europeans publicly adopt here in Parliament and in accordance with the UN's guiding principles on business and human rights. The European Union must use its trade policy agenda together with all other relevant instruments, including the promotion of corporate social responsibility, which aim to promote human rights provisions in accordance with our fundamental values and in relation to our trade policy: our action to form a freer and fairer world also passes through here.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report defends the idea that the European Union's trade strategy should be a lever to promote democracy, human rights and sustainable development in third countries. In concrete terms, this document recommends the inclusion in the new trade agreements of binding social and environmental clauses. These clauses would therefore require third-country governments to commit to generalizing access to water, health and education for their people.  While we share the desire to restrict tariff concessions to countries that deliberately engage in social, environmental and fiscal dumping, we remain perplexed by the idea of imposing our conception of democracy in third countries in return for trade agreements. On the one hand, the European Union has no legitimacy to interfere in the internal affairs of third countries, on the other hand it is the responsibility of international institutions to protect civilians in states where human rights are violated. That is why I abstained on this subject.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the need to implement all recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility, recommendations made by Parliament to the European Commission in 2010. Stronger action at European level is needed in this sector, bearing in mind that the EU has the capacity to contribute positively to respect for human rights and sustainable development worldwide through its trade policy. At the same time, the link between, on the one hand, trade and human rights and, on the other, social and environmental standards, has become an integral part of the EU's trade and economic relations. I believe that the EU should use its trade policy to set high global standards in the field of human rights and social rights, consumer protection and the environment, which is why I support this report by voting in favour.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU’s trade strategy should be a tool for the promotion of democratic values in third countries. Enhanced trade agreements and trade preference programmes could be used to promote human rights, eliminate forced and child labour, ensure food security and the rights to health, sustainable development, high safety and environmental standards, and economic opportunities. It is important for the EU to build cooperation at a multilateral level. There needs to be a more effective cooperation and regular dialogue between the WTO and the relevant UN agencies and WTO trade policy review mechanisms need to be reformed to include the social, environmental and HR dimensions.  Therefore, I voted in favour of this report that will set human rights, environmental and social standards at both a unilateral and bilateral level. Member States should actively promote responsible business conduct among EU companies operating abroad. By accounting for the impact of trade and investment agreements on vulnerable people and by using trade policy to encourage EU partner countries to adopt higher social and environmental standards, the EU will set a global standard to protect human rights, society and the environment.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility. The aim is to strengthen the coherence between development aid policies in third countries and the european Union's trade policy. Trade and direct investment abroad promote the prosperity of these countries. The EU's trade strategy must be an instrument for promoting European values around the world. However, the current clauses have a limited impact on compliance with human rights obligations. I am inordies to strengthen the system with the integration of a 'Corporate Social Responsibility' component into multilateral trade policies.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility because, now more than ever, we need policies that reconcile economic and social and environmental objectives with a view to future sustainability. A company is socially responsible whenever it equips itself with approaches and tools to integrate environmental, ethical, respect for human rights and consumer rights into its management, with the dual objective of maximising the creation of shared value with the operators concerned and preventing or mitigating the negative impacts of its business.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which calls for legally binding human rights and social and environmental standards in the EU’s international trade agreements. It also calls for human rights impact assessments and sustainability impact assessments to become binding and highlights the Commission’s recent decision to rubber-stamp the Vietnam EU free trade agreement without having done so. The resolution calls for the Commission to act within the World Trade Organisation to promote the setting of enforceable rules for the sustainable management of global supply chains by multinational companies. In addition, it insists that countries signing trade agreements with the EU must also ratify and implement the ILO’s core labour conventions, as well as reasserting the need to maintain and strengthen the role of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) in international trade agreement negotiations. It calls for full transparency in the negotiations, which is still lacking in the ongoing negotiations on agreements such as TTIP and TiSA. Sinn Féin are committed to ensuring that social and labour rights are protected and for these reasons I voted in favour.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report that stresses how trade and foreign investment can have a positive impact on economic growth, human rights and environmental protection and can be used to influence these crucial issues. After analysing the implementation of the 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility in trade policy, the rapporteur brought up aspects that need further progress. Trade agreements should incorporate gender equality and greater coherence with development aid. I believe that better trade policies are for the benefit of sustainable development and social stability.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report calling on the Commission and the Council to take greater account of objectives such as the protection of human rights, the promotion of high environmental standards and sustainable development in the union's trade policy. In fact, with the amendments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, all the objectives of the Union's external policies are set out in Article 21 TEU, which imposes an obligation of coherence and synergy in the implementation of the various policies. Therefore, in implementing the Union's trade policy, we cannot ignore other objectives such as those mentioned above and it is appropriate for the Commission and the Council to act in accordance with the provisions of the Treaties.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. – We support the report and call on the Commission and the Member States to integrate a gender-based approach into all their policies, including EU trade policy, and to ensure, inter alia, effective compliance with the UNITED NATIONS Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW).

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility is another reminder of the obligation to respect the rules governing European society. I think it is a useful report and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on 'social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility' because I believe that the Eu ropean Union's trade policy can boost social progress, the quality of life and can contribute to improving human rights protection. I also believe that trade agreements have a strong impact on the protection of human rights and sustainable development.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with this proposal, which is simply intended to assess the progress made by the European Union in recent years. In fact, good results have been achieved in the field of sustainable development and environmental protection during this period, but there is still a lot of work to be done. In my opinion, the European Union should play an important role in achieving the objectives set out in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. I am also convinced that the Commission's decision to carry out impact assessments on sustainability and human rights, both before and after, for trade agreements must become binding so that the Eu ropean Union can constantly have up-to-date data on the development of these two factors. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report and had no objections to it.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In November 2010, the European Parliament adopted a set of recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility, in two reports focusing on respect for these dimensions in trade policy and the conclusion of trade agreements. I acknowledge that important steps have been taken in these years, recalling the adoption of the Generalised System of Preferences (GSP and GSP+) or the consideration of sustainable development and human rights objectives in the Commission's Trade for All Strategy. I believe that trade policy is an instrument for promoting the values of the European Union and therefore must safeguard respect for social and environmental standards, as well as combating human rights violations such as slavery or forced labour. I follow the concern to place these issues in the Union's multilateral and bilateral international relations, in particular in the negotiations of trade partnerships. I underline the need to fully implement the 2010 recommendations, adapting them to the reality of 2016, in an effort that the Commission has been leading. I agree with the appreciation of corporate social responsibility in this context. From the foregoing, I support the report.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ By linking trade, human rights and social and environmental standards the EU sends a clear message embracing social corporate responsibility that reflects a holistic approach that understands the role of businesses within the community. While all businesses must act responsibly, socially, environmentally and economically, one has to distinguish between the rules applicable to small businesses and SMEs and multinational corporations. Setting targets for SMEs, such as corporate responsibility all along the supply chain, would jeopardise their development through measures that are too cumbersome for their structures to withstand.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report deals with the implementation of three previous EP reports with recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate civil liability in union trade agreements with third parties. I voted in favour of it because it certainly points out where the deficits are in Parliament's previous recommendations, while going further and introducing new aspects, in my view, extremely positive and important, such as requiring that the human rights clause in those agreements be binding.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trade plays an important role in promoting trade opportunities, creating prosperity, increasing employment and boosting economic and social development. The EU has always been committed to sustainable development through its trade policy, as reaffirmed in the Commission's 'Trade for All' strategy. I support this resolution because it highlights two important factors. The first, on strengthening respect for social and environmental issues within the European market, reiterates the need for Member States to promote binding measures to ensure that companies pay taxes where economic activities take place and to promote good governance in the tax field, as well as effective tax collection. In fact, a company's tax policy is an integral part of corporate social responsibility, and strategies for tax avoidance or the exploitation of tax havens are incompatible with socially responsible behaviour and the sustainable development of the European market. The second factor concerns the EU's role in trade relations with third countries. European trade policy in third countries and cooperation at multilateral level must take account of respect for human rights, the environment and democratic principles as key elements of corporate social responsibility.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In 2010, the European Parliament adopted resolutions on human rights and social and environmental standards in international trade agreements, as well as on international trade policy in the context of overarching climate change needs, as well as on corporate social responsibility in international trade agreements. In these resolutions, Parliament called for the future EU trade strategy to become an instrument for a more responsible fair trade that can guarantee the effective inclusion and implementation of social and environmental standards. This report looks at what has been achieved so far and sets out new objectives in terms of the conditions needed to respect human rights and legally binding provisions in the chapters of trade agreements on development. Unfortunately, I do not support this approach. I believe that trade can promote human rights in the long term. A engagement strategy should be involved in which trading partners commit themselves to improving the human rights situation, and therefore the trade agreement becomes a tool in which monitoring and implementation are essential elements. In view of the above, I voted against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it outlines valid factors which are important in the implementation of social and environmental standards and human rights, and for ensuring corporate responsibility. Business and trade should incorporate a gender-mainstreaming approach, as they can play a pivotal role in promoting gender equality. We need greater coherence with respect to development, to really and truly have a sustainable environment. The EU’s trade strategy can also be a tool for the promotion of democratic values in third countries. Trade and human rights reinforce one another and our strategy may also have an important role to play in offering positive incentives in terms of promoting human rights, democracy, environmental standards and corporate responsibility.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today the European Parliament adopted a resolution on the implementation of the recommendations addressed to the Commission in 2010 on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility, thus taking a very specific position on extremely important aspects of the European Union's trade policy. This resolution calls on the Commission to step up its efforts to ensure that all trade agreements being negotiated or renewed between the EU and third countries have as their priority sustainable development and the safeguarding of high environmental and social standards. This means, in fact, that in the definition of trade treaties with countries outside the Union, the Commission cannot ignore the inclusion of clauses relating to corporate social responsibility, as well as provisions that promote gender equality and also allow international environmental commitments to be respected. Indeed, I firmly believe that a fair and equitable international trade system must be based on respect for the fundamental rights recognised by the international community. For these reasons, I wholeheartedly supported the resolution.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to analyze the implementation of social and environmental standards and corporate social responsibility (CSR) in trade negotiations.  It outlines the main progress made in this area and recalls the need for closer cooperation with the International Labour Organization (ILO), but also to monitor and enforce the corporate social responsibility (CSR) clauses on human rights and sustainable development in international agreements.  Considering that European trade policy must also respect the environmental, human and social interests of the European Union, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this because we oppose the politicisation of trade by the EU. Trade should be about trade, and not the EU using its financial muscle to force weaker trade partners into obeying its political ideology.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which refers to the implementation of the recommendations made in 2010 by the European Parliament on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility in the framework of European trade policy. It was particularly important in this report to recall the role of trade and foreign investment in promoting economic growth, good governance and the protection of human rights. Indeed, trade remains an undeniable tool for promoting our values in the world.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trade is a means of promoting European values, which can serve as a social and environmental cord in everyday life. Closer cooperation with the International Labour Organisation is needed in the application of the sustainable development provisions. It will also be necessary to apply the human rights clauses ens in the International Treaties of the European Union and to monitor the implementation of the legislation, in particular to ban products created by slave labour and violations of fundamental human rights from European markets. The report relies heavily on the application of the human rights and corporate responsibility proposals in the 2010 Parliamentary Recommendation on Sustainable Development, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendations to promote social human rights policies and respect for the environment by businesses. This includes support for equal opportunities, social inclusion and a sustainable economy. The recommendations promote transparency and reliable accountability mechanisms and play an important role in preventing corruption within the EU. They also provide for coordination with other international organisations, such as the OECD, the ILO and the WTO.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Union, the world's largest trading power, accounts for 16.5% of total world imports and exports. The link between trade and sustainable development requires us to put trade at the service of development. The rules governing trade, both at European and global level, must integrate social and environmental standards, corporate social and environmental responsibility, and human rights.  Improvements must therefore be made to the Union's trade policy. At the bilateral level, during trade agreement negotiations, the EU must ensure that sustainable development provisions are strengthened, that ex-ante and ex-post impact assessments are systematized, and that corrective measures are applied in the event of non-compliance with human rights by its partners. At the multilateral level, there is a need for greater synergy between the work of the WTO (World Trade Organization), the ILO (International Labour Organization) and COP 21.  In general, the EU's trade policy should encourage European companies to act socially and environmentally responsibly, both in the countries where they operate and in those in which they source.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. According to this text, WTO trade policies must contribute positively, through legally binding clauses, to the promotion of human rights, social and environmental standards, the right to health, education and protection of children, access to water and sustainable development in third countries. The report provides for the possibility of legal action with sanctions against violators, a trade agreement that can be suspended if necessary. It also seeks to ensure that multinationals are taxed where economic activities take place. By good intentions, the report aims to impose a certain conception of human rights on the whole planet through free trade. I therefore preferred to abstain on this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report implementing the 2010 recommendations of the European Parliament on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility, as in my opinion the application of conditions in trade agreements will not instantly reduce cases of human rights violations, but rather will have negative consequences on trade and business.  The measures we take should not harm trade and businesses, because it is poverty and low standards of living that are most often the main cause of the poor human rights situation in the country. I am of the opinion that trade can promote respect for human rights in the long term and it is essential that we demand commitment from trading partners to improve the human rights situation.  Achieving a good level of respect for human rights is a long-term problem and that is why it is important to have sufficiently good mechanisms to monitor and assess countries where there are concerns that human rights are being violated.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union's trade relations must serve the economic and political interests of the Member States and European citizens and not the 'democratic values' as perceived by the Union's leading circles. Interventionism and economic blackmail cannot be regarded as "values" in 2016. The resolution is in complete disharmony with reality and is characterised by Marxist conceptions of international relations and trade.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trade is a means of promoting European values, which can serve as a social and environmental cord in everyday life. Closer cooperation with the International Labour Organisation is needed in the application of the sustainable development provisions. It will also be necessary to apply the human rights clauses ens in the International Treaties of the European Union and to monitor the implementation of the legislation, in particular to ban products created by slave labour and violations of fundamental human rights from European markets. The report relies heavily on the application of the human rights and corporate responsibility proposals in the 2010 Parliamentary Recommendation on Sustainable Development, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as several of the suggested proposals are positive. Environmental protection is a very important issue to my constituents in Wales, and I recognise that our priority is to strengthen the guarantees in trade and sustainable development chapters.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's trade policies should aim to achieve greater prosperity, equality and social progress for all, and this excellent report by the 5 Star Movement is a step in the right direction. The report insists on the need to have a more transparent, accountable and effective trade policy, which will primarily protection small and medium-sized enterprises and farmers, with agreements that bring tangible benefits to citizens and that are in harmony with the sustainable development goals that this planet needs. I voted in favour.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Trade plays an important role in promoting business opportunities, creating prosperity and increasing employment, as well as boosting economic development, social progress, living standards, quality of life and the long-term improvement of human rights standards. Member States should therefore promote binding measures to ensure that companies pay taxes where they carry out their economic activity and create value, promote mandatory information about each country by the private sector and boost good governance, in particular in relation to tax issues and tax collection. I also agree with greater transparency and accountability of the basic organisations in formulating international trade rules and national trade policies, while ensuring consistency with respect for workers' rights and human rights, including women's rights.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention: agree with some of the wishes expressed in this report but very circumspect on how to mix or even impose free trade, human rights, social and environmental standards.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We fully support the spirit of this INI report aimed at empowering the Council and the Commission in the field of trade policy, from the point of view of greater attention to sensitive issues, such as human rights, sustainable development, access to the commons and corporate social responsibility. Particularly important, in this context, is the call, addressed to both the EU institutions and the Member States, to promote binding measures to ensure that companies pay taxes in the place where economic activities take place and the value is created and, consequently, to promote mandatory 'country by country' reporting.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We value the rapporteur's efforts in the preparation of this report, in particular when it underlines the absolute need for respect for and appreciation of labour rights and conditions, as well as the role of the International Labour Organisation. But beyond the recommendations that may emanated from this Plenary - some positive, some negative and some still very negative - it is important not to lose sight of the essentials. So-called social responsibility unadidly clashes with the interests of large economic and financial groups, the promotion of the relocation of companies and labour and social dumping, the attacks on collective bargaining and trade unions, the exploitation of resources and workers in third countries, digging social and gender discrimination. It will not be EU trade policy that reverses this reality. On the contrary, it will only tend to aggravate it. The need to repeal the Treaty of Lisbon and to reverse its trade policy provisions is well demonstrated. It should be up to each country to define its trade policies and agreements, in a sovereign manner and in accordance with its interests and needs.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as I believe it is important and very beneficial for international treaties to incorporate environmental, social and human rights clauses, in line with the Trade for all strategy. I believe that trade treaties are also a good tool for promoting European values and to help raise both social and environmental standards globally. This needs to be done through specific clauses and not as an ex post exchange of information, as was common in previous trade agreements.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because I believe that the EU's human rights policy should continue to be integrated into other EU policies with an external dimension, including trade policy. Therefore, the EU should use trade policy to promote the objective of setting high global standards on human and social rights, consumer protection and environmental issues.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE)
text: Written. We Moderates voted today in favour of the report on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility in trade policy. Eu trade policy shall be conducted in such a way as to promote sustainability, human rights and poverty reduction. It is also something to which current trade policy contributes. On the other hand, it goes without saying that tax policy is an issue to be decided at national level - we do not therefore support the requirement for corporate taxation to take place where economic activity takes place, because it risks preventing countries from deciding for themselves how to levy company tax.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution explicitly includes the need for the EU to make it legally binding that international trade agreements must respect human rights so I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Already in 2010, the European Parliament issued a recommendation to the European Commission on social and environmental standards for human rights and corporate social responsibility. However, some of these recommendations have not yet been implemented. There is still a lack of a regulatory framework on how businesses comply with human rights obligations in relation to social and environmental standards. Businesses must act in a socially and environmentally responsible manner, because the link between trade and the rights in question has gradually become an integral part of the European Union's economic and trade relations.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because it does not criticise the current economic model that is creating inequalities and does not create development in the poorest countries.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union's trade relations must serve the economic and political interests of the Member States and European citizens and not the 'democratic values' as perceived by the Union's leading circles.  Interventionism and economic blackmail cannot be regarded as 'values' in 2016. The resolution is in complete disharmony with reality and is characterised by Marxist conceptions of international relations and trade. For the above reasons I am voting against the report.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is an own-initiative report on implementation of the 2010 recommendations of Parliament on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility, which among other things, calls on the Commission to urge for a reform of WTO governance, incorporate a gender-sensitive approach, include effective HR clauses in trade agreements, and further involve the EP in decision-making. I support the call for ambitious Trade and Sustainable Development chapters in all trade agreements; for binding corporate social and responsibility standards, focusing on ‘enforcement’ mechanisms; to see Civil Society Organisations and Social Partners formally involved in the monitoring process; and to support a gender-sensitive approach to trade. Social, environmental and human rights standards in trade agreements have become of major concern to citizens. This report has raised concerns about the level of ambition the EU has to uphold these. We want to see legally binding and enforceable standards to hold corporations and governments to account, taking on board the important views of civil society.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trade is a means of promoting European values, which can serve as a social and environmental cord in everyday life. Closer cooperation with the International Labour Organisation is needed in the application of the sustainable development provisions. It will also be necessary to apply the human rights clauses ens in the International Treaties of the European Union and to monitor the implementation of the legislation, in particular to ban products created by slave labour and violations of fundamental human rights from European markets. The report relies heavily on the application of the human rights and corporate responsibility proposals in the 2010 Parliamentary Recommendation on Sustainable Development, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of Mrs Forenza's report, as gender mainstreaming and the prevention of tax evasion by multinationals must be integrated into all our policies, including the EU trade strategy. Effective compliance with the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW) should be guaranteed. The report calls on the Commission to take gender issues into account in the impact assessment of the EU trade strategy for women's rights and calls on the Commission to systematically assess existing trade and investment agreements in order to identify the impact on gender equality. It should be pointed out that the report highlights the role of trade and foreign direct investment in increasing prosperity in poorer countries. In the context of the EU's trade strategy, it is also important to properly tax companies to pay taxes where economic activities take place and value is generated, and to support the private sector's reporting obligations by country. The tax policy of multinationals should be seen as part of CSR and the exploitation of tax avoidance or the opportunities offered by tax havens is not compatible with socially responsible behaviour.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report convinced that we must continue to ensure that companies maintain and improve social and environmental standards, human rights and civil liability. This means achieving effective taxation in the countries in which they carry out their economic activity, the inclusion of human and environmental rights clauses in trade agreements, etc. The Union can and should contribute, together with civil society and businesses, to improving the living conditions of millions of people, not in the Union but around the world.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the report on 'Social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility'. As a social and human rights expert, I generally welcome corporate social responsibility measures that strengthen values in the economy. However, it must be clear: CSR cannot be enforced by anyone, it must remain voluntary – only then can it become a signpost for value-oriented development. The report sets the wrong tone here.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the implementation of Parliament's recommendation on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility. Trade can be used as an instrument to apply European social and environmental standards. The regulation also contains an EU ban on imports of goods produced in violation of basic human rights standards by modern forms of slavery and forced labour.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for swift and full integration of refugees into the labour market and for their social inclusion in accordance with the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination. The report calls for a much-needed European approach to address key issues such as access to education and training, non-discrimination, health care, labour and social protection, and the recognition and validation of skills and qualifications. A key aspect of any strategy is ensuring that families are able to be reunified and that the situation of vulnerable groups (particularly those with disabilities, women and children, and especially unaccompanied children) is addressed. Human dignity of refugees must be at centre of any strategy – and they must be allowed to gain economic independence and significantly contribute to their successful integration into the host societies. This report addresses many of these aspects, and along with my Labour colleagues I voted in favour of it.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report which sets out the need to make the human rights clauses of trade treaties binding. Other elements that we have welcomed are the granting to the ILO of official observer status in the WTO. Finally, we consider that the call for all parties to multilateral and bilateral agreements in which the Union is involved to ratify and implement the ILO's Fundamental Conventions can be very much in the context of the TiSA and TTIP negotiations (since the US has not now acceded to these Conventions)

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour this report which is fully in line with the Labour Party and trade unions’ positions, and calls for the Commission to reform WTO governance – including a gender-sensitive approach and human rights clauses in trade agreements. It further endorses the ITUC’s priorities for the responsible management of global supply chains, and calls for giving a formal role to trade unions in the GSP regulation.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. It insists that countries signing trade agreements with the EU must also ratify and implement the International Labour Organisation’s core labour conventions, as well as reasserting the need to maintain and strengthen the role of the ILO in international trade agreement negotiations. The report sends a strong message that the European Parliament calls for legally binding human rights and social and environmental standards in the EU’s international trade agreements

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Closer cooperation with the International Labour Organisation is needed in the application of the sustainable development provisions. It is also necessary to monitor the application of the human rights clauses entresed in the International Treaties of the European Union, in particular the ban on products created by slave labour and violations of fundamental human rights from european markets. The report relies heavily on the application of the human rights and corporate responsibility proposals in the 2010 Parliamentary Recommendation on Sustainable Development.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report explicitly lists the need to make the obligation legally binding when the EU concludes international trade agreements to respect human rights, which must be universal and constantly monitored.  It also calls for the ongoing trade negotiations with EU partners, in particular those relating to the TT IP, to ensure that a legally binding human rights clause is incorporated into the agreements.  The report also recalls the proposal to grant the International Labour Organisation, the status of official observer to the World Trade Organisation and the creation of a Committee on Trade and Decent Work. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I had no objections to the final approach taken.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trade is a means of promoting European values, which can serve as a social and environmental cord in everyday life. Closer cooperation with the International Labour Organisation is needed in the application of the sustainable development provisions. It will also be necessary to apply the human rights clauses ens in the International Treaties of the European Union and to monitor the implementation of the legislation, in particular to ban products created by slave labour and violations of fundamental human rights from European markets. The report relies heavily on the application of the human rights and corporate responsibility proposals in the 2010 Parliamentary Recommendation on Sustainable Development, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As longstanding European Parliament Rapporteur on Corporate Social Responsibility, I welcome this report and am grateful for support for my own amendments referencing the framework of the International Integrated Reporting Council, towards the EU itself adhering to the OECD Declaration on International Investment and Multinational Enterprise and reiterating our call for the EU to engage constructively in the UN Working Group for a treaty process on business and human rights. In this debate, I draw attention as well to the importance of the ‘Compass’ which is enabling business to measure its contribution to the UN Sustainable Development Goals and to the Long-term Investment project being undertaken by the UN Principles for Responsible Investment. I particularly welcome support for the concept of a ‘Sustainable Capital Markets Union’. As I said to a recent meeting of the European Social Investment Forum on this subject which we hosted in the European Parliament, investors are the key to long-term value creation so that European business can itself be sustainable.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU has done important work in the fields of social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility. This report notes however that there is still much to do. It is a pity that the UK has voted to exempt itself from future progress, as the rightward drift of Westminster politics is unlikely to keep up with the EU. This is yet another reason why it is essential for Scotland to retain its place in Europe.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe it is important to see legally binding and enforceable standards to hold corporations and governments to account, taking on board the important views of civil society.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for Parliament's 2010 Report on the Implementation of Parliament's Recommendations on Social and Environmental Standards, Human Rights and Corporate Responsibility, as there is still no regulatory framework for compliance with human rights obligations in corporations in relation to social and environmental standards. The private sector, as well as the public sector, must contribute to sustainable development and act in a socially and environmentally responsible manner. Furthermore, this report promotes gender balance and aims to ensure effective compliance with the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW). With its trade policy, the EU has the opportunity to contribute positively to greater respect for human rights and sustainable development globally, so I stand by this report with my voice.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, in its intentions, aims to impose the same conceptions of human rights on the whole planet through free trade. All my colleagues in the ENL Group and I agree with some of the wishes expressed in this report but very cautious about how to mix, or even impose, free trade, human rights and social and environmental standards. That's why I abstained from this vote.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trade is clearly an important EU instrument to ensure cooperation with third countries and promote democratic values, be they environmental issues, human rights or corporate responsibility. Trade has great potential for the EU, which unfortunately is still not being sufficiently exploited. I therefore supported the report, which analyses the progress made by the Commission in implementing such standards and comes up with new recommendations. The aim is to balance economic diplomacy with the removal of trade barriers, to ensure greater cooperation between development support and trade policy, to promote binding measures to ensure that firms pay taxes in the country where trade takes place. At the same time, this report points out that trade policy deserves to be an EU priority.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Eleonora Forenza's report on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility. The report assesses the progress of these standards in EU policy and trade negotiations. As trade is by extension an instrument for the promotion of European values, the text proposes to adopt an open approach and to follow up through transparent verifications, in order to discourage modern forms of slavery or forced labour. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Forenza report on 'Social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate civil liability' assesses the implementation of the European Parliament's recommendations adopted in 2010. It reiterates important issues to be taken into account in the Union's trade policy: respect for human rights, gender equality, environmental protection and sustainable development, defence of labour rights and eradication of child labour. It also recognizes the right to access to water, health care and peoples' education, promotes the elimination of fossil fuel subsidies, is committed to energy transition and renewable energy development, and requires rigorous compliance with corporate civil liability. That is why EH Bildu supports the report, and voted in favour despite the doubts that mentions may raise that foreign trade and investment increase the prosperity of poorer countries and are essential for economic growth, sustainable development, good governance and the protection of human rights. The experience of the current business model shows us that reality is not that and, it is essential and urgent to implement the recommendations made in the report.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the recommendations of Parliament, which in November 2010 had voted on two initiative reports on "Human Rights and Social and Environmental Standards in International Trade" and "Corporate Social Responsibility in International Trade Agreements". The Forenza report reflects the Commission's efforts to best include these references and implement the recommendations of the 2010 reports, as shown by the new standards in trade agreements.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 We must recognise the Commission's adoption of the key guidelines proposed by the European Parliament in relation to social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility. However, much still needs to be done, particularly with regard to issues relating to women's industrial relations and the crucial issue of child labour. The EU must not show that it has low standards on these issues when concluding trade relations with external partners. Parliament, as co-legislator of international trade relations, will continue to be the guardian of these social requirements.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report on the implementation of Parliament's recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility has, in principle, supportive objectives such as promoting sustainable development, improving working conditions and increasing efforts in the field of environmental protection. However, the explicit call for the Commission to include a gender mainstreaming approach in all policies, including trade policy, is problematic. That is why I am abstaining on the report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it calls on the Commission to urge for a reform of WTO governance, incorporate a gender-sensitive approach, include effective human rights clauses in trade agreements, and further involve the European Parliament in decision-making.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I was very happy to support the report on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility. I think it is important that the European Parliament really scrutiny of the Commission's activities (especially the current one) and, even years later, make sure that the Commission acts as it should. In particular, I appreciated that the report recognises that universal access to public goods such as water, health and education are essential elements that demonstrate a Member State's capacity to respect human rights and ensure social law. The Commission should recognise that this is the way to make the lives of EU citizens better, not its directives and quotas.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is a report of the utmost importance, which promotes the anthropocentric, social and environmental approach to European trade policy.  The Commission and the Member States are invited to work to ensure that all parties to trade agreements comply with international standards on human rights, gender equality, labour law and respect for the environment. These guarantees can also be decisive for the outcome of the TTIR negotiations. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Who would not support the promotion of workers' rights, gender equality, the enforcement of strict social and environmental standards and the elimination of child labour in partner countries. Or who wouldn't support companies paying taxes where their actual economic activity is going and the value is created. It's all well and good. It would be if, once again, elements that were not in the interests of a wide range of societies, but only those of multinationals, were not woven into the material.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility. I believe that all Member States need to include a gender mainstreaming approach in all their policies. There are already benefits of efforts to improve social and environmental issues in the framework of EU trade diplomacy. All this increases trade and foreign direct investment, which affect well-being in poorer countries. And greater well-being also leads to better protection of human rights, social and employee rights, as well as environmental protection, which cannot in any case be ignored. A stricter policy must be put in place to monitor the implementation of human rights clauses and factors affecting trade in environmental goods. An example is anti-dumping policies in the renewable energy sector, intellectual property regimes, restrictive funding programmes and national environmental policies that create demand for such goods.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote, Parliament recognises that the link between trade and human rights, on the one hand, and social and environmental standards, on the other, has become an integral part of the European Union's economic and trade relations. That is why we call on the Commission to ensure greater coherence with regard to development, to ensure effective policy assessment and effective coordination between development aid policy and trade policy. It is essential for us that the Commission also works to ensure that all parties concerned comply with international standards on human rights, gender equality, labour law and respect for the environment. In addition, we call on the EU and the Member States to take binding measures to ensure that companies pay taxes in the place where economic activities take place and value is created. We also call for mandatory 'country-by-country' reporting by the private sector, and for good governance, particularly in the area of taxation, as well as effective tax collection.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the initiative proposal to analyse the implementation of social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibilities in the field of trade and policy. The report is based on a report previously adopted by Parliament on social and environmental standards, human rights in international trade and corporate social responsibility in international trade agreements. Although there is still much to work on, the report acknowledges the Commission's efforts to call on trading partners to introduce the aforementioned references into trade treaties. It also presents a series of recommendations and proposals aimed at implementing the established rules for an overall improvement of the system, to preserve the environment and protect human rights.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the report on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility. The main thesis of this paper is that trade policies must contribute positively to human rights, social and environmental standards. According to the report, the EU's trade strategy should be a tool to promote democratic values and interests in third countries, a lever to promote human rights, the right to health, child labour, sustainable development and environmental standards. This text, in order to serve good intentions, aims to impose the same conceptions of human rights throughout the world through free trade. We agree with some of the wishes expressed in this report but very circumspect about how to mix or even impose free trade, human rights, social and environmental standards.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of the text is to introduce a social and environmental dimension into trade policies. Values such as human rights, democracy and sustainable development should be defended by the Commission in the WTO (World Trade Organization) agreements, as well as in free trade treaties. Although the defence of these values is positive, the rapporteur tends to impose on all the countries of the world a truly Western vision of values, including the dogmatism of free trade. I abstained.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. 'As an N-VA delegation, we abstain from the resolution on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility.  Better respect for human rights does indeed contribute to a democratic, peaceful and safe international environment. Trade, as the EU's exclusive competence, plays an important lever in this. Trade agreements can have a positive impact on human rights. N-VA therefore believes that free trade can serve as a tool to promote human rights in the long term.  However, trade agreements should not be confused with human rights agreements. They are primarily there to stimulate trade and investment. Trade agreements must be negotiated in such a way as to give partners incentives to make sustainable commitments themselves on the improvement of human rights. We therefore cannot support the demand to impose binding, conditional human rights clauses for all future or ongoing trade negotiations. If it were found that trading partners are involved in a conflict or that they are violating human rights on a large scale, it is important to proceed carefully, to evaluate file by file and, if necessary, to intervene.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because I believe it is essential to establish mandatory traceability systems, which allow companies of all sizes and throughout the production chain and, at the end of the process, the consumer to obtain sufficient information to be able to assume their share of responsibility. But the first responsibility must lie with governments, as guarantors of the well-being of their population, and large multinationals, for the obvious impact of their activity.  The report calls on the Commission to: take the lead in the reform of the World Trade Organization (WTO), strengthen its legitimacy and enable more effective and more coherent global trade regulation with sustainable development goals, with responsible and sustainable management of global production chains; ensure the mainstreaming of the gender perspective into trade policy; include in all trade agreements strong regulations on corporate social responsibility and human rights, with ambitious, binding and fully enforceable chapters on Trade and Sustainable Rights; It also calls for the strengthening of parliamentary participation and civil society in all trade negotiations, promoting these objectives within and outside our borders.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report deals with the implementation of three previous EP reports with recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate civil liability in union trade agreements with third parties. I voted in favour of it because it certainly points out where the deficits are in Parliament's previous recommendations, while going further and introducing new aspects, in my view, extremely positive and important, such as requiring that the human rights clause in those agreements be binding.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. Trade plays an essential role in promoting job opportunities, social development and economic progress, it is important that companies find support in the Union to carry out their activities safely. Trade and investment agreements have direct implications for human rights and sustainable development, and therefore must be designed to be a reflection of European standards. This is reflected in the 'Trade for All' strategy in which the link between them has finally been established, and therefore the need for action by the European Union to assist its citizens has been crystallized. Since the European Parliament made some recommendations to the Commission, some of which were not implemented, and because there are still companies established within the borders of the Union which do not respect human rights, I vote in favour of this report which calls on the Commission to have the highest level of ambition.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as trade is a vehicle for bringing European values into general practice. This report calls for a ban on the importing of goods produced through slavery or forced labour into the EU. It recognises the importance of sustainable development and standards that must be maintained in future trade agreements.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ With its trade policy, investment and trade agreements, the EU can contribute positively to greater respect for human rights and sustainable development globally. The EU trade strategy can be a tool to promote democratic values in third countries, leverage to promote human rights, ban forced labour and ensure food safety and health rights, sustainable development and respect for high environmental standards.  The report considers it essential to continue to respect the OECD Declaration on International Investment and Multinationals, ensuring that guidance in all new AGREEMENTS between the EU and third countries implies an active approach in tackling the problem. Member States must engage in the work of the UN Human Rights Council and the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) in maintaining transnational corporate accountability, in protecting human rights and environmental standards.  As the EU is the world's leading actor in terms of national corporate social responsibility action plans, I consider it necessary to ensure transparency in access to corporate responsibility information, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the report which called on the EU and the Member States to promote binding measures to ensure that companies pay taxes where economic activities take place and value is created, to promote compulsory country-by-country reporting by the private sector as recommended by the OECD, and to promote good governance notably in tax matters and effective tax collection.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the Report on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 4/7/2016, and because this Report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. This document is about WTO trade negotiations. The European Union would like to see social and environmental criteria introduced, which could thus be imposed on third countries. If so, these criteria could be suspensive for any trade agreement with a third state that does not respect all or part of it.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – Regarding the report on implementation of the 2010 recommendations of Parliament on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility, I voted in favour, as the implementation of the recommendations will stimulate economic growth, enhance living quality, and improve the human rights standards in a long-term perspective. The promotion of further reforms of the WTO will sustain the management of global supply chains at the same time. The implementation of the recommendations will be beneficial to the European Union certainly.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The Forenza report follows a series of recommendations made in 2010 by the European Parliament. At the time, parliamentarians - very concrete proposals to support it - called on the European Commission to adopt a trade policy that promotes the protection of workers rather than the race for dumping. Unfortunately, the European Commission has not taken these recommendations into account, hence the need, six years later, to make even more pressing requests.  In the Forenza report, which I amended, we call on the European Commission to systematically include binding chapters on sustainable development, which condition the introduction of trade preferences on the parties' compliance with their human rights commitments. This is an important clarification: the economic partnership agreements currently being negotiated with Africa do not contain such chapters. We also urge European negotiators to demand ratification of the fundamental conventions of the International Labour Organization (ILO) by their trading partners: Canada has not done so, despite the CETA agreement. I therefore voted in favour of this report - which lays the foundations for a new globalisation - but hope that this Parliament will be able to show consistency on these issues.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In general, this is the importance of trade and foreign direct investment for the protection of human rights. Some sensible considerations are being made, but the proposal is so distorted by demands in the area of gender mainstreaming that I finally had to abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. I agree with some of the wishes expressed in this report but very circumspect about how to mix, or even impose, free trade, human rights, social and environmental standards. So I abstained.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report in recognition of the importance of human rights oriented approaches to economic and environmental practices and policy. In adopting this report, we move towards a more equal society in both the economic and social environments.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Union is the world's leading power and enjoys extraordinary soft power. International trade is one of its pillars. In this context, the European Parliament encourages the Commission to include in its trade strategy the desire to strengthen respect for human rights, and to defend social and environmental standards. The European Union and the Member States are not the only players. As the report stresses, the responsibility of companies in implementing these priorities should not be underestimated. To this end, the report once again calls on the Commission to include corporate social responsibility in EU trade agreements.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development recognises the fundamental impact of trade policies in meeting the targets, as it covers a number of policy areas, such as rules of origin, food regulation, commodity markets and gender equality. The link between trade, human rights and social and environmental standards has become an integral part of the Union's economic and trade relations, as human rights and democracy policy in third countries should continue to be integrated into other Union policies with an external dimension, including trade policy. I believe that the Union should use trade policy to support the objective of setting high global standards in the areas of human and social rights, consumer protection and environmental issues. I therefore appreciate the strengthening of trade agreements and programmes relating to trade preferences as instruments for promoting human rights, eliminating forced and child labour, ensuring food security and the right to health, sustainable development and high safety environmental standards, as well as economic opportunities for all. The Union is also a major global actor in national action plans for corporate social responsibility, and it is therefore necessary to actively promote responsible corporate behaviour in EU companies operating abroad, with a particular focus on strict compliance with all their legal obligations.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on social, environmental and human rights standards in trade agreements because these issues become of a major concern to our citizens. The report raises concerns about the level of ambition the EU has to uphold these. It is important to see legally binding and enforceable standards to hold corporations and governments to account, taking on board the important views of civil society.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report places sustainable development at the heart of EU trade policy and reaffirms the role of the European Parliament in making sure that the goals of the EU in this area remain ambitious and are systematically achieved. The report contains specific recommendations for further measures that could be pursued by the EU at multilateral/WTO level, in bilateral trade agreements and unilaterally through the system of trade preferences for third countries. It also calls for systematically addressing EU trade and investment agreements issues like gender equality, tax avoidance or corporate social responsibility. I therefore supported this report that ensures that the European Parliament remains engaged in promoting the necessary link between trade and sustainable development and sets the basis for the EU to maintain its leadership in the area of human rights, environmental and social standards.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. In its resolution of 8 November 2010, Parliament issued recommendations to the Commission on social and environmental standards, human rights and social responsibility. In its report, the Committee on International Trade reviews the recommendations implemented and not implemented. It proposes that Parliament ask the Commission and the Member States to integrate the gender mainstreaming approach into all their policies, including the EU trade strategy. It also calls on the Commission to ensure greater coherence in terms of development, to ensure an effective evaluation of policies and coordination between development support and trade policy, and for the European Union and the Member States to take binding measures to ensure that companies pay taxes where economic activities take place and value is created. Finally, it proposes that the EU's trade strategy should be a means of promoting democratic values in third countries. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, in its intentions, aims to impose the same conceptions of human rights on the whole planet through free trade. We agree with some of the wishes expressed in this report but very circumspect about how to mix or even impose together free trade, human rights, social and environmental norms. Forbearance.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the framework of the Trade for All strategy, sustainable development is pointed out as one of the primary objectives to be pursued by the European Union, as set out in the Treaties which established it.  In an integrated policy approach, EU trade policies should serve not only as an engine for promoting economic development, but also as social progress, a good standard of quality of life and respect for human rights.  In 2010, the European Parliament had the opportunity to address to the Commission a set of recommendations on social standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility, which should be taken into account in the framework of trade agreements concluded between the Union and third countries. To this end, I am voting in favour of this report, which the Commission should ensure that the Commission is responsible for the practical implementation of the recommendations made by the European Parliament for the promotion of sustainable and integrated development.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, in its intentions, aims to impose the same conceptions of human rights on the whole planet through free trade. I agree with some of the wishes expressed in this report but very circumspect about how to mix, or even impose, free trade, human rights, social and environmental standards. I therefore abstain on this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which is fully in line with the Labour Party and trade unions’ positions. It endorses the ITUC’s priorities for the responsible management of global supply chains, and calls for giving a formal role to trade unions in the GSP regulation.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility. I support the provisions of this text which aim to reduce discrimination against women, particularly in relation to compliance with the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against them.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the FORENZA report on the implementation of social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility. Trade is also an instrument for promoting European values, which can generalise the effective and systematic inclusion and implementation of social and environmental standards. Closer cooperation with the ILO in this area is essential; How does it work? For example, by monitoring and enforcing human rights clauses in the EU's international agreements with an open and inclusive approach, by establishing a closer link between human rights clauses, by introducing regulations prohibiting the importation into the EU of goods produced by the use of modern forms of slavery or forced labour in violation of fundamental human rights standards. , or by improving the Commission's model for assessing impacts on sustainable development.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the great potential of trade policies and agreements as an instrument of sustainable economic development, with particular reference to environmental protection, human rights and corporate social responsibility; assessed the risks of poorly regulated globalisation characterised by increasingly interconnected and opaque value chains; We are voting in favour of the Forenza report. As recognised by the 'Trade for All' strategy, proposed by the European Commission to launch a new trade policy, we believe in the deep link between international trade and respect for social and environmental standards. Furthermore, noting that only some of the recommendations made by the European Parliament in 2010 have actually been implemented, we call on the European Commission to follow up the demands made by this House as a matter of urgency and we encourage the Member States to legislate as consistently as possible with the global development objectives. We also support this report because of the attention it pays, thanks to the work of socialists and democrats, to the gender issue by making it one of the priorities for the development of the trade strategy and making it an indispensable issue for trade agreements. Finally, we share the desire for a reform of the governance of the World Trade Organisation that will reassert the multilateral system.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility. The importance of foreign trade and investment are important instruments for achieving economic growth, sustainable development, good governance and the protection of human rights.
