The European Union is committed to consistently promoting and respecting human rights and democracy in its relations with third countries in all its policies, including trade through agreements that have a strong impact on both human rights protection and sustainable development.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report because I consider it extremely important that both the private sector and the public sector should help to achieve human rights, social and environmental standards. Companies must act responsibly, both socially and ecologically. The EU's next-generation trade and investment agreements call on the partners to comply with human rights protection and social and environmental standards, but it is not enough to hold the other side accountable, but also to ensure them at Member State and EU level.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that reiterates the fact that all religious, racial, ethnic and political groups should be allowed to develop in a single society valuing the diversity among both men and women. This approach should be integrated in EU policies, ensuring a better coherence with regard to development, effective policy assessment and coordination between development aid and trade policy.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which rightly emphasises the importance of trade and foreign investment as important instruments for achieving economic growth, sustainable development and the protection of human rights. I believe that well-established trade and direct investment regimes increase well-being in poorer countries, and that increased well-being is a prerequisite for better protection of human and social and workers' rights and better protection of the environment.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which calls for legally binding human rights and social and environmental standards in the EU’s international trade agreements. It also calls for human rights impact assessments and sustainability impact assessments to become binding, and further highlights the Commission’s recent decision to rubber-stamp the Vietnam EU free trade agreement without having done so. The resolution further calls for the Commission to act within the World Trade Organisation to promote the setting of enforceable rules for the sustainable management of global supply chains by multinational companies. In addition, it insists that countries signing trade agreements with the EU must also ratify and implement the ILO’s core labour conventions, as well as reasserting the need to maintain and strengthen the role of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) in international trade agreement negotiations. It calls for full transparency in the negotiations, which is still lacking in the ongoing negotiations on agreements such as TTIP and TiSA.  Sinn Féin in Europe are committed to ensuring that social and labour rights are protected and are continuing to fight the implementation of the neoliberal agenda. For Sinn Féin, human rights and social rights must always come before profit.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report contains good approaches in principle, but the report cannot be approved due to the further consolidation of the gender mainstreaming idea. That is why I abstained.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In order to improve the economic situation, issues such as the protection of human rights, gender equality, good governance and also sustainable development must be linked to economic activity, and member states need to make more efforts in these areas. The EU is committed to consistently promoting and respecting human rights and democracy in its relations with third countries through all EU policies, including trade policy and all relevant EU external financial instruments, and this needs to be done in real terms.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. Trade and human rights can strengthen each other. Elements such as the Sustainable Development Goals demonstrate that trade can be used to promote the defence of human rights, and trade diplomacy and trade agreements are one of the ramifications that the European Union has to firmly protect social rights and environmental protection. If we let these weapons lose their meaning and become something that is predatory, not only will we be lacking our international responsibility, but we will be going against the past and the spirit of the Union. The European Union has at its disposal a tool such as trade, important to achieve the export of common values, values that are much needed in many places outside our borders. By being responsible and fair, we can get a lever to decisively promote the defence of human rights outside the Union.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I supported the report. It is essential to ensure that international standards in the areas of human rights, gender equality, labour law and the environment are properly respected not only in the EU but also globally. It should be noted that these recommendations are one of the means to promote democratic values in third countries. Trade agreements and trade preferences programmes are levers for promoting human rights, promoting forced and child labour, food security and health rights, sustainable development and high safety and environmental standards, as well as ensuring economic opportunities for all. Their development must therefore be continuously promoted. Of course, trade policy should contribute more to a different model of energy consumption, and EU trade measures should promote the use and development of renewable energy and the development of environmental goods and technologies in Europe. In order to achieve sustainable economic and social development, the corporate social responsibility agenda must be adapted to the specific needs of regions and countries, which will enable the objectives set to be achieved more effectively and effectively.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this because we oppose the politicisation of trade by the EU. Trade should be about trade, and not the EU using its financial muscle to force weaker trade partners into obeying its political ideology.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt obliged to vote in favour of this proposal. The European Parliament, as co-legislator, has a central role to play in the definition of European standards. Therefore, its recommendations on human rights, corporate responsibilities and social and environmental standards require enforcement by the Commission. Furthermore, since issues relating to the development, trade and promotion of human rights are of fundamental importance in all EU policies, I believe that greater cooperation at multilateral level in the areas of greatest interest and in the forms indicated in Mrs Forenza's proposal is timely and necessary. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution, which stresses the importance of trade and foreign investment as important tools for realizing economic growth and good governance, and calls on the EZ to be active in achieving the SDGs. Trade plays a strong role in promoting business opportunities, creating prosperity and increasing employment and guiding economic development, social progress, living standards, quality of life and improving human rights standards in the long term. The EZ must make a positive contribution in these areas, thus supporting social and environmental progress.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. I supported the Report on Social and Environmental Standards, Human Rights and Corporate Responsibility because I think it is very important that we all get as close as possible to the SDGs.  Protecting the environment must be one of our priorities because only by working together and striving at all levels and taking care of our environment do we have a chance to preserve our planet for new generations. Economic development is also important, we must worry about the economic stability of the Union, as this also leads to the economic stability of our citizens, bearing in mind that not all countries are equally economically developed and that those less developed need help. But we must not allow the economic balance to be the most important item for us, it is necessary to take into account the protection of basic human rights, the protection of workers' rights and their dignity, equality and solidarity.  I supported this report because it's all contained in it. Nevertheless, I should note that I think even more effort is needed to make real and tangible progress.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, in its intentions, aims to impose the same conceptions of human rights on the whole planet through free trade. I agree with some of the wishes expressed in this text but very circumspect about how to mix free trade, human rights, social and environmental standards. This method is actually a baseless belief. So I prefer to abstain.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 International trade can play an important role in promoting economic development, employment, social progress and quality of life and improving human rights standards. The European Union, as reaffirmed in the 'Trade for All' strategy, is committed to promoting sustainable development, human rights and good governance. The need for trade agreements that protect human, social and environmental rights is increasingly felt by citizens as well. This report therefore calls on the Commission to make a more determined and ambitious commitment by negotiating trade agreements that involve the responsibility of multinationals and governments in this area and control mechanisms to ensure that social and environmental clauses are applied. The report also calls on the Commission and the Member States to integrate the gender perspective into all their policies, including trade policy, and to ensure effective compliance with the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW), by carrying out regular evaluations of agreements in force. Economic recovery and growth, in Europe and throughout the world, are compatible, indeed synergistic, with the principles of social justice, environmental sustainability and respect for human rights. I therefore support the report and vote in favour.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I call on the Commission and the Member States to introduce gender mainstreaming in all their policies, including trade policy, and to ensure, inter alia, effective compliance with the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. The EU's success in the area of social and environmental problems in the context of its trade diplomacy is well ahead of other global trading players. But it is important to stress the importance of trade and foreign investment, as important tools for achieving economic growth, sustainable development, good governance and the protection of human rights. I recall the impact of trade and foreign direct investment on increasing prosperity in poor countries. I would like to recall that by no means is the link between increased prosperity and better protection of human rights, social rights and workers' rights. I call for increased transparency and accountability for the so-called grassroots organisations (organisations 'from below') in formulating international commercial rules and national trade policy, while ensuring consistency with regard to respect for labour and human rights in general, including women's rights. In my view, it is essential to continue our efforts to comply with the rules of the OECD Declaration on International Investment and Multinationals. I call on the Commission to ensure transparency with regard to access to company management information and the introduction of an effective reporting system.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is the largest player in the field of world trade. That is why I consider it very important that a great deal of emphasis be placed on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility when concluding trade agreements. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it very important for the Commission to ensure consistency between development policy and its trade strategy, which includes fair taxation. I therefore supported the provision that taxes should be paid precisely where economic activity takes place. Although foreign investment and trade usually lead to economic growth and higher well-being, this does not mean that human rights are being improved in the same way and the overall environment is improved. Deforestation and forest degradation are also evidence of a negative relationship between the two factors. Multinational supranational enterprises and groups therefore need to play a much greater role and provide positive incentives in the field of protection. In particular, they should ensure, for example, responsible logging, felling and sourcing of commodities, as well as social justice. I therefore voted to place much greater responsibility on businesses in this regard. The Commission must become stricter and ensure that the principles set out within the UN are applied consistently.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a Social Democrat, I consider this report to be very important, as some of the fundamental principles of the functioning of European society, namely human rights, corporate social responsibility and, last but not least, social and environmental standards, are often forgotten. It is essential that our high European standards are taken into account today, when the European Union is negotiating several important international treaties. Rules for the protection of European workers also need to be firmly anchored in international treaties. Last but not least, I see as essential the fact that the adopted Report of the European Parliament encourages greater transparency in the negotiation of international treaties, currently this concerns, for example, the TTIP.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report, which is a continuation of a 2010 work on human rights and social and environmental standards in international trade and on corporate social responsibility in trade agreements. Indeed, trade is not merely a tool for economic development: it allows the European Union to promote its values, allowing harmonisation to the top of standards beneficial to each party in the framework of trade agreements.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. In November 2010, the European Parliament adopted the following reports: 'Human rights, social and environmental standards in international trade' and 'Corporate Social Responsibility in international trade agreements'. The reports rightly state that by establishing certain regulatory requirements in trade agreements it is possible to promote European values and raise awareness of the importance of good social practices. In the same way it is possible to fight against the production of goods without respect for human values, such as slavery, prohibiting the importation of them.  The report here shows that the Commission is doing a good job of implementing the 2010 standards. This is without prejudice to the recognition that much is still to be done in this area, since many developing countries will be reluctant to include social and environmental responsibility measures.  This effort must continue. My vote is therefore in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this because we oppose the politicisation of trade by the EU. Trade should be about trade, and not the EU using its financial muscle to force weaker trade partners into obeying its political ideology.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I have supported this resolution, which sets out detailed proposals to be implemented by the European Commission to ensure that the Union's trade policy is a relevant instrument for defending and promoting social and environmental standards, human rights and the principle of corporate social responsibility. Trade policy takes place at different levels of action, both at the multilateral level within the Framework of the World Trade Organization, as well as at the regional and bilateral levels. That is why our assembly makes recommendations for action and reform for each of these levels. In addition, with regard to corporate social responsibility, we call on the European Commission to update its corporate social responsibility strategy to ensure better implementation of the UN's guiding principles.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. Mr President, the EU's trade strategy should be an instrument for promoting democratic values in third countries. The Commission and the Member States should incorporate a gender mainstreaming approach in all their policies, including trade policy, ensure coordination between development aid and trade policy, foster respect for international standards on human rights, gender equality, labour legislation and environmental protection, and also promote binding measures to ensure that businesses pay taxes where they carry out their economic activity.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In order to be effective, the Socialists believe that trade policy should be another tool for sustainable development and, in order to be effective, must be inescapably linked to objectives that are mandatory and fully enforceable in social, labour, environmental and human rights, holding both governments and businesses accountable. This initiative report gives us a new opportunity to remember that it is the responsibility of all, the public and private sectors, men and women, to ensure that international trade benefits the world's population equally, putting the general interest society ahead of any other objective. That is why I voted for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In 2010, the European Parliament had already had the opportunity to make recommendations to the Commission on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility. While I am pleased that some of these recommendations have been implemented, I can only regret that others have gone unheeded. This report was an opportunity for our institution to highlight some priorities. The report adopted by the European Parliament contains a number of important recommendations in the areas mentioned above. Recommendations that should make a better life for European citizens and workers. I will stress paragraph 40 of this report which states that 'the effective implementation of these recommendations is a crucial element in Parliament's assessment of the trade agreements negotiated by the Commission'. As far as I am concerned, I say and I repeat, I will not vote for trade agreements that would jeopardise the health of our European citizens and the quality of life of our workers.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because this document provides an overview of the progress made by the European Commission since 2010, when the European Parliament adopted recommendations on trade policy, human rights, environmental and social responsibility relations.  The report stresses that the European Commission has failed to implement the necessary policy reform. So far, although this has been possible, trade has not been fully exploited as a means of achieving the European Union's objectives in the fields of environmental protection, human resources and the implementation of the principle of social responsibility.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report notes that, although some of the European Parliament's recommendations in 2010 on social, environmental, human rights and corporate social responsibility (CMR) regulations have been implemented, others have remained unrealised. This report thus draws attention to the implementation of some of the main recommendations that deserve to be taken into account from now on. The European Union (EU) trade strategy should be a tool for promoting democratic values in third countries as well as promoting human, labour and environmental rights by strengthening trade preference agreements or programmes. In addition, the European Commission (EC) should take a leading role in reforming the Governance Model of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), with a particular focus on the objectives of strengthening cooperation, which should be more effective and allow for regular dialogue between the relevant agencies of the United Nations (UN) and the WTO.  The EU should also strengthen its leading role in the review of multilateral trade policy - on a global scale and in the mechanisms for including the social, environmental and human resources dimensions. By agreeing with the measures in question, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, of which I was shadow rapporteur for the EPP, which deals with the implementation of the recommendations made by Parliament in 2010 on human rights, social and environmental standards, and corporate social responsibility in international trade.  The text thus reminds us that trade contributes to respect for human rights through, among other things, the presence of human rights clauses in EU agreements and the insertion of ambitious sustainable development chapters. The European Union must continue its actions to improve the contribution of trade to respect for human rights as well as social and environmental standards. For example, the EU must continue to improve the GSP system to ensure compliance with the conventions; it must also expand its initiatives such as the Global Solidarity Pact to other actors (an initiative implemented in the wake of the Rana Plaza tragedy in Bangladesh).  Finally, I wanted to point out a recommendation already made in 2010 which did not receive an answer: the Commission must act to combat forced and child labour.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report which sets out the need to make the human rights clauses of trade treaties binding. Other elements that we have welcomed are the granting to the ILO of official observer status in the WTO. Finally, we consider that the call for all parties to multilateral and bilateral agreements in which the Union is involved to ratify and implement the ILO's Fundamental Conventions can be very much in the context of the TiSA and TTIP negotiations (since the US has not now acceded to these Conventions)

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to support this report on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility. Binding corporate social responsibility standards and greater involvement of civil society organisations will deliver better employment conditions and give more credibility to international trade deals. Trade policy should bring social and environmental benefits, higher standards for consumers and better conditions for workers. The paragraphs on reform of WTO governance, sustainability impact assessments, gender mainstreaming and greater democratic accountability are especially welcome.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As tragedies such as the collapse of bangladesh's Rana Plaza factory have shown, European consumers are also closely affected by the working and social conditions of workers in third countries. Compliance with basic social, labour and environmental standards should therefore be guaranteed in all trade agreements concluded by the European Union. This applies not only to companies in third countries, but also, in particular, to companies based in the European Union but operating beyond its borders. Such steps can contribute to achieving sustainable development or combating forced and child labour, which is why I was happy to support this report.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report deals with the implementation of three previous EP reports with recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate civil liability in union trade agreements with third parties. I voted in favour of it because it certainly points out where the deficits are in Parliament's previous recommendations, while going further and introducing new aspects, in my view, extremely positive and important, such as requiring that the human rights clause in those agreements be binding.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this because we oppose the politicisation of trade by the EU. Trade should be about trade, and not the EU using its financial muscle to force weaker trade partners into obeying its political ideology.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not actually reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution because I consider responsible corporate behaviour, with a particular focus on strict compliance with all their legal obligations under either national law or any bilateral or international legal obligations relating to their business activities, to be an integral part of the EU's good economic and trade relations. I see the link between trade, human rights and social and environmental standards that go hand in hand with the promotion and observance of international standards and rules as the basis for quality trade relations that strengthen mutual understanding and common values such as the rule of law, good governance and respect for human rights. It is pleased that the positive impact of European businesses operating worldwide on human rights, as well as their operation, which is a good example of a non-discriminatory corporate culture, has long been recognised. As such practices are not common for all businesses, I welcome the efforts of the Commission and the Council to introduce such legally binding human rights clauses into all trade and investment agreements in line with the common approach. At the same time, I expect the Commission to be able to carry out an investigation into breaches of corporate social responsibility obligations.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report talks about the progress made by the European Commission since 2010, when the European Parliament adopted recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility. This resolution called, inter alia, on the Commission and the Member States to include a gender perspective in all their policies and, inter alia, to ensure that the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women is effectively respected. At the same time, the report also reminds us that the EU is committed to promoting and respecting human rights and democracy in a coherent way in its relations with third countries in all its policies, including trade, and in all its relevant external financing instruments. The report reveals that the European Commission has failed to implement a radical reform of its policy in order to turn trade into a tool to achieve the EU's objectives and to protect the environment and human rights. The report mentions the reform of the World Trade Organisation and proposes a number of good changes, but at the same time fails to address the main problem of the hierarchy of norms within the United Nations. The report supports the conditionality of trade agreements with human rights and supports the idea that chapters of trade and sustainable development and human rights provisions should be covered by the main dispute settlement mechanisms of trade agreements. Although I would have liked the report to have been better, I believe that it contributes to improving the situation, which is why I supported it.

name: Renato Soru (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour today on the report on social standards, the environment, human rights and corporate responsibilities, which calls for the EU's commitment to developing its trade policies in line with other European policies on social protection, sustainable development and fundamental rights. I therefore consider it important, as proposed in the report adopted today, to ensure greater coordination between development aid and trade policy, and to make the impact assessments of EU trade policy on human rights and sustainability binding in the context of trade agreements, as key elements for promoting good governance and democratic principles in partner third countries as well.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Continuous and sustainable development is conditional on the development of both the private and public sectors in a socially and environmentally responsible manner. The new trade policy and its strategy highlight the fundamental values that we profess in the EU.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility. It calls for a peculiar melange from EU levels, Member States and private companies. Together they should pull together. As well as many concerns about the protection of human rights may be, this is not the way forward. Private companies should not be put into service by the state in order to carry out its tasks. This encourages corporatism. I do not ignore the social responsibility, which every company must recognize and perceive as a free actor, if its owners so wish.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. In 2010, Parliament sent recommendations on social and environmental standards and responsible business to the Commission, but some of these recommendations were not implemented. The link between trade and human rights on the one hand and social and environmental standards on the other are an integral part of the Union's economic and trade relations. Member States must include a gender balance approach in their policies, including trade policy. It is of utmost importance for the European Union to cooperate at multilateral level. I support this proposal for a resolution, as I believe that trade plays a strong role in promoting business opportunities, delivering prosperity and increasing employment, and fostering economic development, social progress, living standards, quality of life and, in the long run, raising human rights standards. The Union has committed to integrating aspects of gender into all policies, and men and women must benefit equally from social change, economic growth and job creation.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility. Some of the European Commission's recommendations in 2010 have been taken into account, but some have not. I therefore support the call for the Commission and the Member States to include a gender perspective in their policies, while at the same time taking gender aspects into account in its assessment of the impact of EU trade policy on women's rights. I also support the call for the Commission to ensure greater coordination on development and to ensure effective policy assessment and coordination between development aid and trade policy.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union's trade relations must serve the economic and political interests of the Member States and European citizens and not the 'democratic values' as perceived by the Union's leading circles. Interventionism and economic blackmail cannot be regarded as 'values' in 2016. This report is in complete disharmony with reality.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trade is a means of promoting European values, which can serve as a social and environmental cord in everyday life. Closer cooperation with the International Labour Organisation is needed in the application of the sustainable development provisions. It will also be necessary to apply the human rights clauses ens in the International Treaties of the European Union and to monitor the implementation of the legislation, in particular to ban products created by slave labour and violations of fundamental human rights from European markets. The report relies heavily on the application of the human rights and corporate responsibility proposals in the 2010 Parliamentary Recommendation on Sustainable Development, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, as co-legislator, is stepping up the development of common trade legislation in the Union, for example by approving trade agreements. I believe that social, environmental, human rights and corporate responsibility elements should be the most important parts of the agreements. I agree that trade plays a key role in promoting business opportunities, creating prosperity and increasing employment rates, and that it promotes economic development, social progress, quality of life and long-term improvement of human rights standards. I also agree that the EU can make a positive contribution to greater respect for human rights and sustainable development globally through its trade policy. These agreements have an impact on human rights and sustainable development and should therefore support social and environmental progress, ensuring that European standards, human rights, social and environmental standards are respected. With regard to corporate responsibility, the report highlights the fact that companies have to pay tax where they carry out their economic activities. In this connection, when debating this report, I called for confirmation of the ban on tax havens within the EU. I believe that when we talk about tax differences in the case of trade agreements, we must not let the Member States lose tax revenues from each other. Overall, I agree with the report and voted in favour of it.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 A functioning global trade policy also requires the identification and adequate consideration of non-economic criteria. I voted in favour of this report because the whole fully took into account almost all the norms affecting trade policy.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union has a duty to set high corporate social and responsibility standards and the Alliance of Socialists & Democrats has always pushed for ambitious Trade and Sustainable Development chapters in all trade agreements. Our group wants to hold corporations and governments accountable and this can only be done through binding and enforceable standards. I support this resolution as it reflects a good compromise on all the main areas. Furthermore, this report incorporates notions of gender mainstreaming in all policies, which is a significant achievement and a great step in the right direction.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this report. Like other colleagues, we have insisted that compliance with the EIGHT basic labour standards and the four ILO priority conventions for industrialised countries, as well as relevant EU legislation, must be included by a social clause in all bilateral or multilateral EU trade agreements and that these standards must be applied. Incentives are needed to encourage companies to make corporate social responsibility (CSR) commitments and proactive measures to identify and prevent violations of human and environmental rights, as well as any form of corruption or tax evasion, including in their subsidiaries and supply chains.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Trade is an important tool for the European Union to promote democratic values in third countries, such as environmental and social standards, human rights and corporate responsibility. This is why I voted in favour of this report, which analyses the progress achieved by the Commission in implementing these standards and provides new recommendations. The recommendations aim to reflect the right balance between economic diplomacy and diminishing trade barriers, by ensuring greater coordination between development aid and trade policy, promoting binding measures to ensure that companies pay taxes where their economic activity takes place, and advocating that this issue is given priority on the agenda.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Corporate social responsibility is becoming an increasingly important issue. This is an issue which cannot, however, remain a subject for insiders alone. Only participation and knowledge contribute to real change. Compliance with existing legislation and collective agreements between the social partners is a necessary prerequisite for achieving this responsibility. In order to fully meet their responsibilities, companies should have a process to integrate social, environmental, ethical, human rights and consumer demands into their business operations and business strategies, in close cooperation with stakeholders.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on parliament's recommendations on the implementation of social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility, because in our time trade and human rights should strengthen each other and prevent social exclusion. Companies should be obliged to take greater responsibility for respecting labour rights, respect for social justice and fundamental human rights. In this context, it is necessary to stress the importance of monitoring compliance with these rules. This should be one of the tasks of the EU institutions. For this reason, a decent work programme adapted to the needs of specific regions and countries must be implemented. Of course, in order for social policy to be an effective tool for the protection of workers' rights, it must be supported by the additional EU actions discussed in this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility. The purpose of the report is to analyse the implementation of social and environmental standards and corporate social responsibility in trade policy, particularly in trade negotiations. From 2010 to today, however, there have been many changes in the area of standards in trade agreements. Trade is a tool to promote European values and an instrument that can bring, in general practice, the effective and systematic integration and implementation of social and environmental standards. The inclusion of sustainable development provisions in trade agreements will benefit all parties, and closer cooperation in this area with the International Labour Organisation is essential.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report which sets out the need to make the human rights clauses of trade treaties binding. Other elements that we have welcomed are the granting to the ILO of official observer status in the WTO. Finally, we consider that the call for all parties to multilateral and bilateral agreements in which the Union is involved to ratify and implement the ILO's Fundamental Conventions can be very important in the context of the TiSA and TTIP negotiations (since the US has not now acceded to these Conventions).

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is my belief that the EU should have a stronger stance, in its trade dealings with third countries, on human rights and environmental standards. It is very detrimental for Europe and its values that these issues are not as yet fully taken into account.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report argues that trade policies must make a positive contribution to human rights and social and environmental standards, i.e. promote the right to health, the prohibition of child labour by no longer producing in countries that can practice this, sustainable development, or environmental standards.  According to the European Union, the WTO should apply these principles to the whole world, and that is what is embarrassing about this report.  Of course, all the points mentioned above must be defended, but not through globalised free trade. This free trade and the creation of a globalized market cannot allow us to defend the weakest, wherever they may be.  So I chose abstention.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 CSR should cover new areas such as work organisation, equal opportunities and social inclusion, anti-discrimination measures and the development of lifelong learning and training. By my vote, following the group's position, I supported it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report which sets out the need to make the human rights clauses of trade treaties binding. Other elements that we have welcomed are the granting to the ILO of official observer status in the WTO. Finally, we consider that the call for all parties to multilateral and bilateral agreements in which the Union is involved to ratify and implement the ILO's Fundamental Conventions can be very much in the context of the TiSA and TTIP negotiations (since the US has not now acceded to these Conventions)

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the fact that the requirement for large businesses to report on human rights is included in the EU's non-financial reporting directive, and I call for its immediate implementation. I call on the EU Member States to transpose this directive into national law quickly and effectively; I draw attention to the guiding principles of UN reporting, human rights criteria in enterprises and the objective of 'integrated reporting', and I call on all EU listed companies and their stakeholders to respect the spirit of the directive within the EU and in trading outside the EU.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on implementation of the 2010 recommendations of Parliament on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate responsibility. This report calls on the Commission and Member States to incorporate a gender-mainstreaming approach into all their policies, including trade policy, and to guarantee inter alia effective compliance with the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women. In addition, the report calls on the EU to play an active role in achieving the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) contained in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. The report equally urges the EU and the Member States to promote binding measures to ensure that companies pay taxes where economic activities take place and value is created. Furthermore, it stresses the significance of trade and foreign investment as important tools to achieve economic growth, sustainable development, good governance and the protection of human rights. I voted in favour because I am of the opinion that the EU has to remain committed to the coherent promotion of and respect for human rights and democracy in its relations with third countries in all its policies, including trade policy, and in all its relevant external financing instruments.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The report calls on the European Commission and Member States to adopt in all their policies an approach that integrates major issues such as the realization of the seventeen Sustainable Development Goals of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development adopted by the United Nations General Assembly, the need to ensure access to common goods such as water , health care and education to ensure social rights and respect for human rights, as well as the importance of promoting corporate social responsibility (SRSE) and forging cooperation at the unilateral, bilateral and multilateral levels of social, environmental and human rights standards to advance these objectives. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report deals with the implementation of three previous EP reports with recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate civil liability in union trade agreements with third parties. I voted in favour of it because it certainly points out where the deficits are in Parliament's previous recommendations, while going further and introducing new aspects, in my view, extremely positive and important, such as requiring that the human rights clause in those agreements be binding.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my colleagues, I voted in favour of this report because it is intended as a follow-up to a series of recommendations issued in 2010 by the European Parliament with respect to social and environmental standards (referred to under the heading of TSD for Trade and Sustainable Development), Human Rights and Corporate Social Responsibility in the context of the EU’s Common Commercial Policy. These recommendations relate to the multilateral level (in particular with respect to WTO governance), the bilateral level (EU Free Trade Agreements) and unilateral EU actions (the EU’s trade preference regime).

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'The report calls on the Commission and the Member States to integrate a gender perspective in all policies, including trade policy. I voted in favour of this report because the Commission is being asked to take into account the aspects relating to gender equality, environmental and social standards when assessing the trade strategy.  The report highlights the importance of trade and foreign investment as important means of achieving economic growth, sustainable development, good governance and the protection of human rights. It is recalled that trade and foreign direct investment increase prosperity in poorer countries. There is a significant link between increased prosperity and better protection of social and human rights, workers' rights and a higher level of environmental protection.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This debate reflects the profound contradictions of a neoliberal system based on free trade and on the basis of a purely mercantile logic that subjugates everything and everyone in the name of profit. As reality shows, it will not be through vague and non-binding rules that we will improve the fate of those who are exploited inside and outside the European Union. What about the human rights safeguard clause in the association agreement between Israel and the EU? Has this agreement ever been called into question despite the successive human rights violations of palestinian people on their territory on a daily basis? As long as free trade and the private interests of large enterprises prevail, it will certainly not be the well-intentioned words of this House that impose corporate social responsibility. That is why we stand for a new model of cooperation mutually beneficial to both sides and with respect for the sovereignty of national states.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The importance of foreign direct investment (FDI) for the protection of human rights is discussed here. It is also stressed that foreign direct investment and trade can increase prosperity in poorer countries. However, I believe that there are some gaps in the report that need to be clarified before it can be approved.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. – My colleagues and I voted in favour of this resolution as it is in line with Labour and trade unions’ positions. It endorses the ITUC’s priorities for the responsible management of global supply chains, and calls for giving a formal role to trade unions in the GSP regulation. The principles laid down in the report are also in line with the Alternative Trade Mandate that I support and to which the European Parliament subscribed in 2014. It was put together through consultation with more than 50 civil society organisations, including trade unions, and I believe it is important that the European Parliament sticks to its principles.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because it responds to the implementation of Parliament’s 2010 recommendations and makes some very important remarks. I mainly support this resolution because it recognises an element that is essential in safeguarding and enhancing human rights, namely trade. Moreover, it establishes the link between trade, foreign direct investment and sustainable development. A logical consequence of trade is indeed an increase in employment and prosperity. I welcome the resolution’s affirmation of the EU’s continuous support of human rights and democracy. In this regard, I agree that the Commission has a very important role to play.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report of the Committee on International Trade which recognises the important steps forward in developing countries on our objectives of human rights, sustainable development, the promotion of corporate and social responsibility, but also highlights the initiatives to be taken in the future for even better results.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I very much agree with this report, as I think it is very important to take environmental and social aspects into account when establishing any kind of trade agreement. It is a work that the Union has been doing for years, so that all its agreements include provisions on trade and sustainable development, enhancing transparency and dialogue with civil society. Currently, the Union also simultaneously implements the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) and its idem for developing countries (GSP+), with the aim of further enhancing the role of the environment and the role of green technologies, which are central to negotiations with other countries. I therefore believe that the Union is carrying out a role which can undoubtedly contribute positively to sustainable development by including clauses on the aspects I have mentioned.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility follows on from the European Parliament resolutions of 2010, in which Parliament called for all future business strategies to act as an instrument for more effective inclusion and implementation of social and environmental standards. The report took stock of what has been achieved on this issue since the adoption of the 2010 resolutions and set new human rights targets. Among other measures, the report recommended the EU's trade strategy as a tool for promoting democratic values in third countries, as well as taking into account overall the impact of trade and investment agreements on particularly vulnerable persons (members of minorities, geographically isolated persons, poor or socially excluded persons). In addition to these areas, the report also touched on such serious topics as the elimination of child labour and the ban on imports of products produced using child labour or the topic of neutralising energy subsidies. However, despite these positives, I abstained in the final vote because of some aspects that I do not support.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Forenza report on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility because I believe that the EU has the capacity to make a positive contribution to greater respect for human rights and sustainable development at global level through its trade policy as proposed in this report. I would stress that the European Commission should act on the bearing in mind that trade and investment agreements have an impact on human rights and sustainable development and should therefore be designed to support social and environmental progress by ensuring that European standards are not called into question, safeguarding human rights and ensuring respect for social and environmental standards. I would like to point out the efforts made by the European Socialist Group to increase the level of ambition and to establish legally binding rules to compel businesses and governments to account to civil society.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trade is a tool to promote European values and an instrument that can bring in general practice the effective and systematic integration of social and environmental standards. I believe that the inclusion of provisions and standards on sustainable development benefits all parties. The Commission is making careful efforts to integrate social and environmental standards and to implement the 2010 recommendations in trade agreements. Against this is the case, I also supported the Report on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – In the competition for bizarre sentences, the preamble (t) of this report would be distinguished, which reads: 'As other variables, such as demographic changes, will also have a negative impact on the EU's position at world trade level. As the EU's share of the world's population is expected to fall from 7.1% in 2013 to 5.3% in 2060." Therefore, children are not born in the European Union, or at least not in sufficient numbers. There's a demographic crisis, but what's the problem with that? The fact that this is unpleasant for our share of world trade. We don't really deal with this demographic challenge, by the way. Let's just say, in such a completely unviable, anti-life approach, or in relation to migration. When the European Union already has an answer to this problem. Isn't it that you want to see what we've done wrong? What is wrong with this Europe that people do not want offspring, they do not want children? We are going to do it by importing from the other side of the world– well, to put it this way – people from completely different cultures, in miserable conditions, who should create a society and an economy for themselves there, locally. It's kind of sad.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the international trade scene is changing rapidly. The economic importance of the European Union has decreased, in 2050 it will represent only 15% of world GDP. Economic power is shifting east. Japan will become the world's largest economic power in 2025 – that's what economists' forecasts tell us. What do we need in the European Union to move forward? We need, first of all, innovation, investment in research. Without investment in research, nothing will change. Industries, new industries, need to recreate, reinvent themselves, but that's only after they have solutions that only research can give. That is why the first point from which we must start, if we want to evolve economically and be competitive, is investment in research, innovation and then putting them into practice.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – I supported the present report because I consider free trade to be an important prerequisite for well-being. For the same reason, I voted against the alternative resolutions tabled by two left-wing political groups. But I would like to point out that, although the rapporteur claims that the EU's status as the world's largest economy is sustainable, it is only his wishful thinking.  This is due to the low birth rate and the deepening demographic crisis, which will result in the contraction of the economy. At the same time as the number of seniors increases, pressure on public budgets will continue to grow and an increasing proportion of GDP will go to finance them.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo mar a rinne 534 Feisire as 710. Taispeánann sé sin gur tuarascáil mhaith í agus go bhfuil an chuid is mó de na daoine sásta léi – agus cén fáth nach mbeadh? Tá mé i mo bhall de Choiste INTA; bímid ag plé cúrsaí trádála agus dar ndóigh muna féidir leat trádáil a bheith agat conas a bhféadfá earraí a dhíol agus a easpórtáil, agus mar sin de?  Dá bhrí sin, ní thuigim uaireanta cad a bhíonn á rá ag an eite chlé nuair a bhíonn siad i gcoinne gach aon chomhaontú saorthrádála – i gcoinne CETA agus i gcoinne TTIP. Cá bhfaighimid na jabanna? Tá sé sin an-tábhachtach. Dar ndóigh, caithfidh an comhaontú a bheith féaráilte; caithfidh coinníollacha oibre a bheith ceart. Ach ag deireadh na dála, is féidir linn comhaontú trádála maith a dhéanamh ar son ár saoránach, ar son an geilleagar a chothú agus jabanna a chruthú dár saoránach.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – I supported this report on a forward-looking and innovative future strategy for trade and investment. But, in particular, I supported the section which speaks about the fact that we need to have an honest debate about the costs and the benefits of free trade. I absolutely disagree with those who say that free trade brings only benefits but, equally, I absolutely disagree with those who automatically oppose free trade. In any trade agreement there will be winners and losers, and not to recognise and plan for this is simply unacceptable. We really do need an honest debate about some of the consequences of free trade, such as manufacturing job losses, the offshoring of certain activities and increased imports in different sectors but, equally, there are benefits. We have increased exports for various sectors. We will have opportunities in the services sector and opportunities for public procurement. It is important – as I said earlier – to acknowledge that there will be winners and losers. We need to say how we will support those who lose, instead of pretending that everybody will win.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – The report we adopted this morning on an innovative strategy points to the need to adapt more quickly to rapid changes in global trade trends. We need to support a transparent trade policy and greater citizen participation and achieve greater coherence between the Union's trade objectives and other aspects of its foreign policy in the field of trade for development. We defend the promotion of world trade from a multilateral approach within the World Trade Organization, as well as being able to decide, in our own interests, which free trade agreements to negotiate in the future. In this proposal too, we make clear our opposition to the granting of market economy status to China and the need for more effective trade defence instruments.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is, to date, the most prosperous economy in the world, although its economic importance is set to decline, due to the shift in wealth in the Asian region. In the wake of these forecasts, in October 2015 the Commission developed a new trade strategy, which is not particularly attentive, however, to the manufacturing sector and european challenges such as migration. On the contrary, this report aims to ensure coherence between trade objectives and European policies, such as sustainable development, environmental protection, respect for human rights and social standards. For these reasons, I voted in favour, believing that the new trade strategy cannot ignore these issues.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We feel that the best way for international trade to proceed is for nation states to agree deals with each other, not for the EU to create yet more trouble in international trade with its demands. We feel that an independent Britain, which is now on the horizon of being made official, will be a leader and example in this regard.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report deals with the Commission's latest communication: 'Trade for all'. I voted against it as this new communication reaffirms the direction in the Union's trade policy towards accelerating the liberalisation of public services. I have not been able to vote in favour of the report because in my view the Union's trade policy should take a 180-degree turn and be respectful of asymmetry in each bloc and between blocs and should be based on fair trade and not on achieving the maximum benefit of European interests. That's why I voted against it.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, while initially highlighting the lack of debate in the EU on its trade strategy, suggests extending trade relations (based on tariff-related agreements) to the establishment of other standards, including the application of human rights. It proposes to introduce uniform international standards, sees the establishment of an international arbitration tribunal as an opportunity to protect international investors, which is not certain. In addition, it calls for the opening of public procurement to the principle of reciprocity. In other words, it opens a loophole for foreign investors to (protected) markets to which they do not have access. Finally, it opposes any strengthening of protectionism and under the guise of free trade even insists on the need to bring down the latest standards. Given the risks this report poses to our economies, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ While it includes some constructive language around low-carbon economies, illegal wildlife trade and some mention of the precautionary principle, overall this is a very negative report containing some very regressive provisions. In particular, it called for the Trade Agreement CETA to be ratified as swiftly as possible for the ‘future interests of EU businesses’. Sinn Féin in Europe has worked tirelessly on highlighting the dangers of these trade agreements. Moreover, it welcomes the TTIP reading rooms for MEPs as a Commission ‘transparency initiative’, despite the fact that any MEP has to sign a confidentiality agreement before entering the room. It should further be remembered that what’s inside the reading room is just the tip of the iceberg; the most sensitive documents are still hidden from MEPs and even national governments. The report also celebrates the Commission’s efforts in bringing forward the new Investment Court System, an initiative with the sole purpose of allowing corporations to sue governments for enacting policies in the public interest through the democratic system.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. If we welcome the European Commission's change in tone to finally base trade on EU values, we call on the EU to translate these commitments into action! Trade is not automatically virtuous as the Commission claims! That is why, in this report, we highlight a number of blind spots in his thinking as the necessary re-industrialisation of Europe. We also demand the protection of sensitive agricultural sectors, the exclusion of public services from the scope of negotiations. We oppose the granting of market economy status to China. In addition, transparency must be drastically increased and the link between trade, development and the raising of social, environmental and labour standards must be automatic. Finally, we call for caution in the proliferation of trade agreements: the Commission must take into account the cumulative impact of the quotas offered in the various negotiations, particularly in the agricultural sector, which should not be sacrificed.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on a forward-looking and innovative future strategy for trade and investment. EU public opinion has become increasingly interested in international trade due to the negotiation of agreements such as TTIP, CETA and TiSA. International trade is an essential element for the EU economy. On 14 October 2015, the Commission published an ambitious trade and investment strategy entitled ‘Trade for all: towards a more responsible trade and investment policy’. The report focuses on some essential elements such as the importance of global value chains, the trade in digital goods and services, the strengthening of sustainable development and the promotion of human rights, labour and social standards and environmental sustainability. It underlines the need for more transparency in trade negotiations and for the modernisation of trade defence instruments, especially as China is firmly requesting the granting of Market Economy Status (MES).

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on a new forward-looking and innovative future strategy for trade and investment which highlights the need for Europe to be open to trade for the benefit of work and growth. However, it is nevertheless stated that the right international rules and safety nets are needed to ensure that ordinary citizens benefit from trade and investment.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This text has some positive aspects such as combating the illicit trade in wildlife products, strengthening trade defences and not to China's market economy status. But it calls for the fight against protectionism, more free trade, free trade in the services sector, a convergence of international standards and an arbitration tribunal to protect investment. I therefore voted against this report, as well as the greens/FTA replacement report, which is for more multilateralism. It opposes the EU's new policy to "force" developing countries to cooperate on migration control and readmission procedures and against the gue/NGL group report because its vision of a more democratic WTO, regulating globalisation, is not acceptable, as is the inclusion of human rights and women's rights in trade agreements.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns a trade and investment strategy for the European Union, and it is reasonable to expect trade partners of the European Union to act in a fair and reasonable manner. However, the language throughout this report seeks to give greater power to the Commission, and for that reason I had to vote against overall.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which reminds us that trade is not an end in itself, but a means of ensuring prosperity and equality, promoting trade prospects, sustainable economic development, social progress and understanding between cultures, generating jobs and improving living conditions without burdening public finances.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ If we want Europe to become a strong global player in the future it is crucial that the European economy becomes more influential on the global scale. Therefore, this report combines several aspects, namely, lowering of the unemployment rate and encouraging growth of jobs is coupled with focusing on human rights, efficient development and good governance. The Commission is working hard on incorporation and mainstreaming of human and labour rights, environmental and development issues into all trade agreements. I believe that in this fast-moving world it is crucial to facilitate growth based on a set of common standards for trade and investment. Policy makers need to ensure that economic growth is not only sustainable but responsible towards the broader population and our environment.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a new viable and innovative strategy for the future on trade and investment. Today, the EU has the world's richest economy. The economic importance of the EU will be diminished: by 2050, only 15% of global GDP will be generated in the EU-28, while 23.7% was created in 2013. The Centre for Wealth Creation is heading east towards the Asia-Pacific region, and demographic change will also have a negative impact on the EU's position on the world trade stage. An effective, comprehensive and forward-looking trade and investment strategy is therefore essential for the European Union. October 14, 2015 The Commission has proposed a new trade and investment strategy for the European Union "Trade for all. Towards a more responsible trade and investment policy". I agree with the shame that the strategy does not attach much importance to the manufacturing sector and to the trade challenges associated with tackling migration problems. It is important that trade policy in the 21st century responds to people's concerns. More transparency, participation and accountability are needed for all stakeholders.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is about a new, forward-looking and innovative future strategy for trade and investment and is essentially based on the Commission's october 2015 proposal entitled 'Trade for all: towards a more responsible trade and investment policy'. In this, the Commission set out the clear objective of rapidly enhancing the liberalisation of trade and continuing the integration of the Union into global value chains. We do not agree with the neoliberal mindset that global free trade can only lead to lasting stagnation for the average European citizen, just as real wages have been stagnant in this region for almost two or three decades. The reason is simple: if multinationals can produce in low-wage countries but sell their products in high-wage countries at prices corresponding to higher wage levels there, they will make a huge profit, but the result, in addition to cheaper products, is high unemployment, insecurity and economic stagnation. In a global free market environment, wages will be balanced in the long term, but the price of this is the degradation of developed areas and the emergence of rust belts. On the basis of all this, I rejected the report.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which calls for a more ferocious fight against all forms of protectionism and insists on a more general implementation of the sacrosanct Free Trade, especially by extending it to the services sector.  Such a policy of forced liberalisation, which has already shown its negative effects on our industry, can only exacerbate the EU's economic difficulties if it were extended to the services sector, which remains one of our last assets.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Foreign trade is a key factor in the development of the European economy. The European Union is the richest economy in the world. However, this situation is likely to falter: forecasts indicate that by 2050, the 28 EU Member States will now account for only 15% of world GDP, up from 23.7% in 2013.  The Union must therefore have an effective, elaborate and forward-looking trade and investment strategy.  This report incorporates, for the first time, the requirement that trade policy be used to increase cooperation in the fight against corruption, tax evasion and tax evasion. Consistency between the Union's trade objectives and other facets of its foreign policy is a priority in the face of the challenges facing the Union in the 21st century, including the migration challenge. Trade and investment agreements should be designed to strengthen sustainable development and promote human rights, social and labour standards and environmental sustainability around the world.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon has led to profound changes in the common commercial policy, changes that have taken place at a time of severe international economic crisis and increased public attention to trade negotiations. The Beghin report, which I supported with my vote, focuses on the importance for the European Union of developing an innovative and forward-looking strategy on trade and investment. The text stresses the importance of transparency in the negotiations and calls in particular on the Council to make public all negotiating mandates. Strengthening parliamentary control is a key element in ensuring an adequate response to citizens' fears and concerns about possible deregulation risks generated by trade agreements. The development of an effective and forward-looking trade and investment strategy involves strengthening and updating the Eu ropean Union's trade defence system, which today appears to be threatened by China's demand for recognition of market economy status. In the new world scenario, the EU must commit itself to regularly updating its trade strategy by presenting annual reports enabling European citizens to verify the commitments made by the Commission.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted abstention because, although there are some very positive aspects to this report, it is ambiguous in supporting a strategy that is essentially favourable to the free market at any price such as 'trade for all'.  We welcome the fact that it draws attention to issues that free-market dogma tends to camouflage in most debates (i.e. "considering that there has been no serious debate in the EU on free trade policies"), immediately publish negotiating mandates, strengthen policy coherence for development, and make labour rights chapters binding , social and environmental agreements. However, we cannot vote in favour since the underlying logic is the support of the Commission's strategy, and boost foreign trade as a solution to European problems and support for the Commission's trade for all strategy, which proposes a strategy for the future that can only lead the EU and its partners to deepen inequalities , the increase of which we have been experiencing for decades.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the new innovative and future-oriented strategy on trade and investment, and voted in favour of greater protection of the full spectrum of intellectual property rights and for the Commission to develop legislation aimed at prohibiting the importation of products manufactured through any form of forced labour or modern slavery. In addition, I supported the reference to the Union's manufacturing industry, which is too often neglected in favour of the services sector.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I objected to this report by the INTA Committee on a new and innovative trade and investment strategy, which is a ram that is supposed to break the doors to any form of protectionism in favour of global standards and, of course, the king market. Thus, this text is a plea for a "global economy", which has already shown its disastrous consequences, except for the powerful multinationals. One of the report's most aberrant proposals is the creation of an international arbitration tribunal to "protect international investment", i.e. to give power to large groups at the expense of sovereign states and their citizens. Finally, the alternative report of the Green Group is no better since, if it has the merit of denouncing austerity policy and unfair international competition, wants to go further than the original text on the international arbitration tribunal, which would only permanently lay sovereignty in the hands of the large groups.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report being voted on is clearly in favour of the Union's trade policies. There is no reference at all to the need to involve the national institutions of the Member States in the process of trade negotiations with third countries, on which entire production sectors of Italian and European Made in, such as TTIP, depend. Furthermore, the text does not mention the trade war with Russia caused by wrong EU policies that brought thousands of our businesses to their knees. For these reasons, I did not want to support the text with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against the report. Eu trade policy is fundamentally governed by the profit interests of large European companies. The trade agenda under Commissioners Mandelson, De Gucht and now Malmström are examples of this. Perhaps with the difference that the Commission has a slightly softer choice of words in recent years, it has been inspired by the growing popular criticism of trade agreements such as TTIP. But in real action, nothing has changed.  The report supports the policy pursued by the Commission and supports, among other things, the undemocratic TTIP and TiSA agreements currently being negotiated, including special courts (ICS) where large companies can sue states. The report also contains some positive wording, for example on the participation of the ILO, CSR requirements and the role of UNCTAD. But fundamentally, the report continues to support the trade policy governed by the profit interests of large European companies, which is why I have voted against.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Union's new trade and investment strategy goes through a more effective trade policy, to generate new, more transparent economic opportunities, opening up trade negotiations to greater public control by publishing its key, more responsible, texts, redoubled efforts to ensure responsible management of supply chains, safeguarding the European social and regulatory model within the Union and promoting European values such as sustainable development in the world , human rights, fair and ethical trade and the fight against corruption. This initiative report welcomes the Union's new trade and investment strategy while requiring greater transparency in trade negotiations, strengthening control of respect for labour and environmental standards throughout the supply chain, including legally binding chapters on human rights, social, environmental and labour standards, including principles of corporate social responsibility. Moreover, on a socialist initiative, the report calls for intensified efforts to use trade negotiations as a tool to promote gender equality around the world. For all these reasons, I supported the report with my vote.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament endorses the Commission's promising and innovative strategy for the future on trade and investment. Today, the European Union has the world's richest economy, but in the future the economic importance of the EU will diminish. An effective, comprehensive and forward-looking trade and investment strategy is therefore essential for the European Union. 2015 The Commission has proposed a new trade and investment strategy for the European Union "Trade for all. Towards a more responsible trade and investment policy".
