The Commission has adopted a new trade and investment strategy, a future-oriented innovative future trade and investment strategy that takes into account the EU's new challenges. In this strategy, the Commission sets itself a clear objective of rapidly accelerating trade liberalisation and further integrating the European Union into global value chains. In view of the external challenges facing the EU, one of the priorities is the consistency of the EU's trade objectives with other aspects of its external policies. We need to develop our trade and investment agreements in such a way that they are an effective tool for strengthening sustainable development worldwide, promoting human rights, labour and social standards and promoting environmental sustainability. As the global trade arena is changing rapidly, the Commission needs to keep up to date with the trade strategy.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is currently the most powerful economy in the world. However, the economic importance of the European Union will diminish: the centre of wealth creation will be shifted east towards the Asia-Pacific region, and demographic changes will also have a negative impact on the UNION's position on the world trade stage. An effective, comprehensive and forward-looking economic and investment strategy is therefore crucial for the European Union. 21st century trade policy must respond to people's concerns. We need greater transparency, participation and accountability for all relevant stakeholders. Trade and investment agreements must be shaped to serve as a powerful means of strengthening sustainable development and promoting human rights, labour and social standards and environmental sustainability worldwide. I voted in favour of this decision because it formulats strategies to achieve these objectives.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I also supported the proposed report on a forward-looking and innovative strategy for trade and investment. This kind of trade policy is of exceptional, even vital importance to the EU. The report represents the EP's reply to the Commission's 2015 Strategy Paper Trade for All – a more responsible trade and investment policy that takes into account most of the challenges ahead for the EU in the trade field in the coming years. I fully support the report's direction that transparency must be strengthened in the context of the negotiations on trade agreements, people's concerns must be raised and the importance of agreements for the future of the European economy must be properly presented to them. The call on the Commission to extend the transparency initiative to all future negotiations therefore seems to me to be crucial in strengthening citizens' confidence in the EU institutions. I have long said that european standards must be insisted on when negotiating international agreements. Whether that applies to respect for the principle of subsidiarity with regard to the cultivation of GMOs or animal welfare standards. The provision in the report, which warns that imports of agricultural products into the EU should only be allowed in cases where these products comply with European standards for consumer protection, animal welfare and environmental protection and minimum social standards, seems to me to be a good indication that we do not intend to derogate from our standards in the EU.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report and believe that Europe really needs to be open to trade, creating jobs and increasing growth. But I also think that this openness should be linked to ensure that ordinary people benefit from this trade as well. I therefore call on the Commission to deliver on its promises, while also welcoming the efforts to achieve communication as a significant shift towards the values that our group has been advocating from the beginning.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This text highlights some positive directions such as combating the illicit trade in wildlife products, strengthening some trade defences such as the protection of AOCs, or taking into account a number of social and environmental values at WTO level, or denying China market economy status. Nevertheless, and on the other hand, it advocates free trade, an end to all protectionism and the convergence of international norms. As I believe this will mean the bankruptcy of developed countries including France, I voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Whilst there was some constructive language around low-carbon economies, illegal wildlife trade and some mention of the precautionary principle, overall this is a very negative report which contained some very regressive provisions. In particular, it called for the Trade Agreement CETA to be ratified as swiftly as possible for the ‘future interests of EU businesses’. Sinn Féin in Europe have worked tirelessly on highlighting the dangers of these trade agreements. Moreover, it welcomes the TTIP reading rooms for MEPs as a Commission ‘transparency initiative’. This is despite the fact that any MEP has to sign a confidentiality agreement before entering the room. It should further be remembered that what’s inside the reading room is just the tip of the iceberg: the most sensitive documents are still hidden to MEPs and even national governments. Moreover, it recognises the Commission’s efforts in bringing forward the new Investment Court System, which holds the sole purpose of allowing corporations to sue governments for enacting policies through the democratic system. It was for these reasons that I voted against this resolution and in favour of both alternative resolutions since they cover Sinn Féin’s main concerns on corporate trade.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A forward-looking trade strategy that is sustainable in the long term is of great importance to the European Union. It is a fact that the EU's trade weight is decreasing: 23.7% of the volume of global trade represented today by Europe will decrease to 15% in 2050. The EU needs to integrate more closely into the chains of increased commercial value of goods and services produced or managed, focusing on innovation and sustainability to cope with the trend towards shifting wealth and the centre of global trade to the Asia-Pacific area. The increased public attention to this issue, combined with the approaching new trade negotiations by the EU and the as yet unresolved context of the economic crisis, should spur us to call for greater transparency in the negotiations and decision-making procedures together with the full involvement of the interesting, local, national and European parties, bearing in mind the positive contribution to internal cohesion and the increase in the quality of negotiations resulting from the action taken by all parties. , in a cohesive and harmonious way, towards the common effort.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report considers that trade agreements cannot be limited to lower tariffs but must be intended to bring international standards together. Paradoxically, this text advocates combating all forms of protectionism while proposing to include social and environmental clauses in future trade agreements and to condition tariff concessions on respect for democracy and human rights.  Although this report defends the fight against illegal trade in wildlife products and opposes China's market economy status, I have opposed this text, which makes the removal of tariff and non-tariff barriers its priority. Finally, I would like to point out that the rapporteur welcomes the creation of an arbitration tribunal which will bring States and their peoples to their knees before multinationals. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is currently the richest economy in the world. Unfortunately, according to specialist forecasts, by 2050, the EU 28 will represent only 15% of world GDP, down from 23.7% in 2013, so that the wealth generation centre will move eastwards to the Asia-Pacific region.  In view of this slippage, I believe that a comprehensive and forward-looking trade and investment strategy is urgently needed to provide a revival of economic and trade activities. I support the need for a trade policy that responds to citizens' concerns, and at the same time we need more transparency, commitment and accountability to all parties involved. I was in favour of this report, considering that EU trade policy is of particular geopolitical and economic importance for Europe to shape globalisation, strengthen international standards and improve access to foreign markets.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Trade negations have brought public attention to European trade policy. While many EU citizens believe globalisation will result in job losses, the contribution of foreign trade to the development of the European economy is important. As wealth shifts eastward, the economic importance of the EU in the world trade scene will decline. It is important for the EU to devise an effective, comprehensive and forward-looking trade and investment strategy. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report so that there will be increased transparency and openness at all stages of trade negations and greater coherence between the EU’s commercial objectives and other aspects of its external policy on trade for development. This will enhance synergies between trade and internal market policies. The opening-up of trade will also lead to higher productivity, increased external competitiveness and brings significant consumer benefits. This future strategy for trade and investment will be a powerful means to strengthen sustainable development, promote human rights, labour and social standards and environmental sustainability worldwide.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on a new and innovative future strategy for trade and investment. Foreign trade is an essential factor in the development of the European economy. In 2015, the European Commission proposed a new EU trade and investment strategy.  21st century trade policy must address the concerns of the public. It needs to be more transparent, more engaged and more accountable. The coherence of the Union's trade objectives with other facets of its foreign policy is a priority in the face of the challenges facing the Union, such as the migration challenge. The aim is to strengthen sustainable development and promote human rights as well as social and environmental standards around the world.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on a new innovative and forward-looking strategy on trade and investment because corporate social responsibility is a strategic tool for achieving a more competitive, socially cohesive society capable of modernising and strengthening the European social model. The European Union must work to ensure that trade and human rights can strengthen each other. The business community, which is also obliged to respect human rights, can also play an important role by offering incentives to promote human rights, democracy, environmental standards and corporate social responsibility. The Union will have succeeded in its ambitious objective if it is able to establish a trade and investment policy based also on values and not just on the market.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution. While there were was some constructive language around low-carbon economies, illegal wildlife trade and some mention of the precautionary principle, overall this was a very negative report which contained some very regressive provisions.  In particular, it called for the Trade Agreement CETA to be ratified as swiftly as possible for the ‘future interests of EU businesses’. Sinn Féin in Europe have worked tirelessly to highlight the dangers of these trade agreements.  It welcomes the TTIP reading rooms for MEPs as a Commission ‘transparency initiative’ despite the fact that any MEP has to sign a confidentiality agreement before entering the room. It should be remembered that what’s inside the reading room is just the tip of the iceberg; the most sensitive documents are still hidden to MEPs and even national governments. The resolution also recognises the Commission’s efforts in bringing forward the new Investment Court System, which holds the sole purpose of allowing corporations to sue governments for enacting policies through the democratic system. For these reasons I voted against this resolution and in  favour of both alternative resolutions since they cover Sinn Féin’s main concerns on corporate trade.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which proposes a forward-looking and innovative strategy for the EU in the field of trade and investment, taking account of the challenges that come along with globalisation. Globalisation is not an enemy to the EU but an opportunity for economic growth and job creation once matched with a compatible trade framework. Good interactions between the European and global markets are of mutual interest for both. I therefore welcome open, transparent and updated trade agreements that help the EU realise the full potential of the Single Market and maintain its competitiveness in the world.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The phenomenon of globalisation is increasingly perceived as a potential cause of job losses and lowering the level of social protection. In order to avoid such negative implications, it is therefore important for the Union to identify a clear trade and investment strategy. This was presented by the Commission in 2015 and in the report in a way that I fully support, it is emphasised that, given the external challenges facing the EU, coherence between the Union's trade objectives and other aspects of its foreign policy remains a priority. Trade agreements must also become effective instruments for promoting sustainable development, human rights and standards of social, labour and environmental standards. I certainly voted in favour.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome the new strategy proposed by the Commission entitled ‘Trade for all – Towards a more responsible trade and investment policy’. Therefore, I also support this resolution. One of our biggest future challenges will be to keep the EU’s position as a global trade player; for that, it is necessary to have solid trade agreements with third countries, which would bring more jobs and growth. We have to waive protectionist practices and support free trade outside of the European Union just as we have done within it.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Increasing globalization has shifted production and growth to third countries, particularly those in Asia and the Pacific. While international trade is an opportunity for all, the possibility of the Eu ropean Union conceding trade agreements with international partners raises concerns for businesses and citizens who fear job losses and market share. An example of this is the TTIP, on which many people fear that this agreement could lead to a weakening of European standards in social, health or environmental policies.  Given the impact these negotiations can have on the economy, it is important that these are conducted transparently by publishing content and updates. Above all, however, the European Commission, as a negotiator, must develop models of trade and investment agreements where environmental sustainability and respect for human rights are essential conditions for starting and closing negotiations. Parliament wanted to emphasise and insist on respect for workers' rights and the ban on imports into the EU of goods produced through forced labour or without compliance with environmental standards in the supply chain. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. – We support the report, as we believe that an effective, integrated and dynamic trade and investment policy is fundamental to the European Union.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on a new long-term and innovative strategy for trade and investment. Such efforts are not necessarily negative, as they can serve to improve conditions in the economic sector, trade and business.  However, I believe that this report focuses too much on strengthening existing policy without providing solutions and without proposing changes to the trade strategy, to the defence of jobs or to climate change. That's why I didn't.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on 'a new, innovative and forward-looking strategy on trade and investment' as I consider it extremely important to implement an effective, comprehensive and forward-looking trade and investment strategy that responds to the EU's new challenges. I believe that the new trade policy must be a policy that is increasingly attentive to the concerns of citizens, capable of ensuring greater transparency, commitment and accountability. A new trade and investment strategy can also help to strengthen sustainable development, human rights, labour social standards and global sustainability.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am convinced that the strategy presented by the Commission on guidelines for international trade has very good potential. In fact, the proposal brings to light important phenomena, including the increasing use of the digital economy. In this regard, the rapporteur is right to point out that it is essential that the European Union's trade policy should keep pace with digital and technological trends because, in my opinion, falling behind would mean losing part of the market that would end up in non-European countries. A second point that is very close to my heart is the inclusion of a chapter calling for greater attention to be paid to the specific needs of small and medium-sized enterprises so that they can take full advantage of trade and investment agreements and thus conduct international activities, including outside the European Union. I am therefore convinced that this is a good proposal and have therefore voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report and had no objections to it.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Promoting jobs, growth and investment is the european Union's priority challenge. In this way, the EU should develop an effective, comprehensive and forward-looking trade and investment strategy that take account of the EU's new challenges.  I agree with the need for a strategy that increases the level of transparency, involvement and accountability of all stakeholders, addressing people's concerns about transparency and participation, well-being and jobs, business expectations for a global and interconnected economy, the fight against poverty and the need to ensure a fairer distribution of income from trade , to address new issues such as digital commerce.  A future-looking trade policy should pay more attention to the specific needs of micro-enterprises and SMEs and ensure that they can fully benefit from trade and investment agreements. At the same time, an effective enforcement mechanism should be included with regard to labour and environmental rights similar to that applied to the verification of human rights.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the Commission's resolution on a new trade policy for Europe within the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy. I regret that the Commission does not set out clear priorities. With our own-initiative report, we are showing a necessary and concrete focus on specific issues and sending a clear signal to the Commission that, among other things, we need to move the Digital Single Market and also the trade in digital services forward with more investment.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 THE EU's trade policy is extremely important geopolitically and economically in order to strengthen international standards and increase access to foreign markets. The Commission's new strategy is a more responsible trade and investment policy with a new emphasis on supply chain management and the global digital market. I voted in favour of the new strategy because it aims to combat forms of protectionism in trade policy, including by reducing unnecessary non-tariff barriers, and to guarantee new opportunities for market access, particularly for SMEs. I believe that open, responsible and free world trade, based on effective, transparent and sound global rules, is essential to realise the full potential of the single market, making it work and growing and making it beneficial to citizens, consumers and businesses, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises. Opening up trade leads to increased productivity, contributes to increased external competitiveness, employment and brings considerable benefits for consumers.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Trade policy needs to be relevant within market changing circumstances. Trade has moved towards digitalisation and is driven by innovation. It has embraced e-commerce and cross-border data flows. SMEs need the EU to have a solid forward-looking strategy that builds on a coherent industrial policy, research and the digital agenda.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report deals with the Commission's latest communication: 'Trade for all'. I voted against it as this new communication reaffirms the direction in the Union's trade policy towards accelerating the liberalisation of public services. I have not been able to vote in favour of the report because in my view the Union's trade policy should take a 180-degree turn and be respectful of asymmetry in each bloc and between blocs and should be based on fair trade and not on achieving the maximum benefit of European interests. That's why I voted against it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 At a time of low economic growth, the contribution of external trade is crucial both in terms of employment and in bringing benefits to consumers, in particular through increased competition, lower prices, increased choice and the promotion of innovation. The European Parliament resolution welcomes the European strategy on trade policy presented by the Commission. By voting in favour of the resolution, I intend to support this new European approach to trade policy, which emphasises elements such as responsible supply chain management, the global digital market, trade in digital goods and services, fair and ethical trade and the social costs of trade liberalisation, which reduces unnecessary non-tariff barriers , which ensures the strong participation of society and at the same time protects citizens. A new and strategic European trade policy must ensure new market access opportunities for micro-enterprises and SMEs. In this respect, it is necessary to pay more attention to their specific needs and to ensure that they can take full advantage of trade and investment agreements, reduce trade costs through the streamlining of customs procedures, the reduction of non-tariff barriers and the simplification of rules.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The economic importance of the European Union is expected to diminish and the focus on wealth creation will shift towards the Asian region. An effective and forward-looking economic and investment strategy is therefore crucial for the Union. The Commission proposed the strategy in October 2015. Interest in trade agreements has increased, more and more EU citizens are concerned about the negative effects of globalisation, so 21st century trade policy must also respond to people's concerns. We need more transparency. Given the external challenges facing the EU, coherence between EU trade objectives and other aspects of EU external policy is important. Trade agreements should be shaped to serve as a powerful means of strengthening sustainable development and promoting human rights and environmental sustainability. The global trade scene is changing rapidly and the Commission should regularly update the trade strategy and prepare an annual implementation report. In its report, the European Parliament welcomes the Commission's commitment that no trade agreement will yield on the results of European consumer protection standards. Parliament will continue to monitor the various negotiations and urges the Commission to speed up its procedures so that it can refer the negotiated trade agreements to Parliament within a shorter period of time.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In October 2015, following several requests from the European Parliament, the European Commission adopted a communication setting out the European Union's trade strategy for the coming years. This strategy focuses for the first time on a value-based approach to trade, highlighting not only the importance of market access issues, but also the importance of the principles and values that underpin and take into account new trade agreements, such as the increased need to make trade policy more inclusive and more transparent. I support open and free trade and have welcomed the new strategy. The ECR Group tabled a number of amendments in an effort to highlight Parliament's sustained support for the completion of ongoing trade negotiations with major partners such as the US and Japan, as well as for the opening of new negotiations, not only with similar partners such as Australia and New Zealand, but also with some large emerging economies in the Asia-Pacific region. In view of the fact that the final wording is balanced by certain demands for increased market access to large and growing economies, as well as increased support for small and medium-sized enterprises in order to take advantage of the opportunities offered by trade, I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as it demands that trade policy should focus on delivering tangible improvement in the living conditions of all citizens. There is also an important reference to taking account of the needs of SMEs. The report introduces a significant shift towards value-based trade, which also increases cooperation in the fight against corruption, tax fraud and tax evasion. I strongly agree that we need to be open to trade in order to further increase jobs and growth. The Commission needs to deliver on its promises and ensure that the Transparency Initiative is applied to all ongoing trade negotiations.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, given its focus on increased support for small and medium-sized enterprises and expanding market access into growing economies of the world. However, I have some concerns about certain protectionist elements of the report which my Conservative colleagues have argued against in the International Trade Committee.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trade for All strategy, published last October by the European Commission, finally puts transparency, sustainable development, the fight against poverty and corruption at the forefront, demonstrating a new approach to trade, based on the promotion of common values and respect for human rights. At the same time, however, the strategy does not adequately highlight some of the issues that I consider to be strategic: I am referring, for example, to the issue of the protection and revitalisation of European manufacturing industry, a sector that is just as important as the one that is most often mentioned in services. I am also referring to the issue of modernising trade defence instruments and the need to re-establish conditions of equal competitiveness with our major partners. In this context, I would like to point out that the strategy makes no mention of the issue of market economy status, which Beijing would like to see recognised in a few months' time and which would have very strong negative repercussions precisely on the European productive fabric. With this report, Parliament is expressing its guidelines to the European Commission, which will have to demonstrate in practice a real change of pace in the progress of the European trade agenda by putting people, citizens, workers and businesses back at the centre. That is why I voted strongly in favour of this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to set out the European Parliament's priorities on the European trade strategy. International trade is indeed a major issue for the European Union, which is the world's leading trading power.  This is also a crucial issue for the European agri-food sector (EUR 12 billion and 6% growth in 2015), so I wanted the Committee on Agriculture to take up this issue via an opinion for the Committee on International Trade. I believe that European agriculture must develop new markets on the international stage in order to support and develop its production, but it is also necessary to protect certain productions, whose abolition of tariffs on the products of its competitors would undermine the existence. I believe that agriculture should not be used as a bargaining chip for other sectors such as services or industry. Finally, the protection of our know-how and the wealth of our territories is a priority: trade agreements must not be concluded without the recognition of European geographical indications (GI) by our partners.  Considering that these principles are contained in the final report, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We feel that the best way for international trade to proceed is for nation states to agree deals with each other, not for the EU to create yet more trouble in international trade with its demands. We feel that an independent Britain, which is now on the horizon of being made official, will be a leader and example in this regard.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the new innovative future strategy for trade and investment because it takes into account the evolution of international trade policy and economic realities in proposing a medium- and long-term trade strategy. This new trade and investment strategy must also integrate the fight against corruption and tax evasion to be fully effective and transparent. Finally, the spirit of reciprocity and mutual benefit must be the prerequisite for the European Union's trade relations with its partners.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. In order for the European Union to remain a major commercial player on the international stage, it is of course essential to develop an innovative future strategy for trade and investment, which is why I supported this report.  However, I would also like to support the statements of my fellow Member of the European Parliament Esther Herranz Garcia: as a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, I too would like to say once again that agriculture is too often a variable in the adjustment of these trade negotiations. As I have said on other occasions, this should no longer be the case! While trade agreements with third countries are necessary, and bring many significant benefits, let us not forget to protect sensitive sectors such as agriculture, ensuring that it is not sacrificed for the benefit of other sectors! I hope that European citizens, and in particular farmers, will know that we understand their concerns and that we are taking action to protect their interests!

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is currently the most powerful economy in the world. However, the economic importance of the European Union will diminish: the centre of wealth creation will be shifted east towards the Asia-Pacific region, and demographic changes will also have a negative impact on the UNION's position on the world trade stage. An effective, comprehensive and forward-looking economic and investment strategy is therefore crucial for the European Union. 21st century trade policy must respond to people's concerns. We need greater transparency, participation and accountability for all relevant stakeholders. Trade and investment agreements must be shaped to serve as a powerful means of strengthening sustainable development and promoting human rights, labour and social standards and environmental sustainability worldwide.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This strategy promotes a more prosperous future for the European economy. In fact, today the European market is the largest in the world but due to emerging markets in Asia, such as China and India, the European economy is expected to shrink. In addition, the strategy supports trade and investment agreements to strengthen sustainable development, promote human rights, social and labour standards. For these reasons, I felt it was important to vote in favour of this strategy.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. This text provides critical support for the Commission's new trade strategy for the European Union (which aims to ensan world trade to values and increase bilateral agreements) while highlighting the shortcomings.  One of the reasons I voted for this text was because a number of amendments were able to cross the line. The resolution stresses the need for transparency in trade negotiations. It indicates that trade is not an end in itself but a means of strengthening social, environmental and working conditions. We also stressed the importance of restoring an industrial base to Europe and protecting Europe from unfair practices. In this case, we caution against the status of a market economy for China. We call for the unblocking of the reform of trade defence instruments, reciprocity in access to public procurement, and consideration of the particularities of certain sectors, notably agriculture where our interests are mainly defensive.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Trade and investment must support growth and jobs. Hence the importance of an appropriate European strategy. The EU's trade policy must defend the interests of Europeans, producers and consumers. It must be conducted in a transparent manner, especially in trade agreement negotiations. And to involve civil society and national parliaments much more with its objectives, so that the defence of our interests is truly taken into account.  In this spirit, Europe must quickly strengthen its trade defence instruments, and adopt a unique, unambiguous position vis-à-vis China by refusing to grant it market economy status until Beijing has carried out the necessary reforms.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. According to the report, trade agreements must go beyond lowering tariffs, aiming for convergence of international standards and combating all forms of protectionism. The text aims to include human rights, social and environmental standards in trade policy. This text has some positive aspects such as the fight against the illegal trade in wildlife products or the denial of China's market economy status. Nevertheless, it aims for more free trade in services, a convergence of international standards and welcomes a future international arbitration tribunal to protect investment. So I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today the EU is the richest economy in the world, but over time this will change. The centre of wealth generation is shifting eastwards towards the Asia-Pacific region and demographic development will also have a negative impact on the EU's position on the global trading scene. For this reason, I believe that the EU, and in particular every Member State, needs to develop a strategy for the sustainable development of the economy.  Together with this strategy, the EU needs to provide more information to its citizens on TTIP, CETA and TiSA, because it is believed that they will not help the Economic Growth of the Union, but on the contrary will help to impose corporations on national states. There are serious concerns that the signing of these contracts will raise the unemployment rate.  All this is affected in Tyiana Begin's report on the new forward-looking and innovative future strategy for trade and investment, and i therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The trade and investment strategy should be based on improving the regulatory frameworks for the development of enterprises, in particular micro and SMEs as well as agriculture within the EU, based on the specificities of each country and on its sustainable development.  The primary objective is the prosperity of countries and not of business at the expense of citizens and states.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is currently the most powerful economy in the world. However, the economic importance of the European Union will diminish: the centre of wealth creation will be shifted east towards the Asia-Pacific region, and demographic changes will also have a negative impact on the UNION's position on the world trade stage. An effective, comprehensive and forward-looking economic and investment strategy is therefore crucial for the European Union. 21st century trade policy must respond to people's concerns. We need greater transparency, participation and accountability for all relevant stakeholders. Trade and investment agreements must be shaped to serve as a powerful means of strengthening sustainable development and promoting human rights, labour and social standards and environmental sustainability worldwide. In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's trade policies should aim to achieve greater prosperity, equality and social progress for all, and this excellent report by the 5 Star Movement is a step in the right direction. The report insists on the need to have a more transparent, accountable and effective trade policy, which will primarily protection small and medium-sized enterprises and farmers, with agreements that bring tangible benefits to citizens and that are in harmony with the sustainable development goals that this planet needs. I voted in favour.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Currently, the EU is the richest economy in the world. However, its economic importance is expected to decline: by 2050, the EU 28 will account for only 15% of world GDP, up from 23.7% in 2013. The centre of wealth generation is moving east to the Asia-Pacific region and demographic change will also have negative effects on the EU's position on the global trade landscape. It is therefore essential for the European Union to develop an effective, comprehensive and forward-looking trade and investment strategy. In its 'Trade for All' strategy, the Commission sets out the clear objective of rapidly increasing trade liberalisation and further integrating the EU into global value chains to which it must add to the modernisation of its trade defence system.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I am voting against the Greens' report, which calls for the fight against protectionism, more free trade, free trade in the services sector, a convergence of international standards and an arbitration tribunal to protect investment.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is good that the Eu ropean Union should have a strategy on trade and investment that is appropriate to the times ahead. We know that the economic importance of the European continent is threatened by the advance of the Asian giants, mainly for demographic reasons. This strategy will, of course, have to take into account the specificities of our economic systems, but also the need to update the Union's trade defence system. We fully support the proposal to shape trade and investment agreements in such a way that they become effective instruments for strengthening sustainable development, promoting human rights, social and labour standards and environmental sustainability worldwide.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has proposed a trade and investment strategy for the EU entitled 'Trade for all: Towards a more responsible trade and investment policy'. This report focuses on this strategy, the objective of which is to accelerate the deregulation and liberalisation of trade and to further integrate the EU into global value chains.  This is a presupposition that separates the waters and dictates the fate of this report – with more or less regulatory flourishes (namely 'green' and 'social'), of the two: either whether it is for free trade or if it is for regulated trade. The rapporteur opts for free trade, underpining her dogmas, and that is her original sin. In this context, calls for an EU trade defence system that is urgently modernised, especially in view of China's firm call for market economy status. This is also an inquinado debate for other reasons. What about the human rights safeguard clause in the Association Agreement between Israel and the EU? Has this agreement ever been called into question, despite the successive human rights violations of palestinian people on their own territory on a daily basis?

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as I consider it of great importance to seek new trade and investment strategies, in line with the 2020 Strategy and adapted to new challenges and changes worldwide.  A strategy is needed that takes into account new factors such as the digital economy or the growing responsibility of emerging countries. I also think it is important to give one voice to the Union in these matters, so that we can promote our values through trade and make it fairer and more ethical.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU can now see itself as the most prosperous economy in the world. However, the EU's economic importance is set to decline. Indeed, the centre of wealth production is moving eastwards, more precisely towards the Asia-Pacific region, and demographic developments will also have a negative impact on the EU's position in world trade. It is therefore extremely important for the European Union to define an effective, global and forward-looking trade and investment strategy. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of this report because, it stresses that policy must provide immediate responses to citizens' concerns about trade strategy. Specifically, the European institutions must ensure greater transparency, commitment and accountability to all stakeholders.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU is currently the richest economy in the world. However, economic importance is gradually declining and forecasts say that in 2050 Europe will account for 15% of world GDP. This is due, on the one hand, to deteriorating demographic developments, which have a negative impact on the EU's position on the world trade scene, as well as the shift of production eastwards to the Asia-Pacific region. Therefore, an effective, comprehensive and forward-looking trade and investment strategy is crucial for the EU. In the presented 'Trade for All' strategy, the EC has set out a clear objective for a rapid increase in trade liberalisation, which means that we need to modernise the EU trade defence system as quickly as possible. We also need greater transparency and accountability for all actors.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report which fully supports the Commission's trade policies, including the TTIP, Ceta and Tisa agreements, to which I have always been opposed and sceptical.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on a new long-term and innovative future strategy for trade and investment, as the trade and investment strategy should be based on improving the regulatory frameworks for business development, particularly for micro and SMEs as well as agriculture within the EU, based on the specificities of each country and in the light of its sustainable development.  The primary objective is the prosperity of countries and not of business at the expense of citizens and states.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report contains Parliament’s reaction to the Commission’s ‘Trade for All’ Communication on its future trade policy. It welcomes the communication as a significant shift towards value-based trade in line with our Group’s position but insists that the Commission must deliver on its promises. The report reaffirms Parliament’s previous recommendations on the TTIP and TiSA negotiations and its opposition to granting market economy status to China. Since it is a horizontal report it does not prejudge any final position by our Group on any particular trade agreement or the proposed Investment Court System. Instead it refers to ongoing debates. The report emphasises the need to account for the needs of SMEs and the manufacturing sector in trade policy which must be in line with a re-industrialisation strategy and SMEs. It deplores the Council’s inactivity on the reform of trade defence instruments.  I believe Europe needs to be open to trade in the interest of jobs and growth. But that openness needs to be flanked with the right international rules and domestic safety nets to ensure ordinary people can benefit from trade. I support the call on the Commission to deliver on its promises on value-based trade and demand that the TTIP transparency initiative is extended to all ongoing trade negotiations.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is currently the most powerful economy in the world. However, the economic importance of the European Union will diminish: the centre of wealth creation will be shifted east towards the Asia-Pacific region, and demographic changes will also have a negative impact on the UNION's position on the world trade stage. An effective, comprehensive and forward-looking economic and investment strategy is therefore crucial for the European Union. 21st century trade policy must respond to people's concerns. We need greater transparency, participation and accountability for all relevant stakeholders. Trade and investment agreements must be shaped to serve as a powerful means of strengthening sustainable development and promoting human rights, labour and social standards and environmental sustainability worldwide.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on an innovative future strategy for trade and investment. We need to recognise Europe's current challenges not only because of the Brexit referendum, but also in terms of our global ambitions. At present, the EU is the strongest economy in the world, but our economic importance will decrease by 2050 and the 28 EU Member States (still) will represent only 15% of the world's GDP, compared with 23.7% in 2013. The centre of wealth accumulation will be shifted east towards the Asia-Pacific region and demographic changes will also have a negative impact on the EU's position on the world trade scene. Many EU citizens identify globalisation with job losses and are concerned that EU trade and investment policy could undermine European standards. We must listen to their concerns. At the same time, the contribution of foreign trade to the development of the European economy is essential. However, we need greater transparency, participation and accountability for all relevant stakeholders.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report considering that it is vital for the European economy to have an appropriate strategy at the commercial level that benefits businesses and citizens equally. We must have an innovative and forward-sighted strategy on trade and investment that responds to citizens' concerns. We need more transparency, participation and accountability in relation to all parties involved to change the view that more trade and globalisation results in the unprotection of the European citizen. Trade is and should be one of the pillars of the growth of the EU economy, but bearing in mind that its existence must benefit society as a whole.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report presents and achieves several important conclusions and outlines important policy lines that we should consider moving forward.  The convergence of the external actions and policies of the EU and the Union’s trade policies and objectives is one of these important guidelines. It will give our external action much stronger backing while providing our external trade relations with diplomatic backing. I am also happy that the report calls for the Commission to address the needs of SMEs horizontally in all chapters of our trade agreements: this is very important as SMEs are the economic backbone of the European economy.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Investment and growth are essential to relaunch Europe's role in the world and to better protect employment and the social model, and the message we have sent as a Parliament in response to the commission's new trade strategy is therefore important.  Europe must continue to protect trade openings, but we need guarantees of respect for international rules and protection for our consumers and for European competitiveness. I therefore supported the report that has just been voted on because it paints a clear perspective on sustainability and progress, in particular with the introduction for the first time of the call for trade policies to be used effectively and intelligently to combat illegal practices such as corruption and tax evasion at international level.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on a new, innovative and forward-looking strategy on trade and investment, because I believe that in future the Common Commercial Policy (CPC) must be able to adapt to rapid changes in global trade trends, so that more responsible management of supply chains, the global digital market, fair and ethical trade are considered to be social costs of trade liberalisation. The eu's new CPC to the rest of the world must combat forms of protectionism, including by reducing unnecessary non-tariff barriers, and ensure new opportunities for market access, particularly for SMEs. The Commission must ensure a strong and balanced participation of civil society and the social partners, in order to improve the content of EU trade policy and to direct it towards the defence of citizens' rights, thereby strengthening their legitimacy. This also requires greater coherence between the EU's trade objectives and industrial policy, and in the context of external action between the CSC and development policy. Finally, I strongly supported the opposition to the granting of market economy status to China and the need for effective trade defence instruments.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on a forward-looking innovative strategy for trade and investment because it addresses an issue that I have been stressing time and again since my election to the European Parliament: the EU must be a world leader in the development of new, transparent and democratically controlled 'fair trade agreements'.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome this own-initiative report as it focuses more on the innovations of future trade and investment strategies. These also take into account new issues and economic sectors such as the digital economy, approaches to dealing with international value chains and the fight against corruption and tax evasion.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which contains Parliament’s reaction to the Commission’s ‘Trade for All’ communication on its future trade policy. It also reaffirms Parliament’s previous recommendations on the TTIP and TiSA negotiations. While not providing specific details, the report aims to set down general principles for EU trade policy. I welcome the fact that several of my Socialist group’s priorities were included into the report, including our commitment to a multilateral approach in the first instance, as well as our desire to see enforceable sustainable development chapters in trade agreements. Furthermore, we want the TTIP transparency initiative extended to all negotiations, and underline the need for further debate on the proposed Investment Court System.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I do not see how what the report proposes is a new strategy for trade and investment. Of course, it wishes to involve citizens in the conclusion of a new trade agreement by informing them. And for good reason: the ongoing negotiations on the transatlantic treaty, as well as the next ratification of the agreement with Canada, CETA, are causing hostility throughout Europe in the most diverse circles. I note that if the concerns of the citizens were really taken into account, this Parliament would be up against the TTIP negotiations and would be preparing to reject CETA. This is not the case, and for good reason: the "new strategy" consists of even more liberalisation of world trade and the flow of capital, an acceleration of globalization that only makes predatory multinationals and international finance happy. A sparadrap here and there, such as trade defence instruments that can hardly be more paltry than those we have, access to public procurement or the market for services from other countries, which will enrich businesses without really creating jobs in Europe, does not change the substance of the problem.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted abstention because, although there are some very positive aspects to this report, it is ambiguous in supporting a strategy that is essentially favourable to the free market at any price such as 'trade for all'.  We welcome the fact that it draws attention to issues that free-market dogma tends to camouflage in most debates (i.e. "considering that there has been no serious debate in the EU on free trade policies"), immediately publish negotiating mandates, strengthen policy coherence for development, and make labour rights chapters binding , social and environmental agreements. However, we cannot vote in favour since the underlying logic is the support of the Commission's strategy, and boost foreign trade as a solution to European problems and support for the Commission's trade for all strategy, which proposes a strategy for the future that can only lead the EU and its partners to deepen inequalities , the increase of which we have been experiencing for decades.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on a new, forward-looking and innovative future strategy in the field of trade and investment. The trade policy of the 21st century should respond to the concerns of society, which is currently concerned about the phenomenon of globalisation associated with job losses. That is why it is so important to shape trade and investment agreements in such a way that they are a tool for strengthening sustainable development, safeguarding human rights, labour standards and environmental sustainability worldwide. It is also essential to regularly update your trading strategy.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I encourage trade, not as an end in itself, but as a means of achieving prosperity and equality, promoting business opportunities, social progress and cultural understanding, as well as increasing the number of jobs and raising living standards without increasing public spending. In other news, I believe that the new generation of trade policies must address concerns about transparency and participation, well-being and business-like jobs of a globalised and interconnected economy. It must provide for measures to combat prosperity and ensure a fairer distribution of trade revenues, addressing issues such as digital trade and the essential role of SMEs in the development of a sustainable economy.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as it contains Parliament’s reaction to the Commission’s ‘Trade for All’ Communication on future trade policy. It welcomes the communication and supports a shift towards value-based trade whilst insisting that the Commission must deliver on its promises.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. As the attention of the public to trade agreements has increased and more citizens are worried with regard to globalisation, it is important that trade policy in the 21st century needs to respond to people’s concerns. We need more transparency, engagement and accountability towards all stakeholders involved. Additionally, the access to certain information strengthens parliamentary scrutiny and the report therefore calls on the Commission to extend the transparency initiative to all future negotiations as well as calling on the Council to publish all negotiating mandates.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is currently the most powerful economy in the world. However, the economic importance of the European Union will diminish: the centre of wealth creation will be shifted east towards the Asia-Pacific region. Demographic changes will also have a negative impact on the EU's position on the world trade scene. An effective, comprehensive and forward-looking economic and investment strategy is therefore crucial for the European Union. 21st century trade policy must reflect people's concerns. There is a need for greater transparency and accountability for all parties involved. Trade and investment agreements must be shaped to serve as a powerful means of strengthening sustainable development and promoting human rights, labour and social standards and environmental sustainability worldwide.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a group we have tabled an amendment overturning the overall text of the report. This, however, was not accepted by the plenary. The report follows the step on free trade agreements. The positives of the report call for Parliament to play a greater role and for impact analyses to be carried out on the possible impact of such agreements, but there is no criticism of the policies pursued and the impact they have on citizens. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I agreed with the focus taken by the final report and its push for an effective trade and investment policy.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is currently the most powerful economy in the world. However, the economic importance of the European Union will diminish: the centre of wealth creation will be shifted east towards the Asia-Pacific region, and demographic changes will also have a negative impact on the UNION's position on the world trade stage. An effective, comprehensive and forward-looking economic and investment strategy is therefore crucial for the European Union. 21st century trade policy must respond to people's concerns. We need greater transparency, participation and accountability for all relevant stakeholders. Trade and investment agreements must be shaped in such a way as to be a powerful means of strengthening sustainable development and promoting human rights, labour and social standards and environmental sustainability worldwide.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report amounts to business as usual for the Commission.  There is growing concern amongst Europe’s citizens with regard to the EU’s trade and investment policies and this report was an opportunity to address some of these concerns. That opportunity has been missed and I accordingly voted against.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this report which aims to adapt more quickly to rapid changes in global trade trends, to create a transparent trade policy and greater citizen participation, to establish greater coherence between the Union's trade objectives and other aspects of its foreign policy in the field of trade for development and to promote transparent global value chains that respect fundamental values and standards throughout the World World.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Europe needs to be open to trade in the interest of jobs and growth. We need commitments based on international standards, country-by-country reporting obligations and an automatic exchange of information. We also need the right international rules and domestic safety nets to ensure ordinary people can benefit from trade.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the New, Innovative and Future-Oriented Trade and Investment Strategy Report, as it encourages faster market adjustment to frequent changes in world trade. This report welcomes the Commission's new strategy entitled 'Trade for all: towards a more responsible trade and investment policy', where the focus is on responsible supply chain management, the global digital market, trade in digital goods and services, fair and ethical trade and the social cost of trade liberalisation. I voted for a report aimed at better coherence between the EU's trade objectives and other forms of Trade Union foreign policy, while also fostering transparency and respect for core values and standards worldwide.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The report notes that there has been no debate in the EU on free trade policies.  Trade agreements must go beyond lowering tariffs to a convergence of international standards. This text has some positive aspects such as combating the illegal trade in wildlife products, strengthening trade defences and no to China's market economy status. But it supports the fight against protectionism and encourages more free trade, especially in the services sector. It also encourages a convergence of international standards and an arbitration tribunal to protect investment. For all of these reasons, I objected to the text.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 If the European Union wants to maintain its economic importance in the face of competition from other parts of the world, it needs a truly effective, comprehensive and progressive trade strategy. I therefore voted in favour of the resolution calling for greater participation and accountability of all stakeholders involved in trade and greater transparency, especially in order to gain the trust of citizens. It is certainly important to call for regular annual implementation reports to enable the EU to achieve the best possible strategy thanks to current requirements.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Tiziana Beghin's report for a new trade and investment strategy. The fight against social dumping in public procurement will be a major driving force for job creation and growth. The report proposes a strategy that takes into account the constant evolution of the international trade scene, the need to ensure transparency and the imperative to promote universally shared values through trade. However, as a member of the Committee on Culture and Education, I regret that this report is not more committed to the development of the digital economy, since it is indeed a pillar of tomorrow's international trade. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to develop a much more innovative and forward-looking future strategy on trade and investment, in order to take account of the constant evolution of the international trade scene.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is crucial that the Commission updates EU trade policy in a coherent and relevant manner. We are at a time when the challenges of globalisation are creating the image that jobs are being lost for European citizens. However, this is not accurate and the Union enjoys competitive advantages which should be made more obvious to the European citizen. It is also crucial that the new circumstances lead to an update of the Union's trade objectives in order to emphasise that the EU's manufacturing sector and agricultural products are protected in relation to their designation of origin and quality.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report on a forward-looking innovative strategy for trade and investment presents the Union as the healthiest economy in the world, although the EU's economic performance is projected to decline within the next 50 years. The rapporteur calls for trade and investment agreements to be designed to promote human rights, labour standards and social standards, and calls for a reform of existing trade defence mechanisms in the face of China's demand for market economy status, while failing to make clear statements on critical issues such as geographical indications of origin, and continues to regard ISDS as a legitimate means of foreign trade. For these reasons, I do not agree with this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it contains Parliament’s reaction to the Commission’s ‘Trade for All’ Communication on its future trade policy. It welcomes the communication as a significant shift towards value-based trade but insists that the Commission must deliver on its promises.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support the European Parliament's resolution on a new and innovative future strategy for trade and investment. Business is not an end in itself. It is intended to contribute to social, economic, political prosperity and stability, sustainable economic development, social progress, cultural diversity, as well as the creation of quality jobs. It is intended to raise living standards, and the resolution did not remember that. Moreover, it did not say that more and more citizens were clearly criticising and even rejecting free trade agreements. They do not make it possible to solve all these problems and have a profound and long-term impact on the national and regional development of trading partners, on their ability to develop their own production capacities in order to guarantee long-term sustainable economic performance contributing to economic growth and prosperity of citizens. This includes the current negative impacts on macroeconomic and micro-economic relations and the conditions very often causing the abolition of SME industries, job losses, relocation of entire sectors to third countries, environmental and social dumping, disappearance of family farms and medium-sized enterprises, restrictions on access to basic public services, restrictions on cultural diversity, as well as the deterioration of negative trends such as climate degradation and persistent poverty , both in developing and industrialized countries.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report on Trade for all, trade on future strategy for trade and investment, is issued in the context of a growing opposition to those who orient policies exclusively to business. But what is missing in this report is a real change in trade strategy, to orient policies in order to defend jobs, European industrialisation and to tackle climate change. The report is better than the first outcome from the Commission, it contains some improvements and some good proposal. However I voted abstention to this report since I think that there is a lack of alternative strategy.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The recipe for multi-companies is simple: take production to where labour is cheap, it's okay to have child workers, or if there is no union advocacy, then sell the product where higher wages increase purchasing power. The result is misery and exploitation in one place, unemployment, futurelessness on the other. Shattered societies everywhere. And no matter how much profit you make, it's never enough. You just have to look at the statistics on how many families hold the vast majority of the world's wealth. Is this good for humanity? As far as possible, it is necessary to return to local production, trade, for example, you do not have to go far, only to Switzerland, Finland. And if even lending remains within the national framework, then the age of liveable societies may indeed come.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the future trade and investment strategy because I think it is necessary if the EU wants to be a factor on the international trade scene.  The contribution of external trade is crucial for the European economy, which delivers growth and creates new jobs. A transparent trade policy based on clear and consistent rules is therefore needed, addressing the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises and providing new opportunities for citizens and businesses.   In my view, trade policy should be seen as an integral part of EU foreign policy. Trade and investment agreements are of great importance to both the EU economy and the internal market. They must be transparent and ensure EU civil, labour and social standards, as well as support the fulfilment of the objectives set out in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and Environmental Protection.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Although EU trade is now at the heart of the global market, its economic importance is expected to decline in the coming years. It is therefore essential to implement a comprehensive and lasting business and investment plan. In fact, the proposal aims to assess the new strategy presented by the Commission in 2015. The report is positive about the efforts of the Commission, which has taken account of the new trade challenges facing the Union, and reiterates the complementarity between multilateral trade and plurilateral or bilateral negotiations. It also focuses on citizens' concerns about the relationship between globalisation and unemployment, and therefore calls on the Commission to increase transparency, commitment and accountability. Lastly, it calls for trade strategies and the instruments set to be constantly updated in order to contribute effectively to the promotion of sustainable development, human rights and the implementation of social and labour standards. I therefore welcome the adoption of a new, future-oriented strategy on trade and investment.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report entitled "New Innovative Future Strategy for Trade and Investment". This text has some positive aspects, such as combating the illegal trade in wildlife products, strengthening trade defences and no to China's market economy status. But he advocates the fight against protectionism, more free trade, free trade in the services sector, a convergence of international standards and an arbitration tribunal to protect investment. The report welcomes a future international arbitration tribunal to "protect" international investment. It calls for a reciprocal opening of public procurement.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The report is a non-exhaustive list of ideas to guide the EU's future trade strategy. Some positive arguments include combating the illicit trade in wildlife products, strengthening trade defences and denying China's status as a market economy.  Nevertheless, the general thrust of the text runs counter to our European and national interests, calling for the fight against protectionism, increased free trade, and a convergence of international standards... Two alternative reports have been tabled by the Green and GUE/LNG groups and oscillate between more multilateralism and ideologism. I voted AGAINST all three reports.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because the report welcomes the Union's new trade and investment strategy and puts on the table some of the absences of the Commission communication.  The report calls on the Commission to implement the recommendations made by the European Ombudsman on access to documents relating to all trade negotiations. It requires respecting Parliament's recommendations in its resolutions on the TTIP and TiSA negotiations and establishing a multilateral solution to investment disputes in the medium term. The report opposes the granting of market economy status to China. It stresses that labour and environmental standards must be respected throughout the supply chain and requests legislation from the Commission with the aim of prohibiting the importation of products manufactured through any form of forced labour or modern slavery. It requires that no trade agreement give rise to a lower level of regulatory protection, that any change in the level of protection can only be upwards and that the right to regulate public authorities is fully protected, while retaining European standards.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report deals with the Commission's latest communication: 'Trade for all'. I voted against it as this new communication reaffirms the direction in the Union's trade policy towards accelerating the liberalisation of public services. I have not been able to vote in favour of the report because in my view the Union's trade policy should take a 180-degree turn and be respectful of asymmetry in each bloc and between blocs and should be based on fair trade and not on achieving the maximum benefit of European interests. That's why I voted against it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The Commission's proposal is a new EU trade and investment strategy entitled 'Trade for all - Towards a more responsible trade and investment policy'. It is very important that this new strategy responds to citizens' concerns about globalization. Greater transparency, participation and accountability are needed for all parties involved. To this end, the Commission is requested to extend transparency in future negotiations and the Council is requested to publish all negotiating mandates. As regards the external challenges facing the Union, I believe that coherence between trade objectives and other aspects of its foreign policy is a priority. Trade agreements need to be defined and human rights, labour and social standards and environmental sustainability promoted. For all these reasons, I am voting in favour and urge the Commission to regularly update the trade strategy and to submit a detailed annual report to enable European citizens to check whether the Commission is complying with what has been agreed.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to pursue a more forward looking strategy on trade and investment in the context of global trading today.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The report calls for a nonsensical assessment of the impact of trade agreements on 'decent jobs created'. I'm all for free trade, not for making a name for it.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. Today, the EU is the richest economy in the world, but the centre of wealth creation will move eastwards in the future. Therefore, an effective, comprehensive and advanced trade and investment strategy is essential for the Union. Given the external challenges, it is necessary to align the Union's trade objectives with other foreign policy aspects. We need trade agreements that will be a means of strengthening sustainable development, promoting human rights and social standards, and sustaining the environment around the world. As the global trade scene is changing rapidly, trade strategies need to be regularly updated and annual implementation reports submitted to allow European citizens greater transparency. I supported this report because I believe that the Union's trade policy has geopolitical and economic importance in achieving globalisation, strengthening international standards, increasing access to foreign markets and creating jobs on the domestic market.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. – I support Parliament’s call on the Commission to regularly update its trade and investment strategy and to publicly present every two years a detailed implementation report to Parliament, starting in 2017, to ensure that it delivers on its promises and expedite its procedures so that negotiated trade agreements can be referred to Parliament within a shorter period of time, thereby allowing them to  be applied provisionally or entered into force more swiftly.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The strength of the Union economy depends on a number of factors. Europe's economy accounted for 23.7% of world GDP in 2013, will decline by 2050 and Europe will account for only 15% of world GDP. Eastern Asia-Pacific countries, especially China, will become the decisive player. I agree with the proposal that the Union must be prepared for this situation and must keep looking for ways and forms to strengthen its position. Trade cooperation with other countries in the world, built on mutual benefit, respect for, respect for and protection of human rights, strengthening workers' working conditions and people's social security, and protecting the environment, is a means of ensuring sustainable development and improving the quality of life of Europeans.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The Beghin report assesses the European Commission's "Trade 4 All" communication made in October. This communication sets out the Union's new trade strategy around two areas: to support trade with values of transparency, democracy and respect for human rights and, on the other hand, to promote the conclusion of bilateral agreements that create jobs and benefits equally distributed.  This report has struck a balance by supporting the Commission's communication while pointing to its limits. The latter calls for greater transparency in the negotiations, as well as the preservation of a large industrial base in Europe. It also stresses the need to remain cautious in the proliferation of trade agreements. Indeed, the cumulative impact of the contingents offered in the various negotiations could prove detrimental. This last point directly raises the problem facing the UPRs with regard to the proliferation of free trade agreements with sugar-related countries.  This report proposing significant improvements to the future strategy for trade and investment, I am voting in for.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on a forward-looking and innovative future strategy for trade and investment, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 4/7/2016, and because this Report is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
