text: In writing. I voted against both reports. This report has some positive points: the fight against illicit trade, the refusal of the granting of market economy status to China in particular.  Nevertheless, this report follows a liberal economic line by advocating greater deregulation of trade and convergence of social norms. It also proposes the creation of an arbitration tribunal to protect investments.  We also rejected the counter-report tabled by the Greens. However, it calls for the questioning of austerity policies and condemns unfair competition in trade matters. Finally, and despite its resolutely anti-liberal content, we rejected the text of the unitary left, in particular because of the insistence on human rights and the promotion of gender equality in trade.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – Regarding the report on a new forward-looking and innovative future strategy for trade and investment, I voted in favour, as innovative future strategies for trade and investment will tremendously boost economic development, and promote more business opportunities and cooperation. The successful implementation of the report will also prevent the further doubts from EU citizens and SMEs toward large industries’ associations, and the transparency of the trade will benefit all investors and ensure the fairness of the trade and investment.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome this report, which outlines strategies to keep the EU a leader in the global economy. We need more transparency in order to provide a proactive response to the economic challenges of our time; The promotion of employment and international trade without relocating jobs outside Europe. A responsible trade policy will ensure high standards of consumer and environmental protection, and will enable citizens to adapt to an evolving market.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The Aim of the Beghin Report was to critically assess the European Commission's recent "Trade 4 All" communication, which was in the process of declining the EU's trade strategy for the coming years. If I had at the time welcomed the Commission's turn towards values-based trade, I had denounced its ideological blindness to the automatic virtuous nature of free trade for workers. I also criticised the fact that the Commission too often uses the agricultural and industrial sectors as bargaining chips to promote the services sector.  The report put to the plenary vote, which I helped amend, managed to strike an interesting balance. First, we call for a drastic increase in the transparency of trade negotiations. We also believe that trade should not be an end in itself, but more a means of increasing social, environmental and labour standards on a global scale. Finally, we clearly recall the need to preserve a broad industrial base in Europe, by strengthening trade defence instruments and rejecting China's granting of market economy status. I supported that report.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This report attempts to illustrate how opening up the market is intended to generate more foreign investment and growth – a consideration that, while quickly convincing on paper, quickly falters when projected onto reality. In addition to the lack of reflection on the increased pressure on the already weak labour market through tougher competition, ISDS, for example, is regarded as a legitimate means of foreign trade.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report dares some criticism of EU trade policy, assuring that "trade is not an end in itself, but a means of ensuring prosperity and equality". Or announcing that there can be no "trade agreements without protections". The report also opposes the granting of market economy status to China until the EU has "more effective trade defence instruments". But it establishes a framework limited to these criticisms that cannot "question the contribution of free trade to economic growth".  In the end, the text merely calls for "future trade agreements and negotiations to take into account and respect the views expressed by Parliament in its resolutions on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP)". All for that? I am voting against this unnecessary text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This text has some positive aspects such as combating the illicit trade in wildlife products, strengthening trade defences and not to China's market economy status. But he calls for the fight against protectionism, more free trade in the services sector, a convergence of international standards, an arbitration tribunal to protect investment. I therefore voted against this report, as well as the greens/FTA replacement report which is for more multilateralism. He opposes the EU's new policy to "force" developing countries to cooperate on migration control and readmission procedures and against the GUE/NGL group report, as its WTO vision is not acceptable.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report in order to ensure that the European Single Market is able to adapt to the ever-changing nature of the global market. A creative and forward-thinking strategy for EU trade and investment is essential to maintain the prosperity and economic market of our Union.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. It is crucial for the European Union to define an ambitious trade and investment strategy in order to consolidate its role as the world's leading trading power. The importance is all the greater since the economic outlook for 2050 estimates that the EU should account for only 15% of world GDP (compared to 23.7% in 2013).  As this report stresses, it is imperative to combat all forms of protectionism and ensure a policy that is coherent between the internal market and external trade in order to put the priority on job creation. It is also important that this strategy takes full account of respect for human rights, social and environmental standards.  Finally, it is imperative to strengthen intellectual property rights. European creativity is our strength. Without respect for the right to intellectual property we lose one of our greatest assets.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Union is currently the richest economy in the world. However, its economic importance will decline in the coming years as the centre of wealth creation moves east to the Asia-Pacific region. Demographic developments also have a negative impact on the European Union's position on the world trading scene. The share of foreign trade in the development of the European economy is essential and an effective, comprehensive and forward-looking trade and investment strategy is therefore essential. We need greater transparency, commitment and accountability from all stakeholders, given that more and more Union citizens are concerned about globalisation. It is essential to formulate trade and investment agreements in such a way that they are an effective means of strengthening sustainable development, human rights, labour and social standards and environmental sustainability worldwide. In view of the above, I support the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because Europe needs to be open to trade in the interest of jobs and growth. But that openness needs to be flanked with the right international rules and domestic safety nets to ensure ordinary people can benefit from trade.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report, adopted on 5 July as a reaction to Commission’s Communication ‘Trade for all’ reaffirms the main themes of the European Parliament’s stance on trade, notably the mainstream idea that EU trade should contribute to growth and jobs, promote sustainable development and be consistent with other EU policy objectives. I supported this approach by voting in favour of the report. I welcome in particular the emphasis on specific needs of SMEs, on the role of recognising professional qualifications in promoting new market opportunities as well as on digital trade and on the need to cooperate with trade partners to fight against corruption, tax fraud and tax evasion.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Report of the Committee on International Trade assumes that, although the European Union is currently the world's strongest economy, its economic importance will diminish: by 2050, the 28 EU Member States will represent only 15% of world GDP, compared with 23.7% in 2013. It therefore calls for an effective, comprehensive and forward-looking economic and investment strategy for the European Union. It also notes that public interest in trade agreements has increased and that many citizens are concerned about globalisation and stresses the need for greater transparency, participation and accountability for all relevant stakeholders.  It points out that access to certain data strengthens parliamentary scrutiny and therefore recommends that the Commission extend the transparency initiative to all future negotiations and call on the Council to publish all negotiating mandates. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This text has some positive aspects such as combating the illicit trade in wildlife products, strengthening trade defences and not to China's market economy status. But it also requires combating what is akin to protectionism, it imposes even more free trade, including in the services sector, as well as a convergence of international standards and an arbitration tribunal to protect investment. Unfavorable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2009, with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Union saw its competence in trade policy expanded and has since been competent to negotiate trade agreements with third countries in accordance with Article 218 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.  Currently, the European Union is the largest trading bloc in the world, accounting for about a third of world trade. However, its economic importance is estimated to decline in the coming decades. In the framework of the new strategy, it should be stressed the importance of a coherent approach between the Union's trade objectives and other aspects of its foreign policy, as trade agreements should be understood as an instrument leading to the strengthening of sustainable development, the promotion of human rights, labour and social rights and environmental sustainability. To this end, I am voting in favour of this report, as I believe that the European Union should focus on a trade and investment strategy that provides the Union with the tools necessary to meet the new challenges of the future.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This text has some positive aspects such as combating the illicit trade in wildlife products, strengthening trade defences and not to China's market economy status.  But it calls for the fight against protectionism, more free trade, free trade in the services sector, a convergence of international standards and an arbitration tribunal to protect investment. This is therefore not acceptable and I am voting against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which sets down general principles and guidelines for EU trade policy without going into detail on specific areas.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the new innovative future strategy for trade and investment. It is essential for the European economy, which today is the world's first, to have a new strategy in order to maintain its leadership, which is expected to falter. Indeed, by 2050 the 28 EU Member States will account for only 23.7% of total GDP compared to 50% in 2013.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is important to implement an effective, comprehensive and forward-looking trade and investment strategy that can respond to the eu's new challenges. We need greater transparency, commitment and accountability to all stakeholders in order to reassure citizens who often identify globalisation with job losses today. Trade and investment agreements must be shaped in such a way that they become effective instruments for strengthening sustainable development, promoting human rights, social and labour standards and environmental sustainability worldwide. I therefore voted in favour of the measure

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In today's globalized world, the majority of people are concerned about the impact that perennoming relationships will have on their lives. I therefore welcomed this proposal, which intends to define a comprehensive and effective economic and investment strategy. It takes into account the challenges facing the European Union. I consider it very important to develop innovative solutions in these areas, as trade makes a major contribution to Economic Development in Europe. In a rapidly changing economic environment, the aim is to achieve a long-term sustainable development that ultimately leads to a trade system that benefits everyone. The European Union is currently one of the largest economies in the world and we want to maintain this position.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ On 14 October 2015 the Commission proposed the new trade and investment strategy for the EU ‘Trade for All - Towards a more responsible trade and investment policy’. Its goal is to make trade more effective by constantly updating trade policy in order to continue delivering economic opportunities. I have voted for this report that will quickly increase trade liberalisation, further integrating the EU into the global value chains.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. – Trade policy must contribute to ensuring a transparent production process throughout the value chain, as well as compliance with fundamental social, safety and environmental standards. EU trade policy must keep up with digital and technological trends, as cloud computing, mobile internet services, smart energy networks and online communication platforms are driving the radical transformation of the business environment. Although services account for 70% of GDP in the EU and will provide 90% of future jobs, EU manufacturing must be an essential component for the reindustrialisation of Europe. The strategy on the reindustrialisation of Europe must place more emphasis on the role of this sector in the EU's common trade policy.  We urge the Commission to work with trading partners to ensure that their markets are more open to EU companies, particularly in the field of transport, telecommunications and public procurement, since foreign companies belonging to them still enjoy broad access to the EU internal market.  I voted for the report on a new innovative and forward-looking strategy on trade and investment.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, where I appreciate, among other things, the Commission's efforts in the context of the new system of investment courts, which should replace criticised and not very predictable private arbitration, together with the emphasis that this system of investment courts must comply with the EU legal order, in particular the jurisdiction of the courts in the EU, and specifically with EU competition law. In this context, I support the Commission's approach to TTIP to date, including increasing transparency and openness at all stages of trade negotiations.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Whilst there was some constructive language around low-carbon economies, illegal wildlife trade and some mention of the precautionary principle, overall this is a very negative report which contained some very regressive provisions.  In particular, it called for the trade agreement CETA to be ratified as swiftly as possible for the ‘future interests of EU businesses’. Sinn Féin in Europe have worked tirelessly on highlighting the dangers of these trade agreements.  Moreover, it welcomes the TTIP reading rooms for MEPs as a Commission ‘transparency initiative’, this despite the fact that any MEP has to sign a confidentiality agreement before entering the room – and it should further be remembered that what’s inside the reading room is just the tip of the iceberg: the most sensitive documents are still hidden to MEPs and even national governments. Moreover, it recognises the Commission’s efforts in bringing forward the new Investment Court System, which holds the sole purpose of allowing corporations to sue governments for enacting policies through the democratic system.  It was for these reasons that I voted against this resolution and in  favour of both alternative resolutions since they cover Sinn Féin’s main concerns on corporate trade.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because it focuses too much on Commissioner Malmström's previous line, contains untapped statements on critical issues such as geographical indications of origin, and continues to regard ISDS as a legitimate means of foreign trade.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Economic growth in the EU has slowed, so reviewing the trade strategy is essential. It is necessary to encourage the creation of jobs and equal opportunities, fair business practices and to address new areas such as digital trade. The inflow and outflow of investment is essential for economic growth and the rights of EU companies must be protected as they expand into third-country markets. Coherence of the EU's trade objectives with EU foreign policy is also important.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled. An effective, comprehensive and forward-looking trade and investment strategy is essential for the European Union. It is essential that trade policy in the 21st century responds to people's concerns, while also paying attention to the rapid change in the global trade arena. More transparency, participation and accountability are needed for all stakeholders. The European Union will be further integrated into global value chains, as this proposal will broaden transparency policy for all future negotiations and accelerate trade liberalisation. In order to achieve a more transparent trade policy, it is essential that citizens are given the opportunity to express their will properly. I believe that the current trade defence system in the EU needs to be updated in order to provide an appropriate response to unfair practices that undermine international trade in a globalised world.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We feel that the best way for international trade to proceed is for nation states to agree deals with each other, not for the EU to create yet more trouble in international trade with its demands. We feel that an independent Britain, which is now on the horizon of being made official, will be a leader and example in this regard.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the European Commission last October proposed a new trade and investment strategy for the European Union to enable the Union to adapt its trade policy to future challenges, which the European Parliament had already expressed in 2011 the need for forward-looking action in this regard and that the Commission's proposal appears to be in line with the wishes expressed by the European Parliament in 2011. , that Mrs Beghin's proposal sees the manufacturing sector and trade challenges linked to migratory flows as two elements not adequately considered in the Commission's proposal, and also that greater transparency in trade policy is essential, especially as it allows for an up-to-date and functioning trade defence system, I feel I must express my positive opinion. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Illegal border crossing in 2016 is almost two times more than the total previous five years. Through trade policy to promote human rights, social rights, environmental rights, democracy and rule of law.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of changing the report because I believe that, as an EU, we need to respond more quickly and adapt to changes in the global context. The EU currently holds the richest economy in the world with a third of its richest economy, which is projected to fall to 26% by 2020. The centre of wealth creation is moving east towards the Asia-Pacific region, and demographic developments will also be affected by the EU's negative position. We therefore need transparent and open trade negotiations at all stages, while ensuring greater coherence between the EU's commercial objectives and other aspects of foreign policy.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal for a "Trade for All" strategy, but I must also agree that such a strategy has its drawbacks. Globalisation and internationalisation in global trade have brought an opportunity for EU growth and development, as well as problems such as labour exploitation, non-participation of women, intellectual property distortions, undermining medium and small businesses, and China's growth threatening the EU market.  EU trade and investment policy must create favourable outcomes in employment and wealth creation for citizens and businesses, and create the betterment of all those involved in the common trade policy in dialogue with social partners, regulators and other groups. Investments in the trade sector, modern trade mechanism and union trade protection system are of particular importance if trade development is to be maintained especially when China seeks recognition of the status of the economy market.  I am committed to making sure that the EU responds more effectively to the problems and that trade defence instruments must be an indispensable part of the EU's trade strategy. Through a stronger regulatory system, any unfair practice must be combated and thereby create a healthy entrepreneurial climate on EU territory in order to maintain jobs and further development of member states. All of this is clearly highlighted in this report on a new innovative and future-oriented strategy for trade and investment, so I supported it.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This text has some positive aspects such as combating the illicit trade in wildlife products, strengthening trade defences and not to China's market economy status. But it calls for the fight against protectionism, more free trade, especially free trade in the services sector, and a convergence of international standards, an arbitration tribunal to protect investment. These points are unacceptable to me and I therefore vote against this report.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union's trade policy strategy, contained in the Commission communication 'Trade for all', represents an important step towards trade based on values and respect for human, social and environmental rights. I therefore agree with the report's call for good intentions to be put into practice now. Citizens are increasingly interested and attentive to the new trade agreements, especially as they are concerned about the possible consequences that these could have on employment levels and their lives. It is therefore necessary to ensure transparency on all current and future negotiations, including through greater parliamentary control, and to ensure that trade policy creates benefits for all. The report emphasises the importance of considering the needs of SMEs and the manufacturing sector, with a view to the European reindustrialisation strategy. It deplores the Council's inadity on the reform of trade defence instruments, which is essential in view of China's call for recognition of market economy status. And it calls for trade policy to promote cooperation in the fight against corruption, fraud and tax evasion. International trade with fair rules and guarantees for European industries and workers can generate jobs and growth.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Trade negotiations such as ACTA, TTIP, CETA and TISA have brought European trade policy to the public's attention. Many EU citizens equate globalisation with job losses and fear that the Union's trade and investment policy could undermine European regulations and standards. At the same time, the contribution of foreign trade to the development of the European economy is fundamental. On 14 October 2015, the Commission proposed a new European Union trade and investment strategy entitled 'Trade for all: towards a more responsible trade and investment policy'. As part of the Trade for All strategy, the Commission has set a clear objective of rapidly increasing trade liberalisation and better EU integration into global value chains, and I therefore welcome a new, more innovative and future-oriented strategy for trade and investment. Today, the EU is the richest economy in the world. The EU's economic importance will decline: by 2050, Europe with 28 members, soon to be 27, will participate in global GDP with only 15%, down from 23.7% in 2013. The center of wealth creation moves eastwards, towards the Asia-Pacific region. An effective, comprehensive and advanced trade and investment strategy is essential for the European Union, which is why I support this report.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 An innovative approach plays and, above all, will play a key role in the EU economy in the future. We must remember that the importance of the EU economy will decline globally in the future, even though it is currently the richest economic area in the world. The wealth creation centre is moving east to the Asia-Pacific region, a trend that I think we will not stop, but we must respond to. This is why debates about future innovative strategies are so important for trade and investment. As a socially democratic-minded politician, I think that the Union's trade defence system needs to be modernised, even in view of china's continued efforts to grant market economy status. We must not allow jobs to be threatened and unemployment to rise, which would result in a decline in European exports or, on the contrary, a disproportionate increase in imports, especially in certain sectors. On the contrary, it is necessary to be one step ahead and to define trade and investment agreements in such a way as to strengthen sustainable development and not allow labour and social standards to fall, including as regards environmental sustainability.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to assess the Commission's new strategy on guidelines for international trade. Overall, the assessment is quite positive and we recognise the Commission's efforts and intentions to have included important elements reflecting new challenges in international trade, such as the digital economy and the responsible management of so-called 'global value chains'. The traditional relationship of complementarity between multilateral trade - which remains the first choice - and plurilateral or bilateral negotiations, which are dictated by much more pragmatic needs, is reiterated. The common commercial policy is one of the most important competences that the Member States have entrusted to the European Union. I believe that, if the EU is to negotiate new trade agreements, priority should be given to the protection of European specificities and quality standards. Europe must use all its trade weight to be a leading player on the global stage. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On 14 October 2015, the European Commission, following several requests from the European Parliament, adopted a Communication establishing the European Union's trade strategy for the coming years.  Open and free trade is worthy of support. It is important to emphasise the importance of Parliament's support for the ongoing trade negotiations with major partners such as the US and Japan, as well as its support for the opening of new negotiations not only with partners such as Australia and New Zealand, but also with many major emerging economies in the Asia-Pacific region. The report calls for increased access to markets for large and developing economies, as well as for increased support for small and medium-sized enterprises so that they can take advantage of the opportunities offered by trade. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text which will enable the development of an innovative new trade and investment strategy. In order to have an effective trade policy, the European Union must take into account new economic realities and globalisation, while promoting its values. Above all, it is a question of understanding that by speaking with one voice, the Member States are all the stronger on the international trade scene. Despite the often high-profile presence of many critics of global trade, it must be understood that trade and investment are the only drivers of growth and therefore of job creation.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Currently, the European Union (EU) accounts for about 23.7 % of world GDP and is the richest economy in the world. However, by 2050, its representation in world GDP is expected to decline to only 15 %. At the root of this decline may be the displacement of world wealth to the east and, in addition, the negative effects of demographic change. Therefore, an efficient trade and investment strategy is imperative, as these are important drivers in the development of growth and job creation. The report warns of the need for a new focus on responsible supply chain management, the global digital market, trade in digital services and goods, ethical and fair trade, as well as the social costs of trade liberalisation. The need for a transparent and more voiced trade policy for citizens is invoked, in the particular case of the TTIP negotiations and on the attention paid to SMEs and their specific needs. Because I consider the development of an effective commercial investment strategy, also at European level, to be fundamental.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We feel that the best way for international trade to proceed is for nation states to agree deals with each other, not for the EU to create yet more trouble in international trade with its demands. We feel that an independent Britain, which is now on the horizon of being made official, will be a leader and example in this regard.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which makes various proposals to found a new and innovative future strategy for trade and investment. We stress the importance of a more transparent and democratic trade policy, and the use of monitoring, evaluation and monitoring of existing agreements. We call for a tailored selection of future free trade agreements to be negotiated and reiterate the need for effective trade defence instruments.  In addition, we call for greater coherence between the EU's trade and industrial policy in order to ensure a level playing field for European industry and to give it access to new markets.  Finally, trade policy must provide concrete benefits to consumers by, for example, limiting unjustified geoblocking practices or strengthening passenger rights. Furthermore, we remind us that no trade agreement should lead to a decline in the achievements of European consumer protection standards, including in the digital revolution, and I welcome that.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr President, in view of the increased public attention to trade agreements and that more citizens are concerned about how they are negotiated, a greater level of transparency, involvement and accountability of all stakeholders is needed. Furthermore, it is essential to strengthen parliamentary scrutiny, and the Commission and the Council should also promote transparency in all future negotiations.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Union's new trade and investment strategy goes through a more effective trade policy, to generate new, more transparent economic opportunities, opening up trade negotiations to greater public control by publishing its key, more responsible, texts, redoubled efforts to ensure responsible management of supply chains, safeguarding the European social and regulatory model within the Union and promoting European values such as sustainable development in the world , human rights, fair and ethical trade and the fight against corruption. This initiative report welcomes the Union's new trade and investment strategy while requiring greater transparency in trade negotiations, strengthening control of respect for labour and environmental standards throughout the supply chain, including legally binding chapters on human rights, social, environmental and labour standards, including principles of corporate social responsibility. Moreover, on a socialist initiative, the report calls for intensified efforts to use trade negotiations as a tool to promote gender equality around the world. For all these reasons, I supported the report with my vote.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the initiative report on a new and innovative trade and investment strategy that, while not perfect, has the merit of highlighting some important elements.   I am particularly pleased that through this text the European Parliament believes that the ILO's fundamental standards must be binding and be an essential part of the European Union's trade agreements through binding commitments.  In this text, the European Parliament also says that until China meets the five criteria required by the EU to qualify for market economy status, the EU should use a non-standard method for investigations into dumping and subsidies on imports from China. The European Parliament also believes that the current trade defence legislation needs to be modernised. We cannot accept that products from countries that dump both social and environmentally compete unfairly with our European companies.   The European Union must be socially and environmentally ambitious when it comes to trade agreements. And I'll make sure that's the case!

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on the report on a 'New forward and innovative strategy for the future on trade and investment'. Admittedly, this report does not offer anything new and innovative. In essence, the text of the report proposes to continue what has been done in the past, despite growing scepticism and opposition from citizens to the liberalisation of the labour market. In the report, neither the Commission nor the rapporteur gives real steps to reforming trade policy. Although there are important references, one of them, the call for the Commission to create sustainable and responsible trade. It also underlines the importance of providing for chapters on sustainable development in trade agreements that would allow for strict social and environmental standards throughout the supply chain.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, which I voted in favour of, reflects the need for a new, innovative, effective and future-oriented trade and investment strategy. The European Commission adopted a new trade and investment strategy in 2015, following a resolution adopted by the European Parliament on the subject. There are several trade challenges facing the EU, despite the current world's largest economy, with a decline forecast by 2050 by shifting wealth to the Asia-Pacific region. It is therefore important that this strategy be focused and targeted at people, giving a greater level of transparency and accountability in trade negotiations - current and future, that ensure sustainable development and promote respect for human rights, labour, social and sustainability standards worldwide. I support the need for a modernisation of the European trade defence system, taking into account the objective of increasing trade liberalisation and EU integration into global value chains, as well as strengthening cooperation and coherence between the Union's trade objectives and other aspects of its foreign policy.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which looks at the EU's trade strategy for the coming years. The text thus establishes an overview of the Union's trade policy and sets out objectives to be achieved.  It is thus recalled that trade must take place in a spirit of reciprocity and mutual benefits. It is also central that trade negotiations exclude public services as well as audiovisual services, allow the protection and recognition of geographical indications, and finally provide an opportunity to access the public procurement of our partners.  Certain specificities must also be taken into account, such as the peculiarities of the outermost regions in trade policy.  In addition, trade negotiations and EU policy must also ensure the sensitivity of certain products, including agricultural products, with the implementation of appropriate specific measures.  Finally, the report calls on the Commission to continue its efforts on transparency and once again calls for the modernisation of trade defence instruments, without weakening them, in order to make them more efficient, faster and accessible to SMEs.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Beghin's report aims to assess the European Commission's new strategy on guidelines for international trade. I could only vote in favour of the text, which welcomes the Commission's proposals on international trade. The new strategy takes into account current challenges, such as the digital economy and responsible management of global value chains. In addition, the EU once again presents itself as a supporter of the multilateral approach to international trade, but does not deny the use of bilateral or plurilateral agreements where they are most effective. However, what puzzles me in the strategy adopted by the Commission is the lack of a clear list of priorities that can guide this institution's action in the field of international trade. I would like to point out that this is a matter for the EU. Trade policy is one of the pillars of the EU, which is the world's largest exporter of manufacturing and services, as well as the main import market for more than a hundred countries.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted abstention because, although there are some very positive aspects to this report, it is ambiguous in supporting a strategy that is essentially favourable to the free market at any price such as 'trade for all'.  We welcome the fact that it draws attention to issues that free-market dogma tends to camouflage in most debates (i.e. "considering that there has been no serious debate in the EU on free trade policies"), immediately publish negotiating mandates, strengthen policy coherence for development, and make labour rights chapters binding , social and environmental agreements. However, we cannot vote in favour since the underlying logic is the support of the Commission's strategy, and boost foreign trade as a solution to European problems and support for the Commission's trade for all strategy, which proposes a strategy for the future that can only lead the EU and its partners to deepen inequalities , the increase of which we have been experiencing for decades.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Having the purchasing power of the world’s largest single market gives us the leverage to promote standards and principles to ensure that international trade benefits everyone. Trade policy should create opportunities for all businesses, especially small and medium sized enterprises, and not just the large multinationals. Negotiations should focus on ensuring that environmental, labour and consumer protection standards are improved rather than undermined. I especially welcome the amendments tabled to this report by my political Group on environmental protection, renewable energy, labour standards and gender equality. I urge the Commission to adopt these priorities in its ongoing and future trade negotiations.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report deals with the Commission's latest communication: 'Trade for all'. I voted against it as this new communication reaffirms the direction in the Union's trade policy towards accelerating the liberalisation of public services. I have not been able to vote in favour of the report because in my view the Union's trade policy should take a 180-degree turn and be respectful of asymmetry in each bloc and between blocs and should be based on fair trade and not on achieving the maximum benefit of European interests. That's why I voted against it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is now the most prosperous economy in the world. However, its economic importance is set to decline: in 2050, the EU-28 will account for only 15% of world GDP, compared with 23.7% in 2013. In addition, the centre of wealth production is slowly shifting to the Far East regions. It is therefore very important for the European Union to outline an effective, comprehensive and forward-looking trade and investment strategy to cope with future socio-economic changes. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the Commission to keep a continuous update of the European trade strategy and to submit an annual detailed implementation report.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We feel that the best way for international trade to proceed is for nation states to agree deals with each other, not for the EU to create yet more trouble in international trade with its demands. We feel that an independent Britain, which is now on the horizon of being made official, will be a leader and example in this regard.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report which lays out the European Parliament’s reaction to the Commission’s future trade policy communication on ‘Trade for All’. I am pleased to see that so many of the priorities of Socialist MEPs have made it into the report: from a commitment to the multilateral approach, as a first and best option, to a desire to see enforceable sustainable development chapters in trade agreements, and the notion that trade may work for ordinary people only when paired with the right flanking measures , in relation to social policy, education and public investment to name a few.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which also points out, among other things, that EU trade protection legislation must be more effective, more accessible to SMEs and adapted to the current challenges and structures of trade.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I did not support the Report on a new, innovative and future-oriented strategy for trade and investment, as the Report has little reference to attempts by industrialised countries to add new issues such as digitalisation, investment or competition before concluding an agreement. The report supports the Commission in order to protect and exercise the full spectrum of intellectual property rights, including patents, trademarks, copyrights, design, geographical indications, designation of origin and pharmaceutical products. Trade is still seen as crucial in generating growth, and given the weak activity in the EU, we need to turn to new markets, especially Asia. Trade and investment agreements should be put into words in such a way as to be a powerful tool for strengthening sustainable development, promoting human rights, labour and social standards and environmental sustainability around the world. I believe that this proposal will not meet these criteria and therefore I did not support this report.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 At present, the EU economy is the richest in the world and EU trade is one of the strongest policy instruments, not only in promoting European interests, investment and entrepreneurship, but also in promoting European values abroad. It is uncomfortable to agree that the EU's economic importance will gradually decline and in 2050 EU Member States will account for only 15% of world GDP, compared with 23.7% in 2013. I believe that an effective, comprehensive and future-oriented trade and investment strategy is therefore essential for the EU. I supported the resolution because I believe that it is essential to modernise current EU legislation in order to protect trade. I believe that EU trade legislation will be more effective in the next period, more accessible to small and medium-sized enterprises and, above all, adapted to the current challenges and the structure of trade. Future-oriented trade policy must pay greater attention to the specific needs of micro-enterprises and SMEs and ensure that these enterprises can fully benefit from trade and investment agreements. Personally, I cannot accept that only 13% of European SMEs operate internationally outside the EU, so I recommend that new options be explored on how best to help these businesses.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has also approved, with my help, a resolution on the European Union's trade strategy. In it, the European Parliament recalls the Role of the European Union in the world and stresses that trade in a sustainable and responsible manner is the strongest instrument for promoting European interests and values abroad. European Union citizens are often troubled by the potential effects of trade agreements that Europe negotiates with its trading partners. In this resolution, the European Parliament emphasises, for example, greater transparency in negotiations or the need for a comprehensive analysis of the impact of The European Union's trade initiatives and asks the European Commission to provide data on the impact of trade agreements already concluded, in particular on small and medium-sized entrepreneurs, the environment, etc. In this resolution, the European Parliament also touches non-EU countries, mentioning, for example, the importance of new markets for European agricultural production, but also calls for development aid. Funds such as the European Development Fund (EDF) are intended to support, for example, the fight against poverty or to reduce the causes behind migration. The resolution also talks about cooperation with specific countries, so in the resolution I supported, for example, the call on the European Commission to start negotiations immediately on an investment agreement with Taiwan.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Trade has become a rather controversial and political topic, and the European Commission has failed to make the necessary changes to improve the situation. The report therefore calls on the European Commission to introduce concrete responses to issues related to sustainable development and human rights. I believe that the report is significantly weakened in relation to the Greens' demands on the trade and investment strategy. Thus, for example, it does not contain a direct refusal to set up an investment court system. What is more, the report supports the European Commission and its intention to protect and enforce intellectual property rights, including patents, trademarks, copyrights, and others. It is true that the report also has good content, such as calling for greater transparency and access to documents. The report also confirms the need for a change in citizens' concern that trade, mainly due to the introduction of non-trade barriers, threatens compliance with European Union regulations. The report also calls for effective implementation of decisions relating to international environmental and social standards and human rights provisions in the area of trade agreements. Overall, I believe that the report could have been much better, which is why I decided not to support it at the meeting.

name: Renato Soru (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report in which Parliament responds to the Commission's Trade for All communication on international trade, stressing the need for this policy to be pursued with responsibility and attention for the citizens of Europe and partner countries. The Commission's strategy presents positive proposals which go in the direction of more responsible trade geared to the promotion of European values. It is essential to meet the needs of SMEs and the manufacturing sector, creating new opportunities for economic operators, within the framework of a trade policy that can bring about concrete improvements in the living conditions of our citizens. If trade agreements are to act as instruments for promoting the Union's values, it is necessary to provide for and implement binding requirements on sustainable development, human rights, fair trade and the fight against corruption, with sanction mechanisms for those who do not respect their commitments in relation to social and environmental rights. Parliament will therefore exercise its prerogatives with the utmost commitment with regard to the Commission's implementation of these guidelines in its trade initiatives.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The new comprehensive strategy reflects the eu's current needs, in particular changing trends in world trade, such as better protection of intellectual property rights, opening up new market opportunities, harnessing the digital economy for future world trade, better customs cooperation for a better and, in particular, a more progressive future.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution of 5 July 2016 on a forward-looking innovative strategy for trade and investment. The report's fundamentally positive tone on the usefulness of world trade in reducing poverty and increasing overall prosperity is gratifying. Unfortunately, the report slips into demands that run counter to this, for example when it is demanded that 'trade policy must contribute to ensuring a transparent production process along the entire value chain'. I am in favour of free trade, not of transparently organised free trade. Politically enforced transparency can only be used to manage trade flows – the result would not be free trade, but managed trade. It is also problematic that the report recognises 'the Commission's efforts with regard to the new Investment Court System (ICS)'. This system is not new, but I believe that it is no longer the case at the moment – and this may change – than the previous arbitration tribunals under new labelling.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Many Union citizens equate globalisation with job losses and fear that globalisation trade and investment policy could undermine European regulations and standards. The Union today has the world's richest economy, but economic importance will decline by 2050, experts believe, and Europe with 28 members in global GDP will participate with only 15%. The European Union's new trade and investment strategy, 'Trade for all: towards a more responsible trade and investment policy', guarantees greater transparency, engagement and accountability towards all stakeholders. I support the proposal for this Resolution because I believe that the Union must align trade objectives with other forms of foreign policy. Trade and investment agreements must be worded in such a way as to be a powerful means of strengthening sustainable development, promoting human rights, labour and social standards and environmental sustainability around the world.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on a new forward-looking and innovative strategy for trade and investment. Trade agreements are still needed by the European Union, because, as the text rightly shows, trade is not an end in itself, but is a means of achieving prosperity and equality, while promoting business opportunities, sustainable economic development, social progress and understanding of cultures. I share the belief that the report shows that the European Union's manufacturing sector is crucial for the reindustrialisation of Europe, and I therefore agree with the call on the Commission to work with trading partners to ensure that their markets are more open to EU businesses.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The trade and investment strategy should be based on improving the regulatory frameworks for business development, particularly for micro and SMEs as well as agriculture within the EU, based on the specificities of each country and on its sustainable development. The primary objective is the prosperity of countries and not of business at the expense of citizens and states.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is currently the most powerful economy in the world. However, the economic importance of the European Union will diminish: the centre of wealth creation will be shifted east towards the Asia-Pacific region, and demographic changes will also have a negative impact on the UNION's position on the world trade stage. An effective, comprehensive and forward-looking economic and investment strategy is therefore crucial for the European Union. 21st century trade policy must respond to people's concerns. We need greater transparency, participation and accountability for all relevant stakeholders. Trade and investment agreements must be shaped in such a way as to be a powerful means of strengthening sustainable development and promoting human rights, labour and social standards and environmental sustainability worldwide. I voted in favour of this decision because it formulats strategies to achieve these objectives.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on a new, forward-looking and innovative future strategy for trade and investment, which, likewise, I also welcome the Commission's new strategy for a more responsible trade and investment policy. I agree with the report's approach that trade is not an end in itself, but a means of achieving prosperity and equality, promoting business opportunities, sustainable economic development, social development and cultural understanding, increasing employment and improving living standards. Furthermore, I approve of the fact that the report has highlighted the importance of the agri-food sector and calls for new markets to be opened up for EU agricultural products such as dairy products, meat and live animals, as well as for fruit and vegetables. Finally, I support the report's points on trade policy transparency, greater involvement of civil society and social partners, and the specific needs of micro-enterprises and SMEs.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because a balanced trade and investment strategy creates opportunities for economic growth in several sectors. I also welcomed the inclusion of the agricultural sector in the trade strategy. The problems caused by the agricultural crisis for producers may be mitigated in the future when alternative markets are available.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted on Tuesday in favour of the report by our 5-star colleague Tiziana Beghin, which sets out a new commercial and investment strategy for the European Union. As a result of the increasingly impacting negotiations on free trade agreements such as TTIP and CETA, citizens have begun to become increasingly concerned by associating the phenomenon of globalisation with job losses. On the other hand, the contribution of external trade to European economic development should not be underestimated. So the position that we tried to support and defend was to have a trade strategy that was not a useful tool for multinationals to enrich themselves on the skin of workers, but a means of achieving prosperity, equality and social progress. Thanks to the good work of Tiziana Beghin, the M5S has managed to achieve many good results such as respect for SMEs and farmers and the exclusion of the MES China within the strategy. Whenever an agreement is to be reached, accurate impact studies will have to be drawn up to assess whether or not it is convenient and for whom. Within the strategy, we at the M5S have succeeded in including the defence of geographical indications, the fight against counterfeiting and therefore the protection of European excellence.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is one of the main promoters of free trade worldwide. At the same time, however, the European institutions are the main guarantors of the interests of European citizens. When the latter are threatened by international trade activities, it is the Union's role to propose fair multilateral regulations in order to allow free trade in the interests of its citizens. This report seeks to propose a new approach to trade activities at Union level in response to the Commission communication of November 2015 entitled 'Trade for All'. The main proposals aim at more transparency, commitment and accountability to the parties involved, the design of trade agreements to strengthen the development of human rights, social and labour standards, gender equality and environmental protection worldwide. At the same time, greater attention must be paid to the interests of SMEs with a view to developing a fair policy of reindustrialisation and sensitive agricultural sectors, and illegal migration, as well as forced labour and modern forms of slavery, must be combated. Union trade policy must also be more closely linked to development policy. This is an important document, which will help to increase the fairness of the Union's trade policies, which is why I support its adoption.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Trade negotiations, such as ACTA, TTIP, CETA and ACS, have brought European trade policy to the attention of the public. For many European citizens, globalisation means job losses. They fear that eu trade and investment policy could jeopardise EU regulations and standards. At the same time, it is important to know that foreign trade is an essential factor in the development of the European economy.  Today, the European Union is the richest economy in the world. However, this situation is likely to falter: forecasts indicate that by 2050, the 28 EU Member States will now account for only 15% of world GDP, up from 23.7% in 2013. Wealth production is moving eastwards to the Asia-Pacific region. Demographic changes will also have the effect of demoting the European Union's position on the world trade scene.  The Union must therefore have an effective, elaborate and forward-looking trade and investment strategy.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ While the EU is the wealthiest economy worldwide, an effective, comprehensive and forward-looking trade and investment strategy is of vital importance if we want to keep our economic importance in the face of the growing competition from other continents. This is why I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for more transparency, engagement and accountability towards all stakeholders involved in the trade, namely to regain the confidence of citizens regarding the benefits of international trade. I particularly agree with the need for regular updates and annual implementation reports that will allow us to achieve the best possible strategy.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The global trade scenario is changing rapidly and citizens identify globalisation with job losses and are concerned that European regulations and regulations could possibly be undermined by the Union's trade and investment policies. As set out in the report, trade and investment agreements need to be shaped in such a way that they are effective tools for strengthening sustainable development, promoting human rights, social and labour standards and environmental sustainability worldwide.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. Trade and investment form the basis for growth and job creation. The EU needs an effective policy to address new economic realities. Trade and investment policy must be more transparent, and it must be based on values that it needs a forward-looking programme of negotiations to shape globalisation. I supported the report on a new forward-looking and innovative trade and investment strategy because it highlights the development of a much more advanced and innovative trade and investment strategy, taking into account the challenges that come together with the changing phases of world trade. The report places new emphasis on elements such as responsible supply chain management, the global digital market, trade in digital goods and services, fair and ethical trade and the social costs of trade liberalisation. The report also stresses the importance of sustainable development chapters and respect for human rights and corporate social responsibility. In addition, elements and sectors such as the digital economy and the fight against corruption and tax evasion should also be an integral part of the new forward-looking strategy.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted abstention because, although there are some very positive aspects to this report, it is ambiguous in supporting a strategy that is essentially favourable to the free market at any price such as 'trade for all'.  We welcome the fact that it draws attention to issues that free-market dogma tends to camouflage in most debates (i.e. "considering that there has been no serious debate in the EU on free trade policies"), immediately publish negotiating mandates, strengthen policy coherence for development, and make labour rights chapters binding , social and environmental agreements. However, we cannot vote in favour since the underlying logic is the support of the Commission's strategy, and boost foreign trade as a solution to European problems and support for the Commission's trade for all strategy, which proposes a strategy for the future that can only lead the EU and its partners to deepen inequalities , the increase of which we have been experiencing for decades.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is my belief that a re-think of our trade policy is fundamental to achieving greater benefits from our current agreements and in order to diminish the least desired economic and social effects of current policy.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This text has two sides.  A rather positive first in which the rapporteur defends the AOCs and the sensitivity of the agricultural sector by strengthening trade defences, the fight against illegal trade in wildlife products, or the no to the status of a market economy for China.  Another side where we are talking about fighting protectionism, to promote more free trade in services, or finally to establish a convergence of international standards in this area.  These contradictions in the text lead me to vote against it. How can we claim to defend the AOCs, true symbols of French and European know-how, while giving this same national market as a pasture to the large stateless multinationals?

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Foreign trade can be crucial for the development of the European economy. There is a lot of concern about these forecasts, which speak of a decline in the importance of the European economy; according to some, EU countries will generate around 15% of global GDP by 2050. By comparison, in 2013 it was close to 24%. That is why strategies are so important to try to stop unfavourable trends and respond to the fundamental challenges of the European economy. The proposal in its proposed form meets these criteria, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trade negotiations on the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement, the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement and the Agreement on Trade in Services have put European trade policy at the heart of public interest. Many EU citizens identify globalisation with job losses and are concerned that EU trade and investment policy could undermine European standards and standards. At the same time, the contribution of foreign trade to the development of the European economy is essential. I voted in favour of the final text.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted abstention because, although there are some very positive aspects to this report, it is ambiguous in supporting a strategy that is essentially favourable to the free market at any price such as 'trade for all'.  We welcome the fact that it draws attention to issues that free-market dogma tends to camouflage in most debates (i.e. "considering that there has been no serious debate in the EU on free trade policies"), immediately publish negotiating mandates, strengthen policy coherence for development, and make labour rights chapters binding , social and environmental agreements. However, we cannot vote in favour since the underlying logic is the support of the Commission's strategy, and boost foreign trade as a solution to European problems and support for the Commission's trade for all strategy, which proposes a strategy for the future that can only lead the EU and its partners to deepen inequalities , the increase of which we have been experiencing for decades.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the fact that the Commission has announced a number of initiatives in support of fair trade and I encourage the Commission to continue to propose such measures within the framework of the common commercial policy.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on a new forward-looking and innovative future strategy for trade and investment. The report stresses the link between the single market and EU trade policy, which should be fully compatible with each other and with the wider policies and values of the Union. Moreover, it emphasises the link between the single market and EU trade policy, which should be fully compatible with each other and with the wider policies and values of the Union. I voted in favour because I believe that open, responsible and free global trade, based on effective, transparent and strong global rules, is essential in order to enable the single market to realise its full potential by functioning, growing and working for the mutual benefit of citizens, consumers and businesses.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This report highlights that trade and investment are powerful drivers of growth and job creation and that the European Union needs an effective policy that addresses new economic realities in this globalized world. We are talking about a report which has been the subject of great consensus and negotiation in the International Trade Committee and I consider it necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report deals with the Commission's latest communication: 'Trade for all'. I voted against it as this new communication reaffirms the direction in the Union's trade policy towards accelerating the liberalisation of public services. I have not been able to vote in favour of the report because in my view the Union's trade policy should take a 180-degree turn and be respectful of asymmetry in each bloc and between blocs and should be based on fair trade and not on achieving the maximum benefit of European interests. That's why I voted against it.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it contains Parliament’s reaction to the Commission’s ‘Trade for All’ Communication on its future trade policy. It welcomes the communication as a significant shift towards value-based trade in line with our Group’s position but insists that the Commission must deliver on its promises. The report reaffirms Parliament’s previous recommendations on the TTIP and TiSA negotiations. Since it is a horizontal report it does not prejudge any final position by our Group on any particular trade agreement.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report because the European Union is making a little more effort on a forward-looking and innovative strategy for trade and investment. The European Parliament wishes to keep the Commission's commitment that no trade agreement will lead to a reduction in European consumer protection standards. I am very pleased that the report highlights the specific needs of SMEs and the agricultural sector. Here, too, we can make more efforts to support our entrepreneurs.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the "trade for all" strategy proposed in October 2015 by the European Commission. The title is already a "challenge" in itself.  The stated objective of this strategy is unsurprisingly to strengthen the EU's trade policy by multiplying free trade agreements and making them more "effective"... This strategy therefore supports the negotiations of the famous TTIP and the new investment protection system "ICS" (formerly known as "ISDS") i.e. private law mechanisms that private companies can use to directly attack Member States.   In addition, the Commission is using this new strategy to incorporate return and readmission agreements into free trade agreements with third countries for its fight against "irregular" migration.  So I voted against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This debate reflects the profound contradictions of a neoliberal system based on free trade and on the basis of a purely mercantile logic that subjugates everything and everyone in the name of profit. As reality shows, it will not be through vague and non-binding rules that we will improve the fate of those who are exploited inside and outside the European Union. What about the human rights safeguard clause in the association agreement between Israel and the EU? Has this agreement ever been called into question despite the successive human rights violations of palestinian people on their territory on a daily basis? As long as free trade and the private interests of large enterprises prevail, it will certainly not be the well-intentioned words of this House that impose corporate social responsibility. That is why we stand for a new model of cooperation mutually beneficial to both sides and with respect for the sovereignty of national states.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report mentions that increased foreign investment and thus the full opening up of our market could lead to more growth. However, it is concealed that the resulting increased competitive pressure will also destroy jobs. Although there are good approaches, such as the possibilities offered by the TRIPS Agreement, to provide affordable medicines to developing countries, the report is, in the end, far too much along Commissioner Malmström's previous line. In addition, the report continues to regard ISDS as a legitimate means of foreign trade. I therefore reject the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012I voted in favour of the report on a new, innovative and forward-looking strategy on trade and investment. In particular, the report emphasises the importance of considering the needs of SMEs and the manufacturing sector in negotiations. In addition, trade treaties must be subject to ex ante and ex post evaluations to ensure that the aim is to improve the labour market and stimulate economic growth. Europe must be open to free trade inso far as it creates jobs and stimulates growth while respecting consumer protection. I firmly believe that this report lay the foundations for more transparent trade negotiations in the interests of the consumer.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. – The resolution sets down general principles and guidelines for EU trade policy. I voted in favour as I believe these principles are in line with the principles that my Labour colleagues and I share, such as reaffirming that commitment to the multilateral approach is the first best option; that enforceable sustainable development chapters should be added in trade agreements; that the EU needs to focus increasingly on implementation of concluded agreements; and that the European Parliament wants the TTIP transparency initiative extended to all negotiations. The resolution also emphasises that labour and environmental standards must be respected throughout the supply chain and reaffirms that trade only delivers for ordinary people when paired with the right flanking measures (such as social policy, education, public investment).

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I support the call for this EP resolution because trade and investment are essential to the EU economy. As economies in other parts of the world are becoming increasingly important, so are our relations with them. An important part of these relations are the agreements that enhance trade and investment. I strongly welcome a trade and investment strategy at EU level and agree that a liberalisation of trade will have a positive effect on the economy. In conjunction to the above, we need to ensure that the EU markets are protected from unfair competition and therefore need a trade defence strategy that is up to date.  Trade is one of the EU’s strongest tools in achieving its goals, both within and outside the Union. In this regard, it can be used to enhance sustainable development and promote human rights. Consequently, I can only be in favour of this resolution.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the own-initiative report on a new innovative and forward-looking strategy on trade and investment. I welcome the rapporteur's approach and the fact that she has tried to build an exhaustive report in terms of the objectives that the EU should pursue in its trade and investment policy. The report focuses on a transparent trade policy and a stronger voice for citizens, a forward-looking trade policy that takes into account the specific needs of SMEs, or on the creation of new market opportunities for European service providers and the recognition of professional qualifications: an essential element of the EU's trade strategy. I welcome the call on the Commission to monitor, assess and follow up existing agreements, as well as the call for encouraging global trade through a multilateral approach within the WTO.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report of the Committee on International Trade, which is the product of an enlarged majority among five political groups, which agreed on a large number of compromise amendments, which were also adopted by the committee responsible.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I very much agree with this report, as I believe that trade and investment are the two key pillars for EU growth.  For this reason, I fully defend this strategy, which will take into account aspects such as global production chains and which will seek to improve factors such as trade policy, transparency and policy values. I believe that this new strategy will undoubtedly be a source of development and prosperity that will contribute to growth and employment both in the EU and beyond.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trade negotiations such as ACTA, TTIP, CETA and TISA have brought European trade policy to the centre of public attention. Many citizens identify the phenomenon of globalisation with job losses and are concerned that European regulations and regulations may possibly be undermined by the Union's trade and investment policies. At the same time, the contribution of external trade to the development of the European economy is of fundamental importance, as is an effective, global and forward-looking trade and investment strategy. The report welcomes the fact that the Commission has adopted a new trade and investment strategy, but stresses that the Commission does not pay specific attention to manufacturing and trade to address the challenges of migration. The fundamental importance of updating the EU's trade defence system is underlined, especially as China is strenuously calling for recognition of the state of a market economy. We must now shape trade and investment agreements in such a way that they become effective tools for strengthening sustainable development, promoting human rights, social and labour standards and environmental sustainability worldwide.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this report because I realise that an effective, comprehensive and future-oriented trade and investment strategy is essential for the European Union. At the same time, I am aware of the concerns that citizens have. Many European citizens associate globalisation with job losses. I therefore believe that trade policy in the 21st century must respond to citizens' concerns. We therefore need greater transparency, involvement and accountability in relation to all stakeholders. In view of the fact that the global trading environment is changing very rapidly, I believe that the trade strategy should be updated regularly and the Commission should report in detail on its implementation in order to allow for scrutiny of European citizens.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on a new forward-looking and innovative future strategy for trade and investment. Although the original draft report was all too critical of the new EU trade strategy issued by the European Commission last October, changes to the text have been made during the negotiations to such an extent that the report can be considered well drafted and balanced. In particular, the report emphasises the transparency of trade policy, the possibility of public scrutiny and the reflection of citizens' concerns in these areas. According to this report, trade policy should be based mainly on values and should, inter,be directed towards social security or job creation. Reducing administrative burdens is also a very important element, in particular through enhanced cooperation between authorities. Such measures will help facilitate trade and investment. Moreover, the excessive administrative burden has a negative impact, in particular on small and medium-sized enterprises, which should be relieved by the proposed measures in the report. The positives of the report include a focus on the benefits of trade agreements for consumers and calls for accurate product information or a reduction in geo-blocking.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Beghin report because I believe that Europe needs to boost trade by boosting job creation and economic growth, but that this openness must be accompanied by a legal framework ensuring widespread access to trade benefits.
