Trade is not an end in itself, but a means to achieve prosperity and equality, promote business opportunities, sustainable economic development, social progress and cultural understanding, increase employment and improve living without increasing public spending. I therefore advocate a trade policy that avoids protectionism and promotes the reduction of unnecessary non-tariff barriers to trade, ensuring access to new markets, especially for SMEs.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The vast majority of the products we use every day, from cars to mobile phones, are the result of a production chain that spans the whole world. With this report, which I voted in favour of, we in the M5S have been loudly demanding that these global supply chains be clean, sustainable and respectful of workers' rights. We want to know whether the good you buy is the result of exploited work, child labour or worse than a violation of human rights. But we have not stopped there and we have pushed for the sustainability of trade to also take account of respect for the environment and animals, demanding greater control of compliance with the rules for trade in protected species and farm animals. In order to ensure that these commitments are maintained, we have included in the report that the new free trade treaties contain binding chapters on sustainable development with clear sanction mechanisms for those who do not respect their commitments. We wanted the investigations to be launched on the initiative of the European Parliament itself. We in the M5S have been working on new legislation to make trade an instrument of prosperity, equality and social progress for all.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on a new forward-looking and innovative strategy for trade and investment. THE EU's trade policy has an extraordinary geopolitical and economic importance for Europe in shaping globalisation, strengthening international standards and increasing access to foreign markets. The Commission's new 'Trade for All – a responsible trade and investment policy' places emphasis on responsible supply chain management, integration into the global digital market and promotes fair and ethical trade.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – "Combating trafficking in human beings in eu external relations" is the title of the report. Well, please, this fight against trafficking in human beings, right, trafficking in women – this fight has been going on for as long as I can remember. Not just in the seven years since I've heard of all sorts of struggles here, but long before that. Somebody show me the results of all these fights. I mean, revenue expenditure, so to speak. So how many posts did you have? We are now at the point where one of the most disgusting quasi-industries is human trafficking, a terrible form of crime. But there is a parallel industry with jobs, huge international organizations, fighting human trafficking, women's trafficking. Where are the results? Because all we hear about are ever-worsening numbers, more and more tragedies. What all this investment and fighting has brought – point 1. Point 2, what's the conclusion all the time? People in very difficult situations will be victims of human trafficking, so to speak, in the third world. What's the solution? Legal migration. Here's the trick that got me unable to vote for this report. Thank you! Because that's not the answer.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – I welcome the fact that the resolution adopted covers various forms of this crime and also calls for the prosecution of clients who are knowingly involved in the abuse of victims of trafficking in human beings. It also stresses the need to cooperate with civil society organisations in this field.  Also in Slovakia, many NGOs deal with this serious issue with selfless help from volunteers. The role of these organisations is irreplaceable and therefore deserves not only our apprequification, but also concrete help and support for their work. Among other things, the report concerned surrogacy as one form of trafficking in human beings, but unfortunately the approved text condemns only forced surrogacy. However, it should be stressed that even any voluntary (whether commercial or so-called 'altruistic') forms of surrogacy make babies the desired goods and women's uterus produce such babies. Therefore, all forms of surrogacy are unacceptable here, because they undersug human dignity and at the same time humiliate a person on the subject of demand.  Some proposals also interfered with member states' competences, particularly on migrant issues, while others placed disproportionate and unrealistic demands on private companies. That is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the profit of trafficking in human beings has reached 150 billion dollars. In less than 1% of these cases, the prosecution is completed and we have a final decision of the judiciary. This means that in less than 1% of cases it can be confisced or victims can be saved. Women and girls make up 79% of victims of sexual exploitation. Men make up 83% of victims of forced labour. Now let us also refer to children: the Europol Director said that more than 10 000 children, refugees and migrants have disappeared in Europe. I voted for this report because states need to pay particular attention, particular importance – and this is a priority – to register refugees, to pursue them, precisely so as not to be stolen, not to be subjected to trafficking in human beings. In particular, minors, who are a disadvantaged category and do not manage on their own, are at high risk of being exploited and, as such, they come first to be protected.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I asked Commissioner Malmström in the debate whether today, six months after the tragedy of 10 000 children missing on illegal immigration roads was revealed, the Commission could say what happened to some of them. Unfortunately, the Commission is not responding. 10 000 children have been killed and human rights europe is not spoiling well-being. Of course, the European Commission may remain silent, but we will not remain silent. This event, this drama to which we still find no answer, shows the truth about illegal immigration. Let us remember that it was the declarations made by the European Commission's leadership on a Europe open to borderless immigration that created a unique economic situation for the activities of the people-smuggling mafia. And it's time to show what really was behind these platitudes.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – I very much regret that the present report did not accept the motions in the resolution of the Committee on the Environment on surrogacy, that is to say, drug maternity. Because renting a uterus and buying a baby from a clinic meets all the characteristics of human trafficking. Unfortunately, paragraph 31 of this report only speaks of forced surrogacy, while fundamental human rights and the dignity of women and children violate every form of surrogacy.  A woman is not a children's factory, and a child is not a commodity anyone can buy. Surrogacy in every form must be part of the fight against trafficking in human beings. If we want to eradicate human trafficking, we need to tell ourselves the truth. This text is turning a blind eye to the billion-dollar trade that is already taking place in Europe, which is why I was unable to support the text in the final vote and abstained.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it could be said that human trafficking is the modern example, despicable as it is, of man’s inhumanity to man – or perhaps man’s inhumanity to woman and child, because it is nearly always women and children who are exploited and trafficked. Ms Morvai asked a question on what the European Union has been doing and where the results of all its efforts are. Well, in fairness, if we look at what was happening in the Mediterranean prior to action by the European Union in dealing with the people-smugglers from North Africa, at least there has been a reduction in that area. But, within Europe, the fact that 12 000 children have disappeared is a cause for major concern and obviously means that Europol and the Member State security forces have to cooperate far more in the future to try and bring these perpetrators of man’s inhumanity to fellow man to justice and, hopefully, custodial sentences.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in this House we strongly denounce and reject trafficking in human beings, which represents a rising business at the expense of human suffering and affects all societies and economies in a profound and persistent way. Without a doubt, we are facing an extremely lucrative business and unity, collaboration and firmness are needed to eradicate these practices and the different forms of exploitation. That is why the Union's policy on trafficking in human beings, as we have adopted in a report in this parliament itself, must be connected to Community external action, in order to establish more coherent and effective cooperation in developing systems to identify, protect and assist victims, improve trafficking prevention , facilitate the prosecution of traffickers and create a network to respond quickly to difficulties that may arise.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. The European Parliament today voted in favour of a non-legislative report 'on the fight against trafficking in human beings in the EU's external relations'. I supported this, as trafficking in human beings through the way it turned people into goods is one of the worst violations of human rights. It is about the weakest and most vulnerable people in Sweden, Europe and the world.  I welcome the constructive proposals for action contained in the resolution. Since KD is opposed to a European Prosecutor's Office, I would like to stress that this is still the case, since there are wordings on extending the mandate of the 'future Union General Prosecutor's Office'.  Moreover, the report rightly condemns forced surrogacy, but at the same time calls on the Member States 'to consider the consequences of their own restrictive reproductive policies'. This wording surprises me, because so-called altruistic surrogacy is a controversial phenomenon. Moreover, like other medical-ethical issues, the issue clearly belongs at national level. Since MEMBERS of the European Parliament have previously had views on eu countries' abortion legislation, it is certainly logical to take views on other medical-ethical legislation in the Member States. But it is, nonetheless, wrong. I would therefore like to stress that the Christian Democrats take a critical approach to surrogacy.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings can be defined as the recruitment and illicit transfer of one or more people, from one territory to another, for profit. The report before us, on the other hand, adopts a very broad definition of this crime, allowing it to be applied to various forms of prostitution, child labour and organ trafficking. Unfortunately, this is a structural phenomenon, certainly not a transitory one, created and fomented by wars, corruption, poverty and dysfunctions in the migration system. In view of the call for legal immigration channels, the recognition of specific rights for victims and, finally, a system to combat corruption, I voted in favour.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative report. We are strong supporters of any measures to combat the trafficking of people, however we do not support the European Union taking actions on these measures. The free movement of people and Schengen has contributed to an increase in people trafficking within the EU. We think it is hypocritical of the EU to discuss measures outside of the EU when it refuses to acknowledge this. However out of respect for the sensitivity of the subject and our support for measures to combat it we abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. It is an initiative with positive intentions, but it does not offer concrete and specific solutions that contribute to the real fight against trafficking in human beings. Priority is not given to urgent measures that must involve actions by transit countries that are crucial to combating this scourge. That's why I abstained.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text on the fight against human beings in the Union's external relations. Indeed, through this text, the EU is using the fight against human trafficking to strengthen its international power. However, we could not object to this text in relation to the subject which obviously deserves a real fight.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The report has some commendable aspects; it calls for cooperation in combatting human trafficking, it is strong on the impact for women and children, calls on the EU to do more to find missing refugees, etc. However, the inclusion of calls for greater EU military presence in the Mediterranean, claims that exploitation does not occur in transit countries, some questionable suggestions regarding refugees, and calls for an EU cross-border labour mechanism, make the report impossible to support. Therefore, on this basis, I abstained on the final roll-call vote.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which stresses that human trafficking is a very lucrative activity and the proceeds of this criminal activity are largely re-injected into the global economy and the financial system. The report also highlights the clear link between migrant trafficking and human trafficking. I condemn in the strongest terms all these forms of exploitation. It is essential to include the fight against this phenomenon of another age, but also the rights of victims, including the right to reparation, in EU policies towards third countries.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the fight against trafficking in human beings. The trafficking of human beings is a modern kind of slavery and a serious crime which constitutes one of the worst forms of human rights violations. Trafficking in human beings represents a highly lucrative business, therefore it is important to fight against the corruption which facilitates it. The EU and its Member States shall increase cooperation with third countries and improve the exchange of information with the aim of investigating and combating transnational trafficking. At EU level, the report recognises and supports the work of the EU Anti-Trafficking Coordinator, established to improve coordination and coherence among the EU institutions, agencies and Member States and third countries and international bodies, and urges the Coordinator to further develop concrete joint action and measures by all these protagonists.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which concerns the fight against trafficking in human beings, underlines the huge financial revenues from this criminal activity and how they re-enter the global economy and the economic system. Different forms of trafficking in human beings, the right of victims to rehabilitation and the need for countries to cooperate at local and international level are mentioned.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Trafficking in human beings, together with drug trafficking and arms trafficking, is one of the most profitable criminal activities. The refugee crisis has brought with it an increased risk of trafficking in human beings, especially for unaccompanied minors. Awareness-raising programmes are designed to raise awareness among Member States' staff responsible for receiving refugees and asylum seekers to the difference between smugglers and traffickers. It also aims to strengthen guardian systems for unaccompanied minors. It is estimated that 35.8 million people worldwide are kept in a form of modern slavery, which is why it is also necessary to ensure that European companies operating in third countries comply with labour standards. I fully agree with the proposal, as better international cooperation is essential for combating trafficking in human beings.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained from voting on this report because the EU is using the fight against human trafficking to demand more power from abroad. The theme makes the opposition politically sensitive.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I support most of the aims and objectives of this report, but not all should fall within the European Union’s sphere of responsibility. I therefore abstained.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which strongly reminds us that human trafficking is a modern form of slavery, an extremely lucrative international crime and one of the worst forms of human rights violations.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. My vote in favour of this report on the fight against trafficking in human beings in the context of the EU's external relations was due to the good document drawn up by my rapporteur, especially when it asks the Commission to assess the need for a possible revision of the mandate of the future European Public Prosecutor's Office in so that the fight against trafficking in human beings is integrated into its powers. I would like to stress the attention paid to trafficking in human beings in the EU's political dialogue with third countries, as well as through its cooperation programmes. Furthermore, the fact that it considers it essential that strategies for the prevention of trafficking in human beings address the factors that facilitate it, as well as the causes and circumstances of this phenomenon, and that they follow an integrated approach, bringing together different actors, mandates and national and international perspectives.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Cooperation and coordination between Member States is crucial in the fight against human trafficking, and this report is an important step in that direction. The report urges the EU and the Member States to deal intensively with the crime of human trafficking. This growing illicit industry of human suffering affects all societies in a profound and enduring manner. The trafficking of human beings is a transnational issue of global nature that is a modern form of slavery. To combat this, we need measures that fight the issue at the root causes and global trends. The EU and Member States should take necessary efforts to combat forced labour in EU industries abroad, particularly in third countries. International cooperation is crucial in the case of trafficking in human beings, where there is currently an insufficient level of cooperation. The EU Anti-Trafficking Coordinator needs further coordination, joint action, and coherence among the EU institutions, agencies, Member States, third countries, and international actors. This report is a great step in the fight against all forms of human trafficking, However, the EU should develop a new post-2016 anti-trafficking strategy with a stronger and more targeted external dimension.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on combating trafficking in human beings. Trafficking in human beings is one of the most horrific forms of human rights violations, as it converts people into goods, essentially and consistently violates the dignity and rights of victims and affects entire families and communities. The ILO estimates that illegal annual profits from forced labour, including money laundering, amount to approximately EUR 150 billion. In the USD, 90% of victims are expected to be exploited in sectors of the private economy and two-thirds of the profits come from commercial sexual exploitation. I support the calls for the Commission to assess the use of the Internet in human trafficking, in particular sexual exploitation through the Internet. It is important that Europol strengthens the fight against trafficking in human beings online. I support the calls on the Commission and the Member States to also develop a definition of trafficking in human beings by strengthening legal instruments to combat trafficking in human beings, including references to new ways of trafficking in human beings. It is also important to review the mandate of the future European Public Prosecutor's Office in order to mandate it to combat trafficking in human beings once it is established.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the EU's participation in international programmes to combat human trafficking. If I am totally committed to this cause, I can only see that the EU is using a really crucial subject to gain more power in terms of foreign policy. Moreover, it is only to note the various failures that other initiatives of this kind, once carried out by the EU, have experienced to understand how illegitimate this claim by Brussels is. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which recalls that, according to the UN Office on Drugs and Crime's Global Report on Trafficking in Persons (2014), 70% of the total victims identified are women and girls. Parliament's report denounces what it considers to be a type of modern slavery and a serious crime constituting one of the worst violations of human rights. Recalling that human trafficking is a transnational crime of a global nature, the report stresses the importance of a coherent approach to the internal and external aspects of EU policies aimed at combating trafficking and deplores the chronic lack of adequate legislation that would make human trafficking a criminal offence in many countries around the world. In the face of this scourge, the report calls in particular on the EU and member states: - to make the necessary efforts to combat forced labour in EU companies operating abroad by enforcing labour law and standards for worker protection; - to provide more support to charities involved in psychological support for victims of forced prostitution.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Lochbihler report on combating trafficking in human beings in the Union's external relations. This is an important issue that shows how the EU's international commitment must go hand in hand with combating crimes that constitute serious human rights violations. The text, starting from a careful analysis of world trends, underlines the existence of a strong economic dimension of the phenomenon and defines some possible lines of action. Firstly, the Commission and the Member States must strengthen legal measures against trafficking in human beings, broadening their definition and providing for their inclusion among the competences of the future European Public Prosecutor. The Eu ropean Union's efforts must take account of the strong gender dimension of the phenomenon, which takes the form of child marriages, the sexual exploitation of women and girls and sex tourism, particularly in some countries with which the EU has relations. It is up to Europe to place particular emphasis on combating trafficking in human beings, especially by calling on third countries to pursue the enforcement agencies more and to increase the mechanisms for protecting victims.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report. Although the text contains elements that I support, as regards the effective protection of persons in situations of forced mobility, and in particular the most vulnerable, I do not share the general approach of the text, which exempts European countries from any responsibility for the root and structural causes, as well as, from the dramatic consequences of mass migration, by concentrating actions only on trafficking and trafficking networks, which are but the consequence of a failed asylum and immigration system. Nor do we share the sectarian view of the humanitarian crisis, which on the one hand doubles victimizes refugees and on the other hand generates a very lucrative business linked to large arms companies, whose expansion is linked to the prevalence of wars that cause mass exoduses.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and good work in this report on combating trafficking in human beings in EU external relations. It believes that Governments should foster dialogue and partnerships between different stakeholders in order to take joint action against trafficking in human beings and to ensure respect for workers' rights. Legal measures are also requested to ensure the transparency and traceability of products in the supply chain. Products must be ensured to be free of exploitation throughout the supply chain and to establish responsibilities in cases of trafficking in human beings occurring anywhere in the chain, including subsidiary and subcontractors.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report on the fight against human trafficking in the external relations of the European Union. Of course, I myself am disgusted by the commodification of human beings , and I am surprised that it is denounced in this report, but that Members do not get excited about other forms of commodification such as the GPA. I also welcome the rapporteur's lucidity on this type of modern slavery. However, I condemn the European institutions' habit of using sensitive and even emotional subjects to wield more power, including replacing Member States in the field of foreign affairs; Member States are perfectly capable of forging bilateral partnerships, particularly in the area of police and judicial cooperation, in order to combat this modern scourge of human trafficking, in particular to apprehend those responsible for trafficking and networks in this area. Moreover, the rapporteur seems to want to use this drama in order to legitimise ever more legal channels of immigration. I denounce such an instrumentalization of human tragedies by the European authorities.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I agree with the objectives that the text initially set itself, namely the fight against trafficking in human beings, I believe that some of the proposals put forward in this report are not acceptable and that could open up future critical issues for our socio-economic fabric; For these reasons, I have decided to abstain.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've dropped my voice. The report has many positive proposals to combat trafficking in human beings. Gender aspects are included and it shows a clear link between prostitution and trafficking in human beings. The problem is the support in the text for The Fort Europe policy. The EU's inhumane and increasingly restrictive refugee and migration policy appears in several places in the report. Anti-trafficking is even used as an excuse for cooperation with dictatorships in the context of the Khartoum process and for legitimising the EU's military action in the Mediterranean (EU Med Nav For). This is not acceptable. What is needed is to combat demand, criminalise the purchase of sex, to discourage the sex industry, which is making huge profits at the expense of vulnerable women, and, above all, to create safe and legal routes into the EU so that women do not become victims of trafficking. That's why I'm going to put my voice down.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Trafficking in human beings is one of the worst forms of human rights abuse, reducing people to mere goods, violating the dignity, integrity and rights of the victim and affecting entire families and communities, deliberately taking advantage of situations of vulnerability, such as poverty or isolation. It is also an extremely lucrative business, whose income is re-injected into the global economy and financial system. In view of this situation, the report, which I have supported, calls on the Commission and the Member States, interrelatedly, to strengthen cooperation with third countries in order to investigate all stages of trafficking in human beings, to improve the exchange of information and to undertake operations, (financial) investigations and legal proceedings on a preventive basis. Likewise; calls for them to adapt their cooperation with third countries to the new situation created by the development of internet trafficking and to strengthen national child protection regimes in Europe as part of the Union's anti-trafficking strategy. And it encourages the EU to develop a new strategy to combat trafficking by 2016 with a stronger and more selective external dimension.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it is necessary to combat trafficking in human beings in the external relations of the European Union. The European Parliament stresses in this report that trafficking in human beings is a type of modern slavery and a serious crime and recognises that trafficking in human beings is carried out both externally and between internal borders, and that strong internal laws on combating trafficking in human beings and cooperation between countries are therefore necessary. The European Parliament condemns the fact that trafficking in human beings is a highly profitable business and that the vast majority of the proceeds of this criminal activity are reinvested in the global economy and the financial system. It is emphasised that trafficking in human beings includes sexual exploitation, prostitution, organ trafficking, forced surrogacy and other cases. Forced marriage can also be considered a form of trafficking in human beings. It is noted that children and people with disabilities are considered to be the most vulnerable to trafficking in human beings. Calls are therefore called for these groups of people to be given close attention and to strengthen national child care systems in Europe or to continue efforts to combat the phenomenon of child-soldiers. It must be acknowledged that information and communication technologies are becoming increasingly important and play a role in trafficking in human beings, and Parliament therefore asks the Commission to adapt its cooperation with third countries to take account of new circumstances such as trafficking in human beings on the Internet.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. Trafficking in human beings is an increasingly important problem in the European Union. Forcing people to change residence has always existed, but with the improvement of border interoperability, it has gained new impetus. I would like to call on the EU institutions and the Member States, in line with the union's fundamental values, to pursue a coherent policy, both inside and outside the Union, by making human rights a central element in the Union's relations with all third countries and using it as a means of promoting human rights, in particular economic and trade relations. It is important to work on information and education among vulnerable population groups, as this would prevent a significant number of cases. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the proposed report on combating trafficking in human beings. Trafficking in human beings is one of the most serious forms of human rights violations and is not acceptable in a society based on respect for these rights. It is a modern form of slavery that needs to be addressed comprehensively - from sexual exploitation, forced labour, organ trafficking, forced begging, forced marriage, to inhumanity, such as the forced integration of children into military structures and the trafficking of babies. Europe must not be immune to these despicable acts, we must clearly condemn them and stand up to them more strongly. First, we need to sweep up at our doorstep, where more and more dirt is accumulating. We do way too little to prevent the above-mentioned acts against EU citizens who also become victims of trafficking. I therefore agree that cooperation between countries in the field of organised crime needs to be strengthened and legislation to be tackled more effectively. The refugee-migrant crisis is a multibillion-dollar deal for traffickers, and the more effective we will be in dealing with the crisis, the worse it will be for these traffickers. We must also extend our activities beyond the EU's borders, especially to less developed countries, where trafficking in human beings is most prevalent.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is one of the most serious forms of violation of fundamental rights and is usually linked to other types of crime and forms of exploitation, such as sexual exploitation, organ trafficking, forced labour and enslavement. Unfortunately, we are faced with an increasingly widespread phenomenon which cannot leave us indifferent. With the resolution voted on today, which I supported, Parliament wanted to loudly denounce all forms of trafficking-related crime, highlighting the need for the Union to be consistent and decisive in relation to a phenomenon that is, today more than ever, transnational. Adopting a shared approach at European level and ensuring coherence between the internal and external dimension of the Union's policies is therefore essential. It is also appropriate to invest in sufficient and appropriate resources to combat this crime, developing the technologies and skills necessary for its prevention, for tracing and prosecuting criminal networks, but also for providing adequate assistance and full access to justice for the victims of this phenomenon.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this Anti-Trafficking Report on EU external relations. The report describes global trends in human trafficking, and stresses that trafficking is a very lucrative business and starts with how these crimes are largely injected into the global economy and financial system.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This text calls for EU participation in international programmes against human trafficking, which is commendable. My feeling is that, beyond good intentions, these proposals are in fact only intended to strengthen the EU's powers internationally. So I abstained.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The report has some commendable aspects; it calls for cooperation in combatting human trafficking, it is strong on the impact for women and children, and calls on the EU to do more to find missing refugees etc. However, the inclusion of calls for greater EU military presence in the Mediterranean, claims that exploitation does not occur in transit countries, some questionable suggestions regarding refugees, and calls for an EU cross-border labour mechanism, make the report impossible to support. Therefore, on this basis, I abstained on the final roll-call vote.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU and its Member States cannot accept trafficking in human beings in any way or the exploitation of people in whatever form. According to the International Labour Organisation, around 21 million people worldwide are victims of the most common forms of modern slavery, including forced labour, which generates profits of more than EUR 30 billion per year, organ trafficking and forced sexual exploitation, which affects 80% of all victims of trafficking in human beings; notes that men are no exception, but the most vulnerable groups, such as the elderly, women, the sick, people with disabilities and children, are most affected, with an estimated 5.5 million children being treated. Conservative estimates by the International Organisation for Migration put the profits of child trafficking at around €7.6 billion per year. Interpol data also shows that more than ten thousand children have disappeared after arriving in Europe, becoming victims of trafficking for the purpose of begging, sexual exploitation or illegal buying and selling. We must act to stop these unworthy events.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the European Union's participation in international programmes against human trafficking. While we are, of course, in favour of doing everything possible to eradicate the criminal organisations that engage in these barbaric practices, we consider that the European Union has no legitimacy and credibility to deal with this issue. That is why I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is one of the most serious forms of human rights abuse, in deep and long-term violation of the dignity, integrity and rights of the victim. One of the obstacles to combating trafficking in human beings is to apply the legal framework poorly at national level, as well as the lack of an appropriate legal framework in third countries. We need European and global action, bearing in mind that this issue is one that transcends borders and thus is extremely difficult to resolve at national level. It is estimated that 53.8 million people worldwide have fallen into the trap of modern slavery, which means that human trafficking is endemic in nature and affects all regions of the world. This data cannot leave us impassive, we need to react and combat this ever-expanding phenomenon. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's fight against all forms of human rights abuse also concerns trafficking in human beings, one of the most serious actions that deeply violates the dignity and integrity of people. Vulnerable people most often fall victim, through threats or force, for the purpose of exploitation, be it sexual, reproductive, forced labour, slavery or slavery-like practices. In addition, trafficking in human beings also hides an overwhelming gender problem, as according to the Eurostat 2015 report, more than 80% of victims are women. This phenomenon is present all over the world, both in rich states (the destination of many sexual victims, in begging or in illicit transplants), and in developing countries (the country of the start-up of many victims and exploitation through modern slavery). This international criminal activity constitutes a profitable and highly developed business, seriously violating human dignity. I believe that states should make efforts and cooperate closely to change traffic from a low-risk and high-profit business to one with high risk and low profit. The EU's role in external relations in combating trafficking in human beings is decisive, and this report reinforces legislation in this regard.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the fight against human trafficking in the external relations of the European Union. Trafficking in human beings is a type of modern slavery. It is one of the worst forms of human rights violations. It is one of the most lucrative criminal activities in the world. In many countries, the lack of legislation does not effectively combat trafficking. This scourge also affects Europe. For example, more than 10,000 unaccompanied refugee children or migrants have disappeared in recent years. The European Union must strengthen cooperation, coordination and information exchange with third countries.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of paragraph 41 of the report because, although condemning the illegal is superfluous and can lead to confusion, I cannot afford to vote against it to remove an explicit reference to the negative of conducting illegal business.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted 'yes' to the report on combating trafficking in human beings in the Union's external relations because I believe that the trafficking in human beings which is the slavery of our time must be combated in every way. This is a huge violation of human rights and a complex transnational phenomenon that also has its roots in gender inequality. Every effort must be made, now more than ever, to prevent and combat trafficking in human beings, to protect victims and to establish common rules to be applied in all Member States. Our objective, the Objective of the European Union, must be to identify and better understand the links between organised crime and the exploitation of human beings, because in order to combat a criminal phenomenon, we must first clearly outline its characteristics. The Member States must make every effort to combat this odious practice, including with the help and support of civil society.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The report has some commendable aspects; it calls for cooperation in combatting human trafficking, it is strong on the impact of trafficking on women and children, and it calls on the EU to do more to find missing refugees etc. But the inclusion of calls for greater EU military presence in the Mediterranean and claims that exploitation does not occur in transit countries make the report impossible to support. For these reasons I abstained on the final vote.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which addressed trafficking in human beings and called for effective measures to combat it. I welcome the EU engaging in the anti-trafficking fight as our fundamental principles are based on respect for human rights and gender equality. To  fight the well-organised criminal chain, I call for regional and international cooperation in drawing up specific legislation and ensuring uniform implementation as it is the only effective way of fighting cross-border crime. Moreover, women and children are more vulnerable to those crimes and should be given special care and attention.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report defines very broadly the crime of trafficking in human beings by covering all related forms, such as the exploitation of prostitution, organ trafficking and labour exploitation. Due attention is also paid to the root causes of the phenomenon, as well as to the economic aspects of trafficking in human beings. I support the view that the fight against this phenomenon will take place on several fronts, that is, through the fight against corruption and the confiscation of resources and revenues related to the phenomenon. In the light of all these aspects, I voted with great conviction in favour of this report.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is unacceptable that practices like human trafficking still exist in the modern world; they have to be fought against. Thus, such motions as in this report have to be supported. It is our duty to not only protect our citizens, but also to promote human rights and to fight inhuman treatment all over the world. Our political and economic capacity is the tool.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings brings huge profits to organised crime, effectively reducing people to goods. This crime affects the most vulnerable, as shown by UN estimates, where women account for 70% of the victims. The Union must make the necessary efforts at international level to prevent and repress the slave trade, to achieve the complete abolition of slavery in all its forms as soon as possible, by ratifying all relevant international instruments and by creating legal access routes to Europe so as to avoid any possible exploitation. There is also a need to strengthen cooperation with third countries most affected by trafficking, given that in many of them the lack of an adequate legal framework for trafficking in human beings is one of the main obstacles to the fight against this serious crime. The resolution identifies the necessary actions to be taken at international level, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. – We support the report and stress that trafficking in human beings is a modern type of slavery and a serious crime which is one of the worst forms of human rights violations and cannot be accepted in societies based on respect for human rights, including gender equality.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on combating human trafficking in the EU's external relations concerns a particularly important social issue that we must address with caution. The need to protect citizens is constant and such reports contain positive elements. However, the fact that the report does not come up with concrete proposals, while at the same time not focusing as much as it should on the protection of refugees, has led me to the decision to abstain.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on 'combating trafficking in human beings in relations outside the Union' because I believe that trafficking in human beings can be considered a new form of slavery, a serious crime on the increase. I also believe that the common response to this fight must be regional and interregional cooperation and that it is essential to promote coordination actions and the exchange of information between The Member States, while also increasing their financial and technical support in response to the problem, together with a strengthening at legislative level.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am convinced that the strategy presented by the Commission on guidelines for international trade has very good potential. In fact, the proposal brings to light important phenomena, including the increasing use of the digital economy. In this regard, the rapporteur is right to point out that it is essential that the European Union's trade policy should keep pace with digital and technological trends because, in my opinion, falling behind would mean losing part of the market that would end up in non-European countries. A second point that is very close to my heart is the inclusion of a chapter calling for greater attention to be paid to the specific needs of small and medium-sized enterprises so that they can take full advantage of trade and investment agreements and thus conduct international activities, including outside the European Union. I am therefore convinced that this is a good proposal and have therefore voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the fight against trafficking in the EU’s external relations.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. Trafficking in human beings is one of the most serious forms of human rights violations and is one of the most profitable organised crime activities, affecting mostly women for the exploitation of sexual services but not only. I support the Lochbihler Report on the fight against trafficking in human beings in the context of the EU's external relations which repudiates this activity and which cannot be tolerated in the light of European societal values and standards and which unfortunately also occurs within our internal borders. I regret the lack of adequate legislation to combat this scourge and the lack of cooperation between countries and the number of known victims who do not have access to adequate protection and support is limited or non-existent access to justice. Particular attention should be paid to illegal migration flows that increase the risk of trafficking due to their vulnerability and irregular situation, in particular unaccompanied minors such as the 10,000 children who have disappeared in Europe according to Europol. It is pressing that the EU continues with all its efforts to combat this phenomenon in all its forms (sexual, slavery, forced begging, organ trafficking) in particular in its relationship with third countries.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is a phenomenon that requires specific measures and it is essential to distinguish between the concept of trafficking in human beings and that of trafficking in migrants. Targeted awareness-raising programmes should be developed to distinguish migrant trafficking from trafficking in human beings, in particular with regard to the identification and protection of trafficking victims of children and unaccompanied minors at risk of trafficking. Trafficking in human beings, as an organised crime, occurs at both cross-border and national level, so we need strong internal laws against trafficking and cooperation between countries. The EU and its Member States must adopt a human rights-based approach that focuses on crime prevention and victim protection. I voted in favour of this report because it aims to strengthen coordination, cooperation and the systematic exchange of information in order to investigate and combat trafficking in human beings, through the strengthening of financial and technical assistance and the strengthening of communication, cooperation and the establishment of cross-border capacities at the level of governments and law enforcement authorities.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report focuses on the victims of human trafficking and takes cognisance of the geo-political circumstances and socio-economic factors that drive people to fall victims to human trafficking. It proposes European action addressing causes of human trafficking. It also focuses on trafficking networks, takes cognisance of their impact on the human rights of the victims, on societies and economies. It proposes stronger internal laws against human trafficking and cooperation between countries. It asks the EU to engage with third countries and to ensure enforcement of legislation and to invest in technology and expertise to identify, trace and combat misuse of the internet by criminal networks who recruit victims and sell victims online. It identifies different purposes of exploitation including sexual exploitation, forced labour, organ trafficking, forced begging, forced marriages, child soldiers and trafficking of babies, and proposes measures to enhance the role of authorities as well as civil society organisations in assisting victims to walk away from the abuse.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully supported the report on the external dimension of trafficking in human beings because this modern slavery is a global challenge that needs a global response. We need to step up our  police and judiciary cooperation to fight traffickers and combat impunity. The majority of victims of trafficking are women and girls to be exploited for prostitution. Countries need to reduce demand, and criminalising the use of services of a victim of trafficking is crucial. We need to do more on prevention, to identify early potential victims of human trafficking, even by using the internet to raise awareness. Protection of victims is also essential, with shelter and psychological assistance. Particular attention should be given to children, abused, trafficked all over the world to be exploited for child labour, child soldier, child marriage and other kind violence. Let’s join forces to eradicate this atrocity. It is time for women, children and men to be freed!

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. It is an initiative with positive intentions, but it does not offer concrete and specific solutions that contribute to the real fight against trafficking in human beings. Priority is not given to urgent measures that must involve actions by transit countries that are crucial to combating this scourge. That's why I abstained.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is one of the worst forms of human rights violations. Women and children are the main victims of traditional forms of trafficking - sexual exploitation, forced labour, child slavery, organ collection - and new forms such as forced exploitation in sectors such as domestic work, production and cleaning services. This resolution brings global attention to a cross-border issue, which tends to increase and feed on migratory flows, international conflicts, repressed socio-economic situations that act as incubators. It is important to reiterate that the demand for sexual services in developed countries and forced labour in European companies against third-country nationals fuel trafficking in human beings from developing countries, and that the use of the Internet can facilitate trafficking. By voting in favour, I hope that the resolution will encourage all countries in the world, and in particular the Member States, to have adequate legislation to prevent this phenomenon, punish the perpetrators of crimes and guarantee victims access to justice, as well as to cooperate in financial investigations that recover goods and money from trafficking and re-enter the world economy.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report takes a very clear stance against trafficking in human beings in all forms: forced labour, forced surrogacy, begging, torture and extortion, organ harvesting, etc. The figures are shocking: the number of victims worldwide is estimated at 35 million and the annual profits from trafficking in human beings amount to hundreds of billions of euros. The report contains a number of recommendations, most of which should be supported. These include a call for closer international cooperation, a call for increased action to recover illicit profits and a call to reduce the overall demand for victims of trafficking and their 'services'. Trafficking in human beings is an extremely serious problem that needs to be addressed, including in the EU's external relations. The report also calls for the EU and the Member States to hold companies, as well as related companies and subcontractors throughout their supply chain, accountable for trafficking in human beings. All companies, of course, should be vigilant, but the above request is unrealistic and unfair. For these reasons, I abstained from voting.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Trafficking of human beings is a violation of human rights. We need to address all types of trafficking in order to fight this reality and safeguard all citizens. We need to make sure that the rights each citizen is entitled to are safeguarded, and that we ensure a solid framework of cooperation between the Member States and with third countries. It is also fundamentally important to understand and acknowledge the difference between trafficking in migrants and the trafficking of human beings. For these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings, understood as sexual exploitation, forced labour, organ trafficking, child soldiers or trafficking in babies, affects all societies today and must no longer be tolerated. The European Convention on Human Rights, the European Social Charter and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and all relevant international treaties on human rights condemn trafficking in human beings, as it is one of the worst forms of violation of human rights, as it violates the dignity and integrity of the individual. I want to call on the EU to strengthen coordination, cooperation and exchange of information, the strengthening of financial assistance and communication between Member State governments and third countries. Furthermore, given the insufficient level of international cooperation on trafficking in human beings, the EU must strengthen cooperation with NGOs and other international organisations as soon as possible and adopt appropriate legislation to effectively combat trafficking in human beings in all its forms. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on human trafficking and recognizes human trafficking as a new kind of modern slavery, a crime against humanity.  However, the report stresses the necessary distinction between human trafficking and migrant trafficking, considering that these concepts involve different legal responses and different obligations of Member States. The report places particular emphasis on regional and international cooperation against human trafficking, calling for greater coordination and systematic exchange of information.  Considering that the external policy of the European Union must provide answers against human trafficking in conjunction with our partners, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative report. We are strong supporters of any measures to combat the trafficking of people, however we do not support the European Union taking actions on these measures. The free movement of people and Schengen has contributed to an increase in people trafficking within the EU. We think it is hypocritical of the EU to discuss measures outside of the EU when it refuses to acknowledge this. However out of respect for the sensitivity of the subject and our support for measures to combat it we abstained.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the fight against human trafficking in the Union's external relations. This report focuses on regional and international cooperation against human trafficking. This seems to me to be paramount given the increasingly cross-border nature of this crime. The European Union must strengthen the exchange of information but also cooperation with third countries to dismantle criminal networks of human trafficking. In addition, the vast majority of victims, women and children, must be able to make themselves known and have access to justice and information about their rights.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation voted in favour of the report. The cross-border nature of trafficking in human beings requires an international and European approach. The figures are staggering, an estimated 35 million people worldwide have already been victimised. The N-VA is pleased that the report takes a very clear position against trafficking in human beings, and in all its forms: sexual exploitation, forced labour, torture and extortion, the illegal removal of organs and tissues. In addition, an integrated approach to trafficking in human beings is proposed. The proposed initiatives concern the prevention of trafficking in human beings, assistance to victims and the detection and prosecution of traffickers.  Nevertheless, the N-VA wishes to make three critical comments on the report. Firstly, we regard a strict separation between immigration authorities and labour inspectorates as a counterproductive measure. Indeed, many Member States are just trying to coordinate the work of their various public authorities so that trafficking in human beings can be tackled more efficiently. Secondly, the N-VA considers it unrealistic that companies should be held liable for the activities of affiliates. Finally, it prefers non-binding recommendations to respond to the business world, rather than an international legally binding instrument.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the fight against human trafficking in EU external relations because it contains a series of recommendations which I support with energy and conviction. Although most countries in the world have laws prohibiting human trafficking, these laws are unfortunately not properly implemented or are very superficial. In addition, some companies located in the European Union benefit from forced labour in other countries. The resolution supports the idea that EU trade policy should be used as an instrument to demand more work from third countries. Finally, with regard to victims, it is necessary to ensure that they will receive adequate legal protection and that they will not be threatened with being sent back to where they came from. At the moment, only a few victims go to court because we do not protect them enough.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Trafficking in human beings is one of the most unacceptable forms of organized crime. At the initiative of now globalized networks, this crime violates the fundamental values of human rights. According to the latest world slavery report, 35.8 million people are trapped in modern slavery.  Anti-trafficking legislation is not yet sufficiently implemented around the world. To combat this scourge, the European Union must strengthen police and judicial cooperation between Member States and with third countries - in particular countries of origin and transit of victims - in the area of prevention and prosecution. It must also increase its strong incentive to take action against this crime and continue to promote human rights in its external policies - development policies, trade policies, investments, etc.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text deals with EU participation in international programmes against human trafficking. It appears that the European Union is using the fight against human trafficking to increase its prerogatives at the international level. However, given the serious and serious nature of this subject, I preferred to abstain.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Illegal trafficking in human beings is a crime pursued by both international and national law. Today, however, millions of people fall victim to trafficking both within and outside the European Union.  This trafficking directly affects us as we are an external border of the Union and the first place where illegal immigrants cross. Me and my group are firmly in favour of the fight against trafficking in human beings, but we cannot accept some of the proposals in the report, such as the proposal to create "legal" and secure routes for immigrants flooding the European Union. For the reasons listed, I abstained on the report on combating trafficking in human beings in the EU's external relations.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. Unfortunately, such an important issue is not being treated with the necessary seriousness, and so the ideas of certain individuals have enabled this resolution to be turned into a tool to legalise illegal immigration.  The author ignores that the trafficking rings of illegal immigrants in many cases also trade people, and also ignores the fact that a large part of illegal immigrants declare false age in the countries of entry, in order to exploit insidious provisions such as this one. At the same time, the additional funding of the countries where the phenomenon of child soldiers is detected will in no way solve the problem, but will intensify it, as is the case with many of the problems that exist in those countries. It is also at least contradictory that the EU wants to crack down on trade in human beings and organs and at the same time Kosovo is seen as a country to join the EU.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report. There is an urgent need to tackle human trafficking. It is one of the worst forms of human rights abuses and affects millions of people worldwide.  I have worked on this issue for several years and I’m sure that my constituents in Wales would expect me to support action to protect the victims, and ensure the prosecution of perpetrators. This is best done on a European level.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. For me, it is incredibly important that we in the international community work together to prevent people being exploited and subjected to crime. It is important that the EU and its Member States actively work towards the exploitation of people, and in the international contexts in which we act work to develop international instruments to prevent this type of exploitation. For me, it is the result that is important and that together we find the best tools to prevent people being exploited, and not that these tools must look in a specific way.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Around 70 % of the victims found are women and girls and make up 79% of the victims of sexual exploitation. Men make up 83% of victims of forced labour. The illegal annual profit generated by forced labour, including through money laundering, is about US$150 billion, with an estimated 90% of victims being exploited in the private economy and two-thirds of the profits derived from commercial sexual exploitation, making it the most profitable form of exploitation. I therefore voted in favour of the report calling on the EU and the Member States to follow a human rights-based, victim-centred approach and to put victims and vulnerable populations at the centre of all efforts to combat and prevent trafficking in human beings and to protect their victims.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention: The EU is using the fight against human trafficking to demand more powers.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings remains one of the most heinous and current crimes that affects, through modern forms of slavery and the violation of human rights, different categories of vulnerable persons.  Sexual exploitation, forced labour, organ trafficking are just some of the aspects that fuel a global phenomenon that requires a holistic approach and equally global responses and strategies. Coordination, cooperation and the exchange of information with third countries is also essential for the fight against transnational trafficking in human beings, to be pursued both through an effective fight against and repression of the crime of exploitation and through the creation of systems to identify, protect and assist victims, addressing all the factors that contribute to facilitating this abhorrent phenomenon.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report presents exhaustively over more than one hundred points the global trends in trafficking in human beings; the economy of trafficking in human beings, the rights of victims and the issue of their compensation, the defence of cooperation in the fight against trafficking at regional and international level. Finally, it addresses the policy that the EU must pursue on trafficking in human beings in the context of its external relations.  Regrettably, the report avoids addressing some of the root causes of the phenomenon - as evidenced by the rejection of the amendments we have proposed on wars, exploitation and inequalities in the distribution of wealth. On the other hand, it assumes that the phenomenon does not exist within the EU itself and is limited to other continents. Nato's role and action in triggering such phenomena is ignored, for example the Libyan war - which has strengthened criminal activities, including human trafficking networks. It adopts a complacent stance with multinationals that make use of slave or forced labor that comes from human trafficking. Containing positive aspects, the report does not truly seek the causes of the phenomenon. For this fundamental reason, it fails in the guidelines for its combat.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is still the worst form of human rights violations and is part of organised crime. Trafficking in human beings humiliates people for goods, undermines their integrity, dignity and rights. Oftentimes, a state such as poverty is abused. According to the 2014 Human Trafficking Report, 75% of victims are girls and women, especially in the area of sexual exploitation. Trafficking in human beings can therefore be characterised as a gender-based crime. According to Europol, the worldwide expansion of internet access allows for the increasing development of trafficking in human beings online. There is also a link between migrant smuggling and human trafficking, as it is groups of smugglers who offer their services over the Internet and this is not a transitional phenomenon. It is illegal migratory flows that increase the risk of human trafficking and there is a risk that traffickers are targeting unaccompanied minors.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. Unfortunately, such an important issue is not being treated with the necessary seriousness, and so the ideas of certain individuals have enabled this resolution to be turned into a tool to legalise illegal immigration. The author ignores that the trafficking rings of illegal immigrants in many cases also trade people, and also ignores the fact that a large part of illegal immigrants declare false age in the countries of entry in order to exploit insidious provisions such as this one. At the same time, the additional funding of the countries where the phenomenon of child soldiers is detected will in no way solve the problem, but will intensify it, as is the case with many of the problems that exist in those countries. At the same time, it is at least contradictory that the EU wants to crack down on trade in human beings and organs and at the same time to regard Kosovo as a country for EU membership. That is why I am voting against the report.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report describes the global trends in trafficking of human beings; it also underlines that the trafficking is a highly lucrative business and that the proceeds from this criminal activity are largely re-injected into the global economy and financial system. The rapporteur reports on the different forms of exploitation, the victim’s rights including the right to remedy, the cooperation against trafficking in human beings at regional and international level and the EU policy in its external relations. Moreover, the report makes a clear link between trafficking in migrants and trafficking in human beings. I supported the report in the Plenary.

name: Мария Габриел (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported this report because of the important message it sends by recognising trafficking in human beings as a serious criminal offence of a transnational nature. The report recognises the importance of a coherent approach to the internal and external dimension of EU anti-trafficking policies. I support the fact that it distinguishes between the concepts of trafficking in human beings and migrant smuggling, as the two concepts require different legal and political answers. I believe that it is essential to pay particular attention to the fight against trafficking in human beings in the EU's political dialogue with third countries, as well as through cooperation programmes and in multilateral and regional for a. I have always stressed the need for coherence of internal and external policy, which implies the development of partnerships with third countries in the field of combating trafficking in human beings, in line with the fundamental values of the Union. I welcome the fact that the report recognises and supports the work of the EU Anti-Trafficking Coordinator and calls for joint action between the EU, Member States, third countries and international actors in order to establish more coherent and effective cooperation to establish systems to identify, protect and assist victims of trafficking.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. – According to the latest Global Slavery Index, 35.8 million persons are estimated to be trapped in situation of modern slavery worldwide, while according to the ILO around 21 million people are in forced labour globally, being trafficked for labour and sexual exploitation or being held in slave-like conditions. Therefore, the fight against trafficking in human beings should remain at the heart of the EU’s development policies and partnerships with third countries. The EU and the Member States should increase cooperation with third countries in order to investigate all stages of trafficking in human beings. With clear, firm steps against smugglers / human traffickers, the death of thousands could be prevented during the current migration crisis.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of the report on combating trafficking in human beings. Trafficking in human beings is one of the most horrific forms of crime, and the unfortunately growing sector based on it must therefore be completely impossible. I agree with the element of the report that in our society, which is based on respect for human rights, including gender equality, there is no place for similar activities. The concept itself must be interpreted in a holistic way and focus not only on sexual exploitation, but also on forced labour, organ trafficking, begging, forced marriage, the problem of child slavery or the trafficking of babies. Trafficking in human beings can also be a consequence of global economic and social inequalities, which can be exacerbated by social inequalities between men and women. This must be prevented, as violence against women is defined in the EU strategy as the root cause of trafficking in human beings.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report with the firm determination to once again position the EU in the fight against trafficking in human beings, one of the worst forms of human rights abuse. According to the latest Global Slavery Index, an estimated 35.8 million people worldwide are trapped in situations of modern slavery, confirming the endemic nature of trafficking in human beings and their impact in all regions of the world. We must work to eradicate a desponable practice that constitutes a transnational crime of a global nature and take a victim- and vulnerable-oriented approach that puts them at the focus of all efforts to prevent and protect them.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The trafficking of human beings is one of the most serious issues that the EU is facing in the present moment and this lucrative business need to be fought at every level of governance. Since the start of the refugee crisis in Europe, more than 10 000 unaccompanied migrant children have disappeared. This cannot be tolerated and we must do everything within our capabilities to stop these activities. In terms of external actions, we need to strengthen our regional and international cooperation in order to put pressure on the human traffickers and we must include this aspect in our dealings with third countries in our neighbourhood.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on combating trafficking in human beings in the Eu ropean Union's external relations because I firmly believe that this new form of slavery must be condemned and combated with all the instruments at its disposal. This modern trafficking in human beings, which consists of reducing people to goods and objects and which mainly affects the most vulnerable people, such as women and children, is the new tragic frontier of the business of international organised crime and is the worst form of exploitation and human violence. Trafficking, exploitation and slavery are defined as practically all kinds of violence against the most help-helped: from prostitution, forced labour, the recruitment of untidy children, to organ collection and trafficking. All repulsive, degrading practices which the international community must combat with all possible forces. As advocated in the EP resolution, it is of paramount importance that the EU strengthens police and judicial cooperation between Member States and the countries of origin and transit of victims of trafficking in human beings, as well as making greater efforts in the field of information exchange and in identifying situations of forced labour in EU companies abroad.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on combating trafficking in human beings in the EU's external relations. The text sets completely the wrong tone on this very important subject. Moreover, as a Christian politician, I will never accept official documents from the European Parliament declaring abortion a general human right.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the report on combating trafficking in human beings in the EU's external relations. The report recognises trafficking in human beings as a modern form of slavery.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 At the last sittings of parliament we have repeatedly addressed issues relating to war situations, women being violated, child soldiers, the exploitation of entire populations and their subjugation to the absurd will of ruthless formally democratic dictatorial governments. Unfortunately, It seems to me that the time has come to get out of the particularism and to acknowledge that there are realities, even very close to us, in which people are treated as objects, without dignity or worthy of respect. We have a very powerful weapon for promoting human rights if we put this issue as a priority in the Union's international relations with third countries. We should remember that people are worth more than goods and the protection of the weakest is a pillar of this Union. It is with great conviction that I support this report: I believe that every relationship with third countries must from now on consider the implications in terms of combating trafficking, organised crime that is the commodity of women and children.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report. Although the text contains elements that I support, as regards the effective protection of persons in situations of forced mobility, and in particular the most vulnerable, I do not share the general approach of the text, which exempts European countries from any responsibility for the root and structural causes, as well as, from the dramatic consequences of mass migration, by concentrating actions only on trafficking and trafficking networks, which are but the consequence of a failed asylum and immigration system. Nor do we share the sectarian view of the humanitarian crisis, which on the one hand doubles victimizes refugees and on the other hand generates a very lucrative business linked to large arms companies, whose expansion is linked to the prevalence of wars that cause mass exoduses.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report, which I voted for, condemns all forms of human trafficking and addresses challenges linked to it, such as migration, modern information technology and lack of legislation. The report underlines the links between trafficking in migrants and trafficking in human beings. The report further recommends enhanced cooperation with third countries and highlights the importance of using existing instruments to prevent and combat human trafficking.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Member States should do more to protect victims of human trafficking, especially women who make up 80% of trafficked persons, yet their specific needs are not being taken into account. EU legislation meant to protect victims of trafficking is not being properly implemented. Trafficked people must be treated as victims, not criminals, and given enough support to recover and return to a normal life.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
