text: Writing. \u2012 In the report there are very important elements and proposals to tackle trafficking in human beings. There is a broad analysis of what trafficking is, what forms it takes and especially which categories of the population are most vulnerable. Specific references are made to refugees, migrants, women and children.  The report calls on the Commission and the External Action Service to raise this issue in the context of the Union's external action and to attempt international cooperation to combat the phenomenon and also to support victims of trafficking. However, the references to Operation Sophia with which we as a group disagree, as well as to measures to strengthen borders and controls, force us to observe a position of abstention.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒  Given the transnational nature of human trafficking, there is need for a consistent approach to the internal and external dimensions of the EU’s policies for combating it. There has been a lack of adequate legislation to criminalise and effectively combat trafficking in human beings in many countries worldwide. As well as this, there is a wide gap between the legislation that does exist and implementation thereof, including on the one hand the limited or non-existent access to justice for victims and on the other hand the lack of prosecution of perpetrators.  I support enhanced coordination, cooperation and the systematic exchange of information to investigate and combat transnational trafficking in human beings by stepping up financial and technical assistance and strengthening cross-border communication, and capacity building at government and law enforcement level, including border guards, immigration and asylum officials, criminal investigators and victim support agencies, civil society. The EU should enhance police and judicial cooperation between Member States and with third countries – in particular with countries of origin and transit of victims of trafficking in human beings – in the prevention, investigation and prosecution of trafficking in human beings.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this report as it takes an in-depth look at the current fight against trafficking in human beings in areas where the EU has built relations with external parties. The report makes important distinctions between human trafficking and migrant smuggling, whilst also clarifying a number of issues that have developed in the fight against human trafficking.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report on the fight against trafficking in human beings in the EU's external relations, as the name suggests, is aimed at combating trafficking in human beings in all its forms. It provides facts and figures on sexual exploitation and enslavement, organ trafficking, child soldiers, etc. and makes sensible proposals on how the EU, in cooperation with international organisations and third countries, can actively combat these criminal activities.  The original version has been supplemented with paragraph 12. It calls for all companies and subcontractors to be held liable and, accordingly, to be sanctioned if any form of trafficking or exploitation has played a role along their entire supply and production chain. This requirement is totally unacceptable because, for obvious reasons, a company or even a subcontractor cannot have an overview of every single step in the supply and production chain and is not responsible for each of these steps. The demand therefore amounts to wanting to redistribute responsibility. Although I personally strongly support the fight against trafficking in human beings, I voted against the report because of paragraph 12.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The trafficking of human beings is a scandal in the twenty-first century affecting millions of people worldwide.  EU cooperation has a vital role in tackling this issue and this report makes a number of important recommendations.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. "U2012 I vote in favour of this report which sets out trends in trafficking in human beings in the world, as well as the economic dimension of trafficking in human beings, underlines the rights of victims, including the right of appeal, promotes cooperation against trafficking in human beings at regional and international level and proposes a fair Union policy on trafficking in human beings in their external action.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report talks about different forms of exploitation, the victim’s rights including the right to remedy, the cooperation against trafficking in human beings at regional and international level and the EU policy in its external relations. One major problem underlined in the report is that the level of international co-operation is insufficient on cases of trafficking in human beings, particularly where countries of origin and countries of transit are involved. The report indicates that the EU should develop a regional approach, concentrating on the so-called ‘trafficking routes’ and should offer responses which are adapted to the type of exploitation in the different regions.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on combating human trafficking in EU external relations (2015/2340(INI)), as I support the efforts of the EU, Member States and partner countries to combat this very widespread and unfortunately archaic criminal activity. The consequences of human trafficking are terrifying. This is about modern slavery, child exploitation, prostitution, begging, potential security danger, endangering basic human rights, one of the worst forms of denial of human dignity, murder, human organ trafficking, and the increasing strengthening of criminal organisations. This problem is not sufficiently addressed only in the internal territory of EU countries. The EU needs to develop its own policy, adopt a strategy and carry out activities, and strengthen cooperation with third countries where the source of this problem lies. Building functioning states, the legal, legislative and security systems of the most vulnerable countries, especially those in the neighbourhood, should be helped so that they can confront criminal groups that trade in people. The fight against criminal networks engaged in human trafficking requires an international response where the EU needs to play a leading role in particular in cooperation with countries from the immediate environment.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report refers to the EU's participation in international programmes against human trafficking. In view of the political sensitivity of this theme, the European Union is using it as a pretext to increase its powers more and more with state actors, but also internationally. To this extent, I have preferred to abstain so as not to allow the Union to extend its prerogatives further.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings in any form is undoubtedly a reprehensible business and essentially a kind of modern slavery that has no place not only in today's Europe, but in the world in general. Unfortunately, this is still a growing industry, with women mostly victims of sexual abuse, men being used for forced labour. Moreover, in 2014, more than 10,000 unaccompanied minor refugees and unaccompanied children were lost in Europe, and we do not know whether they ended up in the hands of traffickers. I therefore voted in favour of the report, which calls for increased cooperation between Member States in the fight against trafficking in human beings as part of the Union's foreign relations. The key in this fight is to realize that human trafficking takes many forms and it is necessary to actively fight them all. Similarly, we must focus on the rights of victims and promote a strategy for the EU on this issue.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Barbara Lochbihler's report on the fight against human trafficking in EU external relations. This report reminds us that human trafficking is an increasingly common modern form of slavery. The text identifies several forms of exploitation and calls for victims to be given several rights. It encourages greater regional and international cooperation against trafficking through information sharing, the fight against corruption in the public sector and private sector accountability. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The Lochbihler report has many positive proposals on how to combat trafficking in human beings. It contains many good ideas but the overall language and spirit of the report, when it comes to migration and asylum issues, is very much that of Fortress Europe. The gender perspective is present and a clear link is made between prostitution and human trafficking. The problem is the ‘hidden’ support in the text for a Fortress Europe policy. The EU’s inhumane and increasingly restrictive refugee and migration policy pops up in several places in the report. Efforts to combat human trafficking are used as an excuse for cooperation with dictatorships, under the Khartoum process, and to legitimise EU military operations in the Mediterranean (EU with NAV). This is not acceptable. Therefore, since there are many positive points but also some which are not that positive, EH Bildu abstained in the final vote on this report.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which recognizes human trafficking as a modern form of slavery, an extremely lucrative international crime and one of the worst forms of human rights violations. Moreover, the text makes an essential distinction that must be made between human trafficking and migrant trafficking, indicating that each concept requires different legal and practical responses. If Parliament had assessed the implementation of EU legislation last May, it was time to take this phenomenon more into account in the Union's external relations.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted for the report on the fight against trafficking in human beings in the EU’s external relations as it addresses a universal need to tackle human trafficking in all of its dimensions. For that, a coordinated interdisciplinary approach is needed, and this report attempts to encompass all the various aspects of the problem with a multi-dimensional solution.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report rightly states that trafficking in human beings is part of organised crime and that the fight against it must take a more prominent place in the EU's foreign policy strategy. The high number of missing minor migrants within the EU demonstrates the special need for protection of this group, and children who are victims of trafficking in human beings in particular are often abused for child pornography. I agree with the report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it condemns all forms of human trafficking and addresses challenges linked to it, such as migration, modern information technology or lack of legislation.  It makes clear recommendations, encouraging enhanced cooperation with third countries and pointing out the importance of all existing instruments to prevent and combat human trafficking.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although this report is part of the fight against the heinous form of modern slavery that is trafficking in human beings, I have decided to abstain.  I believe that the text presents a number of good practices, but at the same time does not go into concrete measures. In addition, it is necessary to clarify a number of reports on the proposed capacity building at government and law enforcement level, including the capacities of border guards, immigration and asylum officials.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on combating trafficking in human beings in the EU's external relations. Trafficking in human beings is one of the most serious forms of human rights violations. This serious crime must be dealt with in a holistic manner, focusing not only on sexual exploitation, but also on forced labour, organ trafficking, forced begging, forced marriages, child soldiers and baby trafficking.  The EU must target foreign policy instruments in order to break this lucrative and immoral model and increase the protection of victims of crime.  According to statistics from the UN Office on Drugs and Crime, 70% of the victims are women and girls and are most often from Eastern Europe, in 53% of cases trafficking is carried out for sexual exploitation and in 40% of cases trafficking is carried out for forced labour. I believe that financial investigations that track, seize and seize property acquired from criminal activity, as well as anti-money laundering actions, play a crucial role in the fight against this crime.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Trafficking in human beings is constantly increasing as a result of the EU's migration crisis. This crisis has also created confusion between the different definitions of this phenomenon and it is essential that, in order to solve the problem efficiently, the appropriate responses are given. Indeed, Parliament's proposal recognises trafficking in human beings as a form of slavery, and therefore a serious crime. It also stresses the importance of distinguishing between trafficking in human beings and trafficking in migrants, calling for definite legal answers. It also sees the need to combat corruption at the level of national and international institutions. Finally, it acknowledges the work done so far, but affirms the obligation for greater cooperation between the institutions and the implementation of European guidelines for the identification of victims of such violations. Confident that this document will contribute to the protection of fundamental rights, I am voting in favour of Parliament's proposal.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the report on the fight against human trafficking in the external relations of the European Union. This is an extremely serious problem, but the question must be asked as to what the European Union's participation in international programmes against human trafficking brings, in addition to the Member States. There are valid elements in this text. I am thinking in particular of the traceability of products to avoid forced labour. However, the EU is using the fight against human trafficking to demand more powers at the international level.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The text put to the vote is part of the European Union's commitment to international programmes. It turns out that she is involved in a project to combat human trafficking. However, through this delicate subject that needs to be defended, the EU is asking for more international powers and I am opposed to it. Therefore, I ABSTAINED.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it stresses that human trafficking is a highly lucrative business and the proceeds from this criminal activity return to the world economy and the financial system. The report reviews the different forms of exploitation. Describes the rights of victims, including the right to compensation or compensation.  The report also deals with cooperation against trafficking in human beings at regional and global level, and the Union's policy in its external relations. A clear relationship is established between illegal trafficking in immigrants and trafficking in human beings in general.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Even though it is an initiative with positive intentions, it does not offer concrete and specific solutions that contribute to the real fight against trafficking in human beings. Priority is not given to urgent measures that must involve actions by transit countries that are crucial to combating this scourge. That's why I abstained.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The report deals with the Union's responsibility for its work against trafficking in human beings, and aims to improve coordination relations between institutions and to promote the creation of joint measures. The aim is not only to ensure that these measures can be implemented within the borders of the European Union, but also to improve relations with third countries in order to facilitate the identification of victims so that they can be protected and assisted. It also includes the need to put in place ways to control cases of forced marriages, as these can sometimes have a transnational character and a direct relationship with trafficking. The report also states that people with disabilities are particularly vulnerable and can therefore be the focus of these groups. Because of the need to adopt a coherent policy both internally and externally, and because it is a reflection of the Fundamental Values of the Union, I vote in favour of its approval.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report on the fight against trafficking in human beings in the EU's external relations, as the name suggests, is aimed at combating trafficking in human beings in all its forms. It provides facts and figures on sexual exploitation and enslavement, organ trafficking, child soldiers, etc. and makes sensible proposals on how the EU, in cooperation with international organisations and third countries, can actively combat these criminal activities. The original version has been supplemented with paragraph 12. It calls for all companies and subcontractors to be held liable and, accordingly, to be sanctioned if any form of trafficking or exploitation has played a role along their entire supply and production chain. This requirement is totally unacceptable because, for obvious reasons, a company or even a subcontractor cannot have an overview of every single step in the supply and production chain and is not responsible for each of these steps. The demand therefore amounts to wanting to redistribute responsibility. Although I personally strongly support the fight against trafficking in human beings, I voted against the report because of paragraph 12.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which recognises the rights of victims of all kinds of human trafficking, recognises the links between human trafficking and corruption, and calls for international cooperation to stop human traffickers.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. The report deplores trafficking in human beings, stresses the importance of combating traffickers and people smugglers. I do not consider this report to be beneficial or harmful.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. In addition to the illegal trafficking of drugs and weapons, human trafficking is one of the most lucrative organised crime activities in the world. According to the latest world slavery index, 35.8 million people in the world are victims of modern-day slavery. Some 14.2 million are forced to live in forced labour conditions, 4.5 million suffer forced sexual exploitation and 2.2 million are in a state-imposed position of forced labour.  The report condemns the practice of human trafficking and regrets that no appropriate legislation has yet been adopted in many countries around the world to legalise the effective fight against human trafficking. Trafficking in human beings differs from migrant smuggling, so a different legal and practical framework needs to be applied. It is important that prevention strategies also take into account the factors that support this trade. The EU must develop a new strategy to tackle human trafficking with a stronger and more pronounced external dimension for the post-2016 period. In doing so, recognition of victims of trafficking is important so that they can exercise their rights, including access to justice, legal recognition of identity and citizenship, return of property, appropriate compensation and medical and psychological care and long-term integration assistance. I agree with these points and have therefore supported this report.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the fight against trafficking in human beings in the External Relations of the European Union. Globally, nearly 36 million people are trapped by modern forms of slavery. The fact is also that 10,000 children have gone missing in Europe since the refugee crisis began, presumably victims of traffickers. Against the background of this data, the EU has no choice but to take the leadership role by committing to measures directly attacking traffic networks and the root causes of their existence. This problem is of a global nature and the EU must therefore increase its financial and technical assistance and improve europol's effectiveness.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support asking the EU Anti-Trafficking Coordinator to further develop concrete joint action and measures among the EU, the Member States, third countries and international actors so as to set up a more coherent and efficient cooperation in establishing systems that identify, protect and assist victims of trafficking, step up the prevention of trafficking in human beings, seek increased prosecution of traffickers and  establish a network capable of responding to emerging concerns.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is one of the most profitable organised criminal activities in the world, in addition to illicit drug and arms trafficking. This transnational global crime denies people any rights, it demees human dignity.  It puts them at the level of goods and the source of illicit financial gain. The most at risk are women and children, where physical weakness, ignorance and addiction are heavily abused. I support the resolution calling on the Member States and the Union authorities to step up the search for and investigation of this serious crime, analyse its various forms, update the related legislative standards and promote and streamline international coordination and assistance with all the countries involved.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained in the Report's vote on combating trafficking in human beings in the context of the EU's external relations, because this Report is not sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. This text deals with the European Union's participation in international programmes to combat human trafficking. Even if it is a vehicle for European interference in the internal affairs of other Member States, we cannot stand in the way of a text on such a serious subject.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – On the report on the fight against trafficking in human beings in the EU’s external relations, I voted in favour. Due to human trafficking’s enormous profit, the supply of it has flourished tremendously, which has hugely harmed human rights and people’s safety. According to the report, child trafficking in Africa is the highest in the world, which is intolerable as children are the future of a country, and child soldiering is cruel and grievous which must be stopped. The fight against human trafficking is certainly necessary and inevitable to sustain people’s safety and defend human rights.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is a terrible problem, but often ignored in Europe and around the world, so I am happy to vote in favour of this report. Victims of trafficking are often the most vulnerable in society, including children and people in poverty. To combat the practice, we need a strong international partnership of cooperation and support for the people who have been exploited.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This resolution highlights the dangers that ill-considered and hasty visa liberalisations can pose. It is precisely the past that has shown that such measures can inadvertently promote sex tourism and trafficking in human beings. It is therefore useful to extend cross-border cooperation in the fight against them and to establish the importance of a country of origin for illegal immigration before issuing visas to such persons.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. With wars, trafficking in human beings increases (domestic workers in the dark, organ trafficking, ransom of migrants).  This report makes many proposals to improve the legal arsenal and protection of victims. It's a juicy market that brings in $150 billion for criminals. The fight against money laundering and the tracking of criminal networks are therefore crucial.  But large companies also sometimes benefit from this black-and-kind exploitation. The report highlights the unsusted ILO conventions and the importance of actively participating in the work of the United Nations in the development of a binding treaty for multinationals.  The right has obviously put its salt in the sand and is calling for a strengthening of fortress Europe so that it can "sort" migrants of interest to the European labour market and bring down the passages concerning aid to refugees.  I also regret the timidity of the text on the issue of so-called 'forced sexual exploitation' prostitution and above all on the 'deep causes' of trafficking that have been ignored: the responsibility for military interventions and a European trade policy which plunder, force exile and traffic entire populations. I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because the EU is using the fight against human trafficking to demand more power on the international stage.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The current crisis of migration has created new channels for deplorable acts of human trafficking, especially concerning the trafficking of women and children. I am in support of this report as combating human trafficking within the European Union is a priority for the promotion of safety and the protection of human rights for all peoples.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Trafficking in human beings must be considered a type of modern slavery that constitutes a serious violation of human rights. Human trafficking practices leading to other illegal practices such as trafficking in human organs or the sexual exploitation of women and children must therefore be strongly condemned.  In order to combat these intolerable practices, a coherent approach by EU Member States should be encouraged in the area of companies that must adopt the necessary legal measures that will eradicate human trafficking in their supply chains. To do so, Member States must put in place intergovernmental and legally binding legislation defining human trafficking as a criminal offence. I therefore call on the Member States to carry out a systematic exchange of information by establishing better communication with third countries on cross-border traffic which will strengthen efforts at the level of the Union's external relations.  With this in mind, other concrete solutions to end human trafficking are needed to enable migrants to reach the EU legally, without having to be exploited in any way.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Trafficking in human beings is one of the worst forms of human rights violations, as it deeply and permanently undermines the dignity, integrity and rights of the victim and affects entire families and communities, while also deliberately exploiting a state of vulnerability such as poverty or isolation. Complex and interlinked factors such as systemic and structural discrimination, human rights violations, poverty, inequality, corruption, violent conflicts, lack of education, unemployment and dysfunctional labour migration regimes increase the vulnerability of people and their exposure to exploitation and abuse. This is a complex regional and global problem that cannot be tackled exclusively at national level. Criminal networks are increasingly using the Internet and social networks to recruit and exploit victims, so, as part of their efforts, Member States must invest sufficiently in technology and expertise to identify and trace the misuse of the Internet by criminal networks to recruit victims, as well as to offer services aimed at exploiting victims. Member States must strengthen cooperation with third countries in order to combat all forms of trafficking in human beings and with particular emphasis on the gender dimension of trafficking in human beings.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the fight against trafficking in human beings in the EU’s external relations, which describes the global trends in trafficking of human beings. The report also underlines that the trafficking is a highly lucrative business and that the proceeds from this criminal activity are largely re-injected into the global economy and financial system. Moreover, the report makes a clear link between trafficking in migrants and trafficking in human beings.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Report of the Committee on Foreign Affairs emphasises that trafficking in human beings is one of the most serious forms of slavery and human rights violations, which capitalises on human suffering and therefore clearly condemns it. It points out that in addition to sexual exploitation, this includes forced labour, organ trafficking, begging, forced marriage, recruitment of child children and infant trafficking. It takes stock of global trends in trafficking in human beings, its economic aspect and various forms of exploitation. It also includes victims' rights, including the right to appeal. It makes recommendations on the EU's policy on trafficking in human beings in its external actions. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Trafficking in human beings constitutes a serious violation of fundamental rights and an offence to the dignity of the human person, and this criminal activity is one of the most profitable in the context of organised crime at international level. This scourge is of a global magnitude, so the answer must also be viewed from a global point of view.  In this context, efforts should be made to improve the combat strategy, in particular through cooperation with third countries in order to combat trafficking in human beings from recruitment to arrival places; a better distinction between the concept of trafficking in human beings from the concept of illegal introduction of migrants; the adoption and implementation of anti-corruption measures and the introduction of profits from the commercial exploitation of this activity in the financial system; and better implementation of existing legislation on the protection of victims of organised crime, especially the most vulnerable groups, such as women and children. To this end, I am voting in favour of this report, because I believe that a coherent approach to EU policies is needed, both at the level of its internal and external policies.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The Eu-2012 is using the fight against human trafficking to demand more powers in international relations. I therefore abstain on this text, even if its objective remains laudable.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which condemns all forms of human trafficking and addresses challenges linked to it, such as migration, modern information technology or lack of legislation. The report highlights the link between trafficking in migrants and trafficking in human beings. The rapporteur makes clear recommendations, encouraging enhanced cooperation with third countries and pointing out the importance of all existing instruments to prevent and combat human trafficking.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this text, one of the provisions of which underlines the obligation for the Union to have a binding and mandatory legislative system for the resettlement of refugees. I have always voted against the european Commission's irresponsible policy of migrant quotas, which is an air appeal to illegal immigration and which, among other things, has resulted in the emergence of slums such as the Calais Jungle.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the absolute and essential need to respect the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and given that trafficking in human beings is now a form of modern slavery, a manifestation of one of the worst forms of human rights violations, I can only welcome a proposal aimed at promoting the fight against trafficking in human beings in the Union's external relations. In order to prevent, prevent and repress this practice, it is necessary for the EU to strengthen judicial cooperation and express concern at the insufficient level of international coordination on cases of trafficking in human beings. The call is to strengthen joint actions and concrete measures between the European Union, Member States, third countries and international actors in order to establish coherent cooperation and promote the systematic exchange of information to investigate and combat trafficking in human beings, through the strengthening of financial and technical assistance and the strengthening of cross-border communication and capacity building at government level. Furthermore, since it is necessary for the Union to pay particular attention to the prevention of the phenomenon in humanitarian crisis contexts, such as migration, the proposal establishes a clear correlation between migrant trafficking and trafficking in human beings.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on combating trafficking in human beings in relations outside the Union because I believe that today is a serious crime which is one of the worst forms of human rights violations that cannot be tolerated in a society based on respect for human rights. It is necessary to promote coordination actions and the exchange of information between Member States, and also to increase their financial and technical support in response to the problem.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the apparation, as I consider all forms of human trafficking and modern slavery to be a serious and heinous crime affecting all parts of the world.  The release of human life is a serious violation of the dignity of human life. Nevertheless, this sector is growing and is gaining ground thanks to modern technologies. Victims of trafficking in human beings are often invisible because, where exploited, they face difficulties caused by cultural and linguistic diversity, making it more difficult for them to protest or send any signals to the outside world. I think it is important to combat crime with all existing and new tools and to use preventive methods, for example in the field of education.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that denounces and rejects human trafficking. The report stresses that human trafficking is a modern kind of slavery, a serious and transnational crime of global nature, calling for measures aimed to fight its root causes through robust laws against as well as improved cooperation between countries.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that human rights are universal and must be defended worldwide. In this respect, as the document adopted today states, combating trafficking in human beings must be a priority for the European Union and its partners. I welcome the proposal contained in the report to step up cooperation between the European Union, Member States and third countries to investigate and combat trafficking networks. Last but not least, I appreciate that the report encourages the European Commission and the Member States to adopt legislation with regard to organ transplantation that makes it mandatory to know the provenance of these organs in order to prevent and stop illegal procurement practices.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which I endorse, inter alia, the call for the EU and the Member States to make the necessary efforts to fight forced labour in EU industrial enterprises abroad and in relation to third countries, through the application and enforcement of labour standards and by encouraging governments to adopt labour legislation ensuring minimum standards of protection for workers, including foreign workers , and to ensure that European companies operating in third countries comply with these standards. I consider it important that governments enforce labour laws and guarantee equal rights for all workers, regardless of their nationality or origin, and that they pay due attention to the eradication of corruption.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The report has some commendable aspects; it calls for cooperation in combatting human trafficking, it is strong on the impact for women and children, and calls on the EU to do more to find missing refugees etc. However, the inclusion of calls for greater EU military presence in the Mediterranean, claims that exploitation does not occur in transit countries, some questionable suggestions regarding refugees, and calls for an EU cross-border labour mechanism, make the report impossible to support. Therefore, on this basis, I abstained on the final roll-call vote.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the report contains very good approaches and calls, for example, for the extension of cross-border cooperation to combat child marriage and sex tourism. Another point is the fight against illegal trafficking in human beings.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The fight against trafficking in human beings requires cross-border cooperation to detect and confiscate criminal money, more exchange of information, more financial and technical assistance and greater cooperation between police and law enforcement authorities (including Europol, etc.) and it is also important to focus on helping and ensuring the security of victims.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled. Trafficking in human beings is a type of modern slavery and a serious crime that commits one of the most serious violations of human rights, and cannot be accepted by societies based on respect for human rights, including gender equality. It should be noted that one of the biggest obstacles to the fight against trafficking in human beings is the inadequate implementation of the legal framework relating to trafficking in human beings at national level and the lack of an appropriate legal framework in third countries. It should be noted that trafficking in human beings is a highly profitable illegal activity and the vast majority of the proceeds of this criminal activity are reinvested in the global economy and the financial system. This organised crime is carried out both externally and across internal borders, and strong internal laws on combating trafficking in human beings and cooperation between countries are therefore necessary. It is necessary to make the fight against trafficking in human beings more visible to society. I believe that it is extremely important that, in the case of unaccompanied minors, the identification of children victims of trafficking in human beings, in particular at border crossing points and reception centres, is extremely important, as well as to strengthen interdisciplinary cooperation in order to ensure effective protection of children's interests.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The JRC strongly condemns all forms of trafficking in human beings, one of the most repugnant derivatives of the exploitative system. The report, however, systematically concealing its cause with what it proposes, not only does it not tackle trafficking in human beings, but instead moves on the territory of those factors that give birth to it and reproduce it.  It calls for strengthening the EU's repression mechanisms, which have been shown not to address the problem, seeking to legitimise in popular consciences these mechanisms developed with the main objective of the grassroots-labour movement. It promotes the replacement of the responsibility of the state and its structures to combat and support victims from controversial to suspicious NGOs, leading mathematically to a giant of criminal enterprises.  Because trafficking in human beings is a huge criminal enterprise that makes untold profits. It is a consequence of the transformation of the labour force into a commodity in capitalism, which automatically gives birth and the conversion of people themselves into commodities, in order to serve the unique value that the rotten system of exploitation recognizes: the profit of capital.  The battle for the definitive eradication, but also the decisive fight against this inhuman enterprise, is insoluble tied to the struggle to eliminate the very matrix that gives birth to it, the barbaric capitalist system.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative report. We are strong supporters of any measures to combat the trafficking of people, however we do not support the European Union taking actions on these measures. The free movement of people and Schengen has contributed to an increase in people trafficking within the EU. We think it is hypocritical of the EU to discuss measures outside of the EU when it refuses to acknowledge this. However out of respect for the sensitivity of the subject and our support for measures to combat it we abstained.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of this proposal, as I fully agree with my colleague that trafficking in human beings is an unacceptable and intolerable practice in a society, such as the contemporary one, based on respect for human rights. The global dimension of trafficking in human beings requires a global response in order to combat a phenomenon which, unfortunately, is not considered a crime in all countries of the world to date. Furthermore, the spread of the phenomenon online requires greater cooperation not only between the Member States of the Union and between them and third countries, but also between the Commission and the European agencies. I therefore believe that the Member States must step up their efforts to combat a phenomenon which, over and above its geographical dimension, has so many facets that it appears to be extremely widespread. Furthermore, convinced that it is up to the Union to promote greater attention to policy on trafficking in human beings in its external action, I voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Union is faced with one of the greatest challenges in its history in the face of the refugee crisis. From the refugees who are illegally smuggled in Europe by criminal organisations, through the men that work years without payment to the women forced into prostitution, these activities devaluate all basic human rights and permanently damage victims and their families. The coordination between Member States on all aspects of human trafficking should be enhanced. I voted in favour of the report of Ms Lochbihler on ‘modern day slavery’, which aims to fight money laundering in the EU and hold accountable EU companies that tolerate forced labour in their factories of supply chains.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report focuses on trafficking in human beings, a real crime that includes the exploitation of prostitution, child labour, as well as organ trafficking. The causes that trigger and favour this lucrative business controlled and managed by organised crime, including wars, corruption, poverty and dysfunctions in legal migration systems, are clearly highlighted. In the ENVI Committee, we adopted an opinion in which I took an active part, pointing out, for example, the importance of the role of doctors, nurses and other health workers, which are often the first point of contact for victims, and the need to impose severe penalties in the event of their involvement in the illicit trafficking of organs. I have also called for the promotion of a transparent international organ traceability system, which ensures donor anonymity, and pointed out that many orphaned children can become an easy target for traffickers. Another very important issue is that of climate migrants, another category at risk of illicit trafficking. For these reasons, and given the very nature of the report, I can only vote in favour of it.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Modern times are characterized by overall progress, especially in the technological field, and yet we are witnessing that in the protection of basic human rights we do not make the desired positive developments. It is frightening to think that people in the 21st century are treated as commodities, that their uniqueness and the inimitability with which they enrich society are priced, that their dignity is brutally and cruelly trampled on and reduced to a traded item. I supported this Anti-Trafficking Report on EU external relations, as we really need to fight in this area by all available means and financial gain must never be above man and his dignity.  I believe, however, that with this Report we could have done more and I am sorry that my amendments that equally condemn the trade in reproductive cells and fetal tissues and cells have not been adopted because human life begins at conception and it is equally inadmissible and monstrous to bring fetal organs and cells down to purchase facilities. Only when we put an end to these barbaric and inadmissible acts of human trafficking will we be able to call ourselves a society of progress, freedom and respect for man.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the EU's participation in international programmes against human trafficking. I am of course very sensitive to the issue of combating human trafficking, but this subject is a pretext for the EU to demand more powers internationally. I refuse to give him any expertise in this area and that is why I prefer to abstain on this report.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is an intolerable modern form of slavery, a serious crime that is one of the worst forms of human rights violations. It needs to be addressed in a comprehensive way, focusing not only on sexual exploitation, but also on forced labour, organ trafficking, forced begging, forced marriages, child soldiers and trafficking in babies. Trafficking in human beings is also a transnational crime of a global nature, so effective national laws combined with effective cooperation between states are needed. In many countries of the world, legislation in this area is still not enough and, all too often, existing legislation is not properly applied. The number of victims identified remains well below estimates and access to justice and psychological and material support is limited if not entirely absent. I support the call in the resolution for the European Union to make the fight against trafficking in human beings and trafficking in human beings one of the guiding principles of its external relations by promoting the application of the UNITED Nations and ILO conventions in third countries and by improving judicial cooperation and the exchange of information between police forces in order to tackle and defeat international criminal networks.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I condemn and reject the practice of human trafficking, which is increasingly common, causes human suffering and permanently and profoundly affects all societies and economies. I emphasise the fact that human trafficking is a modern type of slavery and a serious crime that constitutes one of the worst forms of human rights violations and is unacceptable in societies based on respect for human rights, including gender equality. Moreover, I believe that the problem of human trafficking should be addressed in a comprehensive way, focusing not only on sexual exploitation, but also on forced labour, organ trafficking, forced begging, forced marriages, child soldiers and the trafficking of newborn children. I regret the wide gap between existing legislation and its application, which, on the one hand, includes limited or non-existent access to justice and, on the other hand, the fact that no prosecutions are brought against perpetrators. I condemn the fact that trafficking in human beings is a very lucrative business activity and that the proceeds of this criminal activity are largely re-injected into the global economy and financial flows. I condemn that the most structured and powerful international criminal organizations are involved in human trafficking and have created a real international and extensive criminal network. I call on all countries and relevant actors in this field to make low-risk/highly cost-effective trafficking activity a high-risk/unprofitable activity.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a report addressing the issue of combating trafficking in human beings in the context of the EU's external relations. The title immediately denounces thematic contextualisation on the basis of a presupposition that we do not recognise: EU foreign policy. The report comprehensively presents in more than 100 points global trends in trafficking in human beings, the economy of trafficking in human beings, the rights of victims, devoting the issue of compensation, the defence of cooperation in the fight against trafficking in human beings at regional and international level, the policy that the EU must pursue on trafficking in human beings in the context of external relations. If it is true that there are some positive aspects, we cannot depart from a character of profound hypocrisy that is evident throughout the extensive report. On the one hand, it follows a line of money laundering in the EU's migration policies. On the other hand, it legitimises the structural policies that are at the root of this humanitarian crisis and sanctions the return policy, the outsourcing of borders and the role of EUROPOL and FRONTEX. At the same time, it re-holds states out in their role of welcome and solidarity. These unacceptable considerations justify voting against.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's report on global trends in trafficking in human beings. Trafficking in human beings is a modern form of slavery and a serious crime that constitutes one of the worst forms of human rights violations. Tragically, in the 21st century, human trafficking is still a globally lucrative business that is linked to other crimes, such as money laundering. Unfortunately, this is facilitated by non-existent or inadequate legislation in a number of countries around the world. Thus, revenues from human trafficking are being returned to financial systems. The report offers an overview of the different forms of trafficking in human beings, but also proposes concrete forms of cooperation in the fight against it at regional and international level. EU policy in building relations with third countries, e.g. exchanging best practices, training police and humanitarian workers on how to communicate with victims, etc. At EU level, the position of anti-trafficking coordinator has been established to improve coordination between EU institutions, agencies and Member States with third countries and international actors. The report deals separately with the trade in migrants, who are among the most vulnerable groups, especially women and children. Europol has warned that more than 10,000 unaccompanied refugees and migrant children have disappeared in Europe.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of the report recognises trafficking in human beings as a modern form of slavery. Unfortunately, this is an increasing criminal practice. The report addresses the fundamental distinction that must be made between trafficking in human beings and trafficking in migrants. These two concepts require different legal and practical responses. The Union must monitor more closely the way in which third countries use the funds allocated to cooperation and, above all, to those linked to the fight against illegal immigration and border control. I believe that the Member States must do more to counter, including through joint military operations, the networks of human traffickers who put the lives of miles of desperate people at risk in search of a better life. For all this, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report expresses a very clear position against trafficking in human beings in all forms: sexual exploitation, forced labour, forced surrogacy, coercive begging, torture and extortion, organ procurement, etc. The figures are shocking: the number of victims worldwide is estimated at 35 million and the annual profits from trafficking in human beings amount to hundreds of billions of euros.  The report contains a number of recommendations worthy of support. These include a call for closer international cooperation, a call for increased action to recover illicit profits and a call to reduce the overall demand for victims of trafficking and their 'services'. The report now calls for the EU and the Member States to hold companies, as well as 'related companies and subcontractors throughout their supply chain, accountable for trafficking in human beings'. Businesses, of course, should be vigilant, but the above demand is unrealistic and unfair. It is difficult to support the call for more 'safe and legal routes' for migrants who want to enter the EU. I have hereby abstained.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which reminds us of the importance of combating human trafficking. This scourge, which can be described as modern slavery, is unfortunately widespread. The European Union and Member States need to do more to combat corruption, including strengthening the training of EU officials to deal effectively with this situation. Above all, it is the victims of trafficking who must be assisted and accompanied.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. Trafficking in human beings (THS), which is part of organised crime and is one of the most serious forms of human rights violations, makes men and women goods, in violation of the dignity, integrity and rights of victims. The different purposes of THS - especially sexual exploitation, organ trafficking and forced labour - are a lucrative and growing human suffering industry, affecting all societies and economies in a profound and permanent way. The current migration crisis increases the risk of trafficking due to the vulnerable and irregular situation in which many of the migrants are, and it is therefore up to the European Union to promote programmes to support the inclusion of migrants and refugees, with the participation of third countries and also cultural mediators, which are useful in raising the level of awareness of communities about trafficking and making them more resilient to the penetration of organised crime. THS is a modern form of slavery and a serious crime that cannot be tolerated in societies firmly founded on respect for human rights and should therefore be severely punished.  Because of the foregoing, my vote is in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative report. We are strong supporters of any measures to combat the trafficking of people, however we do not support the European Union taking actions on these measures. The free movement of people and Schengen has contributed to an increase in people trafficking within the EU. We think it is hypocritical of the EU to discuss measures outside of the EU when it refuses to acknowledge this. However out of respect for the sensitivity of the subject and our support for measures to combat it we abstained.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. Trafficking in human beings is an abject crime that reduces millions of people around the world to the state of goods.  To combat this intolerable phenomenon, the report advocates a comprehensive approach, based on human rights, which follows a threefold objective: prevention, protection of victims and strengthening criminal prosecutions of criminals. The fight against trafficking also calls for a coordinated response from the EU and Member States, in partnership with third countries. This requires better cooperation between police and justice authorities, as well as appropriate training for professionals who are in contact with victims. Victims who must receive full information about their rights, effective access to justice, and whose status must be recognised throughout the Union.  Victims who need unwavering support, including legal, medical and psychological support, to help them reintegrate into society.  Among them may be people in need of international protection, especially women and children. In the face of this worrying situation, it is essential to improve the procedures for identifying victims of trafficking throughout the migration route.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which rejects human trafficking and calls for an end to it. Trafficking in human beings remains unbearable as it denies human beings in their rights and freedoms, reduces them to mere commodities and is nothing but modern slavery. Victims must have their rights respected, they must be accompanied and protected. Criminals must be prosecuted and tried. There can be no respite in the fight against this barbarism.  To combat it, it is necessary to ensure a coherence between the Union's internal and external policies. In particular, police and judicial cooperation between Member States and with third countries should be strengthened. In addition, gaps in legislation and improvements must be made to deal with new forms of trafficking and its new channels, such as the internet. Member States should ratify all relevant legal obligations and international agreements.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. Trafficking in human beings is a modern form of slavery and a serious crime that is one of the worst forms of human rights violations, something that cannot be tolerated in societies based on respect for human rights. Trafficking in human beings must be understood holistically, focusing not only on sexual exploitation, but also on forced labour, organ trafficking, forced begging, forced marriages, child soldiers and baby trafficking. As a transnational crime of a global nature, any measures to combat it must take into account the root causes and global trends. Hence the importance of a coherent and urgent approach to the internal and external dimensions of EU policies to combat it.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Trafficking in human beings is one of the worst forms of human rights abuse, reducing people to mere commodities, deeply and lastingly violating the dignity, integrity and rights of the victim and affecting entire families and communities, deliberately taking advantage of situations of vulnerability, such as poverty or isolation. It is also an extremely lucrative business, whose income is largely re-injected into the global economy and financial system. In view of this situation, the report, which I supported, calls on the Commission and the Member States, interrelated aspects, to strengthen cooperation with third countries, in order to investigate all stages of trafficking in human beings, to improve the exchange of information and to undertake operations, (financial) investigations and legal proceedings on a preventive basis. It also calls for it to adapt its cooperation with third countries to the new situation created by the development of trafficking through the Internet and to strengthen national child protection schemes in Europe as part of the Union's anti-trafficking strategy.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Trafficking in human beings, a form of modern slavery, can include sexual exploitation, forced labour, organ trafficking, forced begging, forced marriages, child soldiers and the trafficking of babies. This unacceptable trafficking must be fought forcefully in all parts of the world. The report discussed and voted on at this plenary session of the European Parliament highlighted in particular the role of new information and communication technologies used by networks to attract and exploit victims. It is therefore urgent that the European Commission examines this new phenomenon in order to develop a strategy to effectively combat trafficking. Of course, this fight must not only take place at the level of the European Union, but it is also a responsibility of the Member States of the Union and of all the countries of the world. It is essential that all countries of the world cooperate effectively to fight effectively and quickly against this form of slavery that I refuse to see again in our societies today. In line with the recommendations made in this report, I have decided to support this text.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this important report condemning trafficking in human beings. Despite the fact that trafficking in human beings is seen as a crime, there is a persistent lack of adequate legislation in many countries to effectively combat this modern form of slavery. The report notes that, according to a press release from the Head of Europol's Personnel Unit, more than 10 000 unaccompanied refugee and migrant children have disappeared in Europe. And these are incredible figures, knowing that children may have been involved in the market for sexual services or illegal organ transplantation. At least in part, the problem could be addressed by the European Union, which should share information with third countries by developing a standardised system for collecting and analysing human trafficking data. It is also necessary to establish effective networks of cooperation between law enforcement authorities, both within the EU and globally, which could help to track down and prevent illegal activities.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. This report focuses on trafficking in human beings as a new form of slavery - an extremely serious and highly attentive crime of human dignity, which has increased significantly in recent years, notably through international criminal networks. The rapporteur clarifies the difference between human trafficking and smuggling of migrants, adding that each concept requires appropriate legal and practical responses. In view of the different forms of exploitation that exist, some may be related to corruption, so it is urgent to take effective measures, which are to train civil servants who are capable and properly prepared to respond to these requests. Regional, European and international cooperation against trafficking in human beings is of the utmost importance, and further coordination and systematic exchange of information is therefore needed to investigate and combat transnational trafficking in human beings through measures such as strengthening financial and technical assistance, alongside capacity building at government level and enforcement and law enforcement. Because I generally agree with the content of the proposals in this report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the fight against human trafficking in the Union's external relations. Trafficking in human beings is a serious crime and one of the worst forms of human rights violations. This text reminds us that human trafficking is a transnational crime of a global nature; therefore it must be apprehended by the Union not only in its internal policy but above all in its relations with third countries. According to the ILO, human trafficking generates about $150 billion annually. That is why, as requested by this report, more attention needs to be paid to combating money laundering activities. The Union must strengthen its cooperation with third countries in order to better combat corruption, better locate and confiscate the proceeds of these criminal activities. I supported this report, which calls for enhanced cooperation in the judicial and police field, as well as in the systematic exchange of information and the management of victims of trafficking in need of international protection.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report discussed in the AFET Committee on combating trafficking in human beings in the Union's external relations. The subject of this text is extremely sensitive, since it aims to distinguish legally the trafficking of human beings from the trafficking of migrants. This type of phenomenon cannot be solved at national level, so it is good that Europe should equip its services with effective instruments in order to provide a Community response to trafficking in human beings, which is still a very topical problem. In the case of migrant smuggling, the EU has sought to address the problem through CSDP missions such as Eunavfor Med Sophia in the central Mediterranean. I agree with the proposal in the text for greater coordination and systematic exchange of information to investigate and combat transnational trafficking in human beings.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report. Although the text contains elements that I support, as regards the effective protection of persons in situations of forced mobility, and in particular the most vulnerable, I do not share the general approach of the text, which exempts European countries from any responsibility for the root and structural causes, as well as, from the dramatic consequences of mass migration, by concentrating actions only on trafficking and trafficking networks, which are but the consequence of a failed asylum and immigration system. Nor do we share the sectarian view of the humanitarian crisis, which on the one hand doubles victimizes refugees and on the other hand generates a very lucrative business linked to large arms companies, whose expansion is linked to the prevalence of wars that cause mass exoduses.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is estimated that 35.8 million people worldwide have fallen into the trap of modern slavery, and this figure is a figure of shame. Recently, 10,000 migrant children have been reported missing and probably ended up in prostitution networks. A few blocks away from the European Parliament, on Brussels' famous Avenue Louise, illegal prostitution has been practiced for years, unhindered. It is inadmissible that this is overlooked by the Belgian authorities. At the same time, in Europe, sites promoting child pornography are tolerated.  This issue has been under the mat for too long and we can no longer tacitly accept this phenomenon! International cooperation in cases of trafficking in human beings is insufficient, especially when it comes to countries of origin and countries of transit, which is a major impediment to the effective fight against trafficking in human beings. Action is needed now to save lives, now, not tomorrow!

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. It is an initiative with positive intentions, but it does not offer concrete and specific solutions that contribute to the real fight against trafficking in human beings. Priority is not given to urgent measures that must involve actions by transit countries that are crucial to combating this scourge. That's why I abstained.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Human trafficking is a form of modern slavery that plagues the lives of many people. Trafficking covers various forms of extreme exploitation such as child prostitution, child soldiers, unpaid forced labor and the trade in human organs, and is a very profitable business for criminal organizations. It is unacceptable for human beings to be treated as commodities, that they are continually violated in their dignity, integrity and rights, inevitably referring them to situations of isolation, contempt and misery.  The EU has made a significant contribution to the fight against trafficking in human beings. However, it remains necessary to keep the needs of victims in mind, in particular in the provision of aid, therapy and compensation.  I voted positively because the EU is encouraged to step up its role in protecting and assisting victims, strengthening police against traffickers and improving cooperation with developing countries.  The fight against trafficking in human beings must be a shared responsibility. Unfortunately, however, many countries in the world persist in not adopting legislation aimed at criminalising and combating trafficking in human beings.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative report. We are strong supporters of any measures to combat the trafficking of people, however we do not support the European Union taking actions on these measures. The free movement of people and Schengen has contributed to an increase in people trafficking within the EU. We think it is hypocritical of the EU to discuss measures outside of the EU when it refuses to acknowledge this. However out of respect for the sensitivity of the subject and our support for measures to combat it we abstained.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which condemns all forms of human trafficking and addresses challenges linked to it, such as migration, modern information technology and lack of legislation. The report highlights the link between trafficking in migrants and trafficking in human beings. I am pleased to see that the rapporteur has made clear recommendations, which encourage enhanced cooperation with third countries, and that the report points out the importance of all the existing instruments for preventing and combating human trafficking.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Anti-Trafficking in Human Beings Report in the EU's external relations, as trafficking in human beings, part of organised crime, is one of the worst forms of human rights violations by reducing people to goods, deeply and permanently violating the dignity, integrity and rights of victims and affecting their entire families and communities and knowingly abusing people's difficult standing such as poverty or isolation. Complex and intertwined factors such as systematic and structural discrimination, human rights violations, poverty, inequality, corruption, violent conflicts, land seizures, lack of education, unemployment and non-functioning regimes for labour migration increase people's exposure to exploitation and abuses, as this has reduced their choices and their resources have been reduced. The EU Strategy for The Prevention of Trafficking in Human Beings, which refers to the period 2012-2016, recognises violence against women as the root cause of human trafficking. Human trafficking is a regional or global problem that cannot always be solved exclusively at the national level. The phenomenon of human trafficking is not limited to countries considered less developed, but also present in developed countries.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider trafficking in human beings to be one of the most widespread forms of international organised crime today, linked to serious violations of fundamental human rights, freedoms and human dignity. As I see trafficking in human beings as a long-term phenomenon, and I even admit that this situation can be extended, I welcomed the current report, which comes with concrete proposals in the fight against trafficking in human beings. I must openly admit that I am very concerned about the statistics in human trafficking, which clearly speak of the fastest growing illegal trade in the world. As the methods and practices of traders become increasingly sophisticated and the ways in which new victims are gaining new victims become increasingly insidious, I supported the resolution because I believe that trade cannot always be tackled only at national level. It regrets that to date, in many countries around the world, there is no adequate legislation to criminalise trafficking in human beings and to combat trafficking effectively, so I think it is right that strong international legislation is being created against trafficking in human beings and for cooperation between countries. I expect the EU and its Member States to step up international cooperation in cases of trafficking in human beings, especially when countries of origin and transit are involved.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 When we talk about trafficking in human beings, in any case some financial benefit is realized in the network of trafficking criminal organizations. Even in the current migration processes, there is a huge financial benefit for traffickers, who are often more organised than public authorities and travel migrants to more developed regions in exchange for large sums of money compared to wages and savings in Eastern Europe. Unfortunately, the suspicion that the authorities of certain third countries are cooperating with these criminal organisations in order not to keep large groups of migrants on their territory, but to cross into Europe, cannot be allayed. In these circumstances, it is indeed difficult to explain to European citizens that, while we are talking about combating trafficking in human beings, we are also working closely with the states that support and support this process. I therefore believe that breaking the business model of traffickers can be achieved by a single means, consistent protection of the external borders.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is the first report on the fight against trafficking in human beings in the European Union's external relations and represents an important contribution to the efforts of the European Union and the Member States in this area. The report includes a comprehensive and detailed analysis of the reality of trafficking in human beings, including sexual abuse and forced labour, as well as links of trafficking in human beings to migration and financial aspects. I believe it is essential to improve the situation, as there is a major gap between existing legislation and its implementation, including supporting and protecting victims and prosecuting perpetrators. The fight against trafficking in human beings requires effective international cooperation and increased efforts at national levels to address cross-border crime, including by increasing financial investigations. The report also calls on the European Union and the Member States to do more in the area of victim identification and protection, and also demands that the difference between the concepts of trafficking in human beings and migrant smuggling be understood. Safe and legal means of entering the European Union should reduce the vulnerability of migrants and refugees, thus contributing to the prevention of trafficking in human beings. For this reason, I believe that the report is good and I supported it in the vote.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report on the fight against trafficking in human beings in the EU's external relations, as the name suggests, is aimed at combating trafficking in human beings in all its forms. It provides facts and figures on sexual exploitation and enslavement, organ trafficking, child soldiers, etc. and makes sensible proposals on how the EU, in cooperation with international organisations and third countries, can actively combat these criminal activities.  The original version has been supplemented with paragraph 12. It calls for all companies and subcontractors to be held liable and, accordingly, to be sanctioned if any form of trafficking or exploitation has played a role along their entire supply and production chain. This requirement is totally unacceptable because, for obvious reasons, a company or even a subcontractor cannot have an overview of every single step in the supply and production chain and is not responsible for each of these steps. The demand therefore amounts to wanting to redistribute responsibility. Although I personally strongly support the fight against trafficking in human beings, I voted against the report because of paragraph 12.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Prevention of trafficking in human beings is a fundamental issue. An integrated approach needs to be taken to unite the various actors, mandates and perspectives, both at national and international level, in order to reduce the vulnerability of potential victims.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I condemn without any ifs and buts of all forms of trafficking in human beings. However, I abstained from this resolution because, as is so often the case in this European Parliament, a real opportunity is being used to make unacceptable political demands.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Trafficking in human beings, which is part of organised crime, is one of the worst forms of human rights violations because it reduces people to goods, deeply and permanently violates the dignity, integrity and rights of victims and affects their entire families and communities, and knowingly abuses the difficult situation of people such as poverty and isolation. According to an International Labour Organisation estimate, illegal annual earnings from forced labour are around $150 billion, with an estimated 90% of victims exploited in the private sector and two-thirds of the profits coming from commercial sexual exploitation. I support the proposal for this Resolution, as I believe that these new strategies to prevent human trafficking should take into account the factors that support it and the patterns and circumstances that lead to this phenomenon. We need to create an integrated approach that will cover different actors nationally and internationally.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on combating trafficking in human beings in the EU's external relations. In the context of the fight against trafficking in human beings, I would like to draw attention to the trafficking of human organs, which is one of the ten largest illegal activities of earning money. However, although there is too little talk about the trafficking of human organs, it is a major problem in some countries and we must not turn a blind eye to it. Slovenia is primarily a transit country for such criminal activities, which is why law enforcement agencies have an increasing responsibility in detecting the activities of criminal groups.
