The amber alert written statement, signed by by far the highest number of Members in the European Parliament in the last five years, I have sent to the President of the European Parliament, the President and the Interior Minister, to this day, which does not give me optimism that the Slovenian Government is aware of the seriousness of the problem. In fact, 250 000 children are missing in the EU every year, many of them victims of human organ trafficking.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, such an important issue is not dealt with with the necessary seriousness and so the ideas of specific individuals make it possible to turn this report into a tool to legalise illegal immigration.  The author ignores that the trafficking rings of illegal immigrants in many cases also trade people. It also ignores the fact that a large part of illegal immigrants report false information to the countries of entry in order to exploit legal loopholes to its advantage, to the detriment of people in real need.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report because it can promote the positive change that I have long advocated in the company of other politicians and MEPs: greater coherence of EU foreign and security policy, and the international enforcement of the Union's principles and standards. This report provides the most comprehensive EU argument to date, underpinning the urgency of trafficking in human beings and outlining its instruments. In addition to international aspects, it emphasises for a reason that trafficking in human beings is also a common phenomenon within the EU, with a high proportion of perpetrators being EU citizens and victims typically being women and children. This is also important to me because it can draw attention to my previous initiative to institutionalize enhanced legal protection for particularly vulnerable victims– women, children, the elderly – and tougher punishment of perpetrators in the justice system in the Member States. I am convinced that, in order to reduce the inhumane practice of global trafficking in human beings, the implementation of the objectives and proposed solutions contained in the report we have just adopted must continue to be on the EP's agenda in the framework of close and constructive interinstitutional cooperation.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is one of the most abominable practices that still persists in the contemporary world.  Unfortunately, there is an important level of funds involved in this area and which then penetrate into the international financial system and the global economy. Despite the measures taken by the countries of the world, this type of trafficking manages to be predominantly cross-border, affecting a large part of developing countries.  At the same time, trafficking in human beings also involves a number of migrants trying to move to developed countries but are being exploited by traffickers. In these circumstances, the European Union has a duty to act to strengthen international cooperation, to combat this phenomenon of organised crime and to protect the victims resulting from this process. The current report identifies problems in this area and believes that EU policy dedicated to combating trafficking in human beings must be an integral part of the Union's foreign policy. Only in this way can the Union acquire the necessary credibility at global level as a relevant actor in stopping this type of phenomenon. I support the adoption of this important document for the future.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Trafficking in human beings is a type of modern slavery and a serious crime, one of the worst forms of human rights violations and cannot be tolerated in societies based on respect for human rights, including equality between men and women. It must also be understood in its entirety, with an emphasis not only on sexual exploitation, but also on forced labour, organ trafficking, forced begging, forced marriages, child soldiers or trafficking in babies. The European Union must strengthen police and judicial cooperation between Member States and with third countries - in particular the countries of origin and transit of victims of human trafficking - in the prevention, investigation and prosecution of human trafficking, particularly through Europol and Eurojust.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Human trafficking is a growing industry that constitutes one of the worst forms of human rights violations. Women are mostly victims of sexual exploitation, men are forced into labour, and in 2014, more than 10 000 unaccompanied refugee and migrant children disappeared in Europe. This is why I voted in favour of the report on the fight against trafficking in human beings in the EU’s external relations, which suggests concrete ways to counter this crime. One key element is to understand that human trafficking encompasses many types of exploitation beyond sexual exploitation. The report also stresses the need to focus on victims’ rights including the right to remedy, to increase cooperation against this crime at regional and international level and to promote an EU strategy on this issue with a more targeted external dimension.

name: Eleni Theocharous (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The report takes a very clear stand against human trafficking in all its forms: sexual exploitation, forced labour, forced surrogacy, forced begging, torture and extortion, organ removal, etc. The numbers are staggering as an estimated 35 million people worldwide are victims and the annual profits of the illegal human trafficking trade are hundreds of billions of euros.  Closer international cooperation, exchange of information, not only on fighting human trafficking itself, but also in recovering the illegal profits made are important elements towards fighting human trafficking. The development in a growing number of Member States to criminalise the knowing use of sexual services of trafficked persons is very important in order to fight human trafficking.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is one of the most serious crimes in the world and constitutes a serious violation of fundamental rights. The countries of the European Union are called upon to prosecute all citizens for crimes committed in another EU country and to use all necessary investigative tools. It is also necessary to stress the dimension of the exploitation of children, victims who are often unaware of violent acts, for the body and for the psyche. Women and children, children and adolescents, are the most vulnerable groups and must be able to benefit from measures complementary to humanitarian aid. Helping women and children means discouraging demand and given the complexity of the issues and the interconnection of the different factors that favour trafficking in human beings, a holistic, multidisciplinary and integrated approach is needed.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. I fully supported the lochbihler mep's report because human trafficking is a reprehensible element in the world of organised crime. This is one of the worst ways of violating human rights, because a person is treated as a commodity, violated by his dignity, and it has a negative impact on society and families. The European Union must be more involved in the fight against this criminal activity, especially when its victims are children and women. There should be a consensus on this subject, because trafficking in human beings is a modern unacceptable form of slavery. The consensus reached must be applied on all continents. The EU should therefore strongly encourage third countries to ratify and implement the Council of Europe Convention on this issue. Only a comprehensive approach based on international law will allow us to combat one of the worst crimes more effectively.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Smugglers and traffickers have taken advantage of the refugee crisis and significantly stepped up their criminal activities. Europol's data on the 10,000 refugees and unaccompanied migrant children missing in Europe since the crisis began is truly shocking and obliges us to adopt additional measures that will seriously jeopardise smuggling and trafficking chains. But as I have repeatedly pointed out in this home, I do not think the solution lies in opening borders because such a thing would attract new waves of migrants who can reach our shores only with the help of smugglers for whom business would literally flourish. The European Union must further strengthen Frontex and work much more closely with third countries from where criminal groups operate and through whose territory illegal migrants arrive.  At the same time, order needs to be finally introduced into migration and asylum policy to discourage new waves of illegal migrants and stem demand for smuggling services.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on combating trafficking in human beings in the EU's external relations. The report recognises human trafficking as a modern type of slavery as a serious crime on the rise. It defines different forms of exploitation and recognises rights for victims. It also highlights, inter alia, the need to combat corruption that could contribute to trafficking in human beings and calls, in this context, for appropriate training for public sector staff. Cooperation between regional and international levels is important in the fight against trafficking in human beings. Enhanced coordination and systematic exchange of information is needed to investigate and combat transnational trafficking in human beings and to strengthen financial and technical assistance, together with capacity building at government and law enforcement levels.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report. Although the text contains elements that I support, as regards the effective protection of persons in situations of forced mobility, and in particular the most vulnerable, I do not share the general approach of the text, which exempts European countries from any responsibility for the root and structural causes, as well as, from the dramatic consequences of mass migration, by concentrating actions only on trafficking and trafficking networks, which are but the consequence of a failed asylum and immigration system. Nor do we share the sectarian view of the humanitarian crisis, which on the one hand doubles victimizes refugees and on the other hand generates a very lucrative business linked to large arms companies, whose expansion is linked to the prevalence of wars that cause mass exoduses.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The report on the fight against trafficking in human beings in the EU's external relations, as the name suggests, is aimed at combating trafficking in human beings in all its forms. It provides facts and figures on sexual exploitation and enslavement, organ trafficking, child soldiers, etc. and makes sensible proposals on how the EU, in cooperation with international organisations and third countries, can actively combat these criminal activities. The original version has been supplemented with paragraph 12. It calls for all companies and subcontractors to be held liable and, accordingly, to be sanctioned if any form of trafficking or exploitation has played a role along their entire supply and production chain. This requirement is totally unacceptable because, for obvious reasons, a company or even a subcontractor cannot have an overview of every single step in the supply and production chain and is not responsible for each of these steps. The demand therefore amounts to wanting to redistribute responsibility. Although I personally strongly support the fight against trafficking in human beings, I voted against the report because of paragraph 12.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report about the fight against human trafficking in the EU’s external relations (2015/2340(INI), with the strong commitment to find global solutions to this dramatic situation. Human trafficking is one of the most profitable businesses in the world, generating profits of between USD 600 million and 1.2 billion. Young women, who are used for sexual exploitation, and young men, used for forced labour, are mostly vulnerable. The same report notes that, according to the Director of Europol, more than 10 000 unaccompanied, under-aged refugees and migrants have disappeared from Europe and that it is highly likely these young people have been forced into mafias, prostitution, slavery or organ trafficking. This report, which I support, calls on the Commission, the Council, the European External Action Service and Member States to commit, inter alia, to Directives 2011/36/UE, 2012/29/UE and 2004/23/CE and to the Convention of 1951 on the Status of Refugees in order to send a clear message abroad and put an end to the infringement of basic human rights on Europe’s borders.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. It is very important to keep in mind that human trafficking still exists today and that we must fight it with all our might. However, through this text, the EU is using the fight against human trafficking to demand more powers internationally. The report proposes that the EU be involved in international programmes against human trafficking, which is not its role. So I chose the ABSTENTION.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings, which is part of organised crime, is one of the most serious forms of human rights abuses, as it reduces people to commodities and seriously and permanently violates the dignity, integrity and rights of the victim and has an impact on entire families and communities, and deliberately abuses vulnerable situations such as poverty and isolation. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report. Although the text contains elements that I support, as regards the effective protection of persons in situations of forced mobility, and in particular the most vulnerable, I do not share the general approach of the text, which exempts European countries from any responsibility for the root and structural causes, as well as, from the dramatic consequences of mass migration, by concentrating actions only on trafficking and trafficking networks, which are but the consequence of a failed asylum and immigration system. Nor do we share the sectarian view of the humanitarian crisis, which on the one hand doubles victimizes refugees and on the other hand generates a very lucrative business linked to large arms companies, whose expansion is linked to the prevalence of wars that cause mass exoduses.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – Trafficking in human beings is a type of modern slavery and a serious crime that commits one of the most serious violations of human rights and cannot be accepted by societies based on respect for human rights; I also believe that trafficking in human beings must be seen holistically, focusing not only on sexual exploitation, but also on forced labour, organ trafficking, forced begging, forced marriages, child-soldiers and trafficking in infants.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the fight against trafficking in human beings in the EU’s external relations. The report denounces and explicitly rejects trafficking in human beings, which represents a growing industry of human suffering, affecting all societies and economies in a profound and enduring manner. The report equally underlines the fact that trafficking in human beings is a modern kind of slavery, and a serious crime, which constitutes one of the worst forms of human rights violations that cannot be accepted in societies that are based on the respect for human rights including gender equality. I voted in favour because I believe that trafficking in human beings has to be understood in a holistic manner, focusing not only on sexual exploitation, but also on forced labour, organ trafficking, forced begging, forced marriages, child soldiers and the trafficking of babies.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The fight against trafficking in human beings is a key area of action for the European Union. To combat this abominable behaviour it is necessary to prevent trafficking in human beings, to protect victims and to prosecute crimes and criminals in their various modalities and personifications. This report recognises the work done by the European Union on this subject and calls for greater support in the area to combat this scourge. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. It is an initiative with positive intentions, but it does not offer concrete and specific solutions that contribute to the real fight against trafficking in human beings. Priority is not given to urgent measures that must involve actions by transit countries that are crucial to combating this scourge. That's why I abstained.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'Human trafficking reduces human life to numbers and commercial goods. Trafficking in human beings is one of the most profitable organised crime activities in the world in addition to illegal drug and arms trafficking. According to the ILO's most recent estimates, the annual illegal profits from forced labour – including money laundered – amount to around USD 150 billion, with an estimated two thirds of the profits coming from commercial sexual exploitation.  I voted in favour of this report because it holds companies responsible for human rights violations within their working environment and in their subcontractors. I certainly support the call for more attention to women's sexual and reproductive rights.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Trafficking in human beings is one of the worst forms of human rights violations because it reduces human beings to a commodity. It takes various forms of exploitation: prostitution, services and forced labour, slavery, child soldiers, organ trafficking...  Women and girls are the majority of women, especially in sexual matters (79% of victims). Conversely, men are the majority of victims of forced labour (83%).  Trafficking in human beings is an increasingly lucrative scourge: its illicit profits are estimated at $150 billion.  The report points to the lack or limitations of existing legislation and calls, in particular, for the strengthening of national legislation and international cooperation in this area.  While the proposals in this report as a whole are correct, particularly with regard to the application of ILO standards, some elements are not acceptable. In particular, the report welcomes Operation "Eunavformed" which aims to return the boats to the country from which they come, particularly in Libya.  I therefore regret the report's support for repressive migration policies and have chosen to abstain.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Trafficking in human beings (TSH), which is part of organised crime, is one of the most serious forms of human rights violations, since it converts human beings into goods, blatantly and enduringly violates the dignity, integrity and rights of victims and affects entire families and communities, deliberately abusing situations of vulnerability, such as poverty or isolation. However, this TSH cannot be disconnected from the neoliberal and bellicose policies that spread poverty on several continents and promote this type of practice. Let us live in a world of peace, social progress, genuine solidarity and respect for the differences of each people and certainly the numbers presented would be different.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report calls for a wider scope for the fight against trafficking in human beings in external action. As a result, trafficking in human beings is addressed as part of organised crime, and the definition is based on the (UN—) Palermo Protocol. On the one hand, the special needs of refugees are to be taken into account, in particular by referring to the large number of allegedly disappeared underage migrants within the EU. On the other hand, however, the report also targets child pornography and similar sensitive issues, which I condemn in the most serious way. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is an organised crime. This is one of the worst forms of human rights violations that defines man as a commodity. Moreover, it seriously violates both the dignity and the rights of the victim and has a negative impact on the whole community. I believe that it is necessary to implement a legal framework that will deal with trafficking in human beings. Attention should be paid to the barriers to combating trade in persons in both European Union and third countries. This type of crime affects every place on earth, so the focus should be on implementing appropriate steps not only at local level, but also at international level. Cooperation between Member States, Europol and other countries of all continents is an important tool in the fight against existing networks of criminals involved in trafficking in human beings. I voted in favour of taking action to strengthen and improve cooperation in defence of the dignity of victims of trafficking in human beings.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because human trafficking is a malicious activity that needs to be countered both within and outside the EU. This is a problem that can only be resolved at a global level. It is therefore important for this resolution to call upon the Commission to take into account certain risks with regard to human trafficking, when negotiating visa liberalisation agreements with third countries. Besides third countries, I do agree that we also need the help of our companies.  This resolution offers solutions to some specific problems. For example, I understand the need to place firewalls between immigration authorities and labour inspectorates. It also calls for safer and legal ways for migrants to enter the EU and enhance their integration by strengthening integration programmes. Other important aspects that are related to this problem also get attention, such as the right to sexual and reproductive health. In addition, it stresses the need to search for those refugees that are missing. Finally, I applaud the call for better cooperation with Europol, especially when it concerns child abuse.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the own-initiative report on combating trafficking in human beings in the context of the EU's external relations.  The rapporteur calls on the EU and its Member States to adopt a human rights-based and victim-based approach and to place vulnerable victims and populations at the heart of all efforts made in the fight against trafficking in human beings, to prevent it and protect victims. It also states that trafficking in human beings, as a form of organised crime, occurs both at the external and internal borders, thus requiring strong national legislation against trafficking in human beings, as well as cooperation between countries. In the same document, trafficking in human beings is denounced as an extremely profitable business, the products coming from this criminal activity being largely reintroduced into the global economy and financial system.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution takes into account different aspects of the phenomenon which unfortunately we have not yet been able to combat. This initiative, which I supported, sets a framework for human trafficking and trafficking issues in the EU's external relations, taking into account the global dimension of the phenomenon, different forms of exploitation, international and regional cooperation and victims' rights.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I very much agree with this report: trafficking in human beings is a phenomenon comparable to modern slavery and one of the worst forms of human rights abuse. With globalization, this type of crime has been increasing, as it has provided new tools to facilitate their crimes and hinder their persecution. For this reason, it is increasingly necessary for European legislation to be as forceful and decisive as possible. I believe that the EU Strategy for the Eradication of Trafficking in Human Beings (2012-2016) should continue the lines of action for its review. I believe that aspects such as the identification of the most vulnerable groups, the extension of the ways of combating human traffickers and the recovery of the goods obtained by this crime are key.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The JRC strongly condemns all forms of trafficking in human beings, one of the most repugnant derivatives of the exploitative system. The report, however, systematically concealing its cause with what it proposes, not only does it not tackle trafficking in human beings, but instead moves on the territory of those factors that give birth to it and reproduce it.  It calls for strengthening the EU's repression mechanisms, which have been shown not to address the problem, seeking to legitimise in popular consciences these mechanisms developed with the main objective of the grassroots-labour movement. It promotes the replacement of the responsibility of the state and its structures to combat and support victims from controversial to suspicious NGOs, leading mathematically to a giant of criminal enterprises.  Because trafficking in human beings is a huge criminal enterprise that makes untold profits. It is a consequence of the transformation of the labour force into a commodity in capitalism, which automatically gives birth and the conversion of people themselves into commodities, in order to serve the unique value that the rotten system of exploitation recognizes: the profit of capital.  The battle for the definitive eradication, but also the decisive fight against this inhuman enterprise, is insoluble tied to the struggle to eliminate the very matrix that gives birth to it, the barbaric capitalist system.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support the report submitted, although I condemn and expressly reject trafficking in human beings. In my opinion and that of a number of experts, trafficking in human beings can be regarded as modern-day slavery and constitutes one of the worst forms of human rights violations. It must be remembered that trafficking in human beings is a transnational crime of a global nature, which is why I believe that there is a need for a unified approach to the internal and external dimension of EU policies to combat trafficking in human beings. In particular, it is necessary to ensure the safety of victims of trafficking who testify in court against traffickers. However, this report explicitly supports the redistribution of refugees on the basis of permanent quota systems, of which I am a long-standing opponent.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support Mrs Lochbihler's report on combating trafficking in human beings in the EU's external relations, despite the indisputable seriousness of the subject. The report took a very clear position of rejection against any form of trafficking in human beings, noting that this problem does not only concern less developed countries. The report also makes a series of recommendations to prevent trafficking in human beings, such as enhanced international cooperation or criminalising the demand for services that victims of trafficking in human beings are often forced to provide. A large part of the recommendations also focuses on helping and supporting victims of trafficking in human beings and on properly trained staff who come into contact with them. No less important are the recommendations concerning child victims. However, despite these positives, the report contained a number of articles that I could not support, including calls for ratification of the Istanbul Convention, references to a mandatory quota system in relation to the migration agenda or to the accountability of undertakings for exploitation, regardless of the link in the supply chain, or whether it occurs in affiliated enterprises or subcontractors. I do not consider the latter measures to be realistic and, above all, fair, which is why I decided to abstain in the final vote.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. The report describes human trafficking as a new-age slavery and warns that this is a serious crime on the rise recently. The latest global slavery index worldwide is estimated to have trapped 35.8 million people in the context of new-age slavery. Unfortunately, trafficking in human beings and people smuggling are not a transitional phenomenon and could be exacerbated in the coming years, as conflict hotspots, repressive regimes and the economic situation in the world create favourable conditions for the criminal activities of traffickers and people smugglers. I agree that the inadequate implementation of the legal framework for trafficking in human beings at national level and the lack of an adequate legal framework in third countries is one of the most important obstacles to combating trafficking in human beings. Therefore, enhanced cooperation between Member States, Europol and countries of origin and transit are therefore needed in the fight against smuggling networks. Against this very, I supported the Report on combating trafficking in human beings in the EU's external relations.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Jan Olbrycht and Isabelle Thomas on behalf of the Committee on Budgets on the preparation of the revision of the 2014-2020 MFF after the election: Parliament's contribution in the run-up to the Commission's proposal (2015/2353(INI)) (A8-0224/2016).

name: Jan Olbrycht
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Dear! The Regulation on the multiannual financial perspective provides for an obligation to review the functioning of the multiannual perspective and, where justified, to make appropriate changes. This regulation, of course, mainly provides for the role of the European Commission and the Council. The European Parliament has entrusted us with the task of preparing a position in the form of an own-initiative report, a position showing the Expectations of the European Parliament and the Council in connection with the multiannual financial perspectives. The European Parliament therefore, when adopting its own-initiative report, clearly shows what its expectations are when it is to agree to the findings and changes made after the whole process. In its report, the European Parliament, firstly, refers to the state of play of the financial perspective, i.e. it points to certain elements of difficult or even difficult risks. The European Parliament also points to the changing nature of the European Union budget and the growing role of external financial instruments. The European Parliament's report also shows what Parliament believes – and that was our task as rapporteurs – should be changed even in this perspective. In this regard, we draw attention, inter alia, to the change of ceilings for individual headings. We draw attention to the change in the ceilings for payments to the adjustment of payments relating to commitments, in particular in cohesion policy. We also draw attention to the need to increase resources both for those departments that concern youth employment and for security and migration issues. We are also proposing changes to the flexibility mechanism. The European Parliament will, hopefully after this debate, also adopt the following recommendations that we should indeed change the rules for using the budget surplus. In our opinion, the budget surplus should remain in the budget and not be returned to individual Member States. The whole package of proposed changes, of course, also concerns the issue of simplifications, which we believe should be made in the near future, i.e. in the coming months, so that the perspective can be completed. In addition, in our report, we propose changes to the functioning of the multi-annual perspective after 2020.  The European Parliament therefore makes it clear today that it expects concrete, decisive action from the European Commission and expects not only a review of the budget and policies, but also proposals for change. We are therefore awaiting a revision proposal.

name: Isabelle Thomas
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would particularly like to thank my co-minister, Jan Olbrycht. I believe that we have worked in accordance with our convictions, but above all in the interests of the European citizens, and my thanks, of course, also go to all the shadow rapporteurs, who have enriched the text, and to the Committee on Budgets, in particular to its president. During the negotiation of the 2014-2020 Multi-Year Financial Framework, Parliament had removed the obligation to carry out a budget review and, if necessary, a revision before the end of 2016. It is in order to prepare Parliament's position and a little to refer the Commission that the Committee on Budgets has taken the initiative of a report on this revision. In a Europe that is pitching, doubting and waiting for a new course to be proposed, this text is seen as a revelation, where Parliament makes a clear and clear diagnosis of the budgetary situation. And this report is sounding the alarm: we must respond urgently and use this revision to ask the questions that will allow a budget to be up to the challenge. Youth unemployment, migration crises, the refugee crisis, COP 21, agricultural crises, underinvestment, internal security: unfortunately, in the last two years, new challenges and emergencies have rendered the multi-year financial framework voted in 2013 obsolete. This report takes a clear-eyed look at the situation. What is it? The multi-year financial framework no longer meets priorities, its limits are reached, all the instruments of flexibility have been called upon to deal with the various crises and, without revision, we will continue to undress Peter to dress Paul. Cuts to key programmes have been made - as is the case in Horizon 2020, as is the case in Connecting Europe Facility - and a freeze on commitments to combat youth unemployment has been agreed, while the ceilings, particularly those in heading 3, have exploded.  I think I can say that this report refuses to make any changes between trust funds and facilities. He refuses to allow the proliferation of financial instruments to become the rule at the expense of democratic control that is fading. And then, of course, there are the payments: the payments crisis is coming for the end of the period. If we do not make changes, we must stop being ostrich and flee our responsibilities in dealing with this situation. It is a matter of the credibility of our institutions and, more importantly, of the situation of all those who are waiting for these funds, whether it is local authorities, businesses or Erasmus mobility students who would find themselves waiting for the European Union to be able to pay what is due to them. This hidden deficit of the Union is contrary to the Treaty and this report points it out: the adjustment of the payment ceilings would prevent us from falling into the mistakes we experienced in the last years of the previous financial framework. The Committee on Budgets voted by a large majority on a long list of recommendations. We had asked for it as soon as the Juncker Plan was put in place. The budget cuts of 2.2 billion euros in the Horizon 2020 programme and 2.8 billion euros in the Connecting Europe Facility programme must be fully offset by the increase in commitment and payment ceilings in this category. To the same causes the same effects. How can we accept that there are no more commitment credits until 2020 for youth employment initiatives, when this evil of youth unemployment is eating away at us? The Commission cannot continue to oppose its late assessment, firstly because no one can avail themselves of its own turpitudes, but above all because the evaluation of this programme will not eliminate the need for means of action. It is therefore a priority to review the ceilings in heading 1B, at least in line with what we have done for the two years of launch, i.e. EUR 3 billion per year. The same goes for internal security, for the promises made at COP 21, for the refugee crisis or for agricultural crises. Ladies and gentlemen, how many exits, how many cries of alarm will it take for us to take responsibility? Through this report, Parliament will decide tomorrow whether or not to measure the seriousness of the situation and we are very clear: we want the revision to be presented quickly to carry out, in parallel, the negotiations on the 2017 budget.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to offer my most sincere thanks to the rapporteurs for the excellent work they have done. We look forward to engaging further so we can reflect as we prepare to submit our proposal for the midterm revision in the coming months. We have an obligation to complete this work by the end of the year and we will do all we can on our side to meet that obligation. It is an opportunity to examine the implementation of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and, as the rapporteurs have said, this is not a usual period in the history of the European Union. Since 2008 we have gone from one crisis to another. We have had a financial crisis, an economic crisis in the eurozone, hitting Greece the hardest, the migration crisis, terrorism and now, very recently, we have experienced the earthquake of the referendum in the United Kingdom. In this context, what we have in our hands is, for the first time in the history of the European Union, a smaller budget than the one we had before. Needs have gone up and resources are tighter. This puts us in a position that requires collaboration between Parliament, the Commission and our Member States to make the best out of the budget: to answer the questions that both the rapporteurs have framed about how to help our economies and our people, especially the young people who are jobless in Europe; how to make sure that we have the capacity to address the flows of people coming, seeking rescue or out of hopelessness; and how to make sure that the external challenges of Europe are buffered appropriately with the use of our budget. These are not easy questions and I can say that there are areas where there is very strong agreement and there are areas where there would be a lot of work to do. Where we are in agreement is that we have to expand the flexibility of the budget. I say that every time I have the chance. I thank Parliament for what you have done to negotiate flexibility in the MFF, which is what has saved us in recent years, and I am sure will do so again in the years ahead. We also have to simplify our rules, to use the revision of the Financial Regulation to make it easier for money to get to where it is designated to go. We have, broadly speaking, an agreement on the fact that we have to sharpen the link between money and priorities and make sure that we address top priorities with top euros. There are also very difficult questions and I am not going to shy away from those. The expectations in Council and in Parliament in terms of what we would deliver are quite diverse. We have to work on finding a way to bridge this divergence. We also know that the Monti group is due to produce its report on own resources, and that is going to be an incredibly sensitive – and yet critical – issue for the future of the European Union. From the Commission side, I can tell you that we are working with all we have to make the budget deliver more, bigger and better results for our people, to stretch every euro to the maximum and to use our great creativity and flexibilities to do more with the money we have. I want to address a particular point that Ms Thomas brought up – the issue of legitimacy and accountability to Parliament in respect of the instruments which help us to do more, like the Turkey Facility, but which fall outside the oversight of Parliament. I believe we need to address that: to give Parliament a role, to bring Parliament into the decision making, and to be sure we do the best with the money we have because we will have Parliament’s eyes looking over everything we fund from the sacrifice of our taxpayers. Our commitment to bridging these difficult issues and to bridging the divide is genuine and we count on your being on our side as we go along this difficult road in the months to come.

name: Neena Gill
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. –  Madam President, my thanks to the two rapporteurs. As you said, I am speaking as the rapporteur for AFET (Committee on Foreign Affairs), and we are largely concerned with Heading 4, which focuses on the EU’s external action and within which the biggest crisis has occurred. The problems, from Ukraine through Syria to Libya, are not going to be resolved overnight. At the same time, the ongoing turbulence in Africa and elsewhere will be detrimental to our own future security, and the consequences of climate change are plain for all to see. We have seen a spike in natural disasters across the world. That is why our committee wants a genuine revision that increases Heading 4, to raise the ceilings for both payments and commitment appropriations, and the creation of a permanent crisis reserve, to address the short-term crisis without cutting into the long-term policies that are vital for addressing the root causes. So in these turbulent times I think it is really vital that the EU stands for its values as the world’s largest aid donor, supporting the most vulnerable globally. One lesson from the UK referendum is that many see the EU’s inability to resolve the global crisis as a problem, so I would really urge all, the Council and Commission, to address this as soon as possible by increasing Heading 4.

name: Paul Rübig
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Our main concern is headings 3 and 4, security and Citizenship and Europe in the world. My personal wish would be for us, together with the Heads of State or Government, to increase the European Union's budget by 0.1% and make it available for the crisis. This would help refugees, migration and the fight against terrorism. The central concern must be to help on the ground. How can we ensure food supplies, how can we get clean water and local health care in the spotlight? Family businesses in the small unit in particular would have a great opportunity here, not the large international corporations, but family businesses, small and medium-sized enterprises. How can we support them? That is why we are also calling for the Erasmus programme to be extended to young entrepreneurs, including countries outside the European Union. We also call for the Migrant Entreprerenewableship programme to be a success within the European Union.

name: Георги Пирински
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Madam President, Madam Vice-President, I would like to emphasise the only paragraph of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Policy, which begins with 'underlines': the resources of the European Social Fund and the European Aid Fund for the most deprived are not sufficient to counteract growing inequalities and poverty, with the worst effects of the labour market crisis affecting the young and the long-term unemployed , as well as the unprecedented influx of refugees; calls on the Commission to propose an increase in resources for social policies and to propose an increase in the share of the European Social Fund in the Cohesion Policy budget. And the last focus in our opinion: calls on the Member States to ensure that all necessary resources are provided to overcome the extreme challenges facing the European Union today, taking into account that over 13% of member states' gross domestic product was spent on bailing out banks, while the European Union budget remains less than 1% of this product.

name: Janusz Lewandowski
text: draft opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear Kristalino! The Commissioner called the real challenges by name. We have less money, and the competences of the European Union are growing. This cannot be called into question. In addition, new needs have emerged that need to be financed, namely migration, refugees, the fight against terrorism. This is why, this time, Parliament's expectations of the European Commission are extremely high and are reflected in the report by Mr Olbrycht and Mr Thomas. These are expectations that this will be a real revision, although there is little to be inferred – after these three years of slow implementation of the new perspective – which programmes are actually successful and which are going wrong. As far as my committee, ITRE, is concerned, the expectation is one thing, namely that the new priorities that have emerged should not be financed at the expense of old priorities, because programmes such as Horizon, COSME, Galileo and Copernicus are also very forward-looking.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Madam President, Commissioner, you said that, for the first time, the budget is smaller than the previous one. You're right. Don't forget who forced this budget down. It is no longer or, at last, wants to stop being with us, so you should somehow take action in this direction. There's obviously a lot to do. There is a system, a flexibility tool, as you said, introduced by Parliament. I think you need to use it to the fullest, so that this figure, which is very small, is used 100%. Normally extraordinary things, extraordinary events should be extraordinarily budgeted, that is, the Member States should come up with extra money, with other money, because they were not foreseen from the beginning. At the same time, remember that there are the disengagement situations for 2007-2013 and the disengagement situations that will now come for the current MFF. Please take this into account and the money that needs to be deactivated to stay in the budget.

name: Kerstin Westphal
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Yes, it is important, it is good that we are presenting our position on the revision of the MFF, and therefore a very warm thank you to the rapporteurs for this good report. It is important that the budget is adapted to the current challenges. We want more resources for refugee policy, but also more flexibility to keep the EU budget in a good place to act. When we are currently discussing what europe's benefits are and how they are made more visible, I can only say that structural policy is the most visible thing that the European Union actually has to offer citizens. Structural policy provides support in dealing with the migration crisis. In this context, however, it is also important to create synergy effects between the various funds. A strong structural policy beyond 2020 is what really matters to people.

name: Peter Jahr
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The European common agricultural policy is a success story. Agricultural policy has become a reliable partner for Europe. This concerns the budget, budgetary discipline and, moreover, the error rate, which is one of the lowest error rates in the European Union. We have established the famous first and second pillars in the common agricultural policy. The first pillar is direct payments. The second pillar is about rural development. In other words, agricultural policy feels responsible for the economic development of rural areas. Agriculture is a thinker in generations, and that is why the promises we made to farmers beforehand should be honoured. In other words, we are counting on the stability of the budget. The call for stability in the budget is important. This demand is understandable, reasonable and proportionate and understandable to the taxpayer.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We always have the case that the Multiannual Financial Framework and the debate about it are a de facto debate on the state of European finances, on the economic condition of Europe. How does this condition compare? Not the best. We know it's hard, but it's not the worst. On behalf of the Committee, I would like to stress the need to ensure financial guarantees for programmes such as Creative Europe, Erasmus+, Europe for citizens, but also to prevent a backlog of payments. I would add one more element, which is serious now. It is important to ensure that europe's most important activities are well promoted in order to support information programmes and to –. in short, fake campaigns such as Brexit were not right. We must ensure that our efforts, our institutions, are promote, and there must be no shortage of resources, because other costs will be many times higher.

name: Laura Agea
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the priorities on this important occasion for reorganising the MFF proposed by the LIBE Committee concern, in particular, the need to give more resources to the Fund for Asylum, Migration and Integration. Strengthening Frontex today is a non-solution to the problem: people, however, even if they close their borders, will find other access routes and will still arrive within our borders, and that is therefore not the solution.  We also need to increase EASO funds in order to provide Member States with the support they need, and we also need to create a fund for rescue operations at sea. This should be an important priority for us to bear in mind. We have also criticised the creation of the EUR 3 billion fund that has been negotiated with Turkey, 1) because we have not been taken into account, as a Parliament, in the negotiation phases and 2) because the doubt is that this money will certainly not alleviate the problem of immigrants but will be used for anything else. That's a fact. The immigrant emergency is there and will remain. It needs to be addressed.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Madam President, this year's revision of the multiannual financial framework will be the moment of truth, because then, when we decide on the application of financial resources, we will know whether the concerns that many now proclaim are to be taken seriously.  We certainly need more flexibility in managing funds to respond to unforeseen situations such as the refugee crisis and security challenges. But we also need that this flexibility is not at the expense of the means of cohesion policy.  We must also increase our own financial ceilings and speed up the discussion on the Union's new own resources system, and finally, and this is a very important subject to the AFCO Commission, we must strengthen democratic support for financial decisions by aligning the duration of financial frameworks with the mandates of Parliament and the Commission and strengthening the control mechanisms of this Parliament. This is what we must do for a Union capable of facing the crises ahead.

name: Clare Moody
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality. – Madam President, I would first like very much to welcome this report, which recognises a number of the difficult issues that we are facing right now with the current Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and the need to look at a revision of the current MFF. From the Women’s Rights Committee’s perspective, I also welcome that there is specific reference in this document to the need to recognise gender and the importance of gender budgeting in the work of the MFF and the revision and review processes, because it is clear that without measurement we cannot determine the outcomes. From our perspective, that is a very welcome element to the report that we have today.

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, I would like to record and welcome the excellent work done by the two rapporteurs. In fact, this multiannual financial framework does not have the necessary flexibility to respond to the current challenges to emergencies, as evidenced by the trust funds that are outside the European Union budget. The review is urgent, priorities are clear, employment, including youth employment, promoting growth, strengthening the competitiveness of the Union economy, internal solidarity, external solidarity and internal security as well.  There are simple principles on which we must agree. We must have a credible multiannual financial framework. This means that the financial resources must be in line with our ambitions, our goals and the objectives we set. Moreover, it also seems obvious to me that the commitments made must be respected. We need more flexibility, we need simplicity and if we look, for example, at the implementation of the current multiannual financial framework, we see a huge delay. This is unacceptable and is the result of bureaucracies, both national and European, which need to be eliminated.  We have the support of the European Commission to move towards a real revision of the multiannual financial framework to revive the economy, investment and also to be up to the interests of the population, the longings of the citizens of the European Union. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – You mentioned all these challenges. There are so many challenges at the same time in the European Union – Brexit being the latest one, besides unemployment, terrorism, investment shortfall, refugees, migration – which you mentioned. Do you not think it is the moment to call on the Commission for a total reform of the resources and payment plan, because we cannot continue in this way?

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – The multiannual financial framework, if we look at its implementation, does not have the implementation it should implement. If we look, for example, at payments for 2017, it has a reduction of 6.2 %. What does that mean? That there are delays in the multiannual financial framework. What does that mean, too? That with the resources we have we can do better. This is not only up to the institutions, it also depends on national governments. But I agree that 1 % of the GDP budget for the European Union is not enough and the European Commission should put forward proposals, bringing together other funds such as the Juncker plan, to move towards all the challenges it has mentioned. On Brexit just one point: €39.6 billion is what the UK also has in 2014... (The speaker ends his response outside the microphone.)

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, congratulate the rapporteurs on their magnificent work. Today we have a golden opportunity to make amends for the mistakes that were made when we approved the current financial framework. We were not then able to get the Council to accept the Commission's proposal and in the end there was a financial framework with insufficient funds to deal with the economic crisis, without funds to revive investment, without funds to establish a true and effective youth employment plan and with substantial cuts in development cooperation. I recall that in 2011 this Parliament adopted a report entitled 'Investing in the future: a new financial framework for a competitive, supportive, sustainable and inclusive Europe'. Unfortunately, the facts have shown that the financial framework has not been the case, that there was no funds for a competitive, sustainable, much less inclusive Europe. It is true that, since 2014, we have tried to change the financial framework, but we have not been able to turn our budgets around. To finance the investment plan we have had to cut funds in infrastructure and research projects. To finance refugee policy, we have had to cut back on development cooperation funds. We do not know how we will finance the agreement with Turkey, nor the commitments of the London Conference, let alone know how we will finance that investment plan that we seem to want to make in third countries. In youth unemployment we have not put a new euro since 2015 and the results of COP 21 are not yet budgeted. I could continue to give examples, but I think it has become very clear that we really need to change this financial framework to meet all these challenges. We need more funding for everything I've said, but we also need a proposal on own resources. In the current context we cannot continue to depend on the goodwill of the Member States, as if the European Union were a work of charity. If we want to have a solidarity future project, we cannot have a stingy and regressive own resources system. We need to launch a rate of financial transactions, we need a real common and harmonised corporation tax and we need an 'evasive' against tax evasion. This Union needs a tune-up and of course it is not all money. We need to make things easier, simpler, because today there are funds that cannot be spent because it is too complex, although sometimes I think this is no coincidence and that some Member States are very happy that this is not spent. And we also need a little coherence in our policy. It cannot be that we are calling for investment in the European Union to emerge from the crisis and at the same time have half of the countries of the European Union under surveillance, which cannot co-finance their share in structural funds and in European Youth Guarantee. This can't be. In conclusion: more investment, more income, more ease, more coherence and, of course, less selfishness. We have to define a new Europe.

name: Bernd Kölmel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is perfectly normal that, in a report that is initially planned for seven years, we should in it set new priorities in the focus of our expenditure and therefore also in our tasks. Because it is logical: there have been unforeseen events, especially the refugee crisis, of course. It is absolutely right that we should take a great deal of money into this crisis and invest. I believe that no one in this House has anything against that. But I would like to stress once again that spending money is not enough. We finally need a European plan here. How are we really going to combat the refugee crisis? Where do we want to go, what is the goal, what should the EU look like in 2030 with its migration policy? We must finally tackle this task. In addition, it is, of course, crucial that we always talk about taxpayers' money when it comes to the budget. That is not our money, so we must proceed very carefully here and ensure that we not only spend this money sustainably, but also efficiently and thus also sparingly. Anything else is not appropriate for us as administrators of this money. We must finally get to the conclusion that we can also measure the benefits we achieve with the money we spend through the EU. We are on the first track now, but we need to move faster; that is what the citizens expect of us. It is not acceptable to keep calling for more money, that is simply not appropriate. I would therefore like to strengthen your backs, Vice-President Georgieva. As with the draft budget for 2017, stay on a frugal line here. The citizens will thank us for that. With everything else, we have seen where it leads politically. Brexit was the tip of the iceberg here. Calling for more EU means calling for more state. However, we must strengthen the economy and not just the states.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, as everyone knows, the 2014-2020 multi-year financial framework is too tight on the budget, too technically rigid and too politically conventional. It was negotiated and approved before the migration crisis, before the formation of the Juncker Fund and the levy it involved, before the Embargo of Russia and its consequences for farmers, before terrorist attacks and the need to strengthen the intelligence and security services. It is therefore legitimately, Commissioner, that we are asking the Commission to propose a robust review, to meet today's challenges and their extension, if not their aggravation tomorrow. The Commission must not restrict itself. In any case, it did so on timing with the 2017 budget, which it delayed so as not to favour Brexit supporters. It has been pointless, and I hope that the British government will behave like a gentleman and do not want to block the proposed revision. Having said that, my group strongly supports the excellent report, and I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate its two authors, which is presented to us today. In particular, we support the call to mobilise the necessary resources to support investment in SMEs and boost growth, to sustain the youth employment initiative, to ensure better control of external borders, to organise genuine solidarity between Member States and third countries depending on the burden they bear in welcoming refugees. , to address the true origins of the migration crisis in Africa and the Middle East, and to avoid a new payment crisis that is now inevitable if nothing changes. Commissioner, the Commission must be the driving force behind European policies, it cannot be just the secretariat of the Council.

name: Younous Omarjee
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, I also welcome the work of the co-workers, but we cannot miss Brexit and this moment in history, for it is now that everything must be changed, it is now that we must dare to break up, it is now that we must send a strong and clear message to the European Council to put an end once and for all to austerity policies, to put an end to the 'monitoring and punishing', to put an end to this real false budget which is a reflection of the European Council's lack of ambition. I do not believe that the small additional resources that are requested will be sufficient to deal with the new crises that will come before us and to respond to the demands of the citizens and peoples of Europe.

name: Ernest Maragall
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, let us make a minimum of history. In 2013, the Green Group voted "no" to the current financial framework. There was no mandatory review clause, there was little flexibility, there was no reform of own resources: the facts show that we were right.  But now we have to look forward and that's why we're here, and that's why we're sharing that report.  Changes since 2013 are, of course, clad by real changes in our financial framework. Can we settle for what we have? No. Let's work with those trying to carry out the necessary changes.  "Lucid look, " said Mrs. Thomas. Agree: to properly look at the balance between our principles, which we must not renounce, and the efforts we must make to move forward with these possible and necessary changes.  Mrs Georgieva, it is not enough to exhaust the margins of flexibility or contingency. Also, but it's not just a matter of optimizing available resources. Refugees, climate change, inequality and unemployment, youth, security and defence ..., each of these areas sends an unmistakable message that we cannot fail to listen to or stop attending to.  In Paris, seven months ago, we said "CP21" all unanimously. We must draw the right consequence, we have to be consistent, we have to respect our own unanimous commitment, and that means incorporating to this financial framework the forecasts of increased spending related to climate change.  We are ready in the coming months to work side by side with the rapporteurs - thank you, by the way – and with the groups in this House who want to share this guidance for and for Europe.  We need to revise the multiannual financial framework upwards and that is why we will support the report because that is what it says, the message it sends us. And that is why we are going to table in this House some amendments which will try to clearly show what our basic position is.  It is a report working and thought before 23 June, before the British referendum. This morning's debate has made it clear: a message of change, of profound change, of real change. This report, done earlier, should be consistent and should be read and interpreted in the light of that very debate this morning. Will we be able to maintain ambition by realizing it in compromises? We're going to try sincerely.

name: Marco Zanni
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on 23 June, a momentous thing happened and, perhaps, someone in here struggles to understand it. The British people have said no to the EU and, whether we like it or not, we must take that into account. That is why It seemed sensible to me to suspend the finalisation of this report, pending more details on the timing and modalities of Brexit. The text talks about priorities to be supported and developed and new challenges for Europe. I would just like to point out that the United Kingdom left around EUR 5 billion net in Brussels every year. This money has a major impact on resources in the EU and I do not think we can continue to proceed as if nothing had happened. On the contrary, the need to choose certain priorities, on which to focus, and also to have the courage to leave out others, becomes even more urgent today. The approach must no longer be the one also used for the recent draft budget for 2017, as increasing commitments and reducing payments is certainly the wrong solution.

name: Auke Zijlstra
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – This multiannual budget is yet another blank cheque for all the eu's whigility. Why does the EU pay entrepreneurs to lay people off? Why does Frontex get money to pick up instead of stop so-called refugees? And why did I have to travel for a day and a half here in Strasbourg?  Expenditure ceilings will be increased. Member States will be required to fund all of the European Union's targets, while Brexit will reduce the number of union net contributors. And although every British farmer receives EUR 20 000 in subsidies a year, those same farmers voted to leave the Union. They too would rather be free entrepreneurs than subsidised nationals. American research shows that since 1980, increasing regulation has led to a 0.8% annual reduction in economic growth. That's $13,000 per citizen a year. But it costs energy and taxes, and therefore economic growth to control the lives of others and to be governed. No wonder the European Union has not been getting beyond promising prosperity and jobs for 25 years. Because nowhere is economic growth lower than here.  And that the government is a cost is a lesson that the European Union has clearly not understood. The EU budget is not a mainstay but a stranglehold!

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, the Multiannual Financial Framework is proving in fact to have failed as a cornerstone of budgetary discipline. And that's for two reasons.  Firstly because, over time, the parameters affecting the Union and the Member States are evolving rapidly and secondly because it requires the implementation of a false economic policy, this tight budgetary discipline. It is counterproductive, if not foolish, economic policies which lead the economically weak countries into more recession and the correspondingly strong ones in their sovereignty, to be a legally binding act.  The Multiannual Financial Framework does not need to be revised, it needs to be abolished. It does not have the capacity to deal with existing crises, such as illegal immigration, terrorism, BREXIT, economic recession, unemployment, climate change. It does not have the necessary flexibility to adapt to emerging threats, extreme situations, but also to future looming challenges.  Of course, on the other hand, in order for the heads of institutions to be able to understand the upcoming challenges, they must, in the first place, be able to keep their own home together. Therefore, we conclude, the Union neither knows nor has the capacity, nor has the tools to lead its citizens to prosperity. Why is there? Ask.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: Madam President, I congratulate the rapporteurs and the Committee on Budgets and I support their proposal. On the other hand, I do not congratulate those of our colleagues who are absent and give a very bad image of the European Parliament. It's just the budget, excuse me a little! The agreement reached in 2013 on the current fiscal framework included a requirement on the part of Parliament that, in the mid-term review, the "revenue" component of the budget be reopened: it is the reform of own resources. We are working on that, Commissioner, in the high-level group chaired by Mario Monti. Brexit makes this reform necessary and urgent. By definition, the British rebate will disappear and this is an opportunity to eliminate all other rebates as well, since their only justification was British privilege. The result so far has been an incredibly complex and scandalously unfair system: six of the richest countries contribute less to the European budget than the poorest countries in the Union. We have the opportunity to make the financing of the European budget simple, transparent and fair. We would be unforgivable not to seize it now.

name: Jens Geier (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to thank Jan Olbrycht and Isabelle Thomas for presenting an excellent report. Markus Söder, the Bavarian finance minister, was very concerned over the weekend about whether German contributions to the EU budget would not rise if Britain were to fail as a net contributor. His answer was that savings had to be made in the budget because it was bloated. Either he doesn't know better – that would be bad – or he deliberately tells the untruth – and that would be even worse. However, this is the Bavarian answer to Boris Johnson: obviously no idea about the real facts, but comforted something in the world that diminishes the EU's reputation. This is how Euroscepticism is made. As the Vice-President said, the governments of the Member States have decided that the ceilings of the EU budget will be reduced at least until 2020. At the same time, however, the requirements are going up. Just one example: in order to control the protection of external borders, Frontex is to be expanded. That's right. But do the additional services follow these additional requirements? Of course not. This bad game continues through almost all areas of the budget. I can draw up the European Parliament's draft for the 2017 budget, and this draft is like a patchwork, because the ceiling is too short. We have to cut a hole somewhere to put the patch somewhere else. Because the medium-term financial framework as it is today is a fair-weather event – as we say in German – that does not meet current requirements. Already in the second year, we have to go to the upper limit of the medium-term financial framework in domestic and foreign policy, and it is still stuck in all sorts of corners, because we have to take money away from other important points, for example at the UN Relief and Works Agency for the Palestinians. We are therefore in danger of replacing the Syrian civil war refugee, whose children are being trained with eu money, with the Palestinian refugee, who no longer sees any prospects because his children are no longer being educated. The essential point, then, is that the tasks and requirements have grown since the decision of the medium-term financial framework. Yes, we want to budget sparingly. Yes, we want the use of funds to be as effective as possible. However, this does not change the fact that Europe, which is supposed to help solve problems, needs the necessary resources to do so. Madam Vice-President, I therefore ask you to present an early revision of the medium-term financial framework, and I would ask you to be bold about the ceilings for headings 3 and 4. European policy desperately needs it.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Speaking in this debate, I would like to point out that when preparing the revision of the financial framework for 2014-20, the European Commission should take into account the following important points. The conflicts in Syria, the Middle East and several regions of Africa have had humanitarian and migratory security implications of such a large scale that this has already resulted in spending commitments from the Union budget of at least several billion euros. The low level of investment as a consequence of the establishment of the ESI Funds has resulted in a reduction in funding for Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe – a total of EUR 5 billion – and Parliament has committed itself to offseting these cuts. The persistently high level of youth unemployment up to the age of 25 means that the measures in the Youth Employment Initiative programme, after two years of operation, are in principle over. The long-term negative effects of farmers' losses resulting from the Russian embargo, the extremely difficult situation on the dairy market and the difficult situation on many other agricultural markets point to a persistent crisis in the agricultural sector as a whole, which requires and will require additional expenditure from the Union budget. All these challenges require not only that expenditure from the Union budget be not reduced, including compliance with Article 2 of the Financial Framework Regulation, which ensures that the appropriations allocated to individual Member States are not reduced by revision, but, on the contrary, that the expenditure ceiling is raised, in particular in Headings 1B and Headings 3 and 4.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I thank and congratulate our two rapporteurs. Our budget, which has been locked down in a seven-year framework, condemns the European Union to show its powerlessness in the face of crises. It is pathetic, ladies and gentlemen, to observe the proliferation of budget satellites: guarantee funds, trust funds and other financial stability mechanisms. Madam President, this is a real budgetary galaxy, which is not legible, which is not understandable by the citizens of Europe. These are instruments for begging Member States for failing resources. Without flexibility, our budget is not understandable. Moreover, it is not accessible given the dam made up by the accumulation of bureaucratic procedures and administrative complexity. But basically, the budget is just an expression of a vision, an ambition and a project, if they exist. In 2013, the current framework was concluded under the threat of a British veto. David Cameron then insisted that appropriations be cut for the first time, including migration credits. Parliament's agreement had been torn away on the promise of a mid-term review. We are there, and after Brexit, we have no more excuses for not moving forward. We call on the Council to respond to Parliament's realism in order to give the Union the means to talk to Europeans, Europeans eager to understand what European added value is and how Europe is able to effectively assume what States can no longer do on their own.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL).
text: – A Uachtaráin, ba mhaith liom mo bhuíochas a ghabháil leis an dá rapóirtéir, Isabelle Thomas agus Jan Olbrycht. Ar an gcéad dul síos, tá an geilleagar ina phraiseach agus ní ag dul i bhfeabhas atá sé. Feicimid anois go bhfuil an Iodáil i dtrioblóid; tá líon na dteifeach ag dul i méid; tá géarchéimeanna talmhaíochta againn; géarchéim fostaíochta i measc ár n-aos óg ach go háirithe; agus tá Brexit gan dabht tar éis éiginnteacht a chruthú san Eoraip.  Níl faic cloiste againn uaidh an gCoimisiún. Agus cé go bhfuil tagairt déanta sa tuarascáil seo do na dúshláin ollmhóra atá os ár gcomhair, nílim dóchasach go dtabharfaí aird orthu. Caithfear treoir nua a ghlacadh, treoir a chuirfidh na daoine chun tosaigh agus a dhéanfaidh infheistíocht réadúil inár bpobail agus inár sochaí agus stop a chur le polasaithe déine nach bhfuil ach ag tacú leis na bainc agus leo siúd go bhfuil ualach airgid acu.  Níor tugadh an deis dúinn sa Tigh seo ionchur réadúil nó athbhreithniú réadúil a chur i bhfeidhm ins an gCreat Airgeadais Ilbhliantúil. Mar sin, táim ag impí ar an gCoimisiún agus ar an gComhairle éisteacht agus aird a thabhairt ar ghuth an phobail agus treoir nua a ghlacadh.

name: Helga Trüpel (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to remind you once again that the Greens voted against the financial framework that is now in force, for the reasons that many representatives of the grand coalition who have now approved the agreement have now criticised. The MFF is too small and, for the first time in the history of the European Union, it has sunk. That was a mistake. We deplore a lack of flexibility. There is not enough money for unforeseen events and for emergency measures. We have predicted that there will be payment difficulties – unfortunately, this has also happened. Above all, we do not have enough really new own resources. Mr Lamassoure has pointed out that we need more environmental taxes paid into the European budget. But now there is a chance to change that. In our view, the multiannual financial framework must, above all, be able to spend more on ecological transformation. We criticise the fact that the Committee on Budgets has not now decided on the 30%, because that would have been important, especially after the Paris agreement. Yes, it is true that we must do more to combat youth unemployment. We need to spend more on Erasmus+, the European Union's truly successful education programme, because that too is a contribution to better inclusion. We must do more to integrate refugees.
