We need to upgrade the cultural programme. Above all, we must do more to combat the causes of flight. Finally, yes, we need more own resources so as not to be so dependent on member states' gross domestic product payments. Therefore, please act with courage and put pressure on the Council to increase revenue from environmental taxes.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, much has changed since the start of the Multiannual Financial Framework. The European Union has changed, the issues have changed, the world has changed and indeed it makes sense that you would want to make sure that you plan for that. There is of course this underlying question with regard to Brexit. I have heard the word Brexit mentioned time and again in this debate because it is going to impact on everything that is to come. I speak to constituents on a daily basis who are terrified that our Government will fail to respect the result of the referendum. They think that it is a delaying tactic for British politicians to try to wriggle out of the result. But ‘no’ of course must mean ‘no’, and Brexit of course must mean Brexit. But until the Government actually triggers Article 50, uncertainty is going to continue everywhere. How can you plan for Brexit until negotiations begin and until Article 50 is triggered? The British Government needs to hurry up, it needs to get a prime minister chosen and it needs to start the process. We all need certainty. For any kind of planning – how the EU 27 want to go about budgeting and organisation – you need certainty. Until we have that certainty, the UK continues to be bound by what happens here. So the longer this situation continues, the worse it will be for both parties, for the United Kingdom as much as for the European Union. So my message to the Conservative party is this: get on with it.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we have all agreed that the current Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) has shown its limits. The current MFF cannot cope with unexpected developments, firstly because it is not flexible enough, and secondly because it is built on the priorities of the years 2012-2013. It is only thanks to the European Parliament’s commitment to more flexibility that the EU budgetary system has not yet collapsed. My view is that the Member States have to realise that, if we want a strong response to the current challenges which we are facing, we need adequate financing at EU level. I have two concrete proposals: firstly, we need an upward revision in ceilings in heading No 3; and secondly – and I believe this is really essential – we need to repeal the provision in the MFF regulation that stipulates that the contingency margin has to be offset. What does this mean? This provision means that every time we mobilise this margin we decrease the budget in other areas. We all have to understand that new priorities have to be financed with new funds – with fresh money.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D).
text: – We are talking about a period with historically the greatest onslaught on financial resources. We urgently need economic growth. There won't be one without investment. If people are not employed, they will not shop, inflation will not be needed and public debt will rise. We therefore urgently need investments with high added value.  We have an Investment Plan and a European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) designed to finance high-risk investments. However, there are also commercial and profitable projects among the projects supported, which do not require risk guarantee or European funding. Yes, let's implement them. But not at the expense of Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility, from where we took EUR 5 billion for projects with high added value.  In the 2017 budget guidelines, we called on the Commission to review the YEI by the end of April 2016. This excellent project in Slovakia brought employment for more than 80% of those young people who participated in the project. They remained in employment even after the end of the project. We are all declaring aid to young people, but we have lost one year unnecessarily and we have lost tens of thousands of jobs for young people. The EU has excellent objectives and strategies. The Commission, the Council and the European Parliament have contributed to their preparation and approval. In order to achieve these objectives, we need to improve our joint efforts.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we are faced with a framework which, with the promise of giving stability to certain programmes, has ended us by squeezing and demonstrating that it is unable to meet the challenges we have in the European Union, let alone the crises in which we are in the world. More flexibility is requested, right, but for what? We see how the Juncker Plan is promoted, which doesn't really end up getting the desired or planned investment. We allocate large games for interested programs, such as ITER, space race or even Frontex, harming others such as Horizon 2020, integration policies or asylum policies. We care more about borders and security than about people's futures. We cannot continue to create financial instruments that escape democratic control, transparency and the decisions of this House, in order to get where the Union's budgets do not go. We need to recover the flag of solidarity. We need a financial framework that doesn't limit us. Only then will we have a Europe that no one would want to leave.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE).
text: – Dear colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. It is essential to maintain a balance between long-term priorities and the new challenges. It should be remembered that economic relations are more fruitful for countries with the same level of economic development. This has been proven in theory and in practice. Therefore, the move towards bringing these levels closer, i.e. the cohesion funding already approved, must be maintained. The use of financial instruments must be encouraged, but it is also essential to maintain grants of particular importance for small countries. The protection of external borders must be one of the priorities in order to prevent illegal immigration, and the refugee crisis cannot be tackled at the expense of other tasks. Competitiveness, growth, employment remain topical issues. Support should also be provided for the agricultural sector. At the same time, we should also think about saving money, for example by reducing the cost of administration to the European institutions and reaching an agreement on one seat of the European Parliament.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: Madam President, although budgetary annuality is essential for us, the existence of a multi-year financial framework, the duration of which can be debated, is necessary to mark the european Union's ambition and objectives in the medium term. It is a planning tool, but it must be flexible enough to respond to changes, shocks or crises, such as that of migrants recently. It must be a document shared between the Commission, the Council and Parliament, and it reminds everyone of their commitments. As we know, the budgetary capacity of the European Union is ridiculous in view of the current and future issues. The glass is sometimes half full, sometimes half empty, but still insufficiently filled. This largely consensual report has the merit of recalling the importance of a real budget for the European Union with the introduction of own resources, which would allow us to return to the fundamentals of the financing of the European Union, for that matter, and which would prevent the budget from being held hostage by the States and the Council. For my part, I would like to stress the financing of priority actions such as basic research and digital, rail and electric interconnection, and the preservation, of course, of structural policies such as cohesion funds and the common agricultural policy, as well as all the policies that speak to the European people, namely youth mobility policies. , vocational training or investment in employment. For all this, it is public money that Europe needs and not financial arrangements that are beyond the democratic control of Parliament.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, today's debate on the financial framework is one of the most ambitious and important debates we will have during this parliamentary term. In order to have a strong, effective, efficient and authoritative European Union, we also need a financial framework that is equally authoritative and strong and capable of having an impact. I am sorry to have to point out that the Commission and the Council have waited a long time in this debate. We waited for Brexit. We have been asked to wait and not to influence the Brexit debate, but we have lost hours, weeks, days and we are at the starting point. Today we are debating the report by Mr Thomas and Mr Olbrycht, which I would like to thank for their important work, which is heading in the right direction, namely that of a new ambition for the European Union.  We are at a crossroads: either we continue to stand still, but that means risking stopping the whole European dream, or trying to make the longest leap. This means, however, that, with the review, we have a duty to provide answers. The answers must be on work, investment, development, migration flows, as well as international cooperation, that is, the great challenges we face.  We must give these answers to the citizens, who are frightened and affected by globalisation that is becoming increasingly fierce, but also by our choices of the past which have been very wrong and which have struck deeply. I will end immediately by saying that we must start from the small things, from the federal budget, from greater integration of the euro area and also from a modern framework, from a new and modern multiannual financial framework.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, with or without Brexit, the EU budget needed reform. We should be spending more of the EU budget on creating growth and jobs. So, for example, we should be spending more of the budget on structural funds to create investment in infrastructure and training projects. We should be supporting the continuation of the Youth Employment Initiative, as youth unemployment remains a scandal right across the European Union. We should also be supporting more investment in innovation, research and development for our businesses and for our universities. Now is not the time to reduce funding which can improve our economy. We also need a more flexible budget to deal with crises as they arise. For example, the refugee crisis has been mentioned, but also we have a crisis because of Brexit. There is no doubt that regions across the EU will now face a cut in funding because of that. Finally, I would say, although there is no appetite in the Commission or the Council for major reforms of the MFF, we should take this opportunity to seek reform.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in your proposal to revise the multiannual financial framework, I would ask you to consider the enormous damage that the payment freeze has done since 2011 in the implementation of cohesion and regional policy which, as you know, is the real source of investment for many countries and regions.  Furthermore, the total amount of this policy should not be touched because of other needs that have arisen in order to provide, for example, a concrete response to the migration crisis, while not taking resources away from this policy, not least because cities and regions, which are the first beneficiaries of cohesion policy, are also the implementers of the measures put in place to stem the plight of refugees and therefore resources would be taken from that policy twice.  Secondly, I believe that the regulations for the revision of the Structural and Investment Funds should be simplified, at the same time as simplifying the EFSI regulation, in order to make these two instruments more dialogue-based and more cooperative.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this review responds to the agreement with the Council and the Commission to revisit and amend the outcome of a lousy agreement which led in 2013 to a multiannual budget on the down, still under the diktat of austerity, cuts and sanctions. Three years later, the challenges have multiplied and so has the disaffection towards the European Union, including through the cicattering of the budget.  Today we have not yet managed to emerge from the economic and social crisis, and young migrants, the unemployed, poor and excluded workers, who are numbered in the millions, are losing confidence in Europe and, more seriously, in democracy, because neither the Youth Guarantee nor the Juncker Plan, for example, already have credibility, with insufficient funds dancing from one place to another.  It has also added the cataclysm of refugees that overflow after decades of misguided and stingy European policies with the countries of origin and those who receive and continue to receive them.  Today, Greece, Portugal and Spain are threatened with sanctions for not being able to get out of their deficits, based on cuts and austerity, and for not being able to co-finance their funds for jobs and growth. Add the brexit.  And I would also like to add to the sources of budget, which my colleagues have raised, the possibility of a good exemplary sanction on those countries that have been in breach of the Stability Pact since 2007 with a criminal and excessive surplus of more than 6%.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, let me emphasise the three points that are associated with this report, for which I also want to thank my colleague Olbrycht and his colleague.  Firstly, this concerns the use of Erasmus and Creative Europe, where we have repeatedly called for processes to be simplified to make these programmes more accessible to those who need them, and in this case, in particular, youth and non-profit organisations, which see significant barriers to absorption there. The second point is the repeated calls for an increase in the limit for investment in cultural heritage from 5 million to 10 million, as is the case with UNESCO monuments. Again, this is a repeated request in this area to leave it to the Member States to decide in the end to apply the limits in their programmes, but not to limit investment opportunities above EUR 5 million as is the case today. It is the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework that is a good opportunity for this appeal.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, in the current political and economic context, the multiannual financial framework is becoming an indispensable milestone in the implementation and maintenance of the European Union's financial budgetary policies. That is why I believe that its main objective must be to intensify cohesion policy. This involves financing the instruments and budget lines leading to greater European integration, reducing development gaps, combating illegalities and supporting new technologies and research. Europe, we, must understand that expectations are very high on the part of the citizens we represent. Young people expect the European Union to solve the problem of unemployment. Entrepreneurs want an incentive budget from us. Local authorities hope for development funds, and seniors want more social protection, while everyone certainly deserves a better life. We need to get out of the shell of bureaucratic rhetoric and show all Europeans that money is being used transparently, constructively but, above all, in their interest. That is why, beyond review and nice words, I expect the European Commission and the Council to wake up and understand that we need to work together and properly fund the European project.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, since 2013 it has been decided that the European Union will spend the total amount of EUR 959 billion for the six years 2014 to 2020. In the case of quantitative easing, Draghi could allocate one and a half trillion euros for quantitative easing within eighteen months. Despite the recession, poverty and armies of the unemployed, the Multiannual Financial Framework provides for only EUR 125.6 billion for the period 2007-2013. EUR 15.6 billion to boost growth in the Member States and, crumbs, only EUR 15.6 billion to support growth in the Member States. In the field of security and citizenship, the amount of the aid was EUR 1 million.  But the scale of the current economic and refugee crisis requires a drastic increase in funds here and now, and of course it requires addressing the problems at their root. Tackling unemployment requires abandoning austerity, the refugee crisis requires restoring peace in the Middle East and immediately launching the relocation of refugees from Greece and Italy to the other Member States of the Union.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Dear President, it is far in 2013 when this multiannual financial framework was adopted. The world had other priorities at the time, Europe dealt with other topics. Today, our priorities have been changed. That's why I stand for two principles. The first principle of flexibility of our budget is because really our priorities today are the migrant crisis, the problems in the agricultural market of agricultural products, the problems we face related to terrorism, but also many other things that have happened in the last few months, even weeks. Of course, I mean Brexit.  On the other hand, the principle of simplification is, especially when it comes to the use of cohesion policy funds. European Union cohesion policy is a successful policy. It has helped many countries, especially the new members of the European Union. We need to continue with it, but we should definitely incorporate the principle of simplifying the use of funds into a new policy.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, regardless of the more or less specific aspects that the report rightly points out about the payment gap, instruments and margins of flexibility, the simple truth is that this budget is totally incompatible with the proclaimed objectives of social and territorial cohesion contained in the Treaties.  And this incompatibility stems from two orders of reason: firstly, the amounts fall far short of what is necessary for an effective redistributive policy that allows disadvantaged countries and regions to approach the wealthiest regions. It is also significant that this multiannual budget has declined for the first time in the history of European integration. Secondly, this budget is short because an important part of the resources, which are already scarce, are not directed towards fostering cohesion. A significant part of the budget is today fueling the European Union's repressive and security policies, thereby removing means that should be directed to cohesion objectives or to supporting farmers who are victims of the European Union's external policies.  We want more means, but we demand that these means be put at the service of a distributive policy that attenuates asymmetries and revitalises cohesion.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – So, a multiannual financial plan can also be a very risky instrument, especially if it is not flexible enough and does not offer sufficient possibilities for simple procedures. Particular emphasis must, of course, be placed on europe having changed significantly in recent years, that the ratio of revenue to expenditure is also changing, and that it is important to remember, of course, that there are also events that will increase expenditure on the budget. The refugee wave has certainly not stopped yet and we can expect perhaps an even more high wave of this issue in the coming years. New fronts are opening up, which will be further complicated by Brexit, of course. Even some of the reforms that have been implemented have clearly not given sufficient results. The unemployment rate is rising somewhere, of course, somewhere. But I think colleagues are right to say that radical reforms will be needed. And there are also some expenditures that are in the area of sanctions against Russia, which will also increase expenditure in the field of agriculture. Of course, above all, emphasis should also be placed on the revenue side.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteurs. I think a great deal of work has been done, especially in anticipation, by the time we have this review of the Multiannual Financial Framework. I think it is a multiannual financial framework that was already known in advance that it was going to be insufficient, even if we have new challenges. We have new challenges, but it was in advance insufficient, and I want to make the importance of maintaining CAP money, which is maintained by current needs, seen - it is reflected in the report. We have an agricultural crisis in which new issues have an impact. For example, the political interests of the European Union are affecting and impacting the agricultural economy. So, I think that's the way. Heading 2 has been saved in this report, but I am also concerned about other aspects of this heading which do not definitively address the need for more revenue, more investment and more coherence in European policies.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Madam Vice-President, it seems that in recent years, especially in the last ten years, the European Union has faced its most serious series of crises. First the financial crisis, then the debt crisis in Greece, then the migration crisis, and now Brexit. However, any crisis is an opportunity that we need to take advantage of, and I should not stress how difficult it is because people do not expect this from us. But the review of the Multiannual Financial Framework is one of the necessary reforms. And if I have to use the language of programmers, I will say that our software is outdated and we need an urgent update. And when it comes to hundreds of billions of euros, this task must be central to us. I'd like to see three successes in the coming years. The first is real reform of own revenue. The Monty Group to provide us with workable solutions, to choose the best of them and to ensure security for the budget. The second is genuine synergies, whether it's operational programmes or Horizon 2020, combining funding to make it easier to achieve results.  Finally, simpleification – less bureaucracy, less administration to achieve projects faster. Finally, as climbers walk their own way up the road before ingesting the flag, so we have to do so.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Dear President, I greet Commissioner Georgieva and congratulate my rapporteurs on my colleague Jan Olbrycht and my colleague Isabelle Thomas. The revision of the multiannual framework is a process in which we ask ourselves whether we are actually achieving our goals at EU level and whether the existing allocation of funds corresponds to the challenges we have faced. Our goals are clear: higher employment, higher population education, social inclusion, poverty reduction, uniform development, innovation and technological development, digitalisation, higher investment, strengthening entrepreneurship, etc.  The new challenges we need to respond to are also clear and highlighted in the report: migration, terrorism, soaring youth unemployment, the crisis in agriculture. How to meet growing needs with existing sources of funds? In my view, the answer is not to increase our own revenues or reduce national envelopes. The answer is in greater synergy between the different instruments we implement through the multiannual framework. The answer is also in greater unity and linking to national budgets so that the European budget can add value in addressing national and common European challenges.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, many thanks to all those who have taken part in a very serious debate today. I have listened very carefully and I want to start from the recognition that came from many of you that we have a new budget for a reason, and the reason is that in the EU we have invented one of the best achievements of the 20th century, the convergence engine that enables us to lift up regions and countries that are falling behind and , in so doing, to  benefit everybody. We do that with the internal market, but of course the budget is the fuel for this convergence engine. For it to work we have to make sure that we spend our money carefully so that we can get the highest impact. Let me sum up some of the key messages that I have got from the debate today.  First, there is a very clear recognition that the world is changing, but our budget has not been designed to offer the necessary flexibility. We have to use the mid-term review to see how we can do better in terms of aligning the budget with the priorities in a fast-moving world. Secondly, we recognise that, when it comes to that alignment, there are certain priorities that we have to concentrate on, as otherwise our citizens would not forgive us: how can we get more jobs, especially for our young people; how can we get more innovation to generate SMEs that push Europe forward in competitive terms; how can we get a more hopeful, youthful Europe, without which, I think, we would all be very depressed. I have listened to the conversation here and it is a bit depressing, if we are to be very honest with ourselves, so we have to concentrate on ways of using the budget to lift up our Europe, especially the young people of Europe.  Secondly, how do we deal with the migration crisis? It is going to be with us. It moves from one place to another, but in a world that is, unfortunately, so severely undermined by conflicts and violent extremism, given the geography which we have in Europe there are no walls that can be built to stop the flow of people. Of course we have to protect our borders better. We also have to find more equitable, fairer, and more dignified ways to accommodate the migrants flowing into Europe.  Thirdly, there is a very clear desire for our budget also to play the role of flag-bearer in addressing great global challenges such as climate action. If we are not strong on that front we would be undermined all because of the extreme weather that comes with unmitigated climate change. And the good news is that we have achieved over 20%: 20.3% of the budget is to be spent on climate action. Of course, we have to do more. The same applies to our role internationally when it comes to dealing with conflicts and the stabilisation of fragile countries. So in your next very clear message you turn to us and say look, we have all these demands. Prioritise. We will need your help to prioritise. Given the limitations of the budget, not everything can be funded on an equal footing. There are old priorities and new priorities. We will have to be very disciplined in aligning our budget with them.  Looking to the future, we will have to modernise the budget significantly, and modernisation is not only on the expenditure side. I want to thank Mr Arthuis for reminding us that we have to sort it out and be more systematic. There also has to be modernisation on the revenue side. Obviously the Monti Group is there to help us, and we have to have the guts to come up with proposals that give us a modern budget.  Last but not least, the budget also has to be modern in terms of the rules and procedures that we apply for the use of money and it has to be simplified. In the past every effort to simplify things would start out with great ambition, and then we would all come along, – including, with all due respect, Members of Parliament – and add our bells and whistles so that by the time we were done, things, instead of being simple, had been made more complex. We have a unique opportunity. In the next six months we need to dedicate ourselves to making best use of this opportunity to have a modern budget that serves us to the utmost. I look forward to our cooperation in these next months.

name: Jan Olbrycht
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for This debate has shown that the conversation is not just about money, it is about politics, and there are a few conclusions. First, it's a conversation about what we're supposed to do together and what we're not supposed to do together – it's kind of the first and crucial thing. Secondly, we are thus starting a debate on the next post-2020 perspective. Thirdly, we must have a budget flexible enough that there is no need for another revision. If the British Government notified, we will have to revise the framework in two years' time. That is what we need to be prepared for.  I would like to take this opportunity to thank my co-rapporteur very much: not only have we ensured cross-party cooperation and gender balance, but also mutual trust in work. I would like to thank my colleagues, advisers, the Chairman of the Committee on Budgets and the Commissioner for their openness. Relations between Parliament and the Commission are not always so open. I hope this is a signal for the future. So thank you very much and please accept that this is not our last word, we are just starting work on the revision and we are waiting for the movement on your part.

name: Isabelle Thomas
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the colleagues for their support and the Vice-President of the Commission for listening. If I take the four points that seemed to me to echo among colleagues, I would say, first, Madam Vice-President, that there is a large majority here in favour of a revision, not a technical adjustment. This is the time because the multi-year financial framework is obsolete, and because the historical situation dictates it. Second point: as you have seen, Madam Vice-President, the new financial tools - I hope this is not what you call 'modernisation', are a bit of a concern for Parliament, not just for reasons of democratic control - although I thank you for the proposal to invite Parliament to sit or put its nose, at least, in these funds , but also because we do not want to change the budget into a guarantee fund. , and we will be very careful about that. Third, we do have a new deal, namely the departure of the United Kingdom. I asked President Juncker this morning for the Commission to quickly assess the budgetary implications of the UK's departure, cheque and rebates, because there is also the issue of rebates that we talked about in the report. Fourth point: the causes. As many colleagues have said, the causes of the problem are in the structure of budgetary resources. Twenty years ago, we had a budget of 75% of our own resources and 25% of contributions from the Member States. Today, more than 80% of the budget comes from Member States' contributions and less than 20% from own resources. This is a huge undertaking here, Commissioner, which we really want to open up in parallel with these discussions, because we are only at the beginning of a great story between us, that of the fundamental overhaul of the budget of the multi-year financial framework and the own resources that will finally allow us, at the end of each year, not to be beggars vis-à-vis the Council.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Parliament's Committee on Budgets adopted only last week its report on the mid-term review of the current seven-year framework, in view of the British referendum, before the European Commission's proposal. It is a success that, in order to protect cohesion funds and rural development funds, the text underlines that the reduction of the resources previously allocated to Member States is legally excluded from the review and adds that direct payments under the Common Agricultural Policy should not be affected by the process. This has ensured that the EU tender resources raised by the current Hungarian Government cannot be reduced and supported by Hungarian farmers is not reduced and secured by the review. The report proposes to raise the ceilings for payment levels in order to avoid a 'liquidity' problem in the previous financial framework, i.e. sufficient resources to pay the cohesion accounts received at the end of the cycle. Unfortunately, it must be highlighted that, despite the opposition of the Members of the People's Party in the committee vote, another delusion of a failed socialist-liberal immigration policy, eerily similar to the proposals made by George Soros, prevailed. The Socialists and Liberals would introduce a bonus-malus mechanism that would impose financial penalties on Member States that do not accept immigrants on the basis of the quota imposed on them.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – The report contains many proposals that I support, such as financial allocations for agriculture. However, there are also proposals that I will not support, because they disadvantage the less developed Member States in the EU, such as Romania. Thus, I do not agree with the allocation of immigrants on the basis of mandatory quotas and, consequently, also with the proposed system of financial penalties for those who do not comply with the quotas. I also believe that the Member States should not be penalised by recycling funds from decommitments, but, on the contrary, supported to absorb fully the funds allocated from the EU budget.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the report (A8-0223/2016) by Jeppe Kofod and Michael Theurer, on behalf of the COMMITTEE, on tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect (2016/2038(INI)).

name: Jeppe Kofod
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, if I were to present this report using only four words, they would be these: expose, disclose, punish and protect. In reverse order: we need to protect whistleblowers, we need to punish those who profit so immensely from illegal tax construction, we need automatic and mandatory systems to share and disclose our own data, and we need to expose the shadowy practices of the industry of tax avoidance. The final report of the Tax Rulings Special Committee provides concrete proposals and demands for doing just that.  In the last few years, two events have been absolutely instrumental in our fight against tax evasion and tax havens: LuxLeaks and the Panama Papers. Let me be crystal clear on this point: if it was not for whistleblowers, we would not be gathered here today, and if it was not for the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, the secrecy would have remained and the shadowy business practices would have continued. So to Mr Deltour, Mr Halet and Mr Perrin, I say a clear, warm and heartfelt thank you on behalf of this Parliament and on behalf of taxpayers and citizens across Europe. It is, quite frankly, a disgrace not befitting a modern democracy that two of the three have now been sentenced by a court of law for exposing the crimes of others. This much must be cause for outrage and for real change in Europe. I therefore look to the Commission to come forward with a clear legal framework for the protection of whistleblowers in Europe. I look to the Council to work with Parliament to ensure the swift and efficient adoption and implementation of such new safeguards for whistleblowers. Tax havens should not be able to exist in the year 2016. We know exactly where they are; we know exactly what they are doing; and we know exactly what we, the politicians of Europe, should be doing to stop them. So why don’t we? I want to thank Commissioner Moscovici for his excellent work on the proposal for a common EU list of non—cooperative jurisdictions, the so-called blacklist of tax havens, and it has to come with clear, automatic and substantial sanctions, not only for the countries and territories on the list, but also for the banks, tax advisers and companies who are engaged in unlawful practices in these territories. Europe is an economic superpower, and only together can we bring tax havens to change their ways. Together, we have entered into groundbreaking new agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino and Monaco. Together, as a European Union, we are on the brink of doing away with banking secrecy in Europe. No single European nation, no matter how large, could bring about this change on its own, but together we can – and must – ensure tax justice for European citizens, for developing countries and for small and medium-sized enterprises, who pay on average 30% more in tax than the multinational corporations, and, of course, for the sake of justice and preserving our welfare states in Europe. Transparency and accountability are our most important tools in the fight against tax havens and tax evasion. Today, I am calling for an EU register of beneficial ownership to form the basis of a global register and for the Commission to give serious consideration to the idea of a global register of financial assets. These two proposals alone will cut to the very heart of the shadowy business of tax havens and tax avoidance. We need to bring them to the table now. Let us do away with our own secrecy in the European Union. For years on end, European progress on curtailing harmful tax practices was slowed – and sometimes even stopped – by some Member States in the Code of Conduct Group. The Code of Conduct Group has for far too long provided a closed forum for the countries of Europe to stall needed new rules and legislation. Let us work together to fundamentally reform the Code of Conduct Group to ensure that it is both efficient, transparent and accountable to the citizens of Europe. Finally, I would like to thank my co-rapporteur, Mr Michael Theurer, for his excellent cooperation and constructive spirit. I want to thank the shadows and Commissioner Moscovici, Commissioner Vestager and Commissioner Hill for their contributions to the Special Committee, and I also want to give special thanks to my good colleagues in the Tax Rulings Special Committee for their excellent work. I look forward to the debate.  (Applause)

name: Michael Theurer
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner Moscovici, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Moscovici, for the work she has been on Against enormous opposition, the TAXE Committee has won access to internal documents of the EU Commission and the Group on Code of Conduct of the Member States for this Parliament. This confidential document was first taken to a secret reading room here in Parliament, and we have shown that we are handling these documents responsibly. However, some of these documents are still withheld from us, and this House must not accept this uncontested. Against enormous resistance, we have managed to ensure that representatives of large international companies, banks and tax advisory firms have come to our committee, and that ministers and secretaries of state, Commissioners and the President of the Commission have also answered us. We have gained important insights from this. Some evasive answers, however, have raised completely new questions, which we have also taken up. Two key findings characterise the report. On the one hand, the combination of 28 partly over-complex national tax systems leads to tax loopholes that can and have been used in particular by internationally active multinationals. Secondly, as the documents show, the Member States have been dealing with these problems for years. In other words, the ministers, including the experts, have been discussing these issues behind closed doors for years and have not come to a solution. No, it was not the European Parliament that prevented the Member States from doing so, nor did the Commission prevent them from doing so, but they were not in a position to allow the conflicts to be constructively incorporated into common legislation and to resolve them. There is therefore a considerable need for action. Experts estimate that the global treasury is missing out on more than €200 million through aggressive tax avoidance. Tax justice is one thing, fair conditions of competition are the other. This is particularly important to us as liberals. It cannot be the case that the pastry chef in Strasbourg or Karlsruhe pays his taxes, but international chains and corporations do not. The outlines of the new tax architecture are now becoming apparent. The foundation must be a common corporate tax base in order to stop the manipulation of the tax base. This will create competition over tax rates and no longer on the tax base. We need an automatic exchange of information, which is now law. We are proposing a study centre which will finally deal scientifically with a comparative analysis of EU tax systems in order to propose a consistent policy. And we demand a guarantee that every profit that leaves the EU will be taxed at least once. This means that we need a regime for double taxation agreements, so that double zero taxation and double non-taxation are no longer possible in the future. This would be possible, for example, through a single withholding tax regime. We also want a code of conduct for tax consultancy companies, and what is very important is that this approach is to be brought to a global breakthrough. Here we want reciprocity towards the United States as well. It is not acceptable for us to provide tax data to the United States, but to receive none from there. Nor is it okay for constructions to be possible in Delaware, for example, that are otherwise only suspected in tax havens. Another proposal is a register for the beneficial owners. Whether this must be publicly available on the Internet is a question. But it must be accessible in the case of legitimate interest. We believe that country-specific reporting requirements are necessary, at least with regard to the tax authorities, and these tax authorities must also cooperate jointly, perhaps joint audits, at least in Europe. That is what we want. What we do not want is a public tax denunciation. Patent boxes are an issue that the EU must address, including transfer pricing, and transfer pricing must be taken into account. And most importantly, better protection for whistleblowers. The civil courage of Antoine Deltour should have been rewarded and should not have been punished. This report is a milestone. Parliament can build on this and be proud of it. What is at stake now, however, is that it should be poured into concrete legislative proposals by the Commission. There are a number of things on the table, but this must now also be implemented. We need fair tax competition. I would also like to express my sincere thanks to my co-rapporteur Jeppe Kofod and to the chairman of the committee, Alain Lamassoure, the shadow rapporteurs, the Commission and also our son. Employees in the secretariat and group as well as our assistants.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, rapporteurs, ladies and gentlemen, let me first extend my sincere congratulations to the two rapporteurs, Mr Kofod and Mr Theurer, to the special committee TAXE, to its president, Mr Lamassoure, and to all those who have been involved in the drafting of the report, for a work of very high quality. In order to achieve this result, the European Commission and Parliament, I think I can say this, have worked very narrowly and very positively. I myself have participated, on several occasions, in the debates of the TAXE committee. My colleagues, who have been quoted, Commissioners Vestager and Commissioners Vestager, have also appeared before her and our services have cooperated closely and, I believe, effectively. We are in a political context that we cannot ignore, with turbulence that invites us to reflect together on how we respond to the issues most crucial to the European peoples at the political, social and economic levels. This reflection is beginning and it deserves to be deepened, it must be open and take into account the demands and needs of all the citizens of the European Union in their diversity. A specific issue, which keeps coming up in the public debate, is, of course, the need for greater social justice alongside economic growth, and it is inseparable from the question of transparency. I am not suggesting that this is an easy question to solve, but it is a question that we must answer first and that we must answer quickly. It did not prevail, moreover, with the vote of the British. It has been a concern for us for a long time and must remain the red thread of our action.  In a context where the legitimacy of the European Union is being questioned by some, I am convinced that transparency and fiscal justice are essential to restore a pillar of democracy, which is consent to tax. That is why the Commission has identified fairness, particularly in the area of taxation, as one of its main political priorities for its mandate and, with the full support of this Parliament, our work is progressing, I believe it is fair, considerably in pursuing this objective. Let me review some of the key developments in our tax fairness strategy in the months since the creation of TAXE 2; our interaction has already been extremely positive. Some of these actions, in truth, are already direct responses to the recommendations of this Parliament, which have been directly operational, as the rapporteurs have said. First, and this remains an important point in the report we are discussing today, we have made great strides towards what I call the transparency revolution. Following a Commission proposal in January, Member States agreed to automatically exchange tax information on the activities of multinationals. This agreement is based on greater openness and cooperation between the tax authorities, to which we had already contributed last year with the new legislation on tax rulings. The Commission also recognised that tax transparency should extend beyond administrations. I repeat here - for those who have not heard it - that since the first day of my taking office, I am in favour of country-by-country reporting - I say public good. In April, we proposed country-by-country reporting obligations for large multinationals. Your report welcomes these proposals. He would even like, Mr Lamberts, to go further. This proposal is now in the hands of the Council and Parliament. I am sure you will give an ambitious answer. And we presented our latest initiative today to combat unfair tax practices with a proposal that aims to enable tax administrations to access key information on actual beneficiaries and other data that allow for increased vigilance. These are concerns that you have raised, as have the G20 and the G7. In this way, tax authorities will be able to identify and act against those who hide their income and assets in offshore funds, as was the case with the Panama Papers. You can see that we have an immediate answer to the problems that are raised. We also announced that we would work across borders to expand tax authorities' access to information on actual beneficiaries, and to work towards greater control and better accountability of a profession, namely tax advisors, some of whom, not all of them, allow or encourage tax evasion. Again, these are proposals that I had already made in this Chamber a long time ago. We therefore have other projects to come to ensure greater transparency, in line with the recommendations of your report, which I would say are entirely in line with our priorities - which are my own. Secondly, and on this point too we agree, we have put in place new concrete measures to ensure that companies pay their taxes where they make their profits, a fundamental measure in tax justice - a whole debate that has taken place in the Council on minimum taxation, but this is not about that. , it is effective taxation. In January, the Commission proposed an ambitious directive on tax evasion to end certain loopholes, certain schemes used by some companies to evade tax. I am pleased that less than six months later the Council has reached political agreement on most of the Commission's proposal for a directive. These new rules, once implemented, will deal a blow, a severe blow, to aggressive tax planning in Europe and will allow us to go one step further, towards fair taxation in the European Union. I am not going to argue here that this directive is sufficient or perfect. I am well aware that the TAXE Committee and this Parliament expect more, and I also know that the Commission's proposal was, as is often the case, a little more ambitious than what was decided by the Member States, finally, but again, I believe that we have a good quality compromise, to which the Commission has joined. I will spare no effort to achieve the results you expect. For example, as requested in your report, we will strengthen measures to combat tax evasion later this year, with a proposal to combat hybrid schemes with third countries. We will, of course, as you ask in your report, relaunch the CSTA, the proposed consolidated common corporate tax base, before the end of the year, to make it mandatory for large multinationals. This will create a more favourable and fair tax environment for all businesses in the European Union. This is obviously a fundamental structural measure. I note that the adoption of tax measures, when it comes to combating tax evasion, has nevertheless had a tremendous acceleration effect. It took several years, and again, to pass tax guidelines in the Council, given the unanimity rule. With the high pressure of events, it now takes a few months, as you can see. I hope that this acceleration will also manifest itself when we propose measures that have a structural, long-term structural effect, as is the case with the ICCT. We have failed in the past on this point. We will take it up again in a slightly different way, but I want to tell you the interest, and even the importance, that I attach to this proposal. Third, we continued our work to expand good tax governance globally. On this last point too, the objectives of the Commission and those of Parliament are the same, or very close. Our initiatives to combat tax evasion include a new external strategy to encourage good governance in the tax field, beyond the single market, and to combat countries that do not respect the rules. A central element of this strategy is to draw up a common list of the European Union listing non-cooperative third countries - let us say it in French, but this is understandable in other languages - that is, a pan-European blacklist of tax havens, and also to provide counter-measures, an idea which I know has the approval of the TAXE Committee. We have already embarked on this process of drafting lists with the Member States and, contrary to what was the case in the past, a still recent past - I had proposed a first list, whose limits were obvious to me, but which had the merit of existing a year ago, however things have changed a lot - I note that the Member States fully support this project and I want to tell you that the first list of the European Union must be ready in 2017. This will be a major step and built in articulation with the OECD. I believe that this measure will have a major deterrent effect on third countries that believe they are in a position to to take advantage of the erosion of other countries' tax bases. Of course, the need for efficiency and fiscal justice does not stop at the borders of the European Union. That is why, as part of our external strategy, we place a strong emphasis on supporting developing countries to combat tax evasion and integrate them into the network of good international tax governance. It's not just the G20 countries, it's the whole world.  In The Addis Ababa Tax Initiative, we have committed to doubling our support to low-income countries to help them improve their tax collection. We will keep that commitment and go further, providing full political support to these countries within the OECD and other international organizations. My services have also engaged in discussions with Member States and stakeholders on how to prevent EU and national tax policies from having a negative impact on developing countries. It is, I know, a shared concern on all your benches. Ladies and gentlemen of the European Parliament, I have outlined today the outlines of the work we are doing to ensure fairer and more effective taxation in the European Union, in line with the expectations of our fellow citizens and certain recommendations - the essence of your report. I have been able to cover all of these recommendations, because this report is very comprehensive, but I remain of course prepared to discuss them with you. The strong political pressure of Parliament as a whole, through the TAXE 1, TAXE 2, and I do not forget ECON, because there has been a common work, again, of very high quality, has contributed greatly to the progress made. Our program, my program, continues and it addresses many other areas that you have mentioned, from improving transfer pricing to strengthening good governance clauses in the case of our international agreements. We have a clear public, political mandate to encourage Member States to implement the measures agreed upon, through a swift and ambitious agreement on these initiatives. This has come out, I believe, very strongly from the popular indignation that has not subsided following the publication of the Panama Papers and also from other scandals covered by the media which, in this case, are allies. There is a real demand from citizens, at the European Union level, to strengthen social justice, to improve transparency and to go through with transparency within the framework of an economic and fiscal policy. I am therefore pleased to continue this work, happy to do so in close partnership with the European Parliament to achieve fairer taxation in Europe as our fellow citizens expect, and to this extent I am also very pleased to welcome this report as an important step in our common struggle.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I think that both Tax Committee reports proved that matters relating to tax rulings cover a wide range of issues, from the tax rulings themselves and administrative practices to the protection of whistle-blowers, to beneficial ownership, to tax competition and state aid. The issue is central also because of the amount of funds involved in tax dodging and the impact on growth fairness. But what makes this issue even more complex and specific is its cross—border dimension. Tax dodging thrives on the mismatches between systems and the lack of cross—border cooperation. Unilateral actions to fight it can create unwanted competitive distortions that are harmful for law-abiding businesses. Therefore, when addressing tax avoidance and evasion, it is important that we act in compliance with global standards and achieve a high level of international cooperation.  On all issues covered by the OECD BEPS Action Plan, we really need to have all countries on board, because there are rules that are likely to influence the location of business activities worldwide. And last but not least, when we – as the European Union –plan to go further than the OECD, we must make sure that our ambition is not to depart from those recommendations, but to build upon them. Commissioner, just to end, I would like to tell you that to ensure a follow-up to our report we count on you, and you know very well that your presentation was proof that there are still many things to fix to give our citizens fairer taxation.

name: Peter Simon
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I too would like to begin by thanking our two rapporteurs, Kofod and Theurer, as well as our chairman Alain Lamassoure, very warmly for their work. The climate in this committee has shown that we are pulling together across party lines when it comes to promoting tax justice in Europe. I would like to thank the Commission, Commissioner Moscovici in particular, for the fact that our work here has also been reflected in the Commission's work and that Parliament and the Commission are all pulling together here. But the work in the TAX Committee, as in the TAX 2 Committee, has shown that without the pressure that we have been under with the public over the last year and a half, Member States would never have been prepared to go as far as they are now prepared to go in the current legislative process. But that is not far enough! Because the proposals that the Commission has put forward are being watered down by the Member States – and we are already seeing this now. So it is up to us not only to maintain this pressure, but to increase it. That is why it was important, and it was right, that we, together with the Panama Investigation Committee, have now given ourselves another body here in this House with which we can continue to exert pressure to be able to take stronger action against state-organised tax dumping, but also against money laundering, than has been the case in the past. We can all say today: Commissioner Moscovici, Parliament here is fully behind the work for more tax justice in Europe, for greater transparency, for fairer corporate taxation, but also for strengthening the fight against money laundering. We will maintain this in the Panama Committee of Inquiry, but also in our regular work in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of this House. In the past, we have shown, with the reports by Mr Bayet and Mr Dodds, that we are willing to make legislative progress here as well. This will not decrease in the future, but will increase.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), "blue card" question. Madam President, we have said this many times. We agree with tax transparency, we agree on fair tax competition, we agree to run over those real tax havens. But I believe, with the intense overzealousness shown, that in the end the European Union will destroy its own financial centres and lead all companies, both domestic and foreign, to other tax regions and to other countries, in which the European Union will not be able to exercise any control. We are in favour of fair taxation and fair taxation as well as social justice. But for all this to happen, there have to be companies. If all these companies can't be taxed and they leave our own countries, and so we give them to countries outside the European Union, at the end of the day, all we're going to do is talk about blacklists, it's...  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Peter Simon (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Dear colleague, I am sure that we will actually destroy something. However, it is not the economic activity of companies, but we will put a dent in individual business models of states that enrich themselves here at the expense of other states. We will not allow state-organised tax dumping to continue in Europe as it has been in the past, and then individual states will have to rethink. I am sure that we in this House, among the citizens of Europe, will get a clear majority for this: because it is not acceptable for individual states to ensure that they receive a little, but the majority of the Member States do not have at all the taxes that every company has to pay. We will make progress on this. I do not believe that we will jeopardise companies as such.

name: Bernd Lucke
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We have here a report dealing with the LuxLeaks scandal. However, we must state quite clearly that this is not a scandal, but a whole series of scandals. This is very good to read from the report, and so I am very grateful to the two rapporteurs for the fact that this has been worked out so well. Scandal number one is this: multinational companies do not necessarily pay the appropriate tax burden that corresponds to their capacity. This is a slap in the face to the honest taxpayer who is doing just that, and it is a significant distortion of competition with those companies that do not have these opportunities or that are simply decent enough to pay their taxes as intended. We have developed some measures against this, which are very good. Some people are, to be honest, also in such a way that one thinks: well-meaning is not always equally well done. In essence, however, what has been proposed in this report is a good thing. Scandal number two, however, is that states are also helping with this practice. Some countries in the world, some states in the European Union, are helping businesses, they are actually encouraging them to pursue this tax avoidance strategy. Far too little attention has been paid to this fact, at least in the public debate. We must make this quite clear: it is good that we are committed to having a blacklist of tax havens, and we must tell everyone that the tax havens are not only found in the Cayman Islands and the British Virgin Islands, but that they are also found in the heart of Europe, for example in the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. All this must be made clear. Scandal number three, after all, is that states knew this. The member states of the European Union have known for a long time what practice exists here. They have covered it up by talking about it behind closed doors in the Code of Conduct group, but they have kept all their knowledge secret and tried to sort this out in some way behind closed doors. It didn't work out. The sparrows whistled it from the rooftops that there was this tax avoidance, and tax evasion. Scandal number four: the people who have now brought this into the public eye – the whistleblowers – have been brought to justice and sentenced to prison. The people who have done the tax avoidance go out freely. They still have the benefits of their tax avoidance. But the whistleblowers are put in jail. That cannot be the case, and it is good that the European Parliament is sending out a strong signal against this.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to start with another thank you, thanks to colleagues Mrs Theurer and Mr Kofod. Admittedly, it was in my childhood adventure books that a "crowbar" was an instrument of criminal activity. In Parliament today, Kofod is an instrument of lawful activities, um es nicht "teurer" zu machen.  Today, just in these minutes, the Commission has come out with a proposal to renew the Money Laundering Directive. It is, of course, no coincidence. We saw in the context of the Panama Papers that the Money Laundering Directive in particular has a huge hole in it, even though we tried at the previous stage to correct this. The essence of the work we did at the time is really about what is called "beneficial ownership", i.e. the real owner. Beneficial is translated into Swedish to charity. In this case, it's not about charity. It is a question of building in the mazes of tax evasion various shell companies that make it impossible to follow where the tax money disappears.  During the review we carried out at the time, it turned out that the big problem was really britain's beneficial ownership. The structures of various foundations that Britain has built over the centuries. We know that this is one of the fundamental elements of the whole system of tax avoidance that exists in the world. For this reason, I think we can say today that we are going to turn Brexit into Taxit.

name: Miguel Viegas
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, the extent of tax evasion and tax evasion is too well known. The two TAXE committees 1 and 2 confirmed this breadth and confirmed that this is a widespread practice throughout Europe and in all capitalist economies.  The report points out several highly relevant aspects, but it does not go to the bottom of the problem, because all these assemblies that provide authentic tax banquets do not happen by chance, they happen because of a long process of financial deregulation, which has increased since the 1980s and which has been led by governments and parties present in this House today. Let the Dutch, UK or Luxembourg governments say so.  We therefore do not fully monitor this report because it exonerated the capitalist system that promotes the free movement of capital and financial liberalisation and promotes tax evasion. We therefore believe that an effective fight against fraud and tax evasion implies public control of the financial system and restrictions on the movement of capital. Relying so only on the regulatory path shows that we learn nothing from the past. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, I will be very brief. On some points, I share the opinion of our colleague but since, unless I am mistaken, he is a Portuguese national, I would just like to question him, out of curiosity, on a point. The Government of Portugal, at present, unless I am mistaken, proposes to exempt pensioners, and even very well-stocked pensioners, from income tax, other nationalities who would come to settle on its territory for at least ten years. I would like to know what Mr Viegas thinks of this measure.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – (2) I can only answer for the position of my party, the Portuguese Communist Party, which has been fighting in Portugal against tax havens and against, inter alia, the tax haven that also exists in Portugal, similar to the majority of European countries, and which is located on the island of Madeira.  Therefore, our fight is against tax evasion, inside and outside Portugal, in a consistent and coherent manner.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on the subject of fraud and tax evasion: tax injustice is not the product of a physical, chemical or natural phenomenon. It is the product of political choices and, if it is the product of political choices, which some have chosen to do, others may choose to undo it. I would like to rejoice, in any case, at the strength of the report which was adopted by the TAXE 2 Committee and to pay tribute to Michael Theurer and Jeppe Kofod for having really produced an excellent report. I think this report, indeed, is moving in the right direction. I am also pleased to see that Commissioner Moscovici, on behalf of the Commission, is in tune with this report. But then, where is the error? If there is a large majority here to fight tax injustice, how is it that it actually persists? In fact, I have a clue: it is the requests for amendments to the report that we will adopt tomorrow, and in particular the requests for amendments that come from the largest group in this House, the EPP, which does not want to be appointed Member States, because - Bernd Lucke said - there are many Member States, including my country, which are tax havens and are actively involved in this unworthy tax competition. Ah, can't we name them? Nor does the EPP want us to denounce the role of audit and tax advisory firms, and to appoint them. Oh no, that's not to be talked about. Here, why don't we talk about it? They would have no role to play? The same group does not want us to protect whistleblowers, at least with ambition. We must reduce the ambition to protect whistleblowers, or there is no question, as the report calls for, of banning this new vehicle of tax evasion called patent boxes or patent boxes. We propose that they be banned from 2021, but there are some here, especially in the EPP, who say, "Oh no, all in all, maybe we should leave them." We are at the point of denial of reality where even statistics on inward and outward financial flows from countries such as Luxembourg and the Netherlands are a secret that should not be revealed in our report, because obviously this indicates, perhaps, that these countries have become large-scale financial washing machines. So I am speaking to EPP colleagues: but do you really want to fight fraud and tax evasion, or do you want to look like you are fighting fraud and tax evasion? Because, of course, it is not very popular to charge small taxpayers, whether they are individuals or businesses. That, of course, is the question I am asking you. Quite honestly, I was extremely disappointed to find that, in all respects, the first resistance came from the largest group in this House. I am not talking, of course, about the council seats which are perpetually empty. As you know, heads of state or government and finance ministers do not seem to have much to do with what we are saying here in this House.

name: Marco Zanni
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the text that has emerged from the work of the TAXE Committee is certainly to be welcomed. This must be noted by the two co-rapporteurs, especially for having included a key point, in my opinion, namely the role of banks in favouring tax evasion and avoidance schemes. Unfortunately, however, on this occasion too, it has been decided not to clearly indicate the political responsibilities of individuals and countries involved in practices that are harmful to the community. Those of us who have been able to view the confidential documents have been confirmed by which Member States were blocking the different initiatives, and these nations are linked to the personalities who are now leading the EU institutions. We are obliged by confidentiality constraints on documents that citizens should be able to see in order to understand the credibility of some European politicians. If we have nothing to hide, let us make these documents public and let everyone take responsibility.  I also find it absurd that we did not want to listen once again to Mr Juncker, on whom there was a shadow linked to the Krecké report, and unfortunately we did not want to go all the way, with a real confrontation. Our difficulties in accessing documents, the fact that some have even been lost, by the Commission's own admission, show even more clearly that transparency is the key to everything.  That is why, in my opinion, all measures, although fair, will always be ineffective if all information is not made public and accessible to all citizens.

name: Bernard Monot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the vote in this report of the TAXE 2 committee reminds us that the issue of tax justice is at the heart of any social project. Each rule of law has a duty to combat the abuses of tax optimisation by multinationals. It is no longer possible, in a world of inequality, mass unemployment and growing precariousness, to allow a haemorrhage of budgetary revenues to escape the states. The tax shortfall in France, which has been cut off by large companies, has amounted to more than 15 billion euros per year for nearly two decades. It is detrimental to our public finances. This lack of fiscal resources must be compensated in order to balance the annual budget with your policy of austerity and structural reforms, which the European Commission has, and which all Europeans see the result in Greece. We are a long way from your Europe of prosperity and full employment, which your propaganda boasted to us in 1992 during the Maastricht referendum. Those who suffer the consequences are other taxpayers, small domestic businesses and households, hence their loss of competitiveness and purchasing power. I recall that, since 2014, the National Front has voted all European texts to combat bank secrecy, fraud, evasion and abusive tax optimisation. In the French Parliament, MEPs voted in favour of the law on the transparency of political life in the wake of the Cahuzac case. That is why we will still vote for this report on international European cooperation. The patriots are in favour of tax legislation at European level, but on the condition of unanimity of the states and the maintenance of our fiscal sovereignty intact. Luxembourg, the Netherlands and other countries, under the leadership of their complicit leaders, such as Mr Juncker, have set up and developed lax regimes for unscrupulous multinationals. For patriots, this tax and unfair dumping constitutes an economic crime against peoples. If Mr Juncker had a modicum of honour, he would resign from his current position. Patriotic ethics says yes to tax competitiveness, but not to tax dumping.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Madam President, the picture of tax havens is half that. In the one trillion euros of illegal tax evasion, add many billions of legal tax evasion, i.e. tax exemptions, corporate subsidies from EU and national development laws, such as the last of the Greek government, which the people pay with an explosion of taxes. They will go and no matter how much you save from tax havens.  Sell the fairy tale of fair growth, a fair European Union, without tax havens after Brexit. It doesn't exist! Only, fair, as you say, competition for redistribution of wealth with injustice always at the expense of the people. You cannot remove the DNA of capitalism, i.e. the expansion of poverty by a concentration of wealth, which has no homeland, especially in the Union of its free movement.  Heaven is not the cause, but the result. Finally, you hide the great scandal: either taxed or tax-free wealth is sweat stolen from the only real producers, the workers, who have to take it back into their own hands.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: Madam President, as Chairman of the TAXE 2 Committee, I would like to congratulate our rapporteurs, thank our administrative team and commend the work done by the European Commission, the Commissioner and Parliament on the taxation of businesses. It took the LuxLeaks scandal, but in 18 months, on this subject, we have made more progress than in the previous 18 years, in particular - the Commissioner has given the list - on the exchange of information between tax administrations, including on rulings, on the transparency of the accounts of multinationals, on the adoption of OECD rules based on a simple principle - every multinational company must pay its taxes in each country in proportion to its activities in the country in question - and on the adoption of OECD rules based on a simple principle on the protection of whistleblowers - the conviction that took place a few days ago in Luxembourg must be the last. The next fundamental project will be the harmonization of the definition of taxable profit, the ACCIS, to 27. These results could not have been achieved without the obstinacy of the European Commission and the constant pressure of Parliament, which has thus relayed the expectations of the citizens. In an area where we have no legal competence, I am proud that the European Parliament has been able to emerge as a key partner for our national parliaments, for the United States Congress and for the OECD, among others. It will be necessary to ensure that this new political status of the European Parliament is maintained in this essential area.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I greet co-rapporteurs Kofod and Theurer for this report by the TAXE 2 Committee, which shows that the European Parliament has acted in the face of the Luxleaks scandal and is at the forefront of combating tax fraud, tax evasion and avoidance. We want justice and transparency to reverse the disastrous consensus of financial deregulation and fiscal competition of the last twenty years, which has accentuated divergences between Member States and unbearable economic and social distortions. Beleagueresed by ultra-liberal austerity, citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises are most punished by europe's opaque tax jungle, disproportionately bearing the tax burden. We do not conform to an internal market that cannot ensure fair competition without a minimum of tax harmonisation and which cannot continue to tolerate patent boxes and other State aid, which is immorally given to multinationals in schemes to avoid paying taxes. The Commission and the Council cannot take long to put into practice our recommendations in this report, from country-by-country public reports, to the common consolidated basis of taxation, to the protection of whistleblowers and to sanctions for any facilitators of tax dumping schemes, including confiscation of proceeds. We must stop attacking democracy and the European project with policies and practices that accentuate injustice and inequalities and therefore trigger understandable revolt in our citizens. As Commissioner Moscovici, who I welcome for his interaction with the TAXE 2 Commission, pointed out, this is an essential issue of democracy in our Member States and in Europe.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, without whistleblowers, we would not have the TAXE 2 report. Without courageous individuals such as Antoine Deltour, we would not necessarily have ever heard of secret tax treaties between Luxembourg and large international companies. Without the Panama Papers leak, we would not have set up a new PANA committee of inquiry in Parliament, and tax evasion would continue as before.  Then how do we treat these informants? Deltour was sentenced last week to one year of conditional imprisonment in a Luxembourg court. This isn't right. Whistleblowers should be protected and rewarded, not prosecuted and convicted. One effective way to protect them is to provide the possibility of anonymous whistlebdent. Mere knowledge of this possibility curbs corruption.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the Luxleaks scandal was not exactly a novelty, it simply made more evident what we all knew: an economic zone with free movement of capital and different tax jurisdictions is an invitation to tax dumping. But it is a tax dump on the incomes of large companies, of course, because citizens, these, not only benefit at all, but are still called to compensate for the loss of revenue caused by fraud and the evasion of those who were able to escape. Some path has already been made and this report has many positive aspects. However, on European responsibilities, it maintains serious limitations. What is planned draws little lessons on this scandal and, overall, the European Commission is just waiting for the thing to go to get back into the usual politics. It is the usual policy in which a Europe that not only does not fight, but encourages tax evasion, by tied to the hands of Member States that want to collect taxes owed to them and allowing others to steal revenue that does not belong to them.
