Thus - I will end, Madam President - the European Commission is directly responsible for subtracting legitimate tax revenue, with negative consequences on the public accounts and deficits of the Member States. And why is the European Commission not called to account? Because it's the European Commission.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I will thank you for the very good cooperation that has been ours. We have been successful in making our demand for transparency heard. Of course, the result is mixed in terms of access to documents, but this should encourage us to continue, with the forthness of the Commission of Inquiry to come, the tussle with the Member States which have played so little, especially as it must be said, the LuxLeaks scandal is not yet behind us. The trial and the valuable information of the second whistleblower, Raphael Halet, revealed the dubious links forged between the Big Four and the Luxembourg tax administration.  We don't know everything yet. This article in the newspaper Le Quotidien informed us last Wednesday that for several years PriceWaterhouseCoopers had been able to use letterhead of the Luxembourg administration while doing the work of archiving the mountain of tax rulings, and this outside of any contract, thus recalling that the wrong people had been sent back to the Luxembourg courts. Commissioner, what does that inspire you? Are you considering asking the Luxembourg government for more details after this new information?

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, like it or not, if a nation wishes to provide shared public services such as schools, hospitals and security through its armed services and its police, it needs to raise income. It does that through taxation. The people who pay that taxation demand two things: they demand fairness from those who pay the taxation, but they also demand that the governments who spend that money be fiscally responsible. Clearly, my nation has decided to vote to leave the European Union on the basis of the second point. It did not believe that the European Union was fiscally responsible. We want to have a trade arrangement with the European Union because it is in our nation’s interest, and your nations’ interest, to have a thriving global economy that has taxation clearly at its heart. So we say, when you look at this report, do not tax yourself out of competition with the world. You need to have a taxation system that is fair but competitive with the rest of the world. Look into this report, because some of it is going to make Europe less competitive and ultimately drive down your economies, and we don’t want that at all.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Madam President, Mr President, Commissioner Moscovici, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work she has This report contains a number of recommendations aimed at making corporate taxation fairer and more transparent. The rapporteur has today described it as a new architecture for a fairer financial system, based on a common corporate tax base. There are also other proposals, a number of proposals and measures against the misuse of patent boxes: withholding tax regimes, transfer pricing, but also, within the framework of the external strategy, the drawing up of blacklists and the establishment of central lists for beneficial owners of letterbox companies. A number of these points have already been accepted by the Council, and Commissioner Moscovici has also told us today that the first blacklists will be available as early as next year. Every year, the Member States of the European Union lose around EUR 70 billion through aggressive tax planning, and it is therefore high time that this coordination took place. Let's put it into order! We must deliver so that people can once again believe in a fairer tax system, and 75% of all Europeans call for more action to be taken against tax evasion and tax evasion, according to a recent survey. In other words, it is high time that we implemented it quickly.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I think the debate today illustrates how seriously Parliament is taking the problem of tax gaps and the fairness of tax systems. We have good reasons for that. I am pleased that the Commission sees things in a very similar way and also that the key player in this debate, the European Council, is starting to take decisions. We should be proud of the result. In the last few months we have approved many measures, such as exchange of tax rulings, country—by—country reporting and the Anti—Tax Avoidance Directive, and we will have others: the Anti-Money Laundering Directive, automatic exchange of information, and so on. So Parliament is playing a very important role – and we are pleased about that – through the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures Similar in Nature or Effect and through the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. I think this report includes some very important points. I very much appreciate the stress on the improvement of the function of the Code of Conduct Group, as well as the clear link between trade policy and tax policy. But some measures, in my opinion, go beyond a good trade—off between efficiency, cost and fairness. I think we should pay more attention to the difference between tax evasion and tax avoidance. Public and private interests should be balanced better in whistle-blowers legislation, and in some other respects we should consider the cost of the measures proposed. But otherwise I believe that Parliament will keep playing a very important role in improving the tax system in the European Union and also globally.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D).
text: Madam President, I think that the first people we should thank collectively are those ordinary citizens who once took the risk of revealing to the general public totally scandalous practices. They are currently paying the price, while the real offenders - the audit firms we were talking about and the states, because there are states, even in Europe, that behave like thugs - enjoy total impunity. From this point of view, the presentation of the two rapporteurs was important because, in this text, we have a very comprehensive presentation of these aggressive tax optimization practices which are disfiguring Europe and the image of Europe that we now want to present to our fellow citizens. It is true that the report echoes the recommendations of the TAXE 1 report on the consolidated corporate tax base, on country-by-country public reporting , from this point of view, Commissioner Moscovici has helped us a lot from the beginning - or on the reform of the code of conduct, but it is a text that goes beyond that. So, of course, on whistleblowers, there is frustration because the text is insufficient but, nevertheless, especially on the diversion of tax incentives for research, the text is clear, as is the extension of debates to developing countries. I have one regret - but there is a confrontation with the European right, which does not agree - is that you are advocating for tax competition and for social competition, and that we are unable to say today, even though there is a common monetary policy and fiscal policy, that we obviously need a minimum effective rate of corporate tax. , because otherwise there is no equality, because otherwise there is no progress in Europe. It's the fight of tomorrow. This is the fight that some progressives, in any case, will want to wage in the years to come.

name: Fabio De Masi (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Apple, Google or McDonald's often pay less than one percent tax on their profits. Every taxi driver in Strasbourg pays more for hospitals, for schools. At the same time, Europe is groaning under the stupid policy of cuts. The tax tricks of the multinationals are often legal, but they are still criminal. Many of the demands of the TAXE report also bear the signature of the Left Group. Withdrawal of licences for banks that help with tax evasion, withholding taxes on financial flows in tax havens, an end to patent boxes. There is no barrier to artificial licence fees, minimum taxes, and the EU's freedom of movement for capital makes punitive taxes against tax havens more difficult. These are needed just after Brexit, as Downing Street is planning a dirty tax competition. Documents were not supplied by the Commission, and some were allegedly smeared. My group will continue to refer the matter to the Commission in this regard. The report is like a pretty princess who keeps a dark secret: he looks good, but remains silent on the godparents of the tax cartel like EU Commission President Juncker.  My colleague Eva Joly has written a beautiful book about it: Le Loup dans la Bergerie, "The Wolf in Sheep's Fur". But a Luxembourg court convicted the courageous LuxLeaks whistleblower Antoine Deltour. I witnessed him in his trial. We are therefore not finished and will continue to air dirty laundry in the Panama Committee.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, my first words are to pay tribute to Antoine Deltour and Raphael Halet, ordinary citizens, as was said earlier, who have played their professional careers, even their future, in favour of European citizenship.  And what are the consequences? A sentence of twelve months and a fine, which will assume that they have a criminal record, and that will affect the rest of their lives.  It is absolutely intolerable; and I therefore believe that one of the messages we must send in the vote tomorrow is clearly supportive and that we need legislation to protect informants, who do a great public service.  I have to say that from the report leaving the TAXE 2 Commission we have a very good text with many things, including the protection of informants. But - surprise!— today we get the partial votes which the People's Group is asking for, and it wants to eliminate a lot of things: the reference to the European Investment Bank, the responsibility of States, even the reference to the protection of informants.  Gentlemen, is there anything worse than not fighting tax fraud? Make it look like you're fighting tax fraud.  If we take this seriously, leave the text as it is, as we voted in Commission TAXE 2. Don't destroy it in tomorrow's vote.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. At the end of the mandate of the TAXE-2 Committee, it is a matter of taking stock. And what is the balance sheet, what were the findings of our work? Some Member States have become experts in undermining their neighbours' tax bases. Some multinationals have perfected the way Member States play off their tax issues and minimise their tax liability, often legally. The Member States have looked away and not asked. The Commission has tacitly tolerated non-compliance with the obligation to cooperate in the Mutual Assistance Directive. Tax rulings and transfer pricing agreements were the main instruments in this game. Which of these findings are really new? To tell the truth: none. We could read all this in the newspapers more than a year ago, we already knew all this through the LuxLeaks revelations. And how can this meagre gain of knowledge be explained? The Member States did not want us to enlighten. They have put enough obstacles in our way where we could, for example, when accessing relevant documents. However, I would also like to make it quite clear that we have deprived ourselves of an instrument that would have been able to carry out more information here, namely a committee of inquiry. That is why I hope that we can shed more light on the Panama Committee, where we now have a committee of inquiry, and not just rely on dedicated journalists to reveal the lid on the secrets here.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this morning we were talking about the future of Europe. As a result of brexit, everyone wonders what else we have to do, what we have to do better. Well, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we have in the fight against tax evasion, in the fight against tax havens, in the fight against the fact that multinationals do not pay their taxes properly in each country, in the fight against unfair competition between States within the European Union, a unanimous conscience in Europe. There is a total social alarm for Europe to respond to these problems. And there we have a fantastic opportunity for Europe to respond to these problems, being more Europe and doing better Europe. The roadmap marking TAXE 2, along with the one marked by TAXE 1, I think is a well-founded roadmap, which has a large majority, a broad political majority among the large groups of the House. And I think you have to have two fundamental emergencies right now. Firstly, and I say this with pride, Mr Moscovici and the Commission lead the initiative in this area, and we want it to remain so, but we have enormous concern, because the Council often paralyzes initiatives. I would like to claim here that even the reinforced majority - if necessary - be used for this to move forward. Secondly, I would also like to end by claiming a European tax agency. I think it's time to set up a tax agency to lead and direct all policy from Europe on tax matters.

name: Rina Ronja Kari (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President! This report is a clear improvement on the previous one from TAXE 1, in large part because it clearly criticises the European Commission for not handing over the necessary documents. I would therefore like to start by thanking the rapporteurs very much for your hard work. Unfortunately, of course, there are also seen from my chair clear shortcomings. The report does not deal with the problems created by the internal market, which, all else being equal, have created a very good framework for shifting profits from one country to another in order to avoid or reduce tax payments.  We see this in the case against Sweden, among other things. Sweden tried in 2013 to curb tax evasion by limiting interest deductions for internal loans. The Commission is dissatisfied with this and has sent a letter of formal notice. We should have room to criticise this from the European Parliament. At the same time, of course, it is frustrating and frustrating that we still have to take responsibility. Those who exposed the scandals have been convicted in the Court of First Instance, but nothing has happened to those responsible. They still sit confidently and well in their posts and that is deeply frustrating.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the report reaches this House in very good condition, but tomorrow we will see how it holds up the voting session. We already know that there will be those who try to pour water into the wine or simply exchange the wine for water, and for unclear water.  The report shows how business corporations use fiscal optimization strategies, with the necessary cooperation of some Member States – with the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Ireland and Luxembourg at the forefront – and with the collaboration of financial institutions and certain legal-fiscal engineering services that have developed genuine excellence in the trade of large-scale tax avoidance.  But the report does not conform to this and points out necessary avenues of action: corporation tax, country reports, real and shared transparency on final beneficiaries, protection of all the Antoine Deltour to which we owe so much, together with the need for the European Union to regain global leadership on this issue, demanding cooperation and reciprocity from the United States and acting in international institutions.  I hope that all groups that proclaim themselves supporters of fiscal justice and the defence of the general interest will act tomorrow in coherence with this conviction and with a content approved in committee: we will see, tomorrow. And the day after tomorrow, we will see if it is also committed to the European Commission and the Council or it remains, once again, in the complete store of good intentions, of the wishful thinkings that characterize us so much.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Chairman of the committee, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The Committee was successful, although the extension of the TAXE Committee did not bring any significant new findings. We have managed to improve information, increase transparency, increase the protection of whistleblowers, increase the pressure on the review of distortions of competition, and bring millions of tax payments from Google, Amazon and others into the coffers of the European Union. We knew beforehand that the main problem is the lack of cooperation between the Member States on tax matters. We know that the biggest shortcoming is the absence of a European tax law. We have structural problems. Unfortunately, the practices of companies were not illegal, but are the legal exploitation of inconsistencies between national tax systems. We can only get the problem at its roots if we harmonise in Europe what exactly is taxed on companies, if we get a European tax law in Europe, if we get European tax revenues and get more European harmonised tax policy. We are not finished with the work. The start was good.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: I have to say, we are very much behind. It really is a sign on the wall that money going to tax havens has grown twice as fast in the last decade as the savings in the world. And it is a sign on the wall that a third of foreign direct investment is made through financial arrangements in tax havens. We are lagging behind and we need to make up for that distance, all the more so because a new offshore centre is emerging, namely the Uk which now wants to bring down corporate tax rates to 15% and strengthens that tax competition. I would therefore like to see a blacklist for tax havens, but also a framework for the United Nations in which countries constantly agree on tackling tax avoidance involving developing countries. The report by Michael Theurer and Jeppe Kofod is very welcome to catch up. Thank you for that. It also shows that there is a complex of financial institutions, tax advisers contributing to tax avoidance. It needs to be addressed. Financial institutions must lose their licence if they cooperate in transactions that are debatable, but there must also be a code of conduct for tax advisers if they cooperate in structures that are questionable, and there must be an end to the interconnectedness of universities and tax advisers.  And if I read the Commission that 'will shed light' on these activities, that is not enough. We will have to crack down on this industrial complex of tax advisers and financial institutions.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I read the conclusions of the 'LuxLeaks' case. I agree that there is a long way to go for fair tax harmonisation, for the control of payments between subsidiaries, for the disclosure of hidden assets and the tax arrangements of multinationals, for the prohibition of tax evasion. But I wonder: is it possible to close a commission of inquiry without attributing political responsibilities? Why are we still being denied access to documents that would clarify Mr Juncker and Mr Dijsselbloem's involvement in tax evasion? While two journalists, Deltour and Halet, are unfairly convicted of their revelations, the commission has been unable to question the real perpetrators. On the other hand, we have let banks and tax havens come to publicize the legality of their actions. We are faced with systemic fraud, faced with a tax system designed under capital liberalization and tax competition in the European Union, and their governments have encouraged large companies and assets to pay less tax than their workers. Without political responsibilities, without self-criticism, today—once again—we are closing the debate in false.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I again welcome the European Commission's initiative to combat tax evasion, aggressive tax planning. We must recognise, however, here in the European Parliament, that tax evasion would be much lower if individuals and companies had nowhere to hide their income and wealth. The European Commission is committed to publishing the blacklist of tax havens that do not wish to cooperate by passing the necessary information to the countries where these individuals and companies that hide their income and wealth in tax havens. We are waiting for this blacklist and I believe that, in the European Union, all financial transfers to these tax jurisdictions that do not want to become transparent should be taxed.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, during the campaign in my country for the EU referendum, one issue that was raised was tax evasion. People asked ‘Why do I pay an increasing amount of tax while the multinationals pay very little? It is unfair and it is completely unethical. Why does the European Union not deal with this?’ That is why I welcome the proposals in this report, and my congratulations go to the rapporteurs, Jeppe Kofod and Michael Theurer. I especially support the proposals on the need for a clear list of tax havens and for a legal framework to protect whistle-blowers and prevent tax advisers from setting up tax-avoidance structures. We really have to ask the Commission and the Member States to demonstrate, in the forthcoming legislation, the same level of ambition as Parliament has demonstrated. Personal tax, I know, is a Member State competence, and I support that. However, corporation tax avoidance can be addressed only if we work together. Therefore, the onus is on the EU to address this. The issue was strongly misrepresented by the Leave side, claiming that what we were discussing was personal tax. I think it is really important that we explain what we are doing here and that what we are trying to address is what many Europeans feel very angry about, namely that in one state the multinationals exploit lower taxes, while they make all their money in another state. I really welcome these proposals. I hope they will be implemented as soon as possible.

name: Frank Engel (PPE).
text: Madam President, even if the temptation is great, I will refrain from reacting to a number of hate-sized confabulations against a certain Member State that have been uttered this afternoon. I would just like to reiterate a call to Commissioner Moscovici, who, so far, neither at home nor to the Commission, has not found too much success. I wonder why, even at the end of this debate, there is not even a beginning of the will to grant a tax status to European society. It would be a European element of policy that could generate resources for the Community budget, which needs it so much, and it would probably even be a factor of European competitiveness in relation to our global competitors, in this race to attract what is called good French corporate headquarters. I would be very happy if we could perhaps move a little bit in that direction.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Since the Panama Papers and Luxleaks came to light, there is no question that the EU and its Member States must take decisive action against tax evasion, tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. The Commission calculates that one trillion euros a year will be lost due to tax fraud and tax evasion. This joint action would be facilitated, for example, by the inability or permanent eradication of tax havens. It is in vain for us to cooperate within the Union if harmful tax systems continue to allow tax evasion, operating in parallel. Moreover, tax havens exist not only outside the EU, but also within the EU. It would therefore be necessary for the Commission to present as soon as possible a common EU definition and list of non-cooperative jurisdictions and to block and penalise all forms of cooperation against them for all banks, financial institutions, companies and individuals operating in the Union.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have three points.  First of all, in Europe, we already have the highest tax load in the world. That means that European companies are paying 10% to 15% more tax than in any other region in the world. This is one of the reasons why we have too little investment and we have a decline in investments. That is why it is important for this to be about fighting illegal tax avoidance, not making it more difficult to invest in Europe.  Second, tax is a national competence. Even though I know that very many here would like it another way around, it is a national competence and will remain so. We are not a European tax court. Sometimes, when I listen to the words here, I think some colleagues forget that we are not those who are to judge, but those who are to legislate on the issues we are responsible for. Third, we need to have cooperation between Member States. That is why it is important to stick to the Organisation for Economic Development rules and BEPS recommendations: because otherwise we create new grey zones, disadvantages for the European economy and better opportunities for those who like to illegally avoid tax.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE).
text: – A recent survey of European citizens shows that most Europeans still strongly believe in the EU's added value.  People are mainly looking at Europe on the big issues: migration, the economy, but certainly also taxation. If we want to work positively on the future of the Union, we must make a difference in cases like this. People have the right to a fair tax. We must therefore make it clear to them that our fight will not stop after this report after tomorrow's vote. In the ECON Commission, we will keep up the pressure on the Member States. Fair corporate tax is at the top of our agenda. Mr Osborne's announcement yesterday that uk corporation tax would fall below 15% is yet another indication of the bid for tax competition between Member States. The only winners in this case are the big corporations and the rich. They can afford to shop. But who pays the bill? Indeed, the poor, the middle class and the small businesses. Those shoulders can carry however a lot. But they cannot tolerate the cost of our social prosperity alone. That's not fair. That's not fair.  If this Parliament needs to make its voice heard somewhere, even in the future, let it be about this. We owe it to our citizens.

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has After a year and a half of work, the TAXE Special Committee will now present its final report. This special committee has achieved one thing above all: despite the European Union's limited competences on tax policy, the work of the committee has brought a lot of movement to the issue. The Commission and the Member States have been forced to act consistently to ensure that tax policy decisions in Europe are not carried out on the backs of the honest taxpayer, so that tax coordination in Europe finally works better and more comprehensively, so that existing laws are improved and loopholes are closed, and so that international action is taken to prevent new tax avoidance practices. We have already seen tightening up in the exchange of information between Member States, we have welcomed the decision of the Competition Commissioners on tax rulings by large multinational companies, and we will work hard to implement the Commission's action plan on corporate taxation and VAT. We need rapid progress towards a common, consolidated corporate tax base. We need more movement in the fight against VAT fraud. The substantive debate on the grievances of the past and the work on solutions must continue. The recommendations of the Special Committee are in good hands in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Legislative work will continue here to make the European Union a pioneer in the global fight against tax evasion and illegal tax avoidance.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). Mr President, it is a reality that all of us here want to tackle tax avoidance and tax evasion. None of us are in favour of tax havens and we must fight them. But we have to admit: firstly, the European Union has the toughest and strictest fiscal framework in its countries, but also the strictest framework in transparency, a framework that other countries, especially America, do not have. Secondly, and importantly, each country of the European Union has the possibility and the possibility to have its own tax rates, but not to avoid or evade taxes. Having your own tax rate doesn't mean you're doing tax fraud, you're doing it just to be strong and strong in the competition.  I believe that with the prevailing trend, with extreme positions and positions that essentially go so far as to want to impose a common corporate tax rate, what we will destroy will be our own business centers, our own financial centers and we will essentially make and finish ..... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Luxleaks and Panama Papers scandals represent a serious vulnus to the stability of the financial system, the world's public good, but also the paradoxical merit of having made clear the processes of tax evasion and avoidance and aggressive tax planning, to be opposed by cooperation and transparency. The uphill road and certainly the Brexit affair, involving one of the most important financial centres in the world, do not help to make the geo-economic picture more intelligible.  I am increasingly convinced of the need to strengthen the banking union as part of a genuine economic and monetary union and to combat the moral hazard that involves, first and foremost, financial institutions which, accomplices in the aggressive tax planning of multinationals, have often played a destabilising role. Confidence in Western democracy is also based on consumer confidence, which unfortunately warns of the fragility of the European financial and banking system, a fragility that is also reflected in industrial realities and in the process of standardisation. .

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the extent of tax evasion and avoidance is estimated worldwide at EUR 1 trillion per year and EUR 50 to 70 billion per year in the Member States of the Union. These figures are also confirmed by the LuxLeaks and Panama Papers scandals, which include the names of 400 Greeks linked to 233 offshore companies.  Of course, the protagonists in these practices of tax evasion and avoidance are multinational companies, which do not pay taxes and thus affect public revenues. Moreover, research shows that Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises pay on average thirty per cent more tax than multinational companies, thus distorting competition and leading to job losses.  Tax ruling practices need therefore be hit and the profits of each company must be taxed where they take place, in order to stop businesses turning to tax havens, such as the Netherlands of Dysseblum or Juncker's Luxembourg.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – So, according to the available data, tax avoidance by corporations is expected to cost the European Union budget over €70 billion each year (the figure is likely to be even higher in reality), more than five times the amount the EU has allocated from 2015 to the beginning of 2016 to deal with the refugee crisis. And therefore, with all the expenditure that we have related to the problems facing the European Union, we certainly do not want to take care of the so-called revenue side as well. All these affairs, of course, have also come out with the help of so-called whistleblowers, including journalists, and without them we would not know the cases that we are talking about today. I therefore think that it is essential, of course, to protect their situation, not to judge them, and thus, in fact, to reward those who are causing these tax loopholes and, of course, also to the problem on the revenue side of the European budget.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Sincere congratulations also from my part. The rapporteurs, who, as the work of the TAXE Committee, have also produced this report in cooperation with the Commission, have pointed to a key problem in today's society. Today, through the Panama Papers, through Luxleaks, we have seen individuals or corporations come up with big money in a false way, and on the other hand, the lack of these funds in the budgets of the states, as well as many people who have been left without a real future, feel smoted. I therefore think it is essential that we continue with this work, to actually get to a society in which people feel more equal and also live more equitly. In any case, protection is needed by those who disclose such documents, because the punishment of such people is not correct and must not happen again in the future.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, I would first like to thank all parliamentarians for this rich and interesting debate, which shows the great importance you attach to the subject we have debated and Parliament's involvement in our common fight against tax evasion and tax evasion. A recent survey commissioned by Parliament revealed that 75% of the citizens surveyed want more action at European level in the fight against tax evasion. This is a priority for our citizens. It is preceded only by the fight against terrorism and the fight against unemployment. That is to say how, in a few years, in a few months, this fight has now reached the top of the political agenda. I can assure you that he is at the top of the political programme of this Commission and that, as European Commissioner, I feel that I have the confidence of all, the confidence of the President, the confidence of the college, who have never constrained my initiatives and are very much attuned to what this Parliament can put forward or undertake. This requirement has been well understood by the institutions. The Commission takes full advantage of its right of initiative and rest assured that it also relies on your work and on the revelations that may have arisen here and there. These revelations are never a problem, and we have to go all the way to find out what happened, whatever the situation. They are always an asset because they give strength to those who want to make this fight a priority. Parliament - you, yoursors, my Members of the European Parliament - is a real engine for progress in this area; the actions of the TAXE 1 and 2 committees and the ECON committee and the quality of the report we are reviewing today bear witness to this. Finally, in this context, the Council, at our common instigation, has been led to take quick decisions. It does so with its own logic, with the constraints we know about the tax decision - the rule of unanimity is probably a hindrance - but it does so with much more acuity, much more speed and, I believe, much more ambition than in the past, which makes progress in this area and your role as a driving force. management, monitoring the various stages on our way are essential for fairer and more transparent taxation in Europe. Progress in this area is undeniable and we should all be pleased.  I note, moreover, that this is a subject that allows for a quasi-consensus on all the benches of this House. Your task does not end today. Our common task does not stop. We all need your technical and political vigilance, and as far as I am concerned, you know that you will also be able to count on my personal commitment to continue this fight until the last day of this Commission's mandate. The new initiative that I have introduced in the introduction, which the Commission has just adopted today, is further proof of this, but we still have many more projects to open. I do not want to go back to what I said in the introduction because, in essence, I expressed all the esteem and support I gave to the report of Mr Kofod and Mr Theurer. I would just like to emphasise two points which have come up in many of your speeches and to which the Commission is sensitive. First, it is the protection of whistleblowers. This is a subject that is clearly now important to us and is unavoidable. Although there are specific areas of European law that provide for the protection of whistleblowers, such as rules against money laundering, we must be clear among ourselves. This issue is largely resolved or to be resolved by national legislation. However, I fully agree, and the Commission is also in agreement, with those of you who express a sensitivity, a concern and a wish that we can act to defend them. In this regard, I can tell you that the Commission will look into this issue to see if there are opportunities to strengthen the protection of whistleblowers at European level, while supporting Member States in strengthening this protection at national level. I think that this is a subject which we must in truth all take over together, whether it is the Member States or the Union, which undoubtedly has limited competences in this area, but which can play a role, at the very least, of a useful sting and a driving force in the field which is its own. My colleague Vera Jourova will be with you tomorrow to discuss this further. It is very clear that our sentiment, as politicians, is the same that these men and women must be protected in their roles - and we intend to do so. The second issue that has been raised by many of you is access to documents, which is still a problem for them in the relationship between our two institutions. I would like to put my cards on the table on this subject: since the establishment of the first TAXE committee, I have paid my full attention to the problem, and all the availability of my services has turned to this requirement. On 22 June, I personally wrote to the President of the European Council to relay the requests for documents authored by the Council. I sincerely believe that the Commission has behaved with the maximum openness - and many exchanges have taken place with Alain Lamassoure and with other parliamentarians whom I welcome here in order to reach a solution which allows parliamentarians, as far as we are concerned, to obtain as much access as possible to the documents available to us. But there are still Council documents. I have no doubt that it will take this into account. Believe me, I will continue to lobby the Council to keep things moving forward, because I am sensitive to your concern. In conclusion, I would like once again to thank all those who have contributed to the work of the TAXE 1 and 2 committees, which I think have been a great success. I am convinced that our synergy, that of Parliament and the Commission - again respecting the responsibilities and sensitivities of each one - will continue to develop also in places other than the TAXE 2 committee, starting with the forum in which we are here, namely the plenary of the European Parliament, because it is here that many initiatives have been taken , this is where a lot of political positions have been formulated, this is where many ideas have been expressed. Our future initiatives, the ones I will take as European Commissioner, need you, your unique expertise, your support, your critical support, possibly your vigilant support, your demanding support, but your support. These are the few remarks I wanted to make at the end of this debate which will have shown the mobilization of the whole Parliament on this fight which, believe it, is common to us and will remain so.

name: Jeppe Kofod
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues for the strong support for the report and for our common work on that. I want to start by thanking the Commission and Commissioner Moscovici, including for the decision taken in the Commission today, again enhancing the fight for transparency. I could highlight a number of the issues on which you adopted positions today, but one of them is beneficial ownership: a public register is something that we really need in the European Union and I also commend you for taking the step you did in that regard. I hope that Member States will follow suit on your ambitious proposals. Secondly, there was a debate on what a fair tax system is. We have to remember that a tax system in which some multinational corporations are paying less tax than small and medium-sized enterprises is not fair. It actually distorts competition. It is destroying jobs in Europe when small and medium-sized enterprises, which create eight out of 10 jobs in Europe, do not have the same conditions as the big multinational corporations. Also, if we allow our tax base to be eroded by profit-shifting out of Europe, we will leave the tax burden to ordinary citizens – to labour, to people who work hard and pay their taxes and are maybe on very low salaries. It is really important to understand that a fair tax system is one in which multinational corporations will pay the same type of tax as small and medium-sized enterprises and contribute to society so that we can maintain in Europe our welfare state and our way of life. Tax justice and citizens’ trust in governments also depend on just tax systems, in which multinationals pay the tax they should. Finally, on the discussion here, I want to make one comment in the wake of Brexit. Colleagues raised the issue of corporate taxation. We see in the UK now proposals to reduce corporate taxation to 15%. It is very important for all of us that we fight this race to the bottom. We have to fight fragmented tax systems that allow tax dodging, but we also need to fight a race to the bottom, in which big multinationals do not pay taxes, because this is contributing to the huge and increasing inequality we see in our societies, and we should fight back against that.

name: Michael Theurer
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the We have now heard the whole range of positions in the discussion. Some people rely heavily on dirigiste measures and full control, others do not want to change anything and find the current state completely in order. A large majority of this House says that the solution lies in the middle, because the Member States – and this has also become clear – have known that there are harmful tax practices. It is all the more regrettable that there is no representative of the Council today. The Commission has been, and still is, a good partner in drawing up concrete legislative proposals. We have the situation where we have an internal market in the European Union with the freedom of capital movements. This eliminates the rights for Member States to tax at the source of profit creation, and that is why we need a binding common legislative framework. We must continue to move forward on this, also in the sense of a social market economy. Allow me – we have worked here on a bipartisan basis – as a free democrat, as a liberal, to conclude by saying that we should heed the OECD recommendation, which says that, in addition to tightening up the rules, a simple, low-rate tax system is also a good incentive to reduce tax avoidance. In other words, better laws, yes, but also not lose sight of the fact that rates should not become too high – as an incentive to simply be tax-honest.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 6 July 2016, at the usual voting time. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Julia Pitera (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The annual budget of the European Union amounts to around EUR 150 billion, and losses as a result of tax fraud and tax avoidance can be estimated by the European Commission to be as high as EUR 1 trillion per year. And these are just estimates. Real amounts can be even higher. Tax fraud and tax avoidance have a negative impact on the labour market, competition mechanisms and are not without impact on economic growth. These amounts show that it is not only necessary, but very urgent, to take action to effectively protect the Union's financial interests. Transparency, controls, the exchange of information and the reduction of banking secrecy are essential instruments against tax fraud and avoidance. The obligation to make national reports public or the mandatory automatic exchange of tax information between Member States are just some of the tools in the package presented by the Commission. However, this does not mean that the problem has already been resolved. Indeed, economic processes will always be exposed to unfair practices. Thus, in addition to systemic solutions, it is important to have access to knowledge of unfair practices as quickly as possible. It therefore seems necessary to create provisions to protect investigative journalists and whistleblowers from negative consequences for them as a result of bona fide and public interest disclosures.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. - Work in the Special Committee on Taxation has been completed. The initiatives must now be taken in the legislative committees. Some of them are already in the works or adopted. With regard to the proposal for a directive of 12 April on public country-specific reporting, one thing: clearly we in the European Parliament will have to set new standards. We have committed ourselves to this in the FINAL REPORT of THE TAXE II: in the report, we clearly criticise the fact that the proposal falls short of previous legislation of the European Parliament – in terms of criteria, scope and also the thresholds for public reporting obligations. As an amendment to the Accounting Directive, the purpose of the public CbCR is in particular tax transparency in the public interest. Companies do not "just" owe the tax authorities to report and automatically exchange their profits and the tax paid, even the public, all other taxpayers, have a right to know about them. I am thinking of the workers, but also of smaller companies. All those who comply with the rules of the game have a right to know where the big competitors make their profits, where and to what extent the taxes are paid for them. Multilateral companies must be required to contribute to society. Like any other small or medium-sized enterprise, multinationals must assume their responsibilities: as employers, as taxpayers and as players in Europe's social market economy.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Artis Pabriks on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the European Border and Coast Guard and the repeal of Regulation (EC) No. 2007/2004, Regulation (EC) No 863/2007 and Council Decision 2005/267/EC (COM(2015)0671 - C8-0408/2015 - 2015/0310 (COD)) (A8-0200/2016).

name: Artis Pabriks
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to say first of all that this vote which is approaching and this discussion on the European Border and Coastguard Agency is of the highest importance for the European Union, for our countries and for our citizens: when we are facing global challenges, increased insecurity and increased migration flows, an increased threat of fragmentation in our continent appears. The decision on the European Border and Coastguard Agency actually shows that we can make decisions in a speedy way and in a very efficient way. First of all, I would like to say thank you to the team of shadow rapporteurs present here. If we speak according to terminology of this agency, I would say that if the European Parliament needs a rapid reaction force to make some decisions go through, then these people are probably ready to do this. Secondly, I would very much like to say thank you to the Commission – to both Commissioners Mr Timmermans and Mr Avramopoulos – and, of course, I would like to express my gratitude to the Council, which was represented by the Dutch Presidency. It was very constructive work. There are a number of things which, within this agency, we can really consider as a positive achievement. First of all, we are really strengthening the efficiency and capacity of the existing Frontex. For the first time in European Union history, we have a 1500—person—strong reaction force consisting of border guards from the member countries.  Secondly, what we achieved as a compromise in trialogues with the Council and the Commission, is that these people are not going bare—handed to support some of the member countries which are facing challenges at their external borders, but they will be provided also with modern necessary equipment, starting maybe with night vision goggles and perhaps ending with planes and ships , if needed. Thirdly, I would also say that a big success is the question about positioning liaison officers in the countries with external borders, because this will provide us with the possibility to exchange timely information. In the time when we are facing not only challenges of migration, but also challenges of cross-border crime, terrorism and perhaps even hybrid threats, the necessary information exchange is something which can additionally help our citizens and people to feel secure and to trust that our national governments, as well as European Parliament and European Commission, are working for their interests on their behalf. We have also been putting a number of other things inside, including the guarantee that we can give this assistance to a member country in need without breaching its sovereignty. But, of course, this decision is not a paper tiger. The country in a hypothetical situation, when it is not capable of controlling its borders and when it is not willing to get assistance from the agency – which is just an assistance and not a replacement for the work of a sovereign nation – can also lead to the situation where member countries decide, for temporary reasons and for security reasons, to introduce also border controls with this country because , as a Union, we have to be responsible not only for our security but for the security of other nations as well. Finally, of course, there is the highest guarantee for fundamental rights whenever any job is done, as well as the possibility to help with search and rescue and returns. I am looking forward to a positive vote, because every Member of this Parliament – if he really cares about European Union interests, about the interests of our citizens and rights of our citizens, and wants to make our Union better – will vote in this case to create this agency.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, there is no doubt that among the many challenges we face one of the most serious is the migration crisis. It is equally clear that, if we want to overcome this crisis, we must improve the way in which we manage our external borders because, in an area without internal borders, the effective control of external borders is a legitimate matter of concern to all. That is why, last December, the Commission presented a proposal for a European Border and Coast Guard and why we have made clear that the rapid adoption of this proposal is indispensable for a return to the normal functioning of the Schengen area. It is for these reasons that I am very pleased that Parliament and the Council have been able to reach a political agreement on this important proposal in only a little over six months. I would like to thank and congratulate all those who contributed to this result, in particular the rapporteur, Mr Pabriks, and his team, all the shadow rapporteurs and also the Dutch Presidency. The agreement reached achieves all of the objectives we set out. It will lay the ground for effective and integrated management of our external borders, with a strong focus on prevention. It will be based on the principles of solidarity and shared responsibility. It will ensure that all our external borders will be managed according to the same high standards without affecting the primary responsibility of each Member State for the management of their part of the external borders. Of course the putting in place of the European Boarder and Coast Guard is only a first step. I know we have much more work to do, but the constructive and results-focused way in which we have worked together on this proposal makes me hopeful and should be a model for the future. I therefore call on you to lend your strong support to this important proposal so that we can start implementing our new approach as quickly as possible this summer. With this, Mr President, I ask your permission to pass the floor to my colleague Commissioner Avramopoulos.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a great day today. After six months, as Frans Timmermans said earlier, we have managed all together to deliver. Reaching a political agreement on the European Border and Coast Guard is a tangible success of effective cooperation between the European institutions. This is significant for such a complex proposal and I would like to express my thanks to First Vice-President Timmermans, to Mr Pabriks, our rapporteur, and to the shadow team and the Dutch Presidency. Moreover, this legislation has a symbolic and legal dimension. We are recognising in practice that our European external borders are common European borders for which we all share the responsibility. This very concretely shows what the strength of the European Union can be when we face a common challenge. We have achieved a balanced agreement accommodating the concerns of both co-legislators. At the same time, the proposal has remained ambitious, ensuring the creation of an agency with the task and the means to make a difference, not only during the current crisis but also in the long term. We are providing our agency with a strengthened legal basis and enhanced resources to perform more effectively, particularly when the overall functioning of the Schengen area is at risk. For example, the new regulation establishes a rapid reaction pool of border guards and other relevant staff, as well as a rapid reaction equipment pool to be made available to the agency whenever it is needed for rapid border intervention. We will not have to face again what is one of the main weaknesses of the current system, in which Frontex has to rely on voluntary and often insufficient pledges by the Member States. In parallel, we have put in place a series of strong preventive measures. The agency will closely monitor the management of the external borders, notably by deploying liaison officers to facilitate cooperation between Member States. Mandatory vulnerability assessments will evaluate the capacities of the Member States to face challenges at their external borders, including the capacity to handle the massive arrival of migrants. The new regulation will also allow the European Union and the agency to act where a Member State is managing its external borders insufficiently and thereby jeopardising the overall functioning of the entire Schengen area. The role of the agency with regard to return is also enhanced, without watering down the provisions of the Return Directive as regards return decisions and safeguards. The agency will be able to underpin our efforts to improve returns by making the logistical and operational side more effective. For our European asylum system to function properly we need to encourage third country nationals to use only legal ways of coming to Europe. These elements are comprehensively addressed in other Commission proposals currently on the table. To balance the expanded mandate of the agency, we included a stronger mechanism guaranteeing the observance of fundamental rights. We took into account the views of the European Parliament in developing a complaint mechanism in our proposal, and your amendments strengthened it even more. This will help to deal with possible violations of fundamental rights in the course of operational activities led by the agency. I also emphasise that search and rescue, although a national competence, is recognised as a specific component of European integrated border management. It is an explicit task of the agency during its operational activities. There is one point on which the Commission has some concerns, namely the provision for appointment of the executive director, which deviates from the common approach on EU agencies agreed by the three institutions. The Commission has submitted a declaration in this regard. I look forward to hearing your views on our common achievement. More importantly, I invite you, dear colleagues, to confirm tomorrow the political agreement on this major measure. Last week, the European Council was very clear on the need for swift formal adoption of the new regulation. The immediate next challenge we are now facing is to prepare the implementation of the strengthened mandate in order to make the European Border and Coast Guard operational as soon as possible after the formal adoption of the regulation, as was also requested at last week’s European Council. Making the new rules work without unnecessary delay is an indispensable element in managing migration better and bringing Schengen back to normal, as provided for in our Roadmap back to Schengen. We have no time to lose. This is a unique moment to turn this success story into reality, to show that we can act together, united as one Europe. This will be a clear and strong message to our citizens who are demanding one thing: effective cooperation and results.

name: Илхан Кючюк
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, honourable Commissioners, dear colleagues, the Schengen area is one of the greatest achievements of European integration, but it currently faces a huge challenge that threatens its existence. The current migration crisis and the constant threats of terrorism bring to the fore the need to review and reform the current instruments and mechanisms for the functioning of Schengen. At the end of June, the European Council called for wider efforts in solving migration in a comprehensive way, including by strengthening and better managing borders. In this regard, I believe that the proposal for a European Border and Coast Guard recognises the need to ensure the necessary controls at the external borders by ensuring levels of security within them while preserving the possibility of free movement of persons within the Union. Modernising Frontex and making it a full European Border and Coast Guard will enable integrated border management and strengthen solidarity between Member States. In conclusion, Mr President, both Bulgaria and Romania should be part of...  (The President took away the speaker's word)

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial
text: rapporteur of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Mr President, Commissioners, from the Committee on Budgets we have always argued, we have always supported the need to create synergies and improve collaboration between different agencies that can work in related areas, and we also believe that in order for this new agency to see the light it has to have sufficient budgetary support.  In this case, the endowment for the European Border and Coast Guard Agency will be a total of EUR 1 212 million for what remains of the multiannual financial framework and, in addition, we will also strengthen, with EUR 87.2 million, the European Maritime Safety Agency and, with EUR 30.1 million, the European Fisheries Control Agency , also for what remains of the financial framework.  Since the Committee on Budgets, we have never questioned, at any time, the mullions of this proposal , on the contrary, we have supported them , but we do think it is absolutely necessary, as we discussed in the previous points, to change the financial framework because otherwise we will not have the money to finance the needs of eer this proposal or all those in line with the refugee crisis.

name: Alain Cadec
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. Mr President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the Commission's awareness of the need for coordination of the authorities practising the functions of coastguard at European level. Since 2011, I have been asking for the coordination of the various authorities that manage our coasts. We have identified 316 civilian and military authorities that deal with this management of Europe's coasts and maritime borders. These authorities are facing unprecedented challenges, such as the migration crisis. These challenges call for preventive actions and rapid, effective and European responses to crises at sea.  Thanks to the cooperation of the three European agencies, we encourage joint action and the exchange of information. The European Border and Coast Guard Body respects the sovereignty of member states - this is important - and strengthens the integrated management of the External Borders of the European Union. Thanks to the redesign of Frontex, we are meeting the expectations of our citizens who, today more than ever, are calling for an efficient, readable, supportive and secure Europe.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The enlargement of Frontex and the establishment of a European coastal and border protection mean a fundamental decision for the European Union. For many years, the Member States have prevented the management of external borders from being a European one. For many years, we have had to watch and also discuss, in some cases, where there are excessive demands, where there are special crises, where a Member State alone cannot manage, better management is necessary for joint intervention and that they must be of an order of magnitude that is effective aid for the Member State concerned. Today we have come to the point where we have a decision to do so. The trialogue is, so to speak, ready, and I also congratulate the Commission, Commissioners, for having the courage to go for the first time to 1500 people. Because if you want effective border management and a crisis, then you can't get along with 10, with 20 or with 50 experienced border guards or those who are specialists in this field, but then you need an order of magnitude that is firstly fast, effective, well organized and also equipped with a basic base at Frontex in the agency. that can actually work effectively. I hope that the Member States that are not here today will react as quickly as it is on paper, because it would serve the credibility of the European Union and the efficiency of the management of its external borders.

name: Péter Niedermüller
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like first of all to thank Mr Pabriks and my fellow shadows and their colleagues for their commitment and the willingness and expertise they brought to the table. I would also like to express my gratitude to the Dutch Presidency and the Commission for their efforts.  We have a very intensive five months behind us, but I am really proud to have been a part of this process. We have achieved a lot together. This regulation is a good example of what the European Union can achieve if there is enough political will. This proves that the EU, its institutions and its Member States are able to deliver results. Under the new regulation, the management of the external borders of the European Union will be the shared responsibility of the Member States and the European Union. I very much welcome this new approach, because safeguarding the Schengen area, which provides freedoms for and at the same time ensures the security of our citizens, requires commitment and solidarity among the Member States at their external borders. This is a European matter, and the regulation is clear on that.  One of the priorities of our Group was ensure that the agency had a bigger role in search and rescue at sea. For years, we saw lives being lost in the Mediterranean. This situation will be improved by the new regulation. Search and rescue operations will be an important component of European integrated border management. The agency starts by supporting Member States in carrying out these operations. Given the increased role of the agency in border controls, handling migratory pressures and carrying out returns, we had to ensure that fundamental rights considerations were adequately addressed. I believe we have managed to strike the right balance in this regulation.  The fundamental rights officer of the agency will have an enhanced role comparable to that agency. I know that there are those who are not convinced about this new agency. I share some of their concerns. The European Border Guard Agency is not a silver bullet in solving the refugee crisis in Europe, and will not end the chaos and inhuman conditions at our external borders. However, I do believe that it is a good step in the right direction, and I think we will see good results.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – I recently requested drowning rates and I find them downright shocking. In 2014 3 280 deaths, in 2015 3 770 and in 2016 to now 3 630 victims. The EU's open borders policy is increasingly driving people into rickety boats. That is why Frontex is being transformed into the EU border and coastguard to guard our external borders and actively discourage migrants from making the dangerous crossing.  Yes, the responsibility for border control still lies with the Member States and our external borders, but in an emergency the agency can take over border control. For example, if Greece achieves a low rate of return, the agency can act and carry out its own return operations to Turkey. And if Greece or another member state refuses to let that EU agency work, then other EU member states such as Belgium have the right to close their internal borders for up to two years. Letting everyone in Europe in and forwarding it to our region can no longer be an option.  With the EU-Turkey deal, EU policy will finally focus on return from March 2016. In this context, the EU Border Guard was given broad powers to coordinate and organise return operations.  This expansion is important for the NVA and it is up to the agency to make this happen.  Anti-drowning packages should also be closed with all countries around the Mediterranean. Asylum seekers who were already safe abroad must be returned to those countries after an accelerated procedure. A systematic pushback policy can then be further developed. In Europe, there can only be room for genuine refugees, with a maximum ceiling. The strengthened agency will also deal with the detection and prevention of terrorism. This is important because 17 fighters from terrorist organisation Islamic State have entered Europe under the guise of refugee – as we read in the newspaper this week – two of whom blew themselves up in Paris.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, I, in turn, would like to start by greeting two particular things. The first is the enormous, dense and very intense work of our colleague, Artis Pabriks, on this report and, secondly, it is the culmination of this work in record time, of this dossier which, as you recalled this evening, was a key issue, one of the few issues that our fellow citizens have really heard about and which they understand the very concrete meaning of. The proof here is that, when there is a political will, when the European Union wants to react and act, to adapt to situations, even the most formidable, such as this challenge which presents itself to us and which risks jeopardising the whole European construction, it knows how to be force of proposal and to provide appropriate responses to the situation as it appears. I would like to address a few quick points in the short time given to me, in particular four key points. My first point is that we have an undeniable step forward which aims to remedy the main gap that Frontex has suffered so far, namely the lack of budgetary resources, but also and above all of human resources, since Frontex will now have a reserve in solidarity between Member States of 1,500 people, which can be mobilised very quickly, and that this agency will have , in addition, the ability to acquire clean equipment and use it very quickly. My second point relates to the clear reference to Frontex's jurisdiction over search and rescue at sea. Together with Mr Pabriks and the shadow rapporteurs, we fought this reference, and we got it. Let us remember here that we have a fundamental obligation to save lives. Nearly 10,000 people have died in the Mediterranean since 2014, and I am not talking about the thousands of people shipwrecked, including 304 children who have died since September 2015. Third point: many guarantees in terms of fundamental rights and the reversal of the clear responsibility of ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, as far as we have been in the year, more than 3,000 people have left their lives in the Mediterranean trying to reach our continent, many others have been deported to Turkey or gassed at the borders. Far from taking the necessary measures to prevent this tragedy, such as establishing legal and safe ways to reach Europe, granting humanitarian visas and, above all, complying with international reception legislation, the flagship proposal of the Council and the European Commission is to replace the Frontex agency with a new agency, the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, which may intervene in different Member States to shield borders, even without the consent of these States, which criminalizes migrants, by collecting their fingerprints and other personal data as if they were criminals; an agency with which they also intend to intervene in third countries. This new body is actually a deportation agency to return the bombs and wire to whom it is able to set foot in Europe. This body does not respond to any democratically elected political authority. The lack of transparency and lack of control over respect for human rights have been criticised even by the Ombudsman of the European Union. This new agency is nothing more than a new piece of these racist policies that the European Union has been practicing for too long. You seem to have decided that the best way to stop the far-right election boom is by championing these xenophobic policies yourself.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs.  So here we have it: the European Border and Coast Guard, the one thing that was supposed to solve pretty much all of our problems – everything related to the so—called refugee crisis. But does this ‘Frontex +’ – because it is really not much more – actually really help with our most pressing problems? Does it help against the drowning of people at sea? No, especially not after the Council has blocked most of the proposals that we have been pushing for in the European Parliament. Does it help against the lack of solidarity and political will in the Member States? It doesn’t. Does it help provide better shelter, more asylum officers, faster procedures, medical care? Does it help at all to tackle the reasons people have to flee? No, it doesn’t. Frontex does not solve any of the most pressing issues that we have. Instead, we are sending border guards against people who are actually fleeing from war and persecution. And by giving so much more power to an agency without actually also beefing up its fundamental rights protection, we are creating a pretty dangerous construction. Europe should rather focus on other things – search and rescue, legal ways, accommodating refugees, sharing the responsibility – all of those things are things we should do, and, rather than punishing Member States who are not closing off their borders, we should support them. And let us not forget that the real crisis is the one of those people who are losing their homes, their families, their futures and sometimes even their lives, and in order to help them, we really have to do better. (Applause)

name: Gerard Batten
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – [...] legislation is intended to give the European Union greater powers to control Member States’ external borders. It wants to replace Frontex with the European Border and Coast Guard Agency. This will require more staff, funding and equipment. The new agency will have a mandate to send liaison officers to launch joint operations and operate in the territories of Member States and third countries, and of course it will require a great deal of money. It has an estimated cost of EUR 238 million in 2016, rising to EUR 322 million by 2020. The United Kingdom is not bound by this legislation, but even so, as long as the UK remains a member of the EU, British taxpayers will be liable to help bear the financial cost.  This legislation compromises the national sovereignty of participating Member States, but it will not succeed in controlling the migrant crisis on Europe’s borders so long as the Schengen area continues to exist. There are good reasons why people are fleeing Africa and the Middle East, but a major factor in attracting them to Europe is that they know that once they enter one European country, they will have free access to other European countries in the Schengen area. The first step to controlling the migrant crisis is to abolish the Schengen area.

name: Gerolf Annemans
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Ladies and gentlemen in the European Union, with a totally new proposal that gives you the false appearance of a nice-sounding name, European border and coastguard, and that, like everything else here, the European Border and Coast Guard agency, your European Union is trying to keep the sinking Schengen ship and the european Union's open borders aft.  Instead of a restoration of internal borders and an Australian-based pushback policy, an EU civil service will be given extra grip, with power, with coercive means in the border and immigration policy that originally belonged to the Member States. Instead of humbly acknowledging the moral bankruptcy of open borders and Schengen, you are stubbornly standing up and adding a portion of clean appearance. I call on you, ladies and gentlemen, to give Europe back to its countries.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). Mr President, the European Border and Coast Guard is another european Union military police mechanism against refugees and migrants, with the agreement of the Greek Government. It undermines the sovereign rights of each country, because if a Member State does not comply with imposed measures or refuses intervention by rapid reaction forces at its borders, decided by the Council and not unanimously, that Member State will be threatened with blackmail by the reintroduction of controls at its borders, within the framework of the reactionary Schengen Treaty. The main task of the new reactionary mechanism is to deport and repel thousands of persecuted refugees and migrants fleeing the war and poverty sparked by the European Union, its allies and capitalist rivalries. The Communist Party of Greece makes it clear: solidarity with refugees means recognizing them and their rights, as defined by international conventions, providing temporary, decent accommodation and living by lifting their entrapment, means no facilitation, no involvement in...  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, I very much welcome the fact that tomorrow we will be able to consecrate the text on the European Border and Coast Guard. Let me address the most discussed article. It's Article Eighteen. It concerns the situation at the external borders, which requires immediate action. For example, when there is disproportionate pressure from migrants at the external borders. When a Member State is not coping with the situation and the functioning of the Schengen area may be jeopardised, a border or maritime guard team shall act as reinforcement. However, here we come across objections that the European Union can threaten the sovereignty of such Member States.  For decades, I've lived in a land surrounded by barbed wire. The border guard of communist Czechoslovakia mercilessly shot anyone who tried to cross the border without permission. Rarely has state power granted a citizen an exit visa to the then non-communist world. For just three weeks. You could officially buy just $120 for the trip. It was humiliating. Corruption has blossomed. In the state bank and at the Ministry of the Interior. It was Schengen that made us free, free-breathing European citizens. Schengen was the greatest acquisition we achieved after the fall of communism. I therefore prefer the EU's common action to defend it.   (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I am here from Hungary, which means that it was also a country in a very difficult situation at border control level during a historical period. But life in Hungary is not easy now. And that is why I ask you, do you have any vision of what will happen if one of the Schengen Member States defies this agency, which is now being set up, with noble simplicity?

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. - I've been thinking about this for a long time, I don't think we can let this happen. We must act long enough to convince a country that wants to denounce obedience to obey. It is indeed a matter that if someone fails to comply with the aid offered and the country itself cannot do it, then the directive really has to come in.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the This morning, in the debate on Brexit, we have often heard that the EU is incapable of acting and unable to act collectively. Tomorrow's decision on a European Border and Coast Guard Agency proves the opposite. In less than six months, we have been able to find workable solutions to a problem that has paralysed Europe for months: the dysfunctional protection of our external borders. The regulation is important for a number of reasons: for the first time, there is European support for Member States when they are unable to control their borders – so we have a European dimension. Secondly, parliamentary control rights have been strengthened in terms of accountability, the obligation to provide information and the selection of the director. Thirdly, it has also been possible to improve the protection of fundamental rights, particularly as regards children and disabled people. So far so good. However, this regulation is only one element in resolving the so-called refugee crisis. We must also combat the causes of flight, we must look after aid on the ground and, above all, we need humanitarian entry corridors.
