This is the most important element of a different migration policy.

name: Timothy Kirkhope (ECR).
text: – Mr President, whilst the UK has not fully signed up to the Frontex agency, or indeed the new Border and Coast Guard, it has played an active and supportive role in the agency’s operations over the years and I very much hope this relationship can continue. I have long been a supporter of the work of the agency and, like others in this House, I have called many times for it to take a stronger role with an enhanced mandate. A resilient and well—managed external border benefits all European countries. It protects freedom of movement, the Schengen area and – crucially – public confidence. Greater communication between the agency and national authorities, an efficient returns system and an emphasis on preparedness and prevention are crucial ingredients in bringing much needed stability to our present crisis. Here we have a good result, and I extend my congratulations to the rapporteur and all involved. I hope this regulation is another step towards making the EU’s response in the area of asylum and migration both credible and effective.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The basic idea of the implementation of Schengen cooperation was to dismantle the internal borders between our Member States and instead strengthen the external border. Today we are some way towards this. In fact, the external borders of Sweden are Italy and Greece, if we are now to take the Union seriously. We are now taking a step with this important report, on which I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, a step towards European management of the external borders. What we are achieving is a border control that gives us protection against the import of arms, against drugs, against terrorist activities and all sorts of other things that we do not want. This, I will say clearly, is not about stopping people seeking protection for their lives from war and persecution. It's a misinterpretation. We Liberals wanted to go a little further. We have not come all the way, but politics is, as you know, a marathon and will continue to follow.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The will and proposals to militarise the EU's borders with razor fences, high technology and border guards have been around for a long time, but until today these proposals had been stopped by all of us who believe in an open Europe. All of us who know that we have no future together if we exclude those fleeing war, conflict and extremely vulnerable conditions. You all want to talk about Farage's unpleasant racist nationalism, but do you not see that it is his policy that you are adapting to? Hotspots, deportations, stopping refugees in third countries. The EU has become too much like UKIP. Today, EU cooperation is showing its very worst side, namely the ability to act in excluding people and full incapacity for action in terms of standing up in solidarity for international asylum law. Believe me, there are many of us who do not accept this Europe. There are many of us who believe that SuperFrontex is a super gigantic step in the wrong direction.

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE).
text: This has been hasty and I do not understand why we are proud of it. This proposal rattles and if I may give you an example, I make it personal: suppose, the Dutch government does not control its borders. We have a long coast and we don't do anything about it. And the other Member States do not think that is possible and they want to intervene. And which country is going to help? Belgium! That country is right next to us. Belgium is going to control the Dutch coast. And then the Belgian coast guard picks up a smuggler. Whether it's drugs or people, the Belgian Coast Guard does.  So where do we land that smuggler to be tried? In Rotterdam or ostensive? Under whose right does this happen? Or we'll make it worse: that smuggler won't get caught. No, in a clumsy operation of the Belgian coast guard in the Dutch waters, the smuggler drowns. Who's responsible here now? Not the Belgians. The Dutch, because it's Dutch water. Ladies and gentlemen, it's not going to happen, this system. It's not a European Border and Coast Guard. Continuing national activities, it's Frontex plus. It's not helping our refugee crisis, it's a wheel in mind. It's rushing, it's gossip!

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, what many of you have called 'speed', 'speed', I call 'haste' and haste is often bad advice and almost never leads to good results. So, in my opinion, this Commission proposal has gone too fast and we have forgotten what must be the priorities in order to be able to think of a coastguard and border guard: that is, the passing of the Dublin Regulation 3, a compulsory redistribution mechanism and the provision of legal access routes, because otherwise, with the proposed mechanism, we are simply in danger of making the southern stages a large refugee camp.  Secondly, ladies and gentlemen, this measure has quite obvious democratic shortcomings, and we are talking about the agency that is not well known who is answerable, with bureaucrats who can intervene and even replace the power of the Member States if they do not respond to the recommendations made. I believe that this is something dangerous; Just as there is no provision for any form of control by the European Parliament, which is the only body elected.  I'm afraid that haste will do multinationals a favor. (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Mr President, the creation of the European Coast Guard and Border Guard is yet another stillborn method of leading the European Union that will have the same fate as its predecessor, FRONTEX. As demonstrated by NATO's involvement in the Aegean to supposedly stem the flow of illegal immigrants from Turkey to Greece, multinational, cumbers and bureaucratic mechanisms have no operational effectiveness. Those who, by their very nature and mission, are capable of protecting a country's borders are the country's security forces, and this was demonstrated some time ago when some countries decided to ignore the Schengen Treaty and close their borders. Unfortunately, in Greece, the governments of the Memorandum, in collusion with the EU, did not instruct the security forces to secure the country's borders, in order to give the impression that a European Coast Guard-Border Guard should be created. This method is intended to remove sovereignty and powers from states, such as responsibility for search and rescue, to which Mr Avramopoulos referred earlier, and at the same time to support the German Government's attempt to create a European army.  How this army will behave, we in Greece know it very well. In Chios and Samos, the Germans... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Ελισσάβετ Βοζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνιδη (
text: PPE). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a new era for Europe marks the creation of a European Border and Coast Guard and demonstrates that in difficult times we can work together effectively and act together, aiming at the heart of the problem. Warm congratulations to our rapporteur, Mr Pabrina, for the meticulous work he did and the combination of different opinions.  The European Border and Coast Guard, which will operate without disrupting the sovereignty of each Member State, will be the missing link to strengthen Europe's external borders. Securing the Schengen area and our external borders is now a shared responsibility among all the Member States of the European Union, and part of the solution to the refugee issue, while strengthening our internal security.  For Greece, the importance of the new European Agency is two-way, because Greece is, by geographical location, the main gateway for refugees and migrants to Europe, but also because of its vast coastline which makes it particularly difficult to control at the maritime external borders.  Ladies and gentlemen, strong support for the new service is an essential expression of European solidarity, because let us not forget that even today, thousands of refugees are waiting for solidarity for their relocation from Greece to other Member States, in accordance with European decisions.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: Mr President, what will the new Frontex agency be used for? Certainly not to settle the fantasies of the supporters of a Europe-bunker, but also not to satisfy those who want a Europe without borders. But perhaps the reform undertaken will enable Frontex to participate in a more European and efficient management of our external borders. More European, the Agency may be, because it will have more resources to resolve problems more quickly and collectively. Member States on the front lines at external borders should be helped more effectively, which is essential, especially in view of the current situation in Greece and Italy. It may be more effective, so that this new European corps openly assumes search and rescue operations at sea. I have heard the concerns expressed by several NGOs and I want to make the bet that the Agency will carry out its missions in full respect of fundamental rights, and it will have, as a watermark, the complaint mechanism that the European Parliament has been calling for for so long. But then we must remain vigilant about what might remain a spontaneous reflex of Member States to re-establish controls at their borders, even if this is described as a measure of last resort.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, we are finally responding this time to a crisis faster than usual. I recall that the PNR lasted three years in this House, which is why I am surprised by colleagues who complain that we have moved too fast. Yes, we must move quickly, defend our external borders and regain the trust of the citizens of the Union. The report that we are finally voting on tomorrow – and I am glad that we are voting on it – foresees a strengthening of the Union's external borders through several issues: a body of permanent and reserve border guards from the Member States, which will be around 1,500 people and who will be seconded to the Union's external borders; Frontex – is the border agency – will also fund the training of border guards who are part of the rapid reaction force. In 2016, the Union will pay more than EUR 260 million and in 2017 more than EUR 300 million.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Agreement on the Common Border and Coast Guard shows our determination to save the Schengen area and to preserve the free movement of persons as one of the fundamental pillars of the European Union. However, this will only work with a European approach, because common borders need a common approach. So what we are seeing here is a step in the right direction. It's just a pity that it's a little too short. A glance at the content shows that it does not correspond to the title and its expectations. Unfortunately, we have missed another opportunity to create a genuine common European system. Half-hearted solutions will not protect us in future crises. We should actually look ahead and create instruments that address not only the structural weaknesses of the past, but also future shortcomings. We would have had the opportunity and also the moral obligation to take full and correct measures to show citizens what a real European approach looks like. That would be very desirable for all of us.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the lack of common protection of the Union's external borders is one of the most problematic elements in European architecture. Small and medium-sized Member States thus remain exposed to harassment by other states, such as Greece, which is threatened with war by Turkey if it exercises its legal right to extend territorial waters to twelve miles or even by occupying their territory, such as Cyprus. This entails huge budgetary costs for defence expenditure, i.e. additional difficulties for national economies to meet the Union's objectives.  The creation of a European Border Guard could be a first step in tackling the problem, but for the time being it is limited to immigration control issues. Questions also arise as to the conditions for cooperation between the Border Guard and non-EU Member States. In any case, the protection of the national sovereignty and territorial integrity of the Member States must be ensured in the context of the above procedures.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The proposal is better than the Commission's original proposal, but just because something has improved does not mean that it is good. The fact that decisions can be taken quickly, as the rapporteur stressed, does not mean that there will be good decisions either. Rather, they usually get worse because they are ill-conceived. I have always thought that on that day Frontex's main task is to save lives, instead of shutting people out of Europe, I will give them my support. We now had an opportunity to make a change, but did not take it, and Frontex Plus does not get my support today either. When we started the legislature, it was said that we would not legislate so much but apply what we already have. Instead, there will be a rush of quickly drafted proposals. This took six months, you said, and speed, as I said just now, does not mean that it is quality at all. What we are urgently dealing with now is that the fight against terrorism and migration has become our most important task in europe, and I cannot agree with that. Commissioner Avramopoulos said that people should be given legal avenues, but then we must first create such paths.

name: Diane James (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, this piece of proposed European Union legislation concerning a European Border and Coast Guard system is interesting, since – as ever – it has been constructed to deal with the consequences of an EU decision and action and does not actually address the root cause. The latter, of course, would require a U-turn, which is not likely. However, we are where we are. And it is important that the United Kingdom recognises that, while we will not be bound by the legislation nor indeed even directly affected, we will be contributing to the estimated EUR 230 million project, regardless of the outcome of the Brexit vote. This whole concept has value and I appreciate the value, but the value is going to be even more important to two areas. The first is that of the people smugglers, a business now worth an estimated EUR 16 billion. They are going to have confidence that their activities will not result in as many deaths at sea or on the Balkans route. The second is among the potential migrants who will perceive less risk in making perilous journeys, be it over the Mediterranean or on the other, mountainous, routes. By default, a border and coast guard system should not become a maritime and land-based rescue system yet, in the current climate, this seems to be exactly what the proposition is. I only urge that the rapporteur please listen to my comments and take them on board.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report What are we talking about today? First you make Schengen, supposedly secure the external borders and realise at the first onslaught on Europe that the borders cannot be secured. We are talking about 1500 officials for European border and coastal protection. In 2013, when the Federal Police was renamed, the Federal Coastal and Border Protection, the Federal Coastal and Border Protection, included 40269 officers, and you want to secure Europe's borders with 1,500 officers, fight terrorism and repats illegal immigrants! How is this supposed to work? The best border security so far has been demonstrated by the fact that the nation states have resorted to securing their own borders again. But with 1,500 officials across Europe, you will not be able to keep Schengen.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a migratory phenomenon of exceptional magnitude: Europe's responses must be absolutely as a result. In order to guarantee the Schengen area, that is, a common area of free movement without internal borders, the external borders must be monitored extensively. That is why I very much welcome this proposal for a regulation establishing a European Border and Coast Guard Agency, building on the experience gained by Frontex in recent years, which aims to play a fundamental role, to support the nation states on the subject, above all, of returns, which is the absolute anomaly of the European reception system – just think that in Italy , for example, in 2015, out of 34 000 deportees, 3 488 migrants were actually repatriated, or just over 10.8% – and will continue to support search and rescue operations. That is why I hope that this important act will be adopted by this House and made operational as soon as possible.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in the context of the extension of frontex's mandate through the development of the new European Border and Coast Guard police system, the Romanian authorities have shown their openness to contribute sustained efforts to maintain the security of the internal and external borders of the European Union and to competently manage the flow of immigrants. Thus, Romania will contribute 75 policemen to the backup capacity for rapid intervention, made up of 1,500 people. To date, Romania is making one of the most important contributions in the field, including in operations in the Aegean and Mediterranean, allocating ships and personnel in monitoring and rescue operations. Romania also has the capacity to monitor and manage vulnerabilities that may occur in the Black Sea through the SCOMAR system and has concluded readmission agreements with Turkey and Serbia. Finally, I would like to address the Council and tell it that, in view of my country's contribution to this effort, the Member States will decide to accept Romania, Croatia and Bulgaria immediately into Schengen.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I support the creation of the European Border and Coast Guard because I am in favour of rational decisions. In areas such as the fight against terrorism, the protection of external borders, we can advance our integration, all the more so because the European Border and Coast Guard is not intended to replace and support the efforts of sovereign states. Indeed, I call on the European Commission to ensure that this spirit of cooperation, the spirit of mutual trust, also comes from the European Commission, because then we will have a positive effect. Doctrinal is something that interferes with the planning of good politics. I completely do not share those voices on the left, on the left of the European Parliament, which say: 'let us not attach importance to the protection of the external borders, let us open the door wide to immigration'. Let me be very clear: only a Europe that is safe can truly stand in solidarity. If Europe is unable to be safe, it will not be able to show solidarity.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the current migration crisis has taught us one essential thing: freedom of movement in the Schengen area is only viable if external borders are effectively controlled and protected. There is a second truth that must be reminded of the supporters of control and national sovereignty over borders: in the Schengen area, an external border is no longer just a national border. It has become a common frontier. Whoever lands in Calais or comes by boat to Calais does not come only to France. He can go freely to Berlin, Rome, Madrid, Amsterdam, Brussels. Anyone who lands in Lisbon can go freely to Riga, Warsaw, Budapest. And, in my view, what is a common border, ideally, should be managed jointly or, at the very least, jointly. That is what we are being asked to approve today and my group and I will approve it. If a Member State does everything necessary to effectively control the common border and succeeds in doing so, it will be able to do so without the intervention of anyone. Only when it fails to do so will it be helped by other European states.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, both the structure and the specific technical details governing the functioning of this Agency reflect, on the one hand, the current view that Europe is becoming an enhanced fortress area and, on the other hand, the lack of political cohesion between the Member States of the present European Union.  It is obvious that the refugee crisis has been used as an alibi for the organisation to take its present form. And it is more obvious that this Agency cannot, nor should it, in our view, deal with humanitarian crises such as the recent one, for the simple reason that our external borders are not 'besieged' by migrants, as has been heard here, but by refugees from both bombed and destroyed homelands.  As long as today's dominant European policy makes the peoples of Europe poor and sustains the causes of these crises, organisations like today can neither be useful nor effective in the service of citizens.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the European Border and Coast Guard Agency will be a useful tool to help manage migration flows and safeguard the Schengen area. This is a political agreement of importance.  It is necessary that, in compliance with the sovereignty of the Member States and the principle of subsidiarity, we should coordinate border control, return operations, the fight against crime and search and rescue operations, all with full respect for fundamental rights, especially the most vulnerable groups.  The persistence of freedom of transit depends to a large extent on effective and coordinated border control. I hope that the vulnerability reports and measures to be taken in cases of urgency will put an end to the unilateral border closure episodes we have witnessed in recent months and also that the obligation of this Regulation will enable the parties to fulfil their obligations, making available to the Agency the economic, technical and human resources necessary to ensure their viability.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the mandate for a European Coast Guard and Border Control Agency has evolved greatly, fortunately, in relation to the original version, which proves the usefulness of this Parliament being heard and scrutinising the mandate and functioning of the new agency, in particular in the vulnerability test. Including search and rescue operations in the mandate is crucial to fulfilling European legal and moral responsibilities. But controlling borders and organizing return operations is, by definition, reacting in the final phase of the problem. The priority should be to open legal and safe routes for migrants and refugees not to have to surrender into criminal hands, preventing increasingly dangerous but more profitable routes for traffickers. And invest in the articulation of Frontex or the new agency, with a strengthened EASO and Europol, as well as change the discourse, failing to go to tow the xenophobic far right, telling the truth to our citizens: if refugees and migrants need Europe, Europe also needs them.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, last December, some of us strongly denounced the attempt to take over the national sovereignty of the Member States which is being attempted through the new European Border and Coast Guard. As is now solemnly demonstrated by the famous Article 18. In fact, the new Border and Coast Guard is trying to legitimise, among other things, Frontex's illegal activities.  There are already a plethora of complaints from the Aegean islands about roadblocks set up by Germans and other foreign police officers of the Frontex force, who identify the inhabitants. This is a flagrant violation of Greece's national sovereignty.  After the troika turned Greece into a debt colony, it now wants to turn it into a normal colony. Because, after Brexit, many colleagues wonder about the mistakes of the European Union, the answer lies here: the European Union systematically underestimates the will of the people, does not respect national sovereignty, attempts to impose the ultimatums of Brussels with political authoritarianism. But these will not pass, because the Greek people will not tolerate them.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, only at such a critical time is a common but incomplete approach to the more integrated management of the external borders of the European Union possible. The cooperation of the national authorities with the new agency is decisive. Some positive measures have been introduced: it will have its own resources, strengthen the rescue of people at risk at sea, a mechanism has been created to denounce fundamental rights if they are violated... However, I don't want those changes to help you articulate, for example, floating hotspots. For that, no. And I think it must be taken into account that, without a common system of asylum care, of attention to economic migration, without the solidarity of countries and governments, without better mechanisms of legal migration in an aging Europe, this new agency will only finally be our appalling face. That is why, for me, which I am in favour of us controlling our external borders in a common way, it is very important that we do not become that heinous face.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: – I live in beautiful Stramproy in the Dutch province of Limburg, and I live there a few hundred steps from the Belgian border. So I experience like no other the luxury of a Europe without internal borders. But that luxury also brings obligations, and that obligation is that we are jointly responsible for the protection of our external borders, and this requires strict, good and efficient monitoring. Because the Dutch external border is no longer located in Molenbeersel, but on Lesbos and on Lampedusa. We have just seen in 2015 that there is still a lot of overdue maintenance with this joint border security. It is therefore also good that Europe has now shown action, that within six months that wish for better border security has become a reality, and I look forward to the implementation happening quickly. Europeans expect us to have their business in order when it comes to protecting external borders. And it's up to us to do that now.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in this Strasbourg plenary we discuss and adopt the first reading of a Regulation which is a European law on a European border agency, which learns from the experience and limitations of the Frontex Agency. And some Socialists in the Committee on Freedoms, Justice and Home Affairs have worked very actively to improve the Commission's proposal; to strengthen its linkage to the mandate to protect fundamental rights and, in particular, vulnerable persons: children and persons with disabilities; to strengthen the mechanisms for the expression of individual complaints with respect to those responsible for the European Border and Coast Guard Agency and their commitment to fundamental rights; and to strengthen accountability before this Parliament, transparency; but above all to link the Agency's management with migration, the fight against cross-border crime and rescue, search and rescue operations, which reinforce the humanitarian dimension and commitment to values of the European Union. But we do not want the Socialists to serve as an instrument for the policy of return, return, fence and border, in the face of people trying to access the European Union in search of an opportunity in the face of their despair.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – Firstly, the European Union should have as many common institutions and common competences as our countries share common values and common interests. Secondly, institutions need to be created to pursue our agreed policy, not for new institutions to replace the need for political arrangements between states.  As far as our common borders are concerned and the protection of our common borders is concerned, we have had the worst experience in recent months. The countries at the borders of the European Union that wanted to protect our borders were only under attack, and this is also the case in this House; instead of support, they received attacks. Today, there is no need for new institutions in the European Union, but a whole new leadership is needed. There is a need for a change of policy, not the creation of new institutions, in order to strengthen the policies of this leadership, which should definitely go away.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Exactly 100 years ago, the Battle of the Som began, in which 60,000 Britons, Germans and French people died on the first day of the fighting. They fell because of a politician who viewed the war as a continuation of politics. This mention should only be a reminder of a time when many are once again betting on nationalist and protectionist solutions. Today we have the European Union, which is a project of peace and security. This context also includes common responses to common challenges. Among them is the creation of a common border and coastguard, which will effectively protect us from turmoil from the outside, so that we live freely and in peace within the Union. My colleague Esteban Gonzáles Pons said months ago that we wanted a house with doors, not without them. The European Border and Coast Guard will have this door open to all who want the Union to be good and closed to all who want to destabilise it. Let the agreement between the European Parliament and the Council be put into full implementation as soon as possible.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Dear President, last year over an 11-month period around 1.5 million people did not cross the external borders of the European Union in a regular manner. The proposal on a European Border and Coast Guard aims to ensure the integrated management of the External Borders of the European Union. This proposal should be supported in order to put it into practice as soon as possible and there must be no other unenforced decision adopted since the beginning of the refugee crisis. But this Agency must respect some key elements: fundamental rights and principles of prohibition of expulsion. Independence of the officer to handle complaints of possible human rights violations. Availability of translated documents on asylum rules and rights and respect for the principles of search and rescue.  In particular, I emphasise that effective control of the external borders of the European Union eliminates the need for blockades at internal borders and should serve the interests of all Member States. That is why I welcome the compromise on the inclusion of Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria, as Schengen does not need to be saved by leaving out members who are not yet fully part of Schengen by wire or directives.

name: Николай Бареков (ECR).
text: – The Efforts of the European Union must be thrown to guard our common borders. One of the main reasons for Brexit was the uncontrolled migrant and refugee flow. More effort and resources need to be directed to the external borders for equipment, fences and living power. Bulgaria, Greece and Italy are something of a living shield for the wave of refugees from the Middle East and Turkey. Turkey remains our unreliable ally, i.e. it is not an ally. Bulgaria spent hundreds of millions of the state budget on building a fence on its border with Turkey. The poorest member of the European family – Bulgaria, needs additional funds to complete the security facilities and purchase modern equipment, motor vehicles and others. With more money from the European Commission, we can increase human composition in border areas and even joint combat and technical security forces from the European Union at Europe's external borders with other countries.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is a good day for the citizens of Europe and proof that the EU is doing what is required. The European Border and Coastal Protection Regulation was implemented in just six months, from the Commission's proposal to the trilogue result. We all know that only an efficient EU external border protection can guarantee freedom of movement in the Schengen area and, at the same time, combat criminal smugglers and save lives. What the European People's Party has been calling for for years is finally being realised – against some fundamentalist resistance that has been cracked. Frontex will be expanded with double staff, technical equipment, a rapid reaction force, an intensification of operations – and this in close cooperation with the EU countries. Let me just say a few words: further steps still need to be taken. We are not finished yet, but this Commissioner and his team will be able to do so.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D).
text: – Madam President, overall this proposal on the European Border and Coast Guard agency is a balanced and important framework for improving external border management and helping to uphold human rights and international law. It is critical that the agency is properly supported and enabled to coordinate operations and mobilise resources. In doing so, it can help protect refugees in distress and facilitate the movement of goods and people within the EU and across borders. As a member of Parliament’s Committee on Transport and Tourism, I am confident, following our debates, that the agency will take account of the need for good transport logistics and infrastructure links across borders, including in relation to maritime routes. In these difficult times we must not forget the socio-economic benefits of our EU policies in promoting a connected Europe – and the added accountability of the agency to Parliament and Member States through this proposal is welcome. Furthermore, whatever happens next with the legal and political future of the UK within our shared continent, it is essential we engage constructively with a valuable collective endeavour such as this one.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: – The question of adopting a European border guard is not so easy to answer. The title of the agency raises questions such as: will EU military officers now guard our borders?  The original proposal from the European Commission did indeed go in that direction. The Commission wants to be able to deploy border guards at Europe's external borders unsolicited if necessary. That point has disappeared in the negotiations between the Council and Parliament, and I think that is quite right. Now a strengthened Frontex agency is ahead. It will have a reserve of some 1 500 border guards provided by the Member States. Fifty of them come from the Netherlands.  The border guard will be deployed at the European external border only if a Member State itself requests it and after a decision of all the Member States in the Council. The Agency shall support Those Member States which continue to monitor their own borders. And this happens especially at hotspots, the arrival places for refugees. The border guard will also help Member States to return asylum seekers who have been processed. We want open borders in Europe, where we can do so in a safe and responsible way. This is good for business, good for our citizens. Serious monitoring of our shared border, for example in Greece or Italy, is therefore essential. The European Border Guard is therefore an example of cooperation which we say yes to.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Dear President, the fact is that more than 1.5 million people are estimated to have crossed the border illegally between January and November 2015. This anomaly that occurred with these migrations indicates that the European Union was not ready and therefore we must seek a solution. The solution is to manage migration, manage this process, and that is why I am committed to starting this European agency for guarding europe's border and coastline. It can also be called Frontex plus or an agency with increased powers, but this is what we want: that it has increased powers and increased accountability, and that Member States cooperate more with each other.  What I would like to say here once again today to those populists who are spreading the atmosphere that this is an inducing into the sovereignty of national states is that I think this is not an inducing of sovereignty and that national states remain competent in their territory. This is only aid and can be applied if necessary, especially for those countries that have a long border. And just one more sentence to finish: Croatia would soon like to become a member of the Schengen area.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have managed to build a consensus in record time on the need to manage, in a common and supportive manner, the External Borders of the European Union, which now become common borders of the entire European Union. Unlike the walls, the European Border and Coast Guard will be made up of people, who will be faced with other people, migrants, whose fundamental rights will have to be respected and against whom there is a precise joint and supportive obligation to search and rescue at sea.  The establishment of this agency is a first step towards a common management of the migration phenomenon. But let us not delude ourselves: it alone will not be able to solve the short, medium and long-term challenges posed by migration. If Europe has been able to react quickly and decisively to re-establish the Schengen route, it can act with equal ambition to build a genuine common European asylum system, which really takes into account the principles of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibility.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it took only a few months to agree on a common European Border and Coast Guard, which is urgently needed to control our external borders better, manage migration flows and combat terrorism. This shows to the citizens of Europe that, on key issues which concern them, such as migration and security, the EU is able to deliver fast. Effective control of our external borders is also a precondition for, and paves the way for, restoring Schengen. The beefed-up Frontex should be an operational tool to support Member States in saving lives, fighting smugglers and traffickers, registering migrants with fingerprints, sharing information and now also assisting Member States in return operations. I welcome the fact that responsibility for police and border guards continue to be a national competence and that sovereignty is respected and shared responsibilities clearly defined. The Council can trigger a joint operation with transparent decision—making procedures. Let me conclude by saying that I am happy that we managed to include children’s rights in the new rules.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (
text: S&D). Madam President, Commissioner, within six months we have managed to create the European Border and Coast Guard, and with your considerable contribution. A dynamic organisation which can help the Member States, even without their own consent, if they do not, by qualified majority, of course. The one million refugees who entered the European Union, without effective control, have mobilized our Community reflexes for immediate action, even beyond national obstacles. Of course, they shook Schengen. So we learned something from last year's drama.  But have we learned enough? This will be shown along the way, because we are already discussing the Dublin review, solidarity. Remember, the one that has closed the borders and trapped 50,000 people in Greece and more.  To continue after Brexit as if nothing has been done is not possible. We need, so as not to push people into dead-end national solutions, a New European governance. We will start the debate from the autumn, but the example we are giving is already very important.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: – What we have been saying for a long time has now been clearly demonstrated, that Europe must protect its external borders more effectively. Internal borderlessness, one of our greatest values in the European Union today, can only be maintained if we are in control of the situation at the Union's external borders. Belatedly at least a year, this realisation is good that it has now led European decision-makers in the creation of the European Border and Coast Guard. Finally, this is a concrete, practical step to protect our citizens, to ensure the internal security of the Union, and can become an element in managing the migration wave and eliminating smuggling networks. Where a Member State is unable to protect common external borders, cooperation must be open so that we can ensure adequate border protection through joint action. I hope that the European Border and Coast Guard will be a good practical example of solidarity and close cooperation between Member States.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, when we were elected in 2014, what did we say in this House? That the response to this humanitarian migration crisis should not have been a response solely and exclusively entrusted to the Member States – Italy, Greece, Germany, France – but was to be a European response. And that was a European response! Not only that! A considered European response, made in a short time, considering that we have been talking about it since 2014, and it is an answer, above all of solidarity. Exactly the opposite of what I have heard from so many colleagues: it is not a subtraction of national sovereignty but an act of solidarity for states that are in difficulty with the great migratory flow. It is considered because it takes into account human rights, children and vulnerable people. So the European Border and Coast Guard is doing well.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Brexit campaign was conducted on the subject of immigration, and Eurosceptics and populists insisted that the European Union was incapable of effectively tackling the migration crisis. Well, the Commission and the European Parliament have worked the package of measures to improve the management and protection of external borders. I congratulate Mr Pabriks on his work.  I am of the opinion that the creation of a European Border and Coast Guard is a key legislative step for two reasons. The first is purely of principle, because in the face of such great challenges as migration, integration and cooperation in the field of border control is more effective. The second is of a practical nature, because I think it is very important to combat cross-border crime and trafficking in human beings. All this is necessary in order to protect and safeguard European citizens.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it was no wonder that Frontex struggled to make a difference last year when EU Member States were failing under the weight of the migrant flow. Due to its design shortcomings, a weak mandate and the lack of its own equipment and staff, the current Frontex is little more than a paper tiger. Although the pressure on the EU borders has subsided for the moment because of the EU-Turkey agreement, this situation can change at any time. That is why I am pleased that today we have this proposal in front of us on a border agency with more authority, more means and more power to intervene in the event of disproportionate pressures at our external borders. I would like to commend the speed at which the negotiations on this regulation advanced, as well as the modifications that make the proposed agency both more efficient, in responding to migration and the internal security challenges, as well as more accountable.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in an area of free movement, without internal borders, the management of Europe's external borders can only be a shared responsibility. It is therefore essential to create a truly integrated border management system. Frontex merely assisted the Member States in the management of their external borders. The new agency will do much more. The measures we are discussing today, including the management of our external borders and the speeding up of the return of irregular migrants and the proper functioning of the asylum system and the strengthening of controls at the European Union's external borders, are not a definitive solution, but they are certainly an important step forward. An important point of the new system is also the establishment of the European Return Office, set up within the European Border and Coast Guard structure, and it is important because it confirms the common approach of managing the flows of asylum seekers.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear President, the high pressure of migrants and organised crime on the Union's external borders has not subsided for years, and the latest migrant crisis has made it an almost permanent situation to adapt to.  The Commission clearly understood that the old rules and operational frameworks were not adapted to almost cataclysmic circumstances, so it unduly admied those Member States that were the first to be hit by the migration wave and thus only contributed to the chaos.  The time has come for a comprehensive solution.  This proposal for a Regulation, with well-developed cooperation and coordination mechanisms, clearly and unequivocally states that Member States retain the primary responsibility for managing their part of the external borders. As I support any initiative aimed at increasing security at the external borders without hampering or preventing border control to the competent authorities of the Member States, this proposal has my support.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, there is no doubt that this is a great initiative and I fully support it. It has two dimensions: the humane dimension of rescuing possible afflicted people at sea, but also the oppressive dimension towards criminals who used the situation when migrants were fleeing their countries and ending up, unfortunately, often in the waters of the Mediterranean.  However, Dear Mr Commissioner, I would like to highlight a new element of this new Border and Coast Guard Agency. And this is the fact that, for example, my country Croatia is also at the EU border today. And we need good cooperation with the candidate countries in the Western Balkans. Please note these details, find a way to at least indirectly engage these countries in the work of this agency, because as we know, the countries of the Western Balkans are "closed" to other EU member states. Please find a way to include them.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the European Coast Guard and Frontex are nothing more than instruments for deepening the federalist vision of this European capitalist integration project and its security and militaristic aspect. Expression of a closed European Union in itself, based on the concept of Europe-Fortress and which is consolidated in the outsourcing of maritime borders to third countries in the restrictions on the free movement of persons, discrimination and expulsion of refugees, another side of the xenophobic and racist agenda that characterizes your criminal migration policy and the response to the serious humanitarian refugee crisis that we witness today , a crisis whose causes the European Union has direct and indirect responsibilities with your policies of interference and aggression in the Middle East and North Africa, articulated with NATO and the United States, favoring authoritarian regimes, promoting the political destabilization of countries that confront the interests of imperialism fueling conflict and war.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – So, the coast guard is not, and of course, cannot be a miraculous means of resolving all the problems facing the European Union in resolving the refugee crisis, and I hope that, of course, the Commission has examined all the impact assessments of this solution. So that it is aware of the importance of creating integration and cooperation between Member States in the implementation of this instrument, because we know that Europe or the Member States sometimes have difficulty in implementing what the Commission accepts. And I think here, of course, it raises quite a few questions: from the demarcation of responsibility between the Coast Guard and the authorities of the Member States, to, of course, also the issue of, of course, accountability, because the concept of shared responsibility is absolutely problematic. Either the concept of responsibility is clearly defined or, of course, it is not.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: Madam President, in the face of the migration flooding that Europe is suffering from, the Union refuses to recognise the failure of Schengen. Once again, she is fleeing forward by strengthening European integration, as her federalist dream crumbles with Brexit today and the victory of the FP- in the Austrian presidential election tomorrow. The EU wants to replace Frontex with a European border guard agency. Officially, this new agency will help states monitor their external borders on a voluntary basis. In reality, the Council and the Commission will put pressure on them, starting with Greece, to force them to let the agency act in their place. This is another unacceptable attack on national sovereignty. The Union even goes so far as to impose the presence of liaison officers in all Member States. However, they are representatives of the agency who are responsible for spying on them and forcing them to implement the Union's migration policy. States will thus be subject to a real guardianship.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, first of all, to the rapporteur of the report, I would like to propose, well-intentionedly, that he study the correct meaning of the words 'irregularity' and 'illegality'. Let's consider this: if someone enters their home without their permission, when they call the police, what will they report? That someone entered their home illegally or irregularly? The report is a dangerous breakdown of the national sovereignty of a Member State. On what grounds, for example, will the new agency intervene at the internal and external national borders of a Member State without its consent?  What exactly do you mean by "external border management" when you have been deaf for years to the challenges of the Turks in the Aegean and the occupation of part of Cyprus? Illegal possession, not irregular possession? In the end, with every report coming to the vote, it turns out how right Brexit supporters were when they shouted "we want our country back." Every time the devotees of most Europe plan, the Member States lose their national independence. Every regulation and common policy, especially on the issue of illegal immigration and asylum, has proved to be a complete failure and has led to more uncontrolled illegal immigration, and those responsible for the current situation continue to plan on paper, instead of going home, to rest now.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, there is one issue monopolising the interests of the newspapers and news agencies around Europe, but last week’s events also created a sort of depression to many who lived, dreamed and fought for European integration. Well, we should get rid of this mood. What we need, and what citizens are asking for, is a more efficient Europe.  The European Border and Coast Guard is exactly this. It is a success story, a real achievement, the result of six months of negotiations since the moment this Commission put the proposal on the table. It is the creation of an agency that will have the task and the means to support all Member States in managing the Union’s external borders. It is the creation of a system that will prevent another crisis such as the one we experienced last year. It is the actual recognition that the external border of one Member State is the external border of us all and that managing the European Union’s external borders is indeed an EU shared responsibility. As regards the concerns of some for the United Kingdom’s taxpayers, let us be accurate. The United Kingdom gets back a rebate for all Schengen-related initiatives.  Can you imagine how the situation would have been if we had done what we are doing today two years ago. Understand that the situation we have now is different. Yes, during this period we learned a lot – not only us in the Commission but also Member States. So you were right, Mr Kyrkos, when you said earlier that we have learned our lessons. But what are the next steps now? I look forward to you adopting this political compromise tomorrow. It will be a moment of shared satisfaction and we should enjoy our success. On this point, I would like once again to express my warmest thanks to our rapporteur, Mr Pabriks, and the shadows for this really tremendous work.  Secondly, we as the Commission will support the new Presidency and the Member States in their efforts to make the agency operational the moment the regulation enters into force. Thirdly, we need to go out there and communicate to the citizens this successful outcome, a success story of a political Commission that delivers what its President and all of us promised when elected, a European Parliament that truly defends the rights of European citizens, and a Presidency with the political will to respect the commitment of Member States and to find ways to facilitate the negotiations. This is the Europe we need to communicate to our citizens.  Now, allow me to slip into Greek since some of my compatriots have asked me some questions.  Κυρία Πρόεδρε, αγαπητοί ευρωβουλευτές, αυτή η συμφωνία που επετεύχθη για την ευρωπαϊκή Συνοριοφυλακή, είναι πραγματικά ιστορική και ιδιαίτερα σημαντική. Στην πράξη, αναγνωρίζεται ότι τα εξωτερικά ευρωπαϊκά σύνορα, είναι κοινά μας σύνορα και ότι η φύλαξή τους, η διαχείρισή τους, είναι κοινή ευρωπαϊκή ευθύνη.  Ακούστηκαν πολλά, ήθελα απλώς να σημειωθεί ότι όχι μόνο δεν θίγεται καθόλου η εθνική κυριαρχία, αλλά αντίθετα, αυτό το καινούργιο Σώμα θα αποτελείται από στελέχη όλων των ευρωπαϊκών χωρών και θα έχει την ευθύνη για ολόκληρη την Ευρώπη, και αυτό εννοούσα πρωτύτερα όταν σημείωσα απαντώντας στον κ. Κύρκο, ότι πόσο διαφορετικά θα ήταν τα πράγματα αν αυτό το Σώμα υπήρχε δύο χρόνια πριν. Θα είχε αντιμετωπιστεί διαφορετικά η προσφυγική κρίση, θα έχει τύχει καλύτερης διαχείρισης και θα είχαν διασφαλιστεί και προστατευθεί πιο αποτελεσματικά τα κοινά ευρωπαϊκά μας σύνορα. Σεβασμός, λοιπόν, στην εθνική κυριαρχία.  Η νέα ενισχυμένη Αgency θα συμβάλει τόσο στην πρόληψη, όσο και στην αντιμετώπιση μελλοντικών κρίσεων. Δεν θα επαναλάβω όλες τις καινοτομίες, τα πλεονεκτήματα που έχει η ευρωπαϊκή Συνοριοφυλακή και Ακτοφυλακή, θα τονίσω όμως ότι είμαι υπερήφανος που η πρόταση που κατέθεσα έξι μήνες πριν, γίνεται πραγματικότητα. Μετά από εντατικές και ιδιαίτερα δύσκολες, πρέπει να σας πω, αλλά αποτελεσματικές διαπραγματεύσεις, ανάμεσα στους ευρωπαϊκούς θεσμούς, ανάμεσα στα κράτη.  Αυτή λοιπόν είναι η Ευρώπη που αντανακλάται από αυτό το κοινό μας αποτέλεσμα. Η Ευρώπη της ευθύνης, της αλληλεγγύης, της δράσης· η Ευρώπη που όλοι θέλουμε ως ευρωπαίοι πολίτες· η Ευρώπη που όχι μονάχα θα αντέξει και θα ξεπεράσει κάθε κρίση, αλλά θα συνεχίσει να δυναμώνει, διασφαλίζοντας τη σταθερότητα, την ασφάλεια και την ευημερία των πολιτών και των κατοίκων της. COMMISSION'S STATEMENT "The Commission welcomes that the co-legislators maintained the appointment of the Executive Director by the Management Board on the basis of a shortlist drawn up by the Commission following an open and transparent selection procedure, as foreseen in the Common Approach on EU Decentralised Agencies. However, the Commission regrets that the agreement reached by the co-legislators deviates from the Common Approach as regard the appointment process. The Commission sees no objective reasons for this deviation which could affect the autonomy of the agency. The modalities of appointment of the European Border Cost Guard's Executive Director should therefore not be considered as a precedent for other agencies' founding acts."

name: Artis Pabriks
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the debate showed here in Parliament that the majority of our colleagues really understand the work that has been done in the last few months. Indeed this work was done in a collegial way between three important institutions: the Council, representing the Member States; the Commission, and the European Parliament. I think it is important to say that we have been working in a very collegial way because we understand that either we win together or we will lose separately, and this is one more example to European citizens that we can do this job. Indeed, this agency will not be a silver bullet and it will not solve each and every issue in the European Union, but we must notice and we must understand that this is a highly important fundamental piece in the larger puzzle of our European Union policy, with these big global challenges. As regards the opposition, I would say that I notice the opposition is coming from both sides, or margins, of this House. One side is immediately saying the European Union is needed while the other side, unfortunately, is dreaming about paradise, but in some way it is also allowing the lives of refugees and also the lives of their citizens to be dreamed away. As one politician in history said, sometimes the road to hell is paved with good intentions. Let us work for now, for today, and let us make the European Union and our countries better today, and here, and not dream about something which is extremely difficult to prove and reach. What is next? I expect, and we all expect, that the Member States will immediately join and make this Agency capable and efficient and ready to work in the next few months. Good luck to all of us.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 6 July 2016. Written declarations (Article 162 CRP)

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. – The Schengen area, currently made up of 26 Member States, is one of the greatest achievements of European integration. It allows the free movement of persons, goods and services. Terrorist attacks, but also the poorly regulated movement of refugees, still put him under enormous pressure. The challenges of guaranteeing internal security and order in the countries of the European Union relate to the ability to consistently protect our common external borders. Schengen has literally been subjected to fire testing in recent years. Speeding up the creation of a common European border and coast guard is literally a necessity for maintaining it. Consistent protection of external borders is not a panacea. However, it is an important part of the mosaic in the effective management of migration. So is the detecting and punishing of smugglers making money from human misfortune. It is also our shared responsibility. The Slovak Presidency of the Council of the EU also places emphasis on the creation of a European Border and Coast Guard, while preserving the sovereignty of the Member States. In particular, people and sufficient material equipment of the new reinforced agency will be important. Up to 1500 border guards from individual Member States should create a kind of rapid response force. Continuous monitoring of external borders is essential in order to identify and eliminate their weaknesses.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Border and Coast Guard Corps will provide integrated European management of external borders, which should help to preserve the integrity of the Schengen area. Thanks to the work of the group, the initial proposal has been greatly improved. Search and rescue missions, the referral of people seeking international protection to EASO, or the development of tools to better inform migrants arriving in the EU will be part of the new agency's mandate. It will not be able to adopt return decisions on its own initiative, nor will it be able to coordinate operations to return from one third state to another. Moreover, the transparency of its activities should be strengthened, as it will be directly accountable to the European Parliament and the Council. In this way, it will have to report regularly to MEPs, including on its cooperation with third countries. Finally, I welcome the establishment of a complaint mechanism, which may lead to disciplinary action against agency staff members who have committed human rights violations. While full legal responsibility would have been preferable, it is a first step forward to better protect the rights of migrants.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. – I consider the European Border and Coast Guard to be a key EU instrument for controlling our common borders, which the EU has long lacked. The recent past has shown us that without this common guard, the Schengen area cannot function and thus bring benefits to European citizens. However, I see the added value of eu guards not only in ensuring secure borders and effective migration management, but also in a more effective fight against terrorism or serious cross-border crime.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I consider it important to adopt a regulation on the European Border and Coast Guard. This is a task, not only important, but also urgent, as in 2015 alone the number of illegal immigrants to the EU exceeded 1.5 million people, and this year it is already several hundred thousand people. The creation of a European border guard is intended to improve the effectiveness of the fight against this illegal immigration. The emerging border guards should be based on the current Frontex and much better cooperation between Member States in the protection of the UNION border. The regulation foresees that the number of European Border and Coast Guard personnel will gradually increase from 225 posts in 2016 to 1,000 in 2020. This is, of course, the right direction, but simply increasing the number of posts and financial resources is not enough. The efficiency of the new guard and the speed of decision-making by its management will be of paramount importance. The point is that the European Border and Coast Guard should support countries that are not coping with the influx of illegal migrants as effectively as possible.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the recommendation for the second reading of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection concerning the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting the European Parliament and Council Directive on measures to ensure a high common level of security of network and information systems in the Union (05581/1/2016 - C8-0188/2016 - 2013/0027(COD)) (Rapporteur: Andreas Schwab (A8-0211/2016)).

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I am pleased that, three years after the Commission came to Parliament with its original proposal for a cybersecurity strategy and the proposal for a cybersecurity directive, we can conclude at the end of a long process. I would like to thank all those who have contributed to the creation of this proposal: the shadow rapporteurs, the colleagues from the other committees, Mrs Pilar del Castillo Vera, especially, but of course also the European Commission and Commissioner Oettinger. I think it is a wonderful moment today to be able to discuss the adoption of this directive here in plenary, after we signed the public-private partnership for cybersecurity here over here in the other building in the European Parliament this morning and the Commission came out this week with its communication on greater cybersecurity. The road since 2013 has been marked by many elements which, in my view – and I think I can say this for the European Parliament as a whole – have led to a better proposal overall. It is a good thing that is done wisely, they say in German, and it is, of course, the case that in the last three years there have been various incidents that have made the citizens, but also the competent authorities in the Member States, think about whether we in Europe are actually up to the challenge of cybersecurity. We all no longer only use our mobile phones to make calls, we no longer only use the computer at home to send e-mails, but we find that the digital world has penetrated much further into our areas of life and, at the same time, we have not mapped the element of security in these services to a sufficient extent, at least not in Europe. There was the incident on the French TV5, there was the incident at the Sony Playstation, there were many other incidents. Unfortunately, many of the incidents we have seen in recent years will not be directly covered by the European directive. But there are also incidents such as the mobile operator in Austria – the country from which you come – who could not avert a several-hour-long hack of a cyberattack and where, therefore, the telephone lines were not reachable for several hours, and we have seen the Polish airline LOT, which had to leave its aircraft on the ground for several hours because corresponding digital map materials were also hacked. These two examples will no longer be possible if the directive is adequately and correctly implemented, if, in any case, we oblige the providers of critical infrastructure that operate across borders in future with the directive to take more care to ensure that such incidents can no longer occur. This is an important step, because it will allow the people, the citizens of Europe, who will end up most affected by such attacks, to hope for greater security in the future. A second point was the big question of so-called platform legislation. Can we also include large Internet platforms in the scope of this network and information security directive? We have had a hard time in this as a Parliament, but in the end we have ensured that we have found a very pragmatic, results-oriented way, which I believe also meets with a great deal of support in the economy concerned. That is why I believe that together we have found the right way forward. That is why I am very curious to hear what colleagues have to say about this.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you, Mr Schwab, also for your specific examples. I can well remember what it was like in Austria when the net simply stopped working.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which it has been Three years ago, the Commission first started a cybersecurity strategy to Europeanise data security. With the directive we are debating this evening, we have made a concrete mark-up for legislation. I would like to thank Mr Schwab, but also Mrs Vicky Ford and Mrs Pilar del Castillo Vera, for their excellent, constructive cooperation. The current draft is better than the one tabled by the Commission. What is it all about? All of us – citizens, in the field of social media, in the area of search engine use, industry, the use of data storage, data centers, digital infrastructures – need trust – trust against industrial espionage, against hacking, against disruption and destruction of digital infrastructures and their data. Confidence only returns if you create security, security through technology, hardware and software, and through the corresponding specifications that you develop in industry and which the policy can then determine accordingly. That is what we are doing here. Our mission as a digital union, the creation of a digital single market, needs confidence – in cloud computing services, in search engines, in online platforms. With today's consultation, we are building trust, we are creating a European standard, a European culture for cybersecurity. We have established a partnership with the industry in recent weeks. Today, many companies and many associations and many scientific institutions have been here in Strasbourg to develop a cyber PPP, which will be endowed with Parliament's money from Horizon 2020 with EUR 450 million. The industry adds three times the amount. The European Cybersecurity Organisation (ECSO) is the platform on which industry can be found. By also involving Europeans, we are making start-ups and large people, also industrial policy, and creating for them the opportunity with their hardware, with their software for cybersecurity orders of tomorrow and thus customers of tomorrow and thus jobs for tomorrow. The NIS Directive focuses first and foremost on sensitive infrastructures: energy, transport, banks, financial markets, health. It also dictates to The Member States what to do at national level, i.e. platforms with industry at national level, security requirements, appropriate authorities – a cybersecurity authority at Member State level. With ENISA, the European Union has a body that coordinates, moderates and advises everyone accordingly. I think that this is a major step forward for Europe on the road to the highest level of digital security. We are currently considering whether certification makes sense, i.e. whether we should certify companies that offer hardware, cybersecurity software, so that an energy company, a bank with the certificate, can broadcast trust to customers, can guarantee security. All in all, this is an important step forward.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, I would first like to acknowledge the magnificent work that Andreas Schwab has done as rapporteur, but also the extraordinary work, thrust, dedication and intelligence that Vicky Ford has applied as chair of the Committee on the Internal Market. The Commissioner has said this now and I repeat it again in other words: network security could say that this is something like the core of users' confidence in the digital environment. And that's why cyberattacks need to be controlled and they have to have immediate answers and answers provided. Let me tell you that this is a magnificent example of the value of acting together, of the value of the European Union as a space in which different countries act together. This is the kind of added value — directives like this — that Europeans want to see, answers to today's problems and tomorrow's problems. In this sense, really, it is an unequivocal contribution to the matter in this global world, that joint action matters and that, on the contrary, fragmentation, isolation, do not lead in this global world to solve anything.

name: Nicola Danti
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur and also thank my fellow shadow rapporteurs for the good cooperation we have had in this long and a half year of negotiations with the Council and the Commission. It is precisely the chronicles of recent years and months that remind us how much Europe needs to make up for lost time on the road to creating an area of security, intelligence and threat prevention. The online environment is now a new playing field where terrorist groups and new forms of organised crime challenge our freedoms and rights and put our economic and social relations at risk.  This directive is the first ever attempt to establish Cooperation at European level in the field of cybersecurity and to ensure the security of strategic infrastructures and major digital service providers. The text that I hope we will adopt tomorrow is a distance from the position voted on by Parliament at first reading. We would have liked more, but once again national self-interest and the reluctance of many Member States to cede powers where national sovereignty is maximum has certainly reduced the initial level of ambition of this proposal. However, I am truly convinced that the compromise reached provides a good basis for gradually shaping new common rules and strategies.  The creation of obligations for national authorities and strategic operators and the definition of two levels of cooperation between Member States, one strategic and one operational, based on the Community method, will make it possible to have an ever-increasing level of integration.  And finally, a point, which Commissioner Oettinger has already made: the European response to the issue of cybersecurity will finally give an important boost to the establishment of the digital single market, which is a strategic objective of this Commission and which is based on public and consumer confidence in an online environment, and safety is therefore an essential factor.

name: Vicky Ford
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, cyber-security is a real issue. Cyber-crime knows no borders and international cooperation is needed. This report will help EU countries to work together to prevent and detect network disruptions in critical infrastructure like banking, energy and air traffic control. Member States will set up their own expert teams, share early warnings of risks and learn from each other’s experiences. National security will not be compromised, as Member States will not be forced to disclose sensitive information. Online companies were concerned about bureaucracy if they needed to report the same incident 28 different times, so we have a light-touch, common approach agreed to address this. It has been an extremely complex and sensitive negotiation, which has taken three years to agree. As we negotiate our new UK-EU relationship, I hope space and time will be given for us to continue to work together, when necessary, on security issues such as this.

name: Antanas Guoga
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank all the colleagues who really put in an enormous effort to get this done, especially my learned colleague, Vicky Ford, who was simply wonderful in this whole negotiation. This directive is a very important step forward. A lot of parliaments are waiting on it and ready to implement it. I am hoping that it will improve cyber security and network and information systems in Europe. It is obviously not perfect, but it is the best that we could do under those trying circumstances. Cyber security is essential in today’s European digital economy and society. When people and businesses use and make the most of connected digital services they need to feel that they are safe and secure. So we did achieve a very important step forward for that. The internet knows no borders. A problem in one country can have a knock—on effect in the rest of Europe. I hope that Member States will soon acknowledge that cooperation and information exchange between each other is a key element that will help us tackle the increasing number of cyber-attacks.  I would like to congratulate the Commission on a new public-private partnership agreement on cyber security. That is also a very important step forward. We need investment in this area – a lot of investment, multiply it – but it is a very important step. Keep going. Let us all work together and keep moving Europe forward.

name: Mylène Troszczynski
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the numerous recent cases of data looting and cyber-attacks against large groups, large sectors, but also government agencies, including French ones, call for swift and concrete responses and call for vigorous action. Beyond the damage in terms of data sensitivity, the damage caused by cyber-attacks around the world is estimated by the Commission at EUR 500 billion.  Cybersecurity is a key issue for European governments and peoples. It is therefore equally important to organise voluntary cooperation of nations based on information exchanges and best practices. I stress heavily that this cooperation is voluntary. Cooperation between European neighbours is essential and natural. The ENF group supports the strengthening of national security and defence capabilities for networks and information systems. On the other hand, I deplore, in Chapter 3 of the well-named report, the failure to withdraw the desire to establish a binding supranational system of coordinated declarations and operational responses in response to cyber security incidents. The text also provides regular evaluations of national policies in this area. This far goes beyond the reasonable framework of cooperation, which no longer becomes voluntary, but regulatory and binding. Once again, the text sins by dogmatism. The revision of this text appears necessary, but with the sole objective of strengthening the security and defence capabilities of the networks and information systems of European nations. What is a matter of national security cannot be regulated by Brussels. Let us not hide behind sound objectives any political agenda that would threaten the effectiveness of the text if it were adopted.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE).
text: – I would like to join my fellow Members who congratulated the reporter, Andreas Schwab, for doing a great job. We have really had important discussions that have enabled us to create a European culture of cybersecurity. This environment is important because our citizens live in a digitised world: health, finance, but transport and many more sectors. And we need to gain a sense of security so that they feel that they are moving in this environment and that they can use these tools. It is also important that Member States take appropriate action. As the Commissioner said, we can build infrastructure, involve all the companies that are most affected. We do not need to take exaggerated steps, we must take proportionate steps so that we can take the right step in a good way.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, a high common level of network and information security in the European Union has already been said here is a necessity. I would like to congratulate Colleague Schwab, Nicola and all the other rapporteurs on their work, behold, for three years and finally, following the negotiations, we have a compromise text which we hope will bring about improvements and concrete measures to improve security. Of course it is not a perfect document, because there is still room for improvement, but we have enough things that lead us to the idea that we have a good report and a future directive. I believe that it is a balanced report, that it takes into account data protection and the need for communication between states of information and network security. A high common level of security in the Union is a necessity.
