The fact that obligations are laid down for Member States in this Directive as regards the prevention and management of risks affecting networks and information systems is also a good thing. In this form of the report, the Directive clarifies the way of strategic cooperation between Member States through a cooperation group composed of representatives of the Member States, the Commission and the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security. The Directive sets out obligations for operators of essential services and digital service providers. I support this report and congratulate my fellow rapporteurs. I believe that we have taken an important step, it is to be seen how it will be implemented concretely in each Member State and, obviously, also follow the effects of the application of this directive. Thank you very much and we hope that the Schwab report will be voted on in this form.

name: Lara Comi (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his excellent work with the Commission as well. I believe that cyber-crime is today one of the most insidious threats globally, with an increase on an annual basis certainly decisive and at the same time even greater than the measures we are taking. Think that in recent years, cybercrime has been playing an increasingly important role in the risks that citizens, businesses and governments face. But the media attention is always on the government aspect and on multinationals. But we do not consider or consider very little of the impact they can have on small and medium-sized enterprises and consumers. For this very reason, I believe that it would certainly be useful to try to increase the size and share more information, including at the level of small and medium-sized enterprises and citizens, who are indeed our consumers and the people that we must protect in the first place.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Schwab, and all those who have been involved in the preparation of this directive in recent years. As we have heard, this has been a very challenging directive and it has been very challenging to move the negotiations forward. Cybersecurity is an area which, of course, requires common regulation and common standards at European level, especially as we seek a common digital single market more closely. At the moment, we know that member states' capabilities and preparedness for cybersecurity vary greatly, and that means that the preparedness of the whole of Europe is inadequate, because we can only be as strong as the weakest link in this system.  Initially, the Commission proposed key service providers, energy, transport, banks, financial markets, healthcare, within the scope of this Directive. Later in the negotiations, the supply and distribution of water and digital infrastructure have also been added. It can be assessed that these areas are justified, and it is precisely for key service providers that we must be able to ensure that we operate safely throughout Europe.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – Madam President, congratulations to Andreas Schwab for the great job. The Network Information Security Directive is key for European security. It supports a level playing field across the EU. It describes in a broad way the significance of critical infrastructure and the network between national CERTs managed by ENISA. It requires more cooperation between all stakeholders and among Member States. It is not easy for implementation and we see it. It is time to say that although security is under national competences, cyber security, because of the nature of the cross-border internet, should have a European, fully-harmonised  policy in the future. This is also the opportunity not only for better security, but for cyber-security business development and innovative digital economic growth. I appreciate very much, established by the Commission and partners today, the contractual Public Private Partnership. It will strengthen resilience and the cyber-security industry. It can bring us more understanding of the cyber-security problems, raising the awareness issue, and more practical, business-oriented solutions.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – On my part, too, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteur and, of course, the European Commission, which together with you has produced this document, this directive on cybersecurity. Today, we have talked a lot in this House about security in a wide range of areas, and with military, energy, food security, we must, of course, be aware of the importance of cybersecurity today. The world is changing, technologies are changing, and in the future it is expected that very big developments are expected precisely in the area of these technologies, around which we say that we need protection. Surely it is necessary to have in sight here on the one hand such powers of the state, but if anywhere, this area is what ... an area which knows no borders, these borders are invisible and therefore such a joint activity is also required. The Common Energy Union is ... digital union is our great opportunity. We'll use it if we can protect this area well.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the security of network and information systems is essential for the functioning of societies, as well as for the existence of a reliable environment for trade in services worldwide. However, information systems can often be affected by incidents such as human errors, natural phenomena, or attacks, thus endangering security.  Of course this can cause serious financial damage for a company and more generally for the Union economy. Furthermore, the frequency of such incidents and the inability to ensure effective protection undermine public confidence in network and information systems and for the Digital Single Market.  Therefore, each Member State of the Union should have appropriate mechanisms in place to prevent, identify and address risks in network and information systems. At the same time, each Member State should set up a task force to deal with it emergencies in order to ensure network security.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, this cybersecurity directive is one of the best examples to show that the time for those advocating the dismantling of the European Union is actually passing. Because, ladies and gentlemen, today news and information are no longer being passed on to the horsemen as some might like. It's very different today. Internet networks know no borders. In this context, high cybersecurity is essential for our economy, for what security within the EU means, but beyond. The security of hardware, software, cyber infrastructure that we need today is just as important and even more important perhaps than electricity or water supply, because this supply is being resolved, and here we can have unseen negative consequences.

name: Christian Ehler (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I would just like to remind you once again that today we are coming to the conclusion of a ten-year process, a process, so to speak, which has brought about a gradual Europeanisation of the subject. Ten years ago, the Member States in this Parliament stated that ICT may not be a European infrastructure, but that national protection schemes are needed. Five years ago, in bitter night negotiations with a Commission that was finally convinced, we negotiated the money against the Council, so that the means were available to tackle these very phenomena, but also to have sufficient resources, both industrially and in terms of research, to be able to meet this completely new world of challenges. In this respect, it is a very good example of how the European institutions were initially sceptical, but are now calling for the European institutions, which need money and see what an additional European benefit it is to have this NAS programme today.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which it has been I have listened carefully to what you have said and I am grateful for your agreement. I believe that we have discussed this evening an important step that can increase data security, but which also shows that national strategies are pointless in the digital sector. The Internet is global, and between America and China, only Europe is of sufficient size. We are creating a culture of European data security for the citizen, for industry, for trade secrets, for social media, for everything that is going on in digital networks and storage. And we will implement this directive together with the Member States, we will strengthen the sensitivity to data security wherever possible, we will give the necessary support to our cyberweb partners to industry with concrete projects from Horizon 2020. I am grateful to Mr Ehler for mentioning how it has developed over the last ten years. All I can say is that today we have had over 100 representatives of European science and industry from almost all the Member States, and everyone is behind this project. And we will revise, develop, deepen our cybersecurity strategy, which dates back to 2013. In other words, the legislation that will be adopted tomorrow is one step, and the strategy that can be further developed is the other step. That is where we stand by, and I am happy to be interested in the involvement of Parliament and the leading Members.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The debate has already been clearly summarised. An important sentence from the debate, which I would like to repeat, is: 'Europe is only as strong as our weakest link'. That is why, of course, comments from the outside world are here, the European Union is too much of a mistake, and it is out of place here. Only if we succeed in ensuring that all Member States are able to achieve a comparable level of preparedness against cyberattacks will we, as the European Union as a whole, be safe in the end.  That is why the word trust, which needs to be strengthened, is certainly the key word. I would like to remind you that the Council of Ministers, in particular the Luxembourg Presidency, was crucial in this. We see today that they are not here again, but this time I can say positively that they have played a really positive role in this legislative process. I believe that we, together with colleagues, will now be watching closely how ENISA coordinates operational cooperation, how strategic cooperation works with the 28 Member States, how we can finally transpose the NIS directive, but also the strategy that the Commissioner has mentioned, into national law in such a way that added value is actually created across borders. , that we do not duplicate things, but we coordinate them in such a way that the digital infrastructures that run across borders end up strengthening national security in the Member States and thus throughout the European Union. This will be an important task, especially as we have recently seen THAT NATO has also made cybersecurity an essential main objective of its work. In this respect, it will be important for the European Union and NATO to come a little closer together.  All this will be pursued because we want European legislation to actually benefit the citizens who depend on such critical infrastructures by 2018 – until this directive is transposed.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 6 July 2016. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. –  Recent political developments in Europe have proven that our continent, our Union, our countries need visionary and responsible leadership. Recent events have proven that peaceful living at home is not a given and that remaining secure should be a top priority. In the world of digital committed leadership means timely leadership. I welcome the adoption of the NIS Directive, but it would have been even more welcome much earlier. Indeed, time has only increased the need for it, as around 80% of European companies have experienced at least one cybersecurity incident over the last year. A flourishing economy is a prerequisite for responsible leadership, I am glad that the latest adjustments to the text favour small- or micro-entrepreneurs. As the backbone of our economy, we need to encourage them to further explore and expand the digital economic model. A responsible leadership also means stronger together and intense collaboration. The NIS directive establishes a ‘Cooperation Group’ between Member States for the purpose of supporting and facilitating strategic cooperation and developing trust and confidence. High coordination and optimal use of the new mechanisms are key for fostering a secure, innovative and tech-savvy Europe. This is the Europe I choose to live in.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by thanking you for inviting me to address the plenary on the importance of the synergies between structural funds and Horizon 2020. Unfortunately, as you know, Commissioner Crețu, cannot be with us today, but she asked me to speak on behalf of both. Although synergies have been under discussion and debated in this House for many years, Horizon 2020 is the first research and innovation framework programme that clearly and explicitly refers to synergies with the European structural and investment funds. Indeed, the regulation that set up those funds converted synergies from ‘nice to have’ in past programmes into a ‘must have’ in the current programmes and in the smart specialisation strategies. From wishful thinking, synergies are now on the ground. I do not feel I have to remind you why synergies are so fundamental. The more synergies we can achieve between structural funds and Horizon 2020, the more impact we can expect for jobs, growth and investment from funding at all levels, be it national, regional or European. Recently our services published and distributed to the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) and the Committee on Regional Development (REGI) Members a brochure entitled ‘EU funds working together for jobs and growth’. The brochure showcases many concrete examples of synergies and also highlights initiatives with high potential for synergies, talking about the Romanian competitiveness operational programme or the innovation projects in North Rhine-Westphalia, or the joint Portugal-Spain nanotechnology laboratory, or the flagship Extreme Light Infrastructure in the Czech Republic, Hungary and Romania, or the BONUS programme in the Baltic Sea. Another practical manifestation of synergies on the ground is of course provided by a new successful instrument. We called it the Seal of Excellence. The Seal is a quality label granted to projects submitted to the SME Instrument and Horizon 2020 which succeeded in the highly competitive evaluation but could not, unfortunately, be funded under the available budget. These high-quality projects can then look at alternative funding at national or regional level, and since the launch of the initiative in November, all the expectations were exceeded. My colleague Corina Crețu and I have signed more than 3 200 Seals of Excellence, originating basically from all Member States, and at the same time, we got more than 100 funding authorities representing both the cohesion side and the research side to actually be mobilised and work together on designing and implementing measures to support the Seal of Excellence proposals. So let me also inform you that we realised huge efforts to sort out some discrepancies between the Seal of Excellence and the state aid rules that are now almost solved and will not be creating any more bottlenecks. They are helped in this Community of Practices, which is a platform that was set up by the Commission to facilitate the exchange of experiences and mutual learning to identify and target specific needs and possible obstacles for smooth implementation. I consider the Seal of Excellence to be one of the major achievements of this year, and it is really a big success that was unexpected. But the question is: have we actually done it? Do we have more to do? I think we have a lot more to do. Synergies are a little bit like the simplification process. It is ongoing work. We will have to keep going. We will have to keep on trying more and different. That is why, turning now to the future, we will of course improve and continue to expand the existing synergies – like, for example, expanding the Seal to other areas of Horizon 2020, like widening or the Marie Skłodowska-Curie Actions. In the future we also want to involve our JTIs in that process to explore more synergies based on the excellent work that has already been undertaking by the Clean Sky, that maximise the impact of their projects through tailor-made synergies with regional interests in aeronautics. In that respect, I think that Clean Sky is a model to be followed by other JTIs. But let me touch now on a number of points that Commissioner Crețu intended to draw to your attention, starting with the smart specialisation strategies. These strategies were required to combine from the outset ERDF- funded projects in initiatives with Horizon 2020 in order to actively include actors that, with Horizon 2020 projects in management in entrepreneurial discovery processes, could do much better, and ultimately it was just shaping the research and innovation strategies for smart specialisation. The Commission is continuously assisting Member States and regions in the development of their smart specialisation strategies, notably through the Smart Specialisation Platform based in Seville in Spain. The aim is threefold: to accelerate the implementation of smart specialisation strategies; to facilitate transnational cooperation among the regions; and third, to set up a series of thematic smart specialisation platforms. So far we have in place three of those platforms: one on energy innovation, a second one on industrial modernisation, and the third one on agri-food. These platforms and others in the future will help in ensuring effective use of available structural funds and leverage additional resources from Horizon 2020, but also private funding and EFSI. This thematic smart specialisation platforms approach follows a good example that was developed by the Vanguard Initiative, which succeeded actually to move cooperation between 30 regional governments around innovation in concrete value chains to matchmaking with businesses and research actors. We are also setting up a European strategic closer partnership for smart specialisation investment in support of the thematic Smart Specialisation Platform on modernisation ensuring real participation from business. Finally, a very quick word on the Stairway to Excellence: the initiative here in Parliament with a pilot project that identifies potential for synergies in certain Member States, including the adoption of Horizon 2020 management tools. The need for an ongoing entrepreneurial discovery process involving businesses and research and exploiting transnational cooperation between all the countries. A series of 11 national events dedicated to the project have already taken place. This project is going to be widened soon to other Member States to deepen the synergies there. I shall leave you with a quote from Stephen Covey, who used to say that synergy is really about better than my way or your way – it is actually our way. So thank you very much and I am looking forward to the discussion.

name: Christian Ehler
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I believe that today's discussion on the joint resolution on synergies between the European Structural Funds and Horizon 2020 in the field of innovation is an important signal. Basically, this is the start of the discussion on a next MFF. Basically, this is also an answer to the question: what should Europe do, what can Europe do for citizens, for innovation and for growth? In this respect, today's discussion is an important starting point and not a technical discussion on the budget. Innovation is of paramount importance for social development, for the economy, for the advancedevelopment of Europe. We have cut back in the field of innovation in recent years, we have set other priorities, and we have also paid bitterly in many areas. In this respect, I think that this discussion is important for the understanding that we cannot solve certain problems – for example, the EU13, where we can talk for years about the distribution of innovation funds – if we do not address fundamental structural issues, if we do not also use the Structural Funds to reshape the old Academia system to a certain extent, so that the successful and excellent researchers also have the structural conditions. to get financial resources. In this respect, the European Innovation Council envisaged by the Commissioner is perhaps also a link for discussion in the future and of important importance.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, achieving the 3% of GDP in R&D&I target by 2020 is economically possible: more than 80 billion in Horizon 2020 and more than 120 000 in the Funds. But we need to know how we can align these funds, and that is the question we are asked and asked, and especially the Member States themselves: how.  You have pointed out certain good practices that would need to be disclosed. I also wonder whether it would not be necessary to review whether regulation as State aid to funds is the most appropriate and does not hinder their interaction with the Horizon 2020 programmes. And I also believe that it would be necessary, inter alia, to facilitate the connection between the institutions and smart strategy programmes which they have been developing in relation to the priorities set for them in innovation by the Commission itself with research, with public and private centres.  This and other measures that you have appointed I believe could be the subject of a communication that makes clear guidelines.

name: Ruža Tomašić
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, a group of European conservatives and reformists supports synergies between structural funds and Horizon 2020 with a view to creating added value and maximising the impact of investment.  Horizon 2020 is an important programme for the future of the European economy, as it has the ambition to transform it through innovation and scientific excellence so that it is more in tune with the challenges of the new time and more resilient to the potential impacts of the future. I will take this opportunity to say that I am disappointed that horizon 2020 funding funds have been partly repurposed to finance the Juncker Investment Plan, which has so far failed to deliver the expected results. We believe that some new denial of funds to Horizon would be extremely damaging and would drastically affect the results expected of this programme.  The European Union must set its priorities, and long-term programmes to foster scientific excellence and innovation for the stable economy of the future should be ahead of short-term grandiose policy plans that stand on shaky feet from day one. However, we are of the opinion that cohesion policy funds in this financial period should not be used to finance Horizon 2020, as this would potentially jeopardise another long-term important Union policy.

name: Matthijs van Miltenburg
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Europe needs to invest a lot of money in research and innovation. This leads to economic growth, but also to new jobs.  But the fact is that Europe is lagging behind other parts of the world when it comes to spending on research and development. This means that we must make every euro invested in the European budget pay off as much as possible. That was also the message from President Juncker when he took office. In his State of the Union address last year, he promised us to increase the impact of European investment in research and innovation. Subsequently, the Commissioners, together with Commissioner Creţu, announced a quality mark of excellence to improve the quality of research funding, the seal of excellence.  Unfortunately, in my view, it has been too much for a Juncker promise, a quality mark and a handbook, and in practice we see too little of the promised enlarged impact. Companies and knowledge institutions are presented with great opportunities on paper, but the implementation in practice remains very difficult. For example, it remains difficult to combine the use of Horizon 2020 and the European structural and investment funds to finance one large ambitious project.  I would very much like to see concrete measures from the European Commission to simplify this. As far as I am concerned, these measures should not be concocted in a Brussels office this night, but they must be formulated together with practical experts. A little less from above, a little more from the bottom. More synergy between Horizon 2020 and other funds is not an end in itself, but it is important to use the available money as best as possible in the case of a tight budget. Let us now move on to this issue in the years to come. Let us ensure that investment in research and innovation generates as much growth and jobs as possible.

name: Younous Omarjee
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, Commissioner, we have been calling for these synergies between the Structural Funds and the Horizon 2020 programme for a long time. But we must still ensure that the principles of cohesion are safeguarded and that the least developed regions, the outermost regions too, are not deprived of the benefit of these Horizon 2020 funds. We must ask ourselves why so many small project owners and less developed regions have so much difficulty accessing Horizon 2020. No doubt we think of programs that are too big, and there are probably problems with complexity as well. I believe that the best synergy must move forward with the simplification project, and we are waiting for the return of the working group that has been set up by the European Commission.

name: Ernest Maragall
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, we welcome, Commissioner, this search, which we share, for synergies. The concept of synergy seems to me to be very positive. In fact, right now, we have in our heading 1 of the budget the two concepts: cohesion, and employment and growth, but they are silos, they are practically ships that sail alone, which are not spoken. Research programmes seek excellence, justifiably, and cohesion policy, on the other hand, has often become caught up in an attempt to fix real social problems, but with little responsibility and real result. Even today we see instead how high-speed trains are financed without passengers or airports without travellers, too, and we see how FEIE still today continues to finance projects such as high-speed motorways, mobile vehicle motorways in Germany and other countries. It is very good that the Commission wants to overcome this silo division and wants to promote cooperation and synergy between programmes, such as the pilot I promoted two years ago, with the concept of economic convergence between regions, which is in the implementation phase and which is behind some of the proposals and comments you made to us today. But we must also be clear about the risks that lie behind that policy, in that action. We must prevent the EIE Funds from taking risks that do not belong to it and, moreover, we must prevent this legitimate search for synergies from being the gateway to a policy which the Commission is, it seems, considering, that of a simple change of instruments, of grants allowance. We therefore value your explanation very much, we value successful experiences and the silo of excellence, but we need long-reaching policies shared with States, regions and cities, not just marketing operations.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the synergy between Horizon 2020 and the Structural Funds may be useful, but we must be clear on how to implement it. The Structural Funds are aimed at capacity building, responding to the needs of the regions that need them most, with shared management at national and regional levels. Horizon 2020 is aimed at achieving excellence at EU level. The crucial difference between the different funds is that, while the amount of structural funds is in one region, it is to be expected, as it receives 7-year support, horizon 2020 funding is provided on the basis of competitive criteria. So the fact that a given project receives support is far from certain.  From a practical point of view, synergies make sense to allocate unused resources in an operational programme, to allocate them to a project of excellence that has failed to receive funding with Horizon. Ladies and gentlemen, however, we must point out that the hypocrisy of a European Union which, on the one hand, calls for investment in research and innovation and, on the other hand, takes a good EUR 2.2 billion away from Horizon and allocates it to projects of the Juncker Plan, which are of dubious use, are sometimes incompatible with the objectives enshrined in cohesion policy. This means that a very dangerous path has been taken towards an increasingly two-speed Europe, towards an ever deeper rift between more and less developed states.  So let us not be surprised if we see the reaction of the people against the European Union. In so doing, we are in fact renouncing the very idea of Europe.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE).
text: – Thank you for the good examples you have given, but it can, no, do better with the synergy between Horizon 2020 and the other funds and instruments. 90% of Horizon 2020 investment ends up in the old Member States. 80% of Europe's structural and investment funds go to the new Member States. They are two separate necessary and important funds, but they seem to be two separate worlds. It is not good that many young people are moving away from the new Member States and benefiting more, where others are stagnating. Europe nevertheless stands for balanced development and good territorial cohesion.  Brexit more or less showed the consequences of two separate worlds: booming City of London, lagging countryside and faltering mining and industrial areas. These people turned their backs on such an EU.  That is why we are now calling for a new innovation-driven design in the midterm review. Strengthen the chain of knowledge, innovation in products and services across Europe. You can do that. We already have the ESI funds with EUR 60 billion for innovation and smart specialisation, as you say. This week, Robert Madelin presented his "Mission to Innovate", an innovation pact, a new way of working together. Our resolution and your idea for the European Innovation Council will be made in time for that update.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is clear that we are discussing a policy that is already having its act today and also with considerable resources. Between structural funds planned by individual regions and national authorities, we are around 100 billion investments in research and innovation and 80 billion are concentrated on Horizon 2020. We are therefore faced with a package of significant and substantial resources to strengthen investment, to relaunch innovation, especially for our companies, for our research centres, also for our start-ups, new companies, new companies, especially young people.  The subject we are debating today is something concrete, on which it is perhaps also worth taking a closer look over the coming months and years, on how these two funds are interacting and, at the same time, also to write a page on the future. To create the conditions for greater complementarity and interaction between the two realities, for example: by ensuring, as you partly started as the European Commission, those companies and companies that do not make use of regional and Structural Fund resources.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The intended objective of synergies between Horizon 2020 and the Structural Funds was to enable some Member States to use the Funds to achieve scientific excellence so that they can fully exploit the potential of Horizon 2020. It must be made clear: this objective has not been achieved. The gap between Central and Eastern and Western Europe is widening. Thirteen new EU countries received only 5% of the total budget spent in Horizon 2020. Effective synergies are a result of action on the part of the Member States, but also of the European Commission, which regulates issues related to the permissible level of state aid and the audit of implemented solutions. In addition to the differences in the level of funding between Horizon 2020 and the Funds, competition requirements, evaluation criteria and the language in which applications are submitted are also different. The Seal of Excellence tool does not work to the extent envisaged due to the European Commission's failure to adapt existing regulations. Divergences between the two programmes prevented the introduction of the assumed automatism. We therefore expect the Commission to make concrete proposals for the necessary changes so that this objective, which the Commissioner is talking about, is achieved.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE).
text: – The resolution on the table is a good example of how we can work more efficiently. This is a good opportunity to achieve synergies between the Structural Funds and Horizon 2020.  I am also very pleased that the current text does not compromise the integrity of both programmes, but does demonstrate their complementarity. Horizon 2020 supports scientific research according to the criterion of excellence, but the budget is not sufficient to support all promising projects. The seal of excellence ensures that the structural funds can easily and quickly identify and support them, a good example of synergy. For me personally, it is very important that SMEs in particular make use of this. That is why we must reduce the administrative burden. This is an excellent opportunity to support science, stimulate innovation and thus ensure prosperity and employment in the future.

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. We have a mid-term evaluation of Horizon 2020 ahead of us, as well as preparations for the 9th Framework Programme. It is therefore important to look at the issue of spending in the Horizon 2020, as well as in the Structural Funds, especially as regards the differences in participation in the 'Horizon 2020' of the so-called 'thirteen' countries and the rest of the Union. This has already been mentioned. First of all, it is about spending the Structural Funds on major investments in the future, not just spending them efficiently, while completing the European Research Area and implementing the Europe 2020 strategy. Two examples of what could be done: the compatibility of Horizon 2020 and the Structural Funds is necessary, for example, state aid is allowed in the Structural Funds, but not in horizon 2020; smart specialisations are a funding criterion in the funds, but again not in 'Horizon 2020'. Among other things, the "seal of excellence" mentioned here does not work as well as it could today, so uniform standards are needed for all instruments. Finally, it is important that there be greater openness of research networks to participants from thirteen countries, greater geographical balance in expert and advisory groups. I am convinced that synergy will allow us to correct these shortcomings.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we agree with you, with what you have said and also with the proposal of the European Innovation Council, and we are all aware that today the key words for the effective use of European resources, especially in such a strategic area as research and cohesion policy, are synergy, complementarity and thematic concentrations on priority issues. In short, all those crossed and combined modes, so to speak, that allow the use, for the same project, of different funds and programs that also respond to different logics of temporality but that our capacity must put together, in order to achieve good results, on territorial development projects, on the development that intersects with digitalization, on industrial and competitive research , the enhancement of technological excellence, etc. However, I fear that, as my colleague Mrs Cabezón Ruiz said, all these new avenues of work, which we appreciate you putting in place, there is still not enough widespread competence where they need to be implemented. That is why we need to provide a little more technical assistance, making those good practices known and helping to move in this direction.

name: Искра Михайлова (ALDE).
text: – Dear Madam President, when discussing the issue of synergies between the European Structural Funds and Horizon 2020, we are actually discussing the issue of the coordination and synergies of European Union policies across the European Union. This is a discussion that identifies the general need for synergy and complementarity between investment instruments, for growth and employment, investment for innovation and development.  But when we talk about such synergy, we cannot only consider synergies at European Commission level and additionality at programming level. We need to take into account synergies at programme implementation level, synergy at territory level, synergy at the level of complementarity of individual projects. Synergy that could deliver real results, such as increasing employment and jobs in the European Union. Growth and employment – that's our goal.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the Commission gives theoretical guidelines for establishing synergies between the European Structural and Investment Funds and the Horizon 2020 programme. These funds are endowed with a lot of money, but the effectiveness of the programmes lies not in the amount but in the good management, which consists in eliminating duplication and strengthening links.  It is therefore necessary to promote excellence in the areas of intelligent specialization, combining different programmes in the same project, in successive projects and in parallel projects, also solving problems to promote synergies. It cannot be that aid, co-financed by the Structural and Investment Funds and managed at the national level, is considered State aid when directed at actors engaged in economic activities, because doing so prevents these actors from eligible for Horizon 2020 funds.  On the other hand, SMEs are essential to achieve our objectives. Europe, our Europe, needs more innovative SMEs to generate growth and jobs, and our Europe is not only Brussels or Berlin, it is also regions such as the Canary Islands or Murcia, whose lands have leading projects in agri-food or energy and do so thanks to local companies that, with European funds, create jobs and windows to progress. Ladies and gentlemen, the knowledge society demands more than a simple sum of the activities of the economic sectors and it is our duty to assure all Europeans that not a single euro of which the Union allocates to its projects is wasted due to bureaucratic duplication, and synergies between funds will always be our best ally to achieve this.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner very much for mentioning the Extreme Light Infrastructure (ELI) project, not only because he inspired me to completely change my speech, but also for mentioning that there is a successful story in Europe where the synergies between structural investment funds and Horizon 2020 create miracles.  The ELI project is now being developed in Hungary, the Czech Republic and Romania. The project is not only the largest and the most advanced complex to be developed in eastern Europe, but is at the same time the most advanced and fundamental research in the world. This will change the destiny of Europe, transforming it into a leading power in the physics of high-powered lasers. The ELI project in Romania, in Magurele, will host up to 600 researchers from all the EU Member States and the rest of the world and will transform into something similar to CERN. This is why I welcome the synergy and I welcome synergies and union being spoken about in my country. This is good because we have an example.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: – Madam President, you are also deeply involved in working with us in the Science and Technology Options Assessment (STOA) Committee and we have a target to deliver for the next generation up to 2050. So how can we invest in research, innovation, upscaling, acceleration and spin—offs? I think Europe has to deliver wealth and I do not think it is good if we have a debate about how we can deliver poverty to everybody because poverty to everybody would mean that we should not do anything.  But the truth is that Horizon 2020 and the Structural Funds are a wonderful package to give the right framework for those who want to deliver and create new jobs and wealth.  The truth is that we are in a global world and we have to look forward to the think tanks of this world to see how we can help people who want to be self-employed to create their first job. The Horizon 2020 programme with the financial facility could deliver what we want to have.  Therefore it is very clear that smart specialisation should get new jobs into the right dimension. Education and vocational training will play a key role and we will do our utmost to support the Commission in coming up with this new concept.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, science is building the future, cutting-top science comes from cooperation, and scientific achievements must not stop at national borders. Research and innovation will immediately stimulate the economy and improve industrial competitiveness well into the future.  Horizon 2020, the world's largest science programme, will help Europe move towards a smarter and more sustainable society. In particular, I would like to mention research support for the bioeconomy, the post-fossil era and the digitalisation that is changing Europe. I would also like to thank the Commissioner for his personal commitment to the regional bonus programme in the Baltic Sea.  It is a really bad idea to cut back on research and innovation money. Neither Europe nor the Member States should cut the EU's future growth potential. When the horizon was launched, a balance was already considered, and science should be supported on the Horizon according to quality criteria. In this competition, Europe is in a global battle. Cohesion money is needed to create regional equality, and there is room for this too. When the number of programmes is in the speech, we can also consider policy synergies.  Finally, Mr President, Britain is perhaps leaving the European Union, and that is a very important part of European science. We must be vigilant in the future about how we protect science and keep Britain involved in the European scientific community.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – We have already spoken at this meeting about the Youth Initiative. The President of the Commission has said about the results in the field of efsi. Today we are talking about Horizon 2020, we are talking about cohesion funds. That is, we are talking about the tools at our disposal, so that, on the one hand, we are dealing with poverty, backwardness in Europe, and on the other hand, we also want to make a development breakthrough in those places where Europe has great pro-investment. Smart specialisation is now in some way applied on similar principles to horizon, and when we observe these results and when we see that the old members consume 95% of Horizon, I see that we have problems in this area. Therefore, on my part, Honourable Commissioner, the request that the Commission also provide an organised assistance to the new members so that they can activate both cohesion policy and, on the other hand, Horizon, because otherwise this solidarity principle will not be enforced in Europe and we will have major problems in the future.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, there is indeed an important impact of synergies between the different forms of European investment on national economies. This is also what makes investment policy in science a form of cohesion policy for European regions.  In this regard, I would like to ask the Commissioner how can the Commission think about penalising Member States by accessing European funds? Are we not facing the subversion of cohesion policy itself and leaving science, now we know, in the hands of Ecofin? How is it possible that after the very hard austerity imposed by the Troika for four years in Portugal, it is even thinking of penalising the country because it failed 0.2 % of the fiscal pact in 2015? How do we explain to the Portuguese that there is now a leftist government to be punished for not fitting the neoliberal vision that has marked the European Agenda? Words have weight, Commissioner, and your colleagues should know that. Portugal is already being penalised. The markets heard him. Ecofin too.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Synergy is a nice word. It means combining efforts and resources instead of dispersing them. We live in a Europe that has a very diverse level of innovation in the economy, as well as different methods of catching up, different ways of reaching for European funds. Van Nistelrooij talks about it. North and West mainly reach for Heading 1a, i.e. competitiveness. The south and the so-called new – not very new – countries mainly reach for cohessia. But nothing prohibits cohesive countries from spending a significant part of their resources precisely on research, development and innovation, but that this group of countries, as part of what we call 'catching-up', solves a different problem of synergies than that identified in the joint motion for a resolution. This is the synergy between funding universities, research entities and institutes and business. Such synergies should be particularly rewarded in the distribution of structural measures in poorer countries.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the European Union must be more concerned than ever with identifying mechanisms and levers to express European solidarity and, at the same time, to reduce economic and social disparities at Member State level. Cohesion policy as a whole is the instrument that the Union has at its fingertips in achieving these important objectives. Beyond its flexibility and adaptation to new realities, it is important to have further enhanced synergies between the five Structural Funds, but also with other important programmes in the field. Particular emphasis needs to be placed on research and innovation, on developing and strengthening the position of SMEs, with a view to capitalising on the results achieved so that the number of jobs increases and Horizon 2020 offers multiple opportunities in this regard.  Last but not least, the simplification of procedures, the clear rules for the application of financial instruments and, in particular, the transparency of the allocation of these funds must be a priority for the Commission. This must provide a guarantee that the funds will be accessible to all Member States to the same extent.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, Horizon 2020 supports the Europe 2020 strategy and aims to boost innovation and research in order to achieve sustainable development in the Member States of the Union. The European Commission has already approved EUR 16 billion in funding for 2016-2017, which includes the modernisation of the European manufacturing industry, with funding of EUR 1 billion, as well as the circular economy with EUR 670 million of funding.  At the same time, this programme aims to improve the regulatory framework for supporting new technologies, to revise state subsidies and to finance small and medium-sized enterprises. Given, however, the high unemployment in some Member States of the Union and in particular in Greece, there is a need to increase the funds allocated to innovation, research and development, as well as the need to increase public and private investment.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Dear President, synergy must be a very nice word. I often like to use it in my political speeches, too. But here I'd like to express some kind of caution. Namely, we are clearly short of money in Horizon 2020 and will find it in structural funds or cohesion policy. That's why I'm saying caution. Then let's get another player in the game. Let's insert the European Investment Bank, insert partly the Juncker Fund to support many projects that are essential and funded by structural funds and are essential for cohesion countries and for infrastructure development in new Member States. Let's find a creative formula and create synergy from multiple sources, not just these two sources because it won't be enough. We're just going to pour the money over and we're going to miss the money where we really need it.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the Commission is here today to talk to us about synergies between the Structural Funds and Horizon 2020. The same Commission, which has been on the agenda for months, has imposed unacceptable and illegitimate sanctions on Portugal, sanctions which include the freezing of structural funds and fines. Portugal, the country that was a net contributor to the 7th Framework Programme for Research, namely the predecessor of Horizon 2020, that is, the country that has been funding the science of the rich for years, including some who are now calling for sanctions. Put one thing in your head once and for all: the people Portuguese are lord of their destiny and do not live with their hands outstretched before you. What Portugal receives from the European Union in structural funds is largely surpassed by the outflow of capital from Portugal to the European Union in the form of interest, profits and dividends. It is not only the pressures and blackmails of the European Commission that are illegitimate and intolerable, it is also the real extortion to which the people continue to Portuguese. It's time to say enough, enough submission.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: – Madam President, just as in fairy tales about young children, we know that good always wins only when people are united, the same motto should be had here for Horizon 2020 and for cross-financing between individual financial instruments, namely: all hands on board, together we succeed more.  What do I mean by that? With a budget of around EUR 80 billion by 2020, Horizon 2020 has huge potential to combine with cohesion policy funds worth around EUR 350 billion. It turns out that with the available resource, with sufficient flexibility, we can finance at least one good idea from each European, or almost as much. But there is a catch – very often we do not know how to combine funding, the processes are too complex administratively, and often we do not know the needs of individual beneficiaries. As regards the funds from the European budget, we need a healthy mix of funding: a balance between grants and financial instruments. Both are sides of the same coin. Whether we will be able to combine some of the 500 operational programmes from 28 Member States with almost 26 horizon management bodies remains to be seen. I'm sure the good examples will multiply.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this has been a very interesting discussion – I would say because of three points. The first is that we all agree on the importance of synergies in terms of having better science and better innovation. The second is that we agree that we have delivered on various projects and instruments, and the examples speak for themselves. Thirdly, we also agree that we have to do much more, that this is ongoing work, teamwork that we have to keep doing, and it involves Parliament, the Commission, the various services, the people and the national governments, and we will keep doing it. We need more synergies in order to think really out of the box, and to be able to create different instruments to deliver different results. You have my commitment and that of Commissioner Crețu that we will keep on working very hard on delivering more of the kind of examples we have talked about today. But we need your help, and I am extremely glad of all the support, all the examples cited and all the questions. So rest assured that all the points raised here today we will feed into our work and our thinking. Thank you for all the ideas that came up, which complement our own ideas and are a way of getting us all together in the same boat. Thank you all for the discussion.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. – In order to implement research and innovation policies, in January 2014 the EU launched the largest research and innovation programme, Horizon 2020, which brings together all funding in an integrated programme.  On the other hand, Horizon 2020 is also the first programme to expressly refer to the need for synergies with the European Structural and Investment Funds, such as the Competitive Operational Programme in Romania.  It is a good sign to hear that, among the proposed initiatives, the Commission wants to extend existing synergies, and the Marie Skłodowska-Curie actions would be a good start. Why is that? Because the programme provides grants for all stages of the career of researchers (either PhD students or experienced researchers) and encourages transnational, intersectoral and interdisciplinary mobility; enables research-focused organisations (universities, research centres and businesses) to host talented foreign researchers and create strategic partnerships with leading institutions around the world.  So today we are at the right time to develop synergies between the Structural Funds and Horizon 2020 in the current programmes and in smart specialisation strategies, and I welcome the Commission's intention to deepen existing synergies and start new ones such as Clean Sky.

name: Barbara Kudrycka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Europe's problem is not so much the lack of funds for innovation, but the lack of coherent rules for spending them, synergies between different funding streams. Horizon 2020 was a hope for an innovative leap. After two years of implementation, you can see how much needs to be improved in order for this jump to be noticeable. Low success rates are worrying – at 13.9% throughout the programme and up to 6% in some parts of the programme. Hundreds of innovative projects are therefore in a vacuum! To counter this, the European Commission has created a Seal of Excellence. Projects that have not received funding due to a limited budget receive the certificate for the highest rated projects in Horizon 2020. The "seal" is intended to be a pass for structural measures for them. But it's now a check without coverage. The Structural Funds distributed at national level have state aid rigours that are not available in Horizon 2020. The authors of a project with a 'seal of excellence' must therefore prepare a new proposal, taking into account extremely different requirements and criteria. The project budget is very often rebuilt, as the Structural Funds offer a different level of support than Horizon 2020. Creating a new proposal and reassessing it is a long and costly process. Can we afford to delay innovation like this? I call on the European Commission to exclude 'Seal of Excellence' projects from the rigours of access to the Structural Funds, otherwise this instrument will remain only in the realm of beautiful-sounding platitudes and rhetoric.

name: Michael Cramer
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to express my sincere thanks to the Commission and the Council for their good cooperation. Since the original report did not find a majority in our committee, I was appointed as chairman to represent the committee and to participate in the trialogue. The trialogue has been successfully concluded and the amendments that I have tabled together with four other groups bring the EMSA regulation into line with the trilogue results. In doing so, we ensure that EMSA continues to fulfil its previous tasks and that maritime security concerns do not fall into the background. I look forward to the discussion.

name: Alain Cadec
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, thank you also to the Commission for being here. Ladies and gentlemen, the vote in my report on the cooperation of coastguard functions is simply a victory. Since 2011, I have been calling for the cooperation of the coastguard to make the European Union more effective in dealing with crises at sea. Crises at sea can be multiple: marine pollution, illegal fishing, influx of refugees on dangerous boats. In all these cases, when I first proposed European coastguard cooperation, my aim was not only to prevent disasters, but also to enable the European Union to act in a coordinated and effective manner. We have identified 316 civilian and military coastguard authorities. Until now, this fragmentation has prevented joint actions and the exchange of information. Now the three European agencies - the European Fisheries Control Agency, the European Maritime Safety Agency and the European Border and Coast Guard Corps - have complementary mandates that obviously increase the European Union's response capabilities at sea. The agencies will coordinate the 316 authorities responsible for coastguard functions. We will improve the European Union's capacity for action, and I believe that is what European citizens want today. Agencies are now pooling their capacity for action and information systems and are working in a coordinated way to rescue at sea and prevent illegal immigration. Their mandates are expanded; they support all national or local authorities responsible for coastguard functions through the sharing of human resources and operational resources. Through this decision, we create real synergies between agencies to provide more efficient services, also in terms of costs. In 2015 and 2016, the European Union came under intense pressure at its external borders. Over the past two years, it has become clear that the Schengen area without internal borders is only viable if external borders are effectively protected and guaranteed. This is only possible with joint, solidarity and accountable action by all Member States. Thanks to the cooperation of the three agencies to support the Member States in the protection of our borders, we are building a Europe that is more united because it is more responsive, more efficient and safer. I would also like to point out that we are just expanding the mandate of the European Fisheries Control Agency. This Agency retains its primary, of course, fisheries control missions in Europe in order to ensure a common fisheries policy that effectively fights illegal fishing. On the other hand, the Agency can also be mobilized in the case of other crises at sea. Europe is becoming faster, more efficient and more coordinated in border control.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission welcomes the revised proposal on the European Maritime Safety Agency (EMSA) and the European Fisheries Control Agency (EFCA) that we will be discussing today. We are very grateful to the Chairs of the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the Committee on Fisheries, Mr Cramer and Mr Cadec, for their excellent work. In good understanding with the Dutch Presidency, the European Parliament has managed to negotiate this text in record time. I understand that it was sometimes a procedural headache. I am therefore very glad that the co-legislators succeeded in retaining an identical text on coastguard cooperation for all three agencies involved: EMSA, EFCA and also Frontex, as the Commission had proposed. This is an important achievement. The three agencies will now be mandated to cooperate on an equal footing, as has been stressed by the Chairs. They will be provided with a firm legal basis and additional resources to implement operational activities with great European value added. This cross-sectoral approach will allow synergies between the agencies, and in particular it will allow jointly planned surveillance operations, streamlined sharing of information and coordinated capacity building, as well as enhanced surveillance and communication services based on state-of-the-art technology, such as remotely piloted aircraft systems. The agencies will now be equipped to make a decisive contribution to reinforcing European capability for maritime security and surveillance, including the protection of EU external borders. As was extensively discussed earlier this afternoon, the refugee crisis is one of the biggest challenges for the Union. Our agencies will do their part in addressing this challenge, contributing to the new European Border and Coast Guard and saving lives. In his latest State of the Union speech, before this plenary, Commission President Juncker stressed the importance of developing a fully operational European Border and Coast Guard system. Last April, Parliament adopted a report on how the EU should respond to the current migration challenges. The report discussed the search and rescue operations at sea and praised the contribution of merchant shipping. It also acknowledged the responsibilities of Member States and of the EU for organising a permanent response. At this point I would emphasise that the enhanced services to be provided by the agencies will also serve fully other objectives: maritime transport safety, security and environmental protection, as well as fisheries control, which are the respective missions of EMSA and EFCA. The agencies are ready to act. The resources the EU has invested in them represent an excellent use of our limited budget. We strongly believe in their capacity to help us find efficient solutions and coordinate our efforts.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner Bulc, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Commissioner Bulc, for the work she has done on this report. Common problems require coordinated solutions. This is generally the case when it comes to dealing with the refugee crisis, and in particular with regard to the associated dramas taking place on the open sea. Coordinated cooperation between the existing EU agencies is long overdue. I am therefore very pleased with this good proposal from the Commission, which provides for cross-cutting cooperation between the European Maritime Safety Agency, the European Border and Coast Guard Agency and the European Fisheries Control Agency. To date, more than 300 authorities in the Member States are taking over coastal surveillance tasks in various areas such as security, security, search, rescue, border control. In dealing with the EMSA proposal, we attach great importance to each agency contributing to the support of national authorities within its sphere of competence; Overstepping of competences must be avoided. Nor must the cooperation of the agencies affect the rights and obligations of the Member States as flag, port and coastal states.

name: Czesław Hoc
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab These are the two European agencies that control fisheries and maritime safety, to ensure a uniform and effective level of maritime safety in the European Union, to prevent pollution, to respond to threats from oil and gas installations, to ensure sustainable fisheries, to protect all living resources, to protect fishermen, etc.  What did I remember them from? From arbitrary and highly overzealous control of fishermen and a special penchant for harassing Polish fishermen. These agencies, on the other hand, sat quietly during the construction of the political and highly environmentally harmful Nord Stream gas pipeline, both 1 and 2, as well as during the installation of wind farms in the places of the best fisheries and spawning grounds. I have not seen them in the fight against feed fishing, which, among other things, has led to cod drama in the Baltic, etc. Now, at a time of migration crisis, we are creating a European Coast Guard Agency based on the existing Frontex agency, based in Warsaw, for which the two agencies are to support and assist in the coordination of activities. This time we will be keeping a close eye on them. In the credit of trust we will not be against.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, sharing control of external borders, ending tragedies at sea, requires a European Border and Coast Guard which we must provide with means to live up to its mission. By coordinating the means of geolocation and monitoring available to us at EMSA and EFCA, taking advantage of their knowledge, we will learn much more about how the sinister business of people smugglers works, we will be able to better plan the attendance of people arriving in Europe, avoid tragedies and prevent and prevent inhumane actions against people who are fighting their lives at sea to reach this continent. Until we can stop the conflicts and poverty that drive people out of their places of origin, we need to put all the material and human resources at our we have to know what is going on, sort the situation and prioritize the rescue of people at risk. With the safeguards and guarantees incorporated into the agreement, this objective is guaranteed. And that is also the aim of Amendment No 1 which we hope to adopt tomorrow. It has been agreed between the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs, details the scope and limits of this collaboration and ensures that these agencies can continue to carry out their main mission and ensure that each aspect of the collaboration agreements is approved by the supervisory bodies of both agencies.

name: Tania González Peñas
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, for my group, the european Parliament's show on the European Border and Coast Guard is a totally undemocratic spectacle.  An absolutely ad hoc process has been created, with an 'supercelerated' procedure for this occasion, which prevents a minimal analysis of the consequences of the new border control model in the medium and long term.  Because here we are not simply talking about inter-agency cooperation, but is a proposal to put the resources of the European Maritime Safety Agency and the European Fisheries Control Agency at the service of border surveillance and control tasks, within the framework of the repressive policy being jointly promoted by the Commission and the governments of the Member States.  We would have liked amendments to be accepted on the safeguarding of human rights or the implementation of democratic control mechanisms, but this has not been the case and we would like to see a vote against this report tomorrow.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we note that we will in fact vote on a text negotiated by the Commission and the Council, since there has been no real involvement of the shadow rapporteurs and therefore of the political groups. While we welcome the inclusion of the reference to the defence of individual national sovereignties and the strengthening of cooperation at European level, we must say that there is a lack of work in relation to the general reform of Dublin, the reallocation of migrants or the possibility of creating humanitarian corridors to reach our continent safely.  Italy and Greece are experiencing this problem closely. My city, Taranto, together with other cities in the South welcomes thousands of migrants in hot spots. We can also coordinate transport and safety, safety at sea, and it is good to improve monitoring through satellite systems technologies. But all our efforts will be in vain, if not hypocritical, if we confine ourselves to the coordination of work alone without real political sharing of responsibility. The risk is that the same countries will always face the migration challenge and that public resources will continue to be squandered here.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, you keep talking about democracy, except when voices are raised against your dogmas. What a wonderful example! We are going to vote tomorrow on the Kramer report when initially this report was the Arnautu report, where I have clearly demonstrated that the creation of a new Frontex agency is just another smoke and, obviously, this has bothered you. Endorsing European uniforms under the sole tutelage of European authorities, not to deter illegal immigration, but to facilitate it, is obviously not the solution, but to wait a little longer for the sovereignty of nations. You are blinded by your falsely generous ideology and new damned of the earth, uprooted, will come to enlarge the cohort of millions of unemployed Europeans or will serve as low-cost labour. You stubbornly refuse to hear the scolding voice of the peoples of Europe, as you still do with the vote of the British people. My report is completely scanned. For you, it means democracy. For me, it is the repeated rejection of the will of the people and, of course, we will vote against it.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, inadequate external border controls have proved to be one of the european Union's biggest problems in the past year. In this respect, I am very pleased that this legislative package, the border management package presented by the Commission in December, has so quickly been able to negotiate with the Member States and the European Parliament, and we are now able to reform legislation on both the Maritime Safety Agency, the Fisheries Control Agency and the establishment of a Border and Coastal Control Agency. This is a truly important step at European level, because we know that we will only be able to secure freedom of movement within Europe and the functioning of the Schengen area when we have a good and good external border control.  It has proved that border controls, maritime safety, search and rescue and environmental protection are currently carried out by more than 300 different authorities in the Member States. It is not necessarily enough to flow information, even within a Member State, between the authorities. In this respect, it is now very important that policies are reformed so that information flows between different authorities throughout Europe and, on the other hand, it is possible to utilise common data, reduce duplication and, above all, pool knowledge, pool resources and increase joint operations. All this means that we will be able to guarantee a functioning internal market within the European Union, freedom of movement, and, on the other hand, we will be able to intervene in people smugglers and save people from drowning deaths.

name: Renata Briano (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the many national authorities, which act as coastguards, are responsible for many tasks, in very different areas, such as safety at sea, rescue at sea, border control, customs controls, fisheries and environmental protection.  But there is still no real system of cooperation. That is the problem. There are delays and gaps to be filled, such as pooling information on the competences, powers and capabilities of other authorities, increasing the limited number of operational resources, sharing resources and filling gaps in joint planning and operations.  Thanks to this proposal, maritime surveillance, prevention and control operations will be coordinated at European level, in order to improve knowledge of the maritime situation and to support coherent and effective actions, including from the point of view of costs. This cooperation today is crucial in the current migratory context. The strong migratory flows facing the European Union call for a strengthening of material and human solidarity.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, there is no doubt that 316 national authorities and intergovernmental structures are not accustomed to cooperating and exchanging information effectively in order to achieve the purpose for which it was created. The current formula proposed by the Commission, whereby the European Fisheries Control Agency and the European Maritime Safety Agency cooperate with the newly created European Border and Coast Guard Agency, is an experience seeking to strengthen cooperation, certainly with difficulties, in my opinion, in a first phase, since the agency that will be the beneficiary of these services from the two specialised agencies , with tradition and efficiency in their field of interest, absolutely needs. This European Border and Coast Guard Agency will be created and need expert expertise, as the difficulties of the beginning and the challenges to which it is subjectwill will not allow it to cope on its own. The exchange of information, the possibility of electronic reports or the monitoring of high-tech vessels, the expertise in combating illegal fishing in the protection of the marine environment will be effective and useful to the new agency created but, certainly, where appropriate, the other two agencies will also be involved in the management of the risks we face, migration risks and security risks.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the issue of the control of territorial waters of exclusive economic zones touches on the core of the sovereignty of each State. The Treaty of Lisbon, by establishing the management of marine living resources as an exclusive competence of the European Union, was a negative development in the usurpation of this sphere of sovereignty. The European Fisheries Control Agency comes up in this context. For a long time, some have wanted to go further and pursue the goal of creating a European Union coastguard, a supranational structure, control and intervention in the waters under the sovereignty and jurisdiction of each Member State. However, the political conditions for this have not been met until today. The wave of migration destined for Europe was the pretext they found. From a seated one, they realize an old aspiration and deepen a security and militaristic vision at the internal level, consolidating in the external level the deplorable concept of Europe-Fortress. The fisheries control agency, now integrated with two other agencies, Frontex and the Maritime Safety Agency sees substantially expanded and deepened its already negative role.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I will now tell you something about the origin of this report, apart from our criticism of the substance. As coordinator, I bought this report in committee at the time, and Mr Cramer seemed to have slept through that at the time. Mr Cramer also seems to have slackened the political explosiveness of this report, which He was probably not fully aware of at the time. Of course, this report has been designed accordingly in our political ideas. That was again, of course, not right for Mr Cramer, the Socialists and the Greens, and the report was not adopted by the committee – so far, so good. However, in a meeting of coordinators which he began 15 minutes before the meeting was scheduled, Mr Cramer decided to take this report under Rule 50 of the Rules of Procedure, without informing us in any way. Apart from that, Mr Cramer, the fact that the procedure was not particularly collegial – as you probably know yourself – it is also politically motivated and downright infam, what has happened. The problem, however, is that I am not used to anything else from this chairman, and again, this approach is deeply undemocratic. With regard to the substantive criticism of this report and EMSA, it should be noted, on the one hand, that we are opposed to creating new agencies, as they have turned out to be machines for the destruction of money. Here, for example, there will be an additional cost of EUR 300 million per year, and we absolutely reject the need for liaison officers in the respective governments and Member States to set deadlines to comply with them. This is simply unacceptable to us.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Madam President, my position is absolutely contrary to that of the Member who has surgery before. Let's put where the debate is. The debate is that the mandate of these agencies, the European Fisheries Control Agency, the European Border and Coast Guard Agency and the European Maritime Safety Agency has been extended to have better and greater coordination of all actions. I think it's a very important thing and it's a breakthrough. Duplications of effort must be avoided while ensuring that synergies are acted on in a coherent and efficient manner and that synergies are developed. I believe that this collaboration between the three Maritime Security Agencies will be good, to avoid something as important as human trafficking, for migration challenges, for humanitarian care and, of course, for illegal fishing. I am clearly in favour and believe that it is a step forward in many of the aspects.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the focus on more and better Europe passes through here. In addition to the European Maritime Safety Agency and the European Fisheries Control Agency we will soon have the European Border and Coast Guard Agency.  It is necessary to ensure that these three agencies establish a high degree of cooperation, avoiding duplication or inefficiencies. The synergy resulting from the joint action will allow them to carry out their tasks even more fully and to be even more useful as demanding coordinators of member states' action.
