I agree with the strengthening of the budget of these agencies so that they can acquire equipment, carry out sea missions and hire suitable staff. I am sure that European citizens will gladly support any initiative that reduces the possibility of other children dying in the Mediterranean while their parents seek war-free soil.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would also like to express my satisfaction and appreciation for the establishment of this cooperation between the three Agencies, born with specific tasks but in an area, maritime, where safety, both in fishing and commercial navigation, is so precious in the face of the immense tragedy of the exodus of refugees.  To prevent the loss of life at sea all resources are necessary and the fact that these three agencies, which have been demonstrating their effectiveness in their knowledge of how to avoid accidents and catastrophes, contribute their knowledge to the action of the European coastguard is, at the same time, a synergy with European added value.  However, the idea that the transport sector offers solutions to the European refugee crisis should have been more forceful, braver and definitely more useful. We would have wanted a strong, courageous bet on the creation of safe and multimodal humanitarian corridors; once on the ground, we could have avoided the painful and excessive walking marches of creatures, the elderly and even people with disabilities. I wish our European railways had been exemplary and courageous in offering routes and transport to so many families trapped between borders. Finally, a good air bridge between Greece and the capitals of the Member States, leading to the groups of refugees that governments had pledged to host, would have been much more forceful and resolute. In transport we could have helped a lot more.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the draft amendment to Regulation No 768/2005 on the Community Fisheries Control Agency is another insidious attempt to take over the sovereign rights of the Member States of the European Union. Moreover, this is also apparent from the explanatory statement, which does not even hide the intentions of the European Union. Thus, following the creation of the new European Border and Coast Guard, what is being attempted here is the creation of an umbrella through which the European Union will gain full control of the maritime areas of the Member States. All this on the pretext of better coordination between border-coast guard, maritime safety and fisheries control services.  But the Brussels bureaucracy should be aware that the Greeks have regained their sovereignty over the Aegean and the Ionian Sea after centuries of resistance and will not accept to hand over their seas without a fight to the bureaucrats of Brussels. Greece is a sovereign country, its waters are Greek and the Greeks will continue to protect them, whether they like it or not Brussels.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, the creation of the Maritime Safety Agency is another attempt by the European Union to limit the independence of states and to remove powers from them. We see that one of the objectives of this Agency is to tackle pollution at sea, caused either by ships or by gas installations, as well as to tackle large-scale oil spills. I wonder, however, how it is possible to carry out this task when it does not have the means to do so, when it does not have ships to be able to intervene and supervise.  It is also said that it will be working with the Coast Guard-Border Agency to address the risks that arise in the maritime sector, and I wonder, what risks are posed to Europe's seas and by whom? Even the movement of illegal immigrants to Italy and Greece takes place from certain areas that we know them. So what we have to see and admit is that this Agency wants to control the seas of the peoples of Europe, which will not be tolerated by them.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me thank you for this constructive debate and allow me also to use this opportunity to underline once more the key supporting role of merchant shipping and fishing vessels since the beginning of the refugee crisis. They help people in distress at sea even though vessels are neither built nor equipped for these large-scale search and rescue operations; and even though staff are not trained for this, and both the migrants and ship’s crew are at risk during these operations. It was this House that first sponsored this idea of European cooperation on coastguard functions in the area of maritime safety and ship pollution prevention, and we are not starting from scratch. For instance, the European Maritime Safety Agency (EMSA) is already working with national coastguard bodies in its area of competences. Its ship reporting systems have become today the main European platform for digital maritime services. And it already supports Member States and Frontex to address their maritime surveillance needs, to support intervention and search and rescue operations. EMSA, Frontex and the European Fisheries Control Agency (EFCA) are already working together and now their collaboration will be much improved. Thanks to the pilot project proposed by Parliament for 2016, the agencies are engaging in very concrete work to test the future common activities of coastguard cooperation. I am convinced that they will prove their work is well-prepared, and they will deliver at the highest possible level. As of July there will be a multipurpose mission of Frontex and EFCA, supported by EMSA, for border and fishery control in the central Mediterranean Sea. In the autumn, demonstration projects will be organised by EMSA and Frontex to test drone capabilities for multipurpose surveillance missions and to compare them with the use of manned aircraft. Regarding drones, the agencies are also working closely with Eurocontrol and the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) on technical and regulatory aspects. I hope that your vote tomorrow will support these two proposals which, as I have explained, will contribute greatly to addressing both the refugee crisis and the need to protect our borders. In addition, they contribute to enhancing EU surveillance capabilities in order to support – and, please, not to take over but to support – Member States in all their coastguard responsibilities.

name: Michael Cramer
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I must, of course, respond to what Mr Mayer said. First of all, I would like to say that you have mentioned my name 27 times. But a leader is not a dictator. That is what I want to tell you. The decisions were all correct. The auction system we have has given you the report. I didn't sleep that out, I accepted that, because no one offered more. That is why your group got the report. It is not for me how this will turn out in the deliberations. It was a majority decision of the committee that your report was rejected. As a result, we practically had a coordinator's meeting. How do we deal with this? Because we as a committee had no position. Then it was the vast majority in the coordinators' committee who said: OK, we appoint the chairman. Under Article 50, which was also backed up by the Legal Service, I was instructed to take over in practice. (Interjections from Mr Mayer) Just keep yourself out, I'm talking now. I did not interrupt you either. In any case, that was what we were dealing with, as we have said. I do not know whether you were present at the coordinators' meeting, but you could have appealed by the next day. You didn't do that. You probably didn't read it at all. But it is your responsibility if you do not read the documents and do not exercise your rights that make it possible. As chairman of the committee, I have behaved completely correctly. I had the support of the vast majority in the coordinator meetings and then also in committee. That was quite correct. If the content doesn't suit you, it's your problem, but it was democratic. What you are pursuing is not democratic, it is dictatorial at best, and I am fighting against it with all my power.

name: Alain Cadec
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, my name has not been mentioned, and I will conclude on the merits. I sincerely believe that this text is the foundation of a safer, but also more united Europe. By securing its maritime space, the Union is giving itself the means of its ambitions. At a time when populism is gaining ground throughout our territory, Europe is demonstrating, through this text, its ability to carry out concrete actions at the service of our fellow citizens. This report is not liberticidal, as I have heard. On the contrary, it helps to make our Union safer, with respect for individuals and Member States. We must be realistic and pragmatic, not dogmatic and archaic. I have no doubt that tomorrow a large majority of this House will vote on this report, the relevance of which has unfortunately eluded some.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her This small revision of the OLAF regulation, which we are dealing with this evening, shows that the institutions in Brussels are capable of acting. Only 12 weeks after the presentation of the Commission's proposal, the amendment is fully negotiated on the table. I would ask you to vote in favour of this tomorrow. I would like to thank the Commission, but above all the Council and the Dutch Presidency, which has demonstrated its efficiency impressively – a great achievement and recommended for imitation in the Council! The revision makes a specific but very important change to the OLAF Regulation in force since October 2013. The eight-staff secretariat of the Supervisory Committee, which was previously part of OLAF, is now removed from office and transferred to the Commission's organisation chart. So far, we have had the situation where those EU officials who worked for the five high-ranking members of the Supervisory Committee were subordinate to the Director-General of OLAF, that is to say, the very person whose management of the Supervisory Committee is supposed to be supervised. It is easy to imagine that this posed the risk of conflicts of loyalty and conflicts of interest. This shortcoming has now been rectified and it is to be hoped that this will strengthen the independence of the Supervisory Committee. This should ultimately lead to the supervisory committee being able to carry out its supervisory function more effectively in the future. In order for us to achieve an improvement in the end, it is now important that the committee is not put further and other obstacles in the way. The secretariat must therefore continue to be housed in OLAF's premises, so that it can continue to have access to OLAF's specially secured documents and to the IT system. Existing staffing and resources must also be maintained and arrangements must be made to protect officials working in the Secretariat from conflicts of interest and disadvantages in the wider career path. Tomorrow, the Commission will also make a statement pledging all these points, and we will ensure that this happens in practice. I do not want to hide the fact that this revision is also proof of a huge failure, because the fact that this revision was necessary shows that the power and omnipotence of the Director-General of OLAF had to be limited. It is sad that this revision with this content was necessary after 17 years of OLAF's existence. I consider this revision to be impressive and sad evidence of the lack of professionalism, a lack of management and the lack of fairness of this Director-General towards his staff and his supervisory body. There have always been problems with this monitoring in OLAF, but as urgent and acute as in the last 24 months, this is new. This revision responds to this, and I am very attached to everyone that they have joined in this line-up. We will therefore have to keep an eye on whether the OLAF regulation will continue to be undermined and whether the rights of the Supervisory Committee will be undermined. The fact that we have to carry out this revision is a bad sign. The pressing problems in OLAF and for the Director-General actually require immediate action by the Commission, regardless of the complaints about the immunity procedure and the Belgian investigation. After the reform is before the reform. We will have to deal with further revisions of the OLAF Regulation – not only on this point, but also on other points – namely a much-needed strengthening of the rights of the parties to the proceedings, in order to obtain greater fairness and also greater clarity on the nature of OLAF's investigations and administrative investigations with their criminal content, and also to take account of the fact that the distribution of arms so far is very unequal. I would ask you to give your assent tomorrow.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Ms Gräßle, the rapporteur, most sincerely for the effort she has put into bringing this proposal to the debate tonight. We tabled it on 4 March at the Commission and it is indeed an exceptionally fast development for us, the three institutions, to have reached our common objective. I was with the Supervisory Committee yesterday, and I would like to convey the gratitude of the Chair of the Supervisory Committee and all its members for the action that is being taken with regard to the objective of this proposal, and it will strengthen the independence of OLAF’s Supervisory Committee by very clearly separating the secretariat of the Committee and its budget from the service that they have a mandate to supervise.  I want to stress that the Supervisory Committee has been very active, and the Chair and the members of the Supervisory Committee have been exercising their authority. We do not have material evidence that the independence of the Committee has been undermined, but even the perception of interference in their independence is of course a source of concern. We have listened very carefully to the Members of Parliament and to the members of the Supervisory Committee to make sure that we are coming with a clear solution to what has been perceived as a potential restriction of their independence.  We have already placed the budget of the Supervisory Committee with the Commission’s payment office (PMO), and what we are proposing, to put it in very practical terms, is that we are now attaching the secretariat to the PMO as of the date of application of the amended regulation. This attachment will be of a purely administrative nature in order to facilitate the organisational and budgetary aspects. It will not affect the independent functioning of the secretariat, or of the committee, nor their current budget and staffing. To be sure that this is entirely clarified, it has been agreed that the Commission will make a statement to this end tomorrow, ahead of the vote on this proposal. So again, I would like to express the determination of the Commission to do everything we can for an institution as important as OLAF and its Supervisory Committee to be entirely supported in undertaking their work independently.

name: Petri Sarvamaa
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like first of all to welcome the Commission’s common sense and the rapporteurs’ steam and guts to uphold what might at first glance appear only rational, but with a closer look turns out to be a strange fight against something that we simply should not have to fight against in the first place. The important role of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) Supervisory Committee is to regularly monitor the implementation of OLAF’s investigative function. In order to fulfil this responsibility, the Supervisory Committee needs a well-functioning Secretariat. And as the Committee, also its Secretariat must be independent from OLAF; therefore, appropriate financing should be guaranteed directly by the Commission, separately from OLAF’s budget. All this is rather clear to me – and it is good that the Commission thinks alike on this matter. But as regards the issue of whether the Secretariat should be physically in or out of the same building where the Supervisory Committee and OLAF itself are located, let me be as clear as possible: what we are dealing with here is a very serious matter inside the Union. To move the Secretariat out of the building, using artificial argumentation, is another worrying signal of the state of affairs at OLAF. OLAF is supposed to be – and only to be – concentrating on activities investigating fraud inside the European Union or in the use of the Union resources. It should not be concentrating on issues like this. The effective functioning of the Committee requires constant contacts with the offices of OLAF. Therefore, it is essential that the Secretariat is placed in OLAF premises. Congratulations to the rapporteur for making sure this common sense prevails.

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, I would also like to express my satisfaction at the rapid amendment of the text of the Rules of Procedure, which seeks to reassess part of a much more complex and comprehensive problem and which has to do with the complicated relations between OLAF and its Surveillance Committee, a tension which, being historically logical and which we have also experienced years ago in this Plenary , has been aggravated lately by personal and professional implications and various complaints, which have led to a situation of such seriousness that the suspension of the immunity of the director of OLAF has even been raised, something that we will see evolve. I would also like to say that I hope that, once this independence has been regained, the Supervisory Committee will be able to devote itself again to what it has a mandate for: to defend OLAF's independence from the Commission and any of the other institutions, to scrupulously respect the recommendations of the European Data Protection Supervisor — which had not been so special lately — and to protect the procedural safeguards of those under investigation by the Olaf. I would also like to express my reservation on how, with this quick solution — which I think is positive in this way, how quickly we are trying to solve a problem with which we are going to give the secretariat of the Monitoring Committee a new status in a unit of the Commission and, at the same time, such independence that my question to the Vice-Chairperson would be how and to whom the members of the Surveillance Committee will now be responsible , because I understand that, given your mandate, it is very important that we be clear on what regularity and to whom you are going to be accountable and what your framework of action will be once you have a new location within the Commission.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, it is of course absolutely right and fundamental that the Anti—Fraud Office should always be impartial. It is of course something which must have the greatest possible credibility. Therefore, it is right that it must be independent and that its secretariat must be independent. For once in this place, I have to say that the committee amendments seem to have the most positive intention: to try to make sure that it is absolutely clear that it must be so, and to say that the Commission shall not interfere with the monitoring functions of the Supervisory Committee. So I think there is a lot that is positive in that. Whether or not that goes far enough, and whether or not we can be absolutely crystal clear about independence and no interference, of that I am not quite so sure.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the Anti-Fraud Office, OLAF, was created in the wake of the scandal that brought down the Brussels Commission 17 years ago. It was supposed to moralise the European Union by fighting fraud and corruption. It's completely missed! OLAF has repeatedly violated the rights of the defence and the presumption of innocence. Recently, the diplomatic immunity of its director was lifted at the request of the Belgian justice system. Although an oversight committee, composed of five independent personalities, is responsible for monitoring OLAF, it has so far been unable to exercise its role for two reasons: firstly because it is dependent on OLAF, which manages its budget, and secondly because the Director of OLAF refuses to let it access its data, which is scandalous. I am therefore pleased that a text today proposes to improve the independence of the oversight committee, but I believe that more needs to be done. OLAF has lost all credibility by increasing persecution and abuse of power. As a result, it would have to be abolished, even if it were to be replaced by a new body, in order to get back on a sound footing.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – The Honourable Commissioner is probably joking. We took a decision a year ago, we adopted a resolution calling, among other things, for the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, which was to be done three years ago. OLAF cannot investigate on its own. OLAF is not allowed to control commissioners, and sparrows on the roof tweet about the enormous abuses among commissioners. We have a situation where OLAF's work is paralyzed, where the head of OLAF has accusations and has had his immunity removed – at the moment it is not known whether he has been removed or not – in which the OLAF Commissioner accuses three Commissioners, a strange hit of just non-socialists, but apparently also keeps accusations against others. And you say that you took control of this situation in March. We are dealing with the issue of whether the secretariat is to be in the same building or not. When the supervisory committee is to be replaced in stages, the Commission is attempting to amend the entire supervisory committee, contrary, of course, to the assumptions. The situation requires radical action, not a discussion on where the secretariat is to be set up.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would probably repeat myself, because excellent speakers such as Mrs Grässle, Mrs Sander and Mr Sarvamaa, who actually said everything I wanted to say, had a speech before me. However, Commissioner, I would like to stress that transparency and integrity are our common priority. Both yours and your EP's.  That is why it is extremely important that we have independent supervisory bodies to ensure an objective investigation into potential suspicions of fraud and corruption. It is OLAF that is such an authority, and in order to ensure its maximum impartiality, it must be ensured that its supervisory body is truly independent and able to intervene when any suspicion is raised in OLAF itself.  That is why the function of olaf's supervisory committee and its secretariat is important to us. It must be absolutely independent of OLAF's leadership in order to guarantee this independence and transparency.

name: Julia Pitera (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The European Parliament has repeatedly called on the Commission to introduce a regulation to increase the independence of the secretariat of olaf's Supervisory Committee. The existing organisational rules have raised legitimate concerns about the possibility of conflicts of interest. This is evident where the supervisory authority is financially and humanly linked to the supervised institution. This has often raised doubts as to whether members of the Supervisory Committee can carry out their duties properly. An amendment to the Regulation was therefore urgently needed to avoid suspicions that OLAF might adversely affect the functioning of the Supervisory Committee. The transfer of the supervisory committee secretariat's resources from OLAF's budget line and establishment plan to the European Commission's budget line and establishment plan will allow such independence to be achieved. I would therefore like to thank Commissioner Georgieva for listening to Parliament's voice.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have listened very carefully to this debate, because I must say that we in the Czech Republic, for example, have a strong view of olaf's independence. This is not only a theoretical matter, but in the Czech Republic, for example, the case of Deputy Prime Minister Babiš, whose possible conflicts with legislation are currently being investigated by OLAF, is being dealt with.  And for us, it is important that this body is maximally independent and has maximum authority so that the Czech public subsequently accepts olaf's decision in the case of Deputy Prime Minister Babiš, because this case, a futile effort, will affect and affect political developments and political stability in the Czech Republic. I would therefore like to thank both the rapporteur and the Commissioner for paying such attention to this subject, and I say on my constituents' side, this is not only a theoretical problem with the degree of independence, but it is a very important practical matter that will have concrete political implications in the Czech Republic.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, OLAF is a critical service for the European Union and should therefore operate in full transparency. Thus, OLAF's Supervisory Committee and its Secretariat must finally gain increased independence in order to avoid any conflict of interest. At the same time, OLAF as a special European Anti-Fraud Office should combine transparency with efficiency in the fight against tax evasion.  Moreover, the total number of irregularities reported for 2014 amounts to around EUR 3.24 billion, while the financial impact of the irregularities reported is 36% higher than in 2013, which shows that OLAF has done nothing to help combat tax evasion by multinational companies. Therefore, in addition to the independence of the Supervisory Committee and its Secretariat, it is important for OLAF to play a more active role in combating multinational tax evasion, as well as any illegal activity taking place in the European Union.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for the comments and views expressed. There have been questions directed to the Commission. First on the Secretariat, whether it will continue to be located in the OLAF building: I want to confirm that, yes, the Secretariat will be located within the buildings that are hosting OLAF and there would be full access to information provided. Secondly, there was a question, or rather a concern expressed, that maybe the Secretariat will be absorbed in the Commission, and I just want to be very clear that we have taken seriously the question of proper allocation. We have looked at a number of possibilities from our human resources services to the Secretariat General to the PMO, and we have chosen the Paymaster’s Office because it is an office with no policy obligations whatsoever. It is a very good home for the administrative purpose of providing an assignment for the Secretariat where the budget line can be apostate and where people can be accommodated without any interference in the work of the Secretariat. The head of the Secretariat is in charge, and when we looked across the services we thought that this is the most neutral, non-interfering place we can possibly find, and this is why we have decided on it. There was a comment made that the location of the Secretariat is important, but much more important is the composition of the Supervisory Committee, and there was a call that there has to be renewal or replacement in the Supervisory Committee. Just to share, as Mrs Grässle knows very well, that we have taken this task of identifying the future members of the Supervisory Committee very seriously from the three institutions. We have recently assembled to agree on five new members that would step into their functions as the mandate of the current members expires, plus a reserve list of seven – all very qualified individuals. So we feel that now we are in a very good place institutionally to have a supervisory committee that is fully competent to carry out the job that is trusted to them. We have not been much concerned on this question of how this transition is going to take place because we have the confidence that the people that are being put immediately on the list of five and on the reserve list can, each and every one of them, dutifully serve, and in the next days this process of selection should be finalised with the good contribution of all three institutions. COMMISSION'S STATEMENT "The Commission is fully committed to the independent functioning of the Secretariat of the OLAF Supervisory Committee. The main purpose of the proposed amendment to the OLAF Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 883/2013 is to add further guarantees to the independence of the Secretariat. The implementation of the amended Regulation will be guided by this aim. As confirmed by Vice-President Georgieva to the Chairman of the Supervisory Committee by letter of 20 May 2016, the Commission intends to attach the Secretariat of that Committee, as of the date of application of the amended Regulation, to PMO. This attachment will be of a purely administrative nature, with a view to facilitating certain organisational and budgetary aspects. It will not affect the independent functioning of the Secretariat. As also mentioned in that letter, the administrative attachment of the Secretariat to PMO will have no impact on its current staffing and budgetary means. The Head of the Secretariat will be in charge of the management and appraisal of his staff. The appraisal of the Head of the Secretariat will be based on a report of the Supervisory Committee. The Commission will consider, after consulting the Supervisory Committee, putting in place appropriate internal rules on mobility limiting the duration of the postings of the Secretariat, while ensuring continuity in order to render their independence effective, and avoid risks of conflicts of interests or of revolving doors issues with OLAF. The modification of the Regulation does not affect the access of the Supervisory Committee to information such as that contained in OLAF's IT systems, databases and documents. The offices of the staff of the secretariat of the Supervisory Committee will be maintained within the building currently housing OLAF, protecting the independence of the Supervisory Committee and of OLAF while ensuring ease of contact."

name: Ingeborg Gräßle
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would also like to thank all the Members who have made comments. You are all so right. In fact, this is a complex problem, and Madam Vice-President, you are the first Commissioner who has really solved a problem now, at least trying to solve it. We have tried to resolve it, and we must not forget that today is an important new start in relations, in the possibilities of the Supervisory Committee, and this relaunch will, with everything we have done in addition, hopefully also go the right way and bring the right solutions. I would like to take up what Mrs Ayala said: who is responsible for the Supervisory Committee? Yes, us! We are his stakeholders, we are the ones who, of course, also have to see that he can work and that he is doing the right thing. That is why a good and trusting relationship with Parliament, the Council and the Commission will always be necessary.  One could well fall into philosophical reflection, if one sees the difficulties. I believe that we must now move on to the question of how we set up the office well and how we fill existing legal loopholes. This legal loophole certainly includes the Supervisory Committee's access to the documents and certainly the handing over of the final report to persons under OLAF investigations. They have to get the final report because it is an aberration under the rule of law that accusations have been made that people cannot defend themselves against. I have really learned something about this in the last few years. I believe that we really must take up some of the experience that we have now had for the forthcoming reform of the OLAF regulation, the great opportunity now also with the European Public Prosecutor and a reorganisation, and hopefully also an institutional reorganisation of OLAF in connection with the European Public Prosecutor. I do not hope that some of the shortcomings will be self-sastillated. But we know exactly where we need to go in order to achieve a real solution.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the report and the amendment to the OLAF Regulation. In order to prevent conflicts of interest and to ensure independence, it is appropriate to transfer the secretariat of the Supervisory Committee to the competence of the Commission. This is only a small amendment to the OLAF regulation, but it is of great importance.
